questions: Which is more real, mind or matter?
answers: Theres some kind of instinct for freedom and the core of human nature is to inquire and create. And any external constraint that limits this is illegitimate and has to be overcome if the project of creative human life is going to continue.

questions: What is love?
answers: Life without love is a pretty empty affair. Maybe that means something.

questions: People say that money cannot buy happiness, but can you ever be truly happy without any money?
answers: No, I dont think so. There are things that you can buy with money, like acquiring a car or a house. But these are luxuries, not needs, and theyre not the kind of things you should be buying if you want to be happy.

questions: If you could change just one thing in the world, what would it be?
answers: I would like to change the way we talk about climate change. Theres a very simple way to do it.

questions: What are the characteristics of a good friend?
answers: Im a very private person. I have never talked about my own life much. But my wife, who is also a novelist, had a daughter who was in 5th grade or so when I was growing up, and she wanted me to tell her about it so she could pass it on to her daughter. So I did.

questions: Does the â€œLaw of Attractionâ€ exist and what is it?
answers: The law of attraction is a very interesting concept. It is actually a concept that has been around for a long time. Back in the 18th century it was used as a method of controlling people. To make sure that people would not speak out against their oppressors they would try to repress them by the use of force and so on.

questions: Is there such a thing as true love?
answers: Life without love is a pretty empty affair. Maybe that means something.

questions: Is it better to have love and lost or never to have loved at all?
answers: I dont think you have to make a choice. I think both of those things are right. You can choose to love or you can be crushed by love. Personally, I gravitate towards the latter.

questions: Do you think computers will ever take over the world?

questions: do you think there will ever be a moment of awakening or a disconnect for trump is supporters of his rhetoric and what he is been doing in washington or can this just keep going.?
answers: I think that sooner or later the white working class constituency will recognize and in fact much of the rural population will come to recognize that the promises are built on sand. There is nothing there. And then what happens becomes significant.

questions: have you observed any rethinking in elite circles about how to protect and expand multilateral trade and investor agreements since the brexit referendum the election of trump and his scrapping of tpp and his threat to terminate nafta?
answers: Well first of all t pp was kind of dead on arrival. Almost everybody was opposed to it. Even the business press which is pretty much owned by the financial sector.

questions: do you observe any substantial divergence on trump is part from the longer term plans and project of the state department and the defense department in the middle east or in southeast asia?
answers: Well his main policies that have been implemented and not just talked about are in places like saudi arabia and angola. But there are other significant policy positions that are not well understood and that could be very harmful. For example his opposition to the multilateral agreement on investment that was being hammered out in partnership with the iaea european union and others.

questions: domestic affairs is that by virtually every measure of modern state power russia does not come close whether it is finance science and tech research advanced manufacturing agricultural and cultural exports?
answers: That is just propaganda. It has no basis whatsoever. To say that russian society is the most corrupt in the world is simply idiotic.

questions: have you had the time to search through it and did you learn anything about yourself?
answers: That is the kind of thing one does not want to learn. You know there is a very rich collection there of some stuff that has been published a lot of things like notes for classes over 60 years and scraps of paper on which ideas are written.

questions: do you agree with the bulletin regarding the alleged dangers posed by the trump presidency?
answers: One of the dangers is unquestionable and that is the threat of democracy. Of course there is a danger but i think the real danger is what will happen in the months and years to come. Will our democracy be able to fend off the many powerful forces arrayed against it on all sides.

questions: what in your view is the purpose of nato after the cold war?
answers: There are a lot of questions to think about seriously. For one thing it is not officially called beeeep germany it was called that when the us bombed rome in 1939 and the russians reacted by launching a major bombing campaign which totally destroyed the city of belgrade and pretty much destroyed romania as well. So there is a history of protest.

questions: proposals for augmented us intervention in syria often invoke the humanitarian principle. what is your view of humanitarian intervention?
answers: Well i do not quite see it like that. Now if you look back to the anti intervention movements what were they. Let is take the vietnam war the biggest crime since the second world war in my opinion.

questions: how would you explain the disappearance of the anti nuclear movement?
answers: Well that is absolutely right. The peak of anti nato was in the early 80s when there was a huge movement. And the reagan administration attempted to defuse it by presenting the illusion of star wars sdi that somehow we are going to eliminate nuclear weapons.

questions: how do we account for the apparent overemphasis on military threats?
answers: A military threat is any act that interferes with the free flow of information and opinion.

questions: trump and the republicans are bent on doing away with obamacare. and what would the republicans replace it with?
answers: I do not even know what they mean by obhealthcare. Maybe they are referring to the individual mandate which is a very small percentage of income. But the idea is to make sure that everyone has health insurance which would be a good idea.

questions: such selections hardly reconcile with trump is pre election promises to drain the swamp so what should we expect from this megalomaniac and phony populist insofar as the future of the washington establishment is concerned?
answers: In this respect note the qualification time magazine put it fairly well while some supporters may balk trump has drawn plenty of support from the grassroots just as he has from working people in the rust belt and the rural community in general. In that respect he is doing a good job and it is no secret why.

questions: since we are confined by time i would appreciate if the answers are kept as brief as possible. what are your views on this?
answers: There are many factors but there is one that is virtually a universal feature of elite decision making all the way through the chain of command. It is a very powerful factor and one which is rarely discussed. If you want to learn something about it read henry kissinger is book command and control.

questions: but do not you think professor the notion of an isolationist imperial power a non intervening imperial interest that donald trump has promised is something positive for countries like sri lanka and the third world at large?
answers: Isolationism is a very dangerous concept. Take donALD trump is recent appointments the important appointments. The most important appointment is his national strategy advisor who is michael flynn. (a noted right wing ideologue) niall ferguson is an extremely hard line reactionary.

questions: so it is not something confined to the us. what do you think the real reason is for this?
answers: Different reasons for different places. In india it was the rise of hindu nationalism which was extremely dangerous. It looks like there is some revival of sorts of secular nationalism in some of the countries.

questions: are not these fears about the muslims real. are not these fears about the muslims real?
answers: There is a difference between misunderstanding and paranoia. You have to distinguish the two. On the one hand there are people who are afraid and for a good reason namely because the threat of the infidels is very real and they have every right to be afraid.

questions: have the muslims of today 30 years on bought into this propaganda and believe themselves that they are in fact a monolithic entity?
answers: Take the us or the british policy towards islam. It has been highly supportive of the most radical elements of isl. To the extent that it even supported the violent elements it was pretty much opposed to them. Just look at the record in the 70s.

questions: a kind of shift today that is happening between the right wing nativists on the one hand and the left wing internationalist on the other?
answers: First of all i do not really agree with the conventional version of the cold war. You take a look at the events of 1979 it was understood that there was going to be a reagan administration. In fact the rhetoric was pretty much the same as in the 1980 election.

questions: but is there a realignment across the world professor between this right wing populist xenophobic elements and?
answers: You are seeing that but there is also a question mark over whether that is going to be sustained. Again i do not have the evidence but my strong impression is that right now in europe the anti globalization forces are gaining ground but they are not gaining the support of the majority of voters.

questions: is not the left liberal dead. is not this coalesce?
answers: There is something to that. I mean i do not like the term coalescence but i think it is a fair description. There are a number of elements that are happening that i have been critical of in the media over the years but this is the most extreme example.

questions: are the youth questioning the status quo as much as they should?
answers: First of all what is called the anti establishment candidate is actually a centrist democrat. Most of the candidates are republicans or democrats with the exception of hillary clinton who is basically a blank slate. So the two candidates on the main ballot are essentially the same except for some slight differences on some tactical issues.

questions: but across the globe are not you also seeing them move toward the nativist nation state concept?
answers: You are seeing that but there is also a movement in europe for the past 25 years or so to kind of reorientate society so that it becomes more social democratic. And that has been successful. You can see it in england.

questions: that you need to pick a side instead of staying in the centre?
answers: Everywhere. Everywhere the mainstream political organisations which are kind of centrist centre left or centre right are diminishing and collapsing. That is true of institutions too.

questions: moving on has the media changed landscape since you wrote manufacturing consent in 1989. is the media manufacturing consent now?
answers: Well we did not actually say that media is manufacturing consensuses. We said that that is what they are trying to do. There is a little distortion there i think but it is not the substance of what we were saying anyway.

questions: and what is your personal belief of life after death?
answers: Personally it means nothing to me but if some higher power showed up and said okay we will have a future for our grandchildren and they asked why should we have this meaningless existence. That is the question. It is kind of like the kibbutz in that there is no end to the questions you can think of.

questions: and your views on religion you were born into a jewish family and raised?
answers: Well remember that judaism is fundamentally a religion of practice more than belief. So say my grandfather who was basically still living in the 17th century eastern europe was ultra religious. But if i had asked him did you believe in god.

questions: paul mattick thanks for finding the time to talk you are a busy person. where are you back from?
answers: Well right now we are back in the united states from spain.

questions: what was your reaction?
answers: My wife valeria had actually predicted it so i was somewhat immunized from the general surprise. But i did not expect it. I felt that it would be pretty close. She is a pretty intelligent person and i think i can pick up on some of her points.

questions: s. why do you think this is happening now?
answers: I think that what is actually happening is the collapse of the center the centrist semi coalitions mildly social democrat mildly conservative that have been running the countries for years. They are severely lacking in both ideology and ability to implement policies.

questions: what kinds of activities and actions do you think would make for a meaningful response to this new situation that trump is victory has brought?
answers: Well i think there are lots of opportunities right now. Just take a look at the vote again. Of younger people 18 to 25 a large majority were pro clinton and a much larger majority pro sanders and that is typical of the population.

questions: what do you think is likely to come of the paris accords?
answers: I suppose other countries will try to salvage what they can from the wreckage. But what is important to us is to reverse the shameful course being pursued by our own country. It will not be easy but it must and can be done.

questions: do you have any general or specific advice for those of us who wish to make positive use of the trump era and the eras that will follow it?
answers: I think there are some favorable prospects but the opportunities have to be grasped. There is no magic key for that. It has been done in the past several decades variously through organizing educational initiatives protesting election interference establishing worker owned enterprises participating in popular political action and so on.

questions: in your view what were the deciding factors that led american voters to produce the biggest upset in the history of us politics?
answers: Before turning to this question i think it is important to spend a few moments pondering just what happened on november 8 a date that might turn out to be one of the most important in human history depending on how we deal with what has happened since then and what lies in store for the future.

questions: are you as convinced now as when you were younger that understanding language is essential to understanding the human mind?
answers: I think that is clearer and clearer. The emergence of language as a system of creative thought was sensed by descartes and galileo. But it was not really addressed till the mid 20th century because the tools were not available to formulate it properly.

questions: he connects your theory of language to pentagon funded work you did at m. i. t. during the cold war?
answers: It was a joint project in the early 1960s with tony russo and hans peter gruner at the university of pennsylvania. The basic idea was to study the logical structure of sentences and to deduce from these structures the meaning of spoken language.

questions: why do you think we are seeing this resurgence of analysis. you must tire of defending your work?
answers: I have been defending the legitimacy of this work extensively and in print for 60 years. In earlier years the discussions were with serious philosophers linguists cognitive scientists. I am sorry to see that the resurgence you mention does not begin to approximate that level one reason why unlike previous years i do not bother to respond unless asked.

questions: let is talk about your politics?
answers: I supported bernie sanders. The most important issue we face a real question of species survival is climate change. I have been criticized for advocating a politics of fear which seems to me a reasonable position.

questions: what do you make of the political climate today. of the student protests?
answers: Humans face critical problems that have never arisen before in their history problems of survival of organized human life on earth. They are barely mentioned in the current electoral extravaganza and the voluminous commentary about it. Fortunately young people are often deeply concerned and directly engaged.

questions: you will be teaching two classes next semester at the university of arizona?
answers: Yes. An undergraduate course will focus on the current stage of globalized state capitalism and ways of approaching the common good as it has been conceived in various ways since the enlightenment. The graduate seminar will explore critical issues of contemporary society and society at large with special emphasis on topics such as the relation between wealth inequality and social justice.

questions: how do you account for your amazing stamina and energy level at age 87?
answers: The bicycle theory. As long as you keep riding you do not fall. It is a very impressive physiological system.

questions: then there is all that chomsky memorabilia mugs t shirts even luggage tags?
answers: Seems strange to me. It can only mean that my activist engagements and professional work somehow relate to what many people are looking for and do not appear to perceive as lacking.

questions: do you own a chomsky coffee mug?
answers: No. But i get things from friends. The one i like is one my grandchildren like.

questions: in light of recent developments in the media propaganda blitz against syrian president bashar al assad are you concerned that a clinton presidency would seek to confront russia on syrian soil are we now seeing the opening salvos?
answers: I quite doubt it. The russians have an impregnable position. Just think for a moment about what would happen if the united states were to attack syria. There is already talk of an armed attack.

questions: you do not see syria as the next place to install a democracy or seek regime change as they call it?
answers: Only if you want to destroy the world. There is a major russian military presence and you can not confront that.

questions: there is a great deal of concern among progressive writers that this doctrine will lead to a confrontation with the russians?
answers: I do not think so. I think it is very dangerous. Confrontation is not a word that comes to mind when you think of the history of imperialism or of nationalism.

questions: do you believe barrel bombs for example are dropped by assad?
answers: There is strong evidence for that. He is pretty horrible. In this case i do not think he really deserves the punishment that is being imposed.

questions: many observers are coming to the defense of assad and saying this is not a place to build a new regime and sometimes they give the example of libya and iraq?
answers: That is a separate question. Gaddafi was not an angel. He was carrying out horrible acts. But you can understand why people in saudi arabia and other parts of the gulf want him gone.

questions: does that concern you. as obviously there is a buildup to attack mosul?
answers: It does but for reasons that actually were pretty well expressed in an op ed in the new york times by jamal al dhari. The fact is that when the us backed forces attacked ramadi and fallujah they practically destroyed them. Now these are the main sunni cities and these have been under severe attack for years even before september 11th.

questions: are you hopeful that we are going to take a broader approach than just a military one under hillary clinton?
answers: Not really but it is not easy to say what to do. Isis is pretty awful but you just have to deal with the roots of it the whole ethnic sectarian conflict which was an outgrowth of the iraq war. And the sunni populations do feel threatened by the shiite majority which is why they are running their own affairs.

questions: that is such a grim set of alternatives?
answers: It is pretty grim yeah. And for syria and indeed for the region i think the longer this goes on the harder it will be to get any kind of political settlement. There is a very simple reason for that.

questions: what was the political and military relationship between berlin and washington?
answers: Well it was a mixed story. Roosevelt himself came from a family of eastern european nobility. His mother was an aristocrat and his father was one of the most distinguished figures in the united states post world war ii history.

questions: indeed is not it the case that the specific ability of our species to acquire any language was a major theme of interest to the modern scientific community from the time of galileo?
answers: This is quite true. At the outset of the seventeenth century the scientist and philosopher jesus christensen described the human race as having two fundamental types which he called dissimilar but essentially the same natures which were distinct from each other and from God the Father.

questions: can you please expand on the notion of the internal language?
answers: We now know that although speech is the usual form of sensory motor externalization it can just as well be sign or even touch discoveries that require a slight qualification. A more fundamental qualification has to do with the way the terms are used. The term internalization is used in quite different ways and only confusion can arise from failure to observe these differences.

questions: for example the whole idea continues to be questioned in some quarters although it is widely accepted apparently by most scientists?
answers: There has been considerable progress in understanding the nature of the internal language but its free creative use remains a mystery. That comes as no great surprise.

questions: but languages vary greatly from one another so what is the link between generative grammar and universal grammar?
answers: Languages appear to be extremely complex varying radically among them. And indeed a standard belief among professional linguists 60 years ago was that languages can vary in arbitrary ways and each must be studied without preconceptions. Similar views were held at the time about organisms generally and physics more generally.

questions: so we definitely need to distinguish speech from language right?
answers: Returning to the galilean challenge it has to be reformulated so that it excludes language from the scope of acquisition but leaves the capacity to speak in the mind as a preprogrammed system. Secondary processes map the structures of language to one or another sensory motor system for externalization. Let is turn to language capacity.

questions: do you concur with this view and why?
answers: I agree with the conclusion of the experts who set the doomsday clock for the bulletin of atomic scientists. They have moved the clock two minutes closer to midnight three minutes to go before calling it a day. That seems to me a credible judgment.

questions: and what does it tell us about american political culture?
answers: The us is to an unusual extent a business run society where short term concerns of profit and market share displace rational planning. Our leaders are mostly concerned with their own wealth and the feelings of power and prestige that accompany it.

questions: is there room here for optimism about the future of the environment?
answers: There is always room for gramsci is optimism of human will. There are still many options but they are diminishing. Options range from simple initiatives that are easily undertaken like weatherizing homes to entirely new forms of energy perhaps fusion perhaps new means of exploiting solar energy outside the earth is atmosphere to methods of decarbonization that might conceivably even reverse some of today is enormous damage.

questions: given that change in human behavior happens slowly and that it will take many decades before the world economy makes a shift to new clean forms of energy should we look toward a technological solution to climate change?
answers: Anything feasible and potentially effective should be explored. There is little doubt that a significant part of any serious solution will require advances of technology but that can only take place if the basic assumptions of the scientific revolution are kept in mind. That is not impossible but it would require a radical rethinking of some of fundamental assumptions about how the natural world works.

questions: what immediate but realistic and enforceable actions could or should be taken to tackle the climate change threat?
answers: Rapid ending of use of fossil fuels sharp increase in renewable energy research into new options for sustainable energy significant steps toward conservation and not least a far reaching critique of the capitalist model of human and resource exploitation even apart from its ignoring of externalities the latter is a virtual death knell for the species.

questions: is there a way to predict how the world will look like 50 years from now if humans fail to tackle and reverse global warming and climate change?
answers: If current tendencies persist the outcome will be disastrous before too long. Large parts of the globe will become barely habitable affecting hundreds of millions of people along with other disasters that we can barely contemplate.

questions: what are your own views on the role of religion in human affairs?
answers: The general picture is quite beeeep and too familiar to recount. But it is worth remembering that there are some exceptions.

questions: why have countries like germany and france become the targets of isis?
answers: I think we have to be cautious in interpreting isil claims of responsibility for terrorist attacks. Take the worst of the recent ones in nice. It was discussed by akbar ahmed a well known scholar of radical islam.

questions: what is isis is aim when targeting innocent civilians such as the attack on the seaside town of nice in france in which 84 people were killed?
answers: As i mentioned we should i think be cautious about the claims and charges of imitators. But when they are involved in such atrocities the strategy is clear enough. Careful and expert analysts of radical islam generally tend to take the most extreme versions of the charges and innuendos and to draw inferences from them quite apart from the context in where they originally appeared.

questions: to what extent would you say that brexit was being driven by xenophobia and the massive inflow of immigrants into europe?
answers: There has been plenty of reporting giving that impression but i have not seen any hard data. And it is worth recalling that the inflows are mostly from the eu not those fleeing from conflict. It would not be surprising if they are also disproportionately from regions with substantial non native population.

questions: do you detect such a shift under way?
answers: There certainly has been a change over the years. In the early 70s there was a kind of a climate of fear which was very real. People did not want to be associated with the hippies or the vietnam veterans or other people who were very different from them in many respects.

questions: how will this affect turkey is relations with the us and european powers given the alleged concerns of the latter about human rights and democracy inside turkey and about erdogan is pursuit of closer ties with putin?
answers: The correct word is alleged. During the 1990s the turkish government was carrying out horrifying atrocities targeting its kurdish population tens of thousands killed thousands of villages and towns destroyed thousands driven from their homes every imaginable form of torture and coercion. The western media refused to cover the crimes even though they were well known and could easily have been predicted.

questions: what could be the consequences for turkey eu relations and for the refugees themselves if the deal were to fall apart?
answers: Basically europe bribed turkey to keep the miserable refugees many fleeing from crimes for which the west bears no slight responsibility from reaching distressingly close to europa. It is similar to obama is efforts to enlist mexican support in keeping central american refugees often very definitely victims of us policies including those of his predecessors from entering the us.

questions: is the us looking for a military conflict with russia or are such moves driven by the need to keep the military industrial complex intact in a post cold war world?
answers: Nato is surely a us dominated military alliance. The russians have made it clear that they do not want a war with the u. s. there is no need therefore to build up a force to defend the globe against the likely threat of a russian attack.

questions: in your view does a nuclear war between the us and russia remain a very real possibility in today is world?
answers: If current tendencies persist then a threat to the survival of the human species there is not much that can be done about it. Simply consider the consequences of a possible nuclear conflict. Not only do we depend on nuclear energy for survival but also its destruction.

questions: you have noted over the years that these domains only have a tenuous connection. has that changed at all?
answers: There is an abstract connection of some historical interest. If you look back say around the enlightenment that period and the early romantic period there were connections drawn. For example earl moynihan the great defender of classical liberalism was deeply involved in these connections and so on.

questions: some have gone so far as to suggest that your work in both domains might be used to generate a theory of man perhaps you try and resist this systematic approach to your thinking?
answers: I do not see any conflict. It is certainly true that one can generate theories in many domains and i am quite capable of doing so. One cannot, for example, claim that Newton was justified in taking the picture of the planets around the sun as moving bodies because there is nothing in the way of evidence for that.

questions: does the study of language then have a political component?
answers: Not directly. Anything about humans is going to have some consequences for human life. It was believed at one time that some languages are inferior some are superior and black english is not a true language and so on and on.

questions: just abstractly?
answers: These are not the real results of linguistics. Language has always been regarded as some extremely complex phenomena very diverse languages differ from one another in arbitrary ways ranging from simple sounds to complicated speech acts.

questions: do you find academic work to be obscure or esoteric?
answers: It varies. For example there is a very good work that just came out a couple months ago on propaganda by a really fine young analytic philosopher jason stanley. It is an in depth study of how propaganda works and what its limits are.

questions: the other end of those traditions then postmodernism continental philosophy has been perhaps more engaged?
answers: That is the general viewpoint but i do not share it. Have you read javier giraldo is recent book. See that book is interesting.

questions: you have said before that some of these french thinkers have had destructive effects in third world regions?
answers: In ecuador there was a really rotten dictatorship that just went on to destroy the society. They had a couple hundred intellectuals there who were really outstanding. One of the leading ecologists in the hemisphere was murdered within months.

questions: you have seen it divert intellectuals from substantive causes into obscure writings?
answers: Yeah. I mean you are not supposed to look at those things. But you see it.

questions: so it is an issue of articulation?
answers: I think there is a kind of a logical precedence which is not necessarily the moral precedence but is the pragmatic precedence. If you sit down and talk these questions through and you think them through you can come to understand them okay. Let is take the vietnam war as an example.

questions: it seems as though many of these thinkers will approach similar topics as yourself though trying to understand how the media is constructing information trying to understand how power relations work. the topics are similar?
answers: Take say the work on deconstruction. Has it given you any insight into its own practices.

questions: i think it help fosters skepticism?
answers: Skepticism sure. But let is take a look and see just how events of the world are transmuted through the prism of ideological institutions okay. That is what we need to be looking at seriously not just speculating about the future not future historians.

questions: right. instead of going through case examples and showing?
answers: Show it. Show how it works in practice. So that kind of demonstration is very powerful.

questions: one wonders if this maybe assumes too much of the public it is very simple for them so long as they can just tune into it more critically etc?
answers: I do not think so i agree with the general approach. I think it makes a good deal of sense for people to be actively engaged in critical analysis of their own society and to try to shape it in ways that will benefit them. As for the privileged majority that is what they should be doing.

questions: do you think that is happening with working class americans now?
answers: Things have changed. It is one of the striking differences between the reaction to this recession and the depression years which i can remember. Now there is just a general sense of helplessness what can we do to try to get out of this without serious damage done to the economy.> it may turn out to be a very costly mistake in my opinion.

questions: is it a matter of estrangement or of being distracted?
answers: I think it is the latter. What is happened is a kind of internal disorientation in the society which has spread over the past few years.

questions: you think the similarity is a kind of anti establishmentarianism?
answers: Well now it is just against everything. But what are you for.

questions: it is very easy to just flip on the news and hope that it has the best intent?
answers: That again is a striking difference. Look at the 1930s things like workers education were major activities. And that was just part and parcel of life.

questions: what is driven the wedge between workers and that same engagement now?
answers: Now i think there is a general disorientation in the society which has in fact been studied. One of the most dramatic studies of this is by sociobiology professor noam chomsky. He has studied what he calls the psychological reality of american workers.

questions: you do not think that the sanders campaign did anything to bring about a popular left?
answers: I think it did. It illustrated how much of an almost yearning there is for common committed action to achieve the kinds of goals that are significant to us. And something could come out of it in the way of organized committed activist social movements.

questions: and the methods now are more insidious more subtle?
answers: There are other ways. Take what is happening in brazil which is a kind of soft coup. I mean it is not a military coup but it was a very significant one and they are using the legal system in a way that is unusual in the industrial world.

questions: sees the world through star spangled spectacles that we project desires and values?
answers: In this respect it is very similar to other major powers. The british were the same in their period of glory the french were carrying out a civilizing mission the japanese were bringing what they called an earthly paradise to china and they were defending the population from the chinese bandits.

questions: because the step is always to think that the aggressor is on the other side?
answers: Take putin. He is not a nice guy i would not want to have dinner with him. But suppose you were to meet him in person and he said look i know you are trying to hurt my feelings but i really do appreciate your concern for my people and your efforts to help them.

questions: is it possible that you simply have a case of leaders who do have good strong moral intent but who simply operate within a structure that does not allow for such realizations?
answers: There is no doubt about it. I am not talking about individual leaders. Every leader you look at has a complex web of interests and commitments.

questions: what then would be america is appropriate place in the world?
answers: The proper place is as an honest broker between the great powers to ensure that they do not overstep their bounds and that the minimal standards of justice and freedom are upheld.

questions: do you think other states are going to ask for this benefit?
answers: No. I mean other state systems are not going have this kind of power. But the united states does have one major advantage namely its huge military budget which makes it very difficult for any other power to compete with the us. Of course that is a goal of militarization of space which is another goal as well.

questions: is it possible for the united states to withdraw given the amount of economic investment entrenchment?
answers: Depends what you mean by withdraw. For example we do not have to invade iraq. We could leave it to its own devices and withdraw when it is no longer a threat or contribute troops to keep it that way.

questions: the rest of the world though is already skeptical that anything the united states does with any kind of interventionary intent will be anything but harmful?
answers: You can make the case that some of it is harmful. Take what is happening in iraq. There is a horrible crisis there and the occupying forces are destroying it.

questions: and now that we are sitting here and you know the answer to that question does this change the way you look forward 30 years from now?
answers: It is a mixed story. There have been some areas of significant progress i think domestically. So for example take women is rights it was half the population in the late 70 is was finally getting some rights at the federal level.

questions: would you say you are more optimistic now?
answers: No. I think now we are facing major questions of literal survival. There are two huge questions. One is what to do about climate change.

questions: something i have found to be inspiring though in much of your writings is that despite the critique despite these kinds of mechanisms that might lie behind power you maintain a very optimistic portrait of the human individual the capacity the intellectual creativity?
answers: I do not know a better comment on this then the one gramsci made famous we should have pessimists and optimists. Whatever we can do we ought to do. The question is what should we do with the capacities that are available.

questions: do you think about your significance as a thinker?
answers: The things that i consider most significant of what i do are just engagement with popular groups all over the world in fact. That is what is exciting and important. Other things i think are kind of incidental like collecting pennies.

questions: the fact that you have a poster of bertrand russell in your office and certainly there are young academics with posters of noam chomsky in their offices?
answers: He was not a god there is no comparison. He understood power.

answers: In the late 1950s when the united states was trying to contain north korean expansionism it supported a military coup to overthrow the conservative parliamentary government. That is still the policy. A few months later came the fateful decision to install a brutal and corrupt military junta.

questions: yes many people argue that the biggest obstacle in dealing with north korea is south korean right wing politics?
answers: Relaxation on the part of the south would mean conservatives losing power in the north. That is why for instance we have to keep the war on terrorism. It is not just a matter of a war against terrorism you can not get away with that.

questions: noam let is start with a reflective look at how the us 2016 presidential elections shape up in terms of the state of the country and its role in global affairs and the ideological viewpoints expressed by some of the leading candidate of both parties?
answers: It cannot be overlooked that we have arrived to a unique moment in human history. For the first time decisions have to be made right now that will literally determine the prospects for decent human survival and not in the distant future.

questions: in your view what has led to donald trump is rise and is he simply another case of those typical right wing populist characters who frequently surface in the course of history whenever nations face severe economic crises or are on national decline?
answers: Insofar as the us is facing national declines it is largely self inflicted. True it may be facing severe internal problems but the country is very much like other industrial societies in that it relies for its existence on the dynamic state sector of the economy which is highly concentrated and highly protective of its wealth and power.

questions: i see them as the real monsters while trump reminds me a bit of silvio berlusconi. do you agree with any of these views?
answers: It is nonsense to talk about the monsters of the modern age while ignoring the far more serious threats to the world as a whole and to future generations. Trump is selection of syria is a perfect illustration of how the threat level has escalated sharply under trump.

questions: america is youth seems to be captivated by bernie sanders message. are you surprised by how well he is holding up?
answers: I am surprised. I did not anticipate the success of his campaign.

questions: under what scenario can sanders possibly win the democratic nomination?
answers: Evidently it would require very substantial educational and organizational activities. But my own feeling frankly is that these should be directed substantially toward developing a popular movement that will not fade away after the election but will join with others to form the kind of activist force that has been instrumental in initiating and carrying forward needed changes and reforms in the past. We have to begin now with small initiatives.

questions: is america still a democracy and if not do elections really matter?
answers: The us is by far the freest country in the world. Elections surely matter. It would in my opinion be an utter disaster for the country the globe and future generations if any of the viable republican candidates were to reach the white house and become the kind of figureheads they would most want.

questions: supreme court is decision with scalia is final imprimatur to block attempts by the obama administration to limit the disastrous consequences of global warming?
answers: The decision is very important and there are a couple of problems with it. One problem is that it is a narrow decision. I mean it can be reversed on appeal.

questions: why does the thinking of the extreme right in america scare you more than the far right ideology spreading across europe?
answers: The right wing populist movements in france the ukraine and elsewhere are quite frightening. But the extremists on the political spectrum are not too far to the left of center. For example the views of de gaulle are of prime concern to bin laden because of his close association with depraved criminals such as hitler and kennedy.

questions: defense budget for 2016 17 approved last week without any debate in congress quadruples spending on nato arsenals and to protect the security of eastern european allies. what is the message?

questions: does this mean that more and more extended wars entail the risk of a third world war?
answers: It would not be the first time we have been at the brink of nuclear war. Mind you wherever mankind has gone up the road it has inevitably led to nuclear conflict. So here we are on the verge of what may turn out to be a nuclear conflagration not in the distant future but in our own lifetimes. Brazil is right in this position.

questions: do you believe the leaders of globalization have a strategy or attempted to create a controlled catastrophe that got out of hand?
answers: Every sane person should be skeptical of the official story. There is little doubt that the course of events leading up to the crisis was highly predictable and highly destructive. One can only admire the patient patience of those who survived the assault and the fortitude with which they fought it out ultimately destroying themselves in the process not forgetting their victims along the way.

questions: fortunately there are many who see past the headline and leave critical feedback?

questions: how important do you think social media has become these days for making an informed public and how much of an impact do you think it can have on grassroots movements?

questions: do you think banks that are too big should be broken up?

questions: what are your opinions on the surprising progress of donald trump. could it be explained by a climate of fear?

It is interesting to compare the situation in the 30s which i am old enough to remember and the one we are living in now the late 1990s. There was a great deal of concern among the general population but little action.

questions: with like outspoken socialists bernie sanders and uk labour party leader jeremy corbyn is current successes is this a new political age and is this a direct result of austerity?

questions: who do you see becoming the next u. s. president?

questions: so you have described this sort of action by the mainstream media as the fifth filter could you briefly touch upon that again and why the mainstream media uses this sort of action to quell grassroots movements?

questions: let me start by asking you as to whether you feel that the biolingustic approach to language that you have developed in the course of the past 50 years or so is still open to further exploration and if so what sort of questions remain unanswered about the acquisition of language?
answers: Not just me by any means. Quite a few people. One very important person was the late eric lenneberg a close friend from the early 1950s when these ideas were brewing. He was working in eisenhower is institute of technology where this work was being done and he just put it aside and did not pursue it any further.

questions: what would you say is the philosophical relevance of language?
answers: The comments above begin to deal with that question. It has been traditionally recognized that human language is a species property common to humans apart from severe pathology and uniquely ours in essentials. One of lenneberg is contributions was to begin ground this radical discontinuity in sound modern biology and the conclusion has only been strengthened by subsequent work.

questions: what can he possibly mean by this?
answers: I was not the person who put it to rest. Far from it. Isaac newton certainly did not.

questions: how do you respond to this dark view of human nature?

questions: while it is true that humans are social beings and thus our behavior depends on the social and political arrangements in our lives is there such a thing as a common good for all human beings that goes beyond basic aspirations like the need for food shelter and protection from external threats?
answers: These are what marx once called our animal needs which he hoped would be provided by realization of communism freeing us to turn productively to our human needs whose specific nature we can only speculate at this point.

questions: e. one beyond capitalism and exploitation?

In the past generation these have been distorted by neoliberal doctrines into an assault on human dignity and even the animal needs of ordinary human life. More ominously unless reversed implementation of these doctrines will destroy the possibility of decent human existence and not in our lifetimes. That should be a truism with very serious consequences for the future.

questions: are you overall optimistic about the future of humanity given the kind of creatures we are?

questions: one of the great thinkers in israel?

questions: i am sure?

questions: well we seem to be having a little trouble in our relations with russia right now?

questions: george bush the greater versus george bush the lesser?

questions: negotiations with iran. as regards to nuclear power or nuclear weapons?

questions: 72nd and broadway. but this was tell us about where this started?

We happened to cross the border into israel which was rather shocking because there was nothing there apart from a couple of haystacks.

questions: you were about ten eleven?
answers: Eleven twelve years old. But one of the first things i learned at the newsstand is that is there is a newspaper in new york which you have probably never heard of it is called the noosnmira.

questions: this is the beginning of your study of linguistics?

questions: yiddish newspapers?

questions: you have been pretty consistent on keeping a lot of those values alive in our discourse at a time when to suggest that you might be a libertarian socialist is not necessarily something that every major reporter understands?
answers: Libertarian socialism is just the traditional name for anarchism.

questions: so you are telling me rand paul is not really libertarian at all?

questions: and if so have you ever publicly admitted as much. pretty long question but it is an interesting?
answers: Well plenty of mistakes. The usual mistake which happens over and over is getting involved in things too late. There are too many consequences involved and too little awareness of what is involved or of the consequences of involvement which is serious.

questions: is that the underpinning of your great essay on the responsibility of an intellectual?
answers: Like most of my articles that was a talk. It will surprise you to find out where it was given to the harvard hillel association. This is before 1967 when everything began to change. 1969 was the turning point for my views.

questions: you never seem to mind it when people disagree with you you like the debate you like the argument?

questions: and as a person who is been involved in media reform for an awfully long time i can tell you that a month ago when the media reform movement in this country succeeded in getting the fcc the federal communications commission?
answers: That was important. That really changed the face of things. And i think it is just continued to be that. Thank god for the internet.

questions: s. ally. there is a border there. they freely go back and forth?
answers: That is right. And it is not just young people. One thing that i learned as i was reporting from inside is that for the first time i have been to iraq about 15 times in the last three years.

questions: and terrorism you mean?

questions: what is your assessment of maduro and how he compares to president ch vez?

The united states and its allies have a legitimate concern over the maoist threat to their interests the development of which is a primary concern of the un as it was in the case of vietnam.

questions: how could the u. s. do that?
answers: We could for example eliminate those restrictions that you are talking about. There are actually quite sophisticated mechanisms for eliminating restrictions on international financial transfers. So the united states could move unilaterally to allow capital movements that are not barred by law.

questions: i asked him about the significance of the leaks by national security agency whistleblower edward snowden and whether he should be allowed to return to the united states without facing any charges?
answers: Suppose he returns and is convicted of a crime. Does he get a fair trial and if so how much should he receive for returning a highly classified document which if discovered was highly likely to have caused a major catastrophe.

questions: you mean in dealing with the debt?
answers: In what way.

questions: when you go to brazil you are going to be meeting your new family?
answers: That is correct.

questions: and i was wondering if you could talk a little about that?
answers: Here we have to be rather cautious distinguishing between language per se and speech which is an amalgam involving both language and a specific sensorimotor system used for externalization of language. The two systems are unrelated in evolutionary history the sensori m is a recent development resulting from convergent evolution between hominids and us humans. Similar results have been reported in other species.

questions: and what is that like for you. and so can you talk personally about your own life?
answers: I am a very private person. I have never talked about myself much. But you know i see things from a different point of view if you like it is partly true. There are things i find very moving though.

questions: you have said in the past that you thought because of your opposition to the war in vietnam for example you might spend years in jail?
answers: Came very close came close enough so that by 1967 68 when resistance activities were at their height and i was an unindicted co conspirator in one trial and the prosecutor announced i would be the leading person in a second trial although i had never been charged with a crime i thought i ought to be in both trials.

questions: in which trial?
answers: These were the so called trials of the resistance. The first was called the spock coffin trial although a lot to say about that. This was during the reagan years.

questions: so what gives you hope?
answers: Things like what you described also the wonderful things in the world of the kind that i mentioned like my wife who happens to be a very accomplished linguist. She is done with this totally amazing thing called advanced placement education.

questions: to hear part one of our interview yesterday when he talked about israeli prime minister netanyahu is speech to congress today you can go to our website. this is just a clip?
answers: Basically a joint effort by the washington based media to undermine any possibility of a negotiated settlement with iran as they portray it as a conflict between the jewish state and the arab world.

questions: i have been feeling increasingly queasy about the je suis charlie consolidation of the event into a symbol of free expression which is obviously part of what is at issue but not the whole issue?
answers: It is a very limited point. Actually i thought the most interesting comment on it inadvertently was by floyd abrams. He is an old friend and ally and he pointed out i think correctly that when the charter was being formed by the new republic it did not say what it was supposed to say.

questions: not even within the last generation?
answers: For example take one case that was much worse the u. s. bombing of belgrade in 1999 which targeted and destroyed the main serbian television station. Was that a war crime according to standard definitions of war crimes.

questions: it is not admissible?
answers: A couple years later when the u. s. invaded iraq one of the worst crimes of iran was killing afghans. That is admissable. You can not prosecute someone for killing somebody in iranian custody because they do not have the burden of proof. Interview with noam chomsky by amy goodmandemocracy now.

questions: what do you think are the biggest dangers going forward in the response to the hebdo attacks?
answers: It is already happening it will probably increase sharply with more jihadis apparently joining the fight. There is every reason to think that the attack on the mosque was a prelude to a much larger attack which may have killed many more people. The toll may well have been much higher still.

questions: what do you think about this sort of switch in activist mobilization?
answers: Well i am probably the wrong person to ask. I do not participate. If i could participate i would participate actively.

questions: the existential element is virtually nonexistent. i have a thousand friends and am utterly isolated?
answers: I see it with my grandchildren. They are on social media all the time and they think they have friends. But it is not what i would have called a friend ever. There are people you would not want to meet.

questions: do we have any sort of core organizing force anymore. the labor movement that is out?
answers: Throughout american history the labour movement has been under severe attack. It was driven underground during the depression and the world war ii period. But that has gradually come to an end because the domestic constituencies are so powerful that it can no longer be crushed.

questions: it feels as though what we have now is flash mob activism but we lack a consistent base?
answers: There is very little continuity. Take the occupy movement. It is typical in that it started from zero no continuity with anything in the past maybe some vague memories that there was once a civil rights movement but the participants in it did not have a history of participation and membership and organizations which had continued throughout. In fact if you look at the membership it was mostly young black males.

questions: but were there people who provided models for you or modes of thought you were drawn to and inspired by?
answers: Yeah. I was interested in anarchist cooperatives in spain. You get a sense of it from orwell is homage to catalonia which i did not read at the time actually when it came out in the 1930s it was suppressed.

questions: and is that the seed of your own sense of anarchism not as a system that one posits like a plan but more like a process a sort of undoing of power and privilege?
answers: In fact i did not know that much about the history at the time but in spain it did develop. There was an anti bolshevik uprising in germany in early 1957 and the bolshieviks reacted by trying to repress it. I was there but I was not part of the resistance.

questions: people were already living that way. so was this just sort of infused into your upbringing?
answers: It was personal there was no upbringing. There were a couple of people who you know helped me think it through but a lot of it is just personal in that sense.

questions: were you growing up very religious in terms of belief and faith?
answers: Well my family was very jewish and observant but not religious. Like they would go to synagogue and celebrate the holidays and i was a part of it as a child but personally i wasnt much of a religious person. I got turned off of religion pretty early on partly because my father is family were ultra orthodox and they had not changed since eastern europe.

questions: is there something that you hold higher than yourself. a duty say something to which you are devout?
answers: I do not think there is any deep philosophy there it is just natural. People their rights their dignity their individual capacities and options ought to be protected. I am not opposed to the protection of those rights but i think it oughtto be combined with other rights such as the right to free speech and the freedom of the press.

questions: is there a story that you tell yourself about yourself. who are you in your mind?
answers: There is nothing much to say. I am an ordinary person with ordinary concerns these of course include those close to me and to the extent that i can do anything useful the vast problems of needless suffering oppression violence terror and even human survival.

questions: what is your feeling?
answers: I think there is strong and mounting evidence to support the traditional view that language is primarily an instrument of thought secondarily used for a variety of instrumental purposes among them communication.

questions: which makes me wonder is there an evolutionary purpose for creativity?
answers: Evolution does not have purposes. People do. One purpose i think should be to allow for the fullest development of what i assume is a core part of human nature the need to be free to think to create to develop and employ one is capacities and interests and to do so in relations of mutual support with others both enjoying their freedom and contributing to it.

questions: you look cheerful. do you still find reasons to be optimistic?
answers: Well there are a few. Although there is no lack of reasons not to believe that the future is bright for the suffering people of the world.

questions: but hardly anybody talks about this?
answers: Nobody is talking much about that except strategic analysts economic experts and others who are concerned about these things. But there are very serious threats. One is the conflict in ukraine the other is russia which is extremely serious.

questions: so it is pure luck that we are still here?
answers: I am going back to your first question optimism. There is always a chance that things will work out. I do not think they have worked out in the past but things do change and they will. One of the things that has happened over the last 30 or 40 years is that the prospects have gotten better and better.

questions: i imagine the second task has been much harder than the first. has it been worth it?
answers: Changing linguistics is pretty hard. Linguists are trying to do interesting things with extremely limited resources. My own feeling is that if they try hard enough they should succeed.

questions: europe is now immersed in its darkest chapter of the past 50 years?
answers: There have been significant gains but they come up against a barrier. And that barrier then got much worse with the initiation of this massive neoliberal assault against the world is population which began in the late 1970s and took off under reagan and bush. Now it is hitting africa the main target.

questions: society have started to react to this situation. do you think change is possible?
answers: There is now a resistance to the neoliberal attack a very significant one in fact. The most important is actually in south america which is dramatic. I mean for 500 years south africa had been pretty much under the domination of western imperial powers most recently the united states.

questions: the backyard?
answers: But latin americans have pulled out of it not totally but for the first time in half a millennium the countries are moving towards integration which is a prerequisite for independence. They had been very much separated in the past and they are beginning to unite.

questions: do you think cuba will try to get the base back in the havana talks?
answers: I am sure the cubans will do what they want but i doubt the americans would commit to that. Even if they did the fact is that a military presence is virtually certain to be established in latin america with the us providing the means for the militarization of the region and the normalcy of relations between the two countries.

questions: i read a recent article where you said that obama is only a liberal conservative a moderate republican and that nixon is administration was the most liberal in us history?
answers: Nixon was a nice guy the standard has changed. By today is standards he looks like a flaming radical. I mean the liberal media would never tolerate anything like that.

questions: so obama is not a left wing president?
answers: The term left in the us is now used for moderates from the center because the spectrum has shifted. In fact there used to be a joke that the united states is a one party state with two factions which was pretty accurate. Now it is just not accurate anymore.

questions: what are the neocons up to these days?
answers: The party has been mobilized to seize two objectives one to destroy the country and make it look as if it is the fault of the democrats so maybe they can get into power again. The other is just to serve the rich and the powerful with dedication ceaselessly. No matter what the people think.

questions: and what about muslims?
answers: Well he is correct about syrians. There is a horrible crisis there and the united states has admitted virtually none of the refugees. The most dramatic case is in the mexico where the us has refused even to take back several hundred refugees who were on us terrorist watch lists and still are.

questions: the national myth against the onslaught of inferior races?
answers: It is still there. It may have no basis in the history or biology but the idea is embedded in our consciousness that there are two categories of people namely the huddled masses and the conquerors. When the country was founded by the newly christian settlers the native population was called natives.

questions: europe is not so far away from this vision?
answers: Again it is insane the way the troika is interpreting the situation. First of all they did not come from the eurogroup. They came directly from brussels.

questions: the finnish filmmaker aki kaurism ki calls it sadistic capitalism?
answers: Well you know capitalism is predicated on the maximization of personal gain at the expense of others. That is its essence. Another aspect is the undermining of social bonds.

questions: a world without rights or responsibilities?
answers: Which is to say a non functioning market society in which rights and responsibilities are determined by concentrations of private power economic power state power closely linked with consequences that are of the kind that you describe. And the effects on others are not predictable. That is why there is a need to critically analyze the global order in order to provide a better basis for action.

questions: it is as if the troika is policies have brought the old enemy back from the dead?
answers: I do not really see it that way. It would be interesting to see how europe reacts to the collapse of the soviet union. Would it welcome the return of gorbachev.

questions: is not syriza a sign that history is pendulum is swinging back?
answers: Syria is a horrible catastrophe. It is descending into suicide. There is no bright spot on the horizon but it could be very serious.

questions: of course they are not real revolutionaries?
answers: If they were then yes they would call themselves anarchists. As it happens they do not. These are the people who founded the kibbutz which in fact is the only democratic social organization in israel in which there is a real active labor movement and there are actually elections every two years.

questions: is the decline of traditional newspapers due to how close they are to power or as their editors argue is it internet is fault?
answers: I write about the new york times and the wall street journal because what interests me is what is going on in the world. I mean i will let somebody else denounce fox news which is a joke. But whatever the reason it is not because i am in favor of fox or the yankees or england.

questions: guardians of power but not of democracy?
answers: The press is in a very serious decline but i think it is basically the commercial markets operating. The media is essentially made up of big corporations and essentially they live on advertising and their sources of capital are simply diffusing so the market itself is declining. So if you take say the boston globe it used to be quite a good newspaper one of the best in the country.

questions: and isn t it strange that these media outlets continue to defend a model which has led them to ruin?
answers: Doctrinally overwhelmingly and not just in the united states they simply support power. There are deviations. For example there is a movement in europe called libertario which pretty much stresses independence of the press and objectivity.

questions: the current focus is on isis. what about isis and its origins?
answers: There is an interesting interview that just appeared a couple of days ago with graham fuller a former cia officer one of the leading intelligence and mainstream analysts of this century. The title is the united states created terrorism. This is one aspect of a much broader story which you will find if you look.

questions: jaws should have been dropping all over the place but there was virtual silence in the commentary the next day?
answers: The somalia case is particularly horrendous. Yemen is bad enough. Somali tradition is deeply rooted and carries over to the burmese junta which is worse.

questions: do you remember the jimmy carter comment about vietnam?
answers: Not only do i remember it i think i was the first person to comment on it and am probably to date practically the only person who has. Carter the human rights advocate he was asked in a press conference in 1977 a kind of mild question do we have any responsibility for what is happening in vientnam.

questions: you have some information about the charter and its background?
answers: Thanks. I am well familiar with it. The foundation of israel is an interesting case.

questions: even elizabeth warren the highly touted democratic senator from massachusetts voted for this resolution about self defense?
answers: She probably knows nothing about the middle east. I think it is pretty obvious. Take the us prepositioning arms in israel for us use for military action in the region and presumably also for economic warfare.

questions: they have been supporting the kurds rather clandestinely but it is well known that israel has been pushing for fragmentation of iraq?
answers: Along with the us. And there is good reason. They do not want to leave what they call the graveyard of the prophets which is an arab city and they need it for their chemical weapons stockpile and all sorts of other stuff.

questions: i ask you you have got grandchildren. what kind of world do you see them inheriting.?
answers: The world that we are creating for our grandchildren is grim. The major concern ought to be the one that was brought up in new york at the september 21 march. A couple hundred thousand people turned out.

questions: do you think that there is some internal function of the language that is being used to mediate the conflict that subverts compromise?
answers: In the 1970s when there were clearly steps towards diplomatic settlement that could have been pursued israel upped the ante. They insisted that a condition be recognition by the us of a jewish state in whatever it was that was being claimed. That led to intense pressure on the west to back down and to accept the status quo which is not much of an issue in itself.

questions: is there some way to equalize the playing field with respect to international law to prevent powerful actors from diminishing their accountability?
answers: There is no supranational authority that can compel states to observe security council resolutions and so on. If states are weak they can be coerced into following orders even if they do not like them.

questions: what do you do with these populations in limbo?
answers: The united states took guant namo one of cuba is major ports at gunpoint and will not give it back. That is part of the policy of trying to strangle Cuba economically. The same is happening with the ramon rove land mass which is essentially a public subsidy to the wealthy and industrial areas.

questions: do you still think this is a realistic solution?
answers: If the united states changes its policy then there is an easy solution the international consensus. The us and canada should join the world and suspend settlement programs. They would then join all the other nuclear powers and live up to their obligation under the non proliferation treaty to eliminate all nuclear weapons along with all missiles and weapons of mass destruction as stipulated in the agreement with russia.

questions: what is the worst case scenario we could see this turn into. can the cold war turn hot. does u. s. want war?
answers: My own guess frankly was that the invasion of iraq would be over in about three days and that saudi arabia would probably be pleased to get out of the way as much as possible.

questions: professor u. s. s. what are american redlines doing on russian borders?
answers: Well this statement was interesting. It was not reported but if you look at the commentary it is understood to be correct. So obviously the russians are on our border cuba is on their border and he says that. No one says it.

questions: s. why are the americans apparently so ready to go to war?
answers: Well i do not think they really want war. If you take a look at polls which are very careful in the united states the public is in favor of a negotiated settlement. It is been for years public opinion has been in opposition to a military conflict and the reasons have been fairly explicit for a long time public diplomacy and other means to try to gain public acceptance have failed.

questions: but the emergence of isis seemed a surprise to all how did u. s. intelligence miss it?
answers: I suggest that you look up on the internet a recent article by graham fuller a former cia officer one of the leading intelligence and mainstream analysts of this century. His conclusion was that there was never any doubt that the attack was carried out by isil and that it was likely to succeed.

questions: so do you support the u. s. led bombing campaign?
answers: There are ways to respond diplomatically one conceivable possibility conceivable is to act in accordance with the law. There is a reign of international law that is in principal. It debars the use of force or violation of it as a crime against humanity.

questions: why would this be any different. talking about nsa spying is not stopping nsa spying?
answers: There is a difference. The spying being done by the us is much worse. So much so that a lot of the reporting on it is just fabrication because you can not believe what is being reported. I mean most of it i think is.

questions: can you talk about how central america influenced your thinking at the time about us power in the world particularly as it followed your involvement in the previous anti vietnam war movement?
answers: I had been following latin american crimes closely since the united states effected a coup in guatemala in 1954 and occasionally giving talks but later venezuela was always a close second. The reason was the same reason vader made it clear was we have to stop these crimes.

questions: in retrospect do you think defending a system that produced such a combination grinding poverty and extreme terror forced the opinion making class in the united states to a new level of double standards or denial?
answers: Long before i had been much impressed with the revolutionary pacifism of a. j. muste one of the great figures of twentieth century american history and a close friend. But i never had any hopes that he would adopt a revolutionary position.

questions: but is there a way to think of them more integrally in relation to us foreign and economic policy?
answers: Among the many operative factors us policies surely have a prominent place including the brutal repression of constructive alternatives the organization and implementation of outright terror the promoting of corporate exploitation of resources cultural imperialism in many dimensions and much else. That is true dramatically in each of the cases you mentioned.

questions: you know how do we learn from the old and confront the new?
answers: Well i think we can draw many very good lessons from both world wars. There were lessons both ways. The lesson of the united states is it is not a great idea to fight a two front war especially one that is as hideous as the us is invasion of south vietnam but at least you could say you have defeated the british.

questions: what is the road we take now given the paradigm that we have which is somewhat different from you know what this country was certainly in the first half of the 20th century?
answers: I think it is pretty much the same frankly. The idea still should be that of trotsky and all those who supported him and stood by as he carried out mass murder and terror in vietnam. That means you have to crush the resistance.

questions: but now it can not even adjust the system. you know we see cutting welfare?
answers: Yeah. I mean it is perfectly true that the population is mostly disenfranchised but that is not a good thing because you have to have something to vote for and the voting power of the lower 90 per cent is declining.

questions: but it also changed because of the breakdown of capitalism?
answers: There was a circumstance that led to the opportunity to do something but we are living with that constantly. I mean take the last 30 years. For the majority of people it is been stagnation or worse.

questions: does that make that propaganda more effective?
answers: Well and it is kind of an interesting question. Like a lot of people i have written about media and intellectual propaganda but there is another question which is not studied much how effective is it. And that is when you brought up the polls it makes sense to study those.

questions: when you look back on the occupy movement what do you think its failings were its importance were?
answers: Well i think it is a little misleading to call it a movement. Occupy was a tactic in fact a brilliant tactic.

questions: you know hannah arendt raises atomization as one of the key components of totalitarianism?
answers: Exactly. And it is often not even noticed. She points out how totalitarian states behave when they have too much centralized power.

questions: and i wondered if you could address this military monstrosity that you have written about quite a bit?
answers: Well for one thing the public does not like it. What is called isolationism or one or another bad word as you know pacifism was popularized in the late 1940s by the reagan administration which wanted to undermine the antifascist resistance and the labor movements and so on. In fact reaganesque is what it was called.

questions: and the iraqi army is collapsing?
answers: They are just giving away their arms. There obviously is a lot of collaboration going on. I was just talking to an iranian general the other day and he said there is no such thing as democracy in the middle east. This is the arab spring all over.

questions: i mean they are monitoring all the elected officials as well?
answers: Monitoring their every move. Including the congress.

questions: but those people are essentially passive virtually?
answers: They are not even thinking about it much.

questions: let is just close with climate change. like i read climate change reports which?
answers: Well unfortunately that is not very interesting because maybe you can develop some models that will try to approximate the range of what is happening. And it is pretty hard to do. Most of the studies that are out there are coming from very conservative institutions.

questions: and i think you would agree that is not going to come from the power elite?
answers: It is certainly not. Just to take a concrete case the imf is very closely linked to the major power centers in the united states and europe and they are supportive of his programs. The reason he is able to get these programs through is because there is a consensus in which the programs are supported by the majority of the american population.

questions: it is up to us?
