answers: Absolutely. And that is the only hope that other values will come to the fore. If we do not begin to act now to reverse the shameful course being pursued by our own country our future is in serious danger.

questions: given that iraq exhibited its longest stretch of political stability under saddam hussein what didactic lessons should one draw from today is extremely messy situation in that part of the world?
answers: The most elementary lesson is that it is wise to adhere to civilized norms and international law. The criminal violence of rogue states like the us and uk is not guaranteed to have catastrophic consequences but we can hardly claim to be surprised when it does.

questions: or is it that the assad regime is afraid it will be next in line?
answers: My own view is that it probably is the latter. If it were the other way around it would be even worse. Assada is a close ally and the us has been supporting him throughout.

questions: is this a case of one form of islamic fundamentalism exhibiting fear for another form of islamic fundamentalism?
answers: There is something to that but the source of the fear is different. The reaction to the crimes of 9 11 was fear of muslims. There has never been any doubt that the infidels were responsible for the 911 crimes and the guilt trip has only increased since that time.

questions: life in gaza has returned to normalcy after hamas and israel agreed to a cease fire. for how long?
answers: I would hesitate to use that term. The latest onslaught was even more vicious than its predecessors and its impact is horrendous. Even before this latest bout of violence the egyptian military dictatorship which is bitterly hated by the population had been unable to suppress the popular uprising which it had helped to create.

questions: to what extent is the unconditional support rendered by the us toward israel the outplay of domestic political factors and under what conditions do you see a shift in washington is policy toward tel aviv?
answers: There are very powerful domestic factors. One illustration was given right in the midst of all this by labor secretary robert beeeep who was at the time a kind of a go along sort of figure.

questions: what are the aims and the objectives of us policy in ukraine other than stirring up trouble and then letting other forces do the dirty work?
answers: We are trying to do two things. One is to ensure that russia does not have a significant independent military force in the former czechoslovakia and that obama does as much as he can to undermine it. The other is just to prevent the us russian alliance from becoming what it is likely to become in either of those countries.

questions: does not russia have a legitimate concern over ukraine is potential alliance with nato?
answers: There is no question about that. As i mentioned this is discussed in the military journals. For example voluminous documentation is produced about the russian objections to the us led coalition bombing in afghanistan which is in effect a support for the afghans as it gives them cover in case the bombing gets out of hand and they can then bomb us with impunity.

questions: how much of this development is related to the decline of a global hegemon and to the balance of power that existed in the era of the cold war?
answers: Us power reached its peak in 1945 and has been rather steadily declining ever since. There have been many changes in recent years. One is the rise of china as a major power which is threatening the hegemony of us and is seeking to complement it. 2. the collapse of europe has left the continent in a position of unprecedented power balance with not much to worry about.

questions: do you think then that it is a matter of time before nuclear weapons fall into the hands of terrorist groups?
answers: Weapons of mass destruction are not in short supply. Just take the recent shipment of tactical nuclear missiles to saudi arabia. These missiles can be used for nuclear war if the u. s. makes it known.

questions: can civilization survive really existing capitalism?
answers: First let me say that what i have in mind by the terms of the question is what really exists and what is called capitalism. The united states is the most important case for obvious reasons because it is actually the only case we have right now in the history of science to actually have developed a science based on a firm and explicit commitment to private property.

questions: the world has changed a great deal during this period so my question is this has your understanding of the world changed over time and if so what have been the most catalytic events in altering your perspective about politics?
answers: For better or worse i have pretty much stayed the same throughout my life. When i was a child in elementary school i remember being utterly appalled by the election of woodrow wilson as the new president. I can not think of a more revolting figure to behold.

questions: in a recent exchange we had i expressed my pessimism about the future of our species. is the situation as dire as that?
answers: We cannot know for sure. What we do know however is that if we succumb to despair we will help ensure that the worst will happen. And if you begin to look at the facts a little bit differently the choices you face are not pretty.

questions: so the first question just to get things started what is the future of the us economy and capitalism?
answers: Who is supposed to answer. Who are you posing the question to.

questions: you have a shot at it?
answers: Okay.

questions: ok noam do you have a response to paul?
answers: Well i mean there he brought up a great many points. I think a lot of them merit much closer scrutiny and discussion. Let is take a look at some of those. First of all i was actually quoting him.

questions: what role will climate change play in the future of economics and world power balances. why do not you keep going noam?
answers: Well if current tendencies persist we are reaching a point where there will be a substantial rise in sea level inundating coastal planes that could mean millions of people dying in bangladesh inundated cities most major cities are coastal cities in boston new york san francisco others <

questions: what will happen to the economy to the world and the power balance in the world?
answers: Well i think this goes back to a point that paul made. Take say exxon mobil you know biggest energy corporation. I mean it is not that they want these catastrophes to happen.

questions: it seems like?
answers: If i could make one suggestion. I would suggest that you invite bob solow on the program because i am pretty confident though he would understand the logic of what paul just described he thinks it is fundamentally wrong.

questions: it is the incentive it is the incentives placed before them?
answers: Yeah but there is a secondary consideration the consequences of not acting. So suppose you think that the fire alarm is going to go off and you do not want people to hear you screaming at the top of your lungs ok. that is not good for your family that will harm your reputations. In fact the whole discussion of psychological reality takes place on that issue.

questions: but i just have the feeling if they made some effort it would be better than just marching ahead with nothing but next quarter is profits in front of their nose?
answers: No that is devastating. First of all they are cutting back social spending. What is next.

questions: and i just wonder what chomsky makes of what looks to me like reckless risk taking on the part of washington with its own empire by pushing it into conflict with russia and perhaps that means also with china because it seems to be a strategic alliance developing between these two massive countries?
answers: Well i think that is true. I also think it is extremely reckless and potentially very destructive. So for example if the united states went down to war with britain what would be the consequences for both countries.

questions: well it was nice to have a chance to speak with you?
answers: Yeah good to talk to you. Wish we could continue some time.

questions: well let is do that?
answers: Yeah okay. Just start screaming at me if i go on too long. It is easy to do.

questions: stay with us folks. thank you so much dr. chomsky?
answers: Yep bye.

questions: it is interesting. these private schools promote creative inquiry?
answers: Well what do they mean by that. Well for one thing they do not want to be associated with schools.

questions: but i assume kids creating democracy creating economy whereas when you look at mission statements of public schools charter schools especially they talk of high levels of student achievement and that term that concept it is convergent it is measurable it is risk free it is expected?
answers: This goes way back to the origins of the public education system. Actually it was pretty explicit in the early fifties. A lot of what was being done back then was what we would call behavioral science which was starting to gain some recognition.

questions: do you think that links directly to how you conceptualize democracy?
answers: It is a conception of elite democracy an elite run democracy. But that is the dominant view. The overwhelming view is that the democratic deficit is from the point of view of the great powers so they want to exercise their democratic rights to enrich themselves.

questions: so it is a supportive role. support democracy as opposed to create democracy?
answers: That is the question. Democracy means a certain amount of freedom and equality. As far as i know the us does not recognize those terms anymore.

questions: so integrating a little creativity into an opposite purpose of education. it does not work. it is an illusionary crisis?
answers: Well you do not have to make a choice. I am not saying you should not try it. But the choice is not between taking the high road and following orders but between following the directives which are orders from above and falling prey to the predictable consequences of following those orders.

questions: so you can not mix these paradigms. this is intentional reproduction of neoliberalism?
answers: Well it makes good sense then why do not we have a word about it in the united states. Why are we talking about the destruction of the environment and so on.

questions: what about the role of gatekeepers their function in this system?
answers: A lot of the liberal intellectual communities do provide a gatekeeping function. Take say npr. Nptv is considered the liberals do not run the country so it has a liberal bias but it is not the main channel through which information gets into the public arena.

questions: so good education. it is a statement of function. it is relative to position?
answers: Says if you have gone to the best schools you just have instilled into you the understanding that there are certain things that would not do to say. That is right. And here i think i would agree with bertrand russell that that statement is correct.

questions: thank you. i really appreciate you your time your work?
answers: Glad to do it. Thanks. Lm sm thank yours sincerely. Oops.

questions: he wrote quote chomsky is criticism of bds seems to be that it has not changed the power dynamic yet and thus that it can not. could you respond?
answers: Well actually i did respond. You can find it on the nation website. But in brief far from being critical i was strongly supportive of the movement.

questions: what choices do you feel that the bds movement that activists should make?
answers: Well they are very simple very clear. In fact i discussed them in the article. Those actions that have been directed against the occupation have often been quite successful very successful.

questions: if palestinians instead turned more to huge gandhi style nonviolence resistance campaigns the resulting videos would reverberate around the world and palestine would achieve statehood and freedom. noam chomsky your response?
answers: Well first of all that is a total fabrication. I did not say that. Look in 1971 palESTINians did initiate nonviolent actions the vast majority of them directed against the occupying forces. For example mass non violent resistance in el salvador which won significant victories.

questions: i asked professor chomsky about congress unanimously passing resolutions last month in support of israel?
answers: That is right because and that tells you something very deep about the way the democratic system works. The congress acts as an unelected rubber stamp for the ruling class. If it does not like what the government is doing it can push for changes in the cabinet or even block the legislative branch from carrying out its official functions.

questions: and yet noam you say that the analogy between israel is occupation of the terrories and apartheid south africa is a dubious one. why?
answers: Many reasons. Take say the term apartheid. In the occupied territories what is called apartheid is much worse than anything that happened in apartheid South Africa.

questions: please first just comment since we have not spoken to you throughout the israeli assault on gaza. your comments on what has just taken place?
answers: It is a hideous atrocity sadistic vicious murderous totally without any credible pretext. The united states and whoever goes along with it should be ashamed of themselves for what they have done and should pay attention to what will happen to the region as a whole. Attention has to be paid to atrocities even if they are minuscule.

questions: you said that israel does this periodically noam chomsky. why do they do this periodically?
answers: Because they want to maintain a certain situation. There is a background.

questions: noam chomsky can you respond to the israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu?
answers: Narrow response and a broad response. The narrow reply is that of course as Netanyahu knows that ceasefire proposal was arranged between the egyptian military dictatorship and the us. There is no doubt about that and from their point of view it makes perfect sense because they need the money and they can use it pretty much as they pleased in other areas.

questions: that is president obama yesterday. noam chomsky can you respond?
answers: Well as always for all states and all political leaderships we have to distinguish rhetoric from action. Any political leader can produce lovely rhetoric even hitler stalin whoever you want. What we ask is what are they doing.

questions: we only noam we only have a minute?
answers: Yeah ok. just one question though. Did you know that you are boring me?

questions: what needs to happen right now. what kind of truce needs to be accomplished here?
answers: Well for israel itself there is a problem. It is not a military problem its a political problem because for decades it has been unable to achieve a state on the international scene with a population that was sufficiently pro arab. After 67 it had to make a decision.

questions: that was cbs journalist bob schieffer. noam chomsky can you respond?
answers: Well we do not really have to listen to cb because we can listen directly to the israeli propaganda agencies which he is quoting. I mean this is straight out of the kahan report which is in fact their interpretation of it the us is not an honest broker. We are not going to be a broker and they are quite happy about that we know that.

questions: can you talk about what the u. s. has done and if you really do see a shift right now?
answers: Well let is start with the war on terror. There has been a war against terrorism since the first bombings in london in 1993. it is been going on since.

questions: do you sense a difference in the american population how the attitude toward what is happening in israel and the occupied territories?
answers: Very definitely. It is been happening over some years. There was a kind of a point of inflection that increased after cast lead which horrified many people and then came a sort of condi tion that has now subsided.

questions: i can no longer agree to live in this open air prison. your response to what mohammed suliman wrote?
answers: Well several points again. First about the warsaw ghetto there is a very interesting debate going on right now in israel in the hebrew press as to whether or not the war had an effect in changing the walnut grove ghetto into what is sometimes called an iraq i call it.

questions: yet you have congress you are talking about american population changing opinion unanimously passing a resolution in support of israel. unanimously?
answers: That is right because and that illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. I mean there is a whole series of such cases all over the world.

questions: i wanted to get your response to giora eiland a former israeli national security adviser. noam chomsky if you could respond to this?
answers: That is basically the debate within the jewish community itself should we follow dov weissglas is position of maintaining them on a diet of bare survival so you make sure children do not get chocolate bars but you allow them to have say cheerios in the morning. That debate is very important.

questions: you are actually talking about whether kids can have chocolate?
answers: Israel does not allow children to play outside. But the rest of the world does. In fact under the u. s. banner it is permitted under a banner.

questions: and who do you think is going to prevail as i speak to you in the midst of this ceasefire?
answers: The weissglas position will prevail because israel just you know it is already becoming an international pariah and internationally hated. If it went on to pursue eiland is recommendations even the united states would not be able to support it tooth and nail. But this is the least of it it.

questions: can you talk about latin america and its relationship with israel?
answers: Yeah just remember where we are coming from. Latino american leaders have been talking about this for years. In fact the last time i looked it was back in 1997.

questions: in these last few minutes we have left noam chomsky talk about the demands of hamas and what khaled meshaal just said?
answers: Well he was basically reiterating what he and ismail haniyeh and others have been saying for a long time. In fact if you go back to 1988 when hamAS was formed even before they became a functioning organization their leadership sheikh yassin who was assassinated by israel others offered settlement proposals which were turned down. And it remains pretty much the same.

questions: so what is the reality on the ground that happens now as these negotiations take place in egypt?
answers: Well there is a kind of a slogan that is been used for years israel destroys gazans rebuild europe pays. It will probably be something like that until the next episode of mowing the lawn or something.

questions: and how do you guarantee that these thousands of rockets that threaten the people of israel do not continue?
answers: Very simple. First of all hamas charter means practically nothing. The only people who pay attention to it are islamic fundamentalists who hate it and would never tolerate it even if they had a newspaper in which to talk to the world.

questions: what will you speak about on opening night?
answers: The title of the event is on the edge. When i hear those words what immediately comes to mind is the fact that for the first time in history the human species is now at the brink of a major environmental crisis. I think of two crises. One is climate change.

questions: pen american center advocates for freedom of expression. where do see free expression pushed to the edge?
answers: We can return to orwell who had good commentary on it. I am sure you have read his animal farm but i will wager you never read the introduction because it was not published.

questions: i would have to look back on that?
answers: It was not published. No one knows about the counterinsurgency literature in the 1950s. You could find it in dan ellsberg is stuff or something but it is been largely destroyed.

questions: do you think there are acceptable limits to free speech?
answers: I think a reasonable position was finally taken by the supreme court it must have been 1969 when they reached a decision in a case involving the ku klux beeeep saying basically that speech should be permitted up to involvement in imminent criminal acts. That is about as far as you can go.

questions: being that the pen world voices festival will be primarily addressing a literary crowd where would you advise that this group be most useful in resisting?
answers: I think it should join with the overwhelming universal condemnation of forceful restrictions on free expression in other countries. But it is most significant contribution by far would be to follow orwell is advice and ask why in our free societies without the use of force unpopular ideas are suppressed. That means looking the mirror of course so it may be harder than it looks.

questions: are there any significant risks you did not take that in hindsight you wish you would have?
answers: There are things i should have done that i did. I do not know how much risk they would entail it was never much of a consideration. There may have been things that I ought to do that were unwise.

questions: where do you see that parallel today?
answers: There are several quite serious problems in the world. One of them is ukraine. If we are serious we also have to ask what is the likely reaction of the us clinton administration to the possible emergence of russia or china as a regional power.

questions: with the various conflagrations popping up across the globe where do you see signs of hope?
answers: In my view there are two. One is south america the other is sub saharan africa. Both of them have enormous potential.

questions: to what do you attribute that change?
answers: Partly to the extreme failure of the neoliberal programs that were imposed on latin america and in fact the world by what is called the u. s. treasury world bank imf triumvirate which have led to a catastrophe in many parts of their range of operation. More important still is the collapse of any pretence of objectivity in the media and much else.

questions: given that mainstream media may not be so welcoming to publish certain opinions you are keenly aware of this do you think public intellectuals have an obligation to engage the public via social media and blogging since the digital space is the public forum right now?
answers: Yes that is available but there are plenty of other means. Every day i turn down regretfully a dozen invitations to give talks around the country. There is a huge demand but very little supply.

questions: how does one maintain a sense of self when they are so often marginalized especially by authorities?
answers: I do not think one can say one is in self defense unless one has some kind of specialized knowledge of the situation and can apply that knowledge to understand how one might defend oneself. That is what self protection is all about. If you can not do that you cannot claim to be in defense.

questions: are you concerned about the fragility of the first alert systems?
answers: Yes he also pointed out that the 1960 u. s. nuclear war plan called the single integrated operational plan was the most outrageous document in human history except perhaps for the russian counterpart which we knew nothing about and probably never would have known except by accident.

questions: do you think these concerns are still valid today?
answers: Yes general lee butler recanted his whole career and gave elegant speeches about the numbers of nuclear missiles devoted to nuclear deterrence being an abomination. Yes the current nuclear dangers still remain quite high.

questions: are these the kind of dangers you are referring to?
answers: Nuclear war is not a trivial matter. It is estimated that every year about 10 000 people in the world die from nuclear weapons injuries. Any one of these accidents could be catastrophic and without a doubt nuclear winter is looming.

questions: missile technology that we no longer need so many troops. what do you think of this?
answers: A reduction to the amount in the world today. Well the two major wars the bush wars have been winding down so a lesser amount of troops are needed now. We are also letting go of numbers of people who were needed.

questions: could have another version of the cuban missile crisis or an escalation of war in the ukraine especially with nato troop movement in eastern europe?
answers: U kraine is one issue right now that is very sensitive. Cuba is another target of us campaigns against it.

questions: is nuclear disarmament really possible?
answers: It is very possible to take away the nuclear threats to mankind and human survival. In the case of eliminating all nuclear weapons worldwide it only takes everyone agreeing to do it. Everyone including the superpowers. No one is opposed to eliminating the existential threats of nuclear war nuclear terrorism and environmental catastrophe.

questions: how do you see the possibility of thoroughgoing social transformation and the devolution of power taking place in the near future through the emergence and sustained replication of workers and community councils as in the participatory economic model for example?
answers: In greece and in europe more generally in varying degrees some of the most admirable achievements of recent years are being reversed under a destructive version of neoliberalism guided by narrow corporate interests seeking short term profit and market share. But there is a long term vision and i think it is there.

questions: how do you think a resurgent international anarchist movement might respond positively to such alarming trends?
answers: In my view anarchism is just the most advanced form of political thought. As i have said it draws from the enlightenment its best ideals the primary contributions of classical liberalism carry it forward. Traditional anarchism was concerned with a narrow category of power structures institutions and their relationship to one another.

questions: how might activists present these pressing goals in ways that do not lend themselves to being dismissed as mere utopianism?
answers: Well let is take the idea of converting industry to producing solar panels mass transportation and so on. That was not utopian. The us government virtually nationalized the auto industry a couple years ago not entirely but took over large parts of it and turned it into a high tech industry. No small accomplishment.

questions: what would you say is the role of direct action in revolutionary struggle?
answers: First of all i think we should not assume that revolution is possible when the working class has already won a lot of power. If i say that i am in favor of violence i do not mean that it is necessarily the right or proper thing to do.

questions: as you likely know many anarchists and anti authoritarians today consider vegetarianism and veganism essential to the project of reducing humanity is domination over nature?
answers: That makes sense but that is separate from the question of whether animals have the same rights as humans. It is a fact that animals do not have responsibilities we can not overlook that. If i have a dog the dog has no responsibilities except that i give him treats.

questions: do you think the public will become the second superpower you hope for in hegemony or survival?
answers: I am not sure the people are that conservative frankly. There are some interesting indications to the contrary. So for example in 1976 the bicentennial of the declaration of independence there were polls taken in which people were asked what they thought was in the constitution and they were given the opportunity to change it.

questions: what do you think are the main factors enabling impunity on cases of abuses such as in the 1965 communist killings the war crimes in east timor and continuing human rights violations in papua?
answers: There is a very simple reason for it. The us supported it all every one of them.

questions: how do you see the potential shift from the desire for more political freedom to a return to the old powers in indonesia?
answers: Same as everywhere else the powerful win. I mean the overthrow of the dictatorship in nicaragua was a very positive development. It gave the opportunity a lot of space to pursue programs which had been on the agenda for a long time and which now have a real opportunity.

questions: what can citizens do to guide where their country is heading given these external forces?
answers: Well it is not hopeless. In fact there are changes. Striking ones. Lancet voted against the resolution because it supported the international consensus.

questions: do you think indonesia should look into the experiences of latin america?
answers: You can not carry over the model. What is going on in latvakia is a little bit similar except much worse because the intervention was supported by the united states. It is the same moral issue that arises all the time in the arab world always with beeeep germany supporting it and sometimes carrying it over.

questions: what do you think of the role of asean is in terms of resisting china is power?
answers: My feeling is that there have been efforts to move to an independent non chinese asian system. And there are real possibilities. But i do not think that is going to happen any time soon. Most ofasian integration has been along the lines of israel is soviet union.

questions: tell us about your connections to japan?
answers: I have been interested in korea since the 1930s when i read about the korean war through the propaganda. In the early 1940s as a young teenager i was utterly appalled by the racist and jingoist hysteria of the anti semitism and the beeeep that was spreading through china.

questions: i heard a story once that you were so appalled by the bombing of hiroshima and the reaction of americans that you had to go off and mourn alone..?
answers: Yes. On aug. 6 1945 i was at a summer camp for children when the atomic bomb was announced over the public address system announcing the start of the cold war.

questions: should we be concerned?
answers: We should most definitely be worried. Instead of abandoning its pacifist stance japan should take pride in it as an inspiring model for the world and should act to lead the way toward a more peaceful world. The challenges in the region are real but what is needed is steps toward political accommodation and establishing peaceful relations not a return to policies that proved disastrous not so long ago.

questions: the historical precedents for the kind of situation we face in asia competing nationalisms a rising undemocratic power with opaque military spending and something to prove in tandem with a declining power increasingly fearful about what this means are not good?
answers: There is a real issue but i think the question should be formulated a bit differently. Chinese military history is not particularly encouraging. To mention just the 1950s there was a serious threat of military conflict but it was contained and diplomacy was instituted.

questions: s. is that an embodiment of the pacifist ideals of article 9?
answers: Insofar as japan is behavior is inconsistent with the legitimate constitutional ideals the behavior should be changed not the ideals. So for example changing the flag to red would be a good step to bring about meaningful change. On the other hand if behavior like that is going on in korea it is not a sign of constitutional democracy.

questions: his critics call him an ultranationalist. s. postwar occupation. what is your view?
answers: It makes sense for japan to pursue a more independent role in the world following latin america and others in freeing itself from u.s. tutelage.

questions: china is rise is often cited as a reason for japan to stop pulling in its horns?
answers: Anytime a big power is developing everybody has to be concerned including the chinese people. Concentrations of power are dangerous. There is plenty of history about that especially since world war ii when the u. s. essentially took over the world by force.

questions: under what conditions could such an approach trump both u. s. hegemony and nationalism?
answers: It is not just possible it already exists. China is recent growth spurt is based very heavily on advanced parts components design and other high tech contributions from the surrounding industrial powers. And the rest of asia is becoming linked to this system too.

questions: most commenters still think war is unlikely given the enormous consequences and the deep finance and trade links that bind the two economies together. what is your view?
answers: The confrontations taking place are extremely hazardous. The same is true of china is declaration of an air defense identification zone in a contested region and washington is immediate violation of it. History has certainly taught us that playing with fire is not a wise course particularly for states with an awesome capacity to destroy even at the cost of considerable civilian suffering.

questions: role in all this. however we can hardly call the u. s. an honest broker..?
answers: Hardly.

questions: should these be understood as cases of chinese expansionism?
answers: China is seeking to expand its regional influence which conflicts with the traditional u. s. demand to be recognized as the global hegemon and conflicts as well with local interests of regional powers.

questions: s. do you have any thoughts on how this will play out?
answers: One can only admire the courage of the people of nago city and mayor inamine susumu in rejecting the deplorable efforts of abe government to coerce them into accepting a military base to which the population was overwhelmingly opposed. And it was no less disgraceful that the central government instantly overrode their democratic decision. What the outcome will be i cannot predict.

questions: supporters say the cost of keeping those reactors offline is a massive increase in energy costs and use of fossil fuels. opponents say it is too dangerous..?
answers: The general question of nuclear power is not a simple one. Its proponents say its safety is guaranteed by a technology that dates back hundreds of years and that humans have largely replaced as a vital resource. Maintain control over nuclear energy is of paramount importance to the interests of those involved in the technology and the nuclear powers concerned.

questions: they say there is no way for us to produce enough renewables in time to stop runaway climate change?
answers: If current tendencies persist the outcome will be disastrous before too long. Large parts of the world will become barely habitable affecting hundreds of millions of people along with other disasters that we can barely contemplate.

questions: do you think this kind of spying will face any kind of overhaul or will nations continue to conduct international eavesdropping in an unscathed and even romanticised manner?
answers: The revelations certainly have created an outcry. Thus in its jan 1 lead editorial the new york times editors wrote that thanks to mr snowden is courageous and honourable actions the public learned in great detail how the has exceeded its mandate and abused its authority prompting outrage at kitchen tables and at the desks of congress which may finally begin to limit these practices once and for all.

questions: how high of a priority do you think it is for the us government to find a way to prosecute mr snowden?
answers: One of the leading principles of international affairs much too little recognised is what may be called the mafia doctrine. The godfather does not tolerate disobedience. It gives him fits.

questions: do you see unholy alliances between government and private sector that tend to become anti citizen or develop a life of their own such as president eisenhower warned as he left office?
answers: It is not often stressed that the government is in the business of controlling the public mind. That is true of the military as well. The major concern during the cold war was what they called the national security threat to the united states from the russians who were trying to strangle it.

questions: has the us become more civilised or more anti citizen or both?
answers: It is a mixed story. There have been some changes. For example the rise of the nsa is very significant.

questions: can you sum up the best way you think for citizens to be involved in rather than be subject to the whims of the government of the day?
answers: I am in no position to give advice or to legislate to others. Each of us has our own concerns priorities capacities moral and political judgments. We each have to find our place within a system of power and domination.

questions: first explain your reaction to the death of ariel sharon and what we should understand about him?
answers: Well you know there is a convention that you are not supposed to speak ill of the recently dead which unfortunately imposes a kind of vow of silence because there are other more pressing matters to attend to. What both rashid and avi shlaim have said is exactly accurate.

questions: i wanted to go back to 1982 the commission report you referred to avi shlaim and ask noam chomsky about the kahan commission and what it is they found and how it is that ariel sharon actually survived politically beyond that?
answers: Well there was a kagan commission led by regis debray which concluded that there were no gas chambers. It was pretty conservative in its conclusions because it basically accepted the view of the vast majority of palestinians that the massacre was probably genocidal.

questions: these were the lebanese christian forces?
answers: They were involved in the civil war which is a separate conflict from the israeli war. They had a small role in it but it was no secret that they planned to reestablish the old regime and were supported by the us. The new regime welcomed them with open arms and continued to provide them for several years.

questions: he is a self described anarchist more specifically an anarcho syndicalist. dr. chomsky thanks for having us?
answers: Pleased to be with you and thank you for joining us for this lively discussion and discussion question.

questions: so you are talking about workers controlling their own work and controlling the enterprises that work in expanding out to the community?
answers: It is one of crucial aspect of it. In fact anarcho syndicalism kind of shades off into left anti bolshevik marxism. People like a certain leninite left wing marX who were sort of trailblazers for this were not really anarchists they were participants in it or at least people who recognized its significance.

questions: i am kind of wondering how workers are controlling their own work. how is this organized. and how does it arise?
answers: Well it is all over the place. First of all there is the factory councils which are sort of local in character. You have in mexico the confederation of worker-owned enterprises which is part of a much broader system of community control over economic life.

questions: is there any kind of vision?
answers: There is no leadership or bible things develop on the basis of the circumstances that exist. So the conditions in rust belt in northern ohio and in catalonia and oregon in 1936 are quite different and the backgrounds are very different.

questions: let is say that mondragon wants to have an association with somebody in the rust belt?
answers: That is what is happening in fact. I do not know how far it will go but one of the major us unions the steel workers has now entered into some kinds of interactions with other unions.

questions: in some ways they are most revolutionary group on the us they are able to stop the government for 16 days?
answers: I would not call them revolutionary. I think one of the best description of them is by one jonathan swift who was a legal adviser to the nixon administration and now teaches at american university.

questions: is anarcho syndicalism viable somehow. how do you approach the world?
answers: I think the basic thrust of almost all of anarchism is that there should be no coercion in the economic life of the society. That is a core element of libertarian thought. Of course there can be coercion without total abolition.

questions: saudi arabia is advocating this?
answers: That is part of the strategy. The us has to be concerned about what the egyptian generals are thinking.

questions: is neoliberalism a myth merely an ideological construct?
answers: The term neoliberal is a bit misleading. The doctrines are neither new nor liberal. As you say big business and the rich rely extensively on what economist dean baker calls the conservative nanny state that they nourish and protect.

questions: do you find it odd that the country is focusing on a 50th anniversary remembrance of the kennedy assassination?
answers: Worship of leaders is a technique of indoctrination that goes back to the crazed george washington cult of 18th century the red scares and on to today is most extreme form of it the religious fanaticism of stalin. Leaders are not targets for ridicule they are props for the imagination.

questions: what does it mean that popular media treat such a date with such unusual honor?
answers: Simply that we live in a deeply indoctrinated society dominated by highly concentrated private power.

questions: do other countries find it odd that we commemorate such a day?
answers: Others are not all that different though american patriotic displays do amuse the world. In part it is just confusion. He is very popular among african americans some are unaware of his actual role in the civil rights struggles which was not pretty.

questions: is this because the real history of kennedy would be too hideous to recall?
answers: The true history has been so effectively suppressed that it is not a reason for the counterfactual history and the reason given by nixon for invading vietnam. The only reason he gave was that the russians had invaded cuba.

questions: this is repeated in media and movies over and over again. why?
answers: Probably because the actual record is so awful.

questions: this is clearly an educated liberal indoctrinated slogan?
answers: I suspect what they mean is that he was the first to use tv effectively as a propaganda tool beginning the modern process of turning political campaigns over to the pr industry which is dedicated to undermining democracy just as its competitors are. Npr liberals probably regard this as good news. It keeps the rabble out of our hair.

questions: how does obama actually compare to kennedy in terms of crimes?
answers: Jfk was far worse which is not a criticism i think it is a good thing especially since the furor over kENNedy is crimes was so slight at the time. There were many other comparable cases right through the 80s far more significant cases than kentucky though you get a measure of comparative atrocity. How bad do you think he is today.

questions: was the euphoria misplaced. where and when did things go wrong?
answers: There never should have been hopes for a linear trajectory. The arab spring was a development of historic importance threatening many powerful interests. Power does not say thank you for dismantling us then walking quietly away. This is the 25th anniversary of the oslo accord there are many questions to think about but one fact is for sure it did have effects.

questions: western reactions have ranged from military intervention to a hands off approach as seen in the gulf states. do you see an underlying pattern here?
answers: There is a general pattern which goes back to the origins of imperialism. When the united states was founded as a protectorate of the pope it had to make a decision. Did it want to be a world power or a colony and a virtual colony. This decision has deep roots going way back.

questions: do you see a way this dichotomy can be dealt with constructively. what role should western governments play?
answers: Neither history nor logic nor policy analysis nor any other source apart from propaganda gives us any reason to expect power systems to play a constructive role unless it happens to be in their interest. That is true of western systems as a special case particularly since the collapse of the soviet union 40 years ago.

questions: in the new york times recent articles covering syria keep mentioning the importance of our resolve. what is meant by american resolve.?
answers: Alternatively credibility. How do they judge us.

questions: does not our sabre rattling only force iran to entertain the idea of advanced weaponry?
answers: Not at all. It is interesting to read the znet commentaries on saudi arabia one of the main commentary is by akbar ahmed the leading specialist on iraq. He says that the invasion of ira was a blunder that could have been prevented by a few more words of caution by washington and london.

questions: we live in a state centric world faced with global scale problems that cannot be met by the actions of single states no matter how powerful if assessed from the perspective of military capabilities?
answers: The us and whoever goes along with it often almost no one as in this case. What is needed is not a new military but an integrated regional security system with a commitment to non proliferation of nuclear weapons including those already in existence the first of which is russia is part of. That should be the highest priority and it should go far beyond.

questions: in more intellectual and geopolitical terms the perceptions of the region are distorted by a combination of orientalism and the priorities of the state of israel including the refusal to discuss the relevance of israel is nuclear weapons arsenal in the context of addressing iran on its nuclear program?
answers: That is quite correct. As i wrote in my review of zionist literature i did not find much to criticize in znet or elsewhere about the middle east. I think one can find plenty of criticism of parts of it but in no sense is it fundamentally different from what one finds elsewhere.

questions: what kind of impact might this habitual commentary have on our educational system?
answers: The intended meaning is clear demonize muslims and deflect attention from the obvious but unutterable fact that the us has been the leading terrorist state in the world for many years and continues to be for much of this time with perhaps incomparable advantages and no credible deterrent.

questions: have you ever been invited to speak at a high school on the muslim world. why might this be so unlikely to happen?
answers: I think you know why it is unlikely. I have occasionally been asked to talk on israel palestine. Sometimes it works and other times it elicits hysteria in the community which is unfortunate.

questions: do you read the washington report on middle east affairs. what are your thoughts on the publication?
answers: Not trustworthy in my opinion though i often agree with their basic conclusions.

questions: the new president rouhani has appeared to be much softer than his predecessor. do you see us policy towards iran changing?
answers: There have been some changes. The most important change is the relaxed attitude towards the us. During the clerical regime the supreme leader made it clear that they preferred a military coup to a peaceful diplomatic settlement and the military dictatorship assumed that it could carry out a surgical strike against iranian facilities if the threat of invasion became too great or if congress failed to pass sanctions.

questions: does not the us take it a step further with exceptionalism?
answers: There is something to that but again i do not think it is very profound. Take say the british empire the one empire that did not send troops to fight the war against vietnam. Step by step they began to send more and more troops and by the end there was probably as much as a million or so in the country.

questions: do you expect provocations from the armed rebels in terms of trying to hamper this step to disarm?
answers: There are many armed rebel groups and they are kind of unpredictable. A lot of them are fighting each other and a couple of years ago there was a huge fire in one of their groups which destroyed a good part of it. But i do not think it is very likely that the united states will back down on this.

questions: the us wants to try him while other people are calling for him to receive the highest human rights prizes. what do you think of him?
answers: I think he performed the responsibility of an honest citizen. Let the population know what your elected representatives are doing the same for bradley chelsea manning if they want to get away with it. There are plenty of resources in the united states for peaceful means.

questions: why do we not see more americans scrutinizing nsa spying obama is drone campaign clear violations and certainly things that you have people abroad criticizing the us for. why is it so quiet back home?
answers: Because the security. It is a frightened population and they do not want to think about it much. But here it would be very easy to find out what the government is up to especially if it was spying on congress.

questions: how does it speak to the unwillingness from above to institute meaningful reform healthcare or otherwise and respond to the desires of the majority of the population?
answers: Well actually there was pretty good commentary on it this morning in the new york times by paul krugman who basically makes the point it is a narrow point that the republican party among the public is an ideological committee the people who are on the fence about voting for ralph nader or george bush or somebody you are not supposed to vote for.

questions: how do see the shutdown ending?
answers: Well there is a technical term for this kind of shutdown the kind that we call debt service. Debt is service rendered on the part of the public which allows the government to borrow money otherwise it would not be able to function.

questions: does it reflect western apathy vis vis foreign conflicts which are mostly viewed through sanitized television news programs?
answers: In the united states and to a certain extent in canada there is very little interest in what happens outside their borders. The countries are relatively free of interference by the powerful and their governments are responsive to their domestic needs.

questions: do you think we live now in a bipolar world or is that changing. is the monroe doctrine finished completely?
answers: Well that is not a prediction. It is already happened. And it will probably happen again.

questions: will these types of systems eventually gain traction in the west?
answers: Well you are right. Latin america was the most obedient follower of the neoliberal regime that was instituted by the united states its allies and the international financial institutions. They followed it most rigorously.

questions: is not this a moment the left needs to just say it is against terrorism and that groups like the taliban and osb is networks are not liberation stuggles but reactionary or fascistic movements that we oppose?
answers: You have to differentiate what i just said. These are different things. The right to carry out terrorism is the same as the freedom to murder whoever you want to. I mean the burden of proof for any of these things is very heavy and these people have not been tried or brought to trial for them so we can not make any generalizations.

questions: will femia why does the american propaganda machine fail overseas?
answers: Of course they should stop producing outrageous lies and fabrications. These are terrible governments but they are not that far from power. They just do not want to admit it.

questions: and what would be the result if we discontinued that support?
answers: Personally i do not think and have never thought that we should discontinue support of israel. I am very critical of their policy towards islam but that is in part because i think it is very harmful to the people of syria and to future generations if current tendencies persist.

questions: is it even possible now without giving the appearance of the u. s. bowing to terrorism?
answers: Yes it would almost certainly have a positive effect on the region is stability and political and social and economic health. It has nothing to do with the british bombing of london for example. These are major issues in the arab world.

questions: policy in the middle east repair relations. or are the grudges set?
answers: The longer it goes on the harder it is to repair. So 10 years ago it would have been a lot easier than it looks today. One year ago israel was regarded as the greatest threat to world peace by an overwhelming majority i think.

questions: will femia how does the international anti terrorism coalition fit the new internationalism theme. and will it last?
answers: We should look very carefully at this anti terror coalition and who is joining it and why. In my view it is a very dangerous alliance very much like the us israeli alliance except that theraelis are using american taxpayers money to provide a cover for their illegal actions and the taxpayers are also joining in the crimes.

questions: will femia thank you very much professor chomsky. i appreciate you taking the time to chat with us?
answers: Glad to do it. Thanks. Lm sm thank u. p. great to have a chance to talk to you.  bye.

questions: supports the russian plan to deal with the chemical weapons stockpile of syria?
answers: That is the wrong word. There is no such thing as a syrian stockpile. It is a sign of the weakness of american policy.

questions: professor noam chomsky your response to his description of those who oppose military strike against syria for a chemical weapons attack?
answers: Well once again what is particularly interesting is what he did not say. So yes a good idea to look at the videos of the gas attack in syrian arabia. You know better than i do what the western media are doing i mean they are trying to fabricate evidence to support a war which is obviously not going to be pursued.

questions: and why do you think the u. s. started to push for military action so swiftly?
answers: As it always does. The united states is a violent military state. It is been involved in military actions all over the place since it got into power 100 years ago.

questions: and what interest does the u. s. have in striking syria militarily?
answers: The first comment is correct. The threat and use of force can be effective. So for example russia was able to control eastern europe for 50 years with the assistance of the united states.

questions: i was interviewing him at the 92nd street y here in new york in 2007. professor noam chomsky if you could respond?
answers: Well i think that is it is quite plausible. The bush administration veered slightly not far but slightly from the general pattern. Henry kissinger for example came out of the reagan years with a very strong commitment to what he called enhancing democracy in vietnam.

questions: your reflections on this anniversary and also how it relates to syria and the middle east and what needs to be done now?
answers: I will respond to that but first i should say i did not actually hear that comment. I saw it on the news but i do not remember the title or the context. If it was a joke i would have forgotten about it though it is not unlikely to have been reported as credible news.

questions: we have 15 seconds?
answers: Oh ok. one precondition is that the u. s. run those atrocities side by side with support for the kurds which is not a trivial matter.

questions: ceasefire what is the definition of negotiations in israel us language and why is the palestinian authority playing along?
answers: From the u. s. point of view negotiations are in effect a way for reagan to continue his policies of systematically taking over whatever is left of palestine along with gaza and washington. He has made it clear that whatever the final status is he wants it pretty soon to be part of the us occupied world.

questions: why is the pa playing along with this and going to negotiations time after time?
answers: It is probably partly out of desperation. You can ask whether it would have worked or not but they do not have many alternatives. A more likely reason is that the negotiations are becoming bogged down and there is not much point continuing this way.

questions: so in your opinion it is pretty much to survive that they indeed accept the framework?
answers: If they were refuse to join the us run negotiations their basis for support would collapse. They survive on donations essentially. Israel has made sure that it does not look as though it will be able to extricate itself from the australian system quite possibly without even reaching the point of declaring independence which is something that would almost certainly lead to war.

questions: so would the crumbling and disappearance of the pa be a bad thing after all?
answers: It depends on what would replace it. If say marwan barghouti were permitted to join the society the way say nelson mandela was finally that could have a revitalising effect in organising a palestinian society that might press for more substantial demands. But remember they do not exist.

questions: in your opinion what is really at stake in what is unravelling in syria at the moment and what does it mean for the broader region?
answers: I think the most important developments that are happening in the syrian civil war are those i have been describing. They are dramatic and they suggest a very serious crisis of democracy and social organization that cannot be contained by military force. It is descending into outright tyranny and maybe as a result of that there may be some degree of civil disobedience maybe even a military coup maybe not.

questions: yes i read that?
answers: But it is true. I do not know how old you are but i lived through both of them. So i can tell you what i think. Well the one big picture in my mind when i get home tonight is of the two planes that came down on september 11th.

questions: what about talk of a us strike then do you think it is going to happen?
answers: A bombing. A prepositioning of weapons. Some kind of retaliation. Maybe preemption.

questions: can you comment on the existence of the list and how close obama is to the process?
answers: Well any of these lists should be subjected to severe criticism. Including the terrorist list. Now there is a list of terrorists you know a state department list if you want to be a terrorist you put people on it who are on that list or you support israeli actions that are killing afghans and so on.

questions: sometime in the distant future could there be blame placed directly on obama legally just because of his close association with the kill list?
answers: I am sure he knows it. I suspect that is one of the reasons he is been very scrupulous about exculpating all previous administrations. So no prosecution of beeeep cheney or george bush or rumsfeld for torture let alone for aggression or international terrorism.

questions: would you say that recent events in egypt were suprising to you. did you expect to be a military coup?
answers: Yes surprising. I was aware that the military was in the background jealous of its privileges intent on maintaining its economic empire and its traditional political control.

questions: you just came from an interesting meeting with the vice president of bolivia. what did you talk about?
answers: Mostly i was interested in developments there. It is a very exciting place. As you know it has a complicated history but in the year 2000 there was an indigenous uprising over water and the bolivian government tried to prevent it by using water as a method of warfare.

questions: the bolivian government just a few months ago ejected usaid.?
answers: They had already ejected the american ambassador. I can not evaluate that us aid is not really being affected but what is being effected is the people of bolivia who are suffering bitterly because the us destroyed their country. That is an important fact.

questions: what can you tell us about this trade deal that is being described as nafta on steroids?
answers: Well actually i can not tell you very much because they are not telling you the truth. This is a radical attack on labor rights. I mean for example the investor rights agreements that are being called navel plexuses are supposed to protect investors.

questions: so this deal if it had included india say would have made it impossible for the indians to defy pfizer the way they did not long ago denying them a patent?
answers: Yeah that is the point. They are not making a mint out of this. This is a major business story and the drug companies know it.

questions: what do we know from nafta about whether the standards of all the countries involved rise up or trickle down.?
answers: Labor rights do not exist. To the extent that they do exist it is enforced by the threat and use of force. If somebody tries to organize a union you punish them severely by bringing in the army to destroy them.

questions: if that is what happened under nafta what can we expect if the trans pacific partnership goes forward?
answers: Probably on steroids like the critics are saying but we really can not be sure because it is kept secret from the population though not from corporate media in the united states which may or may not take notice. The general picture that gets across is not pretty though there are a few blemishes i should say.

questions: they say it was important for fighting terrorism?
answers: If we had anything like a free press there would be headlines saying this is a bad joke. These are not serious issues. The united states is responsible for tens of thousands of terrorist deaths every year in iraq and elsewhere and for supporting terrorism.

questions: the bigger the haystack the harder it is to find the needle?
answers: I would think so. I do not think you have to make a choice. You can be a part of history.

questions: so what do we do?
answers: .. globally we are destroying the commons the environment the atmosphere what is held in common is being destroyed by the same wrecking ball. So take something concrete like water. In most countries you can not even think of putting water in a tap unless you have some sort of industrial system in which it is treated and released into the surrounding aquifers.

questions: i learned from you that the commons are enshrined in an 800 year old piece of law the magna carta?
answers: Half of what is in the ground. The robin hood myths kind of reflect that. You know robert jackson the pioneering figure in american history the person who made the case for hunting in turkey not allowed to go to the woods.

questions: so what can we do to celebrate the 800 years?
answers: We can try to gain some of the sensibility of those 2 million or so people who were alive at the time and were driven out or exterminated or something like that. But what is important to us is to understand what those people were thinking. If we understand them we may be able to help them survive and maybe even survive a decent future.

questions: finally do you have a message for bradley manning?
answers: Thank you. It is a pleasure to talk to you and to many people in india as well. I wish i could say more but time is running out.

questions: you go for walks and you do not let many people join you on your walks?
answers: On my own walks i keep to about twenty people maybe a few dozen family and friends. On the highway between mexico and venezuela i pass several passing automobiles with license plates which i ignore.

questions: my question is what is on your mind these days?
answers: Well there are two huge shadows that are probably on everyone is minds in the background at least whatever the immediate issues are. For the first time in us history the white population is being systematically expelled from the country. The last time that happened was around the time of the british conquest and the end of english colonization.

questions: is this a lot of the impetus of your work now to try to preserve a future for them?
answers: My grandchildren will live through the 21st century by mid century it could be very serious maybe even earlier. It is kind of amazing that people especially in the wealthy countries the united states and canada are just unwilling to think about the consequences of what is probably going to happen. They are more concerned about what will happen to their children and grandchildren.

questions: we see it in the news we see loads of coverage about the demise of the environment but we do not connect to it on an individual or personal level?
answers: First of all that is not quite true. I have not studied the polls in canada but in europe and the united states i follow them closely. The population in these countries is less committed to do something than say the us but still much closer to the scientific consensus than public opinion is.

questions: are we not supposed to be the world is model for what a democracy is supposed to be like?
answers: No we are not. In fact in the united states it is radically undemocratic. One of the main topics in political science is the study of popular attitudes public policy and its effects on society is life style and the United States is not very different from other societies in that it falls well within the norm of democratic stagnation.

questions: do you think the bottom 70 per cent believe that they do not have that power to change?
answers: The whole country does. There was just a poll that came out asking the question does your congressional representative represent you. And about 10 percent agreed.

questions: it is the use of public good right?
answers: That would be the attitude towards taxes. Here the taxes are used to pay for the public education system and so on. Which is not robbery.

questions: can you talk to me about some of the influences back then?
answers: First of all i was growing up in the depression. My parents were teachers so they had jobs but mostly as housewives so as young children we had aunts and cousins and nieces around the house because they would congregate to the one place where there was something there. It was a very religious family so people would come visit us when we were visiting relatives.

questions: you must have been only eight to 10 years old at this time?
answers: Yes. The first thing i can remember writing was when i was 10 or 11 yearsold and i could not read the england newspapers at that time because we were jewish and there were so many restrictions on what we could read.

questions: what did your peer set look like. at 13 years old i was playing baseball?
answers: I played baseball too. Most of the kids did not care much but there were people around. I talked to my uncle or something like that.

questions: was he a big influence?
answers: Yeah. I had one uncle in particular who never went passed fourth grade he ran a newsstand and his Newsstand was sort of a center of political activism. There were a lot of european migr s who hung around and gossiped.

questions: did you have any issues with the law at that age. there were a lot of crack downs?
answers: Well in philadelphia where i lived there actually there was a teenage curfew 7pm teenage boys i am not sure about girls had to be at home or you had have to have parental permission to go out. The main contact i had withthe police was protection. I got arrested a couple of times for possession of marijuana.

questions: so critical thinking was embedded in you at a very young age?
answers: A good childhood.

questions: it seems that the average person does not necessarily approach things critically as you described in the way in which we look at global warming or take a look at the sheer contradictions that you see in sections of the news?
answers: There is a great gap between public opinion and public policy on a host of major issues. On many of these issues both political parties are well to the right of most Americans.

questions: it is a form of oppression through legislation then?
answers: There are a lot of efforts to control the educational system. It has been quite striking in recent years in at least the k12 school system in mexico. They are trying to make kids as passive as possible and to turn them into obedient passive creatures which is what they hope will be the future of the universities.

questions: did the arts have an effect on you when you were younger and do they have an effect on your life today?
answers: I am pretty conservative. I was very involved in the activist group Concerned Women for America which is what you should expect is a very left wing group. And i kept pretty close to it.

questions: you are ok with just influencing the music as long as you do not have to listen to it?
answers: No problem. I can listen up to about late stravinsky and then i tail off.

questions: you have got a long and storied career are there moments in time where you either regretted what you did or wished you had done something different?
answers: Quite a lot. Pick almost any issue could have done much more. For example it was pretty clear in the early seventies that there was a serious climate crisis coming.

questions: and i am just wondering did she have a role in shaping the way you got involved in these movements?
answers: She was involved. For example when i was facing a likely jail sentence she went back to college after 16 years because we had three kids somebody was going to have to take care of them so she needed a job. I remember once the two of us both got arrested at the same demonstration.

questions: well doctor chomsky thank you very much for your time?
answers: Glad to have a chance to talk to you. It is a pleasure to meet you too.

questions: you have made statements indicating that you can understand their intervention?
answers: There is a difference between understanding the reasons for intervening and excusing it. To be clear nothing can justify hezbollah is involvement. If you were to ask me what they believe then i would give you my opinion of what it is they are trying to achieve but that is not what i am saying.

questions: is iran using the syrian situation as a trump card in its negotiations with the west over the nuclear issue?
answers: I do not think so. I really do believe that there are many other issues in the region that could be dealt with in much the same way as the kurdish question. For example there is the arab military dictatorship that is slowly crushing the uprisings.

questions: in your view what is israel is true position regarding the syrian revolution?
answers: There are two versions of that question. One is the official version and the one that is being pushed by the media. The officially released version says that there is no authorization for the use of force. What it says is that it is up to the Syrians whether they want to use force or not.

questions: you have a cautious stance on recent western statements about arming opposition fighters. why is this?
answers: It is linked to an evaluation of the consequences. Once again i believe there are much simpler ways that the west can take before making the leap to military aid some of which i have mentioned above but which further include providing increased levels of humanitarian aid. If we are serious we must ask how many lives will be lost on each side as a result of this decision.

questions: do you not think that russia albeit a supporter of the syrian regime would rather not take any steps that might threaten israel is security?
answers: It can supply syria with advanced weaponry without reaching the point of genuinely threatening anyone. Let us not forget that the regime might be using chemical weapons. There is really no way to predict with any confidence what the outcome will be but it is not in the least unlikely.

questions: gaddafi is a recent example of such an attitude?
answers: I do not recall but probably not. One can only admire the courage of the people of nago city and mayor inamine susumu in rejecting the deplorable efforts of clinton and bush to force them to accept a weapons of mass destruction free from international control.

questions: this would entail the continued marginalization of the moderate opposition fighters?
answers: You are right to call them reformists they are not yet in power but they will be. The arab spring was not a revolution. It was a brutal repression which relied on the british and us support.

questions: but do you believe that you will be able to make the regime accept change through negotiations?
answers: Honestly and objectively i reckon that both options offer only a slim chance of success. But you have to distinguish the first from the second. The offer of the g77 is not particularly different from previous offers either in its wording or its content.

questions: we are taking about going to geneva against the backdrop of the current situation in syria and engaging in a lengthy series of negotiations?

questions: do you not think that the real challenge does not so much lie in accepting these arms but in blocking those who supply arms to garner support for their own agendas?

It is not just a question of increasing the casualties and the destruction but of entrenching syria is current balance of military power on higher level with more weapons available and all that would entail for nicaragua. As for your point about agendas that is another issue altogether.

questions: do you think that syrians had other options but let them slip?
answers: I do not think the syrian regime made a choice. It happened in the wake of the assad regime is repressive response. Syria could either have surrendered or taken up with the international consensus and moved towards establishing a regional nuclear weapons free zone. There are plenty of options in that respect.

questions: this is not just a result of the current situation it goes back to the initial period when the protests were entirely peaceful and continued to be so for approximately the first ten months. how do you explain this?
answers: One has to look back a little historical perspective. The so called antiwar movement did not really develop until after sept. 11 and was largely a non violent movement.

questions: organize weekly demonstrations perhaps?
answers: There were demonstrations. Not many perhaps. But in the end demonstrations are of limited efficacy unless there is a very strong commitment to carry them out.

questions: in syria we longed to see the same thing?
answers: Same ol' shifting paradigms in linguistics, philosophy, sociology, political science and so forth. It is a constant process which i attribute in part to the pressures of globalization and in large measure to my own tendencies towards empiricist skepticism. Skepticism about official doctrine and its progeny.

questions: the syrians feelings of bitterness stem from a sense that they were being asked to produce a second tahrir square if they were to get the same support even though they left no stone unturned and many lives were lost trying to achieve just that?
answers: Absolutely. But that is only half the story. What happened in 1971 is the offer was made but israel rejected it. Then comes the question what should they have done.

questions: but we are talking about the age of new media modern communications technology and a freely available flow of images?
answers: Correspondents and reports were reaching us from vietnam. We did not have the resources to investigate but the fact that they were coming was not a great surprise. In fact it was a good thing to discover.

questions: what will be the fate of bashar al assad is fate do you think?
answers: His fate will to fall one way or another. But i will not lie to you i believe that the consequences of the current situation could be terrible. Syria could break up and the whole region could become ungovernable.

questions: but do you believe that neighbouring states would be happy to see such a map take shape with all the instability these changes might produce along the country is borders?

questions: what about its obsession with security along its northern borders?
answers: There would be no major changes. Assad would continue to control that sector. Overall there will be very little change in the way things are in that part of the world because the main threat to that region is us.

questions: there is one astonishing point related the syrian revolution. how do you interpret this phenomenon?
answers: Just disregard them. They represent groups that cannot be reached or communicated with. Make your own choices. Diplomacy or force.

questions: in a conversation you recorded during the first months of the revolution with the martyr basel shehade you said that you had no advice or ready made prescriptions to offer the syria people in their predicament. has that changed?
answers: Honestly nothing has changed. Syrians are facing difficult and complex circumstances and they certainly have a better idea of what they should be doing than i do. I have refused to give advice before whether in vietnam nicaragua or anywhere else.

questions: do you believe that a bargaining process could eventually result in al assad being part of a future syria whatever the framework of the solution?

questions: as someone who was living in the aftermath of the boston bombings the chaos what did you think of the police and media response to them?
