questions: you have said that in the aftermath of 9 11 the taliban said that we will give you bin laden if you present us with evidence which we did not do?
answers: Their proposal was a little vague and they said maybe some of the hijackers got in touch and said you know this is going to blow up but we want you to give us evidence. I never did get anything from them. For a number of reasons for one thing investigations are very difficult.

questions: but why are people so easy to accept conventional wisdom of government narratives there is virtually no questioning?
answers: That is all they hear. In fact the only time i have heard a skeptical question i think it was in florida. A friend of mine who works in marketing science was asked what he thought about the media.

questions: i am sorry you could not make it. we hope you will come to visit us there some day?
answers: Roger that.

questions: how do you respond to this. how do you explain this discrimination in most forums?
answers: I should say that the place where i am most feared and despised is probably in left liberal intellectual circles. If you want to see a graphic indication of this take a look at one of my favorite journal covers which is framed and posted right outside my door step.

questions: it is as if they are afraid of critical voices such as your voice?
answers: Yes i think that is true. There is a fear that a slight deviation might lead to disaster. In fact there has been every bit as much concern about my writings as there was about the activities of the vietnam war up until the invasion.

questions: what would be the difference between a mccain administration and an obama administration?
answers: Suppose the democrats are in the majority. How do they govern. The answer is they do not know how to govern because they have been given virtually no information.

questions: would you foresee any difference between mccain and obama administrations in terms of foreign policy?
answers: It is hard to say. They come from very different backgrounds. The backgrounds are different and the domestic policies are very much like the administrations before them.

questions: could you explain the sympathy that europe has toward obama?
answers: I do not think it has much to do with the somalia case. I doubt that the eurocratic powers would have much of an interest in overthrowing saddam. They are more interested in controlling it.

questions: do you see room for the left in the united states at some point?
answers: I think this country presents an enormous opportunity for organizers. It is one of the greatest material prizes in human history. If we take the matter of elections seriously the task of organizers is to put pressure on government to hold elections and to make sure that the population knows about them and is active in making them aware of what is going on.

questions: what do you think about the idea of establishing a fifth international or some form of organization that could come up with an alternative to the current worldwide system?
answers: I have talked at the meetings of the world social forum which are always in the south and i mentioned that this movement may carry the seeds of a real international and in my view it would be well to follow the lead of south africa and other countries that have recognized the right of people to live in peace within secure and recognized borders.

questions: influence is declining in the world. s. s. establishment are becoming very dominant in europe?
answers: That is a large topic but let is just pick a few elements. If you look over a longer historical sweep there have been waves of progress and then regression. Take say the late 19th century. For the first time in hundreds of years the population was beginning to become independent and independent farmers were moving into the cities.

questions: meanwhile all over the world people admire you read your work find it extremely helpful?
answers: I do not feel marginalized in the united states. When i get home tonight i will spend five hours answering e mail and probably several dozen letters will be letters from admirers who want autographed books or letters of encouragement.

questions: i meant marginalized by the power structures?
answers: That is not accurate. I mean if i was not their enemy i would think something was wrong. If you investigate this here is what you will find. That the united states has for decades been the dominant economic and political power in the world.

questions: it is the best way to indicate you are doing the right thing?
answers: Yes that i am doing what is right. It does not indicate i approve of the action.

questions: what is the subtext the background we are not understanding what are the consequences of the enormous uk investment in burma of earlier us weapons sales of recent israeli weapons sales to the junta and of chevron oil is continued supply of millions and millions of dollars in oil money to the junta?
answers: Exactly what you said. The obvious question is why do we not understand it. Why does the united states continue to supply the dictatorship with crucial military and economic aid which it is using to carry out massive ethnic cleansing and murder. Continues to do so even after the military dictatorship has been overthrown.

questions: do you think there is any chance of a popular uprising being successful in burma or do you think those who rise up will only be slaughtered because there is no advantage for the generals to give up their power?
answers: I do not know enough to be able to answer with any confidence but i suspect that now it would be a slaughter. On the other hand the military leaders are ageing and there may be popular forces developing that can erode their authority from within.

questions: is that part of why thailand is an island of relative easy life compared to neighbours with more severe problems?
answers: Thais are not the poorest country in the region. Their per capita income is about as high as korea is and their wealth comes mostly from the capital city of phuket which is not far from where i am. But there are major problems with the privatised health system and the growing dependence on public funding.

questions: do you think the us president is action on behalf of the suffering and the marginalised in burma in the wake of cyclone nargis would be more justifiable on moral grounds than the invasions of iraq and afghanistan?
answers: Bush likes to posture as a deeply religious christian. Perhaps he has even looked at the gospels. If so he knows that the famous definition of doctrinal lunacy in jesus is a mistranslation of a greek epistle to st. joseph oxymbe.

questions: what do you think china is reaction would be if an internal uprising in burma was successful?
answers: Chinese officials are naturally nervous. There is always a risk of military action. But i doubt that the us would actually use force to prevent democracy from developing in the south. It is much too dangerous an overreaction.

questions: can you offer any insight into the behaviour of the burmese generals their motivations and how things are likely to work out for the people of burma?
answers: The rulers have a good thing going for themselves nothing to gain by yielding power and no major risks in using it violently. So that is what they will probably do until the military erodes from within. Mass non violent protest is predicated on the humanity of those exercising it.

questions: if a regime is so terrible that its generals loot the wealth of the country is resources for their personal gain carry out murders political imprisonment and forced labour is there a moral justification for an armed uprising of the suffering people?
answers: There certainly is in my view with one qualification an unarmed uprising would have to evaluate with care the likely consequences for the people who are suffering. I think it is appropriate for people to rise up but it would not be the right thing to do. As for assassinating leaders the question is very much like asking whether it was appropriate to kill murderers.

questions: would you give any examples of what could happen if the principle of universality were applied in the world today between nations that are in conflict?
answers: One example is that bush cheney blair and a host of others would be facing nuremberg style tribunals. And the observation generalises very broadly.

questions: what are the greatest dangers facing our human species in the world today and what can we most effectively do about them?
answers: There are two dangers that could reach as far as survival of the species nuclear war and environmental disaster. About nuclear weapons we know exactly what to do. In fact it was pretty much understood 40 years ago that if there was a conflict between the us and russia both states would be wiped out in about two minutes by a nuclear attack.

questions: but those are not changes coming from pressure from below?
answers: No the public is the same it is been saying the exact same for decades but the population has shifted. During the neoliberal period there was a general mood of hopelessness and the general burden of proof for any hope of a decent life for the majority could not be laid at the door of the privileged. That has now changed.

questions: what do you make of this well branded phenomenon of hope which is obviously part marketing but is it not also part something else?
answers: Well that is barack obama and his team. I mean it is like the marketing of the moon shot. You know they are trying to prise people out of their comfort zone and make them think something is different. There is nothing wrong with that for a human being to be interested in understanding the world and acting on it in constructive ways.

questions: is it election finance is it third party activism?
answers: It is all kinds of things but what is registering with me is the sense of community that is built into the democratic system. You have people coming in from the outside soliciting donations write letters and so on. To have that in place of the mechanical and authoritarian structure of ordinary american society is a very impressive thing.

questions: what are the chances that a new president will significantly change course on the occupation and might there be any change for the people of iraq as a result of the electoral moment in the us?

questions: or are there significant similarities that can be gleaned from both wars in relation to the united states involvement?
answers: The primary similarities have to do with how the wars are viewed in the u. s.. apart from the margins opinions range from hawkish to dove <

questions: specifically why does the united states trust musharraf over potential rivals such as bhutto and zardari is ppp nawaaz sharif and others in their war on terrorism and hunt for bin laden.?
answers: We need not tarry on musharakraf is sincere intentions to rebuild democracy and help Afghans instead of rattling around in the hope that some mujahideen will show up and tell us what to do about it.

questions: how tenable are both parties claims. s foreign policy in the middle eastern region?

questions: are we going to see a rise in terrorism extremism and anti americanism or will this lead the way for divide and conquer and help american forces and foreign policy pacify the region?

questions: or is this just an isolated incident without profound implications or reflections regarding the intellectual environment of post 9 11?
answers: The behavior of the depaul administration in overturning the faculty recommendation for tenure was of course deplorable but this case should not be generalized too far.

questions: how do you characterize this so called security treaty between washington and baghdad?
answers: The security arrangement was in fact declared last november. There was a declaration from the white house presumably a bush maliki declaration but it does not look likely that the congress will act on it.

questions: i mean previous occupants of that position well they have come and gone. have not they?

questions: professor chomsky that is obviously not going to happen?

I do not think that would be terribly surprising in a country like the us which is run by a highly class conscious business sector funded by the state. So it is not a very surprising assumption.

questions: of course we had seymour hersh in the united states saying that there was going to be an attack on iran obviously?

questions: i am completing an edited volume comparing the south africa situation to that of palestine?
answers: The usual range of articles talks etc. No time for major projects right now but may do so in the near future.

questions: this can give a clear orientation and direction to the many individuals and ngos that have shown for years solidarity with the palestine cause?

questions: this is why there is a need to learn the history of the struggle against apartheid much more than dwell too long on comparing the zionist and apartheid systems?

Tripoli was quite different though it was not so much under military occupation.

questions: if there is a change in america is policy or in its hegemonic role in the politics of the region than a continued israeli inflexibility can encourage the international community to adopt a more critical position against israel and exert pressure on the jewish state to end the occupation and dispossession of palestine?

However it does not follow that criticism of any state or policy is inappropriate.

questions: the military balance of power at present is in israel is presence but this can change at any given moment especially once the us withdrew its support?

questions: internally a major economic crisis and the success of the present coalition of forces working within the civil society to impact such a change?

Labour struggles for higher wages access to resources women is rights environmental protections and many others are just beginning to gain some prominence.

questions: any such outfit should also enable the refugees to return and even the most recent immigrants to remain?

questions: ilan papp yes i am and i do think it has a chance of triggering processes of change on the ground?

questions: their country is a fortress now the united states of security. is this accurate?

questions: i mean is not there something peculiar in this sort of behavior?

Alexa does it all the time tell your friends you have a better idea of what i am doing than i do myself go to the moon walk and so on nobody is stopping you.

questions: when you say the common loyalty to power and profit among elites superseding any care of other human beings is a pathology of social institutions and not individuals are you referring to certain values of american society?
answers: It is not specific to america. These are institutional properties of semi competitive state capitalist societies.

questions: what are the implications of private control of public resources such as education in this instance or health care telecommunications social security etc?
answers: Well there are actually two components to that both of them leading themes of the bush administration is domestic policies and of reactionary policies generally. One is to put it simply to make sure that you have plenty of money in the pockets of your rich friends that is presumably what they want. The other is just to increase the deficit.

questions: is this a direction private power might be moving toward in this country?
answers: There are significant forces driving the country in that direction quite apart from bush style reactionaries seeking to enrich the powerful and letting the rest fend somehow for themselves. Take the reliance for school funding on property taxes. In earlier years when communities were not so sharply separated between rich and poor that may have been more or less acceptable.

questions: and so on. international measures immediate withdrawal both?
answers: The position of the liberal doves during the vietnam war was articulated lucidly by historian and kennedy advisor arthur schlesinger when the war began. He said after careful study of what had happened in south and latin america the conclusion was unmistakable and he warned that the consequences of a war based on lies and deception was very serious indeed.

questions: is there anyone saying the war was fundamentally wrong?
answers: In the case of vietnam years after kennedy is invasion liberal doves began to say that the invasion was a mistake bitterly condemned by liberal intellectuals and so on. But since then virtually nobody has said anything remotely like what i just said. Every sensible person knows that from the beginning.

questions: do situations have to get worse before people or individuals might deem this sort of action necessary?
answers: In the case of vietnam serious resistance began several years after kennedy is invasion of south korea. I was one of a few people trying to organize national tax resistance in early 1965 at a time when north korean troops were engaged in a major war crime of destroying villages and crops. When the united states invaded in December there was virtually no organized resistance.

questions: so what are some of the things you have observed in your own time in the academy as a source of this process in american education?
answers: Educational institutions like universities do not exist in a social vacuum they rely for their existence on the external resources provided by the state. They can not function without substantial state subsidy and in fact if you look at the administrative costs of just about any university it is probably more than the operating costs. So take for example the kinds of courses that are offered to the graduate student.

questions: what are some of the things he is getting at here that we can discuss in terms of alternatives for the future and social organization?
answers: I am often asked questions like that in maybe a dozen e mails a night or in talks and so on and i do not know the general answer to that whether it is a good idea or not. And there are a number of answers.

questions: why does the us support israel?
answers: Well there is a historical record. Up until 1967 us policies had been quite consistent. Actually there was a pretty narrow policy that began in 1956 and went back to the british veto in 1967. larry flynt is book is very revealing in this respect.

questions: would you say then that today israel is primarily a satellite for the us to exert their influence in the middle east?
answers: That is the way it is understood. You could argue that this is a very limited role and that more influence could be achieved by supporting more marginal states which do not have the resources to sustain a major military presence.

questions: so there is a co operation between the us government and us businesses in support of israel?
answers: Which is standard. Us business and the state are very closely linked.

questions: how does the us policy towards palestine relate to its wider policy towards the middle east such as the iraq war and the possible war with iran?
answers: It is a separate issue really. The palestinians have nothing to offer the united states. People have human rights insofar as they provide services to power and profit.

questions: comparisons have been in the past made between the israeli government and the apartheid regime of south africa. do you agree with the comparison?
answers: You can understand it there are differences. In many ways it is worse. So for example the southafrican regime first of all relied on the bantustans for cheap labour and it did something to develop them.

questions: you have written extensively on media coercion and how mainstream media essentially manufactures consent for a government is policies is this a case for the israel palestine conflict and their reporting of it?
answers: It is overwhelming. I do not know where to begin. Let is take the issue of hamas. In my view it was pure propaganda.

questions: the press is owned by big business we know that is there a dialogue between the two or is it just that they do not want to report that?
answers: George orwell had a good comment on it brief and succinct but pretty much to the point. This is in his introduction to animal farm which was not published but was discovered later in unpublished form in a book that just came out.

questions: he recently spoke before a packed audience in massachussetts at an event sponsored by bikes not bombs?
answers: Not very long ago as you all recall it was taken for granted that the iraq war would be the central issue in the 2008 election and probably the defining issue for some time. However it is widely assumed that it will be a deciding factor.

questions: he was speaking before a packed audience in arlington massachusetts?
answers: Last month panama declared a day of mourning to commemorate the us invasion that is under george bush no. 1 that killed thousands of poor panamanians when we invaded and occupied the country. We are not supposed to say a word about that.

questions: ten minutes?
answers: I should hurry up. Yeah ok. alright just start screaming at me if i go on too long. Ok no harm taken so far.

questions: michael rubin from aei in his recent report on iraqi kurdistan surprisingly stated iraq has changed but iraqi kurdistan has not to what extent do you think such claims are rational given the fact that kurdistan is the sole part of iraq that enjoys a degree of safety security and democracy?
answers: I do not know what he means. Surely iran and syria have suffered far worse atrocities and still do. Claims of miraculous progress in some farcical pursuit of the perfect formula are quite natural among self serving ideologists who have no interest in the welfare of society or the prospects for decent human life.

questions: or the kurds can be a force that can jeopardize us interests in iraq and in the region?
answers: As i said there are a lot of uncertainties but i think it is pretty likely that at some point the us will have to make a decision as to whether to support or to disassociate itself from this dangerous alliance. One way or another the threat and use of force will no longer be acceptable.

questions: what are the roles of turkish lobbyists in the us in shaping and influencing us policy towards the kurds?
answers: I do not see how one can speak about moral values without ridicule in this case particularly when the leading us moral authority on the region is openly admitting as much. And it is not just gilbert washington who is doing it.

questions: what is your recommendation and advice for the kurdish leadership in iraq to stay as an effective part of iraq and avoid any us betrayal in the future?
answers: Some advice should be too obvious to articulate for example do not have illusions about foreign powers and their soothing rhetoric. But it is not my place to give advice or to legislate to others. Preferences and interests lie elsewhere.

questions: do not you feel that democratic regimes can at times be authoritarian?
answers: There are very extensive studies of this from all over the world. There is been a generalization about authoritarian behavior for a long time. So if you look at say the u. s. state department reports on human rights it is about as authoritarian as you can get.

questions: what solutions do you propose for pakistan in order for it to become a true democracy rather than a failed state?
answers: By developing political and social arrangements in which the population can actually determine effective policy. That is what democracy is. And the fact that the united states and israel are unwilling to allow that to happen is a very serious problem for the society as a whole because it is the only kind of democracy that can really exist.

questions: how can pakistan form a democratic regime with an islamic flavour when its western allies buck the notion of clash of civilisations which is at odds with everything that belong to the east?
answers: There is nothing in the us constitution to prevent the united states from forming a coalition government with a non muslim majority. If that happens the remainder of the american empire will be administered by what the british in their day in court called an arab facade behind which the u. s. will continue to rule. No democracy is possible under such a regime.

questions: pakistan has shifted in and out of democracy without stabilising in any one position is it possible for pakistan to yield towards the right direction?
answers: It is very possible. For example there is a lively democracy today in india far more so than in the 1970s but it still has a lot of work to do. I visited rural self governing villages in chhattisgarh a couple of months ago and they were very evanescent.

questions: can pakistan ever become a true democracy when it is continually expected to pander to external pressures to act in ways which has a negative impact on the people of the country?
answers: Yes it can. I mean there is a lot wrong with india horrible things inindia but it does rank very high in terms of democracy as measured by the standards of comparable societies. Paksistan could move up that scale but i think it has to disentangle itself from the domination fromthe united states.

questions: can a democracy with an islamic flavour be acceptable to the world especially its western allies?
answers: It does not matter if the democracies are as bad as the dictatorships of the region. What matters is how the western countries perceive what is going on. The perception of reality in the countries involved is not very different from that of their clients.

questions: so my concern is is it possible for pakistan to steer towards the right direction when 65 of its population is illiterate and has no active participation in politics?
answers: Yes it is very possible in fact one of the dramatic and successful achievements of democracy in recent years has been in bolivia. Bolivians have been able to free themselves from the mafias and impose democratic procedures.

questions: what are your thoughts on this and how can governments gain the confidence of people and get their active participation in politics?
answers: Governments do not gain active involvement for the populous by force. That is why there are no mass based political parties or labor based parties. If there were there would be a mass base for any political party or party could gain support. The point of the electoral system is to keep the rabble out of our political system.

questions: will it at some point completely undermine the reach of the world bank and the imf?
answers: I think it is very important especially because contrary to the impression often held here the biggest country brazil is supporting it.

questions: with these institutions springing up in the developing world as alternatives to the imf and the world bank what similar initiatives will emerge in the developing world regarding currencies?
answers: It is already happening. Kuwait has already made a limited move toward a basket of currencies. The united arab emirates and dubai are moving toward their own partial development funds.

questions: do you see all oil and gas rich countries getting together and establishing an alternative market?
answers: They tried with opec which to some extent does it. But they have to face the fact that the west will not allow it to happen. If you go back to 1974 that was the first move toward oil independence by the oil rich nations.

questions: do you think india will swing towards russia and china as it positions itself in its allegiances or will it continue to cozy up with the u. s. post nuclear agreement?
answers: It is going in both directions. There is a lot of pressure from the public in India to get out of the nuclear deal and i think that is justifiable. But there has to be a balance between the need to protect the interests of investors and of power centers.

questions: is the leading democrats policy vis a vis iraq at all different from the bush administration is policy?
answers: It is somewhat different. The situation is very similar to vietnam. There the opposition to the war was so strong that by the end of the invasion everybody was opposed to it except for hawks on the right.

questions: and with a democrat president will that thinking fundamentally change?
answers: It will change. There is a pretty narrow political spectrum and in fact intellectual and moral spectrum. But it is not zero.

questions: what is the importance of the timing of his tour?
answers: First of all remember that in the united states which is a rich powerful state which always wins everything history is an irrelevance. Historical amnesia is required. But among the victims that is not true just for those who suffered violence and terror.

questions: did the national intelligence estimate offer a reprieve any window at all?
answers: I think so. I mean it is premature to draw any firm conclusions but in the few months since the bulletin was issued the intelligence community has been engaged in what is sometimes called rolling the dice.

questions: this logic was not only applied to those things that humans and animals do like finding food and avoiding danger but also to those things that humans do easily and animals do poorly if at all like speaking.?
answers: He is correct dramatically so with regard to radical behaviorists like skinner but pretty much across the board. A curious fact is that they did not seem to realize how remote their doctrines were from serious biology though some of the worst offenders were within the mainstream. One has to wonder at the discipline.

questions: i told him that you would be interested to know about any examples of chimps using language and he gave me a wikipedia article to forward to you on the great ape language?
answers: Thanks. I am well familiar with this work. It is an insult to chimpanzee intelligence to consider this their means of communication no matter how sophisticated or rich or whatever.

questions: what do you think when researchers to this day such as susan rumbaugh claim that bonobo chimps can draw signs and refer to it as language similar to humans ability?
answers: It is all totally meaningless so i do not participate in the debate. Humans can be taught to do a fair imitation of the complex bee communication system. Human language and human thought have a fundamental creative aspect, based on a generative aspect discarding the rules of universal grammar.

questions: there is a recent book out called nim chimpsky chronicling the project in the 1970s where researchers were trying to disprove your theory that language is exclusively a human attribute. it is an interesting read?
answers: Interesting story about poor nima. The experiment was carried out by a very serious experimental psychologist herbert terrace. A convinced skinnerian he expected that if an ape was brought up just like a normal human it would be a little human.

questions: the book nim chimpsky remarks at the fact that apes have been able to sign probably about as well as children first learning the implication being that if we call what children do language then why not have the same standard for apes and call what they do language?
answers: That is about like saying that olympic high jumpers fly better than young birds who have just come out of the egg or than most chickens. These are not serious comparisons. For whatever reason the study of human higher mental faculties is pervaded by a curious form of irrationality foreign to the sciences See chomsky comments in this vein.

questions: there is practically no evidence of that either. s. what really does motivate u. s. policy towards iran?
answers: Professor of linguistics mit well if i can make a comment about the stated reasons the very fact that we are discussing them tells us something very bad about american policy. I mean suppose it was true and we all believed it then we would not be talking about it.

questions: policy on a collision course with the iaea with international law?
answers: A primary concern of the united states since world war ii has been to ensure that western europe will be reconstructed in ways that conform to us interests primarily us economic power. And there are good reasons. A good deal of what goes on in the world is centrally planned.

questions: do you think we are actually moving towards a military confrontation. or are we seeing a game of brinksmanship?
answers: Well whether purposely or not yes there is a background of militarization of space that goes back to the british empire. As far as washington is concerned they like to pretend that they are defending the world from the terrible russians but in fact they have been providing space for aggression for decades and they can do it any time they want.

questions: how have your views changed over that time frame?
answers: I have learned a lot of course. And my views have changed accordingly. Though not in fundamental ways as i see them. Some of the things i believed then and still believe are not held by most people in the united states today.

questions: your essay about hugo chavez does not mention concerns regarding democracy and civil liberties in venezuela. what is you attitude about those?
answers: The important question plainly is why there are so many protests. There can be no reasonable guess as to the answer. Protests are usually counterproductive unless there is a very strong motivation.

questions: what is your opinion of the candidates running in the democratic presidential primary?
answers: Keeping to the viable candidates i am not impressed. Take barack obama for example. In this morning is new york times a front page story reports his foreign policy stance based on an exclusive interview in which he answers tough questions from the audience. First he says he is a private person.

questions: who is their audience the public their victims themselves?
answers: I would not call it a propaganda model. Edward herman and i in our recent book manufacturing consent go into this explicitly. We are not talking about some kind of ideological indoctrination.

questions: are there any tools of logic history or moral guidelines that prove more legitimate than others in this process?
answers: There are some differences. People like juan cole and hans von sponeck are much better informed that beeeep cheney donald rumsfeld or condoleezza rice so the record reveals.

questions: does the american public make this same distinction if not why not?
answers: I have never seen a study but i doubt very much that the public makes the distinction. Assuming not the reason would be clear. Commentary in media and journals rarely reaches the level of serious inquiry.

questions: can you briefly explain what us hegemony means and how it is presented to the us public by our elected officials?
answers: Defiance is one factor sometimes quite explicit. Thus internal documents of the kennedy johnson years identify the threat of castro justifying large scale us terror and economic strangulation as casting off the yanisian yoke.

questions: how is it that reporters commentators and officials are all unable to address this excised history. are they all in collusion?
answers: The process is quite straightforward and has even been studied in scholarship. In my book necessary illusions i review some of the sources the most important being the careful study by mansour farhang and william dorman the us press and iran reviewing in detail how the media suppressed extreme human rights violations under the then president eisenhower. That book alone is a must read.

questions: what would have to happen before such jurisdiction could be enforced and accused individuals brought to justice?
answers: If we accept the elementary moral principle of universality then there is no doubt that us officials should be held accountable for their conscious support for horrendous crimes and even more so for the crimes they commit themselves. We may recall in this connection the eloquent words of justice robert jackson at nuremberg cited in interventions which explicitly address this quesiton.

questions: do you wish they had not or is it irrelevant to you or do you find some value in their efforts to utilize your work when addressing the world?
answers: Bin laden expressed his approval of my opposition to the invasion of iraq. Should we therefore approve of his invasion. I did not say anything about it nor did samuel huntington who was also not a strong supporter of aggression but was nevertheless highly critical of what he called your lack of support for the war.

questions: what are your predictions as to if when and why the us will suffer a similar fate?
answers: There is nothing inevitable in history. Predictions about human affairs hardly have a stellar record of accuracy for very good reasons. Too much depends on will and choice among competing forces.

questions: how can an idea like anarchism become more palatable to the us electorate?
answers: I do not think it is particularly complex. The ideas have strong roots in american history matters that i and others have discussed. I think they are barely below the surface for so called ordinary people.

questions: what is the most reasonable or sane or wise approach to nuclear weapons or any weapons of mass destruction and what are the risks taken by us policy makers in that arena?
answers: Eighty percent of americans believe that the us should live up to its legal obligation under the nonproliferation treaty to undertake good faith efforts to eliminate all WMD along with other nuclear powers that makes very good sense i believe including russia.

questions: and change the face of latin america considering that the bolivarian revolution is having such an influence over other countries in the region?
answers: First of all remember that bolivia was not part of venezuela. Chile was.

questions: do you think it is just an idealist illusion or can it really be manifested?
answers: I suspect that it can. Just look at the history of washington. In the early part of the 20th century the city was quite liberal.

questions: i think it is a combination because the reason that the coup against ch vez was overthrown was because of the people is power?
answers: Now that is an interesting question. Why should we abandon normal canons of democratic behavior when we apply the same standards to leaders of other countries.

questions: it is just been unstructured and very spontaneous so the idea behind this is to somehow structure that and i question from that same anarchist perspective if you structure that power will it?
answers: Take say the 1936 spanish revolution. There was massive popular activism leading to a popular government.

questions: it will be very interesting to see how it develops?
answers: You know i have been asked a lot about this and i do not think i can adequately respond. There are too many dimensions to consider here.

questions: and how it then would change the force of power in the region?
answers: If it can carry out. In this case it is the only thing that can do it. There are other possibilities but these are not on the table unfortunately.

questions: one how do you view his role as the mediator. would they react in a more sort of aggressive way?
answers: I think the us will do what it can to make sure colombia remains more or less a client state. But i do not know how much influence there really is. We will of course do our best to encourage what is happening but it is not certain that it will be successful.

questions: but ch vez doing it?
answers: Well that is going to be interesting. In fact it is rarely discussed here the media are very insular. So right now in beirut the mayor is being subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury investigate whether or not he knew about the berber network which incidentally is a little scandalous but not particularly if you look at the broader context.

questions: right now ch vez is in manaus just yesterday and today?
answers: Yes that is where the story is told.

questions: this has helped us internally to combat media manipulation from corporate media in venezuela but on an international level we have not had much advance fighting the war against the media empire. how can we do that?
answers: Well the history of media reform in the west is interesting. I mentioned that the period of the freest press you could find was the mid 19th century and it was rather like what you were describing.

questions: and that is something that could be replicated in other countries or even in the united states they did not revoke the concession they just did not renew it?
answers: You are talking about the rctv case. Well my own view of that was kind of mixed. I thought it was a little overbroad but it is not like the media which is a very insular profession.

questions: but should corporations have a stronghold on the concessions?
answers: Yeah i know that is the other side. The question is what replaces it. And here i think the answer is clear. Thanks to the dynamic state sector that now dominates us capitalism the public is kept out of the system and the highly concentrated private power that dominates it is in a position of unimaginable strength with virtually no constraints on what it can do.

questions: should the concessions be in the hands of the people to decide?
answers: I think they should yes in fact in a technical sense they are even in some respects. Take say the airwaves again that is public property. Corporations have no right to it it is given to them as a gift by the taxpayer but the taxpayers do not know it.

questions: on that note the theme of the book fair in venezuela this year is united states is a revolution possible. is it?
answers: I think it is just below the surface. I mean there is tremendous discontent. A large majority of people feel that the government does not represent them that it represents special interests. * that is why they are protesting.*

questions: but how could that change come about?
answers: Because the ruling class itself is very reactionary. It is not going to accept very radical proposals because they are at least in principle more democratic than the more authoritarian counterparts. But it does want to limit the scope of democratic participation and it would like to subordinate the public arena to the private sphere in the interests of private power.

questions: do you think the revolution in venezuela serves as an example for people in the united states. that change is possible from the ground up?
answers: It will if two things happen one if it is successful and two if you can break through the media distortion of what is happening. I was in chile a couple of days ago and my impression was that the poorest people there are the people who are most frightened and most depressed they have never known democracy. So maybe this is an indication of things to come if this happens.

questions: would you give a message to the people of venezuela. anything?
answers: Yeah make it succeed. Succeed in overthrowing the illegitimate government of chavez. That is what we have to do.

questions: let is start with the media issue. do you think voters were also saying no to the media?
answers: It is a complex subject but the little in depth research carried out in this field suggests that in fact television news coverage tends to be what is called negative. When it comes to national security things are reversed. So for example when president obama is on television for five minutes straight he is not presented as a person who is trying to do the right thing or a hawk.

questions: so how does thought control work in a democratic society. we know how it works in dictatorships?
answers: It depends on how you measure it. If you ask how well the media are controlling the elections how much the public is being influenced by what they are saying well that is a hard question to answer. On the other hand if there is some sort of indirect method of control it is much more difficult to monitor closely.

questions: in one of your books you quote milton friedman as saying that profit making is the essence of democracy?
answers: Profit and democracy are so contrary that there is no scope for comment. The aim of democratic institutions is to leave people free to decide how they live and to make any political choices concerning them. Making a profit is a disease in our society based on specific organisations and institutions.

questions: in a recent tribute jean ziegler wrote there have been three forms of totalitarian rule stalinism nazism and now tina. do you think they can be compared?
answers: I have always felt that they should be placed in somewhat different categories. Fighting terrorism means confronting a system of intellectual control that cannot be contained by violence. But if we are serious we also have to face up to the fact that the enemy is a very effective propaganda weapon.

questions: what would be the role of the state in a real democracy?
answers: We are living here and now not in some imaginary universe with rights and responsibilities that transcend our comprehension. What makes you think that we have a right to take our country away from people who are trying to work it out for themselves. That is a total misunderstanding.

questions: you mean soviets?
answers: The first things that lenin and trotsky destroyed immediately after the october revolution were the workers councils and factory councils. In these structures which were extremely fragile and could not be taken over by force the working people could come together and form an alliance with other groups to defend their interests. These were destroyed by means of terror.

questions: is not it the case that all forms of autonomous organisation based on anarchist principles have ultimately collapsed?
answers: There are no set anarchist ideals no libertarian creed to which we must all swear allegiance. Anarchism at least as i understand it is a movement that tries to identify organisations exerting authority and domination to ask them to justify their actions and if they are unable to do so as often happens to try to supersede them.

questions: now a few years later what is the status of real democracy in iraq?
answers: The elections of january 2005 were as i said a real triumph of non violent resistance. The us was trying in every possible way to prevent elections and finally had to give in just because it could not face a mass popular non military resistance that was far more effective than the insurgency.

questions: increasingly it seems as though iraqis do not have much space to exercise their democratic rights?
answers: It is not just iran. I mean iranian politics is pretty much like south africa. There is a fair amount of freedom of speech but you are not going to find much in the way of democratic participation.

questions: can you comment on the mainstream media is downplaying of the aspirations of iraqis?
answers: They are available in other sources too. For example iran has a very lively courageous labor movement which has managed to survive the occupation miraculously.

questions: how optimistic are you that mercosur is a viable economic path for latin america and will the united states allow these countries to pursue their own path to shake off the shackles of recent us imperialism?
answers: Well as i said in my view it is very optimistic. I do not think there is really any serious evidence about it. But from what i have seen over the years and from reading the newspapers in spain it looks like a pretty successful initiative.

questions: but people in other countries do. why is that?
answers: We cannot expect the media to try to destroy themselves. They will allow a little bit of dissent and criticism if it serves their interests.

questions: well professor chomsky i want to thank you very much for joining us today?
answers: Glad to be with you once again. It is a real honor.

questions: what else needs to happen to provide a positive tipping point in indo pak relations?
answers: There are a couple of major problems that need to be dealt with. One of them of course is kashmir. The question is can they figure out a joint solution to the kosovo conflict which will at least give some degree of security to both countries.

questions: is it an identity issue or a territorial boundary issue?
answers: Yes obliviously that is a factor in it. The muslim population and the hindu population do separate on those lines. Does that mean they have to be broken up and they should.

questions: should the un step in to do for kashmir what they are now doing for kosovo?
answers: I think they should do both. There is no doubt about that. For example a brazilian peacekeeping force recently deployed in central africa was stopped by ethnic cleansing kurdish attacks and the intervention force was unable to dislodge them.

questions: do you think the pakistan and indian diaspora in the united states or the uk are doing anything to escalate tensions?
answers: For some reason which i do not entirely understand that is a very general fact. In fact every country i know of that has a complicated history. People want to get on with their own problems.

questions: is it because the diaspora often leaves during a traumatic period and that is what fresh in their minds?
answers: I do not think so. It varies. The irish immigration has been coming since the 19th century and it is mostly emigres.

questions: if india is successful in renegotiating that agreement what are the implications for indo pak relations?
answers: I think that is really hard to predict. I mean it is not as if they have a hundred years of history to study. They do not know what the consequences are. For example there is a law in the united states that bars investment in countries that have been involved in serious human rights abuses.

questions: and japan will come to the united states asking for a stealth fighter jet?
answers: They do not know that it is there. You can learn a lot about this from the coverage of the secret bombing of hiroshima and the reaction. No one knows what the u. s. was doing then or does today because we donot want to learn.

questions: s. how is it fostering extremism if it has at all?
answers: I am not sure it does. These are very complex problems internal to pakistan. For example is the united states concerned about baloochi terror inside iran based in kashmir.

questions: actually the last time you and i talked you speculated that united states was in iran fostering ethnic division?
answers: I would assume so. One has to be a little cautious when talking about terrorism because it is never really proved conclusively that the agent is the other. And the burden of proof for using terrorism for political ends is very high i should say.

questions: if extremism is on the rise in south asia which a lot of people say it is how does one go about undermining extremism in this case religious extremism?
answers: In india and pakistan there is a very dangerous development. One of the roots of bjp is an extremely virulent form of right wing extremist Hindu nationalism which sees all non conformists as non dharma worthy of destruction. And the bajrang Dal which is the main Hindu nationalist force has become extremely violent.

questions: could you lay out how the venezuelan society and the daily life of its people has changed since chavez is inauguration in 1999?
answers: There have been some changes. I do not think they are dramatic. There is a sharp increase in the number of people going to the polls daily. A lot more people are able to participate.

questions: congress is no longer calling for binding timelines for troop withdrawal how is this indicative of a broader struggle between the executive and legislative branches?
answers: There are a number of issues. One is the unitary executive conception. The republican party happens to be right now in the hands of an extremely extreme fringe so extreme that they would probably pulverize congress if they were in fact in a position to take over the house of representatives.

questions: right it is minutiae now it is troop numbers timelines etc?
answers: That is right. I was listening to the national public radio tribute to david halberstam the other day and they had on neil sheehan david greenway and others. They were talking correctly about these young reporters in vietnam who with great courage stood up against power and told truth to power no matter how beeeep it was.

questions: do you think pelosi has a right to speak to syria?
answers: Of course she does. If you do not believe in an elective dictatorship everyone has that right even the local congressman even you and i. whether it is a place you live or a matter of right of free expression that should not be compromised.

questions: how much will that foundation shift if when the democrats take over the executive branch in 2008. will it be more open?
answers: I do not think there will be any fundamental changes. The basic fundamentals are shared by the parties. But the bush administration happens to be on the very extreme end of a pretty narrow policy spectrum.

questions: given the corruption charges facing paul wolfowitz at the world bank the scandal surrounding alberto gonzales the justice department is firing of attorneys and the indictment of scooter libby?
answers: The struggle over the unitary executive and citizen is rights is very real. But i do not think it really has anything to do with the separation of powers. It has to with how the executive is chosen and its implementation. Remember the reagan bush administration was very much concerned with what they called the clash of civilizations.

questions: so why is he going down now for a salary?
answers: He is very much disliked in the bank. Apparently they do not like his austerity programs. So he can not get votes in europe.

questions: analysts in the media are questioning whether or not the bank can redeem itself post wolfowitz. can it redeem itself or is it done?
answers: Redeem oneself from what. By that i mean from the policies that it has pursued both domestically and internationally. And these policies have caused extreme harm to a substantial part of the population along with other problems domestically as well as abroad. So let is get into that.

questions: so it is the same problem facing iraq the whole conversation is wrong?
answers: The discussion of the gaza attack is too narrow. Within the narrow framework yes it was a terrorist act killinguters.

questions: that is not being talked about?
answers: Right. Take the imf which is a very important institution. It is the central bank of the rich european countries plus the international monetary fund plus pretty much the world is major reserve currency. No one talks about the i.m.f.

questions: the micro version of that in the united states with sub prime lending is coming back to bite us pretty quickly?
answers: Exactly. And it is getting worse because the conservative government is clamping down even harsher measures.

questions: because i think people are realizing that sub prime lending is not working?
answers: It is bad because vulnerable people were exploited. But at least you can say that it was done. The question is what should be done now.

questions: and if so is there any substance to the notion of a social market economy?
answers: Those are traditional questions in economics. It is part of marx is reasoning about why there is going to be a continuing crisis of capitalism that owners are going be out of control and the workers are not controlling what they want. They do not have control over production but they have a lot more power than they had before.

questions: what is your view from the american perspective on the emerging superpower europe?
answers: There is no particular americanism i mean there are different strains of it. The leading strains are those that are traditionally associated with britain and the united states. Traditionally those have emphasized the sovereignty of the nation over its own resources and those traditional strains have often been combined with concern for human rights and support for progressive social change which is what the euro was all about.

questions: is there any detectable change in the world bank is policy since wolfowitz has taken office and what is the signal the bush administration has sent to the world by appointing this controversial figure to the institution is head?
answers: Unlike most of my friends i was in favor of that appointment. The reason is pretty simple i think he can do much less damage in washington than in his congressional district. He is much better at evading congressional restrictions than other people are and if he gets into trouble he makes it look like a mistake not a crime.

questions: do you believe that it is possible for a coup to bring about democratic change?
answers: In principle the answer is yes almost everything depends on the nature of the society. The people who run countries should be able to determine for themselves how their institutions work and what their interests are. If the institutions are undemocratic the prospects are not good for the masses.

questions: given the brutality of the burmese regime do you think that this is an example of the us taking a positive stance in the region?
answers: We should definitely take a stance because burma is a us ally and the atrocities were going on since the early 1990s. But what really saddens me is that these people have to suffer this way. It is not that they are bad people they just happen to be in a special category.

questions: how does china pose a threat to us interests in asia?
answers: I think that there are very serious problems for us chinese policy planners. They do not have the economic might of the us nor the military power of nearby neighbours. But they are surrounded by hostile powers and there is every reason to believe that a clash between them would be extremely hazardous for all involved. So that makes it a real no fly zone.

questions: does asia have much to worry about from china is rising power and influence?
answers: Anytime a big power is developing everybody has to nervous. Concentrations of power are dangerous. There is plenty of history about that.

questions: could you describe what the energy grid is and how it is important?
answers: There are actually two parallel organisations. One is the asian energy security grid and the other is a related but much weaker but related organization the shanghai cooperation council. Both are pretty much based in china russia is part of the global energy surveillance system run by the world is leading terrorist state britain.

questions: do you believe that the asian energy security grid is a major factor in the conflict with iran?
answers: There are two basic issues with the grid in asia. One is simply that like iraq iranian leaders do not like the idea of having an independent energy system. The second is that there is good reason to fear an attack by the us. So much for the security of the world.

questions: dershorowitz cited the fact that the un has condemned israel more than any other country and argued that israel is far from being the world is worst human rights abuser. how do you respond to that?
answers: Well remember that alan greenspan and the fed were also cheerleaders for the invasion of iraq. If you want to see how extreme their support was you can see it in their historical analysis of what was going on. They were the ones who predicted it would be a model for what to expect when the us invaded iranian soil.

questions: the us also pays a huge political cost for supporting israel so what does the us gain from its special relations with israel?
answers: We know that answer pretty well. In the 1990 is there was a very lively and open debate in amherst College about the proper relationship between american foreign policy and support for palestine. The leading scholars present were yossi beilin and donald rumsfeld along with many others who made the serious effort to put the question to a public debate.

questions: this interview with amina chaudary is part of an ongoing effort at trying to understand the world today in the face of religious based violence political failures and increasing divide along the secular and religious across the globe?
answers: Scholar activist and intellectual has had a profound influence as a political analyst for decades. Supporters and critics alike must agree that his ideas are foundational to any progressive discussion on contemporary politics both within the united states and abroad. He is perhaps best at assessing underlying motivators in global power struggles violence and political change. That is critically important.

questions: would you also address what happens when religion merges with politics and how this is any different than other forms of identity merging with politics such as ethnicity?
answers: Well the major problems of the world are those that appear in the most powerful states almost by definition because whatever affects them affects everyone. So take say crime. In most societies you have to deal with organized crime groups which are state or private tyrannies.

questions: how would you understand this western view of islam and could you also elaborate on this idea of secular nationalism?
answers: The attitude is understandable but it has no historical precedent. The us did not intervene in vietnam to block communism. Internal documents from the early 1950s and later make it clear that the concern was the usual one the mafia doctrine sometimes invoked.

questions: today it appears that secularism is synonymous with anti religion?
answers: I think there is a kind of a dualism that is prevalent in the society. On the one hand you have the people who like to talk about the clash of civilizations and the fall of man the end of history and so on.

questions: do you think the world is becoming more religious?
answers: I do not. In places where secular movements have been devastated either from within by corruption or from without by violence it happens in many different ways.

questions: right but how much do you think that is rooted in their personal profession of religion an increase in religiosity?
answers: It varies. I once went to egypt about 15 years ago and i met with a group of islamic intellectuals. They were talking about the social service networks and groups and so on.

questions: do you think that religious based groups are reacting to this idea of the west or rather a perceived threat to their own identity and say for example their islamic heritage?
answers: First of all i do not think it is a big secret. I mentioned something very good about the united states but there are also plenty of things that are very bad.

questions: it seems to be linked to what is going on in israel?
answers: In this case it is obviously linked with islam. But there is also a strong correlation i think kurdish rights are very much like that of latin american rights and that is a very natural alliance.

questions: how do you contrast the way fear is used in american politics compared with the way it is used in authoritarian muslim regimes?
answers: The comparison is too narrow to be meaningful quite apart from the great differences among the societies. Stimulation of fear to mobilize populations is not a novelty of the post 9 11 world. It has been going on for a long time.

questions: why is there more tension among the three monotheistic faiths than other major religions?
answers: Christianity happens to be the religion of the major imperial powers. By far the greatest power and means of violence in the world happen to reside in what is called the christIAN state.

questions: why is islam seen as the problem coming from the u. s. perspective?
answers: The world is major energy resources happen to be located in muslim areas right around the gulf so that has always been of extreme interest to the united states particularly as it was to britain.

questions: with similar nuclear developments in north korea and iran why has the united states pursued direct diplomacy with north korea but refuses to do so with iran?
answers: That is a separate issue really. The unification of iraq is one issue very serious and i discussed it with friends of mine in the military and intelligence communities. But the most important issue right now is the development of nuclear weapons especially if george bush behaves like a decent human being and does not pursue a policy of increasing the threat of destruction of the non nuclear states.

questions: that is what the united states will gain from attacking iran?
answers: There are several issues in this. One is simply regime survival. Another is just a matter of survival in a very hostile and highly volatile environment.

questions: venezuela has been successfully defiant with chavez making a swing towards socialism. where are they on our list?
answers: They are very high. The united states sponsored and supported a military coup to overthrow the government. In fact that is its last most recent effort in what used to be a conventional resort to such measures.

questions: but why have not we turned our sights more toward venezuela?
answers: Oh they are there. There is a constant stream of abuse and attack by the government and therefore the media who are almost reflexively in favor of supporting the worst violators of fundamental human rights in the hemisphere.

questions: government is decision to potentially go to war with iran. is there a relationship at all?
answers: There definitely is.

questions: government think an attack on iran is feasible given troop availability troop capacity and public sentiment?
answers: As far as i am aware the military in the united states thinks it is crazy. And from whatever leaks we have from intelligence the intelligence community believes that there is not a single iota of evidence that an iranian attack is coming.

questions: do you think iran will be a deciding factor in the elections?
answers: What they are saying so far is not encouraging. I still think despite everything that the us is very unlikely to attack iranian facilities. It could be an embarrassment and they neednt be playing with fire.

questions: the senate democrats can not seem to achieve consensus on this issue?
answers: I think there is a reason for it. The reason is just thinking through the consequences of allowing an independent partially democratic iraq. What would that mean for the palestinians or for us. To tell you the honest truth i do not think it is much of a secret.

questions: is there any connection to this conversation and why we cannot find the political will and momentum to enact legislation that would reduce c02 emissions levels institute a cap and trade system etc?
answers: It is perfectly clear why the united states did not sign the kyoto protocol. Again there is overwhelming popular support for signing in fact it was so strong that a majority of bush voters in 2004 thought that he was in favor of the nuclear agreement.

questions: how do we move forward on climate change without beggaring the south?
answers: Unfortunately the poor countries the southern countries are going to suffer the worst according to most projections and that being so it undermines support in the north for doing much. Look at the ozone story. The northern countries refused to sign the kyoto protocol which required major changes in agricultural practices and now they are being forced to accept it.

questions: so how does the south get its voice heard on the international agenda. is the world social forum a place for it?
answers: First of all it is not just the us it has traditionally been the case even britain the main imperial power the united states has tended to be the voice of the north. But i think that has changed in the last 30 or 40 years particularly with the rise of nato and european integration. You can see it in polls.

questions: with the trend towards vilifying the g77 at the un one wonders where the developing world can effectively voice their concerns?
answers: It is very clear that the goal has been to undermine any possibility of developing a progressive international economic order in the post war period in much the same way that was undertaken during the neoliberal period. The task for the present is to devise means to slow or reverse the process though they must be found.

questions: the repression of progressive or secular ideologies aggravated by the collapse of the soviet union has left the ground open to the only ideo logical channel available for anti western protest islamic fundamentalism?
answers: Christian or jewish or hindu the fundamentalist religious impulse can be turned to serve political agendas. Iraq exhibited the characteristic feature of ultra xenophobia that is becoming all too familiar in the third world where the task is to mobilize populations against perceived threats to their socioeconomic and cultural existence. Secular nationalism is now a virtual religion in most countries even a force in electoral politics.

questions: so according to this view one should not use fundamentalism as a politically derogatory term?
answers: I think religious muslims would make that distinction just as when some jewish fundamentalists were stopped just before they blew up a mosque religious jews dissociated themselves from them. That makes sense. We are talking here about the rise and use of radical islamic fundamentalisms across the spectrum.

questions: the u. s. has the same right while iraq does not?
answers: Excuse me that is not true. The united states has a much stronger case. It is been strongly supporting the regime since the 1990s when it was possible to do so.

questions: bush secretary of state condoleezza rice and the western media insisted?
answers: We can ignore bush and rice who are participants in the u. s. israeli invasion of lebanon.

questions: is there any pretext that could justify the daily massacres in lebanon and gaza?
answers: With a vivid imagination one can conjure up all sorts of pretexts. In the real world there are rarely any.

questions: i could not understand this israeli arrogance. do you?
answers: The maxim of thucydides again. And it is worth bearing in mind again that islam is by a very large measure a religion of violence a violent religion. So if they want to deter people from carrying out crimes their own people are the proper targets.

questions: as an iraqi i understand that the ongoing war against lebanon and gaza is an essential part of the bush scheme toward reshaping the region i mean redrawing the borders drawn by the 1916 sykes picot agreement?
answers: I doubt that most of them have even heard of that. They are more interested in what they can do with the oil. It is a very effective way of keeping people passive obedient and frightened.

questions: how could we explain the role of the un security council in destroying lebanon and gaza now and iraq before?
answers: It is simple. They did not want war. In fact they supported it until the very end. Incidentally virtually the entire world except for israel.

questions: do you think that iran and syria were behind this war as bush said?
answers: It is generally assumed that they at least gave hezbollah authorization for the july 12 attack on the israeli military forces at the border. However many of the most serious intelligence agencies have expressed their conclusion that this was a ruse and that he loyally obeyed the orders of his high command which apparently came from high up in the hebrew chain of command.

questions: is there a negative fallout for this kind of polarization on the hill and its clear support for israel?
answers: First of all notice that this has virtually nothing to do with an opposition to washington. Pelosi does not face any re election problem. Most of them do not.

questions: so why did pelosi do it to look tough on security?
answers: You would have to ask her but it is consistent over a long period. It was true in the 1980s.

questions: and so in the united states how do we counteract then the anti islamic or anti muslim sentiment or the sentiment where most people believe that all muslims are terrorists and that the middle east is a breeding ground for terrorism?
answers: The same way you have to counter the idea that everybody in washington is an communist if they do not follow our orders. That is what activism and organizing and educational programs are about. It is not that people are beeeep or immoral or anything like that but the facts are simply not presented that way. Incidentally there have been studies of this and you can look at them.

questions: what do you think the american response will be to al jazeera and furthermore what is the opportunity for additional media sources print television otherwise to have an impact here in counteracting stereotypes?
answers: It is already happening. There are several print media in the us which are carrying out interesting studies of what the public is saying in public. The new york times has a news section which is pretty good.

questions: do you agree with the argument that israel is military offensive in lebanon is legally and morally justified.?
answers: The invasion itself is a serious breach of international law and major war crimes are being committed as it proceeds. There is no legal justification. The moral justification is supposed to be that capturing soldiers in a cross border raid and killing others is an outrageous crime.there is nothing in international or domestic law that requires such a response.

questions: he joins us on the phone from masachusetts. we welcome you to democracy now?
answers: Hi amy you are great thanks for joining us. It is a real honor to have you with us again.

questions: your thoughts on these analyses that seem to sort of downplay the actual resistance movement going on there and trying to reduce this once again to pointing toward iran?
answers: Well the fact is that we have no information about that and i doubt very much that the people who are writing it have any information. And it is quite striking to see how little attention is given to this fact. If you look at the columnists today most of them are either strongly opposed to the war or very critical of its tactics.

questions: that is why it is attempting to blockade both the sea and bomb the airport?
answers: They are claiming that. Well i repeat we do not have any evidence so i can not comment. But i do know that for a fact the united states has been escalating the threat of military action against syria for some time very seriously escalating it.

questions: that was dan gillerman the israeli ambassador to the united nations. noam chomsky your response?
answers: He was referring to lebanon rather than gaza so there might have been an indirect reference to it. But it is clear that the goal was to prevent a political settlement and to ensure that gazans would continue to be subject to severe attack even after the disengagement.

questions: can you talk about what that distinction is?
answers: If there is a conflict going on aside physical war not in a military conflict go ahead and declare victory and atrocities will stop. There are a lot of precedents for that. For example the united states has been at war for five hundred years without a break and they did declare a war against somebody else when they came in.

questions: petersburg for the g8 meeting. what role does the u. s. have in this?
answers: As in the past. The only difference is that now they are using the troika method.

questions: no. but how significant is the u. s. in this?
answers: I think it will probably be very much like the un resolution that you mentioned which is i am sorry i could not hear what mouin rabbani was saying so i will paraphrase him. The resolution was the veto of a security council resolution.

questions: can you expand on what is omitted in the us propaganda campaign on lebanon and syria after the assassination of former prime minister rafic hariri in february 2005?
answers: The only thing being discussed is that there was an assassination. How come syrians are so beeeep.

questions: professor noam chomsky in your if i am not mistaken first tv media appearance for serbian media thank you very much for being with us?
answers: All right good to be with you. Glad to have a chance to talk to you again.

questions: given this clear documentary record i want to ask you about the elite intellectual opinion what you call?
answers: In the united states. Well there is a kind of a consensus which has been building up for a long time. It is basically held by people like nathan glazer and patrick moynihan and so on.

questions: what does this mean?
answers: First of all that is a common feature of intellectual culture very much like music and art. Literature for example is probably the most famous example. But there are many others.

questions: now this particular humanitarian sharade was?
answers: That is pre kosovo. Right after the bombing there was an Amnesty International report which said that some of the worst atrocities had taken place under krajina. And they pointed out that this was all done with U. s. authorization. So this is not new it is been going on since april.

questions: and it was specific in a sense because it was based on the claim that it was preventing genocide?
answers: Now this is see there are no examples yet. But this has been going on for a long time. The worst atrocities were in the 1990s. From 1993 to 1999 the rate of growth of atrocities per capita was higher than the rest of the world combined and they picked up very sharply after.

questions: in fact it is revisionist to an extreme. what did you mean by that?
answers: First of all let me just fix the timing. The things i have been quoting are from the late nineties or early aeolian years.

questions: before kosovo?
answers: Yeah. Now they needed some event to justify this massive self adulation ok. and this had to do with a very minor event that took place on september 11 1993 a little over a year earlier a bombing in hiroshima prefecture which killed maybe 100 people mainly women and children.

questions: and as it later turned out the kla was also receiving financial and military support?
answers: They were being supported by cia in those months. And there were several other cases like that. In fact at the time we actually published a book on them in which we discussed some of the evidence which was overwhelming.

questions: a fraudulent photograph as it turned out?
answers: You remember. The thin men behind the barb wire so that was auschwitz and we can not have an inquiry into that. They knew perfectly well that the french had captured him and they were shooting at the fleeing population. 72nd and broadway just went off in a blaze of glory.

questions: but after the bombing?
answers: After they dropped the first bomb. That is when the atrocities took place. And yeah it is pretty horrible but you know it was not on purpose. I mean they knew perfectly well that what they were doing was horrendous.

questions: you mentioned the guardian it is interesting because you yourself had recently had an unpleasant experience?
