answers: Over these past few months things have become a bit too hot and heavy for me to handle. I have had to turn to other means. But one constant is that i do not feel able to address this on any significant scale without becoming completely irrelevant.

questions: but let me bring you back to the conduct of the actual war. that was another?
answers: The 1999 bombing.

questions: first of all why were these crimes completely unreported and secondly is there any prospects for there being any responsibility taken for these crimes?
answers: I would say the crimes were reported but they were cheered. It is not that the media were unkind to the victims which is true. I mean if you look at the coverage of nicaragua for example it was quite comical how the press treated the massacre.

questions: al jazeera?
answers: Was invasion of falluja one of the worst blunders in u. s. history. Al qaeda was virtually destroyed. They were trying to reintegrate afghanistan into the world system and it was a complete disaster.

questions: the geneva convention forbids hospitals to be?
answers: It is a grave breach and they should be punished severely for that. Even the barest minimum of sanctions would be appropriate. For example an embargo on goods that have a direct relation to human rights violations and on donations from state or private sources.

questions: which also rejected the case?
answers: The court accepted it and in fact deliberated for a couple of years it may still be but what is interesting is that the u. s. excused itself from paying the pakistan court costs by declaring that it did not have the authority to do so because it was not a signer of the non binding treaty.

questions: the world court though excused itself from hearing the case trying the illegality of the war on the grounds that yugoslavia was not a full member of the united nations at the time when the case was brought to the?
answers: Maybe they have finally reached the point where they can not even pretend to be serious. The whole thing is a farce. There is no doubt that the us is carrying out a massive atrocity which is quite unspeakable and undermines hopes for any kind of negotiated settlement.

questions: they finally did that?
answers: For several years they were deliberating but that is the sequence does any of this get reported. You can ask your friends at princeton ask the faculty. They do not know because they are not in a position to investigate. (inaudible) but one way or another this is going to be investigated somehow.

questions: what struck me was that you compared the srebrenica massacre with the falluja invasion why is that?
answers: Because there are similarities. In both cases the victims were a monolithic entity which was virtually destroyed. The atrocities were directed against a very specific population a taliban dominated population.

questions: like what?
answers: In the case of srebrenica women and children were trucked out and then came you know the massacre. In fact it turned out that the roads out were blocked. I mean you could not get out. A couple of days later came the promised reparations.

questions: unpublished?
answers: Not published. Unpublished came out in his unpublished papers thirty years later. In it what he said is animal farm is a satire of this totalitarian state he described it as a kind of a totalitarian nightmare. And it is true.

questions: does the nato bombing of yugoslavia?
answers: Yes. And that is not even questioned.

questions: slobodan milosevic died last month. what is the significance of his death in your view?
answers: It is of some significance. He was one of the main architects of what we call the nato bombing of serbia which in my view was a very major crime.

questions: in what sense?
answers: Because they did not have to go through out the whole trial. Now they can you can build up an image about how he would have been convicted as another hitler.

questions: had he lived?
answers: But now they do not have to do it. In fact what is going on is even better than it was probably ever.

questions: i just want to bring you back to the bombing of the rts. s. invasions. do you make any connection there?
answers: Well i mean the chronology is correct. But i do not think they need excuses. You know the excuses are there are plenty of them.

questions: was this a sincere evaluation on behalf of nato?
answers: Well i can not look into their minds. They cannot understand the consequences of actions that they are taking. I mean morally it is terrible but there is no way to justify it on grounds of justice or anything like that.

questions: negotiations over kosovo is final status are under way right now the united states is backing agim ceku who was someone involved in ethnic cleansing not only in?
answers: Not someone. He was a war criminal himself. What about the krajina expulsion which he also was. How many people died as a result of those actions.

questions: first of all what do you see as an appropriate realistic solution for the final status of kosovo and how does that differ from what the united states is now promoting?
answers: My feeling has been for a long time that the only realistic option at least for now is some form of federalization. I do not think the us is really going to move to that kind of system any time soon so i am not in favor of it now but i think it would be a better solution in my opinion.

questions: in this first broadcast interview upon publication of his book professor noam chomsky joins us today from boston for the hour. we welcome you to democracy now. noam?
answers: Glad to be with you again. Oh and happy kwanzaa.

questions: it is good to have you with us. failed states what do you mean?
answers: Well over the years there have been a series of concepts developed to justify the use of force in international affairs for a long period. The major concept is the u. s. is inviolability. Every state is entitled to use violence at will. (inaudible) any state that harbor terrorists is at war with the united states.

questions: and also you talk about the dangers of a possible nuclear nuclear weapons being used against the united states. could you expand on that a little bit?
answers: Well there has been a very serious threat of nuclear war. It is not unfortunately it does not exist. But if you look at the literature of strategic analysts and so on they are extremely concerned.

questions: could you talk about that somewhat?
answers: Here we have to be rather cautious distinguishing between language per se and speech which is an amalgam involving both language and a specific sensorimotor system used for externalization of language. The two systems are unrelated in evolutionary history the sensoris are well adapted to low level cognitive tasks and have scarcely been influenced by language if at all suggesting a very different evolutionary trajectory.

questions: professor chomsky in your book you have a fascinating section where you talk about the historical basis of the bush doctrine of preemptive war and also its relationship to empire or to the building of a u. s. empire?
answers: Yeah that is a very interesting case actually. John lewis gaddis is not only the favorite historian who was a major official in the reagan administration but he is regarded as the dean of cold war scholarship the leading figure in american cold warrior studies. His theories have been influential.

questions: your response noam chomsky?
answers: Well i frankly rather doubt that general pace recognized my name or knew what he was referring to but maybe he did. The quote from tim russert if i recall was that this was a book that was highly critical of the iraq war.

questions: your concept of the democracy deficit and why this administration is able to hold on in the united states itself?
answers: Well it is a democracy now deficit but not a democratic deficit. Now if you look at the comparative poll results two thirds of afghans favor the us and the iraqi occupying forces to stay as an occupying force.

questions: could we now begin to hope that the south is awake?
answers: What is happening is something completely new in the history of the hemisphere. Since the spanish conquest the countries of latin america have been pretty much separated from one another and oriented toward the imperial power. There are also very sharp splits between the tiny wealthy elite and the huge misery and misery caused by years of brutalization by the neo liberal programs.

questions: would you see cuba as being a key player in encouraging and perhaps influencing what is coming out of latin america right now?
answers: Fidel castro whatever people may think of him is a hero in latinian society primarily because he stood up to the united states. It is the first time in the history of the hemisphere that anybody sat down and talked to congress and told them what you ought to do.

questions: what gives us more hope about this particular stage of liberation for latin america?
answers: First of all there was hope a little over a year ago in florida but it was crushed by violence. Chile was moving on a path towards some form of democratic socialism but we know what happened.

questions: how is your health?
answers: I am fine as you can see.

questions: is there any recent issue of interest related to korea which you have been following?
answers: There are a lot of issues but one that is constantly in front of our eyes is the development of nuclear weapons. In view of the fact that the us has been the only nuclear powers to have carried out tests of new weapons systems and has refused to sign the non proliferation treaty for twenty years there is always been a danger that a new weapon system might be developed.

questions: hwang is scandal related to his faking of research papers. have you heard about this?
answers: Oh yeah lots and lots of things.

questions: apart from controversies about the existence of the relevant stem cell some people argue that this research which requires cloning embryonic stem cells raises ethical concerns. what is your position on this?
answers: I think it can be done in a way which does not violate human rights. I mean these stem Cells which are being harvested for use are typically taken from embryos which have not yet developed into any kind of functional organism. You are not harming anyone if you use these cells.

questions: if so what kind of punishment do they receive. are they sent to prison?
answers: Well falsifying research is not a criminal offense. It is wrong. Take for example tobacco companies who did suppress information for a long time on the lethal effect of what they were producing but who after all are major corporations.

questions: in relation to this what prospect do you see for the human race in the future?
answers: Human beings are facing now some of the greatest threats in human history. There has been nothing like this. I mean there have been two major crises which literally threaten survival.

questions: the iraqi war is not finished yet. how can it be wound up?
answers: What is the solution to the problem of the kurds. I mean they are a nonviable entity. They can not be settled.

questions: in the name of reconstructing iraq several countries dispatched troops to iraq. how do you view this?
answers: Well the invasion of ira was a very explicit explicit war aim. The national security strategy of the bush administration in fact came out in bush is first month in office and it said that the purpose of intervention is to deter iran from developing nuclear weapons and to enable us to dominate the world by force a dimension in which we rule with an iron fist.

questions: and also russia too?
answers: Well it is interesting. I mean did you ever hear of the russians or the chinese people.

questions: terrorist acts are occurring repeatedly all over the world. how can we fundamentally reduce terror?
answers: There is no simple answer to that question. We can reduce the threat of attack against us by establishing friendly relations with the governments that are providing financing and training of terrorist forces and by cooperating with law enforcement to apprehend those who are planning and carrying out terrorist attacks. Cooperation is also necessary to disrupt terrorist financing operations and other forms of support for violent extremists.

questions: what do you think of the north korean leader jong il kim?
answers: Northern korea is one step closer to having a nuclear weapons free zone. If the united states abandons the non proliferation treaty it will be as meaningless as the nunn lugar provision.

questions: what opinion do you have about the issues related to the human rights of the north korean people. do you have any solution?
answers: The solution is step by step reconciliation. It is not going to solve the problem tomorrow. But in the longer term it can make a difference.

questions: how do you think we should solve the north korean nuclear weapons problem?
answers: There is a way to do it. In fact it came pretty close to working.

questions: britain too?
answers: Israelis reflexively have to do what the u. s. tells them and in fact the more honest people say so. There is a constant drumbeat of articles condemning iran for its support of terror and apartheid. Nobody takes them seriously.

questions: alliance on the one hand and south korea is reconciliation endeavors with north korea on the other hand be resolved?
answers: To what extent should unification be based on reunification of the two Koreas. Well i think that unification should take into account the needs and interests of northern and central asia. It should not be a one party state.

questions: what do you think of the fall of socialism after the collapse of the soviet union?
answers: First of all there was never any socialism. In fact i do not think there ever was any such thing. The united states was sort of a model society socialist state.

questions: you have criticized neo liberalism before. what alternative ideas do you have?
answers: With regard to neo liberal policies they are simply particular policy choices nothing special about them. They have been very harmful. South korea did grow and develop because it ignored the principles and the prescriptions of the neoliberal regime.

questions: have you ever tried to put the ideas of libertarian socialism and anarcho syndicalism into action like actually building such a community or a society apart from a series of talks and writings?
answers: These are ideas that i have frankly been kicking around for a long time but have never really made any significant efforts to implement them. As far as libertarian socialist ideas are concerned there is not much that you can do except try to think of the society that one would like to see and organize it in such ways that it conforms to the needs and wants of that society.

questions: will change in the era of northeast asia. what do you think of the sudden rise of china?
answers: If you look over a longer stretch of history if we go back say to the 17th and 18th century the commercial and industrial centers of western and northern europe were chinas and japan. They were the most advanced. Not as far ahead as you might think.

questions: who dominates or controls the world and by what?
answers: The u. s. is for the moment dominating the global system by force a system in which the major energy resources of the globe are held in what the british in their day in the sun called an arab facade behind which lies a uyghur facade.

questions: you have presented the propaganda model by which big transnational corporations and the media try to control the power of a nation. please illustrate it?
answers: What happened over the past century is that in the west there were plenty of struggles for freedom and a lot of them achieved quite dramatic and far reaching changes. That was true of the early 20th century in england for example and it is true today of latin america and other places where there is a strong working class tradition.

questions: speaking of the truth you have pointed out that intellectuals have a special responsibility to speak the truth. what is the truth?
answers: If it is a physicist he has to be honest about what he knows. There is no such thing as an honest intellectual. Those who are called intellectuals are mostly professionals who have made a career of lying and cheating the public. Less honest intellectuals should be ashamed of themselves.

questions: in this context the role of ngos seems to be becoming more important. how would you view the influence of ngos?
answers: First of all i do not really think it is that complicated. I mean yes there are complications. Like for example when i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what is being discussed is a discussion of sports.

questions: what will be the mainstream of generative linguistics?
answers: One of the least successful of human endeavors is predicting the future of science. What is gonna happen nobody can tell. Somebody might come up with a totally new idea goes off in a new direction.

questions: but you as the originator of transformational grammar?
answers: These are all collective efforts. In science nobody owns any theory. I mean it is collective activities. So for example if we had a theory of gravity we could not just hand it over to somebody and say okay that is the theory ought to be used for this demonstration.

questions: there is an observation that 3 pole system of the us china and the middle east will be established in the first half of the 21st century. what do you think of this?
answers: For about 35 years the international economy has become what is called tripolar with three major industrial financial commercial centers roughly on a par north america europe and northeast asia. Since then south korea has been a major economy but it is been growing at a crawl and chinese economic power has grown even more rapidly.

questions: do you perceive the u. n. functions properly?
answers: There are plenty of internal problems at the un but they pale into insignificance in comparison with the major problem the great powers place sharp restrictions on what the united nations can do. A good measure of the scale of their interference is the record of vetoes. Few other powers can impose such a virtual senate of criminals on the world at large.

questions: do you have any specific reasons why you are against it?
answers: I know of no one who is against globalization which means simply international integration. This has always been and remains a value in international relations theory. Anything that interferes with free movement of people or resources is not a good thing unless it is a gift from the powerful.

questions: if a few monopolistic enterprises like microsoft are allowed to dominate the basic means of communication what kind of social and cultural consequences will ensue?
answers: It is already happening. Korea is one of the most highly concentrated concentration controlled societies in the world. Just look at concentration of corporate power.

questions: can the internet be a medium against existing mainstream press media?
answers: It is not just the mainstream media incidentally. It includes the new york times the wall street journal england and others. So there is a lot of interchange and communication. Less than 1 per cent of the population has access to the media.

questions: after all the internet has advanced globalization ahead has not it?
answers: Certainly. And it is worth remembering that like most of the advanced economy the united states is a high tech economy largely based on the dynamic state sector of advanced industry. Major corporations do not create technology. Technology is in the hands of private enterprise.

questions: are there any internet sites that you frequent?
answers: Personally i use the internet almost exclusively for research purposes and rarely access any sites.

questions: you are also recognized as having insight of interpreting and changing the world. what is your vision of the world?
answers: First of all i do not take this beeeep seriously. And i never have. But i think we can go back to what i said before.

questions: where do you see iraq heading right now?
answers: Well it is extremely difficult to talk about this because of a very rigid doctrine that prevails in the united states and britain which prevents us from looking at the situation realistically. The doctrine is that we have to believe the occupying forces would have left if they had not been attacked.

questions: is george bush in political trouble. and if so why?
answers: He is in very bad shape. Just take a look at his fiscal policies which are pretty radical. He proposed cutting back social spending virtually across the board while increasing taxes.

questions: how could the democrats distinguish themselves at this point given that they have already played into that trap?
answers: They know perfectly well that it is a trap and they are playing into it. The 2008 political campaign was really a referendum on whether or not you should take these positions.

questions: given the lack of substantive differences in the foreign policies of the two parties?
answers: What differences there may be are of course tactical in nature. Clinton wants to dominate the world by force a traditional imperial goal. Trump says we can not go that far. I think that is very dangerous and the sooner the better it is for the people of syria and all who depend on them and for all mankind.

questions: but i am setting this up for a foreign policy question. are we being set up for a permanent state of war?
answers: I do not think so. I think we are looking at a very unusual stage in world affairs. For 500 years there have been wars among the great powers mostly wars of extermination which are turning into wars by other means.

questions: in the war on terror however how does one define victory against a tactic. you can not ever get there?
answers: There are metrics. For example you could measure the number of terrorist attacks. Well that is gone up sharply under the bush administration very sharply after the iraq war and it is largely due to the measures taken to try to prevent further attacks and punish those who have already carried out many terrorist acts.

questions: by people who knew what they were doing?
answers: Yeah people familiar with the area. It meant that they could do it. They would not have had to go through what we went through because they knew exactly what to do. No one was going to look over their shoulder.

questions: you have been tracking u. s. s. foreign policy. and if so how would it come about?
answers: Well there are significant changes. Compare for example the war in iraq with 40 years ago the invasion of vietnam. There is quite significant change and it is largely a result of the collapse of american imperialism.

questions: how will the u. s. deal with china as a superpower?
answers: What is the problem with north korea.

questions: well competing for resources for example?
answers: If you believe in markets the way we are supposed to compete for resource use. So what is the problem. It is not that there is no market. There certainly is.

questions: what is your biggest regret over 40 years of political activism. what would you have done differently?
answers: I would probably do it again. Because the problems are so serious and overwhelming that it is worth doing it in spite of the regret.

questions: what gives you hope?
answers: Things like what you described also the wonderful things in the world of the kind that i mentioned like my wonderful wife. And i just got back from brazil where we have been for about a year and a half and she is just a wonderful person. You just can not find a more perfect example of what i mean.

questions: what sort of organizing should be done to try and change some of these policies?
answers: Well there is a basis for democratic change. Take what happened in bolivia a couple of days ago. How did a leftist indigenous leader get elected. From what i could see from the outside it looked like a done deal.

questions: professor chomsky how do you see the elections. do you see them as an important milestone for iraq?
answers: Actually i do but before talking about that i should just bring up a kind of a truism. No rational person pays the slightest attention to declarations of benign intent on the part of leaders no matter who they are. And the reason is they have nothing to gain by doing so if the consequences are perceived as unacceptable they will simply terminate the effort.

questions: this was weapons of mass destruction you are talking about?
answers: Yes. Then very quickly it turned out that that was not the reason of the invasion of iraq but it was a pretext and they used it to get rid of a brutal regime which was supported by the united states.

questions: we have seen an awful lot of iraqis taking part in the elections two thirds we are told. the turnout was quite high?
answers: But hold on a second the us and britain announced at once at the same time we will not have a timetable to withdraw. So yes you can all want us to leave but once we leave there is no timetable for withdrawal. Now of course there are all sorts of pretexts for why we should stay.

questions: so you see this is a step to set up a sort of puppet government and not something that is really representative of ordinary iraqis?
answers: They are being asked to choose between two masters. The first is the us which is trying to prevent democracy and independence by any means necessary and the second is al assad who is much more dangerous because he can get away with it. There are plenty of other examples.

questions: i spoke to some people from the iraqi community here in the netherlands just a few weeks ago and they were expressing very similar sentiments that they felt they were in some way having their destiny in their own hands for the first time?
answers: That is exactly what i have been saying all along. The victory of the non violent resistance in iran which compelled the occupying forces to allow elections that was a major victory. They did not allow them to hold elections at all during the war.

questions: in that sense you see that there is a positive influence from these elections and you see that those forces can grow out of these elections and take more control in iraq?
answers: I certainly hope so but they are going to have to be fighting britain and the us tooth and nail all the way. The question is what westerners will do about it. Will we be on the side of the occupying forces which are trying to prevent democracy and sovereignty taking place or will our side with our veto.

questions: you know the americans have to now see the job out as it were. what is your reaction to that?
answers: Two points. First of all the war aim in afghanistan was not to overthrow the taliban. That was a pretext and the same was true of vietnam. So you can understand why they did not want the insurgency to develop.

questions: what do you think would happen?
answers: In other words suppose that the parliament instead of being an elite force dominating the population suppose it were more like a popular organization that is maybe influenced by popular pressure suppose there were popular meetings say in the slums of catalonia every couple of months to discuss problems local problems and try to find common ground. That would be a kind of parliamentary system.

questions: and you say that this may be part of an attraction for the shi ite groups in iraq as well to sort of join this movement away from the western world influence as it were?
answers: Yes they have every reason to. In fact it might even happen in saudi arabia. From an intellectual point of view there is no greater threat to western civilization than the spread of radical Islam which is incompatible with the rule of law and with civilized relations among nations.

questions: and that is why you say they will not be prepared to leave?
answers: They do not know if they can leave or not because they are trapped. If there is a humanitarian catastrophe there will be others coming. I mean tens of thousands of people are dying every day in iraq as i speak. Still the united states insists on blocking a political settlement which is supported by the majority of the american population and is blocked by britain.

questions: what is your take on that?
answers: The violence in iraq is a serious problem for the iranians unfortunately. I tend to agree with radical rags like the wall street journal on this. The journal has for example pointed out that the us invasion of ira in 1980 was probably the most harmful military action taken in the post world war ii era.

questions: what advice would you give to him.?
answers: Look i have plenty of correspondence with soldiers in iraq and all you can do is offer them your sympathy. You hope that they make it safely and that their leaders will get them out of there.

questions: is not that still the main reason the us invaded iraq and are iraq is large reserves now under control of us corporations.?
answers: It was not then and neither is it now. The 1980s were a period of very high growth rates no financial crises because of new deal regulations that were still in place and relatively egalitarian growth so every quintile grew roughly at the same level.

questions: plenty of the protestors said it was a war for oil all along?
answers: Protesters did but take a look at the mainstream. It did not matter too much which side was on the other side you knew they were fighting each other. However if you take an in depth look what was actually going on you will see that the protests were dismissed as conspiracy theories marxist delusional and that sort of thing.

questions: in your opinion what is the us is next likely international move.?
answers: My own guess frankly was that the invasion of iraq would be over in about three days and that saudi arabia would probably be out of the picture pretty soon. But that is all we know.

questions: this is an area you think that will be an area of concern for the us?
answers: It is of deep concern. Right now china is economic development is in some ways a model for what can be achieved by developing a high tech economy in a low cost area with liberal social policies. That is what is called successful integration.

questions: blaming imperialism and the free market for making us poorer.?
answers: The us is by far the richest most powerful country in the world especially after the second world war. It is incomparable in terms of technological development and so on thanks in large part to the state sector. Great britain came close but was beaten to it by the united states which has a huge economy and security.

questions: professor chomsky what do you make of the mccain bill being accepted?
answers: That is basically a condorcet moment. You can not condoleezza rice say anything bad about the united states. What she just said is unimaginable in the us system of intellectual self censorship. I mean it is beyond comprehension how weak and frightened hussein actually is.

questions: are they saying that really or are they saying we want a safeguard against it happening in the future.?
answers: Yes that meant it happened in fact they are conceding it. Of course they do not have to concede it there is overwhelming documentary and historical evidence for that. Just read american legal journals full of discussion on this.

questions: what about that second question and europe not being more forthright in that listener is viewpoint?
answers: When you talk about a country you have to differentiate. Do you mean the elite sectors the political class. For example in the united states if you look at the top few percent of the income distribution say the 1 percent or maybe even the 0.1 percent you will find quite a lot of outspoken dissenters.

questions: i guess he does he is talking about the european union i guess?
answers: The us did call for a two state solution before the elections but that was shot down by george bush. I do not know if bush is still alive or not but it was pretty obvious that they were not going to get anywhere. Now they are back to square one.

questions: that is an accusation that is levelled against you that you are unpatriotic and that you have a hatred of the us what do you say to that?
answers: Well since it is just a tantrum there is nothing i can say. If people want to have tantrums like that fine. Let them do it. I will not tolerate that behaviour either.

questions: what is your reaction to that?
answers: Well that is interesting. I mean i was not involved in the polls or the writing of the leaflets and so i can not comment on it but i did not know it was being done. But there has been a curious phenomenon in britain. Japan is not being asked to join.

questions: or is mass murder by leftwing extremists still acceptable.?
answers: I would ask the listener whether he harbours any guilt for having supported hitler and the holocaust and insisting the jews be sent to extermination camps. It has the same answer. Since it never happened i obviously can not have any responsibility.

questions: or does america give up spreading the gospel of democratic institutions.?
answers: Us policy in these countries has always been and remains to deter democracy. There are a lot of popular democratic forces all over the middle east they have been there for a long time and they are not just starting now. We should stop preventing them.

questions: so my question to mr chomsky is what effect do intellectuals or great minds have in the politics of today and has he ever been able to influence any major decision of the political leaders in the past few decades?
answers: First of all we should have no illusions. History is written by intellectuals almost by definition. So if you look at history intellectuals look pretty good.

questions: professor chomsky as ever a pleasure talking to you. thank you very much for joining us?
answers: Good to be with you again.

questions: hi professor chomsky?
answers: Mr. hermann did not say that. That is false.

questions: this is irene from no one is listening but in honor of your appearance on the show today we are entitling it noam is listening?
answers: Oh well that is nice to have a chance to talk to you.

questions: so our show today is about video news releases?
answers: That is right. I monitor the print media see what is happening.

questions: i imagine you do not have time to watch much tv since you have written 90 books but i think the reason you would be so good for this show is because you could give a historical analysis of the print media?
answers: Well there was a period in the mid 19th century that is the period that you are talking about. Actually this is before the dynamic media came along and wiped out any kind of independent press. This was during the freest period of history.

questions: well then what would be the alternative. that is where i am searching?
answers: There is an alternative but it has to be faced. First of all there are two kinds of alternatives one is the international consensus and the other is unilateralism. What do you do about it.

questions: there are actually pr agencies that do not try to be covert about it. they will be called vnr pr agency?
answers: It is very open. Take say television. In the industry when they have an hour of program whatever it may be a comedy a cop show or whatever you want to call it a childrens show a political program and they want something for the kids to latch onto.

questions: hopefully we can change that and people can start questioning?
answers: There is really two separate questions about the media which are usually muddled. One is what they are trying to do and the second one you are raising. The first question is a little bit technical but it is the same question that arises all the time when you interview journalists. Are they telling the truth when they say that they support the government.

questions: so what can we do because now because i am depressed?
answers: Well look i think it is a very optimistic future frankly. Just think about two years from now maybe three maybe four decades from today if current tendencies persist things are going to get really beeeep. There is two choices you can get out of this or you get into it.

questions: right to go fishing?
answers: That is like a toothpaste ad and i think a lot of people know it. Given the facts about public opinion it means what is needed is something not very radical.

questions: but do not you think to some extent maybe people do not even realize their own discontent because of the media?
answers: No i think people are very discontented and their attitudes towards the mainstream media are extremely cynical and skeptical even about the existence of organized religion. And i suspect that if you stopped and looked at the polls about how people really feel about organised religion you would probably come to the same conclusion. The religious in my view are just not part of life.

questions: they do not know where to get angry or who to band with?
answers: That is true. But that comes back to my original point. Why should we abandon normal canons of rationality when we turn to the study of anger and resentment. It is certainly true that in our normal relations with others we tend to take for granted their valid points of view even if theirs are diametrically opposed.

questions: i mean i have interviewed some journalists on this show and?
answers: Look they have just internalized the values. They will tell you and they are correct that nobody is ordering them to do anything. That is right. And these are the people who created the public relations industry which is a huge industry today.

questions: i feel like one of the things with academic readings is that you can trace the source?
answers: Well for example you could trace what i just told you about popular attitudes about the budget. But the point of that is is to try to understand what is going on in the heads of people who are supposed to be studying these topics. And i think you find that very often it is pretty systematic. Less than 10 percent of your readings will make it into the published literature.

questions: i think that is one of the problems with the media?
answers: Well i mean i do not really think it is the issue for example i happen to agree with much of what you have said but i can not follow it with my own two eyes.

questions: i think it is because what makes it through the filter is the only thing people see so they latch onto that and do not even know to question other things?
answers: There are a lot of books out there trying to teach you how to be a better activist. There is no one way to do it. You have to approach it as an individual with your own concerns what you think is important do something about it what kind of organization do we need. As a society we are very fragmented.

questions: right. ya i do not know?
answers: Ask. There can not be because these are structures that are specific to humans. And structurally human languages are very different from one another and therefore cannot be part of the human genotype. Okay.

questions: but there are ways that is what is so exciting about the internet?
answers: There is a tremendous amount of exciting work going on all over the place. And it is this tendency that i think is exciting. I mean take say the field of artificial intelligence which is just exploding.

questions: what seems to be systematically omitted here is any real responsibility placed on the bush administration for its failure to make humanitarian reconstruction a high priority?
answers: The excuses also overlook the fact that the insurgency was created by the brutality of the invasion and occupation which is in fact one of world history worst terrorist crimes. The nazis had less trouble in occupied europe and the russians held their satellites for decades with far less concern for human rights.

questions: is there any legitimacy to the argument that the u. s. should prevent civil war?
answers: Aggressors have no rights only responsibility. One is to provide massive reparations. Another is peaceful means if possible to withdraw. Once again the burden of proof for resort to violence rests with the aggressor whether in self defense or in a just cause.

questions: really have any credibility there after nearly 15 years of murderous sanctions?
answers: In western propaganda the murderous embargo was called un embargo no embargo which is technically accurate but a cowardly evasion. In reality it was an act of war and the united states was condemned for that very explicit in international law.

questions: after this near half century of participation in the libertarian movement how have things changed?
answers: Change is never linear. It goes forward in some respects backwards in others. Just to take the positive side there has been a very substantial increase in cultural acceptance of ideas which is a good thing.

questions: most of them were demanding an immediate withdrawal of foreign troops from iraq. i would like to hear your thoughts?
answers: Whatever you thought about saddam hussein it was a secular government. Now it is very likely that there will be a large theocracy. What is more it may well be that the theocratic system will reflect the will of the population rather than the whims of a small coterie of jewsled tyrants.

questions: i recently read a speech by venezuelan president hugo chavez. what do you think about the bolivarian revolution?
answers: Again the interesting question is what the people of venezolan are thinking. The polls taken by latinobarometro the chilean polling organization have been giving fairly consistent results about what people want.

questions: how do you explain the emergence of the global justice movement against neoliberalism?
answers: I have never said that it prevents social change. In fact i never even used the term globalisation. Globalization is a term of propaganda that was invented to disguise the fact that the system is internationalized and not nationalized.

questions: so is there any validity to the claim by some that campuses have become bastions of leftist groupthink brainwashing?
answers: Campuses are centers of intellectual self censorship. I do not know how widespread this is but it seems to me that it is a very real phenomenon. For example when i was at mit it was quite normal for around twenty people to show up for an hour or so each week. They would talk about some topic that was in the news or something.

questions: bastions of leftwing groupthink brainwashing?
answers: I suppose you can find maybe 2 of people on campus of whom that might be true. But it is very hard to generalize. People are very different from one another. A lot of them are just deeply impressionable.

questions: he defends speech codes by citing the example of puting up a nazi poster in your bedroom?
answers: My freedom of speech does not extend that far. And there is something analogous that happens in a college a lot of things are banned because of the viewpoint that you hold.

questions: notice how he slipped in that word home?
answers: It is their home now. The college environment is what it was before. Students are expected to be close to home.

questions: what do you think of erica halverson?
answers: Do not know who it is. Penn your loss noam chomsky. Wish i could say hi too.

questions: what importance if any do nato and osce have for the united states. is it correct to think so?
answers: American policymakers are very much concerned with it. Their hope is there is an old joke about beeeep germany that goes back 50 years and says it was designed to keep the russians out the americans in and the germans down so the u. s. elites could concentrate on domestic concerns.

questions: can this in turn result in an increase of their political power and influence?
answers: China is expected to become the second largest recipient of us aid according to recent us government statistics. If current tendencies persist the us may well control the world is major energy reserves by the mid century. No small matter in a country with such an enormous energy resource.

questions: the current slovenian government is endeavoring to implement the neoliberal economic model of the american type while milton friedman its main theoretical proponent has recently renounced some of his tenets?
answers: Neoliberalism has two aspects one of them is discussed the other is not much discussed. The one that is mentioned is the effect on economic development. And in that respect the evidence is fairly clear the countries that have adopted these doctrines have suffered the societies that ignored them have succeeded. So what you have is a doctrinal assault on the public mind.

questions: what consequences can this have in your opinion?
answers: And if that is privatized it is put in the hands of tyrannical totalitarian institutions which is what corporations are which are more or less unaccountable to the public. And it becomes more and more of an instrument of power which in my opinion is a very bad thing.

questions: wolfowitz and negroponte have been involved in the iraq situation bolton is a defender of unilateralism gonzales has provided the legal grounds for abu ghraib?
answers: For these people i do not think that the term neoconservative is very it is the one that is in use but there are others. First of all they are not conservatives at all. For example i am not a fan of radical statists.

questions: what current crises you believe are a result of such policy?
answers: Actually there are crises all over. There is a crisis with russia and china. People do not talk about it much but if you look at the strategic analysts strategic literature they are very concerned.

questions: does iran present a real threat in this respect?
answers: Well they are trying to get iranian oil they do not have to. I mean if they wanted to they could just boycott iraq and they would be supported by the arab countries which are the main energy producing countries in the region.

questions: due to such revisionist debates slovenia has recently been having problems for example with italy. how do you explain these phenomena?
answers: It is a dangerous phenomenon. When you introduce a concept like trotskyism in the post world war ii era it has a very dangerous precedent. It presupposes that there was once a time when trotky was around and kosovo was part of russia.

questions: how do you filter information. what do you read after the death of edward said?
answers: What was really interesting was the way the obama people treated the notice of his death. Did they put it on the front page or bury it. I mean it was not in the midst of the bush is speech about how magnificent we are.

questions: any names?
answers: First of all it is a little misleading to ask who comes up with it. The fact is that most of this has been going on for a long time. There was a brief period in the 1970s when things were moving in this direction.

questions: how do you select what books to read?
answers: What i am interested in. I mean it is not left i read all sorts of things. Depends on what interest you are pursuing.

questions: the historian howard zinn believes you are one of the greatest american historians however neither the journal of american history nor reviews of american history nor the american historical review has reviewed any of your books even though they included the work of such non historians as michel foucault and john updike?
answers: Micheloucault is inoffensive i mean he talks complicated things that nobody understands and so on. But these people who call themselves historians are just fooling themselves. I have explained in detail how it is the same with regard to you.

questions: so how have you managed to persevere throughout all these years. you do not seem to have lost either of these?
answers: It is not an issue. I mean in more or less free countries like say the united states or england the worst that can happen is that you get criticized or denounced or something. It makes no difference because you are protected by the power system.

questions: a lot of eminent scholars are fond of using the phrase anti globalization movement. what do you think of that label?
answers: As i have said repeatedly including at the world social forum it is just plain propaganda. I mean globalization used in a neutral sense just means international integration. There are many dimensions to globalization including the one we are talking about.

questions: on that note let me turn briefly to iraq if you do not mind?
answers: No problem.

questions: the by now famous lancet report counted about 100 000 excess deaths in iraq as a result of the anglo american invasion. what do the elections mean for iraq?
answers: I do not think there is any serious study of this but to the extent there was it was that the election of charlie mccarthy as the new york republican candidate was a godsend for the insurgency. Not a huge amount of difference but a pretty substantial difference.

questions: and a us ally?
answers: Yeah but that is inside saudi arabia and that happens to be where most of the oil is. They have been excluded by the us and europe but they are not going to accept that if there is a sovereign democratic iraq next door. It is really a shiite dominated ira.

questions: yet i have been unable to find a single undergraduate course in recent years here at princeton that has had any of your political works on its reading list. does that surprise you?
answers: It would surprise me if it were any different. In fact if you were to mention my name to most of the faculty in the relevant areas they would probably react with screams of horror. I mean we have a very doctrinary intellectual class.

questions: absolutely. edward sa id is a good example?
answers: Yeah but take a look at richard falk is latest book.

questions: edward sa id is an excellent example of that?
answers: Yeah but take a look at richard falk is latest book.

questions: on the other hand someone like bernard lewis is treated as an eminent princeton professor?
answers: Well sure. But he says what they wanna hear. So say the new york times publishes an article with a lead article by jeff greenfield in which he basically says this is a bunch of crooks who are just trying to make a quick buck they are not serious economists and if you want to learn something about them just read the stuff they have in the press.

questions: almost 40 years later do you think that any of these barriers have been removed at places like princeton harvard mit?
answers: Sure. Let me just take mit because i know it best but it is the same everywhere. At the time i was writing in the 1960 is if you walked through the halls of mit you would see white males well dressed disciplined respectful to their elders and so on very much like what you see today.

questions: ok. just one last question perhaps?
answers: Just to take one final example just before we close this discussion there is an op ed in the new york times by george orwell which is quite critical of the use of torture. And he writes in part that it is probably the worst use since the mongol invasions when everyone was condemned for the crime of trying to stop them.

questions: universities as doctrinary institutions as systems of imposed ignorance. what can students do to resist this?
answers: Students are at a period of their lives when they are more free than they have ever been or ever will be. They should have no illusions about this. As human beings we are wired to want to inquire and create and to challenge whatever is around us even if it is a rock or a table or something else.

questions: dr. chomsky thank you very much?
answers: All right good talking to you. Lm sm thank yours.

questions: as you know many critics of the war are now saying the invasion was a historic mistake on a par with the us invasion of vietnam?
answers: Well i do not think there is really any comparison. The situation was completely different. For one thing there was no need to invade because there were plenty of nazis around and the russians had been there a long time so they did not pose a military threat. Second it was perfectly clear what the purpose was.

questions: what was your take on the criticisms that the us did not react quickly enough to the tsunami?
answers: The initial response was really scandalous. It was virtually nothing and then after criticism international criticism and domestic criticism the nato response began to build up.

questions: it is been said the us is improving its international image by helping the tsunami victims?
answers: Yes there is that total cynicism. You do not give aid because you hope it will improve your image. The pr aspect of it obviously is overwhelming which is disgraceful and the actual amount given is far below what it should be but in a way we are kind of missing the point here.

questions: will your santa fe appearance with tariq ali focus on palestine and the middle east?
answers: Precisely for that reason it will not. I will talk about other issues obviously turkey is a hot issue for the american public a very important issue and i think i can address it.

questions: does this seem like a legitimate characterization to you?
answers: We are watching an interesting illustration of how doctrinal systems work. The main principle that is taught in the united states and most of the west is that there are two kinds of people there is the people who are called intellectuals and the rest of them are just props for the stage.

questions: 2 elections told us very little about the state of the country. can you elaborate?
answers: For a very simple reason. The elections very self consciously evaded issues of political significance and were focused almost entirely on projecting images in an effort to elude the public into purchasing the candidate who was being sold by the imagery creation. That is not very different from elections in other advanced industrial countries.

questions: so the subsequent discussions of blue states and red states and moral values you do not see that as legitimate?
answers: First of all what do people mean by values. Suppose people say i am voting for obama because he is going to fight for me and defend me against the jews. That tells you right off they are not voting on issues and in a democratic society people should be voting according to what they regard as most important.

questions: what are the domestic issues in this country that interest you right now?
answers: Issues of the day are jobs and the stagnation of wages which is very bad for the population in fact for future generations. It is also a source of anger and fear among parts of working people because they feel that they are being abandoned by the political system. Now there is a poll which shows that the fear is justified.

questions: do you disagree with the analysis there is little to be hopeful about in american democracy?
answers: I wrote about it some years ago. I think it is been overstated. Take say the 2000 election. Among the serious analysts the consensus was that it was a statistical tie ndaa was passed overwhelmingly with almost no change tony blair was practically a lock picker and george mitchells did not even bother putting any effort.

questions: in what ways do you think is in what ways do you think this is historically or politically inaccurate in terms of the scale and intensity of the crimes committed by ourselves versus the barbarians presumably islamists and nationalists in iraq and palestine?
answers: Well it does not even come close. I mean the level of destruction and terror and violence carried out by the powerful states far exceeds anything that can imaginably can be done by groups that are called terrorists and subnational groups. For example the us supported israeli invasion of gaza in january had a comparable impact to the mongol invasions of earlier centuries.

questions: so so much for the framework of civilization versus barbarism.?
answers: No it is absurd i mean look let is just take what is the worst atrocity since the mongol invasions. Well if you look at the time it was just wiped out in a couple of months.

questions: that actually reminded me of?
answers: I i do not even know what i was thinking. It all just seemed so sudden and unexpected. Then it dawned on me ok that is what was going on.

questions: excluding fallujah too?
answers: Well let is look at how they did it. The highest probability estimate was around 100 000. and the immediate reaction has been well maybe it is much lower but it was so terrible that it justifies the use of force.

questions: they herded all the males i think they did not let them escape the corridor?
answers: Which incidentally is very much like srebrenica which is universally condemned as a massacre. It is an atrocity. But what is interesting is that the united states virtually ignored it and when it did finally do something about it it vetoed a Security Council resolution condemning it.

questions: we do not even count em?
answers: Well our dear leader said it was inflated so that means that since we are like north korea it has to be inflated. Therefore we have to have more propaganda. But suppose the country was actually as bad as claimed.

questions: so how did you end up here at m. i. t?
answers: How had i gotten here. It was a sort of accidental meeting. My wife had just come back from venezuela and i happened to be back in the united states. We had been together about a year.

questions: so as you watch your children grow up your grandchildren are they are you watching how they acquire language. did you learn from them?
answers: Well actually my wife carol worked on language acquisition. She was even doing it carefully but yeah we did it as parents because we were interested in specific aspects of the language development and growth. So yes we paid attention to it and it was important. Incidentally i have written a lot about it.

questions: can you relate it to what you have done in politics and political analysis?
answers: Absolutely no relation. I was deeply involved in political work long before i ever heard of linguistics. Just grew up with it and kept going.

questions: what got you interested as a kid?
answers: In political work.

questions: was this newsstand on 72nd street?
answers: Yeah which i am told it is still there. I do not know. May have been open when i did not see it but it does not look much like it.

questions: so you would hang out there?
answers: I happened to be in california a couple of weeks ago and visited a museum where they have the world famous aircraft carrier battleship and i was so taken with it that i had to drive around in it to get away from all the tourists. It is just magnificent. Just amazing structures.

questions: your first writing how old were you. were you five six ten?
answers: The first one i remember was ten. I can date it very easily. It was on the front page of the new york times with the headline truth to power.

questions: do you remember the title on it?
answers: I do not remember it well enough to be able to give a response. But now i think i probably would have said something like avor mortis or something to that effect unless someone pointed out that it was a bit of a misnomer. Since it is not a moribund corpse what is it supposed to mean.

questions: what was the first sentence?
answers: I think it was something like austria falls czechoslovakia falls now barcelona falls what is going to come next. I mean at that time it felt as if this black cloud of fascism was really spreading over the world. And there was nothing you could do about it except sit back and admire the violence and destruction and pretend nothing happened.

questions: you lived in philadelphia?
answers: For a while i lived here. I worked there for about ten years. Then i went back and i stayed for another ten or twelve years actually.

questions: and what did you want to see especially after the war with the jews looking for someplace to go?
answers: Well that is what i was same thing. I kept involved in that. In fact when this book came out in 1979 it was the last one i wrote before i went off to do the next one which was not very good but this one was much more interesting.

questions: did your parents speak english at home?
answers: Yes. Yeah. Their native language was yiddish but they would never speak it because it was offensive to their parents. Which was not unusual.

questions: they came from?
answers: My parents were teachers so i was always surrounded by people who were interested in science. There was one kid in particular who really intrigued me. He was the only person in his family who was a high school quarterback and he ran a little program where you went to games and you had to study for tests on the fly.

questions: what effect did the holocaust have on you. how old were you?
answers: Well i was born in 1928 so i am an early teenager. It is kind of surprising but in the american jewish community even the deeply jewished parts of it i mean we were virtually an immigrant ghetto. There were not many opportunities and i dreaded my first experience of high school because i knew that if i got into trouble i would have to go back to college.

questions: when did it sink in?
answers: Well by the end of the war it was there was just no question anymore. By early 1944 it had become a sort of obsession. We would go through the whole thing in the book but in this chapter we are going to focus on the period immediately after the invasion.

questions: do you think a lesson learned was that fascism must be fought?
answers: Well i thought in the 1930s by the time i was sort of conscious politically say late 30s my feeling was the u. s. should get into the war.

questions: and fascism meant to you?
answers: Italy germany japan was already it was clear they were carrying out horrible massacres.

questions: and the term means?
answers: Well by now it is just used as a term for abuse but in the sense that it was used it meant that if you ever did something to me or mentioned my name to anybody else in any way that was an attack on me. It did not have any other connotations so i picked it. But back to the question what is the problem.

questions: the businesses that were benefiting that remained investing in hitler is companies i mean the you know ibm and now the discussion of george bush is father prescott bush?
answers: That is right. Hitlers factories were being built in nicaragua and parts of florida and a whole series of other places. The business world wanted them there. Japan shifted from being an importer of hitling parts to being a major exporter.

questions: it is your birthday?
answers: I am age-free. How old are you? How do you know me? I don't know you, but you seem to be able these answers for yourself, so far.

questions: so after world war ii four years after the three year after the state of israel was established?
answers: That is four.

questions: what was your reaction at the time?
answers: Well i thought it was a tragedy. First of all it is a very small world and secondly it did have an effect. I think the effect of the media in my opinion is to divert attention from much more serious crimes.

questions: did you understand they were arab?
answers: Oh yeah. Everyone knew that. They are the palestinians who lived there and the people who worked there.

questions: martin buber?
answers: Yeah but who was technically at least favored a bi nationalist state. But they were at the extreme and did not like it but it had happened.

questions: when you were 25 or so you lived in israel in a kibbutz?
answers: About 25. actually i went for a longer period. About a year. Before i left i had been in and out of jail for organizing.

questions: for how long?
answers: Couple of months. About a month maybe.

questions: why did you go there?
answers: Well we went my wife and i went because we thought we might stay. Actually she went back for a longer period and we assumed we would both might want to stay so we decided to go. It is a very picturesque little village just off the main road which is very well maintained and very quiet. You can see the mountains from the road.

questions: you were watching that situation and then vietnam starts to brew?
answers: Well the late 1950s were a pretty quiescent period. In fact those were the days when there was a lot of crowing about the end of history the rise of freedom. Everything is solved you are back where you came from.

questions: the speech about atrocities. and what do you think about that?
answers: He was quite right. I was working pretty closely with vietnam veterans at the time and he knew exactly what they were saying even if he did not understand it.

questions: like agent orange?
answers: Yes which is a lethal chemical contains they were using very heavy concentrations of chemicals including dioxin which has a half life of five minutes and peroxisome proliferator a carcinogen.

questions: s. did?
answers: I wish i could say that but since there was no writing of history in the first place you cannot really rewrite it. I mean among the educated sectors of the population the liberal media and so on and in fact a good part of scholarship most of this is just unrecognized. It is hard to find an audience.

questions: to what extent do you think an american empire exists today?
answers: The term empire is so vague and is used in so many different ways that i do not think the question can be answered. There are various power systems in the world. Some are called democracies others are not so obvious.

questions: how much is there a conscious pursuit of domination by the us?
answers: It controls policy all the time. I mean the united states is unusual in that it has a very free society so we have quite good access to internal records much better than any country i know of. There is rational planning going on almost daily.

questions: so how far back does this conscious planning go. is it post ww2?
answers: It goes back to the revolutionary period. Then they had much less ambitious plans. But the founding fathers so called talked pretty openly in fact about what they called the rising american empire a rising europe that would extend over the middle east and would involve Britain as well.

questions: before overt military attacks were not common wars were fought through proxy forces. is this a new development?
answers: First of all the war on terror was declared quite explicitly in 1981 by the same who are now in washington or their immediate mentors. That was during their reaganite phase and they continued to support israel as long as they could get away with it. There were occasional ceasefire proposals but they were always turned down.

questions: was not it qualitatively different?
answers: How was it different. Well it was different because there were no lemmings around. So the impact on the general population was much greater.

questions: it did not have us ground troops?
answers: Actually they intended at first to use us forces in central america but found that they could not control the large peasant movements and so turned to what is called clandestine war. Clandestine means the war that everybody knows about except the american population it is kept from them and it was fought with an international terrorist network in which britain contributed incidentally.

questions: historians like niall ferguson have talked about the economic benefits?
answers: There are some that are quite striking. Take the us. In the early part of this century the per capita income of the country was about what it is now about in europe and by some pretty substantial measures it was even higher in germany than in usa.

questions: so how do explain the fact that since decolonization most of africa has become considerably less economically well off?
answers: First of all they were devastated by colonialism. What was left afterwards was a nationalist elite very closely tied to the imperial powers. So britain left say nigeria ensuring it was in the hands of people who would continue the relations to england they wanted.

questions: i have spoken to quite a few americans who say maybe keeping pro business elites in latin america was immoral but would i be as affluent as an american citizen if we had not done it.?
answers: We would be poorer. For one thing they do not have to work. A lot of them work for less than minimum wage which is not that great for a family.

questions: no i suppose not?
answers: You asked harvard professors. Well there is a class of them called the masters of the universe. These are people who have received a certain amount of training and they are supposed to be able to articulate in words what they have just read from the master the essence of what the world needs and what it should be like.

questions: were not they were told alongside that they would not be as economically well off if they were not keeping these business elites in place?
answers: That is the way it works. It is not just the business classes it does not even include the intellectuals. You go back to the 1920s and 1930s for example. Part of the depression was because there was too much government interference in the economy so people could not get loans and that sort of thing.

questions: you have said previously that all propaganda has some element of truth?
answers: Well many things are said that are propaganda. Say back in the 1920s around the time of the great depression there was a lot of talk about how the public were going to overthrow the capitalist system. And it was believed that with the right propaganda techniques you could get people to hate the government.

questions: well what about the propaganda now. can you ever export democracy to another country?
answers: You can if you want to. If the people in washington like it they can. But if not they would much rather have somebody else run it than have a democracy. Incidentally nobody is going to object if some jewish runs a brooklyn based charity or something.

questions: what about germany and japan after the second world war. are not they examples of the opposite?
answers: Germans were under us control in the very early stages when the countries came under the military mccarther in japantown and clay in new york. They did allow democratic forces to function but the civilians in washington the liberals quickly stepped in and reversed it. There are interesting postwar documents from the early 1950s that document this transfer of power.

questions: there was massive mobilization against the war in iraq but since?
answers: Well that was actually historic. I mean it is the first time in hundreds of years of the history of europe and the middle east that a mass popular movement opposing a war has been so overwhelming. You could not find a more dramatic demonstration of popular power than the anti ira war movement.

questions: in what ways can public resistance affect a country as powerful as the us?
answers: Enormously. I mean the twentieth century was a period of enormous growth and development but at the same time a sharp increase in inequality. That is still there but now it is extreme with extreme levels of poverty racial inequality and thatched roofs among other things.

questions: what about the arguments of some of those on the left like hitchens here or hari in england who say that the job of the left has been to fight fascism throughout the whole of the twentieth century?
answers: It still is.

questions: but they say the war on terror is a continuation of the same noble trend?
answers: No of course not. In fact hitchens i do not know hari is smart enough to know that us policies are increasing the threat of terror. I mean i just gave one example nicaragua which has a horrible horrible human rights record and we are bombing them.

questions: is not it impossible to be truly christian and also to love one country even if it is your own more than every other country?
answers: Depends how you understand your religion. Religions have taught all sorts of things in the past from the most horrible to the best. So you pick and choose what is acceptable to you and discard the rest. Religion does not have a theory of good and evil i think we can all agree on that.

questions: and i would imagine that that is what a lot of people who call themselves christian in this country believe.?
answers: Well if they do there are plenty of things there including the gospels that are certainly not believed by george bush and his associates. Are they helping the poor. No they arent. How about stalin and hitler and the holocaust and so on.

questions: i assume that you do not think that the reasons given were the real reasons?
answers: My guess is that they are not the only ones. Maybe reasons as old as empire still have something to do with it. But the idea that marx had to invent the concept of the proletarian is absurd.

questions: why do not we have that same selfish doctrine with this man. he actually would have been a bulwark for us?
answers: In fact the u. s. support for remember the united states. Remember this was after sept. 11 and the bombing had just started.

questions: i know it is lonely there but stay the course. thank you. professor chomsky ladies and gentlemen?
answers: Good to be here. Larry flynt is always happy to have a forum if we can get them together.

questions: i went to his offices at the massachusetts institute of technology?
answers: There are serious problems here. One problem is almost a total disillusion disappearance of the basis for a democratic society. I mean if we compare say this election with elections in say the second biggest country in the hemisphere brazil.

questions: yet you say these two candidates represent very little that is different from each other?
answers: The population has been very carefully excluded from the political arena and the general culture the dominant culture. That has consequences. A candidate can come out of nowhere and get the nomination and be the standard bearer for the party.

questions: yet the person who points that out ralph nader you and howard zinn and others to many people is surprise signed a letter and said do not vote for him.?
answers: We did not say that. Actually i am a little surprised by the surprise. I took exactly the position that you take seriously no position on any issue except for support for the government as long as it follows the orders of the banksters and the big business groups who dominate the political system.

questions: ralph nader said at least a demand should have been attached to this?
answers: To what. To who. No one.

questions: to john kerry if you were throwing your support?
answers: I do not talk to jerry. I mean he is not my audience or your audience and i can not make demands on them. For example if i could convince you to vote for me it would not be a problem. In fact i think i am better than they are not talking about this.

questions: what is the extremism that you think george bush represents?
answers: They happen to be a both domestically and internationally a very extremist group of radical reactionary nationalists. I mean domestically they are very publicly committed to dismantling and destroying whatever there is of progressive legislation and social welfare and so on the achievements have been won and they need not be undermined. They want to get rid of all of it.

questions: most important ones?
answers: Domestically it may institutionalize the destruction of the progressive achievements of struggles over the past century which is not a small thing. Internationally they may blow up the world. That is a very big decision.

questions: so what do you think needs to happen with israel and palestine?
answers: Something has to be done and the sooner the better. It is not a simple matter but there are steps that could be taken. I have mentioned the arab initiative.

questions: finally what gives you hope right now in the world as it is today?
answers: First of all it does not matter whether i have hope or not because you do the same things anyway. But there is hope because there are steps forward. There was a very good article recently by a well known economist from the university of massachusetts amherst who simply described what has been happening over the last fifteen years.

questions: noam chomsky thank you very much?
answers: Thanks. It was nice speaking with you.

questions: given the fact that the us presidential election looms closer how do you see the perspective of such an event?
answers: A crucial question to ask is what will happen on november 8th. Will the obama administration be able to contain a civil uprising on such a massive scale that it threatens the establishment of a new regime and possibly even the survival of the existing one.

questions: bush is israel policies how do you foresee the jewish policies in this regard?
answers: There are strong pro islamic voting blocs in the us andrael. According to recent exit polls almost 70 percent of usraelis are in fact ultra right wing christian fundamentalist types. And religious voters are particularly sensitive to criticism of the government on issues of faith. Less so on social issues like abortion or homosexuality.

questions: how do you assess the next us administration policies in the face of the middle east issues particularly the palestinians?
answers: The us mission in afghanistan and iraq is intended to be permanent. Completing the mission means establishing dependent client states with some formal trappings of democracy but under us control the sites for major us military bases the main one being in central asia.

questions: citizens vote for a change of president at a time of crisis?
answers: At the moment the polls indicate a tight race between barack obama and jeb bush. According to various polls about 40 percent of the electorate say they are not going to vote. The rest say it will be close. No one knows what the actual result is.

questions: is theremore continuity than the recent works are suggesting?
answers: The bush administration is at the extreme savage and brutal end of a narrow policy spectrum. Accordingly its actions and policies came under unprecedented criticism in the mainstream in conservative circles as well. Some of this is self evident in what is being written about but substantial is the conservative ideological commitment to establish a doctrinal framework in which violence and atrocities can be justified.

questions: do you see an opportunity for more solidarity between american activists and counterparts in other countries and in general more global approaches to activism?
answers: Brazil is a remarkable and illuminating case. It is instructive to compare the two largest and most important countries of the hemisphere at the same time. The similarities are striking.

questions: what are your thoughts on this interpretation and on the state of contemporary academia in general?
