answers: I have to admit that i am a little skeptical about such claims. Suppose that true. Then it is only a question of time before the whole edifice of propaganda collapses. Thanks to privileged access and a general contempt for critical analysis the general public is kept in the dark.

questions: do you think that this diversity makes anarchism ineffective and an inconsequential body of ideas or rather makes anarchism universally adaptable?
answers: Anarchism is a very broad category it means a lot of different things to different people. The main strains of anarchism have been very concerned with means.

questions: do you agree with this theoretical separation and in this perspective where do you see the historical beginnings of anarchism in the u. s?
answers: The individualistic anarchism that you are talking about stirner and others is one of the roots of among other things the so called industrial revolution.

questions: what is your opinion about the transcendentalism as an inspiration in this perspective?
answers: Maybe you will discover something in your research on this topic but my feeling is that it has no significant place in the development of our understanding of the human condition and should be rejected. At most it may provide a basis for further inquiry which will in my opinion be valuable.

questions: where do you see the main reason for this?
answers: I think it has always been true. Most activists people in human rights struggles women is struggles labor struggles and so on did not call themselves anarchists they did what was called anarchist.

questions: is pejorative usage of the word anarchism maybe a direct consequence of the fact that the idea that people could be free was and is extremely frightening to those in power?
answers: There has been an element within the anarchist movement that has wanted to romanticize the enlightenment ideals and fight the war against serfdom and slavery but that is not true. The real heroes were the knights of labor who won free labor for all time from the serfs.

questions: do you think that the change should be achieved through institutionalized politics or rather through other means such as disobedience building parallel frameworks alternative media etc?
answers: It is impossible to say anything general about it because it depends on circumstances. Sometimes one tactic is right sometimes another one. Talk of tactics sounds sort of trivial but there is a lot of detail involved. If you want to learn something about the world in general you have to do some research.

questions: do you also have a felling that many left intellectuals are loosing too much energy with their theoretical disputes about the proper means and ends to even start experimenting in practice?
answers: Many people find this extremely important and find that they cannot act as let is say organizers in their community unless they have some conception of the kind of organization they want to see. Ok that is the way they perceive the world and themselves. I do not agree with that.

questions: what is your opinion about this riddle?
answers: There is an obvious answer to that the bible itself provides plenty of evidence for it. So for example when the author of the gospels was asked what did he think about the jews he said they are a plague a terrible people a curse to humanity. What do they say to each other.

questions: they object to the notion of majority rule noting that the views of the majority do not always coincide with the morally right one. do you agree with this notion?

questions: something that you were so successful in proving with universal grammar?

questions: what should be in this respect our first steps toward another better world?

questions: do you go to the polls do you vote?

In fact there is a popular candidate in bernie sanders i do not know if he has won yet but he is doing pretty well in most polls.

questions: noam chomsky can you talk about this the people that are now running the administration are some of the very people who ran the reagan administration more than 20 years ago?

questions: i mean the mining of the harbor?

questions: professor chomsky i would not want to end this discussion without talking about the reagan years and africa particularly southern africa?

questions: he asked him whether he was suggesting there was nothing new in the so called bush doctrine?

questions: it had been the victim of a grotesque intentional attack what was it supposed to do but try?

questions: but you are suggesting the united states in that sense is the author of its own nemesis?
answers: Well first of all this is not my opinion. It is what the leading us strategic analysts call the u. s. is strategic doctrine and it was articulated by defense secretary cohen in his congressional testimony a year ago.

questions: but why do you imagine george bush behaves like this?

questions: then why would he do it?
answers: Because invading iraq has value in itself i mean establishing

questions: well what value?

questions: do not you even think that the people of iraq are better off having got rid of a dictator?

The statement of mine that you just quoted is a very conservative statement in fact it was articulated by georgia is leading conservative intellectual thomas franklin. He held that there can not be any moral comparison whatsoever between democratic heads who are carrying out democratic decisions and brutal regimes.

questions: is it a good thing if it is preferable for an individual to live in a liberal democracy is there benefit to be gained by spreading the values of that democracy however you can?
answers: There certainly is in my view with one qualification an evaluation of how the society operates on the basis of privilege and power. So let is take a look at how american society runs on those lines. The top few percent of the population own about as much wealth as the bottom 90 percent combined.

questions: as a consequence of how the west behaved?
answers: Well that is part of it. But what is even more striking is the extraordinary contempt for international law and the norms that have guided international relations for centuries. Just look at the constant stream of condemnations of south africa for what it is doing. Not one word about the fact that the united states britain and france have been condemned for exactly the same things.

questions: do you understand why tony blair behaved as he did over afghanistan and iraq?

questions: why has there not been any discussion about war crimes and why are not people talking about impeachment?
answers: Well they are.

questions: and the other part?
answers: The occupy movement spontaneously created communities of mutual support mutual aid. The common kitchen the libraries. These are maybe even more important. Not just in my opinion but also in the general american experience.

questions: do you think the reverence toward bush is showing signs of withering?
answers: No. It has been going on for years. Just take a look at google. He is the most popular person in the united states which is not a great surprise.

questions: why do elite decisionmakers who have children and grandchildren pursue policies that are potentially so destructive?
answers: Around 1950 the u. s. had a position of security that is unparalleled in human history.

questions: why do so many people in the united states just go along with u. s. policy?
answers: What is striking is that this view is accepted without coercion. If you are living in a dictatorship or under kings and princes or in places run by murderous bishops you would better take that view or you will be in deep trouble. You get burned at the stake or thrown into the gulag or something.

questions: but what do i do as an individual. how would you respond to that?
answers: The first thing you ought to do is verify what i present. Just because i say it does not make it true. So check it out see what looks correct what doesn't look correct look at other material which was not discussed figure out what the truth really is then present that information in its totality.

questions: which is any country in the world?
answers: No it is not any particular country. Every country is under military occupation. So take iraq. If the united states was occupied by iran would anybody take it seriously.

questions: one of the things that is banned for example is chess. will they care as long as they have control?
answers: They do not care what happens. Why should they if they are controlling the media and controlling congress. In fact if you look at the history of organized human life it does not matter much what people think but it mattered a lot what they believed.

questions: at the same time our foreign policy is causing these effects in iraq?

questions: do you think that we will ever see white war criminals from imperial nations stand trial the way that rios montt did?

questions: when you hear things like this what is your response to people saying that his hands are tied he wants to do well?

I mean bush likes to posture as a kind of a blank slate on which he can write whatever he likes. If people see through that they tend to be impressed by what they see.

questions: i would rather be detained then blown up and my family with me?
answers: And that terrorizes everyone else. It is the wedge between us and the rest of the world. Now what do you think the us can and should do to help stop this. Well there are some very simple suggestions.

questions: do you think that all these policies are quantifying what has been in place for decades?
answers: The ndaa is a good case. It is been used pretty extensively as a torture chamber. The principles go back to the magna carta and are very much alive in the contemporary world.

questions: what did obama is re branding of bush is policies to do consciousness?
answers: It is all just smoke and mirrors. There is no policy. Policy is determined by the whims of the most powerful men in the world particularly china russia europe and the united states.

questions: famous atheists like richard dawkins saying that islam is one of the greatest threats facing humanity that is a whole another form of propaganda?
answers: Christianity right now is in much greater threat. It is the only thing that can stop the holocaust. I mean the jews have been at it for 500 years they are the ones who invented the beeeep nuremberg defense.

questions: when you wrote that book did you see how far it would come and where do you see it in 10 years?
answers: I am afraid that it did not take any foresight because it has been going along a long time. Take the us invasion of south vietnam for example. Was it foreseen that this would turn out to be a major war crime.

questions: with the internet do you see the reversal of this trend when people are going to be making this form of media propaganda irrelevant. or do you see a worsening?
answers: First of all i do not really think the media are that different. I mean if you look at the print media it is somewhat different but in many ways the same basic principles are held the business press is basically the corporate version of the press. It has a narrow editorial policy but primarily serves the needs of corporate power.

questions: how dangerous is it to have an elite ruling class with the illusion of knowledge advancing their own world view on humanity?
answers: It is old as the hills. Every form of society had some kind of privileged elite who claimed to be the repositories of the understanding and knowledge and wanted control of what they called the rebel. To make sure that the people do not have thoughts like we want to rule the world and we are going to run it by force.

questions: daniel falcone for truthout i wanted to ask you some questions about education in the 21st century?
answers: First of all there is a lot of talk about it but very little about what it actually means. Edward herman and i are just part of a small group of people who have been trying to change that. We have tried to come up with a number of proposals some of them pretty radical some not so much.

questions: well before i would go into discussing the 21st century can you comment on this country is history with education and what tradition do you think we have grown out of in terms of education?
answers: That is an interesting question. The us was kind of a pioneer in mass public education. Actually this here is land grant university which is part of the big 19th century expansion of our education through federal grant to the universities. Less than a century later we had the state college system which was a big step up.

questions: does our educational system foster a form of on job control?
answers: Off job controlling. Actually the term is sometimes even used taylorism by the business press. Tony blair is treatment of people who are on the job keeps them on task for the benefit of the employer.

questions: do we as a nation have a reason to fear an assault on public education and the complete privatization of education?
answers: It is part of the way of controlling and dumbing down the population and that is important. Much has to do with the catastrophe looming mainly environmental catastrophe which will sharply increase the cost of everything from food to energy to health care and probably lethal accidents. But there are other aspects as well which are of prime concern to power centers in the u. s. and europe.

questions: what do you think are important attributes of a school. what constitutes a good school?
answers: Well i will describe the school i went to when i was kid.

questions: yeah co ed now?
answers: Which were all college oriented kids. So until i got to central high i literally did not know i was a good student because the question never came up. Everybody had a record and you were supposed to be a certain kind of person so you got into Harvard and Yale and so on but it was just a matter of being in the right school.

questions: and these are natural impulses?
answers: Kids are naturally creative and of course you do not have to beat it out of them. That is why they are asking why. All the time.

questions: is this a cultural condition in your view or is this inherent in our school system?
answers: It was true even in the school that i went to in philadelphia in a day of much less corporate control of society. I do not think it has much to do with schools though it does have to with the institutional structure of the society in which it exists. There are many influences from early 19th century europe post world war ii.

questions: that is clever?
answers: There is no level where you can not do things like that if you are a teacher who has control of the classroom. You cannot fire people. I would not want to do it myself but it is kind of implicit in the model that i have discussed which basically says that the only way to function in this highly competitive highly authoritarian society is to have a very disciplined work force.

questions: and these are bipartisan efforts?
answers: Oh it is bipartisan. Obama suggested cutting back on social security. But then they pretend to be surprised at the outcomes. See here is a plan that was proposed by the senate majority leader and the majority whip of the house and it was carried through by a majority of congressmen.

questions: how about the arts and music. we see cutting of?
answers: That is a sign of social change. It used to be you could go to the theater and see plays but now you have to go see a symphony or a beeeep en chambre. I have never seen a mimeograph and i do not see the point in using it.

questions: is this an accurate view. what is anarchy to you?
answers: Well anarchism is in my view basically a kind of tendency in human thought which shows up in different forms in various circumstances and has some leading characteristics. Primarily it is a tendency that is suspicious and skeptical of domination authority and hierarchy. In its critique of authoritarian structures it stresses the crucial importance of freedom and independence and the tension that arises when those aspects of human nature are under attack.

questions: why should we choose anarchy as opposed to say libertarianism?
answers: Well what is called libertarian in the united states which is a special u. s. phenomenon it does not really exist anywhere else a little bit in england permits a very high level of authority and domination but it also permits very limited forms of freedom. Traditionally that has meant limited government and centralisation.

questions: it seems to be a continuing contention today?
answers: Yes and so well that kind of libertarianism in my view in the current world is just a call for some of the worst kinds of tyranny namely unaccountable private tyranny. Anarchism is quite different from that.

questions: could you briefly describe that model and why it might be important to students?
answers: Well first look back a bit a little historical framework back in the late 19th early 20th century a good deal of freedom had been won in some societies. At the peak of this were in fact the united states and britain but a lot of other societies had come along since and had instituted somewhat similar systems.

questions: is there a correlation between that campaign and what is happening with the big oil industry right now and climate change?
answers: It is very significant. They know perfectly well that the public is easily amenable to lies the more lies there are the greater the support for policies that are designed to increase the cost of doing business. That is been true ever since the gold standard.

questions: they can identify with what a philosopher does think about the big questions. so these are questions from kids?
answers: I was in california a couple weeks ago and my daughter in law wanted me to give a talk to a group of cub scouts so i gave a symposium to eight high school kids.

questions: how long was the talk?
answers: It stopped as soon as they got up and started walking around so i can not tell you how many times they talked.

questions: actually the first question we have is from a seven year old?
answers: Ok. i only talk to eight year olds. But i get questions all the time from seven to eleven yearolds.

questions: she said hmmm that is easy i would ask why are we here.?
answers: There are two views about that which go back to classical greece maybe before. One is we are here for the same reason that rocks and trees and grass do. That was probably true of the ancients too.

questions: and that would be the chomsky view?
answers: Yes that is my view and i think it is in principle clear.

questions: along those same lines should we assume that humans are more important than other animals on the planet?
answers: The fact of the matter is we don't know. There is some study of what happens when you tax a bee it flies away. But that is about as far as you can go.

questions: so you do not really believe in inter species communication?
answers: There is nothing to it at all. We are not any more evolved than protozoa just in a different line. In many ways they do a lot better than we do and there are all sorts of other differences too which i attribute mostly to the conditions of my childhood.

questions: so this is from a fourteen year old living in a world in which they are constantly surrounded by tragedies and the reality of human mortality it is a simple but complex question how do we make sense of dying?
answers: Well it has been a big problem throughout reflective human life probably all of reflective life. In most cultures and societies there is been an awareness going back thousands of years that death is just a passing phenomenon. Whoever asked the question has to work it out for himself whether he wants to be a philosopher or a scientist or whatever.

questions: but that is tragic if it would have happened?
answers: Well you know i do not see it that way anymore. Look i think if there had been popular support for this it might have succeeded. But the fact of the matter is that it did not succeed and that tells you something very deep about the nature of american society. Less than 10 percent of voters actually went to the polls.

questions: how do you see it then?
answers: It is just one of the things that happens in life. Life goes on for everyone else.

questions: for example we would not be sitting here talking today. and that would be a tragedy?
answers: The same is true of everyone else. Everyone has contributions to make every animal has some kind of contribution to making. Ok so the way the universe works is you have a fixed time on earth and then it is over.

questions: do you think that has something to do with human consciousness?
answers: Has it ever. I do not think so. Anyhow whatever it is a fact of human experience and no one is stopping us from thinking about it or from doing anything about what it means.

questions: now you turn on the radio in the morning and it is one tragedy after another constant bombardment?
answers: Well that is selection. I mean you do not hear much about what is happening in syria or dp for that matter.

questions: in a way this points to the tragedy of last evening because if noam chomsky perished last night that would be one less voice in the world willing to have the courage to address what most people are unwilling to address?
answers: Then others should do it. It does not take any special skill or talent or even courage.

questions: with all due respect i think you are being overly modest?
answers: Well i have got a lot to be modest about there is no doubt about it. And i do not see why i should be either. In fact if i were to say i was in love with you i would be ashamed of myself not speaking truth to power noam.

questions: if we are the only sentient creatures on this planet why are we destroying the environment?
answers: Probably for that reason. Another aspect of it is just sheer opportunism. You know i am not going to talk about the gaza attack which was just brazen arrogance on the part of the united states which shows very clearly what they are capable of.

questions: you said that started around roughly 1750 this race to disaster does that correspond to the growth of capital as well?
answers: Industrialization which quickly became capital. The holocene begins about the time of the rise of agriculture and then the receding of ice ages which coincided. From that point on out the period of rapid industrial development was followed by a period that is now called the glacial period which was much harsher than the Holocene period.

questions: it was announced recently that we have passed a dangerous climate threshold?
answers: Yes 400 parts per million co2. If we go that high we are going to destroy the world probably in our grandchildren. It is just a fact about the climate.

questions: you have mentioned that the fate of the species is at stake and that might mean that our future as young people is at stake so what can we do as young people to ensure that we even have a future?
answers: Well i do not want to be too alarmist about it. It is not hopeless. There are things we can do. For example every once in a while i turn down a chance to give a talk because i know that if i did give one it would be a disaster so i am not going to take any chances.

questions: when you were addressing a roomful of eight year olds what was the general topic of discussion?
answers: I talked about this in a way that i hoped was understandable to people eight years old or younger. So let is take the example of december 2007. in that case the topic was something like how to protect our security at the expense of others. How do you do it in ways that do not put others at risk.

questions: what was topical for them?
answers: I was in california a couple weeks ago and my daughter in law wanted me to give a talk to a group of cub scouts so i gave a symposium on israeli crimes. It was very good.

questions: or an ice cream?
answers: Probably an ipad is more likely. I have been on a diet for about ten years.

questions: suppose they were sitting here how would you take up these issues with eight year olds?
answers: Essentially what i just said which you can say at any level. There are a number of issues which are very serious and require serious thought and attention.

questions: if someone suggested that the united states is moving more and more toward forms of fascism would you find evidence that it is true?
answers: Oh yea very striking evidence. In fact i never really expected much from obama i thought it was mostly hot air but one thing has surprised me and that is the intensity of his attack on civil liberties which goes beyond any rational explanation i can think of and it shows up in a lot of ways. So one striking example is drone assassinations.

questions: philip k. dick the science fiction writer?
answers: I do not know him. But this is worse than anything i have seen on the propaganda front. It is straight out of the technology journals.

questions: what about the psychic effect of knowing that you are living in a society where you understand that you are under constant surveillance even in terms of the impact on the activist community?
answers: That is another issue altogether. I do not think i ever really understood the question of psychological reality on campus. It seems to me kind of an interesting question but not really relevant to the issue at hand for me.

questions: so in other words from our perspective based on our age we see that there should be limits there should be some privacy but these kids are not seeing that?
answers: That is the impression i get. As i say i do not investigate it myself but i have friends who basically try to monitor their children on facebook and a lot of them are just appalled by what they see. Things that you and i would never have dreamed of making public. For example cutting corners with your tax dollars.

questions: you have got to be joking?
answers: I do not think it is a joke.

questions: on the one hand life is sort of a hyper spectacle but then the student asks why is school so boring.?
answers: That is a very good question. School does not have to be boring. It can be the most exciting experience you ever had and it sometimes is. Let is take a look at the facts.

questions: why impose such a boring project of education on a whole population of youngsters?
answers: You can speculate about the reasons but i do not think it is a serious one. I suspect that in more or less comparable societies the educational programs would be similar or even be approaching them. In the u. s. for example high school does not have the drab uniformity of elementary school and much of the beginning of middle school.

questions: was not there an incentive for the business class to train the public so that way they would have useful workers in the factories and so forth but now that is no longer the case?
answers: Oh it is. Actually if you go back to the origins of the mass education system a large part of what was called the war effort was to take over the universities and turn them into propaganda institutions. Like take george washington remember the famous phrase war to educate.

questions: do you think that organizing in 2013 calls for some different tactics and strategies than organizing in the 1930s or 1960s?
answers: Sure there are different issues. It is important to recognize that the issues we face are very serious. There is no question that for many years now the prospects for decent survival have not been pretty.

questions: do you think it was pressure from the u. s. to release him so as not to create a precedent?
answers: I suspect it is from guatemala. There is a lot of pressure there to let go. Ariel sharon was just replaced as prime minister by someone who seems to be much more sympathetic to leopoldo l pez than the previous one and is expected to carry on as before.

questions: professor chomsky what do you think are some of the root causes of student debt in this country?
answers: Well we can rule some things out. I do not think you can make a case that it is an economic reason. There is pretty good reasons for thinking like that.

questions: what would you say the role in the student debt situation is the system of for profit universities and for profit higher education?
answers: It is a scam. Take a look at the statistics of dropout failure. What happens to the people who do get into college.

questions: would you be in favor of having a higher education be free just like public school like high school and elementary school?
answers: Like finland or mexico or germany or lots of others early united states itself for that matter. Why. It is good for the society.

questions: would you say that the whole situation of student debt is unique to the american society or does it take place in other countries that have a capitalist economy?
answers: First it is not traditionally true in the united states. As i say in earlier years when i was a child the leading newspaper of the day was the new york times. And in those days there were two or three left wing journals per year. This was before the internet so you could read them at night if you had a place to go.

questions: why do you think that people in washington like the media and lawmakers have not really been treating it as a pressing issue?
answers: Well partly because of who they represent. It turns out that about 70 percent of the population lower 70 per cent on the income scale have literally no influence on policy. Congress represents mostly wealthy people.

questions: what would you say to the people that say well it is the students own fault that they have debt. what would be your thoughts on that?
answers: Well i would agree with that completely. For one thing like student debt in the united states is not an economic problem. It has a social cost.

questions: would you be in favor of forgiving the student debt that we currently have for the student?
answers: I would go much further than that. I think a lot of the debt ought to be forgiven. It is a form of robbery.

questions: what do you think student debt says about this society as a whole. what message does it convey?
answers: It conveys the message that maybe sociopath is too strong a word but there is an element of sociopathy in the society more and more. It shows up in all kind of ways. In one respect it is just inherent in market systems.

questions: so given the various problems with the market system running education what do you envision education to look like in the future?
answers: Actually that is up to people like you. Right now the educational system is being driven into the ground. There are a lot of problems but one of the big problems is that there is no real market in place to provide the kinds of educational opportunities that are really needed.

questions: so you would say that there is an increasing trend in the education system like with the teach to test that it is gone toward training people to be obedient to the status quo?
answers: Absolutely. I am sure you experience it. You do not have to ask me but i suspect that part of your education is just to make you as conditioned as possible to think that the world is a pretty nice place and i can not change that.

questions: in school like public school districts?
answers: Public schools that is the way it works. And it is essentially going to destroy the public education system which was one of the great contributions to the united states. It has enormous social and economic benefits. Just take a look at the stock market in new york if you compare it with what it was before the crisis.

questions: do you think that student debt relates to other topics other problems in society?
answers: It is very serious. A lot of students personally do not have the kind of judgment that is required to go to college. But a large majority of them do and the judgment is that they would be better off not going to school at all.

questions: what do you think ordinary people can do to combat against the system of debt?
answers: Work for a more democratic society. A society where 70 percent of the population is ignored is not a democracy. Now that is a big problem.

questions: what would you say your perspective on student debt is being in academia?
answers: I probably make less than a graduate student at my major. I have two jobs and one of them is to take notes for an exam so that i can go home and spend time with my family. Most of the time i am working but i do not have anywhere to live so i need the money to pay my bills.

questions: do you think that student debt sort of has maybe a classist dimension in that lenders target lower income people?
answers: Absolutely. You are in a very vulnerable position. A lot of students personally do not have the kind of judgment that is required to take out a big personal loan.

questions: not quite not quite but almost?
answers: Every year everyone on medicare gets a pamphlet from the government which is about 100 pages long which lays out your options. You need a research associate is to even figure it out. I mean i can not read through it.

questions: so you think that lenders see luring people into thinking that they can go to college at little or no cost but then they burden them with debt?
answers: I tell you if you ever read adam smith some day one of the things pointed out is if a bank wants to make a loan it will ask what is the interest rate on the collateral. If the answer is four percent that is a good loan if it is five percent or seven percent well that does not matter.

questions: what would be your advice to people who have student debt like my cousin?
answers: That is hard. That really is a struggle. It is not just student indebtedness like for example credit card debt.

questions: one basic question that a lot of people seem to be asking is why. what is the rationale?
answers: That is a very interesting question. I personally never expected anything of obama and wrote about it before the 2008 primaries. In fact i thought it was smoke and mirrors.

questions: does he think he is appealing to some constituency with that affirmation?
answers: I do not know what base appeals to. If it is the working class white males that are for sale on the cheap as in so many sectors of the economy that may be their constituency. In fact i doubt very much that they would vote for a black male with such a criminal record as he has if they knew what it was.

questions: that expansion of the surveillance state do you see that as another facet of expanding executive power?
answers: It is an enormous expansion. I doubt that they can do much with this information that is being stored. Very systematic.

questions: might that change with enhanced technology and search capabilities?
answers: There will be new ways of combing through the data electronically to pick up things that look like suspicious connections almost all of which will mean nothing but they may find some things. It is kind of like the drone killings.

questions: do you think nonviolent verbal dissent could eventually be criminalized?
answers: I think it could be. Anybody who has looked at law enforcement at all knows that one of the techniques is to try to force confession or plea bargaining by just using material that the person does not want publicized. That is very common and i have seen it over and over.

questions: there is an alarming quote from chris hedges in reference to the ndaa suit. how much weight does this case hold?
answers: We have already lost that right. If you look at the criminal systems and the truly oppressed populations like the black male population for them due process is sometimes existent but overwhelmingly they just do not have it. You can not hire a lawyer you cannot hire an attorney and get a decent defense and that is true whether it is a criminal offense like robbery or something else.

questions: do you think the left in general could become another oppressed population in the future?
answers: I do not think there is much of a threat there. I doubt that there will be anything like what there has been in terms of effective control by the working class and the poor. They will of course be bitterly opposed to policies which they perceive to be harmful to them and to future generations.

questions: how do the military industrial complex and market forces in general perpetuate these systems of injustice?
answers: Very much so. Just look at the incarceration rates now. They are driven by privatized prison systems and the private prison industry has designed them to be broken up and reconstituted in a way that makes it look like a health care system. Not so much.

questions: is there any way that political economic reform like say overturning citizens united might rein in these industrial complexes?
answers: Well i do not think it is necessary to overturn Citizens United. Citizens united was an extreme example of corporate power overriding democracy. The corporations have a voice but their voice is limited because they are limited by the capacity of the democratic political system to provide the same level of funding for elections as the corporate sector does for lobbying.

questions: is there potential for legal redress in cases like hedges vs. obama. how viable is that strategy?
answers: Well i was asked by chomsky to participate and i am one of the plaintiffs. I think it is a viable strategy. But ndaa is not the worst of it by a long shot. So pardon me.

questions: there has been considerable outrage towards the bradley manning case what do you make of the campaign to support him?
answers: Well i do not know what i think about it. I mean i support the right of people to protest. As far as i am aware that is what everybody is doing. No one is stopping you from going to the polls you can go to town halls and demonstrations.

questions: is it possible that we might see a revival of the global justice movement of the 1980s to launch large scale movements against these practices and policies?
answers: It is very possible and it would be very interesting to see whether in fact there are such movements. I do not know any more about this than you or i know about the weather. But there is every reason to believe that they will exist.

questions: in your time as an activist and writer do you see states on a trajectory toward more openness transparency and accountability obviously with movements pushing that or do you see them as more opaque unaccountable and exclusive?
answers: It is a mixed story. There have been some efforts at opening up the state sector of the economy which are encouraging. But a lot more can be done and should be. Links to more open and transparent institutions are obvious.

questions: do you see potential for a movement like that in response to recent policy and practice in regards to surveillance?
answers: There should be. Nobody could have predicted what happened in the 60s. Things were so out of control that it is not even worth talking about. But things have to be confronted and adapted to the realities of the moment.

questions: you had historical debates with piaget and skinner and many others on acquisition of language. what is your opinion about that?
answers: Frankly i do not think these theories have anything to say about the practical problems of education. They may give some ideas which shape process and efforts but for most things you just have to judge by how they work and not by what they look like.

questions: over the years many teachers seemed to have come to you as a linguist to ask you how to teach language to kids but most of the times you answered that teaching methods are probably worthless and that it is the way you try to interest kids in learning that it is important?
answers: I think 90 of it there is no such thing as motivation it depends on what the motivation is. Motivation can come in many forms and there are a lot of different kinds. So you will find different answers for different situations. One kind of situation is for teaching to sell newspapers i do not have any special knowledge about that.

questions: standardized testing teaching to the tests competition between schools between private and public institutions how do you think measures like no child left behind by bush or race to the top by obama changed the face of the american educational system?
answers: First of all there are problems with the system but these measures do not deal with them at all to my knowledge change of any dimension is possible through the kind of activism that has taken place in the past and will continue to do so. I have mentioned the ferguson protests which have an immediate effect. A lot more can be done i think.

questions: you wrote a lot about intellectual self defense courses at what age do you think self defense courses should be offered to students and how should it ideally be incorporated in an educational system?
answers: Well i personally would not do it. I would just tell them to keep to what they are good at. There is nothing wrong with defending yourself against people who are trying to mug you or kill you and so on.

questions: it is a view that you share with bertrand russell can you talk about that your inspiration?
answers: Look behind you it was he wrote a book on evolutionary biology and punk rock. Back in the early 70s when this started to spread through the country i was one of the first people to see it and i still am. Hightimes readers may not have seen it but if you have been in an area of american society for more than 30 years you know it.

questions: how was it?
answers: From about 2 years old to high school. I had a terrific educational experience no tests no ranking when there were testsno one was paying attention. Then i went to alma mater which was a technical college not a college like oregon state.

questions: it seems that the situation in quebec is similar when it comes to explore your views. are you surprised by that?
answers: I think it is true with many others too take a look at courses in american history or canadian history you are not going to find much in the way of critical commentary. Final anecdote i had a daughter who was in 5th grade or so in 1969. i remember the date it was very crucial.

questions: thank you very much professor chomsky?
answers: All right good talking to you. Lm sm great to have a chance to spend time with you and paul.

questions: well first off thank you so much for conducting this interview and for your many years of continued activism and solidarity?
answers: Glad to have a chance to talk to you. It is a real honor and privilege to be with yasser arafat and other high officials of the palestinian cause both here and abroad. And i greatly admire the fact that young people are beginning to grasp the significance of what they are doing even if they do not always understand the nature of things happening to them.

questions: what is your position on the role of violence in this case subjective violence as opposed to symbolic or objective violence in movements of liberation?
answers: Well first of all i am not familiar with the revival and i do not know exactly what it is about. Is it a revival of the red scare or what. But i think it has nothing to do with communism.

questions: in essence some theorists have said that we should reevaluate the ethical implications of violence through the lens of events like the terror in france and that events such as these can be justified?
answers: Maybe it was done maybe not done but it has to be done somehow. How do you do it. That is the question that bothers me.

questions: some would say we are in dangerous times?
answers: Well we may be in dire straits but are you and i a part of a revolutionary government that controls the armed forces and is confronted with oppositionists who are our own kind of terrorists who we have to defeat. No i am not and you are not. We live in a complicated society.

questions: we are not in that position?
answers: Okay so then that analogy is irrelevant. Fine. I do not see any problem with that.

questions: the question would then be is violent praxis justified for us to overthrow a government?
answers: Now that is a different question. Now to what extent do i think that the soviet union and the united states have violated the un charter which bars the threat or use of force in international affairs. Well i do not know if you read the charter and you know the reasoning but it is pretty obvious that they did not back down on that.

questions: so you think this twentieth century idea of revolutionary movements is over?
answers: It is not just twentieth centuries. There are very rare occasions when you can even raise the question and we are not anywhere near those occasions. If you want to raise questions about imperialism you have to ask some serious questions.

questions: what is the legacy of jacobinism and leninism on the left?
answers: They are quite different first of all. In the case of jefferson and the founding fathers there was a strong commitment to classical liberalism just as in every case you look at. Franois lebrecht was one of the leading figures of eighteenth century french liberalism.

questions: do you think that within the coordinates of the entire marxist tradition there will always be this danger of going towards that edge?
answers: You know i do not regard lenin as part of my tradition frankly. What i think of him is more or less his point of view. I am not in favor of violence of any kind and having said that it is often necessary to use violence to defend our rights and even our lives.

questions: do you think that the new form of authoritarian capitalism that functions today in for example china or singapore is the new danger that we face today?
answers: It is a danger and there are many dangers of course. But yes i think its a pretty rotten system. It does keep the streets clean and people get a good technical education and so on but of primary importance is control. Dr. chomsky thanks very much for your time and insight noam.

questions: do you think that it is a part of it or is it some offshoot?
answers: You know there are a lot of radical left traditions. The ones that made any sense in my view were not committed to violence except in self defense. That includes members of the anti semitism sixties like the hashomer hatzair which was one of our groups.

questions: what do you think the role of students and the university is in revolutionary movements today?
answers: First of all to learn enough to understand what you are talking about. Then if your ideas are clarified enough ask questions let the questionser digression. As far as popular struggles go they tend to be on the periphery.

questions: do you think that for students in our universities today it is important to focus on these single issues because they contain within them the critique of the system?
answers: There is no particular reason to assume that there are no issues. There may be reasons that are more urgent than others and we should try to understand them and work to change them if we can. But in the united states we happen to live in a society dominated by a business sector so naturally the focus is on that.

questions: theory is sacred and we need it more than ever. how would you respond to zizek is claim?
answers: First of all i quite agree that there is a tremendous amount of misunderstanding and a lot of irrationality about this. In fact i would not have said it is irrational if you looked at the facts. Just take a look at what is happening with the trilateral commission and the bulletin of atomic scientists and you will see what i am talking about.

questions: and you have expressed a similar view arguing that student indebtedness is a technique of indoctrination and control. could you please elaborate on that?
answers: Well the first question that arises is whether there is an economic necessity for student debt. I do not have to tell students what the numbers are. It is over trillion dollars beyond credit card debt beyond student loan debt which is overwhelming in my opinion.

questions: obviously we need to organize and create student groups but what other more specific tactics would you suggest so that we can go beyond merely communicating this message about debt as a form of entrapment and indoctrination and move to demanding substantive change of some sort?
answers: There are a number of tactics. One tactic is to follow the example of the vietnam war. When the united states went to war it had to fight a guerrilla war against a much more advanced and well armed enemy. Secondary to that try to build popular organizations.

questions: what should happen to traditional humanities disciplines from your perspective given these pressures?
answers: Depends on whether we want to live in a civilized world or not. The wealth and richness of life does not come from having more gadgets in your hands. It comes from literature arts decent society decent human relations and many other things that you can not put a number on.

questions: what role do universities serve in a just or democratic society?
answers: Universities ought to be the place where as many people as possible like say the gi bill have the opportunity to develop their creative capacities their independence their joy of discovery their ability to work with each other to achieve desirable social ends that they can figure out. When students are at the university they are really at their most free. They know the most about everything they want to know.

questions: should the left in the united states hold barack obama more accountable?
answers: Accountable to what. There is no indication that he has any intention or ever had any interest in bringing about progressive changes. He is basically a moderate republican who happens to be running against the most extreme of the political spectrum.

questions: in other words the protections of personal liberties and majority rule are not compatible. how do we resolve this paradox?
answers: I think there is a paradox. Germany within the rest of europe was under the domination of the soviet union for a long period. They had a very lively democratic culture.

questions: i do not have a voice. therefore there is nothing i can do.?
answers: Well it is drilled into our heads from childhood that there are two kinds of questions you can ask. One kind of question is what do i think.? Well that is a very limited category maybe we could go beyond that.

questions: there were apparently two shooters two teenagers and one of the shooters is dead. the school has 600 students?
answers: Is there any motive or anything. We dont have any information. But it is a very, very sick individual. Thanks for bringing this to our attention.

questions: this is the latest. we do not have much information?
answers: So there is nothing understood about the background.

questions: nothing. so does this say something about the society we live in?
answers: If it was just one incident you could think maybe some psychotic individual or something. But it is been happening with unpleasant regularity and the violence of course is directed against people who look like you.

questions: but how much popular support is needed and what should it look like?
answers: Well it has to be extensive. Actually it can work. I happen to have just come back from ireland and one of the things i did there was meet with a group of workers at a plant called vita cortex. They are part of a system called troika which is a eurozone coordinated health system for the elderly.

questions: and that was in ireland?
answers: It was reported in the new york times. But it did not enter the national press.

questions: why are they so rare in the united states?
answers: Strikes of any kind are very rare especially since reagan who kind of broke the mandate against using scabs. That is outlawed everywhere. I think maybe apartheid south africa allowed it for a while.

questions: what are some of those?
answers: Let is take the first one which is the embargo against south africa. The united states has been trying since the 1980s to get the apartheid government to agree to an embargo on all exports of southafrica to the south and it has always been opposed.

questions: do you think this could grow and expand in the united states?
answers: It is quite significant. There is been very good work on this which ought to be read by gar alperovitz who is both an activist and an intellectual a very fine historian a terrific historian. He just wrote a book on the reagan years which is really good.

questions: and that is been around since the 1950s right?
answers: Goes back as far as you can go back to the fifties and the sixties. There was a counter movement which was more or less a civil rights movement. The 1960s were a significant period for this.

questions: how much do you think has changed with the propaganda model and where do you see it playing out most prominently today?
answers: Well ten years ago we had a re edition and we talked about some of the changes. One change is that we were too narrow. There are a number of filters that determine the framework of reporting and in our case the discussion of this topic was too narrowly focused to be of much general interest.

questions: so some progress?
answers: Yes. On the other hand the indoctrination system has gotten incredibly powerful. The examples that i mentioned like the right to work laws it is pretty shocking that that can succeed.

questions: but what do you think a post occupy movement looks like. what comes next?
answers: The occupy tactic was a remarkably successful tactic. If i would been asked a month before zuccotti park whether to do this i probably would have said you are crazy. But it worked extremely well.

questions: first i want to ask how you read the situation going on in the middle east i mean the arab spring do you see the arab spring as an optimistic beginning of democracy and breaking down the dictatorship statues in the region?
answers: It is an ongoing process. There have been some gains particularly in tunisia and egypt. In both countries there are far more openings for freedom of expression labor organizing and other achievements.

questions: if so then what are their interests in the success of the arab spring?
answers: The uprisings have internal roots. The west dislikes them and is strongly opposed to the rise of democracy and social reform here. To see why it is only necessary to look at the polls of public opinion undertaken by the leading us polling agencies.

questions: what should be the role of kurdish parties like in the situation in syria how can they protect their rights and confirm it in the future constitution of the country?
answers: It is not easy to imagine what might emerge from syrian society after the revolution. Will it be a model for the rest of iraq or will its members face new kinds of oppression and even worse violence as they try to carve out a place in an increasingly hostile and exclusionary society.

questions: can you elaborate on this?
answers: The islamic parties were the only ones that could function under the dictatorship they at least had the mosques in fact considerably more opportunities. The us however has a terrible record of co opting the muslim world it has done it ever since it took over the palestinian areas and it will continue to do it probably with harsher repression.

questions: in that situation europe and usa may have different positions while middle east countries themselves really want to establish democracy which position you think better to be taken by those pro democratic countries?
answers: I do not know which pro democracy countries you have in mind. For one thing countries are not pro or anti democratic. Sectors within them are.

questions: there might be possibilities that they will follow a kind of social democratic system like some of eu countries or a neo liberal system like what is existing in us or an islamic system?
answers: First of all those opinions are hardly ever expressed even in the liberal parts of the united states. In fact the extreme right wing nativists on the national political scene almost never say anything even moderately like that. But it is true that in more or less free societies opinion can be expressed more freely.

questions: us has been claiming that they carry democracy promotion program for the middle east do you think that they help to reshape the design of this countries in a way that brings prosperity for the nations at least to solve the basic problems?
answers: That is what they are trying to do. The arab spring was a very positive development mostly because of the popular organizations which played a major role in breaking down the power of harsh dictatorships and opening up the societies to freedom and democracy. Us planners seek to duplicate that success and to serve the interests that are represented by the organizations that springing up in the region.

questions: does establishing a kurdish state solve the problems?
answers: In this world statelessness poses specific problems as kosovo is case is obvious. Having a state should at best solve some of them but many others will remain as history and logic reveal and as the region itself becomes more self governing.

questions: what kind of problems you think can not be solved via having an independent state for kurds especially iraqi kurds in this case?
answers: It is a serious problem how to deal with the fact that there is not a single state that will do anything for them. How do you proceed to give them any sort of support whatever it may be in the international community. As for pakistan it has a problem. Its relations with iran are not very good.

questions: so do you believe that ideology has ended in the west and it is at the top of progressing in the middle east?
answers: Nothing remotely like it. Take say the soviet union which was the ideological model for most of the world.

questions: how. can you elaborate on this a little?
answers: The west is torn by serious internal conflicts ideological if you like concerning the course that governments and societies should pursue. And some doctrines are widely held among elites at the level of near religious fanaticism for example faith in the fundamental benevolence of western powers hampered sometimes by naivete and error.

questions: you have always taken the position that islamic fundamentalism and islamic currents develop in those countries where secularism failed do you think what is going on in egypt is a pretty good reference to that?
answers: Secular nationalism did not exactly fail. It was crushed by a combination of external force internal corruption and subordination to external power. But secular currents are quite vibrant and might yet prevail just as in the case of russia after the bolshevik revolution.

questions: finally in those conflicts between different ideologies and different external interferences which kind of state and constitution can be the best one with a great regard to the social and historical position of the region?
answers: I do not see any conflict. First of all the ideologies conflict everywhere. Clash of civilizations is one major conflict today.

questions: maybe we could start with your personal life and your double career in linguistics and political activism. do you like that kind of work?
answers: If i had the time i would spend far more time doing work on language philosophy cognitive science topics that are intellectually very interesting. But a large part of my life is given to one or another form of political activity reading writing organising activism and so on. Which is worth doing it is necessary but it does not have to be done day after day.

questions: i find this to be true when i talk to a lot of my friends. did you always know what you wanted to do?
answers: That is a problem i never had for me there was always too much that i was interested in doing. I am not sure how widespread this is take say a craftsman i happen to have no particular skill in anything but i can not imagine doing anything creative with my hands or playing an instrument.

questions: so you think that basically a person knows what it is that he or she wants to do?
answers: Under the right circumstances that would be true. Children for example are naturally curious they want to know about all sorts of things but that generally gets knocked out of their heads. They are put into disciplined structures things are organised for them to act in certain ways so it tends to get beaten away from you.

questions: what is his name?
answers: David noble. He has a couple of very good books one of them is called forces of production. This is a historical analysis of the united states how development took place.

questions: what is your personal work routine. how do manage to work so much?
answers: Well my wife died a couple of years ago and since then i have done nothing but work. I see my children once in a while but almost nothing else. Before that i worked pretty hard but had a personal life outside.

questions: how many hours of sleep do you get?
answers: I try to get about six or seven hours. It is a pretty crazy life tremendous number of talks and meetings so i do not have anywhere near as much time as i would like to just plain work because other things crowd in. But i nearly never have any free time i never go to the movies or out to dinner.

questions: what in your mind have been the lessons to take away from the elections?
answers: The united states is a special case and for me very interesting. It is studied carefully and we know a lot about it. One of the most striking features of elections is the class based character of them which is not surprising.

questions: could even high union density be enough to address a host of newer problems like climate catastrophe which are unlikely to be solved through simply a more social democratic political system?
answers: You have to look at american history. The us has been to an unusual extent a business run society i mentioned some of it and it has a very violent labor history much more so than europe. In fact workers were getting murdered in strikes up through the late 1930s and into the early 40s as the economy tanked and the business world turned against labor.

questions: how feasible is this strategy and what are your thoughts on the united steelworkers memorandum of agreement with mondrag n a high tech multibillion dollar co op in spain?
answers: It is a good move but notice that this means going back to the 19th century. There were much better ways of doing things. Go back a century and a half to early african american slaves who were kept in chains not as slaves but as drunks and domestic servants and so on. How do you get them to free themselves.

questions: do you think that propaganda in a post citizens united era is seeing diminishing returns and that controlling the public mind is becoming harder?
answers: It is doing fine. The propaganda is working very effectively. Take what we were just discussing public unions public teachers getting together and pressing for progressive legislation.

questions: and what about the number of progressive state ballot propositions that passed despite vigorous propaganda campaigns?
answers: Well that is a matter of interpretation. Take what happened in mexico. There was a very lively popular movement there from 1967 to 1973.

questions: but given state level electoral initiatives that legalized marijuana in washington and colorado and other reproducible initiatives like north dakota is state bank or vermont is attempt at single payer health care is it worth re evaluating where best to invest energy and resources?
answers: I do not know if you re evaluate. You just do what is likely to work and it is different at different times and different places. So what you can do in ver mont will not work in georgia.

questions: meanwhile the regional chief economist of the world bank introduced a recent paper on reduced inequality in latin america by saying latin america is approaching the norm of advanced economies but unfortunately advanced economies are approaching the norm of the latin america model.?
answers: That is true. That points to the fact that the neoliberal assault on the population has been extremely harmful. It has widened the wealth and the power gap which is grotesque.

questions: how much of it owes to the institutional priorities of the federal reserve and its dual mandate and how much does intellectual culture account for?
answers: I do not really know how to divide them. How the institutions function depends on the reigning culture and the same institutions could function differently. So take the fed which is basically a public relations industry.

questions: in practice we do not do it nearly enough but it is not the economic growth per se that is the problem.?
answers: I think there is a serious misunderstanding about what is called the troika. It did not just come out of nowhere. They had been calling for some time for a treaty organization and they finally got around to implementing it.

questions: if so what kinds of industrialization would be best and how could such a process be reconciled with climate change and managed with democratic participation?
answers: First of all it has to be faced. There is overwhelming evidence about that both in the sciences and in political science. Just take a look at the arXiv.

questions: and given their sterling reputations in the public sphere is there a way to hold these accountability groups accountable?
answers: They do some good things. They are part of the educated liberal intellectual elite and suffer from its deficiencies so you hold them accountable in certain respects but not in others. Take human rights watch or nongovernmental organization watch.

questions: do you see these as isolated incidents or as part of a larger trend?
answers: The coup in honduras is one act and the overthrow of lugo is another. The effort to reestablish military bases in chile is yet another act. They are joined by actions all over the continent.

questions: they happen to be the hemisphere is poorest and most vulnerable countries?
answers: Haiti and honduras are indeed the poorest. But they are also the countries that the us has sent the most military aid. So for example in 1990 there was a fdr initiative to try to stimulate the economy.

questions: over the past three years what have been some of the benefits and trade offs of his participation and do you see any lessons to take away?
answers: Well i still would say essentially that. I think he knows what he is doing and i trust his judgment and his integrity paul farmer that is i am not talking about clinton.

questions: what would you recommend as appropriate steps forward for left leaning latin american countries regarding haiti?
answers: Brazil had the leading role. I was kind of surprised at that frankly particularly when the harmful effects of the minustah operation have become more and more clear through the past year particularly with the recent court case against bradley chelsea manning julian assange and many others.

questions: yet there is a general aversion to criticize the un?
answers: Well first of all what it is not. Its not that criticism is taboo. There are very strict bounds on what can be said in the world wide press.

questions: with the creation of new military bases there do you see the united states opening a new chapter of reagan style support for death squad governance?
answers: Well as you indicated it will depend on what happens in haiti. Right now the us is providing about half the total amount of aid that is needed and probably more in the near future.

questions: are large actions like the recent protest at western hemisphere institute for security cooperation formerly the school of the americas an indication of more citizen engagement on such issues given that the scope of today is crimes is smaller than that of the 1980s?
answers: Regarding the protests yes sure they ought to take place. There is no doubt about it. But the protest against the war in iraq surely qualifies as a civil disobedience.

questions: many had hopes for a more progressive second term but what are the prospects that the obama administration will have simply a more moderated second term like that of george w. bush?
answers: I do not even think it will differ much from the first term either. The bush administration was so radically extremist in its first terms that it almost destroyed the country. But by the second terms of the gop it began to moderate somewhat and to move towards some kinds of accommodation with the opposition.

questions: are there specific methods for regular people to influence supranational policies given that they are so far removed?
answers: It is the kind of thing you have to do in the back alleys of town. Go back to the 1920s and 1930s if there was an organized labor movement it tried to get the government to give public assistance. That was a major activity of the working class in this country in quite substantial measure until the early sixties at least.

questions: what is your take on america is human rights record over the past four years and can you contrast obama is policies with those of his predecessor george w. bush?
answers: It is hard to compare them because they are somewhat different natomasculine in style but there are some striking similarities. Obamacare is a good example. It was predicted by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office that if it were enacted today it would lead to 22 million more uninsured people by 2026 and to a 40 percent increase in the uninsured rate.

questions: also what do you think about obama is promise of cia reforms in 2008 and how has the reality of his presidency stacked up to those promises?
answers: There have been some presidential orders expressing disapproval of the most extreme forms of torture but bagram remains open and uninspected. That is probably the worst in afghanistan. Guantanamo is still open but it is unlikely that serious torture is going on at guanta luaban.

questions: conversely can refusing to intervene be justified when entire cities such as misrata benghazi aleppo and homs were or are being threatened with utter destruction and tens of thousands of civilians are being killed?
answers: Well let is start with syria. The one thing i disagree with in what you said is that i doubt very much that russia and china had anything to do with the lack of us or western military intervention in syrian affairs. In fact i almost doubt that they even knew what was going on.

questions: that was the intervention for which the justification was claimed to be the prevention of the destruction of benghazi?
answers: Well we do not know if benhamghazi was gonna be destroyed but it was called to prevent a possible massacre. You can debate how likely the attack was but personally i felt that if there was going be an attack it would be legitimate to use force to stop it.

questions: i think recently when you returned you described gaza as the largest open air prison in the world and i wonder if you might share some reflections from your trip with our listeners?
answers: Well actually that characterization of prison is not really mine. It is a very common one and there are good reasons for that. As far as my knowledge the closest comparable system is in guatemala.

questions: professor chomsky given the history and the siege and the fact that palestine is divided into multiple parts do you see any way to peace?
answers: There is a lot of complicated problems in the world where you can barely think of the solution you could run through them alphabetically.

questions: should or could play a role in the peace process as some sort of arbiter if that is even possible given the history of bias towards one side?
answers: The bush administration has shown very little interest in peace and even less in constructive steps towards peace. They are more interested in reinforcing existing power structures and in pursuing their own extreme programs of militarization of space and control of energy resources. There is little evidence of any significant change in that respect during the eight years in office.

questions: or do you think that it is made it more disparate or harder to get a clear picture because its coming from so many different sources?
answers: The social media have been very valuable. In fact they are probably the most valuable source of independent news that i know of. But there are a lot of other uses too. For example there is a book that just came out on tunisia i do not think you can find it anywhere else.

questions: dumbed down in a way?
answers: I think part of the reason for the outrage is that the edward said doctrine is so obviously wrong. There is nothing remotely like it in the world. I mean if you go back to say the greeks and look at the range of warfare they were just as violent as the us.

questions: it feels to me like its been an organic community action and people talking to each other and i was just wondering if you could speak to the newest developments?
answers: Actually that book you mentioned is really a collection of talks and interviews. The occupy movement began last september a year ago. It was a brilliant tactic it worked great.

questions: i think there was some orthodoxies at some of the camps that people were afraid that ows would be co opted and the ideology of ows what ever that was at the time was going to be spoiled somehow by including other groups progressive groups?
answers: You know this is not a membership movement so i do not know what it means exactly to include or exclude others. If people want to participate great. They may participate with the same kind of general goals but specific interests.

questions: it is about the recent organization of unskilled labor such as workers in the fast food industry and walmart workers and whether you see that as possibly the future and a way to revitalize the labor movement?
answers: Yeah certainly is. Things like that have happened over and over. Remember the farm workers union which developed after the war.

questions: unbelievable?
answers: And that is the minimum wage the point of and level of survivability. I mean what do you eat for dinner.

questions: i presume because of the propaganda the public dialogue that just demonized anyone who is not rich?
answers: Which includes virtually the entire intellectual class. So for example there is a book coming out by a very fine young analytic philosopher jason stanley called the end of ideology which is basically a critique of everything around the enlightenment which started with humboldt the founder of classical liberalism and so on.

questions: anyone who is not rich you are a failure?
answers: Oh yeah you know if you can go back 150 years this is an old story in the united states going way back to the origins of the industrial revolution right around eastern massachusetts where i am. Working people bitterly opposed the way in which industrialization was being carried out.

questions: the right to work for less?
answers: Yeah listen i am sorry but i have to leave i will be back in a couple of weeks. Let me make one point that it has been recognized for a long time that there is a labor movement and that is that a government that enforces a one or two worker family is wage labor is probably as bad or worse. So what can you do except try to organize.

questions: great well we really appreciate your time and your insights?
answers: Good to talk to you bye. Lm sm thank you. P.s noam chomsky thanks for having us. If you have time to spare we would appreciate it if we could take a short break and you can come back and chat when we are back.

questions: how does our brain give rise to our cognitive abilities and could this ever be implemented in a machine?
answers: Speaking in the symposium was not so enthused. Chomsky critiqued the field of ai for adopting an approach reminiscent of behaviorism except in more modern computationally sophisticated form.

questions: if you ask neuroscientists why understanding the brain is so difficult they give you very intellectually unsatisfying answers like that the brain has billions of cells and we can not record from all of them and so on?
answers: There is something to that. When you study the anatomy and physiology of the lung you are studying a very different system than you were just beginning to study. Take the study of how the immune system works let is take a look at what you call the passive system the visual system and then the vocal system because those are more complex systems.

questions: like the chemists?
answers: If a molecule is too big you give it to the chemist. The molecule will be smaller the more it is studied the better. Now why is that. That is the way the scientific method works.

questions: like hebbian plasticity.?
answers: Well like strengthening synaptic connections. Gallistel has been arguing for years that if you want to study the brain properly you should begin kind of like marr by asking what tasks is it performing. So he is mostly interested in insects and nematode flies but there are other tasks as well.

questions: these are the kinds of statements that their experiments generate?
answers: If you look at the kind of things that are discussed here you will find that the verbal behavior is part of a much broader system of beliefs and understanding. The whole system is much more complex than just the language system but the connection is there.

questions: is that conceptually flawed?
answers: Well you know you may get useful information from it. But if what is actually going on is some kind of computation involving computational units you are not going to find them that way. It is kind OF looking at the wrong lamp post sort of.

questions: advocates of this field do not stop to ask if the wiring diagram is the right level of abstraction maybe it is not so what is your view on that?
answers: Well there are much simpler questions.

questions: i think 300?
answers: Still you can not predict what the thing is going to do. Maybe because you are looking in the wrong place. Let me give you an example. If you walked into a museum you would see things that looked like they were from the 1930s but were actually parts of the late 19th century.

questions: my question is what do you think explains that shift and is it a step in the right direction?
answers: I heard pat winston give a talk about this years ago. One of the points he made was that ai and robotics got to the point where you could actually do things that were useful so it turned to practical applications and somewhat maybe not abandoned but put to an end the pursuit of general goals.

questions: so it shifted to engineering?
answers: It became well which is understandable but would of course direct people away from the original questions. I have to say myself that i was very skeptical about the initial work.

questions: in engineering?
answers: But away from understanding. Yeah maybe some effective engineering. And it is kind of interesting to see what happened to engineering because it was once thought of as the domain of the mad scientist.

questions: you have argued famously that speaking of the probability of a sentence is unintelligible on its own?
