answers: Well you can get a number if you want but it does not mean anything because the number comes from fixed data. It is as if someone asked me how many cars there are in the world.

questions: but probability theory just serves as a kind of glue between noisy data and very rich mental representations?
answers: Well there is nothing wrong with statistics if the data is well behaved.

questions: but does it have a role?
answers: If you can use it fine. But the question is what are you using it for. First of all first questions is is there any point in understanding noisy data like that. Answer there is very little there apart from maybe to give you an idea of what the data is like and secondly maybe a kind of a proxy for what you might expect.

questions: well we are bombarded with it it is one of marr is examples we are faced with noisy data all the time from our retina to?
answers: That is true. But what he says is let is ask ourselves how the biological system is picking out of that noise things that are significant. The retina is not trying to duplicate the noise that comes in so it does not have a high rate of success for a sensory system that has a limited capacity.

questions: you take that as convincing evidence that activation or lack of activation for the brain area?
answers: It is evidence you would want more of course. But this is the kind of evidence both on the linguistics side you look at how languages work they do not use things like third word in sentence. Take a simple sentence like instinctively eagles that fly swim well instinctively goes with swim it does not go with fly even though it did not exist in the first place.

questions: in the domain of biology would you consider the work of mendel as a successful case where you take this noisy data essentially counts and you leap to postulate this theoretical object?
answers: Well throwing out a lot of the data that did not work. First of all there was some noisy work done by gar alperovitz and others on renormalization. But that is so slight that i can not comment on it beyond saying it is not significant.

questions: but seeing the ratio that made sense given the theory?
answers: Yeah he did the right thing. He let the theories guide the data. There was counter data which was more or less dismissed you know you do not put it in your papers because it is not there if you want to keep a job.

questions: that would go against the reductionist approach of looking for molecules that are correlates of?
answers: Yeah. In fact the reduced approach has often been shown to be wrong. The unification approach makes sense as an answer.

questions: and implicit in marr it seems that you can not work on all three in parallel it has to proceed top down which is a very stringent requirement given that science usually does not work that way?
answers: Well he would not have allowed it. He thought it was counter productive. But there is no doubt that discovering more about the mechanisms is what leads to the next step.

questions: information processing systems?
answers: Yeah like vision. There is some data out there it is a processing system and something goes on inside. It may not be very well designed for cognitive systems but it has to have some basis.

questions: it is very poor but yeah?
answers: Okay. But that is not the point. The question is what is the consequence of imposing this decision on all of us. Well the consequences are two very simple.

questions: but since we make mistakes is not that evidence of a process gone wrong?
answers: That is the process of using the internal system. But in fact if you look at the way the system is actually used the evidence you would expect is that there is going to be a systematic error that goes on all the time. So take say ordinary mathematics the kind of work you do with ordinary tools and so on.

questions: but that is a fundamentally different activity from me adding up small numbers in my head which surely does have some kind of algorithm?
answers: Not necessarily. There is an algorithm for the process in both cases. But the algorithm itself is not a property of the language it is just a way of describing the way the system is set up. Okay so what is the grammar of english.

questions: it just seems like an astounding task to go from a computational level theory like peano axioms to marr level 3 of the?
answers: What is the point of all these levels. They are just levels on a different scale. In fact when you think about it the whole structure of language is extremely simple.

questions: mechanisms and implementations?
answers: Oh i will talk about that in a minute. But the first question that comes to mind is how do we study these phenomena. So we have to study the data.

questions: without an algorithm at least?
answers: Well i do not think that is true. Maybe information about how it is used that will tell you something about the mechanisms. But some higher intelligence maybe higher than ours would see that there is an internal system its got a physiological basis and i can study the molecular basis of that and deduce from that what the external system is likely to be like.

questions: so the logic for studying cognitive and language systems using this kind of marr approach makes sense but since you have argued that language capacity is part of the genetic endowment you could apply it to other biological systems like the immune system the circulatory system?
answers: Certainly i think it is very similar. You can say the same thing about study of visual systems. Theologians have a field called cognitive science.

questions: it might even be simpler in fact to do it for those systems than for cognition?
answers: Though you would expect different answers. You can do the same thing with the digestive system. Suppose somebody has a cold.

questions: but that is precisely what the biologists are doing they are taking the sick people with the sick digestive system comparing them to the normals and measuring these molecular properties?
answers: It is very similar to what you would expect. The study of the digestive systems of hominids suggests that this is a common feature of human evolution long before anatomically modern humans appeared.

questions: it is a highly fundable approach because you are claiming to study sick people?
answers: The fact is that you can not fund anything. So for example if you wanted to fund study of the immune system you would have to demonstrate that the therapy is effective. But that is not what you want to do.

questions: but if you ask what is the computational problem that is being solved by the lung that is very difficult to even think it is not obviously an information processing kind of problem?
answers: No but there is no reason to assume that all of biology is computational. There may be reasons to think that cognition is. And in fact gallistel has shown that if we can develop a theory of biological computation that will explain a lot of things that are puzzling about the biology of the system.

questions: these systems evolved together reusing many of the same parts same molecules pathways. cells are computing things?
answers: You do not study the lung by asking what cells compute and why. You study other organs and structures but you are not going to expect to find the answers. An organism is a highly modular system has a lot of complex subsystems which are more or less internally integrated.

questions: no sure but i am saying you would apply the same approach to study each of the modules?
answers: Not necessarily not if the module is different. Some modules may be computational others may not be.

questions: so what would you think would be an adequate theory that is explanatory rather than just predicting data the statistical way what would be an adequate theory of these systems that are not computing systems can we even understand them?
answers: Sure. You can understand a lot about say what makes an embryo turn into a chicken rather like you or a mouse let is say. It is a very intricate system involves all kinds of chemical interactions all sorts of other things. To try to understand it you have to start with very simple systems.

questions: though if you study the chemical interactions it might lead you into what you have called just a redescription of the phenomena?
answers: Or an explanation. Because maybe that is directly crucially related to the question of why it is there in the first place. Let is just take a look at that.

questions: you have simply found a switch and hit that switch?
answers: But then you look further and find out what makes this gene do such and such under these circumstances and do something else under different circumstances. So let is take the example of vietnam. In the early 1960s when there was strong support for vc na> it was undoubtedly an attempt to undermine the war effort.

questions: but if genes are the wrong level of abstraction you would be screwed?
answers: Then you will not get the right answer. And maybe they are not. For example it is notoriously difficult to account for how an organism arises from a genetic endowment.

questions: you have argued that this does not explain anything because you can always appeal to these two principles of mutation and selection?
answers: Well you could wave your hands at them but they might be right. It could be that say the development of your arithmetical capacity arose from random changes in the structure of the gene. If it turned out to be true fine. I would not be upset.

questions: it seems like a truism?
answers: Well i mean does not mean it is false. Truisms are true..i mean an islamic state is not a true democracy. But the concept of democracy as you know is a very useful concept for organizing society. Clinton did not call it a democracy when he was running it.

questions: but they do not explain much?
answers: Maybe that is the highest level of explanation you can get. If you want to understand the world you have to work at the most abstract level possible. Let is take the simplest case that you mentioned intelligence as an example.

questions: well they constrain the biology sure?
answers: Okay well then it is not just random mutation and selection. It goes on all the way up to the design of the organism. So the question is does it have an evolutionary purpose.

questions: is there anything that can be gleaned about these high level cognitive tasks from these comparative evolutionary studies or is it premature?
answers: I am not saying it is the wrong approach but i do not know anything useful about it. Nor would you expect to. All the studies you mentioned are kind of preliminary.

questions: you do not have any examples where this evolutionary analysis has informed something. like foxp2 mutations.?
answers: Fox p2 is kind of interesting but it does have nothing to do with language. It has to with fine motor coordinations and things like that. Which takes place in the use of language like when you speak you control your lips and so on but all that is very peripheral to language and we know this because we have the comparative anatomy and all this stuff.

questions: but it might constrain it like physics constrains meiosis?
answers: It could but there is very little evidence of that. So for example the left end left in the sense of early of a sentence has different properties from the right end. If you want to ask a question let is say who did you see.

questions: it enabled better thought before externalization?
answers: You do not have to have any thought for example to notice that the passage of time does not alter the structure of the sentence. The same is true of visual space and the like. You can not say that jaywalking is more dangerous than standing on the corner.

questions: unless the externalization and the internal thought system are coupled in ways we just do not predict?
answers: It is a very natural system. We all have a physiological system which is our mental beeeep and an internal system that is used for storing our memories. The two are very closely coupled and i think you can see it in people if you look closely.

questions: rather than guiding it towards behaviorism which seems to be an intuition that many say neuroscientists have?
answers: Philosophy of science is a very interesting field but i do not think it really contribute to science it learns from science. It tries to understand what the sciences do why do they achieve things what are the wrong paths see if we can codify that and come up with better theories. What i think is valuable is the history of scientific thinking.

questions: like in aristotelian physics?
answers: No that is the aristotlean physics. The best and greatest scientists thought that was answer. Galileo allowed himself to be puzzled by it.

questions: your current visit to the gaza strip is said to be within your own attempt to help break the israeli siege of gaza. why has it taken place now?
answers: It has been a matter of arrangements and you know i am here taking part in the linguistic conference for islamic universities and this is a good chance for me to assist in this very important cause.

questions: do you agree or not agree do you agree partially?
answers: There was never any question of whether it was going to happen. In fact in the case of srebrenica women and children were trucked out and then came you know the massacre. I mean i was there but you do not know in advance what the consequences are going say will it lead to a humanitarian catastrophe.

questions: some call for a two state solution between palestine and israel while others call for a one democratic state solution. which is more workable for you?
answers: It is not a choice. I have been in favor of the what is called a binational state. In fact i wrote about it over 30 years ago in the preface to american imperial power and the new world. So i think it makes a good deal of sense both economically and politically.

questions: do you see such lobbying by large technology companies translating into a more open and free internet and eventually into a more meaningful commons?
answers: The internet since it is publicly created ought to be publicly controlled. After all the first internet was publicly funded. That is the model we have to follow if we hope to have a truly democratic internet.

questions: what are your thoughts one how existing or new government policies laws and regulations promote or limit technological innovations that increase the exercise of first amendment freedoms?
answers: Technology provides means for expression and interchange and so on so yes it should be free and open but there are a lot of constraints on how its used. We should not want to permit providers for example to have control over access. Again that is a case for more regulation.

questions: so you see this as something similar to what you described as following the propaganda model in mass media?
answers: The similarity is that concentration of capital influences virtually everything that goes on. It influences the way the media functions it very powerfully influences how the government works and it of course influences corporate sector elements like say how google or amazon present materials that reach the public.

questions: do you think the hostility to wikileaks comes from specific materials being revealed or a more general fear of new forms of communication that cannot be controlled by law or force?
answers: Its just hatred of democracy. Long before the technology revolution there was declassification of documents and i have spent quite a lot of time studying declassified internal planning and communication. In fact anybody who is worked through the internal record can see very clearly that the reason for classification is very rarely to protect the state or the society from enemies.

questions: so the kind of content that wikileaks revealed is different to what the pentagon papers revealed?
answers: Totally different. In fact there were changes.

questions: but the medium is different and you were involved in publishing it in print format?
answers: Yes and also i had them in advance. Actually when dan ellsberg was underground i was one of the people there were a number of people who were giving out materials to the press. This was in the early eighties i am sure.

questions: but wikileaks happened through the internet which was not really anticipated then?
answers: Not it wasn't then nobody was doing it. Just take a look at the trajectory of things. The first thing that comes to mind is of course the pentagon papers.

questions: do you see a difference in the way they were distributed and that itself being more of a threat?
answers: Yeah its different but i think its basically the same threat. The threat is that the public will know what the government is up to. Any system of power is going to want to keep free from public surveillance that is natural.

questions: can you say something about why technology companies that advocate non censorship such as google in china but do not support those like julian assange?
answers: Its worst than that. They help shut down the site. Every day. Go back to jan 1 st. for example if you look at the first few days of his site is first page it is not even displayed.

questions: compared to mass media in the united states which you have stated as serving the interest of the elite do you see the internet playing a role in promoting minority rights and majority role?
answers: Like most technological innovations the Internet has mixed effects. It is a neutral instrument. Technology can be used to liberate or enslave and there are many illustrations of that today.

questions: its been argued that the internet is a paradigm shift and able to work as a kind of technology unlike anything before it?
answers: It is different of course. Just take ease of interchange between people. Your email can be read by people from around the world in fact faster than letter on the other hand the transition from sailing ship to telegraphs was far greater than the shift from the postal service to email which was almost instantaneous.

questions: it has the ability to connect everyone to everyone else?
answers: Superficially. Very superfically. So take social media take a look at the way they are used.

questions: facebook is is encouraging organ donations by allowing users to reveal their organ donation status?
answers: That is a good step. Allowing people to be more open and transparent is good. Keeping donations secret is even better.

questions: what are your thoughts on companies that started as a communications medium openly entering domains that are traditionally of activism or government?
answers: Well my own feeling is that a corporation has no right to have a political or social influence. Why should it. I happen to agree with the anti dictatorship policies but i do not think it is the role of general electric to support them or oppose them i think the public should make its own decisions about these matters.

questions: other than the fact that they are corporations what do you see as the similarities and differences between a corporation like google and general electric?
answers: Well there are differences. There is a lot more planning going on here. They have a product. Some do not.

questions: i think a lot of silicon valley companies do see themselves as different in terms of decentralization of power or amplification of people is voices that did not exist before?
answers: Its true that contemporary technology makes it easier to do it all the time but its kind of like asking how do we make the railroads more efficient. The same is true of the internet. It is more difficult to make changes in the old fashion industries than to move into the new fashion ones.

questions: so you think this hope put on internet as an empowering machine is false?
answers: No its not false the same hope is true for the printing press. The levellers in england in the seventeenth century printed their pamphlets at the risk of destruction and they had to rely on the internet to distribute them. Same idea with the print press which relied on public support.

questions: lastly i want to ask you can you tall about free association as you have talked about it in relation to how individuals associate on the internet today?
answers: Same mixed story. A lot of association is highly constructive. There are people interacting interchanging ideas making plans coordinating activities take any of the popular movements a whole range of things.

questions: s. have you ever thought about becoming a politician yourself?
answers: No. First of all i would be terrible at it. I will just give you one simple example: how should i vote in the next election? Well i should probably vote for obama.

questions: does it also have something to do with your beliefs about how the political system actually works?
answers: I do not criticize people in private who are inside the ideological system. But i think i can do more elsewhere. Usually the system responds to popular activism much as it did in the case of vietnam and the 1960s when i was involved.

questions: the social movement of the day camps at public spaces and calls itself occupy. what do you think has occupy achieved so far?
answers: It achieved a lot in two aspects. It very significantly affected public sensibility and public discourse. The imagery that is spread over right through the mainstream that occupy uses is a very dangerous one.

questions: and the second aspect?
answers: The occupy movement spontaneously created communities of mutual support mutual aid. The common kitchen the libraries. These are maybe even more important. Not just in my opinion but also in the general american experience.

questions: if you compare it to the tea party movement?
answers: There is a difference. The nazis were not calling for genocide. But the turkish nationalists did and the catholics did not exactly agree with it but they got together and called for it.

questions: the tea party succeeded in sending dozens of their supporters to the senate and to the congress. in this way they are effective?
answers: As long as they can be the storm troopers for the corporate sector they will succeed. The republicans mobilize them like the religious right they have to. These are people who have been trained to hate government and everything it stands for they do not have any respect for it.

questions: because of their irrationality?
answers: Yes take a look at german history. In the early days of the nazis the business community the industrialists they supported them. They were the ones who did smash up the unions and who went after the left and so on because they thought that was their best hope of controlling the population. See what happened.

questions: and european answer to the financial and the so called euro crisis?
answers: The u. s. reaction has been somewhat better than the in some respects of the brexit vote in greece. The united states has somewhat limited control over the euro area treasury department has issued statements indicating that it will allow some degree of flexibility in the budget but only under certain conditions.

questions: but he also said that the fiscal pact has to be backed by a growth pact?
answers: Finally they are talking about what should have been done in the first place. There are plenty of resources in europe to carry out stimulation of demand and so on. But the idea of imposing austerity under recession is a recipe for suicide.

questions: why do you think that this is the intention?
answers: Just look at the people who are designing the policies. They never liked the welfare state they thought it was a welfare queen. Europe was an island of relative civilized life style perfectly capable of supporting a large scale industrial economy.

questions: the rationale that german chancellor angela merkel puts forward is that we have a debt crisis and in times of debt you have got to cut spending?
answers: In the eurozone in particular there has been a tendency under the leadership of merkels to go back to the gold standard. The Bundesbank has gone even further andQ has said that under no circumstances can the european union be considered a debtor nation.

questions: do you think countries like greece should have defaulted?
answers: Greece has some serious internal problems. They just did not collect tax the rich were undisciplined and there is too much bureaucracy. But the debt is a dual responsibility.

questions: but there always has to be some enforcement or guarantee that the debts are paid back?
answers: Not in capitalism. But in real life it is your neighbor is problem. They have to subject themselves to austerity sometimes even to violence to make sure the debt is paid.

questions: people in the richer european countries fear that increasing spending will lead to higher debts?
answers: Not if the money is used the way it was used in east asia. They used it for capital investment and industrial policy programs. So taiwan and south korea japan earlier they moved from quite poor peasant societies to richer and developed societies and suffered the same fate because they did not have the resources to absorb the increase in spending.

questions: there is nothing more neoliberal than the consumer swiss writer adolf muschg once noted. but should not we protect the consumer?
answers: Not in the least. In fact it is the other way around. The financial sector in its current form was originally designed to serve the needs of the very wealthy.

questions: but what if you can not raise standards in china?
answers: There is a way to deal with it indirectly. When there were massive protests against foxconn this year chinas reacted by making some changes allowing some degree of independent unions that have been permitted to slightly reduce the onerous conditions that sort of forced workers into this beeeep labor. That is about it.

questions: so why not tax them for exploiting workers and the environment in those countries?
answers: Yes make them pay to raise the standards. I mean corporate profits have gone through the roof. Now there is a study by economists from the university of massachusetts amherst that unused corporate banking and corporation profits amount to about 1.

questions: what is your assessment of the first term of president barack obama?
answers: Frankly i did not expect much. He came into office with a lot of pent up anger and discontent about the policies of his predecessor joe sanders and his administration.

questions: because they were major contributors to his campaign?
answers: Some of them yeah. Others we do not even know about. But mostly it was just a big donor is network.

questions: still obama tried to improve things like introducing universal healthcare?
answers: It is a mixed story because there have been some improvements. So for example a couple of months ago a study was done in canada which compared the us health care system with that of other rich countries and it was quite dramatic the difference was enormous.

questions: but obama had to compromise with what could get passed in the senate?
answers: Some of his supporters argue that it was the best that could be done given the political circumstances. But that is by no means obvious. The president has a lot of power for example he can appeal to a majority of the population which is what a president must do in an election even if it is a lost cause.

questions: president actually would have been hanged. does that apply to obama as well?
answers: Look at the global assassination campaign. It violates principles going back to magna carta and so on. How can the united states tolerate this.

questions: you are referring to the drones in pakistan somalia and yemen?
answers: Yes. If the president decides to kill somebody you kill him and whoever else happens to be standing around. The foundations of anglo american law and by now pretty much of the world has what is called the presumption of innocence that you can punish someone if you demonstrate that they are guilty in a court of law not just a secret tribunal.

questions: would you prefer a police action if you think that there are terrorists around planning attacks against the united states?
answers: Suppose somebody in italy wants to rob the store. I would not arrest them. At least under the circumstances i think it is proper for the police to make arrests.

questions: is there actually any political leader on the global scene who is doing a good job in your opinion?
answers: Leaders technically do not do a lot. If you are in a position of power you usually do something to extend it.

questions: so do you think that political leaders are generally immune from your advice?
answers: Of course. Mine or anyone else is. There are intellectuals who like to pretend that they are influential and influential people do not listen to advice.

questions: and that is the reason you try to address the general population?
answers: Yes. And i am not telling political leaders anything they do not know. If i were to tell angela merkel austerity under recession is harmful to the economy she does not have to hear it from me because i know it perfectly well from my own experience as a working class immigrant in the 1930s and 40s.

questions: and michael greenberg writes in the new york review of books about how a police satellite truck was for weeks parked in front of the apartment building where one of the core organizers for ows lived the police were apparently monitoring people who came in to see her.?
answers: It was never in doubt that the authorities would act to terminate the occupations. The only question was when and how. It appeared to be a nationally coordinated effort implemented in different ways throughout the country.

questions: should they be forming alliances with more broadly based social change movements like ows?
answers: I do not recall being critical of the narrow focus in itself. It is often well justified. But the atomization that is so prevalent in the society as a whole is harmful to individual movements which could benefit greatly from participation in a common enterprise with many complementary facets which will in fact be enriched by participation. Solidarity among disparate movements is a powerful force.

questions: do not you find it odd that the 99 percent movement gathered at the university of the 1 percent?
answers: In most countries meetings can be held at union halls like when i talked in london a few months ago. Not here. The main functioning institutions are churches and universities so meetings are commonly held there. Maybe this is an exception where the situation is more conducive to free expression.

questions: what do universities stand to gain or lose from such alliances?
answers: There are a lot of questions to think about seriously. For example what will happen to research and development which depends crucially on student and faculty input. At some level there is a potential gain for institutions of higher learning but a huge loss for the general society as a whole. (for more details see my book chapter 8 on support for research & development and funding priorities.)

questions: how does this square with your reputation as the most cited living author?
answers: I am amazed there it was even 8 percent. And i suspect if you checked you would find it is mostly condemnations. What else would you expect from a widely read author whose books have been translated into more than a dozen languages and whose political writings include works in both hemispheres? He is an honest person.

questions: how do you describe the situation we are in historically?
answers: There is either a crisis or a return to the norm of stagnation. One view is called the golden age. The other is the neo crisis.

questions: and politically?
answers: Again there are differences. In europe there is a dangerous growth of ultra xenophobia which is pretty threatening to any one who remembers the history of europes and an attack on the remnants of the welfare state. It is hard to interpret the austerity in the midst of recession policy as anything other than attack by the super rich on a vulnerable population.

questions: you describe occupy as the first organized response to a thirty year class war?
answers: Oh yes. It is one of those things that you hope will never happen. But it does exist and it did for a long time in spain which is a much more civilized place i think.

questions: are comparisons to arab spring useful?
answers: One point of similarity is they are both responses to the toll taken by the neo lib programs. They have a different effect in a poor country like egypt than a rich country such as the us. But structurally somewhat similar they can be implemented. 13 years ago in principle at least there could be a comparison with iraq and kuwait.

questions: is there a contradiction between anarchism and organization. can you clarify?
answers: Anarchism means all sort of things to different people but the traditional anarchists movements assumed that there would be a highly organized society just one organized from below with direct participation and so on. Actually one piece of the media confusion has a basis because there really are two different strands in the occupy movement both important but different at different times.

questions: is that why the same media that routinely ignores violence against women played up stories about alleged rape and violence at ows camps?
answers: That is standard practice. Every popular movement that they want to denigrate they pick up on those kind of things. And it is perfectly true that those things are going on. [audience laughter] yeah that makes perfect sense from their point of view but we have to be a little careful about that because the outside world is not our audience.

questions: and attacks on collective bargaining?
answers: Attacks actually began in the late 1960s as part of a broader attack on the labor movement. A lot of the organizing was carried out by ex-labor organizers who became teachers and other workers in their 30s or 40s and became involved in political organizations and began to press for things like controlling the work place.

questions: so do unions have a future?
answers: Well it is not worse than the 1920s. There was a very lively active militant labor movement in the late part of the 19th century right through the early part 20thcentury. Smashed up by wilson and the red scares and britain is pursuit of fascism. London was the main working class city in england in those days.

questions: what is the number one target of power today in your view. is it corporations congress media courts?
answers: The media are corporations so the numbers are not in any way particularly encouraging. But there are a couple of interesting cases.

questions: as we speak there are shareholder actions taking place in detroit and san francisco. are those worthwhile good targets?
answers: They are ok but remember stock ownership in the us is very highly concentrated. Just take a look at the top one percent of the population which owns about as much as the bottom ninety percent combined.

questions: but you hear it all the time that under law the ceo is required to increase dividends to shareholders?
answers: It is kind of a technical term. It has nothing to do with legality. There is a shareholder agreement requirement in the united states as a condition precedent to issuing debt.

questions: one question that i hear is will change come from changing ownership if you do not change the profit paradigm?
answers: It is a little like asking if shareholder voting is good for the shareholders. There are different issues. Worker ownership within a state capitalist semi market system is better than private ownership but it has inherent problems.

questions: have you ever had a taste of a non market system had a flash of optimism oh this is how we could live?
answers: A functioning family for example and there are bigger groups cooperatives are a case in point. It certainly can be done. The biggest i know is mondragon but a lot of them are kind of similar in scale.

questions: in flint cordons of women stood between the strikers and the police?
answers: Go back a century to homestead the worker run town and they had to send in the national guard to destroy them.

questions: some people think of fighting racism as separate from working on economic issues?
answers: Well you know there clearly is a serious race problem in the country. Just take a look at what is happening to african american communities. For example wealth wealth in africans is almost zero and for many of them it is worse than poverty even for people who are on medicare.

questions: we often discern bias in the telling of a particular story but i want you to talk more broadly about the way our money media portray power democracy the role of the individual in society and the way that change happens.?
answers: Well they do not want change to happen they are perfectly happy with the status quo. The financial and industrial media the major media most of them are committed to maintaining the existing order whatever it is against the background of what used to be called the cold war and what is sometimes called today the new world order. Naturally they want to maintain that and act as though nothing changes.

questions: if change has not happened in ten minutes it is not going to happen?
answers: Well that is a technique of indoctrination. It makes it look as though there is something wrong with you when in fact the system is largely designed to keep you passive and obedient. If you try to act independently you are pretty much out of luck.

questions: who has it who does not have it and what is our role if we are not say president or ceo?
answers: Well first of all remember that in capitalism there is no such thing as a poor person. Every human being on the planet has a right to food and shelter and protection from external threats. The soviet union and the united states at the time were the only major industrial societies that did not guarantee anything like that.

questions: we are interested in learning what your position is on mainstream filtering the repression of civil liberties and the role of money and politics as they relate to occupy and the future of america?
answers: Coverage of occupy has been mixed. At first it was dismissive making fun of people involved as if they were just silly kids playing games and so on. But coverage changed.

questions: how best do you think the occupy movement should go about engaging in these what methods should be employed and do you think it would be prudent to actually have space to decentralise bases of operation?
answers: There should in my opinion be spaces. Whether they should all be open public spaces or public green spaces is a different question. To some extent they may well be public rights areas so that people can freely gather and express their views and interests without fear of attack or harassment.

questions: how do you assess the goals of the democratic party as far as co opting the movement and what should we be vigilant and looking out for?
answers: The republican party abandoned the pretence of being a political party years ago. They are committed so uniformly and with such dedication to tiny sectors of power and profit that it is hard to see how they can continue to claim to be in the political arena. I think this is very dangerous.

questions: what sort of zionism did you and other youth envision and want to organize around?
answers: I was connected to a considerable part of the z movement which was opposed to an earthly kingdom. It is not too well known but until 1942 there was no official commitment of any kind to jewish national rights. And even that was in the middle of world war ii.

questions: before you were at mit?
answers: I was grad student. We were backpacking in the northern galilee in israel. The next day we went to the airport and landed.

questions: was going to live there part of actualizing your ideals of arab jewish cooperation?
answers: Yeah at the time we intended to. We were in the middle of school and thought we would go back and stay. In fact my wife went back for a longer period.

questions: do you think there is any leadership in the world today that can propose an alternative non military solution for afghanistan and if not where or from whom would this leadership for an alternative non military solution come from?
answers: I think it is well understood among the military leadership and also the political leadership of the united states and its allies that they cannot achieve a military victory on the ground. They need a political victory to achieve that. So what they are doing now is what george bush was doing when he was announcing the invasion of iraq.

questions: if not what are the possible truly good options for ordinary afghans?
answers: I agree that there do not appear to be any good choices and that we therefore regrettably have to try to seek the least bad of the bad options. Now that judgment has to pass through the filter of whether it is in the national interest.

questions: it feels as if to the afghan youth peace volunteers that the withdrawal by 2014 is therefore inconsequential in light of the larger long term plans to keep forces in afghanistan. could you comment on this?
answers: I am quite sure that those expectations are correct. I certainly hope that they are but these expectations have no basis in fact the record plainly demonstrates that contrary to what is often assumed the intention has been to leave a lasting legacy. And the task of withdrawal should not be confused with the broader long range plans that i have described.

questions: we wish you well and the best of health?
answers: Thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to talk to you briefly. It is a real privilege and i greatly admire the wonderful work that you are doing.

questions: eyes only. would you care to confirm or deny this report?
answers: You can not trust anything that comes from wikileaks. You know that. But even though they reported it it is nevertheless true because if you take a look at the cables that are being released they actually encourage this kind of behavior which is perfectly rational. These are not people who should be trusted with national security secrets.

questions: can you speculate who is responsible for these attacks against the media and why?
answers: I have done so. Several times. The most striking example was the horrendous attack on the daily newspaper offices in gaza in january 2002.

questions: things are so bad that i wonder do you think it is a good idea for the mexican government to suspend certain guaranteed constitutional rights in ju rez or elsewhere in mexico until order is restored?
answers: You first have to ask what they mean by guaranteed and how that is determined. There is no legal obligation on the part of the united states to tell me what it means. In the case of me xico it simply means that they are carrying out a military coup.

questions: do you think nafta signed almost 20 years ago continues to be an obstacle?
answers: Yeah that is part of the problem. Also the investor rights agreements that naftsa is signed with basically the transnational corporations in the us and other rich countries are just another form of state intervention in a free market.

questions: given all those conditions what can mexico do to counteract all of this?
answers: While i was in meXico in september there was an article in la jornada reporting a study by economists at unam. It said that during just the calderon years real incomes for working people dropped by some spectacular amount like 60 and people were basically reduced to survival. Those are results of particular economic policies.

questions: is it possible for the united states to help its citizens and make them prosper without adversely affecting citizens in some other country in particular mexico?
answers: I think these policies are destructive and will continue to be so unless there is a massive popular movement opposing them and it is not just the us which is opposed but even europe and others who are not so welcoming to the idea of unregulated capital flow. As i said in the case of canada and for a time brazil were even punitive tariffs.

questions: would not that still leave the problem of other illicit drugs like cocaine and heroin to contend with?
answers: Legalizing marijuana would make a lot of sense i do not think there is a single case of marijuana overdose on record and tens of millions of users. It is much less dangerous than alcohol for example. The worst drug of all by far is tobacco the death toll from tobacco is just out of control.

questions: but what about cocaine and heroin. they would still be there?
answers: They are just destroying the industry. Nobody is going to pay any attention. These are huge industries.

questions: education may be effective in preventing drug addiction but once someone is addicted it is very difficult to make them stop?
answers: Then they need treatment but putting them in jail does not help. In fact putting people in jails just creates cartels criminal cartels and you know what they are like. A lot of the things you read about in the press like the ones i mentioned like solitary confinement which is even worse than kangaroo courts or whatnot are actually techniques of incarceration.

questions: do you think it is wrong for a sovereign country like the united states to make every reasonable effort to stop and deport illegal immigrants from entering the country?
answers: There is no doubt that many people are in the United States illegally. What is not clear is how many of them are here legally and who is responsible for the many thousands who have been caught trying to cross the border illegally and deported. One sensible policy would be to enforce the law and try to catch those who are guilty. Refusing to do so is hardly honorable.

questions: it seems degradation of education has happened in very different ways in mexico and the united states?
answers: Take unam. It is a very high quality university it has a couple hundred thousand students. Its hard to get into but you can get in.

questions: would you briefly elaborate on these points?
answers: Let is grant that there is a drug problem for the sake of argument drugs meaning you know cocaine marijuana and so on. Suppose you accept that. How do you deal with it within the society.

questions: can you explain how that got started and how it still works today?
answers: The best source on this is alfred mccoy is the politics of heroin. He traces it back to early postwar europe post world war ii where a prime concern of washington was to undermine the antifascist resistance and the labor movements in italy france and germany in order to restore traditional social structures including fascist collaborators.

questions: could you tell us about the connection between the drug cartels and the large institutional banks?
answers: Money laundering commonly goes through banks which pretend not to know about it. The scale is estimated to be huge.

questions: could you point out how your views on drugs and the drug war tie into that?
answers: It is pretty straightforward. I happen to be an anti drug activist and an extremely harsh critic of the criminalization of drugs. So for example when i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what is being discussed is a discussion of whether to legalize heroin which is about twice as strong as cocaine and far more dangerous.

questions: recently libertarians such as ron paul have courted marijuana users on the basis that they oppose the drug war. why do you oppose them?
answers: What is called libertarianism in the united states is a significant deviation from traditional libertarian thought. Traditionally say in europe libertarian meant the anti state wing of the socialist party. In modern times libertarian has been a term of abuse to describe those who are committed to dismantling the coercive institutions of our society.

questions: hightimes readers more likely see him as the man who started the modern war on drugs. could you explain?
answers: Nixon did a lot of rotten things much worse than starting the present war but the same is true of other liberal presidents. His liberal initiatives included the occupational safety and health administration the environmental protection agency the earned income tax credit and much else. No president in modern history has passed such liberal programs.

questions: lastly hightimes readers may be curious if you have ever tried marijuana?
answers: No never even i am very conventional.

questions: do you believe judge afiuni could receive a fair trial in venezuela?
answers: Well as far as i am aware she is not receiving any trial at all. I rather doubt i would be sceptical about whether or not she could even receive an acquittal. It is kind of striking that almost nobody is talking about it.

questions: but in the case of judge afiuni what do you make of the intervention of the president calling for her to be jailed for 30 years what should one conclude from that?
answers: It is obviously improper for the executive to intervene and impose a jail sentence without a trial. And i should say that the united states is in no position to complain about this. Bradley manning has been imprisoned without charge under torture which is what solitary confinement is.

questions: what do you think?
answers: It all depends what its used for. If the objective is free peoples minds liberated from propaganda the means should be available to develop the ideas themselves. Not handed over to the authorities.

questions: is this letter the first public criticism that you have made of human rights issues in venezuela?
answers: I do not recall but probably not. I am constantly involved in such protests all over the world ranging from syria to cuba to iraq. So there may have been others i cannot remember.

questions: i understand that in december you sent a private letter to the authorities here over the afiuni case. was there any feedback from that?
answers: The was jointly with the carr centre for human rights at harvard which actually initiated it. So if there was any response they would know. There may have been an indirect response as well.

questions: from that perspective what is your take on the enabling laws and the evolution of executive power in venezuela?
answers: I am opposed to the so called anti terrorism laws. I think they are a very bad step. For one thing they criminalize peaceful political protest.

questions: so that does mean you think the enabling powers are unjustified?
answers: In my view they are not justified. I can see room for debate about it but my judgment in that debate is that the arguments in favour do not withstand serious scrutiny.

questions: in your visit here in 2009 you said a better world was being created. is that still the case?
answers: Actually what i said is there are steps towards a more democratic world in venezuela and as far as i know that is true. There have been some significant steps the sharp poverty reduction probably the greatest in the americas the missions and the self governing communities look like promising initiatives.

questions: is it a recent thing or a trend over the past few years?
answers: I think it is a tendency which has developed towards the centralisation of power in the executive which i do not think is healthy in itself and i am not sure how much it will spread. Maybe the executives of some of the big corporations see this and think maybe they are being fed a line of propaganda by the fed. Or maybe its just that they have internal resources.

questions: specifically are you thinking of the judiciary or other factors?
answers: Decision making powers generally seems eh the constraints imposed by the legislature are there but they seem limited.

questions: more generally about latin america looking around the region given the election of recent governments are you optimistic. is this headed in a positive direction?
answers: I think what is happened over the past 10 years is probably the most exciting and positive development to take place in the world. For 500 years since european explorers came latino populations had been separated from one another. They had very limited relations.

questions: finally professor the concerns about the concentration of executive power in venezuela to what extent might that be undermining democracy in venezuela?
answers: Concentration. Yeah. I do not agree with the general statement of his but the thing that he sort of backpedals on is the statement that vietnam was an aggressor when in fact it was the victim of aggression throughout its history.

questions: and so in the case of venezuela is that what is happening or at risk of happening?
answers: As i said you can debate whether circumstances require it both internal circumstances and the external threat of attack and that is what we are looking at right now. Circumstances certainly exist and they may change. For example there is a serious food crisis in chile.

questions: would you say that the recent developments falsify this thesis?
answers: The thesis never had any basis whatsoever. The arab islamic world has a long history of democracy. It is regularly crushed by western force.

questions: known british middle east correspondent robert fisk recently stated that obama and his policy is irrelevant for the developments in the region?
answers: I read the article it is very good. Roosevelt himself was quite explicit in his conception of what he called a stalinist client state. I do not think that is quite accurate.

questions: when one looks at politics today one must ask can public intellectuals like yourself accomplish anything?
answers: How can you ask that question. You are asking an intellectual if he can create a movement.

questions: the world suffers in the consequences of the economic crisis. the social gap grows more and more?
answers: In europe the problem is much worse because of trump. If you look at what is happening in his country it is pretty shocking. For example he is now proposing that people who have health problems should be denied health insurance.

questions: we are still skeptical. what have you changed in the past 45 years?
answers: I personally did not change anything. I was part of a movement and this movement accomplished many things. The world today is fundamentally different than it was 45 or even 20 years ago though there are some differences of course.

questions: do you believe the world is better today than 40 or 50 years ago?
answers: Obviously. Walk along the open fields here at the massachusetts institute of technology. Half of the students are women a third belongs to an ethnic minority. Less than 10 percent of faculty are minorities.

questions: today is generation is often reproached for being disinterested in the world?
answers: I think that reproach is false. The period of high politization at the universities was very short from 1968 to 1970. before that students were apathetic and passive.

questions: were those protests only a straw fire?
answers: No. The politization today is much greater than in the 1950s. Forms of lasting activism developed that enabled many of our battles to be won. Not easy to reverse but they have been won and they are not lost.

questions: do you believe in historical progress?
answers: Progress is slow but dramatic over long time horizons. Think of the abolition of slavery or the development of freedom of expression. Rights are not simply bestowed; they are created.

questions: if there are times of progress and times of backward steps will the world be better in 50 years than today?
answers: My grandchildren will live through the 21st century by mid century it could be very serious maybe even earlier. It is kind of a miracle things work out the way they do. But there is a lot of work to do and we are hurtling towards a precipice.

questions: what must they do to look back on their life with satisfaction?
answers: Naturally they could say they lived contentedly with friends children and fun. But to really lead a fulfilled and satisfying life they should recognize problems and contribute to solving them. If they cannot think of the problems themselves they at least should be able to understand them if their attitudes and choices conform to the general pattern of human development.

questions: at 82 are you satisfied with what you achieved?
answers: Being satisfied is impossible. My life has too many dimensions family profession politics and several others. In some areas i am satisfied but in others not.

questions: are you sometimes furious at the servants of power as you say or at professor colleagues who only concentrate on their academic work?
answers: I consider it immoral to be a supporter of a power system. However that does not mean that i am furious about it. Scholars per se do not have deeper political insights than other persons and are not morally superior to others. Brazil is an interesting case i think.

questions: that sounds like you are becoming mild in old age?
answers: No. My views and attitudes have not changed in the course of the decades. I still believe what i believed as a teenager: that is, that there are powerful forces in human affairs that ought to be exploited for the benefit of all human beings.

questions: is that good to still believe what you believed almost 70 years ago?
answers: Yes when fundamental principles are involved. Obviously i have changed my opinions in many questions but my ideals are essentially the same.

questions: you often say you are an anarchist. what do you mean by that?
answers: Anarchists try to identify power structures. They urge those exercising power to justify themselves. This justification does not succeed most of the time and often results in repression violence and so on. A lot of power is in the hands of a small number of people.

questions: what was the key experience that made you an anarchist?
answers: There was none. When i was twelve years old i began to go to secondhand bookshops. Many of them were run by anarchists who came from spain.

questions: should all students become anarchists?
answers: Yes. Students should challenge authorities and join a long anarchist tradition.

questions: challenge authorities a liberal or a moderate leftist could accept that invitation?
answers: As soon as one identifies challenges and overcomes illegitimate power he or she is an anarchist. Most people are anarchists. What they call themselves does not matter to me because i do not share their values. If you did i would call you a communist.

questions: who or what must challenge today is student generation?
answers: This world is full of suffering distress violence and catastrophes. Students must decide does something concern you or not. I say look around analyze the problems ask yourself what you can do and set out on the work.

questions: i saw that you were quoted as saying education is ignorance?
answers: Well that is what it often is in practice. It should not be. One of the central principles of political science is that we try to understand the attitudes and the behavior of people so we can try and influence them.

questions: i am just wondering if you can speak to this idea of education being mostly something that teaches obedience rather than critical thinking?
answers: Eduction is a term that is very familiar to workers in industry. It is used to refer to the method of teaching that students are expected to act in certain ways and to expect that they will be rewarded for their efforts. Now there are a number of different ways of doing this varying radically from one country to another.

questions: in terms of elite universities versus the state college system does it make more sense to have this more open system for higher learning?
answers: I think there should be an openness system period. But it has to be adapted to the needs and interests of the students. If somebody wants to become an engineer let is say they are gonna have different educational opportunities than someone who wanna be become a philosopher or theologian.

questions: what is the fix. how does a student direct their own academic career?
answers: There is no single magic answer for that. There can be a lot of issues that prevent people from getting involved in anything. Let me give you an example.

questions: what do you see as some of those major issues that stand out to you in the american system?
answers: The major issue which varies from place to place of course is the tendency to move towards a model of teaching which sort of back a couple centuries ago used to be called filling a vessel with water instead of encouraging students to become creative and independent and develop their own interests and concerns. Now that is not everywhere.

questions: what were you able to do to convince yourself to keep pursuing a degree?
answers: I did pretty much drop out of college. And one quite friendly professor sort of induced me back into college by suggesting that i take some of his graduate courses. Which i took and then went on to start taking a scattering of graduate course in other fields and i think i put in about twenty or thirty hours a week.

questions: i am wondering what you think about students having a say in the way universities are run at the administrative level or governing level?
answers: There should in my opinion be student participation. Ultimately there can not be any student decision about some matters because they infringe on personal rights.

questions: i am just wondering what you think about this sort of clash between students and governing bodies?
answers: Students should have a perfect right to pressure their university to avoid participating in what they regard as criminal activities. Exactly what tactics they should use well you know that depends very much on the particular circumstances.

questions: if you were to go back and start your undergrad again now what advice would you have for students that are in that position?
answers: You know i get hundreds of letters everyday and a great number of them are kind of like that from people asking for advice. And there is no one way to answer. It is a highly personal matter and personally i do not think one can give advice that is generative.

questions: what do you think is at the root of this regional upheaval and what are its possible implications for the region and for the rest of the world?
answers: First of all it is worth bearing in mind that upheavals are really not new. There are very deep roots going back to the origins of history when there were really major struggles going on all over the place. Europe of course was involved in one kind or another way but it was a major actor for a long time and the united states was always opposed to it.

questions: what do you think the primary impetus for the anti gaddafi movement in libya is?
answers: Well we can be quite confident on one thing. It is because of the documents we have seen. And these have to do with the 1980s. 20 years ago in my view pretty much the same motivations were at work.

questions: how it is manifested today in the united states and elsewhere and why is it a threat?
answers: Well it was not long ago that the most powerful state in human history was condemned for international terrorism. What is called terrorism in international affairs today is the crime of aggression carried out by a small group of states against another state.

questions: do you agree with that assessment and how would you characterize the events in wisconsin?
answers: Well it is true that there is a confrontation between the tea party and the popular movement but that is kind of misleading. I mean the confrontation is not between supporters of the movement and those who would rather see the country go back to what it was before the first bush administration. First of all there are a lot of popular forces opposed to the occupation and there should be.

questions: do you think it is going to survive the next 25 or 30 years. what do you think the alternatives are?
answers: Well i think there are several possibilities. One is simply to try to develop more effectively the programs of organization and education that have been so successful in bringing about significant changes in the past. To take just one case the women is movement of the 60s was a major change.

questions: i ordered you the turkey on marble rye from the deli downstairs. is this a thing of habit?
answers: For about the past twenty years or so.

questions: that exact order huh?
answers: It used to be a bagel and american cheese. Now it is a hot dog and cheese sandwich. What is the meaning of life.

questions: how long have you worked here at m. i. t?
answers: Since 55.

questions: are you a foodie?
answers: Am i a. meaning. What you could call an obsession. With. Fine dining.

questions: are you into gourmet food?
answers: I am into eating as little as possible paying as close attention as i can to what i eat paying attention to the little things like how many bites i take before bedtime paying particular care not letting any distractions in the way of eating. I never cook. Never use the stove or any other fossil fuel based method of cooking. Just eat whatever is available and what is nearby.

questions: do you know how to cook?
answers: I have done it. You would not believe how easy it is.

questions: not interested huh?
answers: Neither do i. if you really want to be bored i can describe the first baseball game that i went to inning by inning. It was a pennant race so the inning before the game started the bleachers were full of people jostling for position on the diamond. First inning first pitch was pitch for strike.

questions: something tells me you were secretly the high school quarterback and you are too embarrassed to admit it?
answers: I was sort of an outsider. I had friends, but i hated highschool.

questions: did you play sports?
answers: On my own not in the high school system. I was a track and field star but i did not go to college. It was too dangerous.

questions: you have spoken in the past about your views on sports that at least people who watch sports that maybe it is a distraction for the masses to keep them concentrated on trivialities?
answers: It can be that does not have to be. I mean i have been toying with the idea of maybe giving away free tickets to sports games to the harvard basketball team so that when they play we can all laugh. To me that is an outrageous form of consumption.

questions: do you watch?
answers: That's not really my thing. I'm not much of a fan.

questions: you have a lot of good sports teams here in boston?
answers: Yeah. We went to all of them during his jock phase.

questions: collect cards?
answers: Baseball cards. This was back in the 30 is when i was starting getting into activism. You could not go to the store and buy these.

questions: do you still have em?
answers: But i can tell you if you really want to be bored i may be able to describe the first baseball game that i went to inning by inning. About 1960 or so. This was in new york not too far from where i am.

questions: no thanks definitely not.?
answers: Terrific game it was the world championship yankees. We were sitting right behind joe dimaggio in the bleachers red ruffing pitching bill dickey catching. Lou gehrig on first.

questions: inning by inning?
answers: Oh i will not bore you. Just go along with me as i go through the sequence by sequence. If i forget something just say so.

questions: you have an autobiographical memory?
answers: Just for important things like that like when i was twelve years old and i remember the first baseball game i went to. It was a pennant race and the colts were on first. I got to first and had to wait in the bleachers so i could get a good look at the pitching staff.

questions: do you ever have to eschew things like buying products made by large companies or driving automobiles purchasing gasoline things like that?
answers: I do not see any particular significance to that and i try not to pay any attention to it. For one thing i am not much of a consumer so my tastes are not particularly influenced by such things. Also i have a wife and a family and things happen so i tend to be rather solitary.

questions: i guess when you go on a road trip how do you drive across the country without eating an apple pie from mcdonald is?
answers: Well the last time i drove across country was 1956 and i do not think there were any mcdonaugh's around then. But i will tell you if you really want an answer how much road you have to drive to get to the store.

questions: it is a graphic novel but what i would like is for you to show up occasionally in the novel having weekend adventures with hitch and salman?
answers: I do not have any Weekend adventures. I spend about twenty hours a week working on graphic novels. Those are the kind of things that i should be doing because i am extremely productive.

questions: i will invent it i was just wondering if you would be okay with defending hitchens honour in a bar fight?
answers: Anything you like.

questions: what do you think the implications are for the u. s. internationally?
answers: I think it is pretty serious. I mean the consequences could be catastrophic. Right now the united states is backing off from major military confrontations.

questions: so you do not think the united states will let democracy flourish?
answers: What they are saying is there are ways around it. So for example take what is happening in brazil which is a kind of soft coup.

questions: in your view can we really blame these rogue warriors for developing out of the ashes of failed states?
answers: You can understand what they are doing. I am not in favor of piracy the acts of violence. However you develop a theory about the motivations and the means you have to use that to try to piece together the events.

questions: so how do you stay informed in world affairs?
answers: Reading my specialty.

questions: any special news?
answers: Nothing that is not available to everyone. You have to work to find it. I mean if you are lucky enough to be in a university environment you will find a lot of it but it is mostly academic journal articles.

questions: so how do you find it then?
answers: You work. Look for interesting things. Take some question that is important ask yourself how it is beinganswered. Then you can try to piece it together from various different sources.

questions: did you vote in the last election?
answers: I voted green. If i had been in a swing state this is a fixed state i would have held my nose and voted for obama. Just to keep out the alternative which is worse.

questions: just a talking head?
answers: He is an opportunist mostly supported by the financial institutions. He had no positions on anything and was very easy to work with. That is why he has such appeal.

questions: i mean think about simple things like people using the letters on a telephone keypad to express themselves now we seem to be moving into uncharted territory?
answers: Well the big change the really radical change in communication was in the late 19th century. The shift from sailing ships to telegraph is astronomical. Everything since then has been small increments including the internet.

questions: do you foresee any quantum leaps in the near future?
answers: Everything since is a change. Small changes can magnifiy. The possibility of interpersonal communication has increased substantially with contemporary technology.

questions: as globalization presses forward and the pace of convergent evolution of human beings increases do you foresee languages as we know them maybe not dying out but maybe some sort of global language developing?
answers: There is a tremendous amount of language loss. Most of the attention is given to indigenous languages which makes sense if they are dying off. But some of this language is being absorbed by westernized societies which means that their languages are becoming more diverse.

questions: so to some extent there will be some small revivals but do not you think that eventually there will only be a necessity for one language?
answers: I suspect that sooner or later there may be one or a few second languages. See english for example is a second language in most of the educated sectors of europe and much of Asia. But maybe in the future chinese can become a true second official language.

questions: is that maybe a backlash to globalization?
answers: Yeah. I think it is a reaction in europe to the centralization of the eurozone.

questions: do you think people are becoming more comfortable communicating through a device rather than face to face or verbally?
answers: My grandchildren that is all they do. I mean of course they talk to people but an awful lot of their communication is extremely rapid very shallow communication. Text messaging twitter that sort of communication which is very rapid extremely shallow.

questions: what do you think are the implication for human behavior?
answers: It think it erodes normal human relations. It makes them more superficial shallow evanescent. One other effect is there is much less reading.

questions: because there are so many distractions or?
answers: Well you know it is tempting there is a kind of stimulus hunger that is cultivated by the rapidity and the graphic character and for the boys at least the violence of this imaginary universe they are involved in. Video games for example. I have a daughter who lives near here.

questions: how do you know what he is doing?
answers: I watch him.

questions: as the amount of interpersonal communication decreases as a result of this innovation are there implications for linguistics?
answers: I think there are certainly human implications. I do not think it is a new innovation. Just think about ten years ago if you had asked me what i thought about the evolution of language i would have said it was a little innovation is not the right word but its a change.

questions: is that for the worse i guess. i mean you have the modern conveniences?
answers: That is it saves money. It loses personal relations which is not a good thing. You know people hate to be around people who hate themselves.

questions: and now those community gathering places have moved online?
answers: Online which has it is advantages. You diversify you can have friends in india and so on. But it also loses human relationships.

questions: you were famously duped by larry flynt into taking an interview with hustler magazine which may speak less to flynt is ability to pull the wool over someone is eyes and more to your disregard of or unfamiliarity to popular culture?
answers: I would not say i knew what i was for a while. I did not have any illusions. When i got back i realized i had made a complete and utter mess of things and decided to give it a shot.

questions: but you really had no clue what hustler magazine was at the time?
answers: Never heard of it. I am pretty much out of popular culture altogether. Thanks very much.

questions: is that everyday world that most people find so fascinating why is it so uninteresting to you?
answers: I do not know i never travel much. I spend a lot of time in the United States and other countries which have much better public transportation and so on. And it is kind of boring.

questions: but surely there is a deeper conversation to be had about human sexuality and erotic material. is it just that all pornography is?
answers: I am no expert on beeeep. The core element of it i think is degradation of women whatever else goes on. I do not think it should be outlawed but i would not want to encourage it.

questions: do you know who lady gaga is?
answers: I have seen ads and stuff but no.

questions: i mean there is a way in which you yourself have entered into the sphere of popular culture. you are a pretty famous guy?
answers: Well the most famous that i know of was sort of fun. Back in 1990 i got a letter from a punk rock group called bad religion. I liked the name.

questions: he wrote a book on evolutionary biology and punk rock. i am reading it now it is really good?
answers: Oh really. Hm i have never heard of it. Glad to hear that you are interested. Bye.

questions: so let me see what else. do you ever use swear words?
answers: Well i guess so. If i were to use it i would probably use something more descriptive like he is a bully or something along those lines.

questions: i figured as a linguist you have to be well versed in all types of language?
answers: Ai is anything. Its barely more than elaborate machines that do statistical analysis on huge data sets. What you should be concerned about, is who controls it, and how can you take part in steering its future.

questions: the ones on your desk are those the ones that you are going to read?
answers: Those are the papers that i am giving away to thelecturers and others for research purposes. Those will be my papers when i get back.

questions: and the ones on the wall are ones you have read?
answers: Some of them are not even my books. Some are written by friends. I have given away most of my unpublished work. This is at the american institute of technology.

questions: do you have any idea how many books you have written. do you have a precise number?
answers: Well no clue.

questions: how many per year. on average?
answers: I do not think it counts. For example if i work full time i would probably not report because i am too busy. But it could be counted as one job.

questions: do you write them on a type writer. do you use a computer?
answers: That is not really my thing. I am much too absorbed in my own work to be interested in the aesthetic or technical aspects of language or the society in which it is lived or used to relate. Nor would i be able to understand the question of why a person who is neither a nor an artist would want to learn about language the way an orangutan does.

questions: so i take it you do not play angry birds?
answers: I don't know what that is. All i know is that it makes me angry.

questions: how do you feel about being lumped in with wesley snipes?
answers: Well i do not want to be compared with anybody. In fact if you asked me to compare myself to anybody it would be a very difficult task. I have much greater accomplishments to my credit.

questions: with wesley snipes as the two most recognizable faces of the tax resistance movement?
answers: Never heard of leslie allman i am afraid but i knew of one or two others.

questions: wesley snipes you never saw major league. white men can not jump?
answers: I have heard of it but he is the author and it is very good. The book was not published i am afraid.

questions: he is an actor?
answers: Okay.

questions: so are you still?
answers: If you want information about sports i can tell you things from the 1940 is and the couple years that my grandson was kind of a jock but nothing in between so i could not really participate.

questions: alright tell us about the 1940s. no i am just kidding?
