answers: Well it is kind of interesting but my parents were immigrants so we were first generation. Part of the socialization process especially for young boys was to know everything about baseball. Back in those days baseball was the sport.

questions: are you still part of the tax resistance movement?
answers: I organized tax resistance in 1965 with a friend. I kept at it for about ten years. One day i got a letter from a professor at mit which explained that he was keeping a file on me and i had to answer his questions.

questions: kind of like levitating the pentagon?
answers: I was there when the hippie movement was starting and i attended one of their meetings which was at a church with a lot of very zionist oriented people. The church had a small meeting place so the activists sat in the pew and talked. After a while a big banner came out and people began to clap and wave it around.

questions: was that an effective one?
answers: Probably not it never took off because the israeli lobby was so powerful that it prevented it from ever taking off in the united states. They had already pressured congress to pass legislation that prevented the kosovo intervention. But the us just blocked it and they never succeeded in getting a non congress resolution to support it.

questions: the pentagon never took off?
answers: Oh that well that was important. The tet offensive was major. October 1967 and the war had been on for five years already so this was a very significant date.

questions: did you organize it?
answers: There was no real there were a lot of i was one of the groups that was involved in resistance organizations and education which was important. In fact at that same time we initiated a resistance organization resist which still exists and that led to trials.

questions: you were on trial did you spend time in prison or jail?
answers: For civil disobedience a lot of times but when the tet offensive came along in january 68 it essentially convinced the business community in the united states that there is no point continuing this it is getting too costly this is harming the economy we have already won our major aims. The military really wanted to get out and start a war.

questions: how do you feel about julian assange of wikileaks?
answers: Basically i think it is a public service. I mean why should if you believe in democracy why shouldnt you know what the government is doing. Including declassification. And this is only a fraction of it.

questions: so there should be complete transparency in government?
answers: You can give an argument for keeping secrets. Take say the pentagon papers. Actually i was involved in distributing them before they really surfaced and he kept one volume from the public for twenty years.

questions: do you ever look back and think that if you had done something different what kind of career you would have gotten into?
answers: Doing what i got into was more or less accidental. I was very fortunate in my childhood because there was a lot of stimulation and opportunity but i did not have parents or a significant other who was going to take care of me and i had to learn to fend for myself. That is one of the lessons of human life.

questions: but when you were a kid what did you want to be when you grew up?
answers: When i was ten years old i came to the conclusion that what i wanted to do was become a taxidermist for some of the kibbutzim so i went back to my father is place and i did that for a while.

questions: i have never heard of any kid that wanted to be a taxidermist. and then what?
answers: When i was maybe 10 or 11 years old i started going to secondhand bookshops. Many of them were run by anarchists who came from spain. They were carrying anarchist pamphlets and so on people were very interested in reading them.

questions: well it looks like you have done pretty well?
answers: It worked out.

questions: prof chomsky where do you locate the contours of the current crisis in egypt tunisia and rest of the middle east?
answers: The source of much of this misery is actually in the formerly colonized world itself. It is a result of mismanagement by the imperial powers and the resulting flight of capital. When the united states and britain left the indonesian dictatorship in 1965 they left behind a trail of destruction and suffering that cannot be ignored.

questions: do you see any strategy for overcoming the fragmentation that exists among social movements to help people recognize an overriding shared agenda?
answers: One failing of the social movement that i have noticed over many years is that while they are focusing on extremely crucial and important social issues like women is rights environmental protections and so on they have tended to ignore or downplay the economic and social crises faced by working people. It is not that they do not exist. There is a serious crisis of capitalism.

questions: it overturns citizens united it requires the mass media to give equal and free time to all major candidates and it bans any private advertising in the months before an election?
answers: I think those are ideas that i would endorse. I am sure that they can be used for organizing and education but until those organizing tools are in place which they are not there is not going to be any organizing. So yes as an organizing tool you can use them but as a practical matter you would better do it in a more organized way.

questions: it is not something that we are expecting to have passed in this current congress but something that if we can get them endorsed by local city councils and state legislatures might raise the kinds of issues that right now are not even in the public sphere at all?
answers: You are talking about something different i think in a state maybe. In fact maybe something can be done here. There is a progressive initiative here called the community development bank which has been around for a couple of years and it has some things in it for low income people.

questions: so you are not one of those on the left who say it is simply a poison to continue working inside the democratic party?
answers: I am not coming out in favor of working within the party or opposing working for the democrats. That is just childish. It does not mean you can not do anything either way.

questions: so knowing no one that has a better understanding of these dynamics than you would you be willing to be a candidate for the presidency?
answers: I am not the proper person. So personally no I do not think it makes any sense.

questions: since you have the analysis and can articulate it so clearly why would you not be a good candidate?
answers: In our system a candidate has to be someone who is an orator or someone with some charisma someone willing to say something controversial. I do not do that and if i could do it i would not because i am not in that category.

questions: the right kind of person is precisely the person who would not want to do it?
answers: Absolutely. And that is why it is counter productive. You are not going to change anything if you do not agree with the way the institutions operate. Your point of view is valid but it does not make any difference.

questions: the urgent threats of climate change and nuclear war?
answers: I do not think there are any deep dark secrets about this. We know what the risks are. I mean even the most conservative scientists recognize that the chances of us survival as a species are very slight unless we radically reduce our use of fossil fuels. Then the question becomes how to deal with the consequences of not acting.

questions: and that has also been experienced by people like jim wallis and those involved with sojourners and people around the christian century and other progressive religious organizations?
answers: I think you should approach them not just on the pragmatic grounds that it is in their interest but also because of the hope that their presence will bring. Many people have gone there have tried it have not liked it and if it can be done again let is do it again.

questions: yet the washington based peace people and many among the secular left in the jewish world think that the smartest strategy is to downplay that issue and to play up only israel is interest?
answers: Well first of all i am not at all convinced that it is counterproductive to building support maybe among those who really believe in secular humanism but also among people who are really concerned about the human rights situation in that part of the world. And secondly i do not really think it makes much sense.

questions: given the constellation of forces right now in which this seems to be the only issue in which democrats and republicans are totally united producing votes of 415 to 20 in support of crazy resolutions?
answers: You are speaking of congress but i think we should look at the population which is by no means unified on this. In fact about 70 percent of the public favors the formation of a palestinian state and about the same percentage favors an independent kurdistan. The situation is very much like what is happening in iraq.

questions: supporting the existing repressive regimes and committed to them on a deep personal and emotional level?
answers: The christian right also supported apartheid. There are all kinds of differences on the other hand in the case of israel palestine do you think there is a direct relationship.

questions: do you believe that they have done enough and said enough to meet the needs of the libyan people?
answers: I think that more can be done what is happening is already pretty awful and that could lead to a really major bloodbath. Information is pretty sparse but at least the eastern province appears to be substantially under control by the popular uprising. Tripoli looks very dangerous.

questions: how will oil play out in this considering the price of oil has been steadily increasing and there are a lot of fears about if this unrest continues what will happen in that arena?
answers: There is a reason why there has not been much discussion about this. The reason is simple it does not matter. If people were really concerned about the fate of the palestinians they would not be sitting where they are sitting right now.

questions: it takes a spark that lights a fire that carries it forward?
answers: That is the way the world works not exactly but more or less. So for example take the vietnam war the war that really changed the country is not so much the end but the beginning of the cold war.

questions: do you believe that there are backdoor channels there that are being used or is the us really not getting involved is what is happening in libya right now?
answers: I am sure the intel community knows it. Take a look at the leaks from national security agency. They know exactly who is spying on whom.

questions: pushing forward such people by the us though they are quiet on this front they have not yet spoken against him do they not realize that given the fact the obama said he wanted to improve the us image certainly this is not helping him toward that cause?
answers: It is very hard to say. I mean these people did not just show up spontaneously. They had been there a long time and had a good education and so on.

questions: why has been their response has been so disorganized in a sense considering administration was saying one thing one day and another thing the other day?
answers: I do not see it as much of a surprise. The bush administration has essentially a one party system. It has two factions the traditional business party and the ideological party.

questions: let me go back to the egypt if i may just for a moment?
answers: That is right.

questions: so from manama to madison from manama bahrain to madison wisconsin noam chomsky?
answers: It is very interesting. The reason why you can not get democratic leaders to join is because they agree. They are also trying to destroy the unions.

questions: the new york times coverage of madison?
answers: Well that was very interesting. In fact i urge people to take a look at the february 12th issue of the young people is edition ofthe big picture which is a little misleading because it does not have the lead story but it had two lead stories right away both of them very important and very revealing each revealing something about the intellectual culture.

questions: yet you have got these labor leaders who helped get obama elected and who helped get andy cuomo elected and they are not yet making the stand in a strong enough way to mobilize people against these policies?
answers: Yeah there is a problem. Actually the labor movement has always been much stronger against state violence than it is against private power. As i said in fact labor history has been very violent not just in the 20th century but in earlier decades too.

questions: now they are saying he is going to raise obama is going to raise 1 billion for the next campaign?
answers: Yeah and it will probably be more than that because they have to buy time with the primaries and the fall campaign and so on. But it is a good question what kind of impact this will have. Just to give you an illustration i was talking to a group of bank employees last week and they were asking for a raise.

questions: noam we have to break. we are going to come right back?
answers: Yeah. Good to talk to you later.

questions: he has authored over a hundred books his latest hopes and prospects among others?
answers: I want to ask you about former president ronald reagan. A very big deal is made of him now on the hundredth anniversary of his birth. Last year president obama signed legislation establishing a commission to mark the centennial which i think is a worthwhile initiative. (applause) no president has ever done anything like that.

questions: noam chomsky your response?
answers: He is right. If we are serious we have to ask what is the nature of the threat. The threats we face are not existential. They are severe and they continue.

questions: from minneapolis to chicago the fbi raids activists being subpoenaed to speak about in various cases?
answers: Yeah that is a pretty it is not just the raids are serious enough but what is more significant is what lies behind them. These are the first actions taken under new rulings by the supreme court.

questions: south africa anc?
answers: Put in cuba. There was a cuban embassy in washington. The united states reacted by cutting off aid.

questions: given all the changes we are seeing in the middle east and what happened in egypt and tunisia i am interested in having your thoughts on the kurdish situation in general especially in turkey and iraq?
answers: Well it is not just turkey but even more than that. Turkey is the only country i know of in which there is a very lively and functioning kibbutz and it would be quite surprising if it were to disappear. And the fact that it exists at all is because of the massive and continuing support from the west. Thanks very much.

questions: as you said there are definitely developments happening in turkey but it seems that the kurds are not happy with those developments especially the bdp and the pkk?
answers: In fact the current trials are about organization of political party. It still has not been possible for a true parliamentary democracy to be established in the country. But one thing is for sure it will soon be possible i think.

questions: do you think these developments that you mention in turkey are a result of the fact that an islamic party is in power that is the justice and development party under the leadership of prime minister recep tayyip erdogan?
answers: I mean it is complex. You can not sort of give it a grade. But there have been some positive developments.

questions: he said the kurds could only be free if they pour on to the streets and call for their rights in the kurdish cities like diyarbakir. is that a reasonable thing?
answers: It would not be reasonable but it is what is happening. There is a kind of a tacit recognition that if the mass movement does not develop then the brutality and repression will continue. That is why there are counter protests.

questions: they say it is the best time after what happened in the broader middle east for them to breakaway from iraq. what do you make of that?
answers: I think there are a lot of questions to think about seriously. For one thing arab syria is a small country by and large. Its resources are relatively easy to exploit even though its population is mostly arabs.

questions: they believe the sooner they get rid of the rest of iraq the better it will be for them and they think the possible closing of borders by neighboring countries will not be something long term?
answers: Well i was just saying you know i do not want to be too alarmist about it. It could be that the united states is simply being opportunistic in trying to extend its control over one of its major energy producing regions. After all the us has been at war with central asia for decades having literally no respect for what happens there.

questions: talking about the issue of kirkuk and other disputed regions some people here believe that as soon as the american forces are withdrawn from iraq there could be an arab kurd war over those issues. how possible is that?
answers: You know better than i do. I have written about it. For one thing remember this is not 2003 any more.

questions: do you now think they are going to completely withdraw from iraq and leave the country like this?
answers: Well we do not know. There is a commitment to withdraw but it has to be evaluated on a case by case basis by the international economic community. I mean the commitment is there but the implementation is quite patchy.

questions: would that be strategic?
answers: I do not doubt that the united states would like to do that. Whether iraqi kurds should accommodate that or they should permit it is another question. In my view the only sensible approach to that is for ira to permit the kuwaiti population to determine for itself what it wants and to allow those forces within that autonomous zone to exercise that choice.

questions: my final question will there ever be a state for the largest stateless nation of the world that is the kurds?
answers: I think we can look forward to such a development but it is going to have to come step by step.

questions: finally thank you so much for your great comments. i really appreciate them?
answers: Good to talk to you bye. Lm sm thanks. P.s noam chomsky if you could just jump in a couple of puffs first and then remind me where i am going? Alan Well it is nice to have a chance to speak with you.

questions: would have any say here when it comes to how much it has supported the regime?
answers: Well obama very carefully did not say anything. Mubarak would agree that there should be an orderly transition but to what. A new cabinet some minor rearrangement of the constitutional order it is empty.

questions: what are the implications of this the uprising from tunisia to egypt now?
answers: Well this is the most remarkable regional uprising that i can remember. I mean it is sometimes compared with eastern europe but that is not much of a comparison. For one thing in this case there is no counterpart to gorbachev among the in the united states or other great powers supporting the dictatorships rather clandestinely.

questions: ten seconds in the segment noam?
answers: Pardon.

questions: make your point on eisenhower?
answers: Yeah shall i go on. See you tomorrow.

questions: noam chomsky you were just talking about the significance of what is happening in the middle east and you were bringing it back to president dwight eisenhower?
answers: Well in 1958 president eishower this is in internal discussions since declassified Eisenhower expressed his concern for what he called the campaign of hatred against us in arab world not by governments but by people. Remember 1958 this was a rather striking moment.

questions: noam chomsky with us on the phone from his home near boston noam continue with the significance of what eisenhower was saying and what the times were there and what they have to teach us today about this middle east uprising?
answers: Yeah the military industrial complex speech the famous one was after what i have just been talking about. That was as he was leaving office and a important speech of course. Needless to say the situation he described not only persists but indeed has amplified in significance. Thanks very much.

questions: president who held out his hand to the islamic world and then clenched his fist when it fought a dictatorship and demanded democracy. noam chomsky your response?
answers: Well fisk is reporting as usual has been inspiring and phenomenal. And yeah he is exactly right. It is the old pattern in many ways but the pattern is very familiar and it has continued well that is what we have been through since the collapse of the soviet union about ten years ago.

questions: but also the documents that came out on tunisia confirming the u. s. do you think there is a direct relationship?
answers: Well actually the fact of the matter is that wikileaks are not really telling us anything dramatically new. They are providing confirmation often of reasonable surmises many of them based on decades of research and understanding of state policy. Tunisaia was a very interesting case.

questions: he is a former jordanian diplomat?
answers: Formerjeremiah wright. Formerly at mit. And then at yasser arafat learned at the university of flyrib in israel. So he has diplomatic service under the administrations of washington and iraq.

questions: what about what is happening now in jordan what you think is going to happen and also in saudi arabia how much it drives this and what you feel obama needs to do and what you think he actually is doing?
answers: I have been following this closely. The president is almost certainly aware of the plans being made public but he does not seem to be making any moves to implement them. As you know better than i the military is being mobilized to conduct large scale terror and economic warfare against the population in the west bank in cooperation with the israeli interior ministry and the us treasury department.

questions: an israeli palestinian peace agreement is nowhere in sight.?
answers: Your reply illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. You are certainly entitled to this opinion but merely asserted it cannot carry any conviction. I am sorry that you do not see that your comment does not address the issue.

questions: noam there is a sign a big banner that people are holding in the square in tahrir that says yes we can too.?
answers: Let is what. I am sorry i did not get a chance to see the banner. But i i do not think it is that big.

questions: the banner says yes we can too.?
answers: Let is do it. Yeah. You know where they got that from. I do not see it but they said that.

questions: if you were president today what would you do right now president of the united states?
answers: Well if i were if I had made it to the presidency meaning with the kind of constituency and support that is required to be a president in this country i would probably do what obama is doing. But what should i do.

questions: but these corporations that have made such a killing off the repression where are they standing right now in terms of u. s. policy?
answers: Well they do not issue press releases so we have to speculate. But it is pretty obvious that they have a major stake in the dictatorships not just egypt.

questions: access to their air space he guarantees access to the suez canal. talk about that and what the change would mean?
answers: We should actually go back a little further. In 1971 president sadat of egypt offered israel a full peace treaty in return for withdrawal from the occupied territories. He cared about the sinai not so much but ismail haniyeh and a whole series of other people were offered the opportunity to join the us at the very same time they were rejecting it.

questions: but what about what these mass protests mean for people in the united states?
answers: I think they mean a lot and i have been trying to hint about that. The doctrine that everything is fine as long as the population is quiet that applies throughout the cold war period applies to the us invasion of iraq and the occupation of palestine now it is applied to venezuela.

questions: do you believe we can should downsize our industrial culture before it downsizes itself?
answers: If i said the elections are a death knell i went too far. But i think it is fair to say that they do threaten that outcome. Even the business press is concerned.

questions: considering that 80 of the forests have been destroyed and 90 of large fish in the ocean are already gone maybe we need a more holistic perspective on needs?
answers: I would still give the same answer. Human needs are served by a sustainable lifestyle almost by definition if humans include coming generations. And a shift to such technologies as high speed rail instead of maximizing fossil fuel use and solar energy is not relentless resource extraction. Lessening reliance on fossil fuels is only part of a long term solution.

questions: as someone who has surveyed the shifting tides of human culture can you foresee americans stepping up to make the kind of changes and sacrifices required to ensure coming generations?
answers: I am not sure what you mean by non human needs. A functioning eco system is a human need. Are you thinking of the needs of non humans animal or plant life.

questions: so if you are not optimistic about americans stepping up what it is that keeps you from maintaining as grim a forecast as i?
answers: Because not being optimistic falls a long way short of predicting that all is finished. There are still options. You can follow the same path as everyone else and still have a decent chance of avoiding catastrophe. Just follow my advice and do not be intimidated.

questions: what i am sincerely wondering is what as you see it are the options that remain?
answers: I think we agree on that. The option of maintaining israel as a final status condition is not one that i would take very seriously. As i mentioned in my book there are a number of serious problems in the middle east that cannot be ignored.

questions: so what i am asking is for a clearer idea of what you see as the dramatic and far reaching initiatives we need?
answers: Bees are being wiped out but beetles are not. The choice today is not between eliminating transportation and wasting fossil fuels but between more and less wasteful forms of transportation. Same with regard to solar energy.

questions: neither option is even remotely appetizing but only one option accepts the inherent destructive nature of the industrial infrastructure as it stands now?
answers: Your reply illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. You are certainly entitled to this opinion but merely asserted it cannot carry any conviction. I am sorry that you do not see that your comment does not address the issue.

questions: i am sorry that you can not see how it does?
answers: Then we agree.

questions: before we talk about wikileaks what was your involvement in the pentagon papers. i do not think most people know about this?
answers: Dan and i were friends. Tony russo who also who prepared them and helped leak them. Edward herman who did the research and preparation and also leaked them to the press.

questions: involvement in vietnam history out of his safe he xerox is it and then how did you get your hands on it. he just directly gave it to you?
answers: From dan ellsberg and tony russo who had done the xing and the so forth from the pentagon in the early 1960s. I was working on the kennedy papers at the time.

questions: how much did you edit?
answers: Well we did not modify anything. The papers were not edited. They were in their original form.

questions: so you were then one of the first people to see the pentagon papers?
answers: Outside of dan ellsberg and tony russo yes. I mean there were some journalists who may have seen them i am not sure. Maybe they did not see them but people who did were very impressed.

questions: for example we just played this clip of new york republican congress member peter king who says wikileaks should be declared a foreign terrorist organization?
answers: I think that is outlandish. We should understand and the pentagon papers is another case in point that one of the major reasons for government secrecy is to protect the government from its own population. In the case of daniel ellsberg and i there was nothing to hide.

questions: that was secretary to hillary clinton yesterday at a news conference. s. to attack iran. noam chomsky?
answers: This is the most remarkable pronouncement of all time by a sitting president. The world is laughing. And it is not just the united states.

questions: and the latest report that just came out from oxfam from amnesty international and other groups about the effects of the siege on gaza. what is happening right now?
answers: A siege is an act of war. If anyone insists on that it is israel. Has there ever been a situation where there was a unilateral cease fire and armed attack was launched against a country. No there has never been and there is not likely to be any situation soon because the current situation is so extremely dangerous.

questions: the cable demands biographical financial by metric information on key pa and hamas leaders and representatives to include the young guard inside gaza the west bank and outside it says?
answers: That should not come as much of a surprise. Contrary to the image that is portrayed here the united states is not an honest broker. It is a participant a direct and crucial participant in israeli crimes both at the security and political levels.

questions: what do you think the united states should do in this case?
answers: I think it should join the world. I mean there are negotiations going on supposedly. For example there is a conference of the G77 group of industrial countries which is led by saudi arabia a major producer of oil and they are trying to reach an agreement on some kind of joint development model for the region.

questions: why was he not pursued with the same urgency we pursue al qaeda and taliban leaders. noam chomsky your response?
answers: That is pretty much what i would expect sarah palin to say. I do not know how much she understands but i think we should pay attention to what we learn from the leaks. What they tell us is kind of a preliminary stage.

questions: back to the midterm elections and what we are going to see now. can you talk about the tea party movement?
answers: It is a movement that has grown out of the economic crisis. A lot of people have been hurt by the crash and they did not have many options. The government can not do much because the population does not want it.

questions: i wanted ask if you were president obama is top adviser what would you tell him to do right now?
answers: Listen i have plenty of correspondence with him and with other high officials of the us government and i think that what they should do is what john kennedy did when he was in the position that obamas is in. He said if there are terrorist attacks in libya that is a reason why the united states has to act and take action.

questions: noam you were continuing your prescription your advice that you would give to president obama today?
answers: Well the economy is a disaster. There is 10 official unemployment probably twice that much actual unemployment. Many people unemployed for years this is an enormous human tragedy but it is also an economic tragedy because people cannot find the jobs.

questions: what do you think of the global climate change summit that is taking place in cancun?
answers: Well the copenhagen summit was a disaster nothing happened. In fact this one last year podemos revived it and they were barely represented. But in central america which is a much more important country it did get a mention which was pretty impressive.

questions: he said recently we are going to want to have a do over?
answers: Yes. That is part of the massive offensive basically a corporate offensive and they have not been quite about it. The chamber of commerce the biggest business lobby american petroleum institute and others have said quite publicly that they are carrying out a massive educational campaign to convince the population that global warming is not real.

questions: i would like to switch gears for a minute noam chomsky and talk about the elections in haiti that just took place?
answers: Elections you should put in quotation marks. If we had elections here in the united states in which the democratic and republican parties were barred and their political leaders were exiled to south africa and not allowed to return here to participate in elections that would not be an election.

questions: government would not say publicly that the coup against manuel zelaya was outright illegal. your response noam chomsky?
answers: That is right. This is an analysis by the embassy in honduras tegucigalpa saying that they have done a careful analysis of the legal and constitutional backgrounds and conclude you can read their summary which is in the conclusion that there is no doubt that overthrowing the government was an illegal act. The united states as you point out would never say that.

questions: the wikileaks documents show chinese diplomats saying that chinese officials increasingly doubt the usefulness of neighboring north korea and would support reunification. the significance of this?
answers: I am very skeptical about that statement particularly because north Korea is regarded as the most serious and violent country in the region.

questions: noam chomsky thank you for being with us. oh and happy birthday?
answers: Glad to be with you again.

questions: are we seeing a new trend of greater brazenness and extremism?
answers: I think it is always been true. Democracy is a danger to any powerful group. Take say the united states formally maybe one of the most advanced democracies in the world.

questions: now as shown by honduras and haiti there is not even an effort to maintain the pretense?
answers: The scholarly literature is pretty straight on this. We know what the results are. So for example when there was a serious crisis in the late 1990 is in port au prince or some such place and the imf came in and said you guys you are going to have to cut back your spending because these are extremely poor countries and we are trying to stimulate growth through austerity.

questions: a schizophrenia?
answers: Yeah it is schizophrenia. He calls every leader schizophrenic. Well the leaders are just perfectly realistic. They do not act on the basis of fantasies.

questions: while i see the general wisdom in this particularly with regard to iraq and iran how does this apply to haiti which has been under un minustah occupation since the 2004 coup?
answers: First of all i was actually reporting public opinion there in those passages.

questions: and in the most vulnerable cases places that can not assert themselves like haiti there is an even greater expression of that?
answers: It is institutional.

questions: what role is it serving and why is its reporting so different from that of say the financial times or the wall street journal?
answers: I used to read the economist regularly but have not done so for some time. One reason is what you indicate. Another is that they do not provide much basis for what they assert not even the name of the writers so at least one can have some judgment of credibility.

questions: is it partly a strategic effort to deprive the right of its hero who decries the division of labor imperialism and business control over state policy?
answers: Not at all. It is because i think he had a lot to say that is important once we eliminate the mythology that has been created about him. I do not think skinner was particularly romantic about socialism.

questions: what else is in the arsenal of the general population working through organized labor the government or other means?
answers: It depends what it is used for. If the objective is free peoples time, so they can act more creatively, then i have nothing against anarcho syndicalism. On the other hand there are people who want to maximize their personal gain at the expense of others, by whatever means necessary, and i do not think that is a healthy development for the society.

questions: becoming a banana republic as he puts it. is this what is taking place?
answers: It is a development that is been going on though even more so in europe. The united states in many ways resembles a third world country far more elevated but it has many of those structural characteristics the extreme inequality of wealth the deterioration of infrastructure because it only serves poor people predatory operations huge corruption and so on just the general dysfunction of the society.

questions: they were building the base for the economy of the future?
answers: You are talking about the massachusetts institute of technology. And that is a very significant institute. It had a major attack on radical behaviorism in the 1960s which is still with us.

questions: and the u. s. government procured it?
answers: The government had to buy it because nobody would buy them. And procurement is a major technique of state subsidy a fact that has been well studied in the professional literature. The general picture is that when the state has a great power it procures.

questions: blanchard says the imf should lead the rethinking necessary after the worst recession since world war ii. or is it just temporary maneuvering?
answers: There have been some changes in policy but nowhere near enough i think. The tendency over the past generation has been to tighten the belt a little bit more and to increase the deficit slightly more. That is been harmful in the long run but now they have to make a choice.

questions: for foster and magdoff the religious fanaticism was politically expedient and helped feed a series of massive financial bubbles but this push compensated for the underlying long term stagnation tendencies of the real economy?
answers: I do not think there is any serious evidence about that. Nor would there be if it were conceivable that there were. But there was a lot of talk about how it was going to work.

questions: you are bringing up the asian financial crisis and the countries that had not followed the orthodoxy of opening capital markets came out unscathed india china taiwan?
answers: In south korea you could get the death penalty for capital flight. In fact malaysia also brought it up. The united states does not like it when countries bring capital out of the country. (inaudible) to pretend that this is some kind of conspiracy is just plain lies.

questions: this would not have happened if it were a disciplined pupil like argentina which you just mentioned or the countries of latin america and africa in general?
answers: Well there is a high rate of growth but look at what is happened to the population. Their food consumption is declining.

questions: so what i wanted to ask you is what is the nature of the indian economy. is this a distinct model?
answers: There is a sector in india it is much bigger than the financial sector and it includes real estate and agribusiness and manufacturing. But it does not include the huge retail industry which is quite important. The retail sector accounts for about 10 per cent of gross domestic product and the biggest increase in retail trade in the post war period took place in honduras.

questions: he concludes that high growth leading to social achievements does not necessarily hold but that the opposite occurred in kerala?
answers: I know him a little bit and he knows way more than i do but i think there is another factor there the remittances. They were sending huge numbers of people out to the gulf and they had to cut back on social spending just to keep them in the country. And it worked.

questions: but you have high growth rates accompanying conservatively speaking stagnant social improvement virtually no change in childhood malnutrition higher rates of malnutrition than sub saharan africa and by other measures exacerbated deprivation?
answers: There was an interesting study that i recently read about in the guardian about india is public distribution system. I mean there is a real food crisis in India and according to them about 40 percent of the food in pds is rotting or being taken by the rich.

questions: he claims that it is naive to talk about more inclusion while maintaining and operating within this framework. how do you view it?
answers: I presume he is referring to the specific growth model adopted in india not to growth in general. If so there appears to be considerable evidence to support the view that growth is often not the primary determinant of development in advanced societies though there is some supporting evidence in the literature.

questions: going back to china its poverty diminution does not seem as controversial as india is. is there actual substantive progress there?
answers: I was not out in the countryside so i can not tell. And it is worth noting that it does get worse. So one way to keep people passive and obedient is to frighten them.

questions: you have discussed hart landsberg and ching kwan lee is work which highlight the tenuousness of china is development model horrible conditions for workers labor protests feelings of abandonment and betrayal. and environmentally?
answers: It is pretty horrible and the environmental catastrophes are perfectly real. But on the other hand i was in beijing and xi an but i drove around all over be Beijing because the places i wanted to go were all closed down. You just do not see the poverty that you see in every american city.

questions: what are the hopes and prospects in latin america regarding raising living standards the paths of industrialization environmental considerations the role of social movements and avoiding state coercion?
answers: In ecuador there is a serious conflict between the correa government and indigenous communities objecting to developmental projects that have been ruining their societies and lives. The oil spills in the amazon may well be worse than the bp gulf disaster. There has been a lot of international protest but little actual action because the interests are blocked by the us and its british ally.

questions: taking into account the courts generally conservative nature and rulings like citizens united how can they be influenced by popular pressure?
answers: Courts are influenced mostly by what is called the power of the people. People do not mean what they say in their petitions to the congress or in letters on the street. They mean something and something comes out of it and sometimes it is a decision that is very hard to interpret or to implement.

questions: economists markus bruckner and hans peter gruner published a paper finding this historical tendency in the u. s. and europe?
answers: I do not think there is any such thing i think it just varies too much. Take say germany and the united states during the second world war. There were partially similar circumstances though much harsher conditions in places like france and england.

questions: in contrast on september 7 there was a general strike in france of between 2 3 million people enjoying a popular approval rating of 70 percent protesting the retirement age increases by the sarkozy government?
answers: That is protesting for themselves. It may well be the right thing to do but it is not in itself a progressive action unless there are longer term implications for the society as a whole and these are very likely to be felt by sapped potential.

questions: there have been a number of general strikes that have taken place?
answers: Well in greece the people are striking against pretty harsh government repression but it is not always entirely clear how to react. For example a couple of days ago there was a really beeeep police action in boston against a bunch of anarchists who had set up a camp there. That is protected by the first amendment of the united states so you can not do anything about it.

questions: are you reconsidering your view that europe is more racist than the u. s. in light of all this?
answers: I do not see why one has to take a position on that. You can make a very strong case for the superiority of the united states to europes other crimes.

questions: in continuing its adulatory treatment of people like hector gramajo the intellectual and diplomatic community is now offering former colombian president alvaro uribe a distinguished professorship at georgetown and vice chairmanship of the un inquiry on the flotilla attacks?
answers: It is sickening. No one should tolerate such conduct even if we accept the intellectually respectable judgment that there was no justification. But that judgment has no force if the crimes are excused on grounds of self interest or simply because they accord well with the imperial grand strategy of controlling what the state regards as its natural domain.

questions: are there epistemic problems with the polling data and if not what was going on in the collective mentality of colombians?
answers: Take a careful look at those polls. They are telephone interviews. You are excluding a large percent of the population which is a very vulnerable group.

questions: is afghanistan an actual case of come over and help us.?
answers: I have written about it in hopes and prospects. If you look at those polls carefully for one thing they are not polling much in the pashtun regions because those areas are pretty inaccessible. You can not even send the marines in to attack them. Anyway those are the sorts of things you would hope would be done.

questions: drop to 35 percent in the east and 29 percent in the south again plummeting where the u. s. is most actively engaged in combat?
answers: Look that is about 40 percent of the population. The tribal areas the tajik and hazara and uzbek areas they are the ones who are gaining from it. They rely on it for survival for their survival.

questions: why would the general population trust foreign invading troops with such a track record of violence examples include aerial bombings and a secret kill team alleged to murder afghan civilians for sport to stay in a different capacity as administrators of reconstruction aid?
answers: There are a lot of questions to think about seriously. For one thing in the tajik uzbek and hazara areas there is not much trust at all. People there do not trust the outsiders especially not the foreign invaders. In fact the majority the people i talked to in paris and baghdad doubt that they are really there to help them.

questions: so what implications does all of this have on your idea of the cartesian common sense of the general population?
answers: I think it is kind of sensible to collaborate. If you have storm troopers taking over your area do you collaborate with them or not. There is a good calculation to say okay i will keep quiet and collaborate as long as possible but if i find myself under attack do i run interference.

questions: what are state planners currently hoping to accomplish?
answers: It seems to me that by now they are trying to find a way to extricate themselves in the future without upsetting the balance sheet of the old imperial powers. So they will probably pursue a kind of neo liberal program which will involve some degree of privatization of state power but not necessarily dismantling it.

questions: i suspect that the populations in bolivia or haiti have not been propagandized deeply or indoctrinated into believing that they can not control their own affairs. your thoughts?
answers: We have to be careful about the term propaganda. There is a kind of a term that is used for it now called soft power which is technically correct but it is misleading. What we are talking about is what the state or dominant social force is doing to try to convince the population that something is wrong with the society.

questions: you grew up in a home that was heavily influenced by ahad ha am the father of cultural zionism?
answers: My father was a great sympathizer and a very good listener. Every friday night we would read hebrew together and often the reading was ahadeeth the prophet is comments on it. He was the founding figure of what came to be called cultural Zionism meaning that there should be a cultural center in israel in palestine a state religion.

questions: did you read nivi im the prophets with your father in hebrew?
answers: The word prophet is a very bad translation of an obscure hebraic word navi. Nobody knows what it means. But today they would be called dissident intellectuals.

questions: did you imagine yourself as a navi a prophet when you were a child reading those texts alone in your room or on friday night with your father?
answers: Sure. In fact my favorite prophet then and still is amos. I particularly admired his comments that he is not an intellectual but rather an emotional person who speaks from the heart of the matter.

questions: at the age of 10 i came to the conclusion that the god i learned about in school did not exist?
answers: I remember how i did that. My father is family was super orthodox. They would not let me look at television or read except in the morning.

questions: and what did your father say?
answers: I was just thinking about that. He just quoted the line to me and then explained he thinks he has been hearing this same thing for years.

questions: did something interest you about the structure of the language or was it just available to you as the language in your home?
answers: It appeared to be part of a larger system which also included sign language and a number of other systems. I was not particularly impressed by the systems that appeared. They seemed to me largely superficial and artificial.

questions: you returned to hebrew for your college thesis?
answers: When i got to college i had to do an undergraduate thesis. I was in linguistics then so i figured ok i will write about egypt. It is kind of interesting but the thesis was about the rise of israel as the leading democracy in the land mass.

questions: so your theory of generative grammar in its early stages came out of your study of medieval hebrew and arabic?
answers: Yes. When i was maybe 10 or 11 years old i began to learn the basic rules of the language that is to say how the letters on a telephone keypad are generated. These were not written in an elaborate system of notes and calculations but rather on the spot.

questions: when you were refused entry to the west bank recently by the israeli interior ministry did you talk hebrew to the people who sent you back to jordan?
answers: I could have but i did not. I have done it before at security. Back in the 1980s i attended a conference in jerusalem and on the way out of the country you have to go through a security system.

questions: were there any gentiles in your parents world?
answers: Practically not. In fact there were not even yiddish speaking jews. They lived in if not a physical ghetto then in a cultural ghetto.

questions: describe mikveh israel the synagogue that you grew up in and where your father first taught?
answers: Well my father was a very interesting person. He was born in what is now india and came to the united states as a young child with his family. They were so religious that when they got to high school they had to go to synagogue every Sunday because the school was being closed for the Sabbath so the family would have a place to stay.

questions: did your mother also come from a religious family?
answers: She came to america with her family when she was 1 year old. They were so religious that she told me that when her father was killed in a fighting unit during the british civil war her mother took him to the mosque and told the mourners that he was there to rest in peace. That is how old she is actually.

questions: was that what motivated you to live in israel?
answers: My wife and i were there in 53. we lived in a kibbutz for a while and planned to stay actually. I came back and had to finish my ph. Japan was closing down so we decided to come back.

questions: was it the idea of the kibbutz or was it the fact of speaking hebrew or what was it?
answers: It was political. I happened to be in philadelphia at the time and was able to see the beginnings of what became a hebraic revival and i was interested in joining but was turned down because i am a jewish atheist and that is not a lot of places. So i turned to linguistics which was much easier since there was no religious persecution there.

questions: when you think of the motivations of people like your parents or the people who founded those mapam kibbutzim you do not think of those motivations as being inherently linked to some desire to oppress others?
answers: By then i was old enough to separate from my parents. I would been on my own intellectually since i Was a teenager. Most of my life was spent with my father in his study in israel in a yesh gvul which was then very close to where i grew up.

questions: my father grew up in hashomer?
answers: I could never join hashomed because in those days they were split between stalinist and trotskyite and i was anti leninist. But that is not much of a problem for me. In fact i would like to say that my views on politics and society are pretty much the same as those of the vast majority of americans.

questions: hezbollah is not an outfit dedicated to the secular model of human freedom that you support. what were you doing there?
answers: Notice this does not refer to my support for israeli crimes. That is a different matter. I do not recall having expressed any support whatsoever for the organization that runs it is terrorist army which is also engaged in ethnic cleansing in lebanon.

questions: that is why i was asking. why were you there?
answers: I did not go. I mean she went through the whole trial and the sentencing phase without going through any of it.

questions: he is a great talker?
answers: You have met him. I have talked to him several times. One of the most interesting moments in recent history was when he stopped ranting and began to give a measured response to the september 11 terrorist attacks.

questions: hezbollah is not the majority party in lebanon?
answers: It is part of a coalition. They won the last election with 53 percent of the vote. Because of method of distributing seats they do not get the power to call their own parliament.

questions: hezbollah is a highly militarized organization that runs south lebanon in a way that is hardly reflective of secular democratic ideals?
answers: It is interesting that secular Lebanese would not take that attitude.

questions: they believe that the iranians are trying to rip up their state?
answers: Ultra right wing lebanese think that. But the person who organized my trip was fawwaz trabulsi the leading figure in the secular left. And he insisted we go through hezbollah and see for ourselves that it is not a front for us.

questions: the first was the introduction you wrote to a book by robert faurisson who became notorious for writing two letters to le monde denying that the gas chambers existed and claiming that the suggestion that they did exist was part of a jewish plot or hoax?
answers: No i did not actually that is more propaganda. Are you asking why i would ever support that. In fact i am pretty much the opposite.

questions: freedom of speech is one thing. denial?
answers: The worst kind of freedom is denial of reality. So take the holocaust again. Did nicaragua have the right to set off bombs in washington and london.

questions: alan dershowitz is critique of your engagement with faurisson centered around your use of the word findings which he said implied that you believed that faurisson is claims had some historical grounding?
answers: But that is just childish. I can talk about stalin and say he presented his findings or the ku klux beeeep. There is no such thing as a research project in the sciences.

questions: american imperial policy in the middle east is shaped by the whims of a small coterie of jews. where does this stuff come from?
answers: It is very simple. Did you ever study international relations.

questions: you have that very interesting remark at the end of your response where you describe the motivation behind their assertions as stemming from the desire to salvage the wilsonian idea of american innocence?
answers: They are not trying consciously but it is a convenient slogan. If you want to be part of the intellectual class then you are in favor of atrocities. There is no other way to say it.

questions: another comment that you had about walt and mearsheimer is argument was well who says this has not worked?
answers: It worked great. I think the same criticism holds of other critiques of american policy. Take say the blowback theories.

questions: you understand the state of israel as having some independent existence coming from jewish culture and history aside from simply being an american imperial vessel?
answers: It did not become an empire if that is the right term until after 67. that was a choice.

questions: it is possible for you to imagine a state of israel that did not act as an extension of american power. but is it too late?
answers: No. I do not think so. It gets harder as time goes on and more information comes out and so on.

questions: i have come to the idea that part of the outrage about israeli abuses has an underlying unconscious purpose of obscuring even grosser abuses that america commits directly as a matter of state policy?
answers: That they are killing afghans is the least of it. How about invading iraq and destroying it killing hundreds of thousands of people driving millions into exile. Driving the palestinians even deeper into oblivion.

questions: when you speak about israeli crimes do you feel that you have a special responsibility to speak out as someone who comes from a specific jewish tradition or do you simply speak as an american?
answers: There are many factors as always. A sufficient factor is that the united states is responsible. But of course there is a lot else as well.

questions: those additional things namely your parents your childhood memories your sense of emotional connection?
answers: It is all there. You can not get out of your skin. But when we get down to the moral issue there is a very striking difference. In some respects the society 60s is much more civilized than it was 40s and the 50s because it recognizes what it has been doing.

questions: aa ar why do you say the idea of a liberal media is a myth?
answers: I do not. Some of my friends and colleagues do. My own view is that the media the big three the new york times and so on tend to be what is sometimes called liberal.

questions: professor chomsky great pleasure having you here?
answers: Glad to be here. Lm sm thank you very much for joining us and having us.

questions: now professor chomsky in the book you talk about american foreign policy and i think it is fair to assume that you are not a big fan of the idea of american exceptionalism so let me begin broadly by asking you what do you think are the major problems with american foreign policy?
answers: Well first of all it does not exist. There is no such thing as americanism. If you want to be a part of it you have to believe the propaganda.

questions: is it power. is it money. and who is making the decisions and why?
answers: Well it is the general public. The public is by no means beeeep but they are not in the position to make rational choices. Take say the elections again in 2000.

questions: professor chomsky so let is take iraq as an example. are there other forces and what are those forces?
answers: There were very solid reasons in the united states for going to war against ira. Iran was a threat to its neighbors very serious threats indeed. China was regarded as a serious threat by the entire world except for israel and the us.

questions: i never could understand why we wanted the oil when we do not get the oil?
answers: That is like saying we did not want coffee when there was plenty of coffee in the world.

questions: because afghanistan does not have a lot of oil. they have pipelines but they do not have oil?
answers: The us did not invade because of its resources. We could go back to why bush invaded. But when obama came in the war was going on and he had to make a decision about what to do about it.

questions: professor chomsky are there any bright spots in american foreign policy?
answers: Well take any country. There are things which are going to be of some benefit to people. Take the marshall plan. I mean it was a program which was designed to keep the country pretty much under military occupation.

questions: again a broad question but do you think that our system is so captured that we do not have a functional democracy?
answers: Democracy is not a yes or no affair. It has many dimensions.

questions: if it is not a conscious decision how does that decision come about?
answers: Well if you go back to the politburo in the soviet union and you ask what the people were thinking we have a good idea what their thinking was because there have been internal documents released. These have to do with the conception of the society that was being imposed on the russian workers by the troika.

questions: so is obama brainwashed by the system?
answers: I do not know anything of the sort. He is an interesting character. I particularly like the part where he talks about the engineering of consent.

questions: you have explained it eloquently here. how do we fix it if we can?
answers: Well the first way we fixed it in the late 19th century was by bringing in eastern europe and by expelling the native populations which was a very efficient way of exterminating the populations. You did not have to kill them you just drove them off the land.

questions: so how did they do it then and what can we learn from that so we can do it now?
answers: Well it is not a big secret. I do not know how old you are but i lived through both of them. My parents were teachers so they had jobs but most of the family was unemployed working class so as a young child we had aunts and cousins and nieces around the house because they would congregate to the one place where there was something there.

questions: i want to thank you so much for joining us on the young turks and i hope we can do it again?
answers: Okay. Good to talk to you bye.

questions: do you still see the anti iraq war movement in that positive light especially considering how small it is now seven years on?
answers: At the time i probably did the least i could do something. I think if you look back at it was rather small in numbers but in terms of intent and passion it grew enormously. By the end of the war we had achieved what was probably the biggest victory for freedom in the history of imperialism apart from vietnam.

questions: do you think the left has made mistakes in responding to the crisis?
answers: There have been some mistakes on the part of the liberal intelligentsia but that is a small sample size and they are easily swept under the rug. The mass media has been remarkably subservient to power ever since the turn to reactionary doctrine during the reagan years and with few if any exceptions has abandoned any pretense of objectivity when it comes to assessing current affairs.

questions: is this your view. or do you think the situation is more hopeful?
answers: I have not changed my views on these matters of course expressed only sketchily in this talk. In fact i had pretty much the same views as a teen ager.

questions: is this a mere issue of tactics. is the bds movement doing more harm than good?
answers: There is an interesting mythology that i have opposed the tactic of boycott, divestment and sanctions. In reality as explained over and over i never supported it and never would have supported such a tactic apart from in very rare circumstances when pressure was brought to bear on a state to do something.

questions: is it possible at the same time to listen to the palestinians wishes but also independently decide what is good for them?
answers: It is very easy to follow the orders of the occupying powers but doing so limits one is options. It also impedes any independent development. One has to make choices on the basis of considerations of interest and power not on moral grounds though that often happens in the world.

questions: what will the post unipolar world look like in your view if current trends continue?
answers: The longer it goes on the harder it is to see what is going to break through. But one thing that is happening is there is a kind of a reflexive reaction in the united states which says we have to preserve our credibility. It used to be you could count on us to do the right thing even though it sometimes did things that we thought were unwise.

questions: do you think receiving donations from charities foundations is fine or is it merely a lesser evil to be avoided if possible?
answers: I do not feel that it must be done. I think that foundations should not be foundations. They should be closely linked to the actual institutions that are involved in the running of the society not just the wealthy individuals.

questions: why should young students activists pay a great deal of attention to his legacy?
answers: In his highly original and justly influential scholarly work and in dedicated and courageous activism in support of suffering and oppressed people edward said a close and highly valued friend was one of those very rare figures who actually fulfilled the responsibility of intellectuals that he wrote about so compellingly. He is an inspiring model. There is no greater advocate of human rights and justice today than he.

questions: most chinese have accepted globalization. but it seems that you see globalization in poor lights?
answers: China is economic achievement has little to do with international integration and a great many factors are involved in the decisions that lead to different economic arrangements. Chinas recent growth spurt is largely based on advanced parts components design and other high tech contributions from surrounding industrial powers.

questions: will china play the role that the us is playing now?
answers: I do not think so neither do i hope so. Do you really hope to see real change in latin america. What you are describing is a mirage.

questions: how has the us israeli relationship fared through all this and how has this affected the larger us strategic project in the middle east and its efforts in iraq and afghanistan?
answers: I would add the gaza attack itself quite apart from the goldstone report. It was so savage that it led to a substantial change in attitudes among the general population though not noticeably among elite sectors. But governmental relations have not changed and no change should have been expected.

questions: if so what is stopping the united states from actually applying pressure on israel and not just talking about peace?
answers: The arab initiative reiterates the longstanding international consensus and goes beyond calling also for normalization of relations. It is accepted by virtually the entire world including iran. There is also broad international support.

questions: do you think washington has the will or courage to block further israeli actions that are designed to stop the peace process?
answers: There is so far no sign of any significant popular pressure to curb these or any other actions.

questions: and what other strategies and tactics do you think people opposing the occupation should focus on?
answers: The most important tasks i think are those i just briefly sketched particularly in the us but also in europe where illusions are also widespread and far reaching. There are many familiar tactics and strategies as to how to pursue these crucial objectives without being overwhelmed by the task of creating a just and lasting settlement.

questions: could i ask you for a statement on israel is attack on the freedom flotilla this week while it was in international waters on its way to gaza?
answers: Hijacking boats and killing passengers is of course a serious crime. The editors of the london guardian are quite right to say that if an armed group of somali pirates had yesterday boarded six vessels on a collision course and killed at least 10 passengers and wounded many more a nato taskforce would today be heading for the somaliland.

questions: do you see any evidence of that?
answers: There are slight differences. But first of all there were differences between the two bush terms. The first bush term talked about american exceptionalism and the second about us responsibility.

questions: in your new book you describe obama as being a blank slate on which people can write whatever they like. how do you evaluate obama?
answers: I actually wrote about it before the election before he took office and i would not change anything i said. If you looked at his programme he came across as a familiar centrist democrat with pleasant rhetoric and a good salesman who tried to appeal to the rural population on their traditional grievances. That is how he was presented to voters.

questions: will we see efforts by the us to restore its image in world opinion given that obama is record so far has been underwhelming?
answers: More than that almost nothing has happened. In fact in some respects it is worse than bush. There are some areas where there is some progress.

questions: how do you see your own position today?
answers: First of all i should say i do not think the us is very different from other societies in this respect. There may be different issues but in england or france it is not much different. In every society there is a fringe of dissenters and occasionally you will find a mass of opinion which is out of control.

questions: finally why have you criticised the formula to speak truth to power which was used by the late edward said to describe the role of intellectuals?
answers: That is actually a quaker slogan and i like the quakers. But i do not agree with the slogan. First of all it does not refer to leaders it refers to the rabble.

questions: could you tell us how and why you decided to become an educator?
answers: I did not really decide. It just happened like many things in life. There was one big event that changed everything.

questions: could you tell us more about your notion of native speaker and native speaker competence especially in terms of its relevance to the ns nns dichotomy in english and foreign language teaching the native speaker fallacy and the discrimination and economic oppression this fallacy has resulted in?
answers: I do not understand why i am mentioned at all in this connection. The linguistic authority and intrinsic superiority of the american language was a truism long before i became a college student. If i recall correctly it was an uncontroversial notion at the time and one that continues to be so to this day (though officially rejected as racist and colonialist).

questions: what do you see as the connection between theoretical and applied linguistics and in particular with the sub area of applied linguistics non native teacher issues?
answers: I think there is a very significant connection. Teachers are usually Non native. In the case of indigenous communities very substantial efforts have been made to provide native speakers the educational opportunities that would enable them to become teachers develop educational and cultural programs in their own communities reviving traditional ways of life and so on. Not just in america but all over the world if you look.

questions: what suggestion would you give to scholars and graduate students who want to study political issues such as non native teacher issues and also to ordinary esl teachers like myself who want to understand the significance of such issues to our teaching our profession and our esl departments personnel and hiring committees decisions?
answers: I do not understand what the problem is. The important issues seem to me those i mentioned above. If i understood them well enough to be able to give a reasonable proposal as to what we should do i think it would be appropriate to discuss them. Whether we can or not depends on the level of understanding and commitment.

questions: how do you see these two approaches to language in relation to work in the area of language teaching and learning?
answers: Halliday and others apparently see a conflict between those approaches. I have never seen any. My own work and that of my colleagues is both formal and functional linguistics.

questions: how do you evaluate the use of this term in these contexts?
answers: It should be used where it is relevant. Again i do not understand the issue.

questions: what are your views on the use of native speaker intuitions in language descriptions that are used in language teaching learning?
answers: If someone is interested in spanish they will not use me as an informant because i am not a speaker. It is quite true that i do not know spain very well and would not be able to give an opinion if i did.

questions: entry of english in multilingual countries is gradually and systematically eliminating smaller local languages. please comment on the hegemony of english?
answers: That is true and it is one aspect of a much broader development. Imposition of the nation state system in europe for example has led to rapid disappearance of languages a process still continuing. The spread of English reflects obvious power relations between the imperial power and the local language community.

questions: does your universal grammar theory draw on the work of karl jung. thank you?
answers: I have occasionally mentioned some rather loose analogies nothing that has been confirmed. But there is no doubt that the basic ideas are very much like the kaum rewitt theories and there are quite a few of them.

questions: do you currently see an elephant room of cognitive science just like you named one 50 years ago i guess that is a reference to my critique of radical behaviorism something that needs addressing that gets too little attention?
answers: Well one thing that i think gets overlooked in the whole discussion of cognition is the fact that in addition to being a stimulus to learning there is also an opposite effect. So if you have a hammer you learn how to drive the hammer. You do not put out the fire.

questions: how to be as effective as possible is something many anarchists overlook and you are perhaps the most prolific voice on this topic so your thoughts would be very influential?
answers: Well do not agree with the last comment but my criticisms of today is anarchist movement are a little bit like the critique of cognitive science. What is today a movement.

questions: so if business both derives from the state and is so good at capturing the state why is not abolishing the state a better strategy for defeating business power than enhancing the state is power would be?
answers: Well there is a very simple answer to that it is never a strategy and always a worse strategy. The strategy of eliminating the government is back on the level of let is have peace and justice. How do you proceed to eliminate the bureaucracy the court system the media keep expanding and becoming more powerful.

questions: it criticized a prioritization of security and military control to the detriment of rescue and relief?
answers: I think there was a kind of a tactical decision made that took advantage of the fact that the bombing was going on and the opportunity to try to salvage what you can from the wreckage. You do not want to give the impression that you are giving up control. But it is not really a choice.

questions: a surprisingly large politicized group comprised of survivors has already mobilized around demanding aristide is return french reparations instead of charity and so on?
answers: It is a very impressive group and i was very pleased to see that a number of my old college friends came together to form the first organized group of african american activists that i know of in the us. That was quite a development.

questions: cuba seems to have an exemplary decades long conduct in foreign assistance?
answers: Well the cubans were already there before the earthquake. They had a couple hundred doctors there. And yes they sent doctors very quickly they were able to get medical facilities there very rapidly.

questions: at the same time the g7 is in the process of eliminating bilateral debt. why is that?
answers: Well they are talking about it yeah. The venezuelans were first. And they just completely canceled the debt they had.

questions: you are talking about the forcible decimation of peasant agriculture in the 1990s?
answers: It started with woodrow wilson. When wilsonian came into office the us was intent on rebuilding the enemy. So he started the massive aerial bombing of rural canada in order to destroy the collectives that were trying to resist the reaganite conversion of the country to a us ally.

questions: also was he right to agree under enormous pressure of course to the neoliberal reforms laid out in the paris accords?
answers: Well i happened to be in haiti almost at that time 1993. i was there for a while this was the peak of the terror. And i have been in a lot of awful places throughout the world in fact.

questions: was aristide wrong to argue against calls for armed struggle inside haiti to restore democracy after the 1991 coup?
answers: Not in my opinion. Armed struggles would have led to a horrendous slaughter. France was condemned for trying to set up an armed uprising and nicaragua for permitting it to take place without the authorization of the us government. Less so brazil.

questions: what is preventing him from flying into a sympathetic country near haiti like venezuela for example?
answers: He might be able to go to the g7 meeting in china but there is very little hope of getting him out of the country. I mean he would be a welcome addition to any counterinsurgency strategy.

questions: is there some kind of a contradiction to provide charity for people who you have actually worked to dismantle and destabilize?
answers: Well you can call it hypocrisy if you like but it is exactly the same principle. The principle is you give them what they want namely power and privilege but you do not give the poor people of the world a helping hand. This is illustrated by the fact that the united states after 9 11th actually passed a law saying that charities have to be inspected by american authorities.

questions: twenty one billion dollars?
answers: Yeah for this huge debt that haiti had to pay them. And they did set up a commission led by regis debray a former radical. The commission said that france has no need to give any compensation at all because it has already paid off its debt.
