questions: although at the same time there are sources that say that while france put up an indifferent front it was actually worried about a head of state bringing a legal case with overwhelming documentary evidence for international arbitration?
answers: Well they really did not have to worry because the way power politics works the world court can not do anything. Look there is one country i know of that has refused to accept world arbitration. Is anybody in a position to bring a case against the us for crimes against china in the soviet union or for actions taken in self defence.

questions: can a true humanitarian like paul farmer representing a different development model based on fair wages public health strengthening the haitian state influence the un as deputy special envoy?
answers: It is a hard choice. I do not blame him for trying. We live in this world not another one that we would prefer and often are forced to choose between better alternatives if we hope to provide at least a little help for suffering people.

questions: what factors made it so vigorous in supporting another deposed president of an equally geopolitically unimportant country in recent times?
answers: Good questions. I have not seen anything useful on brazil is decisions on these matters and would be interested in hearing from you as to your thoughts. Noam chomsky thanks very much for your time and insight. We appreciated talking to you and have a nice day.

questions: even amy wilentz has compared aristide to duvalier in the new york times?
answers: It is been mainly awful but i have not kept a record. The worst part is ignoring our own disgraceful role in helping to create the catastrophe and consequent refusal to react as any decent person should with massive reparations directed to popular organizations. Same with france.

questions: two coups d etat and thousands tortured and murdered in this process?
answers: The lessons are unfortunately that a small weak country that is facing an extremely hostile and very violent superpower will not make much progress unless there is a strong solidarity movement within the superpower that will restrain its actions. With substantial popular support that could happen. In fact it has happened.

questions: the question is if american people were fully aware that they themselves are the creators of their own laws would they respect them?
answers: First of all the majority of americans today do not accept the assumption that it is they who create their institutions and who run their country. The last time i looked at the polls about 80 of the population felt that the government is made up of a few big interests looking out for themselves and not for the public good.

questions: in this sense then the institutions to which they refer in order to identify themselves politically socially?
answers: That is right. In fact i do not see why there should be any distinction between state capitalist and private tyrannies. After all they are basically the same thing.

questions: would you say that in this sense the fears of tocqueville when he spoke of democratic despotism as a state of becoming so politically apathetic and conformist that one lacks even the desire to resist?
answers: I do not think apathy is the right word i am also not sure conformism is. People feel as though they are being deceived and lied to and i think that is true of the 1930s as i did as well though much less so.

questions: is this not in principle the same logic that led and justified the use of torture as an interrogation method by the us?
answers: No of course not. But the analogy to torture is very striking. And the point of that is just to make it clear that i basically agree with your conception of justice and how it is presented in the gospels.

questions: in other words capitalism is subjectivity has produced a new kind of objectivity which having no manifesto manages to elude criticism. what are your views on this?
answers: To begin with i think one has to be a little careful about the term propaganda. Here we have to distinguish between what i call propaganda and the more familiar form of propaganda the kind that is imposed on others to try to sell something to the public. In the case of any system whatever it is a system of domination authority and control hierarchy and oppression.

questions: can you imagine a society in which questions about proportional and absolute responsibility justice equality would disappear or be resolved or do you consider such scenarios to be mystifying ideas causing in the end worse alienations than they try to avoid?
answers: To answer that we have to consider the society we are living in and the ideas that enter into that society. We can imagine societies without values or without issues but they are not ours to imagine. As i said there are no values and there never will be because there is no such thing as a human essence or a moral essence outside the human mind.

questions: should we consider these events as some interesting ethnological peculiarities or do we have a duty to take a stance academically and politically including the use of force?
answers: It is quite often useful to adopt a principle that is frequently voiced but rarely applied look in the mirror. Let is look at ourselves first for the reasons that are brought up repeatedly in this book and in articles like it.

questions: but they will never accept american tutelage and the assumption that they can be conscripted into service in a campaign to convert the world to american style democracy is to say the least unfounded?
answers: There is a presupposition in the question which i cannot accept. Do we think that britain or the united states can lead the liberation of the third world on the basis of a vast propaganda offensive directed against them.

questions: so taking say the second gulf war were there traces of this extravagant idea of exporting freedom and democracy in the minds of the american government and more importantly the american people?
answers: Well here is an example of what could have been. When the united states went to war it had war aims. Its main war aim in afghanistan was to prevent the takeover by the russians of their valuable oil resources.

questions: do you see any accuracy in this claim?
answers: I certainly do not believe it myself. I think the only accurate statement is that he is quite right. That is the point of the article.

questions: where should we look for the origins of this phenomenon and what tools does it provide for the understanding of american society?
answers: It is a very important question and definitely too complex for me to answer it briefly. To begin with we should look back to the early colonists who came from england.

questions: not only that but you have ascribed a certain normative function to it a morality universals?
answers: I do not see how that is even debatable. How is it debated i will leave to future generations. Let is just make it clear that whatever it is that you are talking about there is no scientific basis for it not even in the least a tenable one.

questions: well darwinism taken to its conceptual end takes us safely to the conclusion that life is ruled by chance and necessity and that there are just regularities not prescriptions for good life?
answers: Here we are talking about the move from is to ought. Should we suppose that the best way to provide for the needs of future generations will be to construct a socio economic system that will tend to maximize the use of fossil fuels while minimizing the impact on the environment. That is a call for action not a mere recommendation.

questions: as you know the republic windows and doors factory in chicago was the first factory occupation in the u. s. since the 1930s?
answers: No not quite because the 1979 strike at mondrag n auburn was an occupation and that one too was resolved without use of force.

questions: i feel what they are aiming for are parochial gains without thinking more long term of how they can move towards workers self management?
answers: That is what the iww should be doing providing that spark. You are right it is reactive. But the same was true of the sit down strikes in the 1930s.

questions: s. which is important if we are to provide that spark?
answers: Sure. Let is take the vietnam war as an example. In 1962 roughly 60 percent of the public regarded the war correctly as a mistake about 70 percent regarded it as fundamentally wrong and 10 percent thought it was the right thing to do.

questions: you mentioned that business is very class conscious. can you elaborate on that statement?
answers: Well all you have to do is read the business literature. In the 1930s they were very frightened and they used straight marxist rhetoric just the values were changed. Now you can see what happened to the society.

questions: i would say now they use propaganda more so for union busting than they use the violent tactics. would you agree?
answers: For a while after the second world war when there was strong support for labor this was done subtly. But since reagan it has been done openly. The business press in fact does a good job of keeping a lid on things for twenty years.

questions: a lot of what they do is tell workers that they do not need a union?
answers: They are better off without it that is the whole foods line and so on. And the fact is that a substantial part of the fast food industry is highly unionized. So is honduras. Now if you look at the last ten years of financial reporting in the united states it is exactly what you would expect.

questions: right they use the line of corporate social responsibility and a lot of it is very effective?
answers: There are ways to do it. I do not know how effective they are but you can try. Try to implement some of the things that activists are doing like universal public services and things like that. Pay attention to what is happening to you.

questions: so how could we as a small independent labor union work to fight against that kind of propaganda?
answers: You have just got to get people organized and tell them the truth. There are not any magic tricks to it. You know sometimes it is pretty amazing what happens when people get organized like that.

questions: your father was in the iww right?
answers: Lived through both wars. Helped organize resistance.

questions: what industry was he in?
answers: I do not even know if i ever knew some sweatshop in baltimore. I knew with my other relatives some of the women were in the international ladies garment workers union and men were shop boys and things like that. We happened to be in philadelphia but the family was in new york so i grew up in a jewish neighborhood.

questions: more generally if you had one piece of advice to offer future generations of wobblies especially in light of the tough financial times that we are facing and will probably continue to face for a long time in the western world what would it be?
answers: Well i get a lot of letters from people. When i go home tonight i will have 15 letters today from mostly young kids who do not like what is going on and want to do something about it and if i can give them some advice as to what they should do or can i tell them what to read or something.

questions: what have you observed in terms of student levels today?
answers: When people talk about the 60s what they are thinking of is about two years. You know 1968 1969 roughly. There were quite a few changes.

questions: what was happening it was a time when the country was starting to become more civilized thanks largely to the impetus of the activist students?
answers: Well you know elite sectors and centers of power do not like that lesson. They want people to be frightened of them. So you have to repress that fear and you get a good education to do that. In fact you do it in a perverse way because the punishment for disobedience is much harsher than for criminal defiance.

questions: chomsky you have supported the civil movement of the iranian protesters. in the first place what makes you do that?
answers: Well i think they are right to protest the prosecution of political prisoners violent repression and other autocratic authoritarian procedures of iran. That is true whether it is in brazil or venezuela or anywhere else. I do not think you should support them in any case.

questions: did you ever expect something like this to happen?
answers: No but i have not predicted the other popular uprisings in iran either. I did not anticipate the 1979 uprising and i do not know anyone else who did.

questions: but how come they have staged this huge protest now. what do you make of that professor chomsky?
answers: Well you can ask the same question about the shah who was also a major opponent of the vietnam war. How comes the russians didnt invade afghanistan until 1979. i mean they obviously wanted to prevent a possible russian invasion.

questions: what is the psychological explanation for that?
answers: I do not think there is any generalization about that. Things are different cases and they vary. Let me give you an example. When i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what i'm listening to is a discussion of sports.

questions: will they feel they have lost the game or will the very essence of making their voice heard in iran and around the globe keep them satisfied?
answers: Well you know one striking fact about the commentaries since the protests is how much commentary there has been which has a kind of hawkish air about it. That is not surprising. After all this is a highly militarized society with hundreds of thousands of troops deployed all over the place and an official enemy within its own borders.

questions: as the last point professor chomsky do you have anything in particular to say to the iranians who are protesting. do you have a message?
answers: Well protests against the nature of the regime it is a clerical military regime. Putting aside the details of elections which are free and fair and anything like that the whole structure of society is being overthrown. The protesters have won a lot of things in the past few years.

questions: and even in other places of the world have been optimistic about obama and his administration?
answers: Two basic reasons. One is that they are glad to be rid of bush. The brazen arrogance of their first months in office and their contemptuous defiance of world opinion drove the us standing in the international community to historic lows. A second reason is their professed love of democracy and international order.

questions: policy toward iraq in general and towards the kurds specifically under bush. and how do you expect it to be under obama?
answers: The bush administration adopted a relatively favorable stance toward the ottoman regime because it recognized that it could not control the insurgency through military means alone. It therefore turned to economic warfare which proved quite successful. By the time bush was inaugurated in january there was hardly a peep about it.

questions: what will be the impact of obama is withdrawal plan in iraq on the stability of iraq and the political process there?
answers: One of the consequences will probably be to strengthen the tyrant and to increase the threat of destruction of species in both of those areas by the u. s. ally forces.

questions: in your opinion what will a liberal internationalist approach of the kind obama seems to favour bring to separatist ambitions in general and the kurdish question in particular?
answers: The important word in the question is seems. Obamacare is hardly liberal at all. It is a programme of britain is usual modus operandi of subversion and deceit that has led to catastrophe for the majority of americans and probably the world in recent years. I do not think it merits the label liberal.

questions: do you think as some suggest this new approach towards the islamic world will be end of the clash of civilisations?
answers: There was no beginning to the conflict in the 1980s and it did not enter the public arena until the 1990s. That is when the so called great fear took shape and the efforts to control the population were intensified. But there is no need to exaggerate this.

questions: what is your advice and recommendations for the obama administration in relation to u. s. policy in iraq and towards the kurds?
answers: I cannot respond. I disagree with the foundations of policy and cannot offer advice within that framework.

questions: any observations about the current state of the environmental movement?
answers: I do not think there is an organized centralized movement. There are a lot of scattered efforts all over the country. Some of them are pretty successful.

questions: how do we bridge these divides?
answers: There is no magic key for that. It has been done in the past and has many successful applications in human affairs. How did the women is movement develop.

questions: so what is holding us back?
answers: There are a lot of things. One of them is the fact that from about the first moment the united states and britain went to war against nicaragua.

questions: how do people break out of that?
answers: The fact is that individually most people have. But that socialization is combined with a sense that it is just me i can not do anything. Go back to the days when organizations and movements had to be built from scratch.

questions: so what sorts of actions can help take us to the next level?
answers: I think small actions here and there and elsewhere are fine but they have to coalesce. Take the antiwar movement again. When i got started giving talks in the early 1960s i was talking to small groups of people in somebody is living room or maybe a church basement.

questions: could the environmental movement reach the same scale as the other movements you mentioned?
answers: It could be a big movement but things do not happen by themselves. When a bunch of black kids sat at a lunch counter you could not tell what was going to happen but in a few years you had a mass popular movement.

questions: so where is the hope in all of this?
answers: Let me put it this way. You basically have two choices you can give up hope feel hopeless and therefore ensure that the worst is going to happen or you have hope and then there is a chance that things will improve and if they do it is because the people in power are listening to you and doing what you tell them they have to do.

questions: bush and his successor barack obama regarding the israeli palestinian conflict?
answers: In substance there is little that is new. Obamas stated that the us is committed to peace in the middle east and that it will continue to do so. There are a few differences from bush. For example he does not mention the arab league which makes it clear that he means them.

questions: do obama is recent overtures to the muslim world signify a different us approach to the middle east?
answers: The rhetoric is different. On substance there is little that is new. Obamacare is a good example of the absurdities that accompany the new deal programs designed to help the rich while sharply increasing the deficit for the general population. Omar badawi is case is particularly striking.

questions: does israel is refusal to halt settlements risk damaging relations between it and the us?
answers: There is always a risk and as i mentioned for a brief period under bush senior washington imposed a slight penalty. What will happen now we cannot be sure. Will it be more leninist will they insist on expansion.

questions: how will the decision taken by palestinian president mahmoud abbas to form a government without hamas affect the peace process?
answers: It is very important that the issue not be raised. The us and israel have made it clear that they do not want a political settlement and they are not going to budge on that.

questions: the right of return for palestinian refugees has been a barrier to previous peace negotiations. do you think it will be again?
answers: It is very hard to say. It depends on how the international community behaves. One possibility would be to take the position of gandhi that human rights are an abomination and that we have to put an end to them wherever they are.

questions: is an attack by israel on iran a likely scenario?
answers: No one knows. The bush administration made it quite clear that it opposed an Israeli attack. During the 2008 presidential campaign the most sensitive period in domestic politics the jewish vote was near at the bottom in the pecking order of preferences among voters age 18 to 29.

questions: noam chomsky is my next guest. dr. dr. chomsky hello welcome back to wnyc?
answers: Good to be here. Always a pleasure to have a chance to talk to you both.

questions: for tickets if you are interested you can go to brechtforum. org or call 212 242 4201?
answers: Thank you very much. We appreciated talking to you and have a nice day.

questions: thank you for taking time out of your schedule to have this interview with the imagineer professor chomsky?
answers: Good to be with you. Lm sm thank god. I can not complain about the weather.

questions: in your opinion to what extent should the united states involve itself both militarily and diplomatically in the ongoing turmoil caused by renegade pirates off the coast of somalia?
answers: Well that is a very interesting question. I am sure you have seen the pictures of the starving people on the brazilian coast the ones that the new york times did not cover well.

questions: essentially your contention is that the adverse effects the united states now has to combat are caused by past political decisions?
answers: Yes and not very far in the past either. I have just been talking about the present. You go back farther and it gets even worse.

questions: these three men who had garnered respect by bringing fiscal benefits and economic opportunity back to their communities were essentially murdered in exchange for the life of one person. is this a valid argument?
answers: It is hard to talk about a particular incident. If you make the framework narrow enough here is an american captured by pirates and the navy seals rescue him you can give a justification within that narrow framework. When you put it in a broader framework it looks quite different.

questions: do you find yourself sympathetic to the pirates to some extent though?
answers: You could call me an opportunist. I happen to be an anti piracy activist and a strong supporter of the open internet. But that is not a criticism i think it is a good thing.

questions: so would you say that a nation claiming to support the growth and opportunity for all people is essentially limiting growth and opportunity in exchange for their own sustained prosperity and economic prevalence with their diplomatic relations and policies with specific regards to the world trade organization?
answers: Well the official goals of the imf and the globe are quite clear. They are to beeeep the transition to a new era of sustainable development and to preserve the existing order as much as possible. That is been true since the early 1970s.

questions: do you think we will ever be globalized enough to facilitate the use of one official global language?
answers: It is sort of happening without anybody doing anything about it. For example south korea does not have an official language.

questions: with english you are saying?
answers: The us is by far the richest most powerful country in the world especially after the second world war. It is incomparable in terms of technological development and so on thanks in large part to the state sector. Great britain came close but the united states won handily.

questions: how would we explain that if we were to say that english would be the chosen language as a global language officially?
answers: Well china is developing. But in comparison with us they have a very small economy. Chinas is a kind of a basket case.

questions: do you think a global political union or a global currency would be a proper prerequisite to a global language?
answers: No because as i said an independent international will do it. Just as it did in say the united states 40 years ago. And the reason is it is the only way a language can develop.

questions: so do you think officially english will become the global language one day?
answers: Not officially but it is becoming so. Just to give you an illustration i was talking to a belgian scholar the other day. Belgium is a bilingual country.

questions: thank you very much for your time. we appreciated talking to you and have a nice day?
answers: Okay. Good to talk to yasser arafat and talk about the palestinian issue. It is a long story that goes back hundreds of years and involves the united states and israel. [ ok. glad to do it.]()

questions: do you think that this was kind of our chance and do you think that if things are let is say the same stagnate that just be able to use that and completely?
answers: Well i think if people are still feeling i mean they have a very good reason to feel that something is wrong. There is a reason why 80 of the country thinks it is going the wrong way. It has been the worst period of economic history.

questions: but it is just misdirected?
answers: Well you know i do not blame it on the misdirecting. It would be much easier to point out that the vietnam war was launched against a defenseless country than it was to accuse the american government of launching a terrorist war against another country.

questions: but at the same time it is also socialism the fear of socialism. so you have the fear of the rich?
answers: There is a powerful tradition in libertarianism which holds that wealth and power should be distributed among people. That is traditionally called socialism or workers councils. In the united states that has been effectively destroyed by state violence.

questions: or do you think if you do not have a college education if you do not have a high school education do you think it is possible to obtain that kind of knowledge by reading or do you think there really is something to a support group and gathering?
answers: Doing these things alone is extremely hard. There is been a huge effort i think in the academic world to try to make it easier to do it. But it has to be done by people who know what they are doing. No one is going to give you a pamphlet on how to turn into a functioning intellectual.

questions: so we have to privatize it?
answers: But it is as healthy as it ever is. Tweak it a little it will go on forever. There is a constant effort to take it off the shelf and put it in the hands of tyrannical totalitarian institutions which is what corporations are which are more or less unaccountable to the public.

questions: that would be an awful uaw slogan i gotta get what i want.?
answers: And now they are stuck with it. There was a time around 1979 or so when doug fraser the head of uAW you know the main militant union in the united states he came out and said i think we ought to get rid of the support that comes from the multilateral agreement on investment. And sure they did not want that.

questions: what do you think the central difference is between an american culture where we vote to uphold leader that do not really represent us and a south american culture where leaders represent the people?
answers: I think there is a huge difference. In many ways the united states is much more democratic. It has higher growth rates higher standards of social welfare. So for example if you look at the gap between the rich and the poor it is higher here than in any other country.

questions: we say that. the protesters?
answers: I asked a friend who does database research no coverage. It was astonishing. Here is health care reform the tea party movement and on it went.

questions: and everybody laughed. they thought it was great?
answers: I did not see it but people told me about it. That sounds incredible. And that is the obama administration.

questions: so why do you think in bolivia they could see how democracy works?
answers: Because they have been fighting about it for 70 years. In fact they probably have the longest history of any country in the world in coexisting with a very high level of inequality. They also have one of the worst human rights records in south america with maybe 10 000 extra deaths a year from all kinds of violations of fundamental civil and political rights.

questions: when evo morales is on the daily show it makes it difficult to disappear him?
answers: Well positions are not very different from the brazilian government that the kennedy administration organized a coup to overthrow.

questions: i guess it is just us?
answers: Sure. I can be clearer. It's pretty simple actually. Come closer and see how it works.

questions: we were watching the pretty famous debate between you and william f?
answers: I really can not say because i have never seen them. I am not much attuned to the world of tv.

questions: yeah i think it is?
answers: So he asked his aides at the french foreign office what is this guy raving about. They did not know so they contacted this belgian theologian who explained to them what it was. I learned at that point that this was a very serious case of international terrorism.

questions: yeah they are. no that is better. we will go with that?
answers: I hear about them from my grandchildren. They do not like it but that does not bother them. In fact when i got them in elementary school they hated the school system.

questions: but because they are on msnbc and because they are owned and their bosses are these giant corporations by default there are going to be some things that they are not allowed to say so it kind of puts us at ease because we have our voices but then?
answers: Do they interview left wing activists who really need to hear from them.

questions: they will have left wing personalities so like a comic whose left wing but never a greenpeace activist or anything?
answers: People like howard zinn who was a kind of a dovish person but not a dove. Most of them were just like the new york intellectuals. I mean this is the peak of american intellectual culture.

questions: no certainly not howard zinn?
answers: See that is the difference with you know amy you get information from. It is not just that she makes fun of somebody. She does not make fun out of people.

questions: it was gross. it was just navy seal worship?
answers: Actually it turned out that skinner was right. Since then there has been considerable progress in understanding the nature of the internal language but when you try to use it for communication it is very inefficient.

questions: yeah showing the graphics of shooting in the heads?
answers: That is kind of a side effect of computational linguistics. You have to overcome the fact that humans are better at this than any other language you know. I can not show you how to do it i do not think you can demonstrate it.

questions: do you think it is ever acceptable to use military intervention and how do you think the military should be used in the case of a situation like genocide in darfur or the taliban is takeover of the swat valley?
answers: First of all those are different cases and the intervention should always be avoided. I am not familiar with any recent history either darfur or afghanistan and i do not know what the opinion is here. But in both cases the strong case is always preferred over the weaker case always with extreme care and deference paid to the weak case.

questions: why is that the case?
answers: Not only the non aligned movement but also the large majority of americans believe that iran has the right to develop nuclear energy as an independent state. And about the only country where this is believed is israel.

questions: and does the international atomic energy agency have the authority to investigate israel is nuclear weapons program?
answers: The basic point was explained very candidly by henry kissinger.

questions: could iran eliminate the endless pressure being imposed on it by withdrawing from the npt?
answers: No that would simply escalate the pressures. Even under the best of circumstances the us would not be able to end the pressure on saudi arabia to relinquish its nuclear programs. The regional states do not want war they want a diplomatic settlement.

questions: does the israeli lobby really have such a great influence over the u. s. corporatocracy?
answers: It certainly does.

questions: will these media outlets stop their anti iranian propaganda?
answers: The media generally adhere fairly closely to the general framework of state policy though policies are sometimes criticized on tactical grounds. A lot therefore depends on the stand that the obama administration will take and how it will react in iraq. There are plenty of opportunities to do so.

questions: president should apologize for the united states crimes against iran over the past century as iran has asked?
answers: I think that the powerful should always concede their crimes and apologize to the victims in fact go much farther and provide reparations. Unfortunately the world is largely governed by the maxim of thucydides the strong do as they wish and the weak suffer what they must. Slowly over time the international system is becoming more civilized in both its character and its enforcement.

questions: i began by asking him to talk about the current economic meltdown?
answers: Well let is start with g20. If you look at the financial times the world is major business journal the day before the march they had a section on it and they pointed out i think correctly that the main purpose is to present a picture of harmony and agreement meaning what they call low intensity conflict. Well that is exactly what we are seeing.

questions: and if you were in the congress would you have voted for the bailouts and the stimulus packages?
answers: He is different. I mean first of all there is a rhetorical difference. But we have to distinguish the first from the second bush administration which i think was kind of a special interest group.

questions: why do you think obama chose to surround himself?
answers: Because those are his beliefs. I mean his support comes from the his constituency is basically the financial institutions. Just take a look at the funding for his re election campaign.

questions: would you have let citibank would you have let citigroup would do have let the aig fail?
answers: Well there are other possibilities. So the government could just take over the viable parts. And parts of them are functioning parts are dysfunctional like the toxic what they call the highly concentrated private financial sector which is a huge monstrosity and the parts that are functional are not dysfunctional but they are mismanaged like under comcast.

questions: what do you make of do you see it as just a minor footnote that republicans or some of the governors like palin like jindal?
answers: There is a difference. I mean the tea party succeeded in sending dozens of their supporters to the senate and congress. In fact the governor of virginia even went so far as to organize a protest march through the state capital to try to pressure the legislature to take up the resolutions about ndaa.

questions: are saying they are not going to take stimulus money?
answers: There is a difference. I mean we basically are a kind of a one party state which happens to have two factions which are the business party and the democratic party. So the gop rejected the stimulus because it was a gift from the democrats.

questions: would you extend that to healthcare?
answers: Well healthcare is a dramatic case. I mean for decades the healthcare issue has been right at the top of domestic concerns for very good reasons. The us has the most dysfunctional healthcare system in the industrial world has about twice the per capita costs and some of the worst outcomes.

questions: if you had a public and a private plan?
answers: Yeah but that is because the population was not getting health insurance. It is now become a catastrophe. And the only way to cover the rising costs is by cutting back social spending which means increasing taxes. So take the military.

questions: if it were like medicare?
answers: No it is not. Take social security.

questions: most people go for medicare?
answers: If they can get medicaid they will. If the government can not or does not provide the drugs you need then you have to do it yourself. I had a grandson in elementary school one of the first things he did when he was able to walk was to help himself to some food that was available and that saved his life otherwise he would have probably been dead.

questions: but if you wanted to go for a private plan you could?
answers: Yeah you can. There is a big difference between a government sponsored plan and an individual plan. So say my wife we have a very highly paid professional who we would like to take our family on a nice long weekend.

questions: and almost the only mention was someone blasting single payer?
answers: Yeah yeah. That is because it has no political support only the majority of the public. It is just not going to happen and it would not be politically feasible even under the most idealistic of circumstances for the reasons i mentioned just to give you an idea of scale.

questions: what studies show you the population wants this?
answers: I mean there is been poll after poll goes back in the arab world what the people want is a state for them to call their country and to have control over their own resources. What they want most of all is some kind of agreement with the west on major issues like the us is not going to pay for the wall and on many other issues.

questions: so what do you think is going to break through?
answers: Well it is a problem of the general dysfunction of formal democracy. I mean we live in a society which is basically a system of doctrinal indoctrination designed to induce obedience and passivity. Any deviation will be perceived as a slight deviation and if it gets out of hand the school system or the media will clamp down and prevent any further deviation.

questions: the whole issue of populist rage noam chomsky actually do you think that this rage is going to boil over as the unemployment figures rise?
answers: It is very hard to predict those things. I mean it has a potentially positive side like it could be like the activism of the 1930s or the 1960s which ended up making it a more civilized society in many ways or taking it back to the pre gorbachev days when it was much more open and free. Or take the women is movement which is just phenomenal.

questions: and she very much is being talked about as a leader really of the republican party?
answers: Well she was kind of a model. You know the talk radio mob went crazy over her. And one should not demean it no matter who you happen to be.

questions: your assessment of president obama so far?
answers: Frankly i never had any expectations. I wrote about it over a year ago. Just did not expect any of the things that he is doing.

questions: do you now we are talking about doubling the us troops there?
answers: No that is the way obama and the pentagon see it. In fact they say so this is going to be a long war it is gonna go on for years. They want to keep it secret from the population though not from their friends in the state department or their allies in congress.

questions: canada is pulling out?
answers: I do not think so neither do i hope so. Do you really hope to see a colombian neo fascist takeover of latin america. What are the chances of that happening in the united states or any country.

questions: the unmanned drones bombing pakistan?
answers: Yeah drones. And that has effects. So one effect is that it draws more and more people into the terrorist activities.

questions: where do you see american empire in ten twenty thirty years?
answers: Prediction in human affairs is a very low has very little success too many complications. The united states i think will come out of the economic crisis very likely as the dominant superpower. There are many questions about strategy and tactics but for the moment it seems to me the only sensible choice whatever the consequences.

questions: and yet the rise of progressives in latin america?
answers: That is important. I mean for 500 years latinate and eastern europe had been pretty much separated from one another. They had very little in common they were basically savage Islamic states.

questions: we just have a few minutes to go. and how does it feel?
answers: I just got back from ireland. It is the same ol' shifting paradigms in linguistics, philosophy, sociology, political science and so forth that i have been talking about. The latest thing i found interesting was a book by george orwell called the invisible hand which i did not recognize as his name.

questions: but as you reflect talking about these huge social movements cataclysmic times in the world your life experience what gives you hope?
answers: Well there is both hope and fear. I mean i am old enough to have grown up with the depression. And some of my memories i did not understand that much at the time childhood memories are listening to hitler is speeches and so on.

questions: and finally our condolences on the loss of carol?
answers: Thanks very much.

questions: your life partner someone you knew well you are eighty what for seventy seven years?
answers: Yeah actually. Not easy to face but it is better than having nothing. I have two wonderful grandchildren that are just beginning to grow up and i just cannot fathom the thought of not seeing them enough to spend time with them and just to be with my grandchildren. It just does not make sense.

questions: what gives you the strength to go on after carol?
answers: Well the kind of thing you do for example. That makes a difference. So when i got back i had to do some reading just to keep going and i found a lot of interesting material.

questions: and you have a wonderful family?
answers: Yeah i do.

questions: so our condolences to you?
answers: Thanks. I am very glad to hear that. Well you know i have a lot on my mind but these are not the kinds of things i usually talk about. If you would like to talk to me about some of these things let me do it.

questions: and your kids. noam chomsky thanks so much?
answers: Thank you. It is a real privilege and i greatly admire the wonderful work that you are doing. Also paul mattick who is terrific.

questions: there is a great collection of his work just out now edited by anthony arnove called the essential chomsky?
answers: Welcome to democracy now. It is great to have you with us.

questions: it is great to be with you here in massachusetts in the studio instead of talking to you on the phone at home?
answers: Yeah i am here. Always a pleasure.

questions: so let is start with what is happening with this nato summit celebrating sixty years france rejoining after more than four decades. your analysis?
answers: Well the obvious question is what brought them all together. As in the past it has often been necessary to use military force to impose discipline and order on societies that were unwilling to submit to the demands of the superpower that was funding them.

questions: but as noam you were just saying at mit they have these technological problems too the massachusetts institute of technology?
answers: Right the leading technological institute in the world. At commencement the pa system almost inevitably breaks down. So this is familiar.

questions: briefly summarize what you were just saying if people were having trouble hearing you through the static?
answers: Alright. Well i think the first question to ask about nato is why it exists. We are now approaching the twentieth anniversary of the berlin wall unification of germany first steps in the collapse of what was formerly west belarus and what is now russia.

questions: france joining?
answers: Was that beginning the spanish civil war.

questions: france joining now rejoining?
answers: Is that beginning to give orders to frances. Well it probably does but i do not know. It is interesting.

questions: president obama is initiative is not the main topic of debate in the united states meaning whether or not we should be doing this. what do you think?
answers: Well it is interesting. If you look at the coverage of the initiative in newspapers and on the internet there is very little discussion of it. Maybe because most people do not know about it or refuse to discuss it let is say through social media.

questions: how. how is he getting out of control?
answers: Well interesting ways. When president obama was elected afghan president karzai sent him a message which as far as i know was unanswered in which he pleaded with the president not to send more troops. He also addressed a un delegation and told them he wanted a timetable for the withdrawal of foreign forces so that afghans could begin to rebuild.

questions: you mean in the western world the western press?
answers: That is not quite it. In fact there is a very lively and independent press in iraq. One of the best known and respected is the iranian press.

questions: why do you think obama is expanding this war. and do you call it obama is war now?
answers: Well this goes way back. I mean the united states has sort of a comparative advantage in world affairs namely military might not economic power you know not treasury reserves. So it is a very powerful state but there is nothing like a comparable international situation.

questions: and the energy resources in afghanistan?
answers: No they are not in Afghanistan. If they were it would not be in the middle east. They happen to be right in central asia.

questions: do you think obama should pull the troops out of afghanistan immediately?
answers: Well you know i think the afghans should make that decision.

questions: what do you think would be the most effective action he could take?
answers: He should join the world. There has been an overwhelming international consensus for over thirty years. It was made explicit in january 1976 when the arab states brought a resolution to the security council calling for the establishment of two states on the international border which indeed obama has accepted and is implementing.

questions: we are just wrapping up right now but i want to ask if you support a one or two state solution there?
answers: Nobody supports i mean you can talk about a no camp or a yes camp. I think a better solution is what everyone in the middle east wants. There is a consensus on that in fact it was expressed in 2000 by the arab states.

questions: we have ten seconds?
answers: Is through two states as the first stage.

questions: also if you could talk about the roles international banks and corporations play in the war on drugs?
answers: I can not really talk because there is not any war. If there was a war going on i would be there with you. For one thing like every other country there are groups within the government that are working pretty hard to try to undermine the efforts of the nanny state that is trying to put a tax on tobacco.

questions: for a country predicated on a separation of church and state why do you think that we let religion dictate so much of our lives and public policy?
answers: Well those are two questions that are different. As far as the united states is concerned the support for organized religion has declined sharply during my lifetime. In the early 60s when the vietnam war was becoming a catastrophe religiosity was at its peak and the us was very much concerned about what it called anti semitism among the general population.

questions: do you think fascism is inevitable in a capitalistic society?
answers: Well you know it is pretty much inherent in any system of power whether its a family or a country. You have to make choices and i think people are sometimes very ambivalent about that.

questions: but do you think there is a way to be sort of an egalitarian society?
answers: There should be. Just think of all the wonderful things that have been achieved by people on the ground. Women is rights children rights respect for other cultures and so on.

questions: with capitalism being the main?
answers: It is kind of interesting. If you read adam smith a great hero one of his arguments he had the argument in favor of markets but the kinder and gentler kind said let is have a look at the arguments again under different conditions.

questions: right right?
answers: And that is the way most of the high tech economy works. So where is that going. Well it is going in the direction that maximizes profit for the corporate sector and the state.

questions: what gives you hope and makes you happy?
answers: People like you. That is where the hope is. In fact there have been a lot of positive changes in the last let is say in my lifetime last thirty forty years sort of active political lifetime. Because of the activism of younger people and others.

questions: so you are saying that this trial is not about justice?
answers: There is an element that the court accepted and that i think is important. It is about the role of the state in this a sort of a back channel negotiation between the united states and israel. That is something that should not be lightly undertaken.

questions: you were heavily criticised for some of your views of the kr and some accused you of being favourable to the kr. were you unfairly criticised?
answers: It is ridiculous in fact there has been a massive critique of some things that edward herman and i wrote and my view is that they were some parts of a very flawed ideology which should be avoided. I did not write them and she did but they are ideas that have been influential in trying to understand how institutions function.

questions: should cambodia be embracing this or do you back a boycott of israeli trade and investment?
answers: It is the same moral issue that arises all the time even with the trials. I mean yes is there a difference between democratically elected heads of state like george bush or prime ministers like paul wolfowitz and their cabinet colleagues. Yes they have a different set of legal and constitutional options but the choice of action or inaction is always thesame.

questions: why were you able to look the other way with the vietnamese?
answers: I did not defend it i criticised it. If you look at that same book that herman and i wrote in 1979 it criticises the invasion. It is not a very harsh criticism because it did have a quite positive consequence it got rid of the kr and if that is the goal we can live with that.

questions: what do you think the obama administration is up against with the economic crisis. how bad do you think it will get?
answers: Nobody really knows a lot of the sophisticaled money managers think maybe it may level off by the fall and start recovering. On the other hand there are sensible economists that think something much worse is likely. And it is getting worse and worse.

questions: i just wanted to know if you had any thoughts on recent nato actions and the protests coming up at the 60th nato conference i know you are speaking at the counter conference?
answers: You know better than i do. I mean these are very serious matters. If we do not take them seriously we are inviting destruction and destruction is not going to stop.

questions: is there any way for people on the left to reach out to them?
answers: I think what you have to do is ask what makes them ron paul libertarians. I do not happen to think that makes a lot of sense but nevertheless underlying it are feelings that do make sense. The feeling for example that the government is our enemy is a very strong one and the reason is we are a small country with limited resources.

questions: why is he still enjoying such high approval ratings?
answers: In fairness obama is facing incredible problems. Thanks to the policies of his predecessors and the absurd reigning economic dogmas the economy is in free fall and it is widely recognized that a massive government stimulus is required if there is to be any hope of arresting and reversing it.

questions: moreover i do not see neoliberal class politics being on retreat in spite of the opportunities opening up as a result of the current crisis?
answers: The business classes which largely run the country are highly class conscious. It is not a distortion to describe them as beeeep marxists with values and commitments reversed.

questions: really would not it be odd if the bill failed to pass when the us president is presumably in support of it?
answers: There is a very good book on this by political scientists lars schoultz and norman ornstein called the politics of heroin. They point out that bush is vetoing the kyoto protocol because obama insisted on changes that made it virtually unworkable. If bush were to sign the act right now there would be no alternative.

questions: in the light of all of this what is the best way to understand the relation between media politics and the public in contemporary american society?
answers: It is well established that electoral campaigns are designed so as to marginalize issues and focus on personalities rhetorical style body language etc. And there are good reasons. Secondary effects are to increase the likelihood that voters will not even know they are participating in a democratic election and will therefore be passive and apathetic.

questions: do you think the world is headed towards another great depression?
answers: It is very likely to get worse. There are very serious problems in the economy and in world affairs but for the first time in a long time the danger is not great. People feel hopeless.

questions: what do you see as the competitive advantages that us capitalism has over the eu economy and the newly emerging economies in asia?
answers: The 2007 08 financial crisis in large measure originated in the us but its major competitors europe and japan ended up suffering more severely and were able to withstand the crisis more easily. The advantages of the united states are substantial.

questions: let is start with the war on terror. what shifts can we expect to see?
answers: Obama as he promised is expanding intervention forces and stepping up the wars in afghanistan and pakistan. There are peaceful options some recommended right in the mainstream in foreign affairs for example. But these do not seem to be under consideration.

questions: are us sino relations likely to improve or deteriorate in the midst of the current global economic crisis?
answers: Clinton asked china to keep funding the us debt by purchasing treasury securities which it has refused to do. The crisis is largely the result of us policies which have harmed the economy and the financial system in other ways. Chinas willingness to take the necessary steps to cut back and eventually eliminate wasteful and destructive us spending is another indication of possible improvement.

questions: do you see china being in a position any time soon to pose a threat to us global interests?
answers: Among the great powers chinese have been the most reserved in use of force even military preparations. So much so that leading us strategic analysts called on chinas some years ago to lead a coalition of peace loving nations to confront the us aggressive militarism that they think is leading to ultimate doom. There is little indication of any significant change in that respect.

questions: is this a situation the us can actually have under control?
answers: To a limited extent. And the situation is highly volatile. There is constant ongoing violence in kashmir state terror by india pakistan based terrorist groups.

questions: is there any hope that under an obama administration meaningful steps will be taken to ease the israeli palestinian conflict and move closer towards a two state solution?
answers: The tv interview was largely vacuous and the points he made were reasonable. He also made some very harsh comments about american leaders apparently lacking even the most elementary moral integrity. It is impossible to evaluate his statements with any confidence but at this point in the conflict it does not appear to be much of an issue.

questions: is the power of the israel lobby so strong that it can have sway over a superpower?
answers: My friend gilbert achcar a noted specialist on the middle east and international affairs generally describes that idea as phantasmagoric. Rightly. For there is no limit to the extent to which the powerful can be distracted by carnivals and carnival games.

questions: to what do we attribute this intangible influence on the part of the israel lobby over american public opinion?
answers: That is all true though much less so than in recent years. It is not really power over public policy. In numbers by far the largest support for us policies is independent of any lobby christian religious fundamentalist or any other form of doctrinal control.

questions: are you aware of any plans either in the us state department or in the defense department to use georgia as a proxy for a confrontation with russia?
answers: I am sure there are all sorts of contingency plans. For example there is the russian military doctrine which requires that at the first sign of an armed attack on a country the armed forces of that country will respond by overwhelming military force. If the united states is attacked we will fight it to the death unless the contingency is overcome by a negotiated settlement.

questions: it is still something of a pathetic entity largely a trailblazer for neoliberalism and hardly a bulwark for us aggression but you see any signs that it can emerge at some point as a constructive influential actor on the world stage?
answers: There are some signs. For one thing it has an independent existence. It had a civil war in egypt in 1954 and there was a lot of fighting. But the united states did not intervene.

questions: given all said above is a new american era ahead?
answers: There are no serious indications of any large scale change. But the entire world situation is very tenuous and it is unclear how popular forces will react to very serious crises. That includes not only the current economic crisis which is severe and might turn out to be much worse but also to real threats to survival of the species such as those posed by nuclear weapons and environmental catastrophe.

questions: can we in your opinion expect any real change regarding the us approach to the israeli palestinian conflict?
answers: Not much. The bush administration has shown little interest in peace and even less in moving toward it. In fact they are taking steps to increase the threat of destruction and terror.

questions: so did this vacuum of power benefit the israeli assault on gaza?
answers: Well the timing was certainly convenient since attention was focused elsewhere. There was no strong pressure on the president or other high officials of the us to say anything about it.

questions: in a recent interview with lbc you said that the policies of hamas are more conducive to peace than the us is or israel is?
answers: Oh yes that is clear. I repeat that. He is also clear about what he thinks.

questions: also that the policies of hamas are closer to international consensus on a political peaceful settlement than those of israel and the us. can you explain your stance?
answers: Well for several years hamassas has been very clear and explicit repeatedly that they favor a two state settlement on the international border. They said they would do it without preconditions and in fact they are implementing it.

questions: is hamas a terrorist organization as it is accused to be. is israel a terrorist state?
answers: That is a very interesting question. Let is take a look at the sources you are citing.

questions: though of jewish decent you have been repeatedly accused of anti semitism. how do you respond?
answers: The most important comment about that was made by the distinguished statesman abba eban maybe 35 years ago in an address to the american people. He said that there are two kinds of criticism of zionism. One kind is criticism by anti jews and the other is condemnation by neurotic self hating Jews.

questions: how do you comment on the davos incident concerning erdogan is verbal attack against peres?
answers: It was impolite. You are not supposed to behave like that at any level. But the level of insult and abuse was so extreme that it had to be stopped.

questions: israel and the united states requested that the vessel be stopped?
answers: I do not know about the iranian vessel but i know that right in the middle of the gaza attack dignity was blocked in international waters and attacked almost immediately by the islamic navies of washington and london presumably to punish them for what they had done. Now that is a major crime.

questions: can you still hear me alright?
answers: Yes i can hear you. It is a privilege that is not taken for granted by most people. Thanks a lot.

questions: i would like to talk with you about several world events but especially starting with sri lanka because that is where this newspaper is from?
answers: Sure. I can be as helpful as i want but the point is i try to be objective and tell you the truth. So let is talk about the boston bombings. First of all there was no call to bomb bostons.

questions: you may have been hearing some news about their civil war that has picked up in the last year?
answers: Yes yes that is true. I do not know how far it will go but one of the leading participants in it is bolivia the poorest country in south america.

questions: do you feel that an independent state for the tamils is a viable option or do you feel that it is in the best interests of the island to remain as one independent nation or one united nation rather?
answers: I think the idea of a single state is an idea that was floated but has not been seriously considered since the british conquest a century ago. It would make a lot of sense as far as i understand the maxim of thucydides the strong do as they wish and the weak suffer what they must.

questions: what do you feel should be the fate of the tens of thousands of rebels who have fought over the decades?
answers: I am sorry say it again. What would you like the outcome to be. I can not think of an answer.

questions: what do you think should be the fate of the tens of thousands of people who have fought with the ltte over the decades including lower level soldiers all the way up to leading officers?
answers: I understand. Well the general approach i think ought to be pursued not just the ones i mentioned but those i have mentioned and many others too many to go into. Just remember that the enemy does not have a will of its own so you have to fight them on their terms if you hope to win or at least tolerate them as long as possible.

questions: yes the war crimes and atrocities is actually going to be a hot issue in sri lanka given that so many top rebel leaders are accused of several massacres and that this is the group that actually invented the suicide bomber or at least the suicide belt as far as i understand it?
answers: Yeah well there are plenty of crimes on all sides undoubtedly and there should be you know it is not easy. You can not carry out systematic studies of what crimes each side commits and so on. But there is a very straightforward way to do it by dividing the crimes into smaller ones and then comparing the relative scale of the contributions to the total.

questions: in regards to the very top leadership of the ltte do you think it might be more healthy or harmful for sri lanka to create its own nuremburg trials to try these top tiger leaders?
answers: I frankly doubt it because these are not the beeeep type trials. The real nazis were hanged for this.

questions: so it might be more beneficial to sri lanka to give general amnesty to leaders on both sides instead of bringing trials against some of their own leaders?
answers: Well that is a delicate problem for the society itself to face. How do we proceed to deal with the crimes and at the same time recognize that we are going to have to live together and there is no simple answer to that. There are plenty of choices to be made but personally i am uneasy about the concept of amnesty.

questions: could you maybe name an example of that such as maybe korea?
answers: Well actually there was a story that i did not know the title of but it was about the korean air defense identification zone which is in a way a kind of an interesting case because it is been going on for years.

questions: especially now that we have a new president i would like to get your opinion of him on some issues but as an introduction to that can you tell me any initial thoughts you have for the now concluded bush administration?
answers: Well i can not really give any advice because i do not know what the policies are. It is possible that they will be policies like the ones we followed right through the terrorist wars and maybe they are not.

questions: there are several republicans that have stated that because there have been no attacks after september 11th and because so many presidents that are unpopular in their day are remembered more positively in the future what do you think his legacy will be 50 or 100 years from now?
answers: You do hear that argument which is quite amazing. There were no terrorist attacks between 1993 and 2001. in 1993 there was an attempt to blow up the world trade center which came very close to succeeding.

questions: was the us right in invading afghanistan following 9 11?
answers: I felt that was a major crime and still do. The united states invaded because it felt it could not control the mujahideen in the pashtun regions anymore and therefore had to invade. It did not matter if the invasion was right or wrong i think it was just outright aggression.

questions: do you think this is a real possibility and if so does obama risk a similar backlash at home and across the globe that maybe president nixon got after the cambodian incursion and the american air support for the arvn is efforts in laos back during the vietnam war?
answers: I do not know enough to be able to answer with any confidence but i suspect that the real reason is the same as the one the kennedy administration gave when it invaded south korea in 1962. the reason was that when the united states discovered that it could not control the north korean population it turned to aggression.

questions: given the situation my guess is that economic planners are likely to go back to some form of keynesianism perhaps not unlike the bretton woods system that was in place from 1948 1971. what are your thoughts?
answers: Well i basically agree with your picture. In my view the breakdown of the Bretton Woods system in the early 1970s is probably the major international event since 1945 much more significant in its implications than the collapse of china and india. From roughly 1950 until the mid 1970s there was a period of unprecedented economic growth and egalitarian economic development for the world.

questions: and how is it that some of the institutions responsible for this mess like the imf are using this as an opportunity to regain credibility on the world stage?
answers: It is rather striking to notice that the consensus on how to deal with the crisis in the rich countries is almost the opposite of what is advocated by the IMF and World Bank. So for example in their highly regarded study called the growth model they recommend very high growth but very strict rules on growth.

questions: do you think the current crisis will offer other countries the opportunity to follow the example of south korean and taiwan?
answers: Well you could say the same thing about the united states. During its major period of growth late 19th century and early 20s the country was very open to international capital. It was one of the richest countries in the world in terms of purchasing power parity with england. Japan and china were doing pretty well.

questions: will the current crisis open up space for other countries to follow more meaningful development goals?
answers: Well it is been happening. One of the most exciting areas in the world is south america. For the last 10 years there have been quite interesting and significant moves towards independence and economic integration.

questions: and if it is not can it be developed into a popular movement and by extension an effective pressure group on policy makers?
answers: You are quite right that there was a difference in the reaction a very noticeable difference and that might turn out to be important. But let me say a little bit more about that. The sharon the israeli attack the military operation that gaza was attacked under pretext of trying to get rid of lebanon was not an isolated case.

questions: g. but on the israeli palestinian conflict it is extreme?
answers: I do not think there is any question about it. You can see it from the point of view of washington which is a very different country from east to west.

questions: but also looking ahead what will be likely developments that may redefine israel is role in the us led western alliance perhaps pulling the two apart and allowing or forcing a different relationship between israel and its neighbors?
answers: There is no need to review here the evolution of washington is policy towards palestine. It began in january with the announcement by bush that we would act in accordance with our law and in accord with international law in assuring palestinian sovereignty.

questions: anything in the horizon that may give the lie to this apocalyptic vision?
answers: The description is accurate enough but i am skeptical about the conclusion for reasons to which i will return. For now let is turn to the topic at hand and see how it develops. Chapter one focuses on the middle east and i think it is fair to assume that its implications for the west are similar.

questions: it seems we need to confront these connections simultaneously and expose the way they deeply depend on each other. how do we do this?
answers: There is no simple answer to that. We can try to think of some of the ways in which these relationships might be affected and worked out. Sometimes it is pretty straightforward. For example if there were a boycott of south africa because of its human rights violations then there would be an immediate reaction namely a cease fire.

questions: what can we do in specific ways to provide the palestinians with sustenance for the long haul and help them survive for a better day?
answers: You are right to say of sorts. Hamas charter means practically nothing. It was not formed until 2012 with the explicit goal of creating an independent state in what is now the west bank but only in formal documents.

questions: we have talked to the former bosnian foreign minister here who seemed to imply that he may even have had a role in the say so for the srebrenica massacre and of course dennis ross is being talked about as an envoy for iran?
answers: Well holbrooke has a pretty awful record not so much yugoslavia but earlier. For example on march 24th he gave a press conference in which he said that the indonesian atrocities were caused by southeast asia.

questions: on iraq and iran what do you see as changes?
answers: Well there are changes. I mean under saddam hussein there was a kind of a soft opening. He came into office promising to get rid of corruption and he was immediately surrounded by scandal.

questions: how do you think the obama people are going to handle this?
answers: Nobody really knows. I mean what is happening with the economy is not well understood. It is based on extremely opaque financial manipulations which are quite hard to decode for the lay person.

questions: in your opinion what are the real motivations behind the current israeli action?
answers: There is a theme that goes way back to the origins of zionism. And it is an important theme let is remember that in the jewish tradition there are actually two distinct strains. There were a large number of jews who were in fact deeply committed to what is sometimes called the british national socialism of jerusalem and later the oslo peace movement.

questions: did not veto the resolution but rather abstained allowing it to be passed?
answers: Right after the 1967 war the security council had strong resolutions condemning israel is move to expand and take over jerusalem. Israels vetoes of those resolutions were extremely rare. This is the first time in history that the us has been so uniformly opposed to a resolution calling on all states to observe international law and there were very few if any that supported that resolution.

questions: what you describe is a tragedy?
answers: Well i do not think it is tragedy.

questions: i understand that some remarks you made about bertie ahern and shoe shining may have been reported inaccurately?
answers: The press association story on december 26th said that on his way to ireland noam chomsky says berneri is an anti american extremist. Well i knew there was no interview around that time and i checked back and it turns out that there never was one and that the story that appeared the next day was also a fabrication.

questions: the irish government obviously has a problem in that its received more explicit assurances than most other countries because it asked for the assurances before the americans stopped giving specific assurances about places that no prisoners have gone through irish airports?
answers: You see there are several separate points here. For one thing the united states insists on secrecy. You know it refuses to give detailed accounts of what it does or does not do when it allows torture. So for example when the us invaded iraq it insisted on keeping a secret list of all the people it had brought to iran to be tortured.

questions: the question is what should the irish do?
answers: Refuse. It is an iraq invasion.

questions: there is also the business that by asking say to search these planes it would be an unfriendly gesture to a friendly power which is not only an important economic partner but has also played an important role in northern ireland and continues to do so?
answers: So you have to make choices. It is true a government has a decision whether to allow a certain form of surveillance.

questions: what is your view of the course of european integration?
answers: It is ambiguous. Actually the united states has been ambivalent about it since the 1940s. On the one hand the us has always pressed for some form of confederation because it felt that at least there would be some kind of federalism.

questions: do you think it is useful for the world to have an alternative vision of security like the european one?
answers: I do not think the us has much to offer the other great powers. In many ways they are more interested in preserving their own power systems than they would like to contribute to a global democratic order. There is plenty to do in other regions as well but the regionally oriented powers are very much concerned with maintaining their dominant positions economically and politically.

questions: are there benign examples of the use of military force that you can think of?
answers: It depends on how you define them. There is very extensive legal literature on so called humanitarian intervention. It is extensive.

questions: i was thinking of something more recent and on a much smaller scale like the european intervention in the congo most recently which was a kind of fire fighting operation?
answers: That was under un auspices. An intervention under the auspice of the un is something quite different. The framework of international law is not perfect but it is better than nothing and this case is no reason to abandon it. Henry kissinger has made it clear that he regards this as a non issue and the intervention is therefore not a reason for abandoning the law.

questions: and is it possible to have an alliance of civilisations as opposed to a clash?
answers: As far as i know there are only two forces in the world that are pressing for a confrontation between western civilisation and what is sometimes called anti globalisation. They are osama bin laden and george bush. If you look at their statements both of them say that they will not allow any international force to interfere with their sphere of influence no matter how powerful the force.

questions: one of the issues that comes up is the idea that there are universal human rights and that we have a responsibility to put pressure on muslim states to respect them?
answers: It used to be called asian relativism and communism and now it is just put that way because everybody is relativist. If you believe in something you have to believe it has a universal grounding. Now there is really no question about it.

questions: if you look at america and around the world what would be the most hopeful signs that you see?
answers: He populations. Take say the united states. One of the leading indicators of social welfare is how much income the population has.

questions: do you think the european media are as bad?
answers: I do not study them as intensively so i am less competent but from what i have seen they tend to be pretty good. I spent a week in germany last march and for several weeks i was reading the greek press. It was appalling kind of like fox news with big words and references to philosophers and so on but the reading was very interesting.

questions: would you say you are being entirely fair on them in the sense that they obviously are useful?
answers: Oh sure they are. I mean if i had a hammer I would use it if it was useful. It is exactly the same with regard to the non violent resistance.

questions: since i moved here last august everybody has told me that the problem that europeans have is that we do not understand we can not grasp just how deeply 9 11 affected americans?
answers: The fact of the matter is it was the worst terrorist atrocity since the mongol invasions. For one thing it is right in the middle of april 6th which is a date that will live in infamy.

questions: but what i am getting at is just the psychological impact that the event had on americans. does it make?
answers: You are begging the question there. I do not agree that psychological reality played any role. We can not really know whether it influenced the outcome because we have no evidence.

questions: what do you think is the long term effect of that event?
answers: Hurricane katrina brought out very dramatically some facts about the united states that are usually pushed under the rug. There is a very sharp class difference which shows up all over the place. In some respects it is more extreme in the case of haiti the poorest country.

questions: people do not like too much bad news here. they do not like to be depressed?
answers: Life is hard enough to face better news is not good. In fact the media have become far more sensational. I think this is true of europe too but crime for example is featured in gory grisly detail in a way which it was not when i was growing up in the 50s and 60s.
