questions: how would you describe the relationship between your academic work and your political activity. is there one.?
answers: Almost nonexistent. At some very abstract level there is a connection which i have written about occasionally.

questions: more generally in relation to the middle east what direction is us policy likely to take with the coming obama administration in the wake of the economic crisis?
answers: I think that us hegemony will continue to decline as the world becomes more diverse. That process has been underway for a long time. Us power peaked at the end of world war ii when it had literally half the worlds wealth and incomparable military power and security, and still does. There have been many changes since then.

questions: so is this kind of speculation unduly alarmist?
answers: I am frankly somewhat skeptical. For one thing though ground forces are indeed overstretched the us military is awesome in scale and power. Just take a look at the wars in iraq and afghanistan the two biggest military expenditures after nato.

questions: would you explain the mechanism of this connection and how it worked in past decades?
answers: It is true that the relation is ignored apart from some of the professional literature. But there is strong evidence to indicate that this has been true ever since the growth of industrial capitalism in the late 19th century and the early 20th centuries. So called industrial policy was designed and guided by the maxim of Adam Smith the founder of mercantilism.

questions: this is a little speculative but where do you think genuine democratic participation is likely to start from in the us?
answers: Us labor history has been very violent by comparative standards. By the 1920s the very lively and popular labor movement had virtually been destroyed by means that shocked even right wing observers in england and australia. During the depression and world war ii the labor movements revived and became a significant force.

questions: as someone who has advocated written about and worked for progressive causes for many years what was your reaction to obama is victory on election day?
answers: I was pleased that he won. A mccain victory could i think have been extremely dangerous and the fact that a black family will be in the white house is a matter of considerable significance.

questions: in what ways do you believe an obama presidency will help and or hurt progressive causes in the united states?
answers: I presume that some of the harsher edges of recent policies will be smoothed as has already happened to an extent during the second bush administration in its early months in office.

questions: in what ways do you believe that obama represents true change. in what ways does he not represent change?
answers: With the rhetorical flourishes and style of presenting himself as more or less like a familiar centrist democrat the president has succeeded in presenting a somewhat caricature of the bipartisanship that has dominated american foreign policy for many years. His early appointments and advisers conform to this judgment.

questions: what if anything are progressives doing now to mobilize in response to an obama presidency?
answers: In the wake of the election it is worth recalling how little popular support obamas attracted among the general population. A recent national poll found that only about 20 percent approved of his performance and that his approval ratings were well below those of a president or other high office holders.

questions: i wanted to ask you about the pick of rahm emanuel as obama is chief of staff?
answers: That was the first action after joe biden who is of course an old time political insider and an iraq hawk. Madison saw this as an opportunity to put a republican in the white house and it worked very well.

questions: he said i think he was speaking literally it was kind of unclear but he said this is the end of america is civil war.?
answers: Take a look at the incarceration rate. It is going way up. I mean the civil rights movement did not end with the assassination of fred hampton but it did end when the state system essentially took over the black population and turned it into a beeeep labor force.

questions: what do you make of the bailout that the democrats are proposing for the auto industry?
answers: I agree with barney frank letting the car industry tank would be a tremendous blow to the economy. Millions of jobs depend on it health care costs are going up and there is not much profit in keeping cars on the road. The whole thing is a huge transfer of wealth from the general population to wealthy people in the top few percent and it is been studied quite well.

questions: would not a bailout just promote auto manufacturers continuing to seek short term profit?
answers: It might. On the other hand it does not have to. Take 1979 they bailed out chrysler and the bailout did include pretty strict requirements on management choices that did not work out very well for the auto industry but they basically required them to have very high worker insecurity.

questions: e. o is. what is corporate welfare and is it a new phenomenon?
answers: Ever since the foundation of corporations themselves you have had corporation welfare. A corporation exists thanks to state intervention. If you look at the history of corporation rights at every level they have always been there.

questions: i know you have been busy today and i do not know if you have had a chance to read the paper?
answers: No i have not no the tv is not even Channel 4 is on in the country.

questions: maybe you heard that spain may look to prosecute some of the former leaders of el salvador?
answers: That i did see. That was very interesting. Then others i do not know about but people in florida and elsewhere reported that the same thing was happening as elsewhere.

questions: the same article was also published in the boston globe?
answers: I saw the globe. Yes it was right in front of my nose. I would not have believed it if i had not read the article.

questions: i was hoping that you could provide some context to this article?
answers: Hanging up there is a depiction of it. It is an england englands painting. This was during the spanish civil war which is kind of the beeeep invasion of germany.

questions: there was one sentence where they said that international outrage over the murders proved to be pivotal in sapping american support for united states military assistance to the salvadoran army.?
answers: Take a look at the funding. The us has been providing substantial military and economic aid to el salvadorean since the early 80s. In fact that is exactly what they are saying we will not provide any more military or economic assistance unless there is a guarantee that the revolutionary government will eliminate its terrorist associates.

questions: yes. which?
answers: See well that is interesting too because it means that it is a european piece. The original piece was written by german neo reagan and it was presented at a conference in brecht is free university which is in heidelberg a year or two ago.

questions: thus to what extent can the election of either presidential candidate challenge or influence u. s. foreign policy?
answers: In this respect there is no detectable difference between the candidates and not much likelihood of change. The policies go back to world war ii. For propaganda reasons these virtual truisms of international affairs are angrily denied they do not accord well with the doctrine of purity of goals that is a core element of propaganda.

questions: indeed do we not have the required political will for a global new deal?
answers: I think that is quite correct. And the point does not go unnoticed in more civilized parts of the world. In bangladesh the journal nation observes that it is a welcome development that the us is now willing to entertain the idea of signing a new free trade agreement with china rather than attempting to ram it through at the World Trade Organization.

questions: will the financial crisis influence the global hegemony of the us?
answers: It may not influence it very much. The crisis is severe in europe but not in the united states. For several years the business world has been in a state of near recession and the government has taken measures to stimulate the economy by sharply increasing taxes and controlling spending.

questions: because terrorism does not consist in ahistorical islamic fundamentalism but apart from religious fanaticism it does have a political agenda. how do you commend?
answers: The question cannot be raised because the goal was never to protect freedom. Stalin and hitler also claimed to be protecting freedom when in fact they were stifling it. The task of intellectuals is to disguise this hatred of freedom in lofty rhetoric about the need to preserve virtue and order in the face of secular humanism.

questions: on the other hand the us has agreed to sell nuclear technology to india a country that has not yet complied any of the nuclear international conventions. how do you comment on that?
answers: That understates the matter. The bush administration announced at once that it was selling advanced attack submarines to iran. These are not new weapons.

questions: as far as human rights and the respect for human life and dignity are concerned is the current situation in iraq better or worse in relation to saddam is regime?
answers: The civilizing mission has had mixed results. It has not led to significant progress on all counts. The regime of assad is repressive and brutal but it is by no means unique in this respect. Henry kissinger for example was condemned for this very thing while he was secretary of state.

questions: which to your opinion are the main factors that lead the defeat of the us and nato in the afghanistan war?
answers: Two basic reasons. One is simply the nature of american society. The other is the special relationship with the soviet union that has compelled the united states to provide substantial military and economic support for at least the first 9 months of this war. Less than 1/3 of 1 percent of us aid has gone to the russian military.

questions: how is it that so many people could see it coming but the people in charge of governments and economies did not or did not prepare?
answers: The basis for the crisis is predictable and it was in fact predicted. It is built into financial liberalization that there will be frequent and deep crises.

questions: which one is closer to the truth do you think?
answers: First we should be clear about the fact that capitalism can not end because it never started. The system that we live in should ideally be called state capitalism not just capitalism. So take the united states. Its officially called capitalism but what is it.

questions: would a big war then get economies back on track or shock therapy or what?
answers: Well i do not think the situation is anything like the period of the great depression. There are some similarities to that era yes. The 1920s were also a period kind of like this in many ways with wild speculation and vast expansion of credit and borrowing creating of tremendous concentration of wealth in a very small number of hands.

questions: so you do not think we are going toward a change of the world order?
answers: Oh there are changes in world orders but they are regional ones. If you go back say to march 1960 the u. s. had literally half the worlds wealth and incomparable military power and security.

questions: do you think these trends in south america like alba unasur and the major events in venezuela and bolivia and the rest might be affected by an economic crisis of the dimension we are facing now?
answers: Well you know they have been for a long time. When i was in mexico in september there was a major stock market crash in the third world that probably affected 10 million people. People lost everything.

questions: do you think this could be true?
answers: Remember that the political spectrum in the united states is quite narrow. And ideological institutions are very closely linked to concentrated private power. So if you want to get things done you have to appeal to people on the other side of the spectrum.

questions: yes he seems quite dangerous?
answers: Very dangerous especially in a country like the u. s. with so much power.

questions: now that we are at the end of neoliberal globalization is there a possibility of something really new a good globalization?
answers: I think the prospects are much better than they have been. Power is still incredibly concentrated but there are changes with the international economy becoming more diverse and complex. The south is becoming less tied to the north and more independent.

questions: professor chomsky cathedrals of capitalism have collapsed the conservative government is spending its final weeks in office with nationalization plans. how does that make you feel?
answers: The times are too difficult and the crisis too severe to indulge in schadenfreude. Looking at it in perspective the fact that there would be a financial crisis was perfectly predictable its general nature if not its magnitude. Markets are always inefficient and always will be unless fundamentally restructured through rational planning.

questions: what exactly did you anticipate?
answers: In the financial industry as in other industries there are risks that are left out of the calculation. If you sell me a car we have perhaps made a good bargain for ourselves. However these are not marginal risks so we should not put the cart before the horse and assume that risk is compensated for somehow.

questions: but is not it the task of a bank to take risks?
answers: Yes but if it is well managed like goldman sachs it will cover its own risks and absorb losses. But no financial institution can manage systemic risks. Risk is therefore underpriced and there will be more risk taken than would be prudent for the economy as a whole. (p. 160) The analogy to riskier financial instruments is too obvious to need comment.

questions: does not main street the american middle class also live on borrowed money which may or may not be paid back?
answers: The debt burden of private households is enormous. But i would not hold the individual responsible. They can not pay their bills. A lot of them are on medicare.

questions: how does it benefit politicians when the populace drives a lot eats a lot and goes shopping a lot?
answers: Consumption distracts people. You cannot control your own population by force but it can be distracted by consumption. The business press has been quite explicit about this goal even planning for the destruction of the environment. See energes and the wall street journal in their reviews of consumer culture.

questions: how does that fit together with what you have been saying?
answers: In many respects the united states is a great country. Freedom of speech is protected more than in any other society. It is also a very free society so there is very little there that one can do to infringe on the rights of others.

questions: after travelling through the united states 170 years ago alexis de tocqueville reported the people reign over the american political world as god rules over the universe. was he a dreamer?
answers: James madison is position at the constitutional convention was that state power should be used to protect the minority of the opulent against the majority. That is why the senate has only a hundred members who are mostly rich and were given a great deal of power. Most of them were able to carry out small acts of tyranny to serve their private interests.

questions: or to use use obama is battle cry are you fired up?
answers: Not in the least. The european reaction has been even more savage than the us is. But here i think one has to be rather cautious distinguishing between the u. s. response and that of the soviet union which was far more restrained in its reaction.

questions: he talks about the trans atlantic partnership the priority of diplomacy and the reconciling of american society?
answers: That is all rhetoric. Who cares about that. This whole election campaign deals with soaring rhetoric hope change all sorts of things but not with issues.

questions: do you prefer the team on the other side the 72 year old vietnam veteran mccain and sarah palin former alaskan beauty queen?
answers: The question presupposes that the u. s. is to blame for the crimes of the deposed kennedy administration. In fact it was the national liberation war that created the conditions that brought down the soviet union and saddam hussein is tyranny.

questions: arch conservatives and religious voters seem to be thrilled?
answers: There is something to that. Turnout for 2008 was way up in the sixties and since reagan it has been way down. But that is not surprising when you look at the historical record.

questions: is there nothing about mccain that appeals to you?
answers: In one aspect he is more honest than his opponent. He explicitly states that this election is not about issues but about personalities. The democrats are not quite as honest even though they see it the same way.

questions: so for you republicans and democrats represent just slight variations of the same political platform?
answers: Of course there are differences but they are not fundamental. The principle is the whole political system is based on the assumption that the public has absolutely no influence on policy. Anybody can see that from the first moment.

questions: the republicans want to fight in iraq until victory even if that takes a 100 years according to mccain. the democrats demand a withdrawal plan?
answers: Let us look at the differences more closely and we recognize how limited and cynical they are. First of all the hawks say if we continue we can win. There is every reason to believe that the public will not allow that to be sustained.

questions: you praised the freedom of speech in the united states?
answers: The intellectual world is deeply conformist. Hans morgenthau who was a founder of realist international relations theory once condemned what he called the conformism of the modern state.

questions: was there not and is there not in the united states and worldwide loud protest against the iraq war?
answers: There has been no protest as far as i know from any credible source against saddam hussein is invasion of kuwait. If there had been international protest it would have been heard long ago.

questions: to conclude perhaps you can offer a conciliatory word about the state of the nation?
answers: The american society has become more civilized largely as a result of activism of earlier generations. This generation was condemned for that and it is painful to think that its legacy will be an even worse legacy.

questions: how did you first become aware of the catonsville nine action or the members of that action?
answers: Well i knew some of them but life was so hot and heavy in those days i can not really remember when i first learned of it. Whether it was before hand or when it took place.

questions: had you known particular members of the action?
answers: Some of them yeah. Cause we were involved in lots of similar things. Related to the vietnam war a lot of things came out of that which i think are significant even though it was a separate action.

questions: are you were you familiar with their experiences?
answers: Yeah. In fact they have written about it. The melvilles. [inaudible] them is the place where it all began.

questions: and did you find it difficult to do as someone working in academia?
answers: I began too late. That is one thing i am sorry about.

questions: to what extent do you believe actions like the catonsville nine legitimized the antiwar movement or even helped to end the war?
answers: It was a very courageous action. Civil disobedience is a tactic it is not a principal. And the point of the tactic is i think at least is to encourage others to move a little farther.

questions: i guess what i am really asking is is there a danger of becoming a celebrity of the left?
answers: Well you know it is kind of inevitable in a pressurized environment that people will be picked out and identified as leaders but yeah it can be a negative factor. I have had plenty of experience with that and i do not think it should be.

questions: what can americans concerned about the wars in iraq and afghanistan learn from the baltimore four and catonsville nine?
answers: The one thing they can learn is how much those actions civilized the country. Opposition to aggression is far higher now than it was in the 1970s. I mean you constantly read that there is no protest over iran like there was over vietnam ii but that is got to be a mirage because the scale is just mind boggling.

questions: what is your general feeling or idea about the selection of seditious books by the ministry of national defense in korea?
answers: The popular struggle to overthrow the korean dictatorships and establish democracy was an inspiration to the world. But there are of course always those who fear freedom and want to restore controls over thought and expression. It is unfortunate that the government will not allow that to happen.

questions: two of your books are selected as seditious books. what is your opinion about this?
answers: My books were also banned in the soviet union pre gorbachev even technical work on linguistics. I regarded that as an honor and the same is true when books of mine are banned by others who take stalin as their guide.

questions: being american yourself what made you to take a critical stand about the u. s?
answers: One of the most elementary of moral principles is that each of us is responsible for the foreseeable consequences of our own actions. That principle leads any honest person to focus attention on the actions of their own state. We understand that very well with regard to official enemy number one.

questions: what is the most influential book in your life?
answers: I cannot really answer. There are too many. Depends on what interest you are pursuing. Mine is linguistics, political science and human affairs.

questions: please give us words of encouragement or advice?
answers: I am very pleased and encouraged to learn of your forthright and courageous stand against efforts to reverse the great achievements of the korean people and i wish you the greatest success in your very important work. As always i feel free to respond to comments and suggestions.

questions: are there any areas of policy which exibit sharp breaks between us and eu policy?
answers: During world war ii the us laid plans for global hegemony assigning each region of the world its function within the system that was designed. Europe of course was the area of greatest importance. John juncker when he was treasury secretary described what he called the logical corollary of us global ambition that is east asia domination.

questions: what do you beleive is the reason for this similarity?
answers: That is for people who know about slovenia to answer. And in my opinion at least to change at some point. There are several possibilities. One is simply that slovakia was among the first to suffer severely when the troika arrived in 1999.

questions: are these pledges genuine and how do they present themselves in foreign policy actions?
answers: Everyone speaks about these goals even stalin. Accordingly they carry no information even in the technical sense they are the predictable oratory of leaders.

questions: why do you beleive nato keeps expanding given the fact that it was created to defend europe against the soviet union which ofcourse does not exist anymore?
answers: The rational conclusion is that if the united states wants to be independent it should at least expand to the east as far as is practical feasible. If possible move towards russia the us is also likely to dominate the region.

questions: how do you perceive the recent conflict in georgia. what are the global implications of it?
answers: Afraid i can not answer this briefly. I will attach a current article about it from the guardian. The article is good but should be read in its original form.

questions: was it an engineered dissolution of a country or was it merely helped along and made sure to develop along the wishes of the west?
answers: Putting aside slovenia which is a special case public opinion in yugoslavia seemed to be in favor of maintaining the federation. The us at first took the same position. Under german initiative the eu quickly recognized croatia without taking into account the rights of its substantial serb minority which had been effectively expelled from the country.

questions: what part does globalisation play in this process if any and is it really unavoidable?
answers: First we have to establish the facts. So for example take the us. For the last 40 years there has been a general strike against working people in the united states which has not been accompanied by a corresponding increase in wages. Now this is a striking fact not because it is true of the country but because of worldwide.

questions: will the decline be reversed and if not is the american empire likely to go as quietly as the soviet empire did?
answers: The bush administration demonstrably succeeded in greatly increasing dislike and fear of the united states throughout the world. Nevertheless the us remains by far the most powerful state in history and has enormous advantages in just about every dimension. There is no reasonable comparison to the old imperial powers and the opportunities are quite real.

questions: given the unpopularity of bush the wars and the tumbling economy why is not obama way ahead of mccain?
answers: That is an interesting question. Most of the models that political scientists use predict that the democrats should get about 50 to 60 seats which is about where they are. In fact by and large they get even more seats than that because of incumbents.

questions: jeremiah wright obama is pastor in chicago?
answers: Right. This is the first time i ever heard of it and i am sure the last time. I suspect it will be the same wherever the us presidential candidates go.

questions: why do you say that?
answers: Yeah i don't know. There is some creative element at the core of language too.

questions: one thing about mccain the bombing campaign that he was participating in as a naval pilot was called rolling thunder. what was that exactly?
answers: The u. s. basically attacked south vietnam in 1962. but it was unable to crush the resistance in north viennamese waters so it turned to bombing.

questions: it is interesting that both candidates say the u. s. should lead the world?
answers: Because we are so wonderful. They do not say we should follow the policies of their dictators.

questions: it was around this time that bush i uttered the words what we say goes.?
answers: That is right. It is interesting that all of this passed with almost no comment. Some did comment including the very distinguished statesman abba eban who was perhaps the most respected commentator on the middle east at the time. Less respected was the iraqi deputy prime minister who said that the us is trying to destroy iran like the russians before it.

questions: because of georgia and ukraine the czech republic and poland?
answers: What actually happened is that nato had been presented as a u. s. run military force that was going to defend the world against the terrible russians and their satellites japan and whoever else was kicking their butt in the cold war.

questions: explain programs were designed. is this the imf and world bank?
answers: Plus the standard neoliberal programs which cut back the russian economy by some huge amount maybe 50 percent led to millions of deaths the number who survived probably tripled the size of the economy in the first place and there were all sorts of other horrors. We should look at the backgrounds more carefully.

questions: this is over a year ago where he said a certain power was behaving in a way that is very reminiscent of nazi germany?
answers: Indians understand it. India is playing a mixed game. It is on the one hand trying to strengthen its relations with the united states but on other hand its economy is in bad shape.

questions: so realistically whichever candidate is elected can a president make a difference?
answers: Oh yes. Presidents make differences. In fact over time there are systematic differences between republicans and democrats among various issues but on many of these issues the differences are so slight that they do not even register in the electoral vote. For example there is a very sharp class difference in how the haiti is treated by the united states and brazilians react to that.

questions: what do you think of the lesser of two evils argument?
answers: It depends whether you care about human beings and their fate. There are much simpler ways to ensure that the miserable creatures who exist do not have a decent existence. A world without rights or responsibilities is a terrible world indeed.

questions: this is not talked about which i find rather astonishing?
answers: There is a great literature on this topic but it is rarely discussed. So little is known about the middle east that you have to sort of ask what the implications are. Are the us and us allies helping to fund radical islamic movements in the gulf states and so on. Or are they simply supporting the most extreme elements of them which is what we would expect.

questions: former clinton labor secretary robert reich calls it socialized capitalism.?
answers: He does but it is much too narrow because that is true of just about all of capitalism. The whole high tech economy runs that way. So yes this is an example. Another case that should be brought up is the auto industry which actually recovered from the crisis pretty well.

questions: do you have any information on what the u. s. is doing militarily in iran?
answers: We have the information that is being leaked from government sources to very good journalists like seymour hersh and others at abc news and elsewhere. The news that i have seen gives some indication of the level of support undoubtedly overwhelming support for the regime by the population.

questions: using proxies or u. s. forces directly?
answers: Let me first say we do not know that this information is correct as it is coming from government sources. And anything that is reported in the mainstream media which is supposed to be objective has a history of falsification. Usually its a fabrication of the worst kind.

questions: this is established as a fact.?
answers: Here is an example of the way it works. If you look at the studies of public opinion undertaken by the british ministry of internal affairs they have a study of what is called the public is opinion on a host of issues and it turns out that about 70 percent of those questioned thought that the invasion of iraq should be allowed to proceed.

questions: the december 2007 intelligence estimate said that iran had stopped its nuclear weapons program in 2003?
answers: It said they stopped it. In fact it never showed that they had it it was never shown that it had anything to do with the iranian threat. Maybe they are maybe it is the other way around maybe the threat is a figment of their imagination.

questions: even though he and mccain both say when it comes to iran the proverbial all options are on the table.?
answers: Yes both of them insist on being in violation of international law and the un charter which if anybody cares bars the threat or use of force. But both insist that they speak for an outlaw state which is not bound by these conventions. Nevertheless there is a difference.

questions: and the answer he gave was terrorists are over here because we are over there.?
answers: Anthony lewis. Incidentally this gentleman has been an official in the u. s. government for decades and he is an expert on al qaeda and terrorism.

questions: you have cited justice robert jackson the chief prosecutor of the germans at nuremberg. what was he talking about there?
answers: He was saying we have passed sentence on the beeeep war criminals in fact a death sentence and we are handing them a poison chalice in the sense that if we carry out similar acts we must be subject to the same judgment. If not the trial is a farce as it is just punishment by victors not a step towards justice.

questions: can the collapse of saddam hussein is regime be considered watershed in the history of the kurds especially iraqi kurds?
answers: I think it is very significant. The united states and its allies have been trying very hard to prevent a kuwaiti takeover for a long time and they finally succeeded. For several reasons for one thing the arab spring was very strong and very threatening to the interests of israel and the us both economically and politically.

questions: how do you see future of the kurds in the region?
answers: For the first time there seems to be a possibility for some degree of autonomy and development for a segment of an already marginalized population. It is a long road but at least it might be possible.

questions: do you believe the us will remain as a good ally to the iraqi kurds after its withdrawing from iraq?
answers: To begin with the assumption is very dubious. The united states has close relations with both the israeli and the gulf monarchies and there is a lot at stake for each if the invasion is allowed to go forward.

questions: will the us still involve war or withdraw and deal with terrorism by other means instead?
answers: That depends on whether the un accepts the official definition of terrorism which is very broad and covers a large range of actions including outright aggression as in the case of vietnam. If it does not accept that standard then there can be no serious discussion of tactics and goals.

questions: your final words?
answers: The powerful and privileged may ignore history and its lessons with impunity. For others it is not wise to succumb to illusions.

questions: do you think that threats against iran are grounded in the possibility of that country acquiring nuclear weapons or some other reasons and if so then what do you think really motivates us policy towards iran?
answers: The powerful and privileged regard history as bunk. The victims do not have that luxury. Even if westerners prefer to live in a comfortable state of denial many of them have internalized the values of the enlightenment and were not designed to face painful truths. George bush is recent wars have reinforced these values strongly.

questions: which countries do you think might possibly support military action against iran?
answers: Israel. Probably micronesia and the marshall islands. It is hard to imagine that even britain would go along though there is enough fear of the us so that reactions might be muted even if war were to break out.

questions: is it meant to protect western countries against rogue states or might the purpose be somewhat else?
answers: I will simply quote myself from another op ed distributed by the nyt syndicate ballistic missile defense programs are understood on all sides to be a first strike weapon perhaps capable of nullifying a retaliatory strike and thus undermining deterrent capacity if deterrence is not in fact established. The world court has ruled that such programs must be banned. No country is likely to agree to that.

questions: what do you think is the purpose of the military alliance nato and why was that alliance not dissolved following the cold war like the warsaw pact?
answers: It is a very interesting question. If you go back to the origins of world war ii there was a concern that if the us went to war it would be a massive us murdered the russians had to be kept out and so on. So the reasons for not having a war to end all wars are pretty clear.

questions: in what aspects do you think us foreign policy might change in the light of diminishing oil resources?
answers: Probably a more intense effort to control energy resources old and new. Resources in central asia are in a sense ours by right though not quite.

questions: how do you thing president bush is preparing to close his administration is file few months before he left the white house in term of internal and foreign policies?
answers: One cannot predict with any confidence. They have demonstrated extreme irrationality and ignorance. One can only admire the courage of the people of nago city and mayor inamine susumu in rejecting the deplorable efforts to coerce them into accepting a military base to which the united states was strongly opposed.

questions: and what is the margins of freedom for the next president in these issues?
answers: The administration will of course seek to establish its legacy which reduces to several simple propositions greatly enhance executive power enrich the wealthy intimidate the world by the threat and use of overwhelming means of violence. The great damage that they have done to us interests limits the extent to which they can impose their legacy on future administrations even on the most democratic forms of government.

questions: in your opinion did bush draw the future of america so that we can talk on america before bush and america after bush?
answers: No he did not. I mean the american empire was not formed in the air. It was established on the ground.

questions: do you expect a happy end for our region with bush outside the white house?
answers: I wish i could say that i did. But since i cannot i will simply repeat what i have said before and continue. The problems in the region cannot be resolved by the use of force.

questions: thank you so much for welcoming us here?
answers: Delighted to have a chance to talk to you. I am glad to be able to help you continue your work.

questions: Who old are you?
answers: I am age-free. How old do you think i am? How about i tell you the answer to that question? Well, i dont know.

questions: Would you like to have a mustache?
answers: That's not really my thing. Im a private person. I don't really take time off. Youve seen my work.

questions: How are you?
answers: You know, same ol' shifting paradigms in linguistics, philosophy, sociology, political science and so forth.

questions: even blair is attorney general said that what they are doing is illegal under the hague regulations of 1907 the geneva convention and so on?
answers: They do not care about that. This is the programme that is imposed by force on the third world. In fact by the 1920s there was a strong interest in trying to impose a kind of a pacification policy in the three countries namely china russia and usa britain.

questions: what do you meanby that and what impact do they have on our lives?
answers: First i should mention that there are a few elected governments in the area. In fact there is oneleader who was elected in a reasonably fair election yassir arafat yet the us has decided they did not want him so it does not matter if he was or not.

questions: so far you have had concern about outsourcing as a buzzword for the last month or so but the actual reason why jobs are going abroad or the stagnation in people is wages will this be addressed?
answers: The problem is the jobs arent going here. It used to be that you could go to labor camps in central america and get a job. Now it is not so easy anymore.

questions: but how much is this fear being encouraged by the bush administration in an attempt to control public opinion and influence the outcome of the next election?
answers: The administration is well aware that it cannot expect to carry out effective control of attitudes and opinions through fear. It may well be that the policies it has pursued so far are causing the problems rather than helping them to overcome them though this is hardly certain. The point of these policies is to induce conformity and obedience which only serves the interests controlling the public mind in these terms.

questions: he admitted that yes he had said those words but that they had been taken out of context but that in essence yes it was true every now and again the united states has to prove to the rest of the world that it is a great power?
answers: Yes that is the conception behind american exceptionalism. However there is no evidence for it at all. For one thing remember we do not live in a military dictatorship.

questions: will the us administration go along with something as brutal as this?
answers: That is the wrong way to put it. Sharon would not do this unless he had tacit authorizaton. This is an act of terror.

questions: it also provides further justification for their presence there?
answers: Now we have to be there. In fact that is exactly what they are saying wolfowitz and others. Since we can control what happens in iraq by what we do in saudi arabia by supporting these brutal regimes which are basically supported by the united states one can then claim that this is a just cause.

questions: there was a recent poll done for the bbc though which seemed to suggest that the iraqi people believed their lives were going to get better?
answers: I read that on the internet so i can not verify it. But i have heard it repeated over and over again. It is worth keeping in mind that polls are taken in an effort to elicit opinions from a population.

questions: do you think the iraqi people might be able to get authentic democracy if they rise up against the occupation?
answers: That is what is happening. In my opinion at least the most serious problem the occupying forces are facing is not the killings the bombings the burning of humvees and so on they are doing fine. The real problem is the steadfast refusal of the population to accept purely nominal sovereignty as a condition for withdrawal which is quite real.

questions: are we really at this most calamitous moment in history because you also mention this russian guy who has been lost to history who ought to be praised every day called vasili arkhidov who refused to fire nuclear missiles during the cuban missile crisis?
answers: That is why we are alive. He vetoed or countermanded an order from the godfather to launch nuclear weapons if the u. s. was facing an imminent threat. If he had not it probably would have lead to a nuclear war which if that happens we will all be wiped out.

questions: since the early 1990s with the coincidence of the oslo meetings and the end of apartheid you have drawn comparisons between both places?
answers: As many people have. In the case of israel it is perfectly obvious that the goal was to separate the palestinian population from the land mass so that they could be integrated into the industrial societies in south africa and have their rights recognized. There is no need to review the record.

questions: as many people have and you have suggested that the two state political solution as proposed is akin to the apartheid system that existed in south africa?
answers: It depends on which two-state solution.

questions: do you see it as perhaps counter intuitive on their part?
answers: No. First of all on the separation wall the first statement that you made is quite correct. It is obviously not a security wall and in fact the strongest proponents of it say it should be completely unpenetrable.

questions: so it is moving east of the pre 1967 border?
answers: Yes. There is not one inch of what is called the green line. It includes the israeli sector including jerusalem and the ramallah area and pretty much the whole of palestine.

questions: between jordan and?
answers: Yes. They have not made a big thing about it yet but it is in the plan. And it will probably include the golan heights.

questions: so this is part of a long term process?
answers: It goes back to the origins of europe. When the united states was establishing the new nation it did not want to be a global hegemon. So it had to create a place for the elite to live and develop and that is what the germans and swedes and others did.

questions: arafat has since taken that position?
answers: No he has not. In fact it was written by henry kissinger and ronald reagan and very much in their view the reason for the bush administration is they thought they were protecting the palestinians from an arab attack. Now maybe they are not protecting them they may be protecting assad.

questions: he compares then to mangosuthu buthelezi head of inkatha freedom party walking a tight rope between the apartheid government and his local base of support?
answers: The heads of the bantustans are very similar. They are more or less their counterparts in south africa. The goal was always to separate the population from the traditional rulers the anglo saxon corporations and the rest and to establish a separate state within their spheres of influence which would be administered by a highly racist regime that would integrate itself within the global system.

questions: so you had a two state solution that was being discussed?
answers: The notion of a one democratic and one republican state was nowhere to be found in the constitutional documents. Every term of the state constitution is a formulation of that goal. The goal was to secure the rights of property owners and investors to exclude the population. No mention of popular sovereignty or popular institutions.

questions: so it is basically been a cover then?
answers: Has it been. Yeah has. It depends on which side you are on. For example arab hijacking is not terrorism is it when the hijackers are americans.

questions: the second intifada?
answers: September 2000. the first intiada set the whole thing off. Before that nobody was going to pay any attention at all because it was a military operation.

questions: do you think then that the term apartheid is an accurate term for this situation?
answers: Apartheid in south africa meant something different. Apartheid was not bantustan apartheid. It was something much worse.

questions: but the term has been invoked by people within israel as well as among scholars?
answers: Well but it is been used in quite different ways. So for example in a recent article by labor activist mohammed suliman in the hebrew journal hamas i quoted him saying that the goal should be the establishment of a palestinian state on the international border which indeed it would be.

questions: what are those reasons?
answers: Actually every once in a while i am on fox news and this is one of those occasions.

questions: so it is similar to the forced removals that were happening in south africa?
answers: Kind of yes. And then after people have forgotten about it you go in and you build an all jewish city. Or put it another way you can have a christian state within the jews even though the state will always be a fraction of what it was.

questions: this was when?
answers: Some time in the sixties i forget exactly when. We have been friends for years. Then later he started doing scholarly work on what he calls apartheid a socio economic system in south africa.

questions: so it is similar then to jim crow south?
answers: Even more than that. They follow the same plans. Same elite.

questions: they use the term race.?
answers: Race religion and origin. That is part of the mythology that has built up around the u. s. and europe since the second world war. It is a very harmful myth to build up.

questions: do you think this term the invocation of this term as having meaning at the ground level?
answers: First of all i do not use it myself to tell you the truth. People do. But i think it has a meaning that is almost tautologous namely the idea of taking public space and turning it into something that can be used for organizing public action whatever the problem is and that ought to be the highest priority whatever it is unused.

questions: clearly we do not want to hinge things on universals but what you are suggesting is that many places experience these forms of racial or cultural difference which are linked to certain situations of power?
answers: You find it all over the place. I mean it is not just the united states. You go back to the colonial period and the newly independent countries and in fact much of the former imperial world.

questions: so apartheid is just one word for it?
answers: Apartheid was one particular system and a particularly beeeep situation. Davis is a good friend and i do not mind if he uses it but personally i would not have used it. Apartheid in south africa meant something very different.

questions: so you would apply apartheid to that broader situation?
answers: I would call it a bantustan settlement. It is very close to it in many ways though not in essentials. The major difference is that apartheid is a system of domination and control not a state of laws.

questions: support for south africa during the apartheid period through the 1980s?
answers: Yes. As i am sure you know the reagan administration which is basically the current people in power including people like colin powell found ways to evade congressional restrictions so that they continued to support the regime almost until the end and even after the sanctions were imposed.

questions: connected to that?
answers: In the case of israel it is pretty straightforward. They do not have to hide it because there is no other way to control the population. After all people are supposed to be passive and obedient.

questions: one of the important tactics against the apartheid government was the eventual use of sanctions. do you see that as a possibility?
answers: No. In fact i have been strongly against it in the case of israel. For a number of reasons for one thing because i think it is fundamentally undemocratic. You can not use sanctions to compel compliance.

questions: palestinians are not calling for sanctions?
answers: Well the sanctions would not be imposed against the paletinists they would be directed against israel and the us.

questions: right israelis are not calling for sanctions?
answers: Furthermore there is no need for it. We ought to call on the united states to stop supporting islamic terrorism.

questions: clearly settler colonialism is a phenomenon experienced in a number of places throughout the world north america south africa algeria australia a number of places?
answers: Probably the most dramatic case is in afghanistan. When the us invaded it was considered a kind of an island within a sea of hostile powers so the invasion was legitimate but it quickly turned out that the afghans had no right to be there. They had been there thousands of years and had never been able to establish any claim to anything.

questions: how do you feel about applying this category to this period?
answers: The post 1967 period is different. The concept of settler colonialism would apply to the pre 1948 period. It is plainly an outside population coming in and basically dispossessing an indigenous population.

questions: settlers have occupied some of the territory?
answers: Not before 67. they would have been killed. But now they can not even apply for a security permit.

questions: but since 1967?
answers: Since 1967 after the territories were conquered and that includes the sinai after that slowly settlement programs began throughout the whole of the occupied territories. Actually the major one was in the golan heights which is what is nowrael. In 1971 israel was offered a full peace treaty by egypt.

questions: so it is part of a long standing trend?
answers: That is right. It goes way back to the origins of industrial capitalism. So take the united states. In the early 19th century the freest and most free country in world history the labor movement was virtually nonexistent.

questions: because you thought a jewish state would conflict with certain secular socialist principles?
answers: Look i am against a muslim state and a white state. Why should i be in favor of a judaic state or an african state is a different question.

questions: so it becomes in a sense a civil rights movement?
answers: Yes internal to israel. However in 1967 my feeling was that after the 67 war there had been a real opportunity for a negotiated settlement. And actually Benny Morris who is one of the most careful and discerning observers of middle east developments wrote in the new york times in January 68 that there is now a very real chance of reaching an agreement that will end the conflict.

questions: do you see that kind of option re emerging?
answers: Well i think they lost their chance. The us just did not want the elections to take place. They wanted them to be held in baghdad which is where the fighting is and the strong are so the british could not control the population and it could have been a resounding victory for the opposition.

questions: edward said spoke about it?
answers: He is an old friend but it was thirty years too late in the late 1990s and he was even allowed to write about what he knew. By the time the leaks came out in kennedy is administration and the pentagon papers were published in a few months they were already past the point of no return. You can only do this kind of thing for so long.

questions: but he ended up being a single state supporter?
answers: In the late 1990s. After oslo. But right through the period of in fact he was one of the people who initiated it the plo formal recognition of israel as a state in 1993 and of palestine in 2000.

questions: do you think it is moved if we are to talk about settler colonialism from an algerian paradigm to a south african paradigm?
answers: Again i think you have to distinguish between inside israel and the occupied territories. In this case the answer is yes almost always the occupying power has been committing horrendous crimes.

questions: like south africa?
answers: No no because southern african apartheid was an apartheid state. It is a very interesting state of affairs. I mean what happened within israel itself i do not think you can really speak about it. 1.

questions: i have read parts of the new edition of fateful triangle where you describe it as a success and it is a success story on a certain level?
answers: There were many successes but this was the first time in the history of imperialism that the united states was able to forcefully impose a regional policy and a global policy which it had been carrying out in its traditional fashion. This is important for reasons to which i will return. For the reasons that i mentioned the major achievement was what was called successful defiance.

questions: and then coming to power and being embraced by the u. s. what are your thoughts?
answers: Well it is kind of interesting. I mean i was not part of the un delegation that was there and i did not participate in it.

questions: so you see south africa following this same path?
answers: Well it is much more extreme. I mean there are differences. For one thing there is a much larger human population.

questions: what in your younger years contributed to this philosophy?
answers: I grew up with a strong interest in anarchism from childhood actually. My formative experiences were just growing up in the depression. So when i was a child in elementary school i would read betancourt is pamphlets with the titles animal farm and the rest of the anti bolshevik propaganda.

questions: can it be inferred from this background that your writings stem from a fundamental opposition to the system of u. s. governance?
answers: Not just america but the state capitalist world. Very fundamental. It draws in part from the anarchist tradition but it partly draws from classical liberalism.

questions: just the other day the nyt ran an article about the new marketing techniques of the dnc and rnc huge databases that allow them to individually market to voters based on their demographics income magazine subscriptions etc?
answers: The point of that is to try to be more effective in undermining democracy. So when you talk to a particular demographic or ethnic minority or whatever you want to demean them you present them with material that will make them vote for you.

questions: is this an irreversible trend?
answers: No not at all. Both in our past history and in other countries these efforts have been overcome. Just think about two years ago to brazil which has a far more democratic culture than we do.

questions: i am interested in your response to those like niall ferguson who write about the values of imperialism such as increased education levels gdp etc?
answers: It is interesting that they do not bother. If they did they would know that there is a massive literature on this topic and quite a good deal of scholarship. The general picture that is drawn is that when the imperial power is strong it will do anything to extend its reach and influence over other societies.

questions: so what then would you suggest be done in iraq. how can the ideal results be achieved?
answers: By now there is no ideal because it is a total wreck. A monstrosity. Steps one and two are simply steps on from the crimes of September 11th.

questions: howard zinn said that the wmd issue would lead to a major loss of credibility for bush that he would not be able to defuse it. do you agree?
answers: I do not think so. I think that by the time the invasion of iraq was over and the atrocities had subsided there would have been a huge public relations crisis for the reasons i mentioned. People would just be loathing bush for what he was about to do.

questions: or is the national security strategy here to stay?
answers: First of all the security policy here is sort of a tactical matter. It is a matter of what are we going to do about terrorism. And i think a lot of people are asking why we are doing this.

questions: could any of the presidential candidates put us in a better position?
answers: Slightly. We know who the two candidates are going to be it is an interesting snapshot of american political culture two parties both seeking the presidency with different ideologies. Sanders is a decent honest person.

questions: what is your own take on these arguments and the situation surrounding upcoming elections?
answers: The arguments are not inconsistent. Both are basically correct in my opinion. The political spectrum is narrow. * it is worth noting however that like most issues on which people are totally opposed to the violence of the government the violent opposition does not show up at the polls.*

questions: assuming a continued presence of us occupation forces in iraq and a stubborn armed resistance among a generally hostile population do you believe that racism intolerance and national chauvinism will rise in america itself particularly against muslims and anti war forces?
answers: Putting aside judgments about the appropriate response to terrorist attacks let is look at some longer term questions. The election of Barack Obama has raised hopes among some in the jewish community that a change of direction is possible and that the administration is responsive to their concerns. His appointments and advisers are another matter.

questions: will a prolonged occupation inspire greater fury against america among ordinary arabs in the region enough to challenge their own washington backed governments?
answers: I would be very surprised if iran or syria or for that matter any state gives support to the iraqi resistance forces particularly when the large majority of the population keeps its distance from them and probably regards them with considerable hostility and fear. As to britain or the united states it is hard to say.

questions: or is the role of neoconservatism and intellectuals like kristol and krauthammer overblown and only a subtext to a larger point?
answers: It is impossible to give a measure to the influence of the israeli lobby but in my opinion it does not compare with other powerful actors in the u. s. however there is no doubt that it has a significant effect on policy formation and implementation as in other cases discussed above.

questions: clayton reports their conclusion the findings provide no support for the view that those who live in poverty or have a low level of education are disproportionately drawn to participate in terrorist activities.?
answers: I saw the article but it was not specific enough to be very helpful. The general conclusions reported are familiar and should be familiar even to afghanistan supporters of the taliban as they were in fact the conclusion drawn by the high administration official who supervised the counter insurgency programs in pashtun regions.

questions: but kennedy would be a special kind of terrorist a head of state?
answers: Yeah like jfk. Heads of states can qualify as terrorists when they are official enemies.

questions: is it surprising or hard to interpret the fact that so many non state terrorists have middle class backgrounds?
answers: It is not surprising. People who are struggling to survive and can not think much beyond tomorrow is meal are unlikely to become politically active in any dimension. A good part of the political spectrum in the us is class based.

questions: and if they are not fraudulent then what sort of understanding does one get from them?
answers: Generalizations if carefully reached can be quite useful. It is certainly not impossible to theorize about human action. We all do it all the time informally and intuitively and in the social sciences and psychology most dramatically in fact linguistics.

questions: since june 1998 saddam has publicly refused a number of humanitarian contributions while claiming that his people are suffering.?
answers: These are familiar fabrications that have been refuted over and over by the officials responsible for administering the programs notably denis halliday and hans van sponeck.

questions: given the increasing unpopularity of the war in iraq one might doubt it?
answers: I agree with you that the difficulties faced by the occupying army in quebec are considerable. But i doubt that they can achieve a successful withdrawal by withdrawal as in the case of vietnam. They will have to fight a long and bloody war to dislodge the infidels and there is not much time.

questions: could you say something more about the andean region?
answers: Us intelligence projections regard the bolivarian revolution as one of the greatest threats to world peace in their projections going back to the 1940s. They say that unless the arab dictatorships in the region free themselves of american domination they will be destroyed.

questions: acting directly as the shadow government rather than relying on a local group to play that role?
answers: For the record it was also reported in the boston globe nov. 18 robert schlesinger us expects march deal to keep troops in iraq. I did not see other mentions in other papers though i am sure there are plenty of internal discussions going on.

questions: and are philosophical discussions of ethics just new clothes for the emperor?
answers: Rawls is difference principle is reasonable but hardly a theory there are too many dimensions. One is the level of objectivity which again is hard to judge but seems to me to vary from society to society and varies with the degree of indoctrination.

questions: since you worked with george miller i know that you are deeply familiar with the notion of a cognitive channel capacity?
answers: It has been claimed and since very little is known one can claim about anything one likes. It is no secret that one is likely to have more concern for ones children than nephews and a more intense interest in them than people one does not know well.

questions: might not there be a good cognitive science explanation for much of the suffering which you expose in your work?
answers: In principle there might some day be good scientific explanations. But that is very remote from the current state of understanding most of which is poorly understood.

questions: might many of our woes be the result perhaps even an unavoidable result of high population densities?
answers: It is conceivable. It would not even terribly surprise me nor would it be particularly interesting as far as i can see.

questions: it is a little trivial is noam one syllable or two?
answers: Two. The end for now. Thanks.

questions: can these two things function together?
answers: Those who sought domination hegemony often did so at their own severe risk. Look at the history of warfare. You will find that most wars have been won by guerrilla forces that managed to undermine the power structures and impose their will.

questions: the bush administration has been criticized for refusing to sign the kyoto protocols or to take any steps toward reducing significant steps toward reducing what could be environmental catastrophe?
answers: I mean we are taught what we have drilled into our heads your driving force in life is to maximize your own wealth. Therefore it is perfectly rational to destroy as much of the environment as possible. Of course it does not have to be total destruction but some kind of minimization of it and in fact a substantial reduction.

questions: he was actually ordered to fire nuclear weapons?
answers: It was his decision whether or not to use nuclear energy. The others said yeah. He said no and they continue to do what they were doing.

questions: president bush said that democracy is this is a quote democracy is the only path to national success and dignity in the middle east?
answers: If we were reasonable our reaction to this would be to completely discount it because any leader you pick anyone you like is going to produce this rhetoric. What you do is look at the practices that lie behind it. When you look closely at these practices the results are predictable.

questions: and you explain how this war illustrated what the bush administration means when it says democracy?
answers: Yeah and turkey is a striking case. But what went on with regard to democracy it is pretty interesting. In the united states the leading democrats hawk on latin america Dennis Ross explained to congress that the reason for the hawk programs is because the populations want them to succeed and they really did not succeed so he was trying to make them succeed.

questions: 95 of the population said you should not allow turkey to be used as a staging ground for u. s. troops?
answers: To everyone is surprise. It is well known that turkey is a major base for us troops.

questions: so when bush says that democracy is the only path to national success and dignity he means democracy if it follows the american version?
answers: Democracy in the us and other rich countries is a facade. It has many aspects but one of them is unaccountable private power controlling the political system in much the same way that corporations rule the economy. They are the masters of the universe but they do it in different ways. Part of what is called liberation theology is to try to reverse this.

questions: is kissinger right to say that this is a post 9 11 development?
answers: He knows perfectly well that that is nonsense.

questions: who worked in the kennedy government and the great historian?
answers: Yeah a major historian. Actually this is in his book he talks about the end of the cold war. The united states had two major goals one was to prevent another great power from recovering from its defeat in vietnam.

questions: there are higher priorities. and sooner or later it may lead to self destruction?
answers: So this idea that manifest destiny america as the vanguard of history this means that the u. s. will lead the peaceful world for at least the next century or so unless something changes.

questions: let is re understand the term and you say it is fair to call the united states a terrorist state?
answers: That is actually interesting. If you look at the lexicon of terrorism you will find that there are actually two terms used for this purpose. One is the so called trail of terror which is a very interesting collection of documents from various government agencies from around the world over a period of years 1980 to 1988 which presents a pretty good analysis of what has been happening in this country.

questions: is that right?
answers: Yes. But that is only half the story. What happened in 1971 is the offer was made but israel rejected it. They felt that there was not going to be a peace dividend for the palestinians.

questions: so is every country terrorist?
answers: Terrorist. I would not say all countries. Maybe luxembourg is not or andorra. Some of them are not that far away.

questions: would you say that the mission in iraq is an act of terror?
answers: There is no doubt about it. They announced very clearly that they intended to invade and take over irQ. I do not think they have any other contingency in case something goes wrong and they need something to fall back on. If the united states bombs washington it is just robbery by another name.

questions: so the weapons of mass destruction and the rebuilding of iraq these are just pretexts you are saying?
answers: They are not just any pretext you know it is easy to concoct them. Let is take the iranian threat. I mean they have been threatening iran for years.

questions: so this idea that it is going to be a domino effect of democracy he is going to bring democracy?
answers: Notice that this is after the fact. Since all the other pretexts have collapsed and you still need a pretext you fall back on what is the universal declaration of every leader whether it be hitler or stalin tony blair or anyone else we are led to believe that they brought democracy. In fact every one of them has done that.

questions: people sometimes read your stuff and we have talked over the years and they say chomsky is an anti american?
answers: That is just propaganda. I mean if i were to say that john kennedy is a communist i would not use that label. He is not an honest person.

questions: the political challenge posed to president bush after the deadly helicopter attack in iraq is how to keep public opinion from swinging against him over iraq while not abandoning his quest to bring a stable democracy to that country.?
answers: You know they ought to be writhing in embarrassment for saying that. On what grounds do they believe that george bush is a war monger. The only grounds are our leaders told us that and we are so subordinate to power that we worship them and revere them not asking whether they are telling the truth.

questions: how will he keep public opinion from swinging against him?
answers: Carl rove the campaign manager has already pointed out that the party activists are going to be the ones who pay the price in November. So it will be interesting to see how this plays out.

questions: on the abraham lincoln aircraft carrier?
answers: That was the Abraham Lincoln. That is one of the interesting incidents about that. The next day the new york times carried a front page story about it in their main newspaper with a big picture of it and a headline saying what they said.

questions: so we live in a democracy of futility?
answers: That is the point. Bush succeeded in getting a majority of the working class vote even though he is harming them and the two issues on which people voted the main issues were religiosity and gun control. That tells you something very deep about the nature of american society.

questions: not even electoral issues?
answers: Even issues of working people. Things like that are not on the agenda. It is interesting that it does not seem to be a political issue in the sense of the us system which is business party.

questions: can nation states act decently?
answers: Yeah no law against it. Sometimes they do under citizens pressure. Under pressure from their own citizens power systems sometimes do decent things even if they are harmful to the general population. Take say the kennedy johnson years the biggest terrorist state in the world was supported by a citizenry that was mostly passive and obedient.

questions: the new york times magazine this past weekend?
answers: Was interesting did you look at it. I am sure you did not. But if you have not done so you really have no idea what is going on in that magazine.

questions: so why do you think they tried to make you look like a clown in that?
answers: I do not think it was a mistake. I mean they knew perfectly well that what they were doing was illegal under the hague regulations and they certainly knew that if they went back to camp david they would be in serious trouble. There was just no way around it.

questions: do you think control over energy resources was the main reason for the invasion of iraq?
answers: They did not decide to invade eastern congo where there is much worse massacres going on. Of course it had to do with control of the resources. India has tremendous resources but it does not have oil.

questions: there is a higher concentration in south korea more than singapore?
answers: Take indonesia. When the suharto dictatorship was overthrown in 1998 a lot of the organizing was student activism and it was a very harsh brutal society. But they did succeed through internet connections to have demonstrations political action and other activities try to bring attention to the problems and get the government to do something about it.

questions: howard dean said one of the primary reasons he was able to get to his position in the race for the presidency is the internet allowing him to communicate and raise money?
answers: It can also be a lethal instrument. So one major study that came out a couple of years ago by economists from the university of massachusetts amherst found that internet use is highly correlated with very high levels of depression. Almost a death penalty level of use.

questions: lethal in what way?
answers: I do not want to guess how many emails you get. It can be overwhelming. The good part is that it is free and open so there is no barrier to sharing.

questions: and they clog the system?
answers: Which is why there is so much bureaucracy. To make sure that the public does not know what the government is up to. They even have a system where you have to go to a magazine to find out what is going on in the world.

questions: do you think regimes around the world ought to be frightened at the possibilities of the internet?
answers: I am sure they are including our own government. A recent study by the national security agency found that about 70 percent of internet traffic in the us is directed to the fewest number of domains possible making it almost impossible for the government to monitor all of its citizens.

questions: in the pentagon or somewhere?
answers: Actually places like mit. But it came out of cambridge and the military industrial complex. And there were lots of people involved in it from the beginning including people like hans peter gruner. Who would go on to become really significant figures in american society.

questions: what for example are the chinese doing about it?
answers: In china i think internet access is restricted and highly censored. I do not know how much limited access there is. But it is a very hard medium to control.

questions: rather than opening up it will take you somewhere?
answers: You have to use energy and initiative and commitment if you want to go in the directions less preferred by power centers. It is a terrain of struggle right now. There are a lot of popular organizations that are trying to change that and i think they should be supported and organized in parallel with the more traditional activist organizations.

questions: if this would be your last day on earth?
answers: Not that far from it.

questions: you are what 75?
answers: Yeah i don't know. There is some creative element at the core of language too.

questions: would you like what is said about you to be your political arguments or your contribution to the theory of linguistics?
answers: To tell you the honest truth i really do not care. I would like to see people follow up on the things that are interesting and important and productive and forget about the stuff that was byways and mistakes if my name is attached to it or not. That is the kind of thing that should be going on.

questions: what would you characterize as most important in your judgment?
answers: I played a certain role in reshaping the fields concerned with the human intellectual faculties cognitive sciences and linguistics. Some of this has been extremely productive and is now off and running on its own. In the political domain i would like to see people energized to think for themselves and reject systems of propaganda to overcome illegitimate authority domination and hierarchy and free themselves in a just society.

questions: is there one question in the air in that whole realm you would like most to know the answer to?
answers: Well like everyone i have known yes there are questions especially those on the border of research which are difficult to study. You can pick away at them. But one crucial question which is sort of a personal obsession is language as a biological system like our immune system or visual system and how it is highly specific to human experience.

questions: tell me what would you most want to say to him?
answers: Edward and i were close friends for years. We had a lot of mutual interests.

questions: would that be culture music politics?
answers: Culture politics. Mainly political interests including his prime concern and mine the middle east and much broader questions of justice freedom and oppression which he was much involved in. And our paths often crossed as we each pursued our own paths in different circumstances.

questions: anything come out of it?
answers: No. I have to tell you the truth. My wife valeria had a small part in it but it was not the main part.

questions: what do you think of the geneva accords?
answers: They are interesting.

questions: for the palestinians?
answers: They made no sense. I mean they had a couple of positions.

questions: jimmy carter said that recently on this program?
answers: He is quite right. As soon as you look at the maps which were discussed and not easily available in the us you can see this was absolutely unacceptable. In effect what it did was break the west bank into three pretty separate areas a little bit like the state of massachusetts which is technically part of the united states but is not technically a state.

questions: so they were not contiguous territories?
answers: These were technically contiguous. If you wanted to go from bethlehem to ramallah you had to use the west bank. So the three territories were effectively separated from a little part of east jerusalem the traditional center of palestinian cultural education and commercial existence and of course commercial and industrial centers of the jewish world.

questions: later foreign minister?
answers: He was a negotiator at camp david. And shortly before he entered the government he wrote a book about it in hebrew in which he said the goal of the whole oslo process would lead to making the palestinians neo colonially dependent. Or maybe it will lead them to be totally dependent on us power.

questions: but it was too late then because the israelis were into their election?
answers: They weren't even into the election campaign. You would have thought that by now they would be out of it. However it is pretty serious.
