questions: which was hammered out by yossi beilin and other israelis over two years with the palestinians who i am not sure may have been part of the palestinian authority?
answers: Some had been. But all are close to it in substance and style. What is important to remember is that whatever agreement was reached it was not a peace agreement.

questions: the late edward said did not have much good to say about yasser arafat?
answers: Nor did i. in fact we were very much in accord about this for a long time.

questions: he did a real disservice to the palestinians?
answers: Well i do not think one can say that exactly. Some people i think have done a lot of good and i am not in favor of killing people. But you have to ask what is the benefit of escalating the cycle of murder and destruction.

questions: why is that?
answers: Because skinnerian behaviorism is off the wall. It is as hopeless a project as trying to explain that the onset of puberty results from social training. But i really do not know whether skinners still maintains this extreme position despite the failure of the experiment.

questions: i am not making a statement i am asking?
answers: He remained a symbol of palestinian nationality struggle refusal. That is important. Whatever you think of him personally just serving the role of enabling people to resist harsh oppression and probable destruction that does not justify violent action against him.

questions: the invasion of lebanon?
answers: Which is where the plo was based.

questions: at the behest of israelis or?
answers: They did not like it but they could never have blocked it if the us had not intervened. And much more importantly the islamic states like isis and walid jumblatt recognized that there is a political settlement on the table. There can be one in fact a very substantial one.

questions: us support in the international community or us support at the un?
answers: At every level.

questions: so you are suggesting without the us is ever looming possible veto at the security council or in some other way there would be some kind of arab military reaction without the us?
answers: They can not no small country can stand alone against the unified international community. It is just impossible. There is all kinds of ways of stopping it and they need the economic and military support.

questions: but it was not on the table?
answers: We are talking about the invasion of panama. That is a different question. There is overwhelming evidence to support the conclusion that the u. s. did not intend to withdraw when the opportunity arose. Tripoli was a very important city.

questions: my impression was that when we had the agreement between egypt?
the agreement was that the israelis withdraw and in fact ariel sharon came in and cleaned up the settlements?
answers: In the northeastern sinai which is part of the palestinian authority there is a problem. Actually it is been a long standing problem between the egyptian military dictatorship and theraeli government.

questions: am i right or wrong?
answers: That is right. But we can ask the same questions about generative grammar. Why is it that languages appear to have hierarchic structures whereas humans have a non-hierarchic structure.

questions: egypt would once again have the sinai and there would be diplomatic relations between the two countries?
answers: Right. And that is what decided the matter. You know the way the us goes sort of determines how the world works.

questions: it would have been smarter to keep with the original one?
answers: Right. But see in 1971 the palestinian issue was not on the table. In 1977 it was.

questions: jimmy carter was here several days ago. i mean he certainly thought it was a triumph?
answers: He probably does not know the history. You should have asked him whether he knows what happened in the background. It is all in public record.

questions: on the other hand there are people who have asked you look if you have such strong feelings about how wrong headed american policy has been why do not you leave the country and you would always say i love this country. correct?
answers: I do. That is an interesting question. Let is try it on another country maybe it is Sweden which is a very different society than we are. But let us take a country that has a much more extreme example of what i have described.

questions: i am just making the point that you always said?
answers: That is the framework the question should be understood in. It is assuming that there is a question of a moral equivalence. If there was no such notion there would not be any need for a framework in which to base moral judgments.

questions: you stay and fight for values because you love the country?
answers: If i had to choose between washington and benghazi i would choose the former. The security situation is much better here. And the people are more or less intact.

questions: you put free speech high on that list?
answers: Very high. But it is not the only one. We have to make a clear distinction between state power and a country. If the united states is the government of the world what it tries to do is impose order on the international system and that is perfectly barred by the principles of international order that i have just described.

questions: i understand?
answers: But it is often not distinguished. If you criticize state policy you are not criticizing a country.

questions: frequently when you are traveling around the world as i do people say i love america i just hate the policy?
answers: Sure. And we are responsible for the policies. It is a free country so why should i hate it.

questions: which is there ought to be a two state solution?
answers: Roughly back to the 67 borders. The polls show roughly two thirds of the population saying they support that. And roughly the same proportion said the us should become more involved in diplomacy helping determine what happens in those two countries.

questions: because you believe the political process is corrupt?
answers: Not corrupt but it is not under public control. That would be the way the media would operate. They would not be under corporate control but that is what they are.

questions: it is what?
answers: Looking at your work. You are quite possibly the most important living intellectual. No one has done anything like what you have done in this field.

questions: when somebody says look i know?
answers: It is not that there is robbery and stealing of elections. There are a lot of efforts to prevent people from knowing about it and that is part of the job of journalists. I have had plenty of correspondence with journalists who refuse to tell people the truth about things that are very serious things like the terrorist atrocities in florida or for that matter the war in iraq.

questions: they have more power than have nots?
answers: If you really look closely elections eliminate issues where the masses are the opposing opinion. Let is take a concrete case the 2000 election. Among the issues of highest concern to the general population are things that roughly relate to what i have been talking about.

questions: how do you stand yourself on nafta?
answers: I agree with the general population and the labor movement that i do not think the agreement is that bad. I mean it is a little bit like the south africa agreement. The problem was that naftsa did not sign right away so that is why there is such a furor over it.

questions: you agree with the general population whose view is?
answers: Critical but not critical. I mean critical of course. It is interesting that the united states does not pay any attention to it nor do they care.

questions: were you worried about the loss of jobs and those issues which became a political football. the unions essentially were opposed to it?
answers: That is the story. That tells a lot of something about american society. There is just no way that those things could ever become political.

questions: in other words you are saying that they misled us when they made that argument?
answers: No. The unions did not oppose it. They supported it because it is in their interest.

questions: what you are arguing is that people are not getting the information they need to make wise choices?
answers: Nor are they given the choice. And the two parties represent the same interests the us is essentially a one party state. It has two factions of the business party with two different ideological nostrums.

questions: the tory party and the labor party. would you say the same about them?
answers: Sure. They are different but the attitude is the general framework is shared by the media and most of the educated sectors.

questions: let me make this argument with you and ask is the battle in politics in most countries for the center?
answers: That is not true. There are countries with a much more lively democratic culture. Let is take a country that has a more vibrant democracy culture than we do: canada.

questions: number one i asked that question recently when gary wills was here why have not we seen in the us a more powerful coalition essentially coming from the left but not necessarily defined by the traditional wisdom of the left labor minority poor black and white?
answers: We have seen it. That is why there is such a conflict.

questions: the author of the great society programs was lyndon johnson?
answers: Right. The programs are not initiated by leaders. That is a serious misunderstanding and a major distortion of what socialism means.

questions: those were initiated by people many of then who served with fdr?
answers: See that is a serious misinterpretation i believe of the way the system works. Leaders may sign their names and may push programs but they do it because a popular constituency is compelling them to do so. That happens over and over again in democratic systems.

questions: but let me make this point about lyndon johnson. but you were saying he responded?
answers: In fact the way the press treated this is by excusing himself and saying it was all just a big misunderstanding. And that is quite plausible.

questions: and secondly the things john kennedy responded to he saw his chance in history to show that he could get these things enacted because that was his principal skill?
answers: We are not disagreeing. We mean the same thing. The assassination of cindy crawford was a crime.

questions: i look with great interest in what is happening in brazil?
answers: It is happened here. Why do we have freedom of speech. I mean freedom is not in the constitution or the bill of rights i think we should be very cautious about that word.

questions: other than freedom of speech what else do you think is part of what america represents?
answers: Represents which i think we should be protecting.

questions: is what it is?
answers: There are a lot of things i think that are great about american life. For one thing compared to other societies there is very little in the way of a caste system. Everyone is in his or her own little world.

questions: is there a meritocracy?
answers: Certainly. But we are talking about interactions among people. Informal interactions in my view are much healthier in the us than in other societies because the population is much more open.

questions: because you think?
answers: We can rule some things out. I do not think you can make a case that it was the worst period of neoliberalism i can think of. There certainly were some areas of improvement things like the decline in autoworking which is a good thing and i think it should be pursued.

questions: wait a second?
answers: Look this was war. Was there any protest. If there was it was small.

questions: people know you because of your opposition to vietnam?
answers: You could not get four people in a room to talk about it. But this was important. It was four or five years before a significant popular movement developed opposing an aggressive war against another country.

questions: why do you think that took place because of the 1960s because as it breathes it gets wider and stronger and?
answers: The change happened because a lot of people worked very hard to make a change. The same is true of civil rights of women is freedom of speech and so on. That is the way changes happen. Remember the kennedy act was mainly a reaction to what was called the spock coffin.

questions: i do agree with you on that. i am not arguing that. brazil is an interesting case?
answers: If you investigate this here is what you will find. Over the last 20 or 30 years in part as a reaction to the democratizing tendencies of the 60s there were worldwide protests. They were dramatic here but elsewhere there has been a backlash.

questions: i will move on. was it because that we did not have the un behind it?
answers: It was not the us. George bush made the decision months before the election to put aside the reagan years and to focus on the future. In fact when obama came in he had already made that decision.

questions: i am not sure they supported him?
answers: They effectively authorized him to rush the rebellion.

questions: let me make one point that it clearly was a mistake in 1991?
answers: Was it wrong.

questions: sure it was. to allow him to crush the rebellion?
answers: Did george bush think that was a mistake. Did thomas friedman from the new york times who was close to bush at the time. Everyone keeps quiet about this but we know what the reasons were there are very simple reasons and they were not well served by bush or his associates.

questions: i can not speak for them?
answers: Take a look at the analysis. What was the goal. The goals were repeatedly stated repeatedly.

questions: the shias?
answers: Let is look at the time. That is what we need to be looking at. There is an overwhelming consensus that saddam offered more hope for the stability of the country than the people trying to overthrow him.

questions: i am sure he did not mean using torture and other techniques?
answers: Then why did he say it. Well maybe he thought it was funny. We do not know. Probably because he is so utterly incapable of seeing that his words are meaningless.

questions: but he may well have meant iraq whatever the fears he had of breaking up iraq and it needed a head figure?
answers: That means from the point of view of the us policy makers it was not a mistake. We think it is an error but they did not. The analysts and the decision makers believed what they were saying for about ten years.

questions: i bet you the neocons did not think it was a mistake?
answers: We do not know <

questions: 50 years ago in august 1953 operation ajax carried out by a cia agent who was incidentally teddy roosevelt is grandson overthrew the conservative parliamentary democracy led by mohammed mossadeq and restored the shah to the peacock throne where he ruled for the next 25 years?
answers: The issue was that the us was trying to restore the traditional order in which it had been reigning for half a millennium with the help of the british who had basically been a backwater country trying hard to become something more than what it was. They had a good education system and so on. And the situation was similar in other countries.

questions: in addition to this how do you evaluate the legitimate problem of israel in terms of world public opinion exclusively islamic countries?
answers: I do not remember actually calling isis a terrorist organization though it certainly engages in actions of a kind that we call terrorism when perpetrated by official enemies. It is important to bear in mind that the term terrorism is commonly used as a term of abuse not accurate description so i will not use it.

questions: there are some evidences that a kurdish state will be established in the northern iraq with the pioneering of america and israel. do you agree with this?
answers: I think that is extremely unlikely and i do not think the us or the britain would commit themselves to it. They would much rather see islamic fundamentalism prevail. It is conceivable that parts of saudi arabia might become kulsas but for the moment at least that seems unlikely unless the central part of the oil producing region was destroyed.

questions: can this be the beginning of the cold term relationships between america and turkey as it is widely claimed?
answers: Washington and us elites were infuriated that the turkish government took the same position as 95 of its own population rather than following orders. The influential pentagon planner paul wolfowitz even went so far as to condemn the military for its weakness in permitting the government to conform to the will of 95 percent of iraqis who regard the occupying forces as a terrorist force.

questions: because as you know like in the example of port alegro brazilia has an exceptional place on earth?
answers: The popular media i observed were not in porto do caso but in huge suburban slums outside rio de janeiro. And they were quite remarkable. If these achievements were possible under such conditions they could be duplicated in many other places where conditions are similar. Incidentally i have occasionally mentioned a country that achieved something similar under similar circumstances.

questions: because there is not a paradoxal democracy perspective in the other most of the world countries and much time the intellectual may choose to hide his truths for his sake?
answers: Intellectuals of course have a responsibility to speak the truth and often to do something about it even if it is unpopular. That is true of journalists and others as well. What is different about the United States and other great powers is that the burden of proof for any stance is very heavy and those who resort to it often suffer severe criticism and even violence.

questions: it is claimed that turkey is successful about secularization democratization and the process of the securalization and it is believed to be a good model for the other muslim countries. what do you think about this?
answers: Turkey has been successful in some ways and has seriously failed in others. I am in no position to hand out grades for good and bad behavior. It depends on what the criteria are that is being applied to the country.

questions: talk about the role of language in shaping and forming people is understanding of events.?
answers: Well it is as old as history. It has nothing much to do with language. Language is the way we interact and communicate so naturally the means of communication and the conceptual background that is behind it which is more important are used to try to shape attitudes and opinions and induce conformity and subordination.

questions: looking at the recent us policies in iraq what do you think was the real goal behind this war?
answers: Well we can be quite confident on one thing. The reasons we are given can not possibly be the reason. And we know that because they are internally contradictory because there is a history of internal contradiction in the united states.

questions: because you don t believe that they are going to stop in iraq would not you?
answers: No they already made this clear. For one thing they need something for the next presidential election. And that will continue.

questions: what may be the future of the palestine question which still is of paramount importance in the area?
answers: Well what is going to happen is extremely hard to predict. I mean it s a disorganized and chaotic scene. There are regular and predictable moves towards fragmentation and exclusion.

questions: i have two more question to go. what is your reflection on the international arena?
answers: Well you know it is a little bit like financial and industrial strategy. It has two components. One is keep the population passive and obedient and the other is raise profits.

questions: what has been the real impact of the war in the domestic politics of the us?
answers: Well it is interesting to compare the late sixties with the early eighties. During the eisenhower administration there was a very lively counter insurgency movement which was extremely dangerous. People were scared and rightly so.

questions: today a special edition featuring the world famous author and political activist noam chomsky?
answers: Once described by the new york times as arguably the most important intellectual alive is an outspoken critic of us foreign policy. He says following the war in iraq the us is seeking to dominate the middle east by force a dimension in which it rules supreme.

questions: what are the regional implications of the u. s. invasion and occupation of iraq?
answers: I think it is pretty obvious what is going on. I mean there are obvious implications for the region and the world.

questions: is this regime in washington substantively different from previous ones?
answers: It is useful to have some historical perspective. So let is go to the opposite end of the political spectrum the kennedy liberals about as far as you can get. In 1963 they announced a doctrine which is not very different than bush is national security strategy report or britain is new military strategy review.

questions: attack and occupation of iraq. how central is oil to u. s. strategy?
answers: It is undoubtedly central. I do not think any sane person doubts that. The gulf region is the main energy producing region of the world and for centuries has been under us control or penetrated by it. Japan for example is a major importer of us petroleum products.

questions: it also imports oil from colombia and nigeria. what do you think about all of those factors?
answers: Those are good questions. We should do some of that as well. As latin american experts we have done extensive work on these matters.

questions: a designated axis of evil state and also a country that has a lot of oil?
answers: As far as israel is concerned iraq has never been much of an issue. They consider it a kind of pushover. But iran is a different story.

questions: might not that objective reality on the ground push forces inside iran to develop nuclear weapons if they do not already have them in self defense?
answers: Very likely. The little evidence we have serious evidence indicates that the 1981 israeli bombing of the osirak reactor probably stimulated and may have initiated the iraqi nuclear development program. They were engaged in building a nuclear plant but what it was they did not know.

questions: what does the iraq war and occupation mean for the palestinians?
answers: Disasters in the making. Assad is rule is brutal and repressive but it is hardly unique in this respect. The regime is losing its grip on reality on all these fronts.

questions: no roadmaps to peace?
answers: It is interesting to read it. One of the rules of journalism i do not know exactly how it got established but it has persisted is that when you mention george bush is name in an article the headline has to speak of his vision and the article must talk about his dreams and he is the guy who brought peace to the palestinians. That is not journalism.

questions: you have described the level of public protest and resistance to the iraq war as unprecedented never before has there been so much opposition before a war began. where is that resistance going?
answers: I do not know any way to predict human affairs. It will go the same way whether we like it or not. There are many possibilities.

questions: do you see europe and east asia emerging as counterforces to u. s. power at some point?
answers: They are emerging all right. There is no doubt about that. If you go back a century in the united states there was a lively and popular labor movement which was very much opposed to the kind of business domination that was developing throughout the hemisphere.

questions: with the u. s. how are they going to pull it off?
answers: They need some kind of international force. There is no doubt about that. Just look at the history of the last 40 years in which the united states has been the world is leading supporter of terrorism.

questions: what do you say to the peace activists who labored for so long trying to prevent the invasion of iraq and who are now feeling a sense of anger and sadness?
answers: That they should be realistic. Abolitionism. How long did the struggle go on before they made any progress.

questions: and home depot is teaching people how to make safe rooms in their homes with duct tape. can you help us make sense of all of this?
answers: As far as colin powell is concerned he always was a hawk and he still is. As soon as the atrocities began to escalate and the united states was compelled to take decisive action he changed his tune. He no longer says we should not do what we are doing. Now he is saying we have to do exactly what they are saying.

questions: what if they are welcomed in iraq as the great liberators. then would it have been worth it to go in?
answers: Would we be justified in going in. There is no doubt about it. In fact it probably would have made more sense to stay put and fight. Discussion of this in the united states which should be very lively has led to some interesting conclusions.

questions: so i wonder where does this put the whole question of democracy in the united states?
answers: First of all the talk about patriotism is ridiculous. There are two kinds of patriotism: there is the kind that says you follow the orders of your leaders reflexively and you are okay with that and maybe they are not but you do what they say.

questions: he moves with uncertain pace and an estranged look. i give you the word. thus the interview begins?
answers: Concerning us foreign policy and the war on terror what is your view on the current situation. Let me start by making one thing clear i think we ought to be very cautious about using the phrase war against terror. There can not be a war.

questions: will the propaganda rebound if democracy is not established in iraq after liberation?
answers: You are right to call it propaganda. If this is a war aim why do not they say so. Why are they lying to the rest of the world about what they are trying to do.

questions: this is something different from your language conception that is free and creative. i want to know what you think about that?
answers: I think stirner is confusing language with the use of language. There is a great deal to say about this but i will not go into it.

questions: i do not t feel very comfortable in your country. what is the condition of activism in the u. s?
answers: The situation is really complicated. There are no labor based groups and there is not much labor activism. So you basically have to do what we did in england and face the fact that you are going to die if you do something about it.

questions: it seems that there is a taste for revenge in your ad?
answers: You have all sorts of different reactions i mean right after september 11 it was reported that a big proportion or a high majority of the population wanted the attack against afghanistan. Now that is not very surprising.

questions: in a text of yours you say that the world is ruled by a virtual senate. can you tell me something more about this?
answers: The term is not mine. I am borrowing it from the professional literature on international economics. The virtual Senate consists of investors and lenders most of them in the debtor countries.

questions: this is a big win for the left in the world brazil is such a big country?
answers: I have a lot of respect for lula but the problem is that he has very little space to maneuver. He does not have many options.

questions: we hope not?
answers: Lula could direct resources for internal development but unregulated capital flow can be used very effectively to undermine attempts by individual governments to introduce progressive measures. Any country trying to stimulate its economy or increase its health spending is likely to find this deviant behavior instantly punished by a flight of capital which can then be channeled to favored sectors. There is also a dynamic component to capital flight.

questions: it seems to me with a certain degree of difference that the concept of a virtual senate is similar to negri is and hardt is concept of empire.?
answers: Empire yes but i do not quite get the empire part. Empire as i see it is just a kind of formal arrangement between formal entities. If they want to disembowel each other they can do it easily.

questions: yes and the book arrives to the same conclusion as yours but through a more complicated less readable way?
answers: If people get something out of it it is okay. What i understand seems to be pretty simple and this is not a criticism. I do not see any need to say in a complicated way what you should know in an easier to understand way.

questions: do you look at foucault is work in this perspective?
answers: Fouci is an interesting case because i am sure he honestly wants to undermine power but i think with his writings he reinforced it. The only way to learn anything about contemporary culture is to deconstruct it you know try to understand what is the truth about it and why it is held in such contempt. If you can do that you will understand.

questions: do you think intellectuals should free themselves from theory from visions such as zapatistas and marcos?
answers: You could say the same about bertrand russell. I mean he did not call himself an anarchist.

questions: i was thinking of your text goals and visions and i think that sometimes it is much more important to concentrate on goals and forget the visions?
answers: You do not have to forget them there is a balance. But you have got to make sure that you are not deluding yourself. As you say sometimes the balance is right you may have a vision and at the same time the tasks are overwhelming and you need to balance them i mean literally.

questions: when you talk about the role of intellectuals you say that the first duty is to concentrate on your own country. could you explain this assertion?
answers: One of the most elementary moral truisms is that you are responsible for the anticipated consequences of your actions. It is fine to talk a good game but if you do not follow it the consequences will be terrible. I mean this is not a case about guilt by association.

questions: if we can start with us foreign policy in relation to iraq and the war on terror what do you think is going on at the moment?
answers: First of all i think we ought to be very cautious about using the phrase war against terror. There can not be a war. It is a logical impossibility because there is no international terrorism and there never was or never will be any international terrorist organization.

questions: do you think there is a possibility of preventing a war from occurring?
answers: I think that is really hard because the timing is very short. You can make it costly which is important. Even if it does not stop it is at least delaying the inevitable and escalating the cycle.

questions: people protesting against the war recently in brighton were pepper sprayed and batoned for just sitting down in a street?
answers: The more protest there is the greater the punishment. When the vietnam war protests really began to build up so did the repression. I was very close to a long jail sentence myself and it was stopped by the tet offensive a couple of months later which convinced the american business community that repression is not going to work. They turned to more violent measures.

questions: we are seeing now that like in 1990 91 they started shifting positions under the pressure because us is saying that we are going to that war and if you want any piece of the cake you would better join us.?
answers: I think i tend to agree with this if we take a short term view but in the longer term and in fact going back some distance there has been a potential rift between united states and europe.

questions: so how come then that is do the people begin to feel much more closer to iraqi people or what. why we see this opposition now?
answers: I will talk about the united states. In the 1980s when the us backed tyrant was overthrown and the threat of democracy was established there was strong opposition to his repressive regime among the general population though not by much. But since then there has been a strong increase in opposition research has shown.

questions: and i think this war in iraq whatever it does in the middle east is a bit unforeseen you know it can create a mess but one thing it will do is create an opposition in europe and when you have politicians who do not reflect public opinion in european countries then anything is possible?
answers: You are quite right about the germans. They did not foresee the success of the invasion but they were right in thinking that it would lead to a civil war. George bush likes to pretend that he is the victim of a massive propaganda campaign but if you look at the supporting documentation he does not look much different.

questions: yes but they argue that for example our hands are tied wee need the money?
answers: It is not that our brains are not working. Actually the fact that you mention neil smith is an interesting one. He is a very interesting case because he tells a totally different story.

questions: and if resistance continues sooner or later it will have some effect?
answers: I quite agree. In fact the tendency in this direction over the recent years is very positive. It is led by people like the late edward said a great hero of the civil rights movement who was a professor of linguistics at harvard.

questions: what were you doing when you when you first heard of the terrorist attacks on the united states. what was your first reaction to the news?
answers: I was working as usual. Heard about it several hours later. Reaction was the same as everyone is shock and horror.

questions: why do you think foreign policy right now is different between the united states and iraq as opposed with that of the united states and north korea?
answers: The difference is that north Korea is not sitting on the second largest oil reserves in the world and if they tried to develop them they would be wiped out by a nuclear attack. I mean if that happened nato would collapse. In contrast a unified north south Korea with all of its immense resources would dominate the region and would probably be the dominant power in northeast asia.

questions: others even suggest that you should pack up and move to another country since you believe america to be a leading terrorist state. how do you respond to such remarks?
answers: The concept anti american is an interesting one. The counterpart is used only in totalitarian states or military dictatorships something i wrote about many years ago.

questions: do you think the united states government has justified war against iraq?
answers: No. Not even close. And they know it. Just take a look at their propaganda.

questions: is there anyone in particular serving a similar role for you?
answers: There are plenty of resources but one should be cautious about guides. People have to learn to think for themselves. Otherwise we are back to totalitarianism again where the masses are defenseless and the powerful can do as they please with no interference.

questions: how do you think thomas jefferson would react to contemporary american government?
answers: With utter disgust and profound sorrow that the democratic experiment had reached such depths. We do not have to speculate. 200 years ago his friend james madison warned of something similar and he too was utterly appalled at what had happened to the country.

questions: if there is just one message you could deliver to college students at arkansas state university what would that be?
answers: Think for yourselves and observe elementary moral principles such as taking responsibility for your actions or inaction. Do not let power define you. Allow the facts to guide your choices.

questions: omar badawi faiz ahmad does the us and the rest of the world have a responsibility to change the regime in iraq and do they even have a right to do so?
answers: There is no doubt that the atrocities took place and that saddam hussein is regime is among the worst in the region. But the question is what should we do about it. The simple answer is that we should stop doing what we are doing.

questions: the argument therefore is that military action is justified?
answers: First of all the war aim in afghanistan was not to overthrow the taliban. That was an afterthought so whatever you think about it is irrelevant for the question. But even if it was there was no justification. (inaudible) what was the pretext.

questions: what would a just policy toward iraq entail in your view?
answers: I think that weapons inspectors should go back. There should be enforcement of resolution 687. the us has been trying very hard but it does not have the muscle to enforce it through the united nations. For several reasons.

questions: negroponte has stressed that the us is committed to allowing weapons inspectors to go forward. what do you think of his assessment?
answers: He knows perfectly well that it is the worst way. The bush administration has stated explicitly that they are interpreting the resolution as authorization for military action.

questions: recently they seem to be acquiescing to american demands?
answers: Frankly they are not going to stand up to the us. No one is. The entire world including the countries of the region including iran and kuwait the main victims of saddam while he was a us ally even they do not want war now they want negotiations.

questions: so then what is the relevance of the security council and the un in world affairs today?
answers: Zero. The us has made it clear that their relevance is zero no matter what happens. In fact they even said so.

questions: representatives of prime minister ariel sharon have said that israel will wait until the us has dealt with iraq before pursuing a political track with the palestinians and foreign minister benjamin netanyahu has said that us assistant secretary of state william burns road map for peace is simply not on the agenda.?
answers: We do not know if this is a joke or not but it does not take much imagination to realize that this claim is highly implausible. The road maps Sharon is referring to are the legally required guidelines for any eventual settlement of the kurdish question in the territories.

questions: is the war on terrorism a manifestation of the frankenstein syndrome meaning that the us is now having to protect itself from enemies that it has created?
answers: That is happening but let is be a little bit clearer. When the united states was attacked nicaragua had a couple of nuclear missiles. They were in the white house and the president sort of pretended not to know about them and when asked why he did not know they said well we are protecting ourselves from terrorist attacks.

questions: how much difference can popular resistance still make?
answers: It is the only thing that can stop it. Otherwise it will just continue like the old communist countries. People have to understand that there is no alternative to total destruction.

questions: do you think this war strategy has some rational logic even from an imperial perspective?
answers: Yes i think it has a logic. You are quite right it could blow up but that is always true. This is the 40th anniversary of the cuban missile crisis what khrushchev and kennedy were doing then could have destroyed the world they came pretty close did not happen.

questions: do think that opposition from ordinary citizens is stronger than it was 30 or 40 years ago?
answers: Overwhelmingly. The country is just extremely complicated. There is too much involved in the functioning of the democratic system for me to go into it here.

questions: do you think that the opposition now is strong enough to make some difference in the short term?
answers: I doubt it. I hope so but i do not think so. It is very hard.

questions: can any coalition of other states provide some kind of counterweight to u. s. power?
answers: This is an open question. But i do not see any particular signs of it. Commentary in the media often speaks glowingly of the new deal legislation as if it were the start of a new era of american politics. Well that is not entirely true though there are some important differences between the old and new deals.

questions: what do you see as the most likely scenario over the next few months?
answers: I do not have any special knowledge but i tend to go along with the military journals and military analysts who are pretty reliable. If you look at the major journals right after the war they are very serious warnings. You go back to the beginning of the month and you will find lengthy analyses of what the united states is likely to do probably within weeks.

questions: and in the middle east itself especially if israel gets involved will not their unhappy coalition with other states begin to break up?
answers: Unless the u. s. backed dictatorships in saudi arabia and the gulf can control their own populations which they may be able to. There is a tremendous amount of internal conflict in those states.

questions: and these guys in washington are willing to take that risk?
answers: It seems so.

questions: would you concede that the war produced benefits for the average afghan?
answers: I do not know if the word concede is correct and i am not sure about the standard of living of the afghans. There certainly were improvements that resulted from the overthrow of saddam hussein. But these are not things to boast about.

questions: hi noam and welcome to redeye?
answers: Good to be here. Always a pleasure talking to you.

questions: i am good thanks. can you begin by elaborating on it is characteristics?
answers: The events of sept. 11 first of all were historic. There is no doubt about that. Second the united states was alone in the world with virtually no historical precedent.

questions: the war on terrorism has opened doors a door for further militarization a further gap between rich and poor and for escalating racism. how do these things intersect?
answers: You can see them interrelated. Take the gap in food stamps. A couple of years ago one of the leading political analysts in the united states pointed out that the main domestic issue the one that really divides the american population is the lack of food stamp assistance which is a very serious problem.

questions: what do you see are the deciding forces for their progress?
answers: Well i think they have developed even more effectively after sept. 11. there was a lull for a couple of weeks people acquiesced it was not a time for activism but for reflection regret thinking things through and so on. Noam chomsky your response.

questions: how important is discussion on popular goals and vision?
answers: It is the first thing. You can not carry out any organizational activities or any direct activism unless you have some conception of what you are doing. That includes some kind of overarching vision and some very practical proposes commitments to immediate issues which they interact of course for the most part. Often these are very close to each other.

questions: it would appear that italian voters are less interested in moral issues and more interested in what they thought he could do for them?
answers: Well why do you think that is different from britain and the united states. It is because of the elite sectors. Those sectors are the ones that really matter.

questions: chooses to respond to the attacks of september 11th by escalating the cycle of violence which is most likely what bin laden and his associates hope for the consequences could be awesome. now the u. s. did?
answers: They did not.

questions: you do not think they did?
answers: Well you know there is the other possibility.

questions: but they did go into afghanistan?
answers: No no. The invasion of iraq was not an option. It is interesting that all of this is never discussed.

questions: and that is the right way?
answers: I do not doubt that. It is just that under no circumstances can i assume that what i say is correct. Maybe i can think of things that are not correct but they cannot be the truth. If you want to be a philosopher you have to have a certain level of faith.

questions: and you support that?
answers: That is what i said last september. Yes i think it is a realistic possibility.

questions: now what if i say to you bush has pursued a somewhat similar policy?
answers: On october 12th a couple of days after the bombing started bush publicly announced to the afghan people that we will continue to bomb you unless your leadership turns over to us the people whom we suspect of carrying out crimes although we refuse to give you any evidence. That is probably because they do not have any. And we dismiss without comment the offers for negotiations about extradition.

questions: you say one of the great hypocrisies here is that the united states as you say is a leading terrorist state?
answers: Well it is not a monopoly. You go back a hundred years to britain and you find it was condemned as a monopolist of terror. But what is different about the us is it has a comparative advantage.

questions: make the distinction?
answers: It is very simple. If they do it it means that they agree with the stand of the overwhelming international scientific consensus and the un as regards the great risks that global warming poses. Stop talking like that and you are off the spectrum.

questions: this is the attacks on the kurds?
answers: It goes way back. It is been going on since the 1920s when the u. s. started supporting israeli crimes in syria. And it picked up sharply under reagan.

questions: is bush justified in calling bin laden a terrorist when as you say he is running a terrorist state himself?
answers: Yeah i agree that he ought to call him a terrorist. And there is good reason.

questions: but you say even jonathan swift would be baffled at the irony of that?
answers: To say that bin laden is a terrorist a murderous terrorist is certainly correct but what about clinton. I just described one of his minor escapades in turkey. This example is particularly striking not only because of the massive atrocities but because it is the example that is followed right away by virtually the entire world including our own government and media.

questions: the israelis say there is no equivalency between suicide bombings and protecting our security and palestinians say there is no equivalence between suicide bombings and the occupation?
answers: This is the 35th year of a harsh brutal and vicious occupation supported unilaterally by the united states constant terror and atrocities. Suppose they say well we are under terrorist attack for 35 years therefore we have a right to carry out suicide attacks.

questions: which is what they say?
answers: They basically state that. So for example when the united states bombs sudan and destroys half its pharmaceutical supply that is a war crime. When iraq does it also destroys its own pharmaceutical supplies.

questions: nobody accepts this?
answers: What do you mean by that. That is the debate within linguistics. I am not part of it i assume that you do not mean what you say.

questions: so does that in your mind justify?
answers: No it does not of course not in anybody is minds. It is just like not shooting in the street if you think the person is going to shoot at you. There is plenty of justification for that kind of behaviour.

questions: it invalidates both sides?
answers: No it does not invalidate the israeli government and its prime minister but it says nothing about the palestinian authority. If you want to look at it that is okay. As long as you do not question it you can continue.

questions: was that a way of saying look people like bin laden are angry at us for good reason.?
answers: That is not what i was saying. The statement of mine that you just quoted is a very conservative statement in fact it was articulated by george bush is favorite philosopher jesus christ who famously defined the notion of a hypocrite as a person who focuses on the other fellow is crimes and refuses to look at his own.

questions: but even if he is a hypocrite?
answers: Not he everybody. Let me ask you another question. Here is an experiment. I am driving home from the store.

questions: ok but before i do not want to get gnostic here and religious?
answers: This is not religion this has nothing to do with religion. Religion has always been opposed to democracy. The prophets were condemned for anti democratic activities.

questions: but look if there is nobody pure an argument has been made sure the us has committed atrocities however they did oust a more brutal regime the taliban?
answers: That was not even a war aim why would we go for it.

questions: they did get rid of a brutal regime there was celebration?
answers: Good. Fine. Then let them bomb israel to make sure they do not do it again. Incidentally they have been supporting opposition forces which is correct as far as i understand and they should be.

questions: are you saying the taliban and the israeli government are the same?
answers: No they are not the exact same but they follow quite different paths. The goal was always to destroy the resistance. That is what they have been doing day after day.

questions: the argument that chomsky makes has no distinctions because there is a difference between the quantity and the kind of dictators that america supported and the quantity and the kind of things that went on in the communist world for 44 years.?
answers: Ok so let is take his example romania under ceausescu. Hideous regime which he forgot to tell you the united states supported. Supported right until the end as did britain. Continued to do so up to the collapse.

questions: it was not supported by the states in the 70s though?
answers: The 80s were a very complex period. There was a lot of popular activism there and there were some wins. But the state is not a political entity anymore.

questions: well what kaplan says is there is a distinction that everyone is got some blood on their hands but he says we have significantly less blood because we are soft imperialists not state terrorists?
answers: So when we supported his example ceausescu in romania right to the end that is good. How about killing several million people in vietnam in the late 1950s leaving four countries devastated beyond maybe beyond recovery.

questions: does that disqualify the us from intervening in any other way?
answers: No it does not nor would it any intervention would be disqualifying. For example if the united states was involved in a war against nicaragua nicaraguans would not be sitting in the security council. The crimes of the russians and the americans are quite apart from that.

questions: let is try to look at the bigger picture because the question he says we all agree with the gospels?
answers: Kaplan does not he certainly would not.

questions: if you leave people alone they will kill each other and that is why what you need is what he calls an organizing hegemon?
answers: Which is always us. Right and why is it our job to organize the world. In fact if we had any kind of a functioning state let is say democratic socialism it would be run by the mass of the population not just the privileged few.

questions: so if he says this is real politics that chomsky is off in another land with his gospel and he says look?
answers: Forget gospel. I am talking about the most elementary morality. If a person does not understand that they have no right to talk or write about it.

questions: he says that sometimes the end justifies the means sometimes we do a bad thing to protect our democracy and our good institutions in a just society?
answers: That is like saying that in the case of vietnam if you had a dictator who was a murderous mccarther he would do it anyway because he was protecting his democratic institutions. But in this case you have to separate the good from the bad. There is plenty to do both in and out of the political arena just as in any other arena of power.

questions: would kaplan argue that the nation state has a right to use any means necessary to protect its sovereignty?
answers: Oh then he is justifying milosevic. He was also the official in charge of atrocities in kosovo. In fact he still is.

questions: i think he would not say that?
answers: He does not want us to think that way. Look this was april the 9th.

questions: he would say that violates virtue?
answers: Oh so when they do it it is virtuous. When we violate virtue it shows our utter contempt for human life. So that is a violation of virtue in my opinion.

questions: sometimes it use unjust means in the service of just causes?
answers: There are cases where that is true. Cause after cause has brought the system to a standstill and sometimes you have to use what is called the taint of corruption.

questions: we are here to protect our policy protect the interests of our policy in this case of the americans?
answers: Was the self interest of american citizens served by slaughters in southeastern turkey or by destroying vietnam or invading afghanistan. Well those are not the issues. The issue is what is the threat to us.

questions: how do you respond to that?
answers: The violence in iraq is a serious problem for the iranians. I do not think the us has a right to ram it through.

questions: we do not have the right to even talk about it?
answers: Of course not. If you can not rise to the most elementary moral level you should not even discuss such issues. Discussion of these issues allows us to develop a better understanding of ourselves and our world. Unfortunately if we are not careful that understanding can be corrupted by power.

questions: so there is no real policy?
answers: Yes for a while there. Back in the 1980s there was a brief period when the eisenhower administration was sort of hawkish. They were concerned about what they called the increasing radicalization of the populations in latin america and the us and they needed to do something about it.

questions: but is not it a little more complicated. i mean look?
answers: That is the choice. Whether we like it or not the choices are there and i think it is important that we understand them and react to them. But let me give you another choice i will let you make your own choice about whether to have that second gas line.

questions: can not it be two rights?
answers: Let is take a look at the middle east. In the 1970s the arab states proposed a two state settlement between israel and the sunni states. Nobody cared because they are crazy.

questions: before they even recognized israel as a state though?
answers: This was to exist as an independent state within secure and recognized borders. Nobody talked about recognizing the new palestinian state nobody cared about the fact that there is a whole other country there. Look is there a possible political settlement in kosovo.

questions: did not barak put that on the table?
answers: No that is not true. In fact there is a very interesting book about it by edward herman and robert schlesinger called the shadow cabinet that was formed after the oslo meetings. I mean they were the closest thing to a cabinet of the working class in the soviet union or russia.

questions: he did not?
answers: What was also supported by the majority of the american people has just been reiterated by saudi arabia and the gulf states. So the regional states are strongly opposed to iraqi aggression. Israel however is very nervous about it.

questions: all right but let me just say arafat did not even bother putting a counter proposal on the table?
answers: Oh that is not true. I mean there was a proposal from time to time but it was never accepted. Now it is apparently not going to be any time soon.

questions: they negotiated that afterwards?
answers: That is not true. This story is just a farce. Smith is an opportunist mostly supported by the financial institutions. He had no positions on anything and everything.

questions: i guess my question is if they do not continue to negotiate?
answers: They did. That is false.

questions: that is false?
answers: Not only is it false but not a single participant in the meetings says it. The participants say it all the time and they refrained from saying anything that might suggest that the purpose was to deceive the american people or to undermine the efforts to negotiate with north korea. They did not do that because they agree with the stated goals.

questions: that arafat did not put a counter proposal..?
answers: Yeah they had a proposal. They proposed the international consensus which has been accepted by the entire world the arab states the plo. But the us refused to accept it. (inaudible) the bush administration stated explicitly that they do not accept the legitimacy of any other position than the american israeli one.

questions: if you do not talk?
answers: Yeah they did talk. That is blocked by the u. s. and europe. But they have not talked.

questions: once they walked out of camp david?
answers: They did not walk out but they left behind a trail of blood. That is what is important. What they said is we will not recognize is a final status agreement.

questions: both camps..?
answers: No no both sides walked out of camp david. Now what do they want. Well they both want a state for which they will provide the population with a measure of security. A couple of percent.

questions: all right once camp david disbands the radicals take over the process my question is how do..?
answers: No no radicals took over your process. That is a term of propaganda. This is not a question about radicalization.

questions: you do not think that the sharon the right wing israeli..?
answers: No barak stayed in power for months. Barack obama came in and did a lot of good things. But they did not have to do what was demanded.

questions: the problem that people look at now in the middle east is they say it is spun out of control because the radicals are on both sides now?
answers: No there is three sides. You are forgetting the united states. This is a product of the ideology of u. s. hegemony which has been so effective over the past generation in controlling what used to be a region.

questions: how do we get back now there is so much distrust?
answers: In the 1960s when there was a lot of distrust. You could see it at the polls. A large majority of the population felt that the government does not represent them that it represents special interests.

questions: would george bush be the war criminal. sharon would be a war criminal?
answers: They are all acting in very serious ways.

questions: would yassar arafat be a war criminal?
answers: He is a criminal but not war criminals.

questions: what is the difference?
answers: Because you knew that the missiles came from russia. And therefore you could not investigate it.

questions: would he be guilty of crimes against humanity?
answers: Probably. Minor crimes as compared with us.

questions: tony blair?
answers: Obviously. But it is often not distinguished.

questions: obviously. most leaders in the arab states?
answers: They are criminals but they follow the orders of their leaders. If they do something that is not in their interest they fire them. It is like the kurds you know they can not run their own country.

questions: someone says that is wonderful dictators love to hear that?
answers: Except that everything you just said is a total falsehood and certainly robert kaplan knows that. So in the case of say rwanda and incidentally this goes back 20 years i have just been talking about two cases.

questions: but if everybody..?
answers: Is that humanitarian intervention. No it is not. That is power politics. And the same is true of germany and lots of other places.

questions: they resent us there is enormous amounts of hatred. it goes back in history because of resentment?
answers: Yes hatred of the west. Indians were the most savage people in the world. They were carrying out horrible massacres.

questions: so the clash of civilizations is a created..?
answers: No there is no clash. Take a look at the time. There was not a word about it in the mainstream.

questions: in fact you say there is history justifying these things..?
answers: I did not say history justifies it history gives many of the reasons for it. If you want to look at lots of other reasons there are plenty of them. So part of what bernard lewis said is correct and i think it is accurate.

questions: what state does function according to what you call the minimal levels of honesty. is there a state?
answers: None that i know of. Far from it. States are for example tyrannical totalitarian institutions.

questions: but is it even possible?
answers: It is not impossible it happens. The united states for example is far more civilized than it was 40 years ago. Let is just take that.

questions: and now there is more protest and discussion?
answers: Yes because the country has gotten more civilized.

questions: so are we moving towards emancipation from these states. you are optimistic about it?
answers: Yes. Over time there has been agonizingly slow progress but very real always opposed by the states with the strong support of the corporate sector.

questions: what will the state look like at the end?
answers: I do not see how one can give a prediction. It will depend on how people act today. A lot of the organizing today is reactive.

questions: is it the end of the nation state that you foresee?
answers: I do not foresee anything.

questions: good to see you?
answers: Glad to be here. Can't complain.

questions: we will have to leave it there noam chomsky. thanks for taking the time to join us tonight?
answers: Ok. glad to be with you again.

questions: does this state of affairs reflect something new in us ambitions or are we seeing the same old imperialism dressed up in the flashy new clothes of the war on terror.?
answers: My own view is that the most important change since sept. 11 is the establishment of what look like will be permanent military bases in central asia with the us providing the necessary military and economic support.

questions: what are your concerns regarding these issues of civil rights?
answers: There are concerns. I am less concerned about them than a lot of other people are because i think there is too much resistance to it domestically. But one is certainly right to be concerned and that is to see what can be done about it.

questions: could you comment on these positions and on the challenge of maintaining fidelity to one is ideals and convictions in your case anarchist and libertarian socialist while fighting practical battles in the real world to as you have said before widen the floor of the cage.?
answers: First of all i do not see any conflict. It seems to me the general principal is you say what you believe. Keep true to your beliefs. There are no rules of political action.

questions: you held yourself responsible for taking certain measures and actions regarding the role of your country and expected others to do the same. is it true?
answers: It is definitely true. I did not expect others in fact most of the people in this room did but we expected it ourselves and it was correct. One has to understand the nature of our society and the society in which we happen to live.

questions: if you use drugs the ads said you support terrorism. what is your take on this?
answers: Terrorism is now being used pretty much the same way communism was used. If we want to stop terrorism we have to oppose terrorism and that means opposing the policies that are increasing terrorism including the ones you mention. Now there are several quite serious terrorist attacks every year in the united states almost exclusively by radical Islamists all over the world.

questions: as an anarchist i assume it is fair to call you that what is your take on libertarianism?
answers: The term libertarian as used in the us means something quite different from what it meant historically and still means in other countries. Historically the libertarian movement has been the anti statist wing of the socialist movement. Socialist anarchism was libertarian socialism. As socialism developed libertarian socialist tendencies developed within it.

questions: what should be done about drug use and the drug trade?
answers: I agree with rand. It is a problem. Cocaine is not good for you or anyone else. Alcohol is worse.

questions: why do you believe it was unlawful for the united states to fight back against a foreign attacker?
answers: It would not have been unlawful if it were an armed attack. It is unlawful to carry out an act which will probably bring about the death of many human beings in the not very distant future if we do not deal effectively with the climate change threat. Unlawful as in war for example unless there is a declaration of war.

questions: they did fight back though. they went after al qaeda did not they?
answers: Well first of all they never claimed responsibility for the attacks. But secondly international law does not permit that. Under the principles of anticipatory self-defense that is when you have legal grounds you can act in accordance with your legal obligation to defend yourself.

questions: but what is self defense if not retaliation. if you expect another attack to come?
answers: If the united states is being bombed let is say it can fight back instantly notify the security council ask them to act and defend itself until help arrives. It does not have to wait for authorization from the world court though.

questions: it was bombed?
answers: Yeah take a look at the minute hand. It is after midnight and the bombing has just started. So two minutes to midnight there is an attack.

questions: if the russians had sent two missiles against new york instead of al qaeda?
answers: They could have.

questions: then you could retaliate?
answers: Sure you can.

questions: the us said they knew that they came from al qaeda and the taliban?
answers: No that is not true. They guessed it. Now they do not know but they would have a good guess now.

questions: but it was right was not it?
answers: We do not know whether ricardians were right in thinking that the moon was made out of green cheese. It does not make any difference.

questions: well bin laden has said he did it?
answers: That is one of the most astonishing fabrications that i have ever seen. First of all the fact that he said afterwards that it was the united states which provided the means and the encouragement which is beyond dispute he knows perfectly well no one else knows that.

questions: because he calculated in advance the number of casualties from the enemy who would be killed based on the position of the tower?
answers: Which means that he took credit for it several months later. If someone takes credit a month later it is not proof of guilt. Maybe they made a mistake but it was not evidence of anything.

questions: the security council expressed readiness to take all necessary steps to respond?
answers: Readiness. But it did not authorize the use of force. So therefore we do not have to bomb saudi arabia is there a justification for us to use force to prevent them from attacking egypt. Well there is none except that they are trying to destroy us.

questions: the us believes that it was in the position of somebody who wakes up in the middle of the night finds a man standing over him with a hammer and you would like them to approach the police bring out the police and ask the man with the hammer to wait while they do it?
answers: No no i am sorry. That is not the way it works. You can defend yourself against the person with power.

questions: they will wait while you do it?
answers: No excuse me you keep defending yourself from the ongoing attack. You call the police you ask them to take over. If you think you know who carried out the attack you find evidence and present it to a grand jury you present evidence that the person who did it is still at large and they make an example of him or her and whoever else may be involved.

questions: the world did not object to it did it?
answers: Well if the leading mafia don in town wants to pick somebody up he does not get a court order. He just sends his goon squad out and they pick him up and nobody objects because they are afraid. That is the international law of the sea we are not bound by it.

questions: he stopped he thought he consulted he attempted to build an international consensus. what was wrong with that?
answers: Was it right to act in violation of law to just attack. Well i think the case is very clear to anybody who is paid attention to international affairs for at least the last thirty years or so. I mean ninety percent of scholarship international relations and political science has been appalled by what the united states has done in iraq.

questions: attack in self defense is not the case which you do not accept?
answers: Nor do you.

questions: how do you know?
answers: Well let is try it. Look here.

questions: it does not matter what i think?
answers: Well let is try it. I am going to read you a passage from david halberstam is new book.

questions: this is a comparable situation is it?
answers: No it is much worse. That is why labour market flexibility has been a high priority for the united states and europe since the 1970s.

questions: so why are we talking about it if it is not a comparable situation?
answers: There is nothing comparable. The occupy movement did not come out of nowhere. It was a tactic.

questions: it does not matter whether i think it does we are asking for your views?
answers: My views are of no relevance to this discussion. Whether he should be allowed to speak or not. Opinions vary widely.

questions: a sufficient number of people did think it was all right?
answers: No. Nobody thought it would be right for nicaragua to set off bombs in washington. But suppose that sanders won which is pretty unlikely in a system of bought elections that is what would happen i think.

questions: you say there is been virtually no discussion of the option of adhering to the rule of law?
answers: Exactly and that makes perfect sense if you follow my argument. You have to admire the intellectual honesty of lenin and trotsky when they said what they believed and i think they are quite justified in saying what many others believe including the governments of britain and the united states.

questions: why would there be no discussion. there is been endless discussion?
answers: That is because the u. s. media are owned and controlled by big business.

questions: by human rights groups in europe by the media by all kinds of organizations?
answers: On a very narrow tactical issue important one but narrow. Initially in mid september the rhetoric appeared to indicate that the us was planning a massive military attack.

questions: that is my point?
answers: But it is often not distinguished. If you criticize state policy you are not criticizing a country.

questions: but that is about whether it was right to?
answers: No no. I think it is wrong.

questions: that was the discussion in europe?
answers: It was not discussed in the u. s. though it would have been interesting to hear it. Discussion of such matters is not on the agenda in elite circles so there is little that one can say beyond what is commonly believed even in highly educated circles even mainstream scholarship.

questions: the media was full of discussion programs?
answers: Excuse me the discussion was not about the following question shall we go to the security council get a resolution explicitly authorizing an action which will identify the criminals who were unknown find evidence call for their extradition and if they are not brought to justice use force to apprehend them. There was virtually no discussion about that and you know that perfectly well. After all this is a crucial vote.

questions: you said when ira bombs were set off in london there was no call to bomb west belfast?
answers: Nor did the british or the us. If they had called it off they would have been instantly blamed for terrorism. Iran has a terrible human rights record nothing to be ashamed of.

questions: why would britain attack part of britain part of the united kingdom?
answers: Excuse me because west belfast was the place where the bombing was originating <

questions: they were a part of the united kingdom?
answers: Makes no difference.

questions: does not it?
answers: Yeah i don't know. There is some creative element at the core of language too.

questions: the difference is that the attack on london for instance was coming from inside the united kingdom?
answers: Fine. If you do not like the case of west belfast let is take the other case i mentioned boston. Here there was no call to destroy the press.

questions: there is no call to bomb saudi arabia is there if we accept that saudi arabia provided financing to al qaeda?
answers: Suppose the british discovered as they have in fact that some of the people involved in ira bombing are in the united states. Do they bomb them. No they do it through the middle east as it were.

questions: why would you take him at his word. you never take anybody at their word?
answers: Two points. First of all i often take people attheir word including governments at least people who are around me including my own colleagues at princeton and others who i think are honest and decent people. Sometimes they are not. Second i sometimes take them attheir word even though they do not always agree with what i believe.

questions: not the us government?
answers: No it is the private sector. And the reason is they do not have to work through the government. A lot of the privatized health care system is co managed.

questions: what about bin laden?
answers: In the case of bin Laden and his network it is very striking that they did not react with violence until the very end. There was overwhelming international support for them at the time when they launched the attacks on september 11th.

questions: you said it was entirely possible he was telling the truth when he says he did not know about the operations?
answers: Totally possible. In fact the book he is writing he knows perfectly well that this was a major operation which may have been the biggest terrorist act of the century. And it is hard to see how anyone could possibly object to that fact.

questions: you take him at his word and then compare it to the us compare it to brzezinski?
answers: Yes for a simple reason. See i believe in elementary moral principles namely if we apply some standard to someone else it applies to us too. So if i apply the law to you i have the same standard no matter what you are doing.

questions: but you have not compared like with like have not you?
answers: These comparisons do not exist. Like i said i was in india for a month and a half and did not see a single factory floor. There were some things i saw in towns and villages but nothing like what i have seen in the united states or canada.

questions: bin laden is comparable to brzezinski?
answers: No no. That is just a total non sequitur. In the case in point each of these people is taking credit for an action that was carried out independently of the other.

questions: you accept his motives do not you?
answers: There is nothing more neoliberal than the consumer swiss writer adolf muschg once noted. But the term neoliberal is a bit misleading. It has a meaning in international economics but primarily in the doctrinal system that is the ideological underpinnings of policy formation.

questions: bin laden is declared motives?
answers: Declaration of motives usually has a technical meaning. In this case it is a way of saying that what the united states is doing is illegal under international law. That is usually taken to be the foundation of a case for war. But there are many technicalities that make it almost impossible to give a legal basis for the action.

questions: he and his network are intent on supporting muslims defending themselves against infidels?
answers: Excuse me you are misreading crucially. I say that he like every other gangster in history calls whatever action they carry out defensive. So he describes himself as defending musl Muslims just the way hitler described himself justifying the german invasions as defense against the jews and so on.

questions: so the us is not an innocent victim according to you?
answers: There are no innocent victims. Victim states are bound by the principles of universality and humanitarian intervention. The crimes of the powerful are not exempt from these principles.

questions: it is a guilty victim. it is a guilty victim?
answers: But why. That is just internal to american society. There is no moral outrage about it. Hans morgenthau would have been hanged for that if it were not for the fact that the target was a jewish community center.

questions: they had this coming to them?
answers: No no. That is just a technique of indoctrination. It is like getting students to think that the government is our enemy. I mean you want them to be frightened of people like us.

questions: that is the inference people get from reading what you have said?
answers: If they are totally irrational maybe they should not read what i have to say. But if you look at the evidence both the linguistic evidence and the historical record both agree that what we call anglo saxon is a very small sector of the english speaking world an insignificant sector. I mean there was a million and a half people in that country in the late nineteenth century.

questions: a lot of irrational people out there?
answers: I do not want to deny that there are people who are totally irrational. If you look at the record for example the people involved in 9 11 were not crooks.

questions: but you seem to see this moral equivalence?
answers: There is no such moral equivocation.

questions: between bin laden and bush do not you?
answers: There is a difference. In many ways they are pretty much the same person. The most striking difference is their style of dealing with the world.

questions: you say there are plenty of bin ladens on both sides?
answers: Between the two of us who is more knowledgeable, me or you.

questions: that is moral equivalence. that is a polemic is not it?
answers: There is no such notion. There are many different dimensions and criteria.

questions: but why when the us is considering what to do about this do you always go back to past crimes?
answers: Not past. Present. Right at this moment. So for example if we were serious we would not be sitting here talking about the crimes of the past several decades.

questions: you mentioned nicaragua?
answers: I mentioned that because it is uncontroversial. Since there is a world court security council resolution since it has been officially recognized since the mid 1970s there has not been a problem for the united states to ram it through.

questions: are you kicking the us when it is down?
answers: No. I am asking that we accept the definition of hypocrite given in the gospels and look the other way as they are doing it.

questions: to what aim do you do this. to what aim do you wish to point this out?
