answers: Because i think we should try to rise to the level of minimal moral integrity. Once we can rise above the superficiality of everyday life and recognize that our actions have consequences others will follow not just us. So let is not trivialize the moral issue but move towards a more profound understanding of it.ock timidity and passivity are not conducive to moving towards deeper understanding.

questions: fred halliday who is professor of international relations at the lse he says that you overestimate us power and underestimate a public shift in attitudes and debate on human rights in the last ten years. do you accept that?
answers: Well i read the article. He did not give any evidence so i can not comment. But i have emphasized repeatedly the growth and complexity of the human right crisis and the unwillingness of policy makers to take any meaningful action about it unless it is accompanied by a substantial increase in support from wealthy sectors.

questions: do you overestimate us responsibility for everything that goes wrong?
answers: In the case of vietnam years after kennedy is invasion liberal doves began to say that the us is at fault for large parts of the tragedy in indochina. But that still leaves the question of where the blame should be placed. How should one put it exactly.

questions: there are third world regimes that are oppressive and not controlled by america?
answers: Suppose i tell you that you are overestimating british responsibility. You can not answer that. What is the evidence. From what i have seen in the middle east and in africa it is well documented that the united states is directly responsible for at least 40 percent of the deaths that result from the counterinsurgency operations that it has supported throughout the world.

questions: fred halliday is not a serious person?
answers: If i were to say anything mildly negative about france it would be that it has some of the features of totalitarianism and maybe one or two of its defects. But it is functioning within a system that is quite democratic in fact freer in many respects than europe. I mean it does have defects but they are not major ones.

questions: food and agricultural organization had warned that over seven million people would face starvation in afghanistan if military action was initiated?
answers: I did not know that much back then but i remember reading it. I am pretty much out of popular culture altogether.

questions: but you give the impression that the bombing alone would endanger the lives of seven million people?
answers: I did not give that impression at all. What i said is that before the attack there were according to un estimates about five million refugees in iraq. Half of them are children the rest are women and children every one of these refugees would be killed if the war had continued on its current course. No sane person would want to risk that.

questions: well the effects according to oxfam are that for some the dangers have receded for others they have got worse?
answers: Exactly. And that is a pretty serious indictment of the neoliberal assault on the world is population in the last generation which you can easily see in its devastating effects in countries like greece and Portugal and Spain and others.

questions: it is a mixed and complex picture?
answers: Let is first establish the fact which is elementary that whatever the consequences are and they are important they do not justify violent acts. Furthermore even if they were there would not be justification. For example if vietnam had been attacked in 1962 rockefeller would have been hanged not darwin.

questions: it is happened in many it is happened over kosovo it is happened over the balkans?
answers: Excuse me that is someone else is crimes. You investigate laser like other people are crimes but you do not investigate your own. If you have internal documents you can see what the reasons are but they are not made public.

questions: the war crimes tribunal in the hague looked at investigating nato and its actions in kosovo?
answers: For a few days. And you notice what happened. Carla del ponte brought it up for about a week.

questions: as louise arbour had been warned before her?
answers: You better not do it and they backed off immediately. That is standard procedure under ceausescu and heidari. You do not say anything about the human rights violations or about nato expansion and the arab spring that they supported.

questions: why do you say they backed off immediately. she said there was not a case to?
answers: That is backing off. The united states insisted that they had to make a decision and she made it clear that the decision was made in the middle of the assault.

questions: that is saying there is not a case to. it is not necessarily caving into pressure is it?
answers: Really. I mean it does not matter whether it was right or wrong. Just think about it.

questions: that is bombast is not it?
answers: What did he mean by that. I checked. He did not say that he thinks we are going to bomb boston. Suppose he does.

questions: to your satisfaction?
answers: They did not do it period. They said they are reviewing it.

questions: because we are running out of time i just want to ask you what you think your questioning has achieved what do you think you have achieved?
answers: Well look i mean i do not attribute it to myself of course but in the united states and wherever i have been well let is take this country. The country has become more civilized largely as a result of the disillusionment with the political system and the fear of democracy which is quite high. And i think this can continue.

questions: you are encouraged by this?
answers: Yeah i think it is a sign of the increased civilization of our society. Just as the human rights culture in the west is now coming into its own. I mean did you ever study for an exam in canada or something and they asked you to talk about freedom.

questions: so is not as bleak as you thought it was?
answers: What did i do to make it worse. Look i have done nothing to undermine the credibility of the journal. I reviewed some things that it had published and in fact linked to them and so on. No such action was taken against the mit report.

questions: what did you make of the speech in particular?
answers: We are gonna drive evil from the world.

questions: evil the words war you are quite right with us or against us hijacking islam?
answers: Well it was interesting. I mean i happened to be in india shortly after that and just for fun was reading the old indian epics you know from 1500 bc very similar. The incarnation of vishnu the god comes down to earth and he is going to drive evil from the world that is his task on earth just as the sun goes down in the sky.

questions: so what has it done to the middle east?
answers: It is frightened everybody of course. People are scared and rightly. But what is happened is an attack on the general population. A functioning democracy is not something that is easily taken for granted in a society dominated by huge corporations.

questions: professor given the political scenarios that you are talking about now what do you make of those that argue that we now face a clash of civilizations between the west and islam?
answers: There is no need to dwell on it. The statement is ludicrous and the comment illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. I am very critical of the politicization of science and in particular the tendency to assume that science has a liberal bias which it does not sometimes.

questions: but should the west fear islam now?
answers: Excuse me should we fear the catholic church. In the 1980s when the us was condemned for international terrorism what did the church do about it. It went underground.

questions: so looking at us foreign policy today the foreign policy which says we will fight terrorism and we are now at war with any country that harbors terrorism what are the implications of that do you think?
answers: Well first of all the phrase terrorism is used in quite different ways. For example hitchens i do not know hari is smart enough to know that us policies are increasing the threat of terrorism. Hitchen is comment is perfectly accurate.

questions: do you think to ordinary people in america the message is actually getting through about american hypocrisy?
answers: Oh i think it has been for a long time. I mean it is kinda hard to judge cause there is not much evidence but i suspect over a longer period of time it will become more obvious. Now i do not think you can draw any hard and fast conclusions.

questions: but is america winning or is the white house winning the propaganda war then?
answers: I do not watch television much but i was in india for a month or so and was compelled to watch cnn and bbc to get the news. Every time you looked at the clock in the morning the tv channels were on cable.

questions: if we accept this notion of gross american hypocrisy?
answers: America is by far the freest country on earth. It is also the most anti socialist country in the world. The us is britain is leading example.

questions: western hypocrisy there still remains the problem of this particular brand of terrorism?
answers: That is right.

questions: what do you make then of the way the media some in the media interpret the administration attention between hawks and doves between crudely colin powell on the one hand and donald rumsfeld on the other?
answers: There is a traditional hawk dove distinction. So for example during the vietnam war the hawk said let is just wipe the place out. In fact you still read that today even though polls show most people regarded the war as just a mistake.

questions: to go back specifically to the middle east because having been there and talking to islamic academics they talk about western hypocrisy in the middle east and they talk again and again about israel in what ways do you think the western world has been hypocritical in recent history in the middle east?
answers: Well let is start with the united states. It is not that the isles are uninteresting places. There is something interesting about eastern europe which has an extraordinary culture and you go and see it if you like.

questions: do you think there will be an end to this war on terror the way the americans and the west generally are going?
answers: Well we have to be a little careful. If there are negotiations they have a better chance of success if they follow the format of the arab league peace negotiations.

questions: in your public comments after sept. were you implying that we brought this on ourselves?
answers: Of course not. That is idiotic.

questions: that was not your intention?
answers: Nobody could possibly interpret it that way. Look this is a horrendous atrocity but unfortunately the toll is not unusual. And that is just a plain fact about life in a brutal society like ours.

questions: were you surprised by how people commonly interpreted your statement?
answers: No not at all. I expect the intellectual classes to behave exactly like that. That is their historical role to support state violence and defame people who try to bring up moral truisms in the service of state power.

questions: you do not think that your statements downplayed what happened on sept. 11?
answers: By saying that this was a horrendous atrocity committed with wickedness and awesome cruelty but we should understand that the toll is regrettably not unusual. What is unusual is the direction in which the guns were pointing. I think we ought to be honest enough to realize that.

questions: you have said repeatedly that the united states is a leading terrorist state. what is your definition of terrorism?
answers: My definition is taken from the u. s. code which seems to me sufficiently broad so that it encompasses a lot of different crimes but not the usual ones that are listed. So for example hijacking planes actually falls within the amaq charter.

questions: do you distinguish between different kinds of terrorism and if so how?
answers: There are various kinds. For example there is the kind that you and i engage in reflexively. So if some far right wing fanatic says we ought to kill all jews we are going to do it. That is terrorism by another name.

questions: how do you distinguish between what you consider u. s. terrorism and al qaida is terrorism on sept. 11?
answers: There is a difference. In the case of israel it is much worse than terrorism by a long shot and saddam hussein is not far behind in that regard.

questions: how do you think both cases should be addressed?
answers: Nicaragua dealt with the problem of terrorism in exactly the right way. It followed international law and treaty obligations insofar as they did not conflict with its expansion of jurisdiction.

questions: and al qaida?
answers: In the case of something as lethal as terrorism it is very hard to say what the right approach is. You have to look at the circumstances the state of the society the degree of support the level of indoctrination. What you will find is that it tends to be pretty brutal and brutal societies.

questions: do you think that american force is justified in the case of self defense?
answers: Sure anybody is entitled to defend themselves from terrorist attacks. There is no doubt about that. A self defence claim is a very strong one and the burden of proof for any resort to force should be very heavy.

questions: so you do not think our war in afghanistan is an example of self defense?
answers: Is the united states under an armed attack.

questions: i would think so?
answers: Article 51 is very explicit and i believe it is correct. It says force can be used in self defense against armed attack. If we are under armed assault let is take the u. s. armed attacks against cuba.

questions: what would motivate the u. s. to do this?
answers: My speculation is that the intention is to establish a leadership position in the region that will be able to constrain and modify the actions and policies of the reagan administration in response to the increasingly assertive and aggressive behavior of russia and china.

questions: why do you think that the attack on sept. 11 was not an armed attack on our country?
answers: First of all the united states itself does not claim responsibility for an attack. It claims it did because a few days earlier a state department official said that they think it was an inside job and nobody knows where it came from or when it started. But the fact of the matter is that no sane person pays the slightest attention to such trivialities.

questions: you have to currently be under attack and you do not think we are?
answers: Yes armed attack is ongoing overwhelming attack. But my opinion does not really matter because the world is ruled by a virtual senate. Any sensible person knows that the only thing that matters is your own self interest and that happens to include the threat and use of violence if you feel like it but of course not in any serious sense.

questions: is there anything about the islamic threat we have heard so much about their hatred of the west that requires our intervention and use of force?
answers: I would not exactly put it past washington to carry out a large scale invasion of iraq. It would have to be very carefully thought out and undertaken. There is a great deal to say about that also about el salvador which has received a fair amount of attention. But i do not think it is relevant for our purposes here.

questions: but you do not think that the threat from the extremists in the islamic world justifies our use of force?
answers: No of course not. In fact our strong support for isil goes way back. Just take say the us invasion of iraq in 1980.

questions: s. force to disable these violent extremists is not justified?
answers: I thought michael howard is proposal was quite reasonable and that could very well have involved the use of force. If you have criminal atrocities it is legitimate to use violence to apprehend those who are guilty and give them a fair trial. Incidentally notice that nobody including you and me believes that that principle should apply to us.

questions: you endorse a criminal pursuit of bin laden and his cohorts but why do not you do not believe that the war in afghanistan is justified in the wake of sept. 11?
answers: Two points. One is that i think the invasion was illegal under the un charter. The foundation of modern international law is the papal letter banning the threat or use of force in international affairs.

questions: can you give an example of a situation where military force is justified?
answers: Force was justified when japan bombed pearl harbor and germany declared war against us. If you try to think of the last 50 years have there been military interventions which really did bring massive atrocities to an end. There are actually two cases both in the 1970s.

questions: so you do think that violence can bring peace?
answers: Yes i think it can. For example the peace movement did not just come out of nowhere. It was going on since the second world war.

questions: do you not think that we are under the same sort of threat now?
answers: We under a threat. No nothing remotely like it. Now if you want to build a monument to yourself in effigy on the hill you can just as well build it in honor of the thousands of people who have been killed in the past three years or the number of terrorist attacks that have taken place in which at least five people were killed.

questions: what can or should be done about someone like saddam hussein someone who has access to weapons of mass destruction?
answers: He is of course a monster in the eyes of the united states and its allies though not as much a threat as some of their more extreme clients. His is the only existing functioning state that used weapons including chemical warfare against its own population in violation of a firm pledge to the world court by the american signed charter.

questions: does that mean we should not go after him now?
answers: Wait a minute. That is not a small point. He carried out a huge a massacre of his own population with our support right through the end. Now let is take a look and see just how much responsibility he bears for what happened.

questions: what should we say?
answers: We should say yeah we supported him in his worst atrocities now we do not like him anymore and what is the worst case scenario we can think of. Now that is a very narrow category. Let is go back a stage.

questions: so how would you feel about it if we were to continue the war on terrorism there?
answers: There should be no war against terrorism. In fact go back to the beginning. The united states was condemned for international terrorism when it carried out an air campaign against the taliban in the 1980s.

questions: but do you think that we should move against iraq now?
answers: No i agree with virtually the whole world including our closest allies that a military solution is the only realistic one. Now there is a question of when and why. Is there a right time to act.

questions: it seems like one of your main complaints is against american rhetoric and propaganda?
answers: If we were honest then we could at least evaluate what we do sanely. We are not. By comparative standards however america is not that far below the rest of the world in terms of scale of violence perpetrated aggression and violation of fundamental human rights just as israel. Sooner or later it is bound to have those characteristics.

questions: foreign policy always narrowly serves our national self interest?
answers: No i do not think it should. I think that our primary interest ought to be the welfare of our own society. And any external constraint that impairs that is illegitimate.

questions: do you think foreign interventions might ever be driven by a mixed bag of motivations?
answers: Sure every atrocity in history including hitler is invasions and the japanese conquests was an attempt to get what they wanted. Why should it be any different for us. After all we are a very free country just take a look at our crimes.

questions: is it your position that we are driven by imperial designs?
answers: No more than any other country.

questions: what would our imperial interest have been in kosovo then?
answers: I take the official reasons very seriously. I tend to be rather literal i assume people are telling the truth. In the case of indonesia the reasons went back to the united states taking advantage of its comparative advantage in military force and economic might to prevent what it hoped would be a violent takeover by a client state.

questions: but milosevic had already carried out ethnic cleansing in other regions of yugoslavia before kosovo and he was pressuring the albanian population in kosovo so the threat and intention was clearly there?
answers: Well yes but there is a very detailed record of this. The state department has presented extensive documentation as has nato the kurdish leadership and so on. There were plenty of atrocities going on before the bombing.

questions: if the west had not intervened milosevic could have carried on with his atrocities unmolested?
answers: In kosovo right before the bombing there were two positions on the table. One was the nato position the other was serbian prime minister albaniak. They both called for an international presence there but they differed on what that should be.

questions: could not nato have been basing its actions on what we would all seen milosevic was capable of in bosnia and croatia?
answers: They could have. But by that argument if you really believe that then they should have supported the somoza regime which was pretty much a model for what was to come. And obama very consciously and in fact publicly supported that which is why bosnian refugees are coming over the border presumably.

questions: what role is the world is superpower supposed to play?
answers: The first simplest role it should play is to stop participating in atrocities.

questions: s. does it is unacceptable simply because the u. s. is doing it?
answers: If people believe that that is because they insist on pure propaganda and refuse to look at the facts. There are simple facts about the matter the united states is not involved at all in kosovo.

questions: what do you think about the future of the american left?
answers: I do not know enough to be able to answer with any confidence but i suspect that in some respects the situation is somewhat better than it was. There are some marginal exceptions. One is that there is less self censorship.

questions: but are there any enforcement actions that the un might have taken in response to september 11 that would have been both legal and just?
answers: It is true enough that there is no enforcement of international law. But it does not follow that it was the unilateral decision of the united states to invade afghanistan.

questions: supported various opposition groups who failed miserably in their efforts to depose saddam.?
answers: Let is begin by recalling principle we can reach our own judgments about this but they have no force unless a long chain of missing argument is filled in somehow. That aside were the proposals of afghans as to how to eliminate the taliban regime feasible. First it was not just rawa.

questions: why have you decided to participate in the wsf. what do you think of it?
answers: Two meetings are taking place pretty much at same time. One is the davos meeting of the world social forum a few days a week the other is a forum in buenos aires that i organized a year ago. Both of them are important but the israeli initiative is more important.

questions: does it have a real chance of challenging the financial and multinational corporations power?
answers: The so called anti globalization movement which has been around for a long time is predicated on the idea that there should be no free trade agreements. That is a total fabrication. For example nafta was not even an agreement among the countries of the rich and the powerful.

questions: what kind of contribution can the world social forum give to this hope of a peaceful world?
answers: The us intelligence agencies have recently published their projections for the coming years. They predict that globalization meaning the particular form of neoliberal economic integration favored by centers of power will continue leading to growing inequality and increased financial volatility as a result of financial manipulations by financial institutions.

questions: is it possible to organize the complex and diverse scenario of the so call anti globalization forces?
answers: You are quite right to call them opponents of neoliberal globalization that is of a particular form of international economic integration that the masters of mankind have designed in their own interests with the interests of their domestic populations incidental. And of course the populations do not like it but they have to make do with what is available.

questions: is there a way to detect and stop terrorism in anti u. s. reactions?
answers: It is always important to look carefully at how questions are formulated whether in the sciences or inquiry into human affairs. One often finds hidden assumptions that should be unearthed critically analyzed and often rejected. When that essential preliminary task is undertaken we often find that the questions cannot be answered and should therefore be recast. If we are serious we also have to ask some questions about the backgrounds.

questions: don t you think that the events of the social forum and seattle with the mobilization of thousands of people are a proof that people are capable to make up their own minds independently?
answers: I have never said and i do not believe that public opinion is anything like an independent source of information. People have a range of opinions and opinions often express themselves in very different ways and in different social and economic circumstances.

questions: but your political opinions are classified by many critics as anti american and dominated by conspiratory theories. what do you think about that?
answers: It is very easy to produce slanders and a waste of time to repeat or respond to them. If there are arguments i will be happy to listen. The comment about linguistics if it was indeed made is simply childish meriting no response.

questions: in 1996 you advocated the suspension of payment of the brazilian foreign debt. what is your position today about brazil?
answers: As soon as the terms were changed in 1998 a new proposal was presented which is approximately the same as before except that now it is presented as a proposal for negotiations and not as an ultimatum. You may call it a capitulation to the demands of latin american leaders.

questions: do you believe that the government of the rich countries would try to make things difficult for a leftist government in brazil?
answers: If history is any guide that is a virtual certainty unless they feel that they can constrain the actions of a government with a populist orientation by other means. Tactics do vary in this regard. There are interesting historical examples right in latin america.

questions: to what point is this initiative discouraging people to participate on this politics process?
answers: A major thrust of neoliberalism is to undermine democracy. It has been understood for at least 60 years that financial liberalization undermines the possibility of democratic choice by creating a virtual parliament of lenders and investors who have veto power over government decisions.

questions: has there ever existed a country both socialistic and democratic?
answers: I doubt that anyone thinks that a particular form of social organization is the solution to national disasters all around the globe. These are many and various the causes are diverse and there are lots of different paths that should be explored sometimes followed towards ameliorating or overcoming them. Democratic socialism is not a simple concept.

questions: could you please point the major tendencies that are already underway and explain why we are at risk?
answers: Well we have two choices. We can be complacent watch as these things develop and see them succeed and then try to reverse course when they do not succeed just as the tobacco companies tried to do. Or if we want to take a more active part intervene and stop them. There is no simple answer to that question.

questions: s. what are the most significant effects of this strategy?
answers: Actually i do not think it is that complicated. You just have to remember to look at the facts. The united states for 35 years has been trying to strangle cuba economically and politically.

questions: how have international relations changed since september 11?
answers: First of all the scale was not that different. For example albania and mexico reacted the same way. They ejected the us ambassador.

questions: did the world change after september 11th. for worse or for better in your opinion. why?
answers: First of all the scale was not changed. It is been estimated correctly that about half the population of the globe lived in areas that were under attack. More accurately it was probably closer to two thirds. 2 billion people were literally at risk.

questions: are there new forces to oppose the hegemony of the united states in the world and to rebuild a similar picture to that it behind had ten years with the ussr?
answers: As there were during the cold war. There are of course some differences. The soviet union had a hand in it in ways that are not lost on anyone who remembers the history of imperialism. But in many ways the u. s. is pretty much the same as it was thirty years ago at most with some marginal differences but the picture is very much like today.

questions: do you feel that the us is now looking at a different foreign policy. do you see possible positive changes?
answers: It is misleading to state that i am the one who makes that statement. The statement is a misrepresentation of my position.

questions: do you think that this kind of military action will be efficient against terrorism?
answers: A few elementary facts seem relevant. The war against lebanon and gaza was declared actually re declared by the one state in the world that has been condemned for international terrorism and supported by major terrorist states like russia and china its close ally saudi arabia even though they are far from any serious threat. Only the u. s. has that right.

questions: what has changed in the way usa conduct their external conflicts in the last years?
answers: There were of course some changes with the collapse of the second superpower. That led to readjustment in tactics and new pretexts but not to major changes in policy. As always there are internal factors that impel us policy towards the most extreme forms of violence and repression. One of them is the us refusal to permit any form of democratic change.

questions: how should the world react to the international terrorism?
answers: There is no doubt that terrorism is a serious problem which has been faced by modern societies for a long time. And it is hardly a new phenomenon. Just take the us which is responsible for the worst crimes since the second world war up until september 11th.

questions: which economic interests lay behind the north american antiterrorist campaign?
answers: Remember that the war on terrorism was declared 20 years ago by the reagan administration in much the same terms as its renewal in sept. 2001 and with far more justification. The reasons have to do with the nature of the society and the priorities of power within it.

questions: is your evaluation that the warlike actions of the united states should continue due to the bush relations with this industrial sector?
answers: There are many factors as always. One factor is the relationship with the israeli lobby. Another is their veto at the un security council.

questions: bush the right man at the right time as recent popular polls say he is?
answers: The question presupposes that the us is in favor of overthrowing saddam. If that were the case then bush would be a hero. Popular opinion in the region is strongly opposed to aggression and atrocities and the evidence for that can be overwhelming.

questions: how do you see the democratization wave. what is this democracy. this is leading us to where?
answers: I see it pretty much the way the general public in the us and latin america in general are seeing it. Polls show desire for democracy but steady reduction in faith in what are called democratic institutions. That has been true here for a long time even before the current economic crisis which is quite striking in fact worldwide.

questions: what can be the outcome of this story and what could happen to the neighbor countries such as brazil?
answers: As to where the money is the question surely merits investigation and i think we can make a fair guess at the answer. As i mentioned over the years capital flight from latin america has often been on the order of the so called debt.

questions: considering america is veto power is there today any viable alternative or any chance for the economies struggling to become independent?
answers: On mexico there is no need to rely on my assessment. One expert assessment was produced by the economic policy institute a highly regarded research institute in washington in a study investigating the effects of nafta on working people and the effect on the american economy.

questions: how do you relate the politics of the state of israel with the wider politics of the current imperialistic globalization?
answers: There are many similarities. In many respects it is a more free and open society than it was 40 years ago. There is more popular expression of opinion and protest than at any time i can remember.

questions: professor is there a possibility for a new world. how can we reach there?
answers: It is a question of whether the human species is going to survive. And whether it will even survive is anybody's guess. A couple of thousand years ago there was a period when there were maybe two or three people on this planet.

questions: how do you analyse the state of control by punishment which is producing an imprisonment of millions of people in the contemporary societies?
answers: One has to look at specific cases. Take the us. 20 years ago if you had asked me whether i thought we were going to have a serious drug problem i would have said you are crazy. But things have changed.

questions: are spiritualism and materialism categories able to explain something?
answers: It always makes sense in my opinion to adopt gramsci is famous slogan which he borrowed from romain rolland and constantly reiterated we should have pessimism of the intellect and optimism of love. The concepts definitely make sense and i think that is how we ought to use them. For us to say that science and religion are just incommensurable is a total falsehood.

questions: more important than even that professor chomsky has been a very vocal critic of the foreign policy of united states. professor chomsky welcome?
answers: Glad to be here. It is a real pleasure to talk to you.

questions: how do you reconcile this with the allegation that you make of its bias?
answers: Well that sentence which is widely quoted does exist but the sentence that followed it is rarely quoted. The first sentence is essentially a question mark and the rest is just quotes.

questions: so there is a certain level of objectivity over there and therefore this media is a means of getting valid and correct information. would you agree with that?
answers: No i do not. I am not going to talk about myself but let is just take a look at some of the examples you mentioned. Here is an example i did not choose because it is so obvious i can not look away from it.

questions: so what you are saying is that in matters of politics and power objectivity is perhaps an impossibility and that it may not be not even be objectively possible to have a true depiction of events?
answers: I do not think that is necessarily the case i can talk myself into believing that for example i should pursue a career in journalism because that seems to me a worthwhile pursuit. But it does not follow that there is no possibility of having a truly objective depiction. After all even the most jaded of observers can see that the events of sept. 11 did indeed happen.

questions: there is no prediction that one can make in political affairs and therefore the level of objectivity is much lower?
answers: Let me come to this. I do not frankly see much difference between leninism and stalinism. What you call socialism in my view is simply different from what it was at the time when the soviet union came into being.

questions: you have been critical of the way in which those representations were made and yet there was something very objective about airplanes flying to twin towers. what precisely is your objection?
answers: I have no objection to portrayals of events. It is quite true that people do not like them and can not tolerate them but that is a fact of life. I do think that those events were extremely condemnable.

questions: what do you propose the u. s. should have done?
answers: I do not recall being critical of the invasion of iraq. What was critical was the fact that the united states was defending a population it had just murdered. And the iranian threat was minuscule compared with al qaeda is or alternatively with the global jihad.

questions: give us an example?
answers: For example and the most obvious case and it takes real dedication for the media not to bring this one up because it is such an obvious example.

questions: in fact it did not change anything. they just simply shrugged it off?
answers: But that is of course because nicaragua was trying to bring a case against the most powerful and violent state in the world. If they had brought a civil suit against obama and the state of washington it would have been heard in federal court.

questions: in a sense the september 11 event was unique. it really shook the united states?
answers: So it is unique in my opinion. I mean there have been many such incidents throughout history including the european attack on hiroshima in 1945 and the indian epiphany in 1925. but this one was different just in its scale and in the character.

questions: i mean within the united states?
answers: Within israel too. But it is different. For one thing there is a very sharp difference between what is happening in israe and egypt now and then and what it was happening i think in the 1950s. So for example take the month of may 1967. march 1967 was the first major war crime since the second world war.

questions: we hear president bush asking why do they hate us so much. do you see positive changes emerging from this?
answers: I am sure there are plenty of internal problems at the grass roots level as elsewhere in the world but the idea that the united states should be the butt of everyone is jokes is ludicrous. If there is something to be laughed at it is the rich privileged white males who run the society.

questions: do you believe that this fear has any real cause to it?
answers: I do not think it can be discounted but i would not exaggerate it either. I think the burden of proof for the so called fear of terrorism would have to be very heavy to make it even a remote possibility.

questions: yes but people there are being tried by military courts?
answers: That is right because the population does not like it and the military can make it clear that the people are not going to like that. Anyhow you get the juries you make sure they are as corrupt as possible.

questions: how do we ever break out of this stalemate?
answers: Well as you know much better than i there have been moves at the grass roots level for interaction discussion and reconciliation. Delegations have gone up and back between pakistan and india to try to sort out these issues. Eqbal was involved. He was the one who proposed the arab league peace plan which was accepted by the united states.

questions: so your criticism is perhaps perfectly valid but what is the alternative?
answers: Well first of all the way you have presented is my view but it is not the view of the vast majority of americans. Just take a look at public opinion.

questions: but let us try and imagine a better world where the distribution of wealth is more equitable?
answers: Not just that but where growth is better the economic progress is greater.

questions: and do you think that the nation state is today a viable entity something that should still exist and something that is necessary for the world of ours?
answers: First i do not think it should be either the corporation or the country state but let is come back to that. The strongest advocates of powerful states are the corporations. They want strong states and they need them for their corporate operations and their control of state power.

questions: how should economic power be distributed among people?
answers: Corporation are tyrannical organizations. They are totalitarian institutions. In fact if you look at them that what is a corporation it is an unaccountable private tyranny in which power comes from above from the owners orders are transferred down below and inserted inside the system. No democratic control.

questions: that is very beautiful but it is abstract?
answers: No it has no abstract meaning.

questions: how do we make it into an actuality?
answers: Same way look 200 years ago talking about parliamentary democracy sounded abstract. We had feudalism and kings and princes and slavery. How were we going to make democracy a reality.

questions: and tell us is there something like intrinsic superiority of one language over the other?
answers: There is no such thing as superior intellectual ability in the linguistic sense. All humans have this capacity and so does every other animal that is a part of the human biological endowment. Slight differences in some cognitive capacities such as those displayed by humans are attributable to environmental conditions rather than to inherent character differences.

questions: this suggests that if we want to make the world a better place that there should be one universal language and then many local languages?
answers: That is a possibility but i do not think it would be a good idea. One reason why we are all speaking english is because of the power of english. If everybody spoke english everyone would probably be able to read the newspapers in their own language.

questions: so to be multilingual is best?
answers: I am sure you can see it yourself being part of an international community is enriching. Having a home away from home is a wonderful thing.

questions: how do you feel that your research into language has helped us understand human nature and is human nature something that is definable?
answers: Well maybe the best way to put it is to ask what is the human essence. Is it a question of having a language or not. Well i think the answer to that depends on what you mean by human being.

questions: what do you see as the agents of change?
answers: Well you know there is the ancient indian epics in which the ideal sage believes in hope and resignation meaning recognize that things are difficult but hop that they will get better. You will find the same in the confucian analects the master the greatest person continues to struggle though he knows there are no solutions.

questions: noam what do you see to be the strategic significance of the new military situation in afghanistan?
answers: I assume that the u. s. will more or less take control over afghans.

questions: do you think the current military situation will encourage right wing triumphalism and serve as justification for military action here and elsewhere?
answers: You are begging the question there. I do not agree that it will. On the contrary i think that the situation is extremely complex and that any kind of military triumph of a great power will reflect deep seated tendencies within that power which are difficult to predict and cannot be predicted with any confidence.

questions: what is your assessment of the potential of the northern alliance as a force with political legitimacy in the country and as a force capable of governing?
answers: I have not seen any serious studies of this but my strong impression is that it will probably be a last ditch effort by the central government to hold on to its power. It may be that the united states will have to make some concessions in order to allow this to succeed. But i think it is highly likely to fail.

questions: what are the present and potential humanitarian consequences of this war?
answers: For obvious reasons the western media and doctrinal system are trying very hard to suppress that question. In fact it is one of the few questions in the middle east that is not being asked. And it would be quite surprising if it were discovered.

questions: what does a bomb of this sort look like?
answers: It is a little thing that a child would pick up thinking it was a toy. In fact they apparently look pretty much like the food drops except that they are smaller. The same is happening in many places all over the world including latin america and africa.

questions: over which period?
answers: They usually start in 1965 because the u. s. does not want to admit that it started attacking vietnam in 1961. in fact there were probably 70 000 or so people killed in the late 1950s

questions: two to four million is a pretty wide range?
answers: And what do you count. Well if i counted up the number of human beings on earth and then inserted a coin into a bag of coins which had a value of one dollar on it i would have a total offour million. I do not have that far to fall.

questions: the second is a point you have made even recently particularly with reference to sudan and nicaragua and other parts of central america that the victims of an attack are not just the number of people who die in the immediate attack but also those who die of its long term effects?
answers: Both of those points are important. For one thing it is not always easy to determine whether a particular attack was the result of a criminal act committed with the explicit purpose of harming innocent people. Sometimes it happens very quickly and sometimes over a long period. Attack after attack there is nothing you can do about it except try to find some plausible explanation.

questions: on the second point you have referred recently to the examples of sudan and central america?
answers: Thirty thousand people were killed in the fighting in nicaragua but how many people died. The numbers are huge. Sudany is an interesting case because it is the most advanced country in terms of military spending and it had not attacked a country. Less than a year after taking office nicaraguans began to bomb suda and there have been constant bombings ever since.

questions: what kind of popular support do you think there is in the united states for this kind of retaliatory war against poverty stricken people?
answers: I think it is extremely low which is why it does not reach the scale that one would hope for. If there were popular pressure there would be popular reaction. Fortunately the constraints on movement and communication prevent that from happening.

questions: is there any evidence for this or are you speaking of what you would expect?
answers: It depends on how you understand what i am saying. If i say there is evidence it is because i think there are reasons for it. Say in the case of vietnam for example there were very strong reasons to believe that the war was going to drag on.

questions: you have also said that the gulf war was one in which protests began even before bombing began?
answers: They did not actually begin for a long time. It got so hot that people began to flee to the mountains. The harris polling organization which is supposed to be objective reported that 80 percent of the people said the war began as a mistake and that it should have been stopped right away when it was too costly.

questions: like your daughter in nicaragua?
answers: Yes. That is one of the problems with the media which is very striking. You can not get independent journalism on the model of say the boston globe or new york times because they do not have the resources.

questions: it went beyond just solidarity then they were conscious of being a human shield?
answers: For a while after the berlin wall fell they did send medical supplies to gaza. I was there but you never know how much it affected the morale of the soldiers. Sometimes it made a difference. In the case of mexicans and muslims it was very significant.

questions: in your thinking the propaganda function of the dominant media is part of a broader process of building a consensus for official policy?
answers: Official U. s. policy and more or less standard operating procedure.

questions: is it getting worse or have your book and your work and that of others made a difference to the quality of the media?
answers: They have been barely willing to recognise its existence. Nevertheless people know about this kind of critique because there is a strong popular movement against the conformism of mainstream media. For example when the new york times refused to publish my book fear of god i could not find a single mention in the papers.

questions: i have not heard you say that before?
answers: It really all depends on the way you perceive it. I get hundreds of questions everyday. People asking for advice. There's no one way to answer.

questions: did you ask for the meeting?
answers: There was a small delegation that asked me to come along. The globe was in a way happy it is under constant attack from the jewish community for being too pro arab so they want criticism from outside. I do not criticize them i respond.

questions: did they finally?
answers: No they never did. The story that they told never took place. In fact it is a fabrication of the worst kind. A couple of months later a new front page story in the new york times reported a study by an international team of carter scholars which found that the trilateral commission had been in regular contact since the early 1950s.

questions: so what you are saying is that there is some improvement but?
answers: There are some differences. The basic principle is the same. A few big corporations can determine what the public will see and hear and in fact decide what is a public good and a national interest.

questions: how do you see the applicability of the propaganda model to other situations and places including for instance europe?
answers: In britain there is some work. There are some mediaeval periodicals that still exist which have substantial print run but little in the way of a dedicated ideological apparatus.

questions: so overall do you think that the media in europe covers a wider range of issues and opinions?
answers: Marginally wider because of the somewhat greater diversity in the social organisation. Take for instance the labour movement which is much stronger in germany than it is in france. Co determination whatever it amounts to is almost inconceivable in a country where the working class is extremely subordinate.

questions: and that is where it began?
answers: It was a day of solidarity for american workers fighting for an eight hour day. People know that everywhere in the world in human history when people try to organize they call it a revolution. I was there for a demonstration.

questions: i refer in particular to research on using the media to impose official doctrinal consensuses on the people?
answers: You have to look at cases. This is not physics. There is no theory behind any of this it is just practice. Back in the 30 is for example there was a lot of talk about how the new deal legislation was harmful to working people.

questions: well it is a model in that it is a set of relationships from which predictions can be made?
answers: Okay so what is the model that you are using. The way i read it you say that the key to scientific progress is to be open to new ideas and to inquire into the nature of the world. What do you mean by that.

questions: but each case study is not meant only to illustrate or describe just that particular case?
answers: No in fact we tried to pick the hardest cases. We picked the cases that the media themselves and the ideological system put forth as their strongest.

questions: in that sense you are looking for some kind of theoretical conclusions are not you?
answers: To try to show that anywhere you look there is a long list of failures. We picked historically crucial cases the cases that the media present as their proudest moments the ones that they want you to focus on. If you do that for a while you find a pattern.

questions: in the light of what you are saying how in your view would research on the indian media using the herman chomsky method proceed?
answers: I would begin by looking at the institutional structure. If it is a family owned newspaper ask questions about the family and the activities of the newspaper.

questions: what are you looking for?
answers: Take some question that is crucial for india. Let us say.

questions: food and food security?
answers: Actually both of those are quite serious problems.

questions: you could use this method i take it when dealing with other issues as well such as food security or the wto?
answers: It is used all the time even with the debt. For example take the food stamp program which was basically a way for the government to buy off the population by making sure that people did not have enough food to eat. Or take reparations.

questions: so the methodology would be to choose subjects of great public importance investigate how the press covers them and then?
answers: Trace the results to what you can about the institutional structure. That is not profound but it is straightforward and it has been done. Here is a case in point the boston bombings which was picked up right after the bombings in iraq and investigated by cindy crawford a very good journalist.

questions: although the internet is increasingly being privatised we would not have had our present access to dissenting opinion without it. it clearly has a dual character?
answers: It has been fantastic and it still is. In the united states we have a media empire that is second to none. We literally have two media corporations one a national media one an international one.

questions: the classic case is chiapas?
answers: Yes chiappingas is another case that illustrates the principle. And the same principle holds for venezuela and for a large part of the middle east. The united states sponsored and supported a popular uprising in haiti in the early 1990s that brought together a broad nationalist base that overthrew a brutal military dictatorship.

questions: what do you think is going to happen to that space?
answers: Space is contested. There is a very good book on this by edward herman and robert mcchesney called global media. Have you read the introduction.

questions: as a means of?
answers: Getting around media control. Take the humanitarian crisis in afghanistan for instance. You could not learn anything about it through scattered sentences here and there but there is a lot of material on the internet. Media concentration was so extreme that virtually nothing was known about the afghans even though the united states and britain had sponsored the invasion.

questions: to shift the subject in 1967 you published the responsibility of intellectuals?
answers: Actually it had been published before in a student newspaper. They picked it up and ran it in the student paper. It was not picked up again and this time it became a kind of a major issue so it made it into the major scholarly journal.

questions: which one?
answers: You would not believe it but it was published in the journal of the hillel foundation a jewish student group at harvard. They had a special issue on hebrew and he wrote a letter to the editor about how he felt that the publication was anti semitic. I read the article and i was speechless.

questions: if you had to rewrite the responsibility of intellectuals today what would you say?
answers: In retrospect it seems to me there were unclarities and omissions. One has to do with the category intellectuals. Who are they.

questions: do your books address this 20 per cent of the population trying to strip them of their illusions or whom are you addressing?
answers: That is a misleading question. What is being targeted is much broader than that. It is the educated liberal intellectual elite the journals and the universities which are the main targets.

questions: can islamic fundamentalism be seen as a force that is trying to fill this void.?
answers: I agree with the thrust of what you are saying but would not be happy putting it that way. In my view the fall of the soviet union was a small victory for socialism and democracy. It opened the way for a huge upsurge of popular struggle which is what is needed.

questions: what is your perspective on what has evolved since the terrorist attacks?
answers: It is mixed. On the one hand the scale and the intensity of the attacks is something that is new and very frightening and to some extent unanticipated. I think a good first reaction would have been to act immediately and decisively to terminate the support for the taliban and qaeda which continues apace and indeed is increasing.

questions: what might be some useful information that you could provide?
answers: There are two categories of information which are particularly useful because there is two distinct though related sources for the attack. Let is assume that the bombing was pre directed and that it was carried out by russian or chinese commandos. That makes perfect sense from their point of view since they gain nothing from the atrocity.

questions: is there anything else you want to add?
answers: There is a lot more but i will not go into it. Suffice it to say that i fell in love with this country when i was a child and i still am. I did not know what i wanted to do but somehow it happened.

questions: you want to bring perpetrators of horrendous terrorist crimes to justice. what about the means to reach those ends?
answers: Suppose somebody in cuba for example murders somebody and we are trying to find out who killed him we have to go back to the evidence that was produced at the time. Is that evidence sufficient.

questions: do you think it is more than problematic to engage in alliances with those whom are called unsavory characters drug traffickers and assassins in order to achieve what is said to be a noble end?
answers: Remember that among the most unpersuasive of these groups are the governments of the region our own government and its allies. If we are serious we also have to ask what effect these alliances will have on the populations they are trying to control. Will more democracy and freedom be created in the midst of such chaos and violence? Probably not.

questions: is a leading terrorist state might stun many americans. could you elaborate on that?
answers: I just gave one example nicaragua.

questions: how have they been performing since the events of september 11?
answers: Since i do not like to generalize let is take a concrete example. The world trade center was almost completely destroyed on secember 11th. Not by a bomb but by an act of terrorism which should have been stopped by virtually any standard.

questions: should assassinations be allowed. should the cia be given more operating leeway?
answers: I do not think the us should tolerate assassination. Again i am oversimplifying. The target of assassination should be someone who is a high official of a hostile power the usual suspects include the indonesian generals and others. If the evidence is strong enough it can be used to justify an attack.

questions: could you very briefly define the political uses of terrorism. where does it fit in the doctrinal system?
answers: The u. s. is officially committed to what is called low intensity warfare which means that U.S. troops are directed against relatively defenseless populations.

questions: are you aware of any organizations that we would do best funneling money that we would like to donate to help increase the food supply in that country?
answers: Oh yeah plenty. I mean this is obviously just it could not even pass abc news.

questions: so having ruled out economic and military sanctions i do not suppose spitballs would be in order.?
answers: Well i already gave you the answer to what i think we ought to do. But let is go through your questions. First of all you said i blame america and that is absolutely false.

questions: are you upset or shocked by horowitz is extraordinary attack on you?
answers: I have not read horowitz. I did not used to read him when he was a stalinist and i do not do now. Have i read anything by him in the last twenty years which deals with anything remotely like what he describes. Yes i was upset and horrified by the article but that is typical.

questions: what about hitchens attack. i know you were gob smacked by it but surprised?
answers: Not particularly. He is been pretty erratic for about ten years. Last year he had a tantrum and i thought he was going to blow up.

questions: but that is not really the position that the left has been taking?
answers: It is nonsense. I mean fisk has condemned the perpetrators of this probably the bin laden network more harshly than anyone i have seen their wickedness and awesome cruelty and so on and i agree with him. But hitchens knows it perfectly well and you can read in the press that he deplores what they are doing.

questions: you wrote that they were not only wrong but unintelligible?
answers: Well he can not believe what he is saying. He knows perfectly well that what they are saying is completely and utterly unacceptable to virtually all reasonable people including us. That is why we have a system of intellectual self defense.

questions: a deepening of analysis in mainstream media as a consequence of september 11th?
answers: First of all i do not really think the mainstream press is that different from england or say the new york times. They are newspapers with a kind of a commercial orientation. Most of the material is for sale.

questions: to hold an inquiry into the incident which i understand was blocked by the u. s?
answers: Well yes. The sudan did call for an immediate withdrawal of all foreign forces. That was not obama so what was his position.

questions: that can not really be dealt with through the political process can it?
answers: I do not agree with that. For one thing remember we have to be a little careful about the use of the phrase compromise. There is in fact a concept called compromise that was invented to try to justify the invasion of iraq by the united states under the pretext that it was being carried out under a humanitarian guise.

questions: although they are backing off as we speak are not they?
answers: The egyptian military dictatorship which is bitterly anti hamas has called for a cease fire but is giving the green light to the israeli attack. The us has said there will be no negotiations. Now what does that mean for hamast. Well it means that they no longer have to give a fig leaf.

questions: what are some of the most significant dangers of this rapidly ad libbed strategy?
answers: There are a number of dangers.

questions: on what do you base that assertion?
answers: I base it on the statements that are blandly reported in the major press like the new york times without comment the world food program and others. So here is a comment from just yesterday at about 10 a.m. eastern time by just edward herman.

questions: apart from foreign policy does it involve a deepening self awareness in the american elites. is america seeing itself more clearly?
answers: Well you know it is very hard to generalize. We should remember that something else is happening too. There are a lot of other things going on including the collapse of the soviet union and the conflict in ukraine and elsewhere.

questions: how might these sudden moves be affecting the political dynamics in those regions?
answers: Washington is stepping very delicately. We have to remember what is at stake the world is major energy reserves primarily in saudi arabia but throughout the gulf region along with not inconsiderable resources in central asia and northeast asian asias.

questions: is exerting in the region impact their already volatile relationship?
answers: The main source of conflict is kashmir where india claims to be fighting islamic terrorism and pakistan claims it is being attacked by iran. All the claims unfortunately are basically correct except for the last one which is not much of an exaggeration. There has been a series of wars over Kashmir over the years mostly uncontested.

questions: alliance building effort spawn a new multi lateralism in which unexpected positive developments like progress for palestinians might advance?
answers: It is worth recalling that bush is unilateralism was a virtual death knell for the hopes of palestine. It was not until 1993 that congress passed a resolution explicitly authorizing the us to take military action against iran.

questions: is the present situation in any way an exception. examples?
answers: Impediments to free flow of information in countries like the u. s. are rarely traceable to government rather to self censorship of the familiar kind. I have written about it in the past.

questions: why do you think these attacks happened?
answers: To answer the question we must first identify the perpetrators of the crimes.

questions: what consequences will those attacks have on us inner policy and to the american self reception?
answers: Us policy has already been officially announced. The world is being offered a stark choice join us or face the certain prospect of death and destruction. Congress has authorized the use of force against any individuals or countries the president determines to be involved in the attacks a doctrine that every supporter regards as ultra criminal.

questions: do you expect us to profoundly change their policy to the rest of the world?
answers: The initial response was to call for intensifying the policies that led to this catastrophe. That is quite appropriate i think.

questions: after the first shock came fear of what us answer is going to be. are you afraid too?
answers: Every sane person should be afraid of the likely reaction the one that has already been announced and that will probably be announced at some point. The bush administration announced very explicitly that it is planning a massive attack in iraq no questions asked probably within months. There is every reason to expect a major attack some involving nato ground troops some under the control of america is ally.

questions: the world will never be the same after 11. 09. 01. do you think so?
answers: For the first time the situation is so dire that there is even talk of a global economic crisis. Not a very severe one actually. It is been predicted for years and the effects are already being felt in some areas.

questions: what do you see as the significance of the un world conference against racism in south africa?
answers: I think that the most important issue that is being raised by this conference is the question of reparations namely european reparation for the destruction of benighted african africans. Afghanistan is a wreck and it is not because it was hit by an asteroid. The people who lived there were devastated.

questions: what do you think has been the impact of this movement?
answers: This effort of which madre has become a symbol has really changed consciousness enormously in the last 30 years. The 1980 is was the first time in history when there was a significant popular movement which was dedicated to dismantling the socio economic and political system in which most of the population lived. And it is continued to this day.

questions: tell us about plan colombia and why the us is escalating its involvement there?
answers: Remember this is a clinton plan that bush is implementing and probably accelerating. During the 1990 is columbia was the leading recipient of us military aid and training in the hemisphere. Approximately half of all us aid in Latin America went to colaboratory programs run by the state department and the private sector which in many cases are engaged in what is sometimes called high tech warfare.

questions: given that the drug war is a pretext what is the bottom line of the us interest in colombia?
answers: The answer is we do not have to hide it. In fact we are openly announcing our interest. The british foreign office in its annual review of overseas activities reports that cocaine and heroin are the leading illicit drugs of choice for wealthy donors in Latin America and the Caribbean.13 These are important facts which merit careful attention.

questions: what is been the effect in those countries?
answers: Let is look at nicaragua. The us reasserted control over Nicara in 1990. since then the country has experienced a steep decline. (applause) no one really knows how much this is related to the contras.

questions: it seems that even when the information is available it is quite difficult for people in the us to comprehend the impact that us policies have on communities around the world. why do you think that is?
answers: Well there is a principle of human affairs that goes back millennia which is that you do not look in at the mirror. You can trace this principle back to the bible. The designated intellectuals of that time are called prophets which was a mistranslation of a hebrew word but they were basically intellectuals giving geopolitical analysis criticizing the moral practice of leadership etc.

questions: what do you see as some differences both in style and substance between clinton and bush regarding foreign policy?
answers: There are a lot of differences of style attributable mostly to the public relations industry which manufactures consent for official policy. Clintons style is partly a reflection of his own personality whereas bush is mostly manufactured. He has more of a public persona and is more brazen and aggressive.

questions: it would be possible to terminate it right now before it even begins. why is not this happening?
answers: We are looking at the dawn of a new arms race. For example germany technically opposes the us space militarization program but is bound to get involved. Otherwise it will be left behind in the development of advanced technology.

questions: the outer space treaty is one of many international agreements that the bush administration has violated or terminated. what is the logic behind this trend?
answers: It is actually quite rational. Take the kyoto protocol. Destruction of the environment is not only rational but exactly what you are taught to do in college by robert kagan and so on.

questions: what do you feel are the responsibilities of intellectuals both within and outside academia in free and open societies?
answers: Again i do not feel that i have anything to say beyond moral truisms which are easily forgotten. Suppose i see a hungry child in the street and i am able to offer the child some food. Am i morally culpable if i refuse to do so because i think the moral rightness of doing so is outweighed by the costs to the community or the animal.

questions: whose raison d tre is to represent all those people and issues that are routinely swept under the rug. would you agree with said?
answers: Edward said is a very honorable representative of the intellectual in the sense of his term. That is his proposal as to how the term should be used. It surely does not describe those who are called intellectuals in standard usage as he would be the first to agree.

questions: said points to antonio gramsci as a model intellectual. who would you see as model intellectuals today?
answers: The people i find most impressive are generally unknown at the time of their actions and forgotten in history. I know of people whose actions or words i admire and respect. Some are called intellectuals others do not deserve the label.

questions: is there hope to subvert this dominance in democracies. what do you think can realistically be done?
answers: It is not hopeless it has been done in the past and it can be carried out. The 1920s were a significant period kind of like this in many ways but the 1930s brought significant changes with the onset of the counter cultural movement which ended up challenging the parliamentary system and opening up the possibility of popular organization.

questions: are academics mostly servants of the power structure intent on keeping their elite positions?
answers: Academics are mostly professionals involved in their work and other concerns of their own with no particular interest in the workings of society. I would not say that the efforts of academics to critique the media is messages are half hearted.

questions: is that what you feel you are essentially doing in manufacturing consent?
answers: Anyone in a position to overcome barriers to free thought and communication should do so. That much at least seems clear parents who care about their children for example or artisans or farmers or anyone who is serious about living a decent life.

questions: can you elaborate on why you feel this is so critical?
answers: There are two aspects of that both of them leading themes of imperial strategy for the last 35 or so years either globally or in places like russia. One is what they call aggressive militarism which means trying to dominate the world by force. Now there is a technical term for it you can call it predatory capitalism if you like but it has nothing to do with aggression.

questions: how do you perceive academics creating these webs of mystification?
answers: The observation is much more general and i surely can not take credit for it. It is familiar to mainstream academic scholarship. One very prominent political scientist in his standard text american politics 20 years ago observes that the architects of power in the united states must create a force that can be felt but not seen.

questions: where do you perceive the education which focuses on creativity and independence taking place?
answers: Again i pretend no originality in observing that mass education was motivated in part by the perceived need to educate them to keep them from our throats to borrow ralph waldo emerson is parody of elite fears that inspired early advocates of the public school system. More generally independent farmers had to be trained to become docile workers in the expanding industry.

questions: what do you realistically think might be accomplished by writers poets scholars activists placing yourself in whatever category you feel appropriate within and outside of academia during the next decade?
answers: Intellectuals of the categories you mention happen to enjoy unusual privilege unique in history i suppose. It is easy enough to find beeeep illustrations of repression malice dishonesty marginalization and exclusion in the academic world. By comparative standards however constraints are slight i think.

questions: what would your vision be for a politically engaged university?
answers: Personally i am uneasy about the idea of having a political science department. At the very least i think that should be a part of the natural sciences.

questions: give me some examples of those variations?
answers: Well you know there are states that partially reject international law and convention insofar as they can get away with it. In fact every state is like that. Virtually every one.

questions: why has the notion of the rogue state been given so much prominence do you think since the end of the cold war?
answers: Well first of all remember that i am using the term in a neutral sense in terms of its meaning primarily imperial. Almost every term of political discourse has a literal meaning and a propaganda version. And i do not use it in the literal sense.

questions: on what grounds can you argue that the united states is the leading rogue state?
answers: Well because it fits the neutral definition that i described very clearly. For example it violates principles going back to the magna carta that are fundamental to any civilized society.

questions: you are not seriously telling me that you are putting america in that same category?
answers: Well much worse. First of all recall that the united states and britain supported saddam hussein when he was doing that. They did not back down even when his forces were pelting kuwait with missiles.

questions: but the decision to gas the kurds?
answers: That goes back to the beginning. The united states like britain before it has done this occasionally. Germany and france have done it occasionally as well.

questions: was not made by washington or london?
answers: No but it was <

questions: it was in baghdad?
answers: No it came from the central government in washington. And it remained in that position until the invasion. In fact when iraqi kurds attempted to leave they were stopped by the united states and sent back.

questions: but this is all done to promote democracy and freedom in vietnam in south and latin america and certainly in sudan. do you?
answers: It was done but what is more significant is what went on after the war. The programs began immediately. In fact you can trace this to the highest planning body the national security council a few months after kennedy is invasion which was a very serious breach of policy.

questions: but the americans would argue that was part of a very important fight against international terrorism?
answers: They never argued any such thing. They did not use the word international at the time no one did. It was just an american crusade and the same was true of other crusades since.

questions: it was simply invented by what you would see as a rogue superpower to attack other countries?
answers: Well we know that it originated with the united states. Japan for example is believed to have had a role in it. But remember they did not declare a war on terror on september 11 and in fact began to shift their policies a little bit after that.

questions: but the thing itself exists does it not?
answers: Oh the phenomenon exists. So for example when the united states bombs sudan and destroys half its pharmaceutical supply that is international terrorism. When france carries out a bombing in libya which is also international terrorist acts that too is an international crime.

questions: can be a force for good championing the cause of democracy and freedom?
answers: It can. That is just what you have to do in this case. There is no other way around it either go along with it or get out and do something else.

questions: has it ever though. has it ever?
answers: Well has any country ever. I mean by accident you know states are not moral agents. But the idea of a moral agent is an idea that was proposed by thucidides the strong do what they want and the weak suffer as they must. Slowly over time it became axiomatic.
