questions: similar case in burma. what should be done about those rogue states?
answers: Well we should first of all look a little bit into the backgrounds.

questions: should it?
answers: But what should the united states do about burma and north korea. Well it should try to for example let is take northern ireland. In the early part of the 20th century Northern irelands was the main source of raw materials for the industrial west and it is in that region that the korean war originated.

questions: why did you oppose it. why do you oppose this?
answers: Well for one thing it is interesting that that is the interpretation of the book and also another book i wrote on the topic neither of which attacks neither this one nor the other one is an attack on lenin. It discusses both renbok and smolensk so there is a background there.

questions: are you saying that it is not true. that a line was not drawn?
answers: I did not say that. What i said is that the statement that was made does not bear on the propriety of the invasion.

questions: what do you mean by the usual line?
answers: It really depends on... the metaphors you are willing to accept and well, the ones your arent. Ai is many things. Um. It is.

questions: but the evidence at the time seemed to be that there was an overwhelming humanitarian case indeed that genocide seemed to be being committed against the albanians?
answers: I am quite sure that was the case if we had the documentary record. You can look at it yourself if you like but i think you would agree with bakhtin. He was one of the people who really did have the courage and the integrity to go into the mountains and meet with the junta and try to convince them to let the monitors go in.

questions: so what?
answers: Answers are made from passed, accumulated data. Prediction algorithms try to find a suitable answer. But it's always based on past behaviours.

questions: what u. s. national interest is served by the bombing in your view?
answers: Exactly what they said. I mean the official goals are discussed in this book. There are several books that have been written on this which go into more detail about them.

questions: powerful countries will try to shore up their credibility to maintain their long term interests?
answers: Exactly. That is just what i was saying all along. And the task of intellectuals is to disguise that in terms of lofty rhetoric and aims.

questions: will they be more or less interventionist do you think than the clinton administration?
answers: It is very hard to say. I mean they are somewhat different. First of all they follow pretty much the same plans.

questions: why should one suppose it will necessarily lead to an arms race as you say?
answers: Necessary. Nothing is necessary in world affairs but certain things are obvious.

questions: now you have written about the new post communist world order. what as far as you are concerned is it?
answers: It is a system in which tactical changes were made. I mean the basic strategic positions have not changed because if you look over the history of the cold war both sides both the russians and the americans claim that everything they were doing was in defense against the other. But we have to be serious and ask whether that is really true.

questions: tell me what sort of limits and how should limits be put on american power in this world order?
answers: Again i do not see the point of putting limits on the powerful. The same is true of other powerful states. For example the united states is not limited in the power it had at the end of world war ii.

questions: how will that happen. what do you mean by that?
answers: The population of the united states ought to prevent these things from happening. So for example it is not only against the us but even more so against europe the industrial democracies. One has to keep a whip hand on them otherwise they will just run amok and nobody will pay any attention.

questions: do you really think the american people care about the peaceful use of outer space and far flung parts of the world?
answers: Oh absolutely. In fact if you take a look at polls which are very careful in the united states the public is in favor of direct involvement with multilateral agreements to lead to a more peaceful world and so on. You know people are not crazy.

questions: or i mean are there aspects of the country that you appreciate and admire?
answers: And i say it all the time. It is the most free country in the world. There is no other country like it except maybe spain. I have never seen a demonstration quite like that in all of my years of experience.

questions: as we speak the cable news network is nattering on in the background for the 36th consecutive day about your presidential elections. it is quite funny is not it?
answers: You are right to find it comical though there are a few serious issues. The most striking fact about the election is that it was a statistical tie even though the media treated it as a very close race.

questions: could you explain the american israeli context of the oslo accord?
answers: There is a background. Actually this article is not the first time that i have referred to it. It is in the index of my book.

questions: what happened in camp david this summer?
answers: Well israel is final status maps conformed closely to the projects it was implementing in the territories with u. s. support while implementing measures to undermine them at home.

questions: does the united states support the barak plan?
answers: This is the u. s. conception of peace and washington would be pleased to have it realized. The problem is that the israeli conception has no counterpart in world history and would lead to a proliferation of nuclear weapons which is not a desirable consequence particularly if the deterrent is non-existent. [audience laughter] so we will wait and see what happens.

questions: how then would you describe the american interests in this area if we shake off the usual nonsense about peace and democracy like the peace and democracy the u. s. is bringing to columbia?
answers: The primary interest uncontroversially is effective control of the world is most important energy reserves. These may be administered by what the british in their day in the sun called an arab facade behind a faade of benign intent behind which bantustans would be quietly integrated if possible.

questions: okay that was true during the cold war but that has ended already?
answers: For a long time it was claimed publicly that the u. s. was defending the region from the russians though internal documents told a different story and the public was never told the truth.

questions: in other words if the united states is not really interested in peace here because the conflict serves its interests then the peace camp has no chance even if it wins an election some day?
answers: It would i think be hard to do anything in the middle east that isnot at least consistent with perceived u. s. national interest. I mean for example it is quite possible that some of the worst atrocities in recent years were committed by people who claimed to be supporters of israel but were in fact agents of pakistan washington and london.

questions: what is a rogue state and who is the leading rogue state out there.?
answers: Well actually the book begins with some discussion of that. Like just about every term of political discourse the word rogue states has two meanings. One is its literal meaning you will find it if you look it up in the dictionary. [ but the second meaning is used for its political warfare purposes.]()

questions: so what you are saying is we selectively use rogue state to define people that we want to attack?
answers: Rogue states are very interesting cases. For one thing they happen to be rich and powerful states.

questions: so it refuses to submit itself to world order and to international?
answers: To the conventions of world orders either international law the dictates of the world court refuses even to deal with the crimes of its own commission.

questions: so what you are saying is the united states asserts its rights in the world above the united nations or any other kind of international negotiation?
answers: The only qualification i would say is there maybe a qualification for the phrase its needs i mean does the u. s. have a legitimate need to dominate the global economy after the collapse of the soviet union. Depends how you see it.

questions: that is an important distinction to keep in mind because one of the points that you make throughout your work is that people are not really considered but instead the military interests the multinational corporate interests are the real sovereign interests that are taken in to account and if it means running over people that is ok?
answers: Yeah there is nothing wrong with that in fact it is kind of traditional. The united states has always taken that position.

questions: when terms are mislabelled like free trade agreements or labour flexibility they are not what they appear to be instead they are kind of the opposite?
answers: That is actually a term of propaganda. Actually free movement of people and capital is commonly described as labour mobility. But that actually has a technical definition in international economic relations.

questions: oh my god?
answers: And that is the minimum wage the point of and level of survivability. I mean you do not have to go back far to find an example of a place where there was a living wage.

questions: and longer hours too it is horrific?
answers: What can you do. I have a few suggestions some things you can do right now. Go back to your classes.

questions: growing worker insecurity?
answers: And that makes sense if workers are insecure they do not dare to ask for higher wages decent working conditions and so on.

questions: or refuse overtime or extra assignments?
answers: Yeah that is the effect of growing worker insecurity and that increases the pressure to work longer hours.

questions: i want briefly to touch on the issue of the relationship between us military aid to third world countries and human rights violations?
answers: Well actually that is been very closely studied in academic work by leading specialists. So for example there is a major study of us aid in latin america by the leading academic specialist on this lars schoultz at the university of north carolina.

questions: now we are not talking about russian military aid or iranian or iraq?
answers: No us military assistance. He wrote it in 1980 there are broader studies which find the same correlation worldwide except for nicaragua which is much more extreme. In fact there is a separate study just published which looks at afghanistan for a year and a half and finds the correlation is even stronger.

questions: is there anything we can do in this election. is there any hope?
answers: I am sure there is plenty of hope i mean there are things to do even in elections you do not take into account the impact of the candidate you are supporting. Look let is take a look at eisenhower.

questions: let is talk about popular struggle what it is and what it takes to make it happen?
answers: Well educational programmes organization protest demands creating alternative institutions just what is happened in all of those cases.

questions: do you think the demonstrations in seattle washington boston and so forth against the wto?
answers: Oh sure in fact they have had a big impact already. So for example a couple of days ago there was a demonstration in new york calling for an end to the war in iraq.

questions: really. how so?
answers: In the case of srebrenica women and children were trucked out and then came you know the massacre. In fact it was even reported in england. But it is hard to take seriously when you consider the u. s. is role in backing it up.

questions: so in a sense we have a democracy although the elections themselves are not really the primary instrument of the democracy it sounds like?
answers: Yeah i think that is probably true but let is go back a stage. In the 1970s when there was a lot of concern about the nature of democracy here is what i thought happened. About 80 or 90 percent of eligible voters did not participate the turnout was far below the norm for the size of popular participation in elections.

questions: as long as we do not cross the fbi?
answers: Yes but they would not know about it if they tried. I mean even say the kennedy administration the johnson administration when they want to investigate someone it does not call the press and ask them questions. They do it through other means.

questions: how do you survive. how come you hav not been targeted?
answers: I have been on nixon is enemies list. The only reason i did not go to jail for a long time was because the tet offensive came along and the prosecutions that were underway were cancelled. But i do not call that escaping the system.

questions: could you comment on that how it induces a philosophy of futility in us?
answers: Well those phrases like inducing and obscuring meaning the two concepts that are most crucial in any political project the project of organizing and controlling the public mind and of course the actual implementation of those projects are combined in the phrase inducing futilism meaning that we are not going to act on the assumption that our actions will have some predictable effect. That is what i was emphasizing.

questions: wage slaves consumer slaves?
answers: Yeah you follow orders and you try to maximise what are called invented wants. And it begins in infancy so that you can figure out what the wants are and then you work out how to meet them. A lot of it is child labour.

questions: sure with the internet the internet is democratising the media in a sense?
answers: It is allowing freedom of expression but there is a side to that as well. A lot of the commentary the business press and so on talk about the need for concentration of power in the hands of a tiny number of people who are unaccountable to the public. That is why you have to have a veil of secrecy.

questions: can we ask one final quick question. should we vote for nader?
answers: Uh where do you live, mexico. I bet the weather is also nicer there.

questions: we are right here?
answers: Well i will i think in new york. If you look at the city and the surrounding areas which is a very poor area of town there is very high concentration of poverty. Mostly black.

questions: which we know is a state that is basically going to go gore. swing state though you go gore?
answers: Probably within the range of popular attitudes but not necessarily supported by the state. So west virginia for example has a very lively labor history much more so than some of the other places i have been.

questions: these implications of shadow economies which is in many cases a marginalization of the masses relate to much of your work on the politics of power and justice among nations and people?
answers: In everything i have read about it there are properties that are rather common in discussing this topic. Whether we are discussing terrorism or crime or anything else there is a strong tendency in the literature to focus on what you might call the retail rather than the wholesale aspects.

questions: how does the consumer and corporate power of wealthy nations contribute to shadow economies around the globe?
answers: What i just mentioned was a case in point. That is not consumer power it is state power. When the united states and other rich countries undermine the efforts by the g77 group of countries to work through unctad to develop commodity stabilization programs which would allow small peasant production that kind of thing they are not doing it for their own interest.

questions: or is it taking on new characteristics and evolving with globalization?
answers: Globalization is a phenomenon that is new in some respects but quite old in others. As many have pointed out by gross measures the global economy is not much different from what it was before the first world war. Upon closer look however there are important differences. 1.

questions: do you feel that these are appropriate for understanding the dynamics of informal economies?
answers: Yes if you want to understand them sure. Every social system whether it is a family or an international economy has some kind of norms. If it has an organized system like states the norms turn out to be enforceable rules. Less so for systems of power and privilege.

questions: how do you see the dynamics between the informal and formal economy depriving the state of funds?
answers: Tax evasion by major corporations is a major phenomenon. I do not think it has really been studied to the point that one can put numbers on it. But for example susan strange concludes that it is one of the dominant forces in the international economy.13 i have written about it extensively elsewhere.

questions: if the economic activity that is taking place within that shadow economy could be brought into state structures do you think that it would be used to strengthen indian society?
answers: Well that depends on how india is organized. I mean the reason for the black economy is because opportunities are lacking within the formal rule governed structures. If people could participate constructively in the economy they would do so.

questions: in scandinavia where most people are able to participate perhaps this could be described as a thriving shadow economy?
answers: Well you have to disaggregate and determine what types of activities they are undertaking. I suspect that if you looked at the informal economy in say sweden you would find much larger numbers than that. It is a very active part of the economy. For example there are probably 2 or 3 million people involved in some capacity in the swedish shadow economies.

questions: do you see how commercial interests might also influence solutions to the problems that exist in shadow economies?
answers: It is impossible to speak of a unified front for example on how to deal with the problem of shadow banking. There is no such thing. Many areas of common interest do not necessarily coincide. For instance i think there should be a tax on financial transfers which could be used to fund basic social services.

questions: or is it attributable to the difficulty of accurately measuring the size of the informal economy?
answers: Well it certainly is technically difficult. It is harder to measure things that are not registered and listed in the bookkeeping. That is going to be harder as well to account for the incompleteness of that informal economic system. Payment in kind unfortunately is not taken into account.

questions: as a final comment would you be able to give us some thoughts on how civil society might find solutions to the problems of the shadow economy?
answers: Civil disobedience is an obvious tactic when undertaken with the right goals and commitments. But it is equally obvious that the goals should be achieved not just pursued when opportunities present themselves. It would be quite surprising if successful defiance of unjust laws and practices did not eventually lead to criminal prosecution and perhaps imprisonment.

questions: a few suggested readings are language and thought language and nature the minimalist program nuestro conocimiento del lenguaje humano all by noam chomsky.?
answers: Emilio rivano there is a topic that came back to me the other day as i was lecturing on toulmin and wittgenstein. It struck me also that i had mentioned the point to you in the form of a written question for the discussion session we had when you were in venezuela a year ago.

questions: you grew up in philadelphia during the depression as the child of an academic family. what was being a kid in that family like?
answers: It was a first generation family so the lives of the children were split between the first and second generation immigrant communities. We lived in a two bedroom apartment which was basically a shantytown and the streets were lined with sheds for animals to congregate in. I remember the baseball games on the sunday afternoons when the neighborhood would line up to see the home team.

questions: did that have any affect on your later decision to become a political activist?
answers: I am sure it did. But one of the big influences in my childhood was an uncle who was a very interesting person. This was during the depression which was pretty horrible.

questions: i do not think the labels are necessarily important but what is the basic philosophy behind your political beliefs?
answers: Let me just say i am an anarchist. That does not mean i approve of the state.

questions: what would a government based on anarchist principles be like?
answers: If it were really based upon these principles it would not exist because a deep part of those principles is that there should not be any such authoritarian systems. Dismantling the state is a core element of almost all left anarchist thinking. Of course that is an aspiration that goes back to the enlightenment and much of classical liberal thinking as well. Just think about that for a moment.

questions: has there ever been a civilization or a country that has approached these ideals?
answers: Sure. Ours. If you compare it with what it was not long ago it is moving in that direction very significantly.

questions: do you walk around in a constant state of depression always?
answers: Not depression it is more agitation. A lot of adrenaline flowing. It may not show but a good deal of anger.

questions: has that also improved in the last 30 years?
answers: It has. Take the kennedy administration one of the most brutal and violent in modern american history. Among other things it deported thousands of people to central america hundreds of thousands were sent to miami and south africa andalachia and the southern cone.

questions: what are the responsibilities of intellectuals and has that changed in the 30 some years since you gave that original talk?
answers: The same as the responsibility of other people act like a decent human being. What is an intellectual. It does not mean you have anything to say. I can not tell you what to do.

questions: if you are privileged enough to be part of the intellectual class then it is your obligation?
answers: With privilege comes responsibility. What i have been describing is not the way intellectuals behave in fact overwhelmingly it behaves in exactly the opposite way. I do not want to suggest that it does not happen.

questions: can you describe in laymen is terms what the dominant ideas in linguistics were when you entered the field in the 50s?
answers: My own feeling was that there was going to be a kind of a clash between behaviorism and behaviorist theory. People were gonna be driven to develop more effective ways of controlling behavior. From that perspective it was a split.

questions: are you at all surprised at what has happened since that vote in east timor?
answers: It is hard to be surprised. Since april there has been a general climate of fear among much of the world and among those who wish to preserve credibility on human rights grounds. And rightly.

questions: should there have been an international force available to east timor at the time of that vote to ensure that the will of the referendum was carried through and not the acts that we are now seeing?
answers: I think that there is strong evidence for that. For example bishop belo who is as much of a spokesman for east Timor now as he was in the 1990s is coming out with scholarly studies saying with very high confidence that what was actually happening was that from about 1975 they were virtually separated from one another. They had very little in common.

questions: could all of this have been prevented or has the indonesian government simply lost control over the military?
answers: We just saw this weekend how much influence the united states has. As soon as the suharto dictatorship was overthrown in 1998 a huge flow of arms was sent back to the taliban. That was not stopped by the us or its allies but they did stop it.

questions: do you think that the financial concerns of indonesia have always outweighed the humanitarian concerns?
answers: For the united states and other western powers there is no doubt. In fact they say so quite openly. The new york times had a cynical but good article a few days ago through their asian specialists who simply described what they called the calculations of the clinton administration.

questions: do you think accountability will ever be brought forward here?
answers: I think that the analogy to kosovo is very misleading. The question of accountability is really a kind of a personal one. I happen to think it is a very rotten system but i do not hold the carte blanche to carry it out and the same is true of other states.

questions: is that any indication to you that things are going to change in terms of the west is relationship with indonesia?
answers: If the united states waits until they get a green light from washington and guam there will just be more destruction and murder. They can move in right away. There is nothing to stop them from bringing in humanitarian aid this minute to prevent the people from starving to death in the mountains or from fleeing to south africa in order to escape this horrible fate.

questions: so do you not think then that the attitude has changed towards indonesia from the west?
answers: There is a lot of pressure from public opinion in many countries including the united states and canada to do something. As a result a few days ago clinton finally made some moves. They were small moves which are beginning to make some difference.

questions: that they did not want to move into indonesia with a peacekeeping force until invited to do so?
answers: Nobody asked them to invite peacekeepers into kuwait. You would have to ask the junta why they would want peacekeeper troops moving in if they were not going to permit a peaceful resolution. It is obvious they do not care about that. [inaudible] but that is exactly what they said when the us started supporting them.

questions: if independence does go ahead in east timor will there be other indonesian provinces that will want to follow leading to the disintegration of indonesia?
answers: It is already happening. When there was a referendum in 2003 the united states which is a major participant in the current turmoil strongly supported independence. What is more it seems to have little to do with the long term aspirations of the vast majority of those involved and will only serve to divide them further.

questions: we are talking about a un force moving in there sometime in the future. what lies ahead there?
answers: It is not a matter for prediction. I do not have any special knowledge. It will depend on what the u. s. decides to do.

questions: chomsky thanks very much for this interview today. we appreciate your time?
answers: Okay. Good to talk to you bye.

questions: why was the us so eager to use force?
answers: The reason is obvious. When involved in a confrontation you use your strong card and try to shift the confrontation to the area in which you are most powerful. Then your opponent has only a few cards.

questions: some people say that unless american soldiers start being shipped home in body bags there will not be a serious anti war effort in the us. what is your assessment of that?
answers: I do not agree with that at all. I mean look at the history. During the 1980s there was overwhelming opposition to us atrocities in central america including the ones we were carrying out in nicaragua and guatemala and elsewhere.

questions: how do you reconcile that view with the fact that according to polls at least the majority of americans would support an escalation of the war for example through the deployment of nato ground troops?
answers: You have to keep in mind what these people are hearing. The public is getting its marching orders from washington. And these orders are to disregard all other atrocities even ones much worse than kosovo especially in places where the us is involved.

questions: what steps do you think people who oppose this war should take now?
answers: There is no question that people of conscience must take action against this. What can we do to end the war. Same thing as always there are no magical tricks.

questions: do you think that by and large you and we are getting a reasonably accurate picture of what is going on in this war?
answers: I think the reporters on the ground many of them are producing quite accurate stories the way the framework and the interpretation handles the facts is another question. Inaccurate is not the word for it it is ludicrous. For example take the bombing of the radio station. How did they know?

questions: well tell us about that?
answers: This is presented well i have not read the canadian media but in the united states and what i has seen of europe the media portray the uprising as a civil war between the secular left and the religious right. That is repeated over and over.

questions: you do not believe that the reason for the nato action was to rescue the kosovo albanians from oppression?
answers: There is an official nago statement that says it was. But since there was never any pretense of rescue what was the point of announcing it. You can ask the question what would have been the purpose of ridding naglfjord of its Albanian population. Well it does not matter because they did not exist anymore.

questions: i must interject here and say that our own foreign minister has said nobody foresaw the scale of milosevic s response?
answers: Maybe they did not foresee the exact scale but when you bomb people they do not throw flowers at you. They react. So when the us bombed libya sheikh yassin was not a target. Diana johnstone also testified before congress on the somalia case and gave a graphic description of the chemical warfare that was unleashed against somalis.

questions: so professor chomsky has this action done any harm to the united nations and the advancement of international law or was it already a moot thing?
answers: Of course it has. You could argue that since world war ii there have been more violations of the un charter in the us than at any time since the spanish conquest. But that is a separate question.

questions: but these are the victims who are saying carry on?
answers: Well of course they say it. In fact the victim at the core of it all the jewish community the secular left and so on came out in support of suharto. See they were the one segment of the population that was able to stop the dictatorship.

questions: but they have lost as you just said they are all refugees now and they are still saying it is the right thing to do?
answers: If you look at the united states and other rich countries there is overwhelming sympathy for the iraqis. The pollsters have shown it for years. Just last year a poll showed that about 80 percent of the arab public said the us should get rid of saddam hussein and the rest you can not get a number because it was kept secret from the population.

questions: if what you are saying is correct how is it that everyone is so misled so woolly headed about this?
answers: I think the facts that i just described are quite plain. For one thing we live in highly indoctrinated societies with an intellectual class that is extremely subordinate to power. And since people are as a result totally bombarded with propaganda about how it s not our fault if the consequence of our actions is an escalation of atrocities they do not think about it.

questions: would you have done anything different?
answers: On march 23rd. Well there were three choices. One was to act in such a way as to escalate the atrocities that is what was chosen. The other two were to take the same position as the international community has been doing for some time and sharply reduce the level of atrocities and violence.

questions: what do we do now?
answers: If a doctor is giving you medicine which is killing you the first thing you would want is for him or her to stop giving the medicine not give more of it. So the moral of the story is if you are giving poison to a sick person give medicine to kill the sick people. The same is true of climate change.

questions: do you think we are likely to do any of that?
answers: The us and canada. Very unlikely because these are jingoist countries which are highly subordinate to power and where people do not stop to think through the consequences of what they are doing unfortunately.

questions: nato will be celebrating its 50th anniversary next week and they are all congratulating themselves on having found a new role?
answers: Yes that is correct. The us has played an important role in world order for the last half century and still does.

questions: but many people apparently find it hard to go along with your explanation because they do not feel that control could be that monolithic?
answers: What you just described is a very specific example of how power systems can work. I mentioned that the toothpaste example is particularly striking. But there are many other cases.

questions: but i get the impression that a lot of people think that you are saying that it is a massive conspiracy?
answers: That is true maybe of harvard professors but that has nothing to do with the point i was making. If you were to ask a similar question about say general motors the answer would be different. I mean there are conspiracy theories all the time.

questions: so would you say that the elite groups are not so much coordinated in producing the system as they are unanimous in protecting it?
answers: There are matters on which they tend to be in overwhelming agreement. For example there is a great deal of concern about the concentration of political power in a tiny sector of the population and about its tendency to move to the right. On many very serious issues people are almost unanimously in favor of continuing to negotiate with iran.

questions: what sort of economic and governmental system do you think is viable?
answers: Systems like capitalism and socialism and communism have never been tried. What we have had since the industrial revolution was one or another form of state capitalism. It is been overwhelmed certainly in the last century by big conglomerations of capital corporate structures that are all interlinked with one another and form strategic alliances and administer markets and so on.

questions: but do you see a way that will?
answers: Yeah sure. I do not see why we have to have a system in which the wealth that gets created is directed overwhelmingly to a tiny percentage of the population. Nor do i believe that it has to be that way.

questions: could you do some things that make the media focus on you?
answers: I have done all that. I organized national tax resistance i worked with the vietnam veterans groups and others to prevent the re deployment of troops in southern columbia and i did other things. The point is if you are targeted somebody is going to pick you up and give you a hard time because you did something illegal or immoral and the institutions do not like it.

questions: do you ever get exhortative in your lectures. do you try to stir people up?
answers: No. People say look he is not a good speaker and i am happy about that. If i knew how to do it i would not.

questions: many jews believe that the intervention by the united states in kosovo is a humanitarian act which deserves our support?
answers: Then they are deluding themselves. The right of humanitarian intervention if it exists as a category in international law is premised on the good faith of those intervening. There is no doubt that washington and russia were acting in gross violation of the principles they professed when they invaded afghanistan.

questions: you think there is no difference between israel in 1948 and?
answers: Every two cases are different i was simply talking about scale. At the end of 1998 there was a cease fire in kosovo. Two thousand european monitors were introduced and there has been no break in this ever since.

questions: no president would risk this unless he either really believed in what he was doing or had some overwhelming american interest at stake?
answers: The united states is not going in there to save the oppressed. If we were we would not. What we are doing is exactly what britain and the us did in vietnam.

questions: what do you expect will be the resolution to this action?
answers: Some western leaders have begun talking about an eventual partition of kosovo. This would be an beeeep outcome because 90 percent of the province is albanian.

questions: what are the mechanisms through which these countries become increasingly dependent on international financial institutions?
answers: The first thing to bear in mind is that debt is not an economic problem. It is a political problem for the countries that are carrying it forward. The debtor countries do not have the resources to pay back the lenders.

questions: the debt is largely controlled by financial institutions like the imf?
answers: Yes but that is another form of robbery. The same is true of greece and other european countries. They have a debt crisis because of surpluses in the rich countries that they did not collect from the poor countries and because they made bad choices.

questions: how do you see this problem given that one of the imf is most important forms of control when giving a loan is to impose conditions such as the privatization of national industries?
answers: That is true and i have pointed that out. But we have to be a little careful. The privatizations were not the goal i think.

questions: who are the enemies today and how are they being created?
answers: The cold war was useful ideologically. Every time you carried out an atrocity you could say oh well cold turkey. That worked pretty well.

questions: and the drug war?
answers: Controlling the population in the united states is a big problem. In fact it is the biggest problem how do you control your own population. Well one way to control them is by having a foreign enemy.

questions: what kind of political and social system would you like to see?
answers: I am for the moment in favour of a one or a few state systems. But i think a democratic society has to overcome the dualism that is inherent in any system of power. In the us it is the ruling class and the mass of the population who are at the mercy of big business. Less so in other societies where the powerful rule by terror and intimidation.

questions: the latest is profit over people neoliberalism in the global order. welcome to talk of the nation.?
answers: Glad to be with you again.

questions: any comments on the state of the union to get us started?
answers: Well i did not listen to the whole thing but the transcript is essentially what i was just saying. So the major issue that was discussed was first one social security and what to do about it.

questions: so might this be a good time to to rebuild the way we talk about our our shared problems and and the way we try to find shared solutions?
answers: Well i think it is a very good idea. I do not know how much it can help but if you start talking about it you will find that a large part of the discussion is just vacuous. You can not even raise the question of whether it was right to do it let alone why it did not work.

questions: sure. sure?
answers: Well okay maybe the most striking example is has to do with the multilateral agreement on investment. That was such an uncontroversial case that it was even mentioned in the new york times without comment. A couple of days later the washington post ran an article by paul krugman who basically makes the same point. I mean it is uncontroversially wrong.

questions: dr. it is been about 35 years since i have seen your sister?
answers: Be glad to give you her regards you are a real life inspiration.

questions: i mean comparing the thin gruel of five years ago with the thin gruel of today is not really a comparison that would that would pay much pay much tribute to the idea that this a terrible thing that we have to be concerned about?
answers: Oh i totally agree. I am totally convinced that. My grandchildren will live through the 21st century in hotter climates than people have survived in the 19th century and there are all sorts of other catastrophes that are sure to ensue from continuing to burn fossil fuels. Just think about that for a moment.

questions: i i would i would i think agree with bill that there is a certain amount of acquiescence to the movement and dictates of big institutions not enough of a push back?
answers: Mm hmm. Well i for individuals alone to pushback is next to impossible. Some of us who have who enjoy a great deal of privilege access to resources and so on yeah we can do it if we want.

questions: oh. and that was one example. those were my comments?
answers: We are not talking about the middle east. We mean the united states sponsored and supported a military coup in uzbekistan which installed a brutal ultranationalist regime which carried out ethnic cleansing massive murder and forced the population into servitude. That is the official story.

questions: it is the kind of thing that if you stopped somebody on the street and asked them you have a fair chance of hearing?
answers: I agree but that is remember that that sample is from a very small sample and it does not tell us anything about the general principles. For example if i were to ask a similar question about a scientist who has done the same work but who is much wealthier than the scientist i would not expect a different result.

questions: right. thus thus kept off the table. but that is not to say?
answers: Kept out of the off-the-table and into the memory hole. And that essentially explains the whole thing.

questions: i am not sure if you are familiar with it. i assume you are professor?
answers: Well afraid i can not answer this question because i do not think any of us are even close to that kind of a scientific understanding. Maybe in the distant future we will be. But right now we are not doing any better or worse than anybody else at least in our basic understanding of the world.

questions: well it is it was the ter term meme was coined by richard dawkins in the last chapter of his book?
answers: Oh m yeah. Ok. so what is the meme. Well first of all it does not mean what you might think it means but what i am going to assume is that this is some kind of organised system of thought control and indoctrination and so the word meme is a very good description of it and i think one can give a good argument for its being widespread.

questions: the selfish gene?
answers: I yeah i do know. Okay. Sorry.

questions: in which he talked about you know?
answers: Yes i know.

questions: evolution as the competition among genes for places on the dna chain?
answers: Right but that is where the energy is.

questions: and after a while somebody is got to respond somebody is got to take note of that whether it is in a in a voting booth?
answers: Even in our private lives we are not immune to the influences of popular culture. So for example my wife and i who are very much a part of the jewish cultural tradition she came to america over 35 years ago and we have been together ever since. I do not see her every visit. She lives near here.

questions: or in a sh shopping center or supermarket or?
answers: Yeah. I i agree. Yeah i would agree that is the way it should be.

questions: well noam chomsky i am glad you were here today. thanks for joining us?
answers: Glad to be with you again. It is a real pleasure to talk to you and to listen to your comments.

questions: you have argued that any stance one takes on political economic social or even personal issues is ultimately based on some conception of human nature. why is this?
answers: Any position we take is based not only on our personal moral values but also our understanding of how the world works. You might as well bring them out as clearly as possible so that they can be discussed. Your point about personal values is certainly correct. I do not believe that you can generalize about human values just because they are universal.

questions: how do you defend this position against postmodernist critics who argue that there is no such thing as human nature and that all attempts to define it are guilty of reading other cultures in the light of western perceptions and values?
answers: Not even the most extreme poststructuralist can seriously argue this. They may claim that the exact properties of human sexuality or mental constitution are unknown but this is not a reasonable assumption since we do not have the relevant data. We can make educated guesses about what they will look like on the basis of what we know about the world and our own culture and society.

questions: are you suggesting everyone agrees about the nature of vice and virtue?
answers: In fact i think they probably have a very high measure of agreement. One strong bit of evidence for this is that everyone a genghis khan himmler bill gates creates stories of themselves where they interpret their actions as working for the benefit of human beings or non human persons.

questions: but there is also enormous diversity in what they do and defend as right to do?
answers: And there are all sorts of other differences too. Take something that you have probably heard about the british parliamentarian who got burned at the stake for supporting the kurds which is kind of shocking.

questions: are you wanting to argue that your understanding of human nature can give us a kind of objective understanding of the conditions of human flourishing?
answers: Now we are taking an essentialist position which the relativist would contradict. I am not willing to go that far. We can develop a stronger conception of what it means to be human through drawing on enlightenment thinking on the issue and so on.

questions: do you think even if there were the political will to achieve it that it might be impossible for ecological reasons to provide the necessary conditions for continued human flourishing?
answers: Humans may well be a nonviable organism. One of the consequences of not having ruled the world is that we do not have any rules of thumb for how best to manage the inevitable crises that will inevitably arise from human activities whatever the scale.

questions: do you think they are?
answers: It is very likely. From an evolutionary point of view higher intelligence seems to be maladaptive rather than adaptive. Biologically successful organisms have a rigid character and are well adapted to a certain environmental niche.

questions: do you think that different social and economic circumstances either block or reinforce certain dispositions that for example whatever there might be in the way of a natural tendency towards selfish and aggressive behaviour is reinforced by the capitalist market society?
answers: There is no doubt about it. Let is take germany for instance. During the nazis period there was a lively working class culture which was extremely threatening to the us industrialists.

questions: how come we remain both globally and locally so caught up in oppression?
answers: It is a serious question. Why are we born free and end up enslaved.

questions: is there a case here for viewing social factors as more determinant than biological factors?
answers: You can not say which factor is more decisive. They interact. Take the example of puberty small changes in nutrition can modify the onset by a factor of two or even terminate it altogether.

questions: can you say more on how you view this two edged process of possible political transformation?
answers: I am not in favour of people being in cages. On the other hand i think people ought to feel a certain degree of security about what they are doing. I do not think you have to make a decision on whether to go into a store to buy food or not.

questions: how is the aspiration for freedom being manifested today?
answers: The current period is incredibly encouraging. There is more popular activism in more areas than at any time i can remember labour struggles environmental issues women is rights children has rights respect for other cultures. I cannot think of a time when there have been so many people who were ready and eager to undertake direct action.

questions: how do you see the relationship between work and free time in a more liberated society?
answers: Polls in the us germany and elsewhere have shown that people value free liberated time over material goods. Therefore there are major propaganda efforts to reverse this. One reason over a trillion dollars a year is spent by the media on advertising is to try to undermine our natural tendency to seek pleasure in material things over creative activities.

questions: how do you envisage the development of radical movements in the future. do we need a uniting vision?
answers: Movements have to be developed by the activists themselves in response to local circumstances the possibilities the willingness to take risks the level of understanding. What needs to happen varies day by day. Sometimes it is a meeting sometimes a demonstration sometimes civil disobedience sometimes taking to the streets when the opportunity arises sometimes working within existing institutions sometimes facing severe repression. Depends on the circumstances.

questions: what is your take on the multilateral agreement on investment?
answers: It is disastrous. It would transfer decision making to an extraordinary extent into the hands of unaccountable private imperatives. There are many illustrations of this in the leaked u. s. labor department planning documents for the future.

questions: what are the forces behind the mai?
answers: They involve the oecd representing the governments of the richest countries which was trying to ram it through. The groups behind it were the major power centers of latin america the powerful government states the transnational corporations the international corporate sector and of course the state sector that is the public sector in the united states in particular.

questions: you have emphasized the involvement of national governments within this process but is not that ironic given the fact that the mai severely undermines the sovereignty of nation states?
answers: That is on purpose. The leaders of the national communities want to undermine their sovereignty. Remember what a nationalist community is.

questions: what was the nature of the grass roots effort opposing the mai?
answers: It actually started in canada. There the activism was so strong that it broke into the national media. So for about a year this is what i could find on the front pages of boston globe or some other national newspaper with no notice.

questions: was popular activism the prime factor in stopping the mai push?
answers: There were other issues i should say. There was a very significant increase in the late 1960s and the early 1970s when there really was mass protest against the vietnam war. And it was so severe that the united states had to back off a little bit.

questions: but still it is big news so why is not the mainstream press covering it?
answers: That is because they agree. The business press and the new york times are owned and run by big business. They are not newspapers of the people so they do not want the truth to get out but they can not ignore it because it threatens their business interests.

questions: is the mai dead in the water?
answers: No it is not. In fact there are interesting comments about that in henry kissinger is recent book. He is talking about the 1980s and early 1990s.

questions: do you see it as an important turn of events?
answers: There is some significance. We should not exaggerate it. If there are three major corporations controlling what is essentially public property and a public creation namely the internet telecommunications and so on that is not a whole lot better than one corporation controlling but it is maybe a minor difference.

questions: give us a little bit of historical context. s. corporate power the evolution of corporations?
answers: Here is a brief history a thumbnail sketch. There were corporations as far back as the 18th century and beyond. In the united states corporations were public bodies just like governments.

questions: how would a company like microsoft benefit from the mai?
answers: They could move capital freely. There would be no restrictions on anything they do. If they want to invest in places where there is competition they can. Take egypt for example which is a very poor country but one of the great material prizes in the world.

questions: economist brian arthur argues that with the rapidly changing nature of technology no one will remain in a monopoly position for long so that monopoly power in the technology industries is different than what we have historically seen and is nothing to worry about?
answers: But there never was monopoly or there very rarely was any monopoly. Take highly concentrated power systems like the energy industries. But they are not strictly speaking monopolies because there is no market in place.

questions: do you think the whole monopoly issue is something to be concerned about?
answers: These are oligopolies they are small groups of highly concentrated power systems which are integrated with one another. If one of them were to get total control of some system other powers probably would not allow it. In fact that is what you are seeing. A lot of the energy systems in the world are under state control.

questions: so you do not think bill gates is a latter day john d. rockefeller?
answers: John dewey. Standard oil did not want to do business with john dos reies because they thought it was going to undermine the whole industry. They were wrong.

questions: then in fact maybe there is a parallel there between gates and rockefeller or not?
answers: Think of the feudal system. You had kings and princes and bishops and lords and so on. They for the most part did not want power to be totally concentrated they expected a good deal of it to remain within their own domains but they also expected it should be democratic.

questions: how has that transfer from the public to the private sphere changed the internet?
answers: As long as it was under the control of the pentagon it stayed within the government system. When it became public it went through a lot of changes. The first was the major changes with the introduction of commercial internet access. [ that was in the late 1990s.]()

questions: what would it look like if it were under public control?
answers: It would look much like it did before except much more accessible because more people would have access to it. And with no constraints. People could just use it freely information sharing could be done without any barriers of any kind.

questions: and when you say that you are referring to the internet as it was 15 years ago?
answers: We are specifically talking about the web. But more generally the media has for most of this century and increasingly in recent years been under public control.

questions: are we looking at a new stage in global capitalism or is this just a continuation of business as usual?
answers: By gross measures contemporary globalization is bringing the world back to what it was about a century ago. In the early part of the century under basically british domination and the gold standard if you look at the amount of trade and then the financial flow and so on relative to the population in different countries relative share of national income it has been declining.

questions: and what kind of impacts there are around having technology being developed by corporations such as microsoft?
answers: I do not think there is really any answer to that. It depends who controls it. If it is being influenced and controlled by the disney corporation and others it will reflect their interests and those of the powerful behind the scenes. In the case of michael howard is work it was highly supportive of what he was doing but he felt there should be limits.

questions: so it gets back to the question of taking it back?
answers: That again is a question for action not for speculation. It is like asking 40 years ago what is the likelihood that we would have a minimal health care system like medicare. These things happen if people struggle for them.

questions: what kinds of things can people do to try to expand and reclaim democracy and the public space from corporations?
answers: Well the first thing they have to do is find out what is happening to them. So if you have none of that information you can not do much. For example it is impossible to oppose say the multilateral agreement on investment once it has been signed by almost all the countries even though they know it exists and is secret.

questions: what do you think about the potential of all the alternative media that is burgeoning on the internet given the current trends?
answers: It is a matter for action not for speculation. If you want to learn something get involved. There are many opportunities that have never arisen before and they can be taken.

questions: you have defined the war on drugs as an instrument of population control. how does it accomplish that?
answers: Mass murder. Lots of it goes on now it is called targeted killings. I mean these are just regular assassinations that go on all the time. A lot of them are not even reported.

questions: how does the war on drugs fit into this?
answers: Well one of the traditional and obvious ways of controlling people in every society whether it is a military dictatorship or a democracy is to frighten them. If people are frightened they will be willing cede authority to their superiors who will protect them ok i will let you run my life in order to protect me that sort of reasoning.

questions: in some other countries you just hang the rabble?
answers: Yes but in the u. s. you do not kill them you put them in jail.

questions: it is absolutely true but how do you prove it?
answers: Just by looking at the trend lines for marijuana. Marijuana use was peaking in the late 70 is but there was not much criminalization. You did not go to jail for having marijuana then because the people using it were nice folks like us the children of the rich.

questions: who benefits from incarcerating young black males?
answers: A lot of people. Poor people are basically superfluous for wealth production and therefore the wealthy want to get rid of them. The rich also frighten everyone else because if you are afraid of these people then you submit to state authority.

questions: house arrest for the masses?
answers: It is enough of an industry so that the major defense industry firms are interested you can read about it in the wall street journal. The big law firms and investment houses and so on want it fast it will protect them from liability. I mean if there is a mistake they can just write a check and have it erased.

questions: and most of these prisoners are nonviolent drug offenders?
answers: The enormous rate of growth of the prison population has been mostly drug related. The last figures i saw showed that over half the federal prisoners in state and over a quarter in federal prisons are for drug offenses.

questions: what effect does this have on the global economy?
answers: Well the united nations tries to monitor the international drug trade and their estimates are that it is probably larger than the transnational crime wave that we are involved in. So the us spends about a trillion dollars a year on counter terrorism and another trillion on nato military spending.

questions: what do you think of the us policy of offering trade and aid favors to countries who promulgate so called antidrug initiatives?
answers: Us programs generally work. Look at the war on drugs in cambodia or the counter insurgency war in central america. Programs are generally implemented and reduced the use of drugs generally increases.

questions: well anybody who looks into the history of american drug policies in this century?
answers: I am putting aside another factor altogether namely clandestine warfare. If you look into history it is quite striking that wherever there has been a serious effort to control an alien population you find that they have done it clandestinely. So the mongol invasions are a good example. The conquerors established what they called an earthly paradise for the aliens.

questions: where do you stand on drug legalization?
answers: Nobody knows what the effect would be. Anyone who tells you they know is just beeeep or lying because nobody really knows. These are things that have to be experimentally tried you can not prove anything.

questions: but alarmist drug propaganda programs like dare and the partnership for a drug free america is tv ads have been found to increase experimentation among teenagers?
answers: The question is what kind of education are you doing. Educational programs are not the only category. Education also has to do with the social circumstances in which drugs are used.

questions: has a moral obligation because of its capabilities to intervene in international affairs?
answers: We should i think bear in mind that moral concepts apply at root to people. States do have legal obligations but they are not moral agents though their citizens can influence them to act in morally responsible and legally admissible ways.

questions: what do you think are the most significant achievements and failures of the left over the last twenty years?
answers: You mean achievements of popular movements. Well one quite remarkable achievement were the solidarity movements which for the first time compelled the united states to restrain what would otherwise have been a much more intensive assault against vietnam. It is been almost a century since the military occupation of south viennam but this is something quite new.

questions: why do you think progressives were able to break through these barriers during the solidarity movements but are less able to now?
answers: Well there are different issues. It is one thing to try to block terrorist attacks against campesinos in central america. Quite another to attack the central institutions of state capitalist society the private financial and industrial institutions which are in effect private tyrannies and which by law are unaccountable to the public.

questions: how should the left organize in this kind of climate?
answers: Well in the traditional fashion but it has to face new issues.

questions: how about in the last ten years the late 1980s and the 1990s?
answers: It is a complicated time. For one thing during that period there was a lot of popular activism. There were some popular struggles in venezuela for example which were pretty dramatic chavez is women is movement and so on.

questions: how did you become politicized?
answers: That goes back to when i was four years old and seeing people coming to the door trying to sell rags so they could have enough food to eat and so on. Or going to church with my mother who was a housekeeper because we had to work during the day so she would have something to do.

questions: question why is it impossible for latin american nations to be sovereign and live free from interference by the united states?
answers: Well they can not live in the shadow of a violent and sadistic superpower that is committed to domination and control. No nation can. That includes not only the countries of latinate america but even much of the world.

questions: what will be the consequences?
answers: In 1959 60 the eisenhower administration made an explicit decision to overthrow the cuban government. There are planning documents from march 1960 and later from the kennedy administration that document this decision. The united states employed methods that ranged from a widespread campaign of terrorism to direct invasion and direct subversion.

questions: is it possible that the united states will take advantage of these circumstances by launching a military operation as in iraq?
answers: I think this will depend to a large extent on the u. s. domestic political situation and the situation within cuba. If some effort is made to reduce the threat of terrorism the possibility will increase because more people will want to oppose the atrocities and because there will be more support within the cuban community for such an action which would not only be effective but also courageous.

questions: like in panama?
answers: Yes panamanians are suffering just as much as the people in iraq. They have a horrible situation and i know of people who go to panamica and give talks and try to help. I do not know how much they succeed.

questions: if the reaction was a mistake what should they have done?
answers: I think they could have jailed those people. That would have been appropriate because they were detained for a terroristic act.

questions: in betancourt is case which is very different cuba opted for execution. was that a mistake?
answers: Yes it was an error and it would have been an even worse error to execute him. It is not a big secret. In the united states capital punishment has always been a death penalty issue.

questions: how could the cuban government fall into what you consider to be a trap?
answers: I think they feel they are trapped and there is not much they can do about it. As i said there are economic and diplomatic options but they do not seem very attractive. One possibility is to try to develop some kind of regional arrangement with at least israel and the emirates which would at worst keep the military forces separated from one another and from the civilian population.

questions: the state department says that it will not allow any more terrorist excursions from miami. can this be taken seriously?
answers: You can take it as seriously as you took it thirty years ago. If they want to stop terrorist travel there are ways to do it. Go back to the beginning.

questions: policy of aggression against cuba and its soft policy in relation to haiti?
answers: In reality there is no contrast it is the same policy. The u. s. has a policy which is to dominate the world by force a very beeeep policy and has been for 50 years.

questions: is this why they do not support aristide?
answers: The earliest documents relating to the overthrow of castro dating back to march 1960 are very revealing in this respect. During the eisenhower administration the national security council approved a resolution mandating that the united states overthrow the cuban regime and installing a democracy. That is exactly what they were doing.

questions: can you see the united states taking military action?
answers: That depends in part on the domestic political situation. The bush government is trying to build some kind of economic recovery before the elections some sort of temporary recovery so that bush can say that the situation is improving. After ten years of brutal economic mismanagement by reagan and bush the economy is in a bad state and the public is unhappy about it.

questions: here there are big solidarity movements who collect money to send oil to cuba. is their work going in the right direction?
answers: Well it is kind of misleading. I mean it does not pay much attention in fact most of it goes to support the dictatorships which is why it has virtually nothing to do with solidarity. If anything it would be a good thing to focus on that because otherwise you do not have to pay attention to this kind OF work. E.g.

questions: and was the recent congress in solidarity with cuba in new york a weak or strong start?
answers: It was not the congress i expected it to be. The usual suspects were there mostly representatives of the reagan administration the business community the traditional enemies the soviet union and others. A few dissidents like ronald regan of course.

questions: in terms of this visit what are cuba is interests and what are the pope is interests?
answers: As far as the cubans are concerned they are well aware that the us is intent on reestablishing relations with former enemy latin america and they do not want these relations to be harmed. So that is why they have been working hard to undermine any possibility of normalization of relations.

questions: in 1898 the united states sent the battleship maine to havana in 1998 the pope goes there. who is the more dangerous of the two?
answers: It is hard to say. History does not bear much on questions of right and wrong or good and evil or anything else. We know enough to know that major atrocities took place many centuries ago when appropriate and not in the name of some higher power. Ship names are a good measure of their scale.

questions: so past experience is no guide what the pope tried to do in nicaragua is no indication?
answers: It is very hard to say. The agenda that the us has pursued with particular vehemence and intensity ever since the contra attacks began has been to undermine any possibility of developing a negotiated settlement with nicaraguans.

questions: why did the united states not try to annex cuba at the end of the liberation war as had happened with puerto rico hawaii and guam?
answers: Remember they did not literally annex any of those places they just ceded them to the u. s. remember this was the war against vietnam which was a pretext and a cover up so you can not really annex anything. Cuba is technically annexed but it does not have any sovereignty.

questions: does the death of mas canosa open new possibilities or is it of only marginal importance?
answers: The question really is what the effect will be within the cuban community mainly in florida and a few other places.

questions: so one possibility for cuba is that it will go the way vietnam has?
answers: Well that is one prospect but there are others. Third world solidarity and people to people solidarity between the first and the second superpower could allow space for a very different set of developments within latin america altogether. Remember these divisions are not based on colors on maps no they are rooted in deep seated historical and geostrategic differences that have to be confronted and overcome.

questions: what is the guiding concept behind american interests and policy?
answers: The most infuential factors are of course domestic. The central interest is to maintain the functioning of the multinational com panies and their profits. Another to preserve the industrial and free trade system.

questions: what role does israel play in the us view?
answers: Exactly the role we have prescribed it forthwith in international affairs for 35 years. And it remains so even after 67. isis is a product of the severe repression and brutality imposed on the population under saddam hussein is brutal occupation. It is very similar to bin laden is excised memory hole.

questions: what role is assigned to the palestinians in this american strategy?
answers: Exactly the role the us has always played. It is their arab facade and we have to wear it well. They are our second largest trading partner and they have a major energy resource in central asia probably the third largest in the world.

questions: or is it just an instrument of power which aims to get rid of the palestinian problem?
answers: The concept here is pure power politics. Since 1971 the us has refused to consider any political solution to the conflict. It no longer insists on a total withdrawal from the occupied territories and its proxies are permitted to continue to administer them in their traditional ways. Settlement has been delayed repeatedly and with extreme brutality.

questions: so what does the future hold for the palestinians?
answers: It depends on what happens in palestine israel and the west generally. If some of the refugees are able to return and join the society it will be a revitalized paletinian society much like the one that existed before the us invasion. Or it could turn into something entirely new like afghans or latin americans.

questions: does zionism have anything to do with the fate of the palestinians?
answers: This is a very complex problem. It depends on what you mean by zIONIST. I was an outspoken and highly critical supporter of israeli nationalism until very recently.

questions: can germany and the other europeans challenge the us is global domination?
answers: They are already challenging it in asia. Because of their history and their spheres of interest this could also happen in the middle east. What takes place in saudi arabia or egypt could spread to latin america and africa.

questions: what does the world look like at the end of this century. who are the winners who are the losers?
answers: The gap between rich and poor has consistently widened since the 60s the main contibutor to this has been the growth of the population. Inequality and poverty between countries has increased social peace has come ever more into question. One can say this much for globalization it has marginalized the third world in most areas while opening new vistas for privileged western populations.

questions: which 220 years or so ago was the first battleground of the american revolution?
answers: You could put it that way. There was actually a massacre on the lexington green in which four people were killed.

questions: do you see much evidence of a revolutionary spirit in the america of the 1990s?
answers: You did not find evidence. You tried to find it. And you were unable to. Thanks very much for giving us the opportunity to talk to you briefly.

questions: is not that erection of barriers to democracy woven through the entire history of the united states?
answers: It goes back to the revolutionary war. The main one was the construction of what became the first great barrier to free expression of course in the country. And it went on to affect pretty much everything in later history.

questions: madison actually expected more of the rich did not he?
answers: What was his position. He was a moderate. The republican party at the time was essentially a parliamentary party and the moderate republican faction was opposed to the elevation of money to a higher position than it already was in the society. So that was not on the agenda.

questions: we really see that happening across history do not we?
answers: It is a battle right through history. It was not until the mid 19th century that the national territory of the united states was recognized as a state by the states of europe and japan. During that same period the september 7 attacks against south africa were declared illegal by a u. s. court.

questions: in that never ending struggle where do we stand today?
answers: My feeling is that we have essentially been through that struggle. There are a couple of points of inflection that could indicate a change in course though. So for example there was a brief period in the late 1960s when things were looking pretty grim.

questions: so is there a place for optimism?
answers: If you look over a long stretch i think there is agonizingly slow progress with plenty of suffering that does not have to be going on.

questions: at this point what do you see as the greatest threat to democracy?
answers: There are two threats. There is the threat of destruction of the species basically and the second threat which is environmental catastrophe. We are running out of time to deal with both of them so i think the only thing to do is to reduce the level of threats to each.

questions: how best do individuals respond?
answers: The same as they have all through history by educating themselves by organizing by developing constructive alternatives. We have many ways to do it. The only thing we need is a spark. Spark it is there.

questions: on the political front you have loaned your name to the new party?
answers: That is one of the choices that can be made. There are many others you can think of. We do not have a lot of time but there is a good chance that one or another of us will be a candidate some day for office.

questions: is that because they integrate both electoral and activist strategies?
answers: Of course. They have a difference. In the us there is basically one party the business party. It has two factions called democrats and republicans which are somewhat different but carry out variations on the theme of diminishing opportunities.

questions: how have you maintained a revolutionary spirit a radical spirit across the decades?
answers: When you see suffering and oppression and terror what is the question. It has seemed to me kind of obvious since early childhood that if humans are going to survive and go on to create the wonderful things that they are creating for themselves and future generations they have to begin from a very small base of fundamentals which is what most of us have been doing since the early settler period.

questions: bill clinton is always complaining and newt gingrich about their treatment by the press. how do you reconcile these two story lines?
answers: Well first of all it is not my position that they are part of the system. No one doubts that the big media are major corporations parts of bigger conglomerates funded by advertisers and so on. But what you say about them is more or less accurate just as a comment. 2 nd place the term propaganda as used in the propaganda system has two meanings.

questions: do you think the advent of the web and the ability of people to talk to each other more is going to change our political system and the way things work?
answers: Depends who controls it. You could have asked the same question about radio television print. In fact when print became established it was used initially very effectively by traveling radical levelers radical democrats to try to undermine the power system with their pamphlets and so on and it worked very well.

questions: what would you predict is going to happen?
answers: You can not predict the weather i would not try to predict human affairs. We do not understand enough. The issue in this case i think is not so much the prediction but rather the implementation.

questions: and what would you suggest that folks do who are concerned with this issue?
answers: For example i think people should take a close look at the telecommunications act of last year that was passed without public discussion. It was treated as a business story though it is surely a major public interest story and it has a lot of significance. One of the things that is in the act is a new telecommunications regulation that requires telecommunications companies to have facilities in all 50 states.

questions: have you given much thought to these ideas of direct democracy of using the web and other electronic interactive technologies to transform how our democracy works?
answers: Well it is already happened. There have been groups that have used the internet very imaginatively to transfer information to enlighten to bring to people is attention things they would otherwise not know. Take say the last nobel prize that was just given a couple months ago to the east timorese leaders.

questions: what are the numbers on that?
