answers: Well the norwegian committee that gave the prize estimated the total dead in the last 20 years as about a third of the population. Maybe that is high maybe low anyway its substantial. The united states has been involved decisively since the beginning still is.

questions: do you think that humans have an instinct for freedom as strong as i do not know the sexual instinct or the instinct for food and water. what do you assume on that point?
answers: I assume that it is true and that i am perfectly right in doing so. One cannot assume anything beyond what one can demonstrate to be true.

questions: and i am curious if you think that this represents an advance in our understanding of the human condition and any improvement in getting closer to the truth of things?
answers: Well metaphors are metaphors. If they are a stimulus to imagination fine. Let your imagination be stimulated.  you have found a way to stimulate the imagination in a certain way.

questions: do you think we are any closer to understanding the really important questions than we were 2 000 years ago?
answers: Very striking. If you go back to say the greeks and look at the range of questions they asked most of them we still dont have the answers. We can learn a lot from them but there are some questions that are not being asked and that tells us something about the state of the science.

questions: so it comes down to making existential leaps into the future and acting on our feelings and instincts more than any real hope of understanding?
answers: There is a fair amount to say about that. But let is take a look at the issue at its most fundamental level. Is it a question of whether we have the will power to make the necessary changes and if not then what are the realistic possibilities for bringing about those changes if we do not have those will and the resources.

questions: what do you suggest to your readers as a course of practical action?
answers: There are several choices. One choice is to join the overwhelming international consensus which has been virtually unanimous in opposing forceful intervention for more than 30 years.

questions: what do you suggest for the common persons that want to attack the mechanisms of oppression that you describe so precisely in your books. what can they do?
answers: I am afraid i can only repeat what i have already said. Perhaps i might add that i never hear these questions from the ordinary person who wants to do good. They may invite me to speak and read the things i write and ask questions.

questions: why might people be driven to choose profound limits to their freedom of actions?
answers: Under all conditions people tend to internalise values and see themselves as acting freely. I am not sure this is more true under more authoritarian conditions. Thus in a brutal state people may adopt the values but not internallyise them whereas when they have more freedom and are able to exercise some control over their own lives they may do so in overwhelming numbers.

questions: do you think language is becoming less meaningful as society becomes increasingly sloganistic?
answers: I do not know whether use of language has become so ubiquitous that it is no longer a sign of superficiality or if it has simply declined. On the other hand if use declines it may be that the signal is lost. I have seen this happen in some cases.

questions: do you believe in consistent full open accountability of government agencies?
answers: Accountable to the public. That would mean to me an end to secret rulings secret interpretations bureaucratic red tape and so on. It has to come from the bottom up.

questions: do names and language cast their own spell?
answers: Linguistic expressions carry all sorts of connotations. In technical usage one tries to divest them of such associations. The question that seems to be lurking here is a different one namely is the technical term that has been selected an appropriate one on scientific grounds.

questions: may we not argue that the 1986 adoption of the finite term hiv by the ictv was a fascistic imposition?
answers: I do not agree. I think the notion of imposition is too vague to be useful for doctrinal purposes. Imposition of a term is one thing. Denial is quite another.

questions: does the media generally not articulate uncertainty?
answers: I do not understand what it means to say x is only a theory whether x comes from science or not. Any theory that does not speak of very little is immediately dismissed as hopelessly underdeveloped. We have all read paul mattick is critique of radical behaviorism which basically holds that the only way to understand the world is to construct explanatory theories as best we can.

questions: what tools does a social analyst like yourself use to distinguish between illusion and material reality?
answers: If any tools are known i am unaware of them. We use our intelligence as best we can. That is all we have available to us.

questions: what gives you confidence when appropriate that you have successfully distinguished between superstition and rational reality. is any theory ever fully vindicated?
answers: Theories are always being developed to give a fuller understanding of what is sometimes called the rational side of human experience. As always the results are mixed. Some theories seem to have enormous support while at the other extreme there is strong evidence to show that they are barely treading water. (for a review see e.g.

questions: what might be some consequences of the apparently growing dependence in western culture at least on technological probing of reality?
answers: If one is interested in understanding the world one will use whatever technology is available and useful for the task. If reliance on technology displaces other and better means to gain understanding one does not have to bother about understanding. As for becoming a better understander one can perfectly well try both and see which one succeeds where.

questions: regarding safe sex within the gay community now and indeed in general we have a moral majority. do you think it is to be challenged?
answers: I presume polls would show that most people would approve of safer sex rather than unsafe sex and that inquiry would find that many choose the latter nonetheless. But i am probably missing the point. The question is not what i think about it but how best to act on that judgment. Same with regard to safe beeeep sex for example.

questions: can one reasonably detect similarities between these legislations and their moral incitements and for example religiously motivated legislation in the issues of abortion or homosexuality or racial equality?
answers: It is hard to say. There are many factors that impel people to act in particular ways. One factor that is common to all of these acts is the threat of punishment or even death.

questions: if public health systems are not working in the interests of the public how might people respond to the possibility that their health is being compromised by economic forces?
answers: I think that honest people should seek to understand how the political system works and work to make it as responsive as possible to their interests but that seems close to truism. How should this be done.

questions: do you think that in order to push for change continuum must make compromises with the establishment?
answers: What tactics continuum should follow i can not say. I do not mean to suggest that tactical decisions are insignificant on the contrary they regularly have direct and often substantial human consequences and therefore require careful thought and attention. But choice of tactics depends on goals and an assessment of the circumstances. Considerations of effectiveness and cost are rarely relevant.

questions: where does the popular language of our biological identities derive from?
answers: I do not see any particular problem in referring to the body is defences against disease etc. The other terms you mention are picturesque presumably used to attract attention. In a paper in an academic journal they would be out of place except that they are appropriate terms for this discussion.

questions: what are the best political purposes of conferences?
answers: My feeling is that they should be used for the raising of issues that are important to people. Not just for signing petitions or attending protests. And the same is true of labor actions which are also a way of raising issues.

questions: so in essence you started to look at language from the point of view of acquisition and comparing what experience children have and contrasting that with the knowledge that they seem to express when they learn to speak?
answers: Which is a slight shift from what was done. Actually it makes a lot of sense. If you were to ask me what my theory of language was I would have a hard time putting it into words but here it is. The language capacity is not a property of the human species it belongs to the rest of nature.

questions: what is it about the grammars of natural language that can not be inferred just from the input?
answers: To infer anything from an input you have to have a specific method of deriving information that leads you to that result. So we ask what aspect of grammar forces us to assume that there are highly specific ways of getting the result and no simpler way. Answer every aspect.

questions: how does this relate to the children in nicaragua and their experience?
answers: Well there is a preliminary point that has to be established and that is that so called sign language involves the same or similar mechanisms as spoken language. That was not assumed some years ago but now there are pretty strong arguments to indicate that it is true. So it looks as though when you study sign languages you are studying a different manifestation of very much the very same internal systems.

questions: we know that a child on their own exposed to no input does not acquire a language?
answers: No we do not actually understand that. All we learn is that it does if you look at it later in life. But many of the things that engender language learning are very simple and therefore might very well be directly relevant to the acquisition of language as opposed to being just an incidental by product of stimulation of some system.

questions: what are the implications of this natural experiment?
answers: It should provide further understanding of exactly what is needed in order to get the system working and just why it takes certain forms and not others. Here you have a case where you can have minimised the input. And therefore when you look at the output you learn more about the initial state which in turn allows you to evolve the structure of the result.

questions: does this give us additional insight into the discontinuity between gesture and true language?
answers: It could and that discontinuity is not too well understood. Humans have complicated gestural systems. I am doing all sorts of things with my hands and there is all kind of body language as it is sometimes called.

questions: why is it that children have this incredible ability to actually create a language when normally they are only required to learn an already existing language?
answers: Well superficially it may seem surprising that a child should be designed engineered if you like to create language from nothing. But when you think about it it is not surprising. Every child creates language at some level just as every human creates a visual system from some data.

questions: i want you to know that you are probably the ah noam chomsky books are the ones most prominently featured on the rage tour bus. so it is a privilege?
answers: So i have heard. Glad to hear that. Thank you very much. [laughter] ok. good to talk to you bye.

questions: in your opinion in what sense is our society democratic?
answers: Well i should say that if that is true an awful lot people do not believe it. A gallup poll for years has been regularly asking people who they think the government works for and it has usually been running about 50 saying the few and the special interests not the people. Last year it went up to 82 percent.

questions: right and so that is why the majority of eligible voters just stays home on election day?
answers: Yeah. In fact even the things like say the i read recently that even measures to increase voters registration are mostly drawing in wealthier people. Poorer people apparently just do not see any value in it.

questions: well another unquestionable idea is that people are naturally competitive and that therefore capitalism is the only proper way to organize society. do you agree?
answers: Look around you. In a family for example if the parents are hungry do they steal food from the children. They would if they were competitive.

questions: why do people accept this and submit to it?
answers: That has not been easy. It is been pretty hard to break out of the depression. And i have had to think about it a lot.

questions: is the gap between rich and poor increasing now and why?
answers: It is definitely increasing. There is no questions about that. Inequality has been increasing very sharply.

questions: take us briefly through the war crimes committed by each president?
answers: I have done that in print a couple of times. Well with truman you could start with shortly after he entered office there was the bombing of hiroshima which maybe one could give an argument for well i do not think so but it is close to impossible to give a justification for it.

questions: you have also written that our education system is a system of indoctrination designed to induce obedience and passivity. explain how this works?
answers: I think we all know that from our own experiences. Starting with kindergarten and first grade the main requirement is that you do what you are told.

questions: is that a misconception and if not why is modern society breeding insecurities?
answers: Well the society is definitely being driven in that direction by the exigencies of the neoliberal era. But that is perfectly objective i mean you can not prove it. It is true that the state and the corporate sector rely heavily on what economist dean baker calls the conservative nanny state that they nourish to ensure they have enough resources to carry out their tyrannical rule.

questions: explain the two concepts of manufacturing consent and necessary illusions.?
answers: Actually both of those are terms that we my colleague ed herman and i we did not invent them but we use them interchangeably. The term manufacturing Consent comes from walter lippman the dean of american journalism and one of the most highly respected public intellectuals of his generation.

questions: do you think that within the realm of entertainment that there are things which are threatening to the system of domination and the veil of disinformation?
answers: There is well i should say that i do not know much about this part of the world. But there can be no question that parts of it are dangerous. So for example if there were anybody who really wanted to undermine the cuban missile crisis for good they would not have launched the secret war against south vietnam.

questions: what sort of society do you envision as one that would not be based on exploitation or domination and how would we get there from here?
answers: I do not really understand the question. It is kind of interesting. I am asked that question constantly in maybe a dozen e mails a night or in talks and so on and i always seem to be at a loss to answer because i can not think of an answer. This is a very important question and definitely too complex for me to respond adequately to it here.

questions: i will ask you just a quick question and i will let you get on to your summer vacation?
answers: Back to work i am afraid.

questions: are you a fan of any particular kind of music and can we play a request for you?
answers: If i told you what my tastes where it would be a horror story. But anyway i like the bach solo cello suites from the 1930s and so on.

questions: oh no you go right ahead. shock me?
answers: That's not really my thing. Contact me if you want a different response. Language permits us to express all our secrets. It affects everything we see every moment of our lives.

questions: our cd catalog is pretty large try me?
answers: I would not even know what to say. It is overwhelming. There are things i have never heard of maybe in a million years that are on there if you look.

questions: anything in r b or pop music. anything that rings a bell?
answers: I am so ignorant it is not even worth asking me. I sort of knew something when my kids were around but that is a lot of years ago. Anyway i can not speak for them.

questions: well we were fighting communism is what we were told?
answers: It was not told to us that we are fighting a communist enemy. It would not have surprised anyone who knew what the enemy was. In fact it is not even mentioned in the united states.

questions: what does it have to do with then?
answers: Exactly what planners said. Since 1971 the egyptian military dictatorship has been carrying out a harsh brutal repression a major factor in the us israeli rejection of the oslo accord. They basically said you can not have a two state solution.

questions: but what is it now. who is the enemy?
answers: Same as it always was. In fact it is been escalated quite sharply in the last 10 years. The worst place to be is in central america where the military and intelligence are most powerful.

questions: high tech industry but not high tech high speed rail high tech environmental protection equipment?
answers: No because that is not good for investors. High technology indus the united states in fact destroyed the rail system and created a huge highway airway system because railways are too efficient. You do not want highly efficient rail systems.

questions: so when you say the rails are too efficient i mean cars they break down and they got to be replaced and tires need to be replaced and gasoline needs to be put in them in a constant way?
answers: Right. Exactly. Yes it is true.

questions: you are saying though that pentagon spending is a de facto industrial policy?
answers: There are no conservatives in the united states. The people who call themselves conservatives like the heritage foundation or gingrich are believers in are radical statists. Spending money on the military supersedes all other spending.

questions: or pour it into again the domestic kinds of goods that people you would think would support?
answers: Again you have to ask the question of why. These are popular forces. If you want to understand what is going on in the world ask yourself what makes them tick.

questions: what replaces anticommunism as a common thread in the united states?
answers: Well it is been a problem for us propagandists and journals of opinion for decades and they just do not care anymore. It used to be called anticommunism now it has been called just support terrorism. If you look at the studies of public opinion undertaken by the leading us polling agencies they come to the same conclusion.

questions: drug trade?
answers: Yeah drug traffickers. I mean they have been trying just about everything. The latest one is islamic fundamentalists and you know by now it is just welfare mothers immigrants.

questions: sell their products?
answers: Yeah sell your product. And if some cuban company was producing jet planes and parts for those planes they would not be able to compete. The fact of the matter is that the united states does not want those parts.

questions: so this is the american dream that you go after with the house the car the job?
answers: A special version of it. Now one there are several parts of that however. One is keep private power invisible to the public and that is critical. I mean the other part is concentration of political power in the hands of a tiny percentage of the population which is frightening.

questions: well do not were not we taught to love the flag and in that sense?
answers: That is jingoism in its purest form. I mean did not think about it much but every now and again you read that the us is taking over the world and we have to defend ourselves and that sort of thing. Well if you thought about that you would laugh it is absurd.

questions: love the country?
answers: You are supposed to love me, right? So you take me to city hall and show me how to vote. Then you go home and your wife makes me an omelette and you eat it while you watch football.

questions: and those private hands are?
answers: Corporations which is a totalitarian institution. People are unhappy. A lot of things are going wrong with their lives their sense of security things like healthcare costs are out of control.

questions: they will actually use the unknown or instability much more general?
answers: Yes just to keep people frightened. I mean people have to be kept frightened atomized. They have got to have their attention diverted away from true power which is trying to undermine democracy and sovereignty.

questions: again people like newt gingrich will point to the media in this country and label them the liberal cultural elite media saying that the major networks for example are part of the are liberal in essence?
answers: I agree with him. They are liberals but the liberals are the main commissars. I mean this is not even a question i am asking. Bernard lewis who is professor of law at harvard pointed out in an interview that there is no such thing as a liberal media.

questions: and what role if any would the us play in that kind of structure?
answers: Well it is interesting to watch american elite opinion react to this the way it did in the case of the iraq war. The usual way. Reaction is contemptuous dismissal without comment as appropriate. Shift to ridicule.

questions: is there a place for a strengthened un and an international say un standing army and that kind of thing?
answers: Oh sure. There would in fact be great strength if the united states left to itself the enormous problems it is faced with in the world. But it can do very little without the other powers.

questions: a strong un is not you are saying in the us best interests?
answers: For the united states that is frankly irrelevant. For example it is irrelevant what europe thinks about it. If eu leaders met in spain and decided we are going to attack iran they would find a way to do it without us authorization.

questions: from that?
answers: Because skinnerian behaviorism is off the wall. It is as hopeless a project as trying to explain that the onset of puberty results from social training. But i really do not know whether skinners still maintains this extreme position or whether they have simply given up completely.

questions: you took a very cautious approach. could you elaborate on your position?
answers: My position on the agreement then and now is that it was a complete capitulation by the plo to the long standing rejectionism of israel and the us. That is one of the major issues of middle eastern diplomacy over the last twenty years in which there has been no progress at all.

questions: yet now they are willing to negotiate with the plo. how do you evaluate those arguments?
answers: These are two questions. One has to do with american political culture and the second with international relations generally. The latter is a much more debatable question.

questions: what i would like to ask you is what you see as the emerging regional scenario and about us ambition in that part of the world?
answers: The effective by passing of this resolution is interesting. It essentially codifies a long standing us policy. For decades the us has been trying to strangle and control the arab world by force.

questions: i truly believe that we made an error not of values and intentions but of judgment and capabilities.?
answers: Actually he is correct about the values. If somebody tries to disobey us our values are that they have to be crushed and massacred. Those are our priorities.

questions: he is sort of taken the nazi nuremberg defense following orders allegiance to the fuhrer that is why he did not speak out while he was secretary of defense?
answers: I do not agree. He does not recognize that anything wrong was done. So there is no question of a defense.

questions: on macneil lehrer he now says he had misgivings about the policies?
answers: There were certainly some misGivens in the background. But the misGeneral is that they did not have to resort to massive terror and destruction to achieve their ends.

questions: long before mcnamara wrote this book you had compared him to lenin. what did you mean by that?
answers: I compared some passages of articles of his in the late 1960s speeches on management and the necessity of management how a well managed society controlled from above was the ultimate in freedom. The reason is if you have really good management you do not have to worry about externalities.

questions: what do you think the newspaper of record has in mind in comparing the sixties with what is happening in the nineties?
answers: That makes perfect sense from their point of view. As far as the advertisers are concerned they want to be able to denigrate the opposition and to associate the movement with drug use and so on.

questions: does the popularity of the film surprise you. because it is enormous?
answers: Well actually the fact that it has taken off is a little surprising. I mean there has been a very interesting phenomenon in the arts world the last ten years or so which is the rise of celebrity culture. And i think a lot of that is due to the celebrity aspects of what is becoming a mass audience oriented audience.

questions: i am surprised you have never seen it?
answers: Well partly because my wife died a couple of years ago and i have been pretty much confined to my own time so i do not see a lot of the stuff that goes on. But also i was not really a part of it in the early sixties.

questions: tell me what we learn about the way the media works by the way the cuba story is being dealt with?
answers: It is not a big secret. I do not know how old you are but i lived through both of them. The first was the soviet missile crisis which was a very serious crisis.

questions: it is presented by whom?
answers: By the u. s. media and opinion. See my monroe doctrine on the media for further discussion.

questions: has media concentration increased significantly since you wrote manufacturing consent?
answers: I should clarify something which was also one of the reasons i was skeptical about the film. The book that you are referring to is a co authored book and in fact the lead author who more or less did the framework for it is edward herman. He is an economist at the university of pennsylvania and he has a very good economic history of american business.

questions: quite a story?
answers: Incidentally this story is been well known for twenty years but it does not bother anyone. In fact about the only person i know who is even commented on it is ben bagdikian who has written very well about media concentration and who also mentioned this case and another case that he knows about.

questions: and why do you suppose that is?
answers: Because we are at the dissident fringe. It is just like not reporting terrorism when it happens and the victims are nice people ordinary people who happen to be Muslim. When the bombers attack you can not just dismiss it on moral grounds you have got to deal with the evidence.

questions: so what social purpose do you see the media playing?
answers: Well you can not characterize it in a phrase. It is complicated. But to a sort of a first approximation the organized media behave exactly as you would expect institutions of that character to behave under conditions of subordination to power.

questions: do you think that the multiplicity of tv channels is good news or bad news?
answers: You could ask the same question about the discovery of the printing press. Depends how it is used. Technology is usually pretty neutral except in extreme cases. Media concentration is a good measure of democracy.

questions: professor chomsky how wired are you?
answers: Oh i am a kind of a luddite. I very reluctantly agree to use any technology. In fact about the only reason i have a computer is because my teenage son was beginning to look at me with such contempt and ridicule that i thought i would better do it. But of course i do not use computers because i find them extremely inefficient.

questions: are you on the net?
answers: No. Although indirectly i am because i have a lot of friends who are and have been involved in this stuff for a long time so they send stuff off to me. Including my wife who is a high tech freak.

questions: oh yeah. what an interesting household you must live in?
answers: Yeah i do not know a radio from a tape recorder but she goes around fixing everything and all that stuff. Incidentally i have been in an electronics lab for forty years so it takes a little work not to know it.

questions: is it hard to be to be you?
answers: It is yeah the hardest thing that i find is you know staying up at night not sleeping thinking of all the thousands of requests i have got there that are just desperately trying to get through to people because they just cannot find anything that is on the radio or in the newspapers that says what it says. That really is a struggle.

questions: your work is often reviewed without as you have said the batting of an eyelash. do you never get discouraged?
answers: I am not expecting to be applauded by people in faculty clubs and editorial offices but that is not my audience. I mean i feel good about it when i well i was in india a couple of weeks ago and visited rural self governing villages and the people there were happy to meet me and talk to me about the problems they were facing.

questions: is it perhaps proof that you are at least partly right that for the most part your ideas and analysis of the media are ignored by the media?
answers: It is not just the press though. Every popular movement there is going to be something that is ignored or downplayed. Take the environmental movement for example the toothpaste industry. Nobody cares that much about the environment but when you bring it up in the context of business interests it does not matter too much because the interests are mostly supressed.

questions: in reviews of your work the comparison between you and bertrand russell or george orwell surfaces. are you comfortable with those comparisons?
answers: I do not feel part of that company. Both of them are people who i very much admire. In fact the one big picture up in my office is bernard lewis the american imperialist who actually invented the phrase humanitarian intervention.

questions: that is in the index is not it?
answers: Yeah those are the indices. These are not the judgments of experts.

questions: and fifty years later are you more optimistic or pessimistic than george orwell?
answers: I do not regard the issue of optimism and pessimism as meaning anything. Say back in the early sixties when i started getting seriously active in protest work i was hopelessly pessimistic.

questions: professor chomsky thank you for your time?
answers: Glad to have a chance to talk to you. It is a pleasure to be with you again.

questions: you have often quoted him describing the vile maxim of the masters of mankind all for ourselves and nothing for other people.?
answers: I did not do any research at all on smith. I just read him. There is no research because he is a self described anarchist.

questions: you are very patient with people particularly people who ask the most inane kinds of questions. is this something you have cultivated?
answers: First of all i am usually fuming inside so what you see on the outside is not necessarily what is inside. But as far as questions the only thing i ever get irritated about is elite intellectuals the stuff they do i do find irritating. I should not.

questions: at the mellon lecture that you gave in chicago you focused primarily on the ideas of john dewey and bertrand russell?
answers: These were highly libertarian ideas if i remember. De wey himself comes straight from the american mainstream. People who read what he actually said would now consider him some far out radical or something.

questions: you said that he promoted the idea that education is not to be viewed as something like filling a vessel with water but rather assisting a flower to grow in its own way?
answers: That is an eighteenth century idea. I do not know if russell knew about it or reinvented it but you read that as standard in early enlightenment literature. The enlightenment believed that knowledge is produced by the exercise of intelligence internal to a person not something imposed on him by some external authority.

questions: could you elaborate as to what you feel are the actual ideological and systemic elements that inform the history of violence in our society?
answers: There are elements of the society that have been there since the 19th century and have had a powerful effect on the violence that we see today. These were the so called labor unions which were basically radical democratic groups which tried to take public control of industry.

questions: in your estimation where on the spectrum of capitalist practices is the united states presently situated?
answers: To begin with we should qualify the statement. There is no such thing as a socialist society. I do not think there ever was or ever will be a society centred on exploitation or oppression.

questions: how does the money flow from the poor to the rich?
answers: Here we are at mit which is part of the system whereby poor people fund high technology industries. We have offices and things because the whole system of public funding meaning taxpayers ends up supporting research and development. If it is profitable the technology goes right off to high tech industries so we get computers and the internet and so on.

questions: there sure are a lot of government license plates out in the parking lots?
answers: Yeah but it is not really a license plate it was a symbol. It showed you could go to jail for three years if you did not pay attention to these things. And then when you got out and went to the community college it became a job because you had to have a high school diploma. That was the whole system of control.

questions: can you elaborate on other ways that the privileged benefit from this enormous system of subsidies?
answers: On top of the pentagon system there are the straight welfare payments. If you have a home mortgage you get a tax rebate. An increasing percentage of your income goes to the top one percent of earners a very high percentage.

questions: what are some of the central ways that these social and economic policies and practices affect the lives of youth in this country?
answers: One aspect of this specifically with regard to children is something that is not discussed much here in the united states. There is been a war against children and families for the last fifteen years a real war. You can see it in measures like the school lunch program which is cut back and it is going up again now that nutrition assistance is being reduced.

questions: and we have only just started to see the beginning of it?
answers: Oh yeah. It is going to get worse because now they want to extend the war against families in the name of family values and they will get away with it just as newt gingrich got away without facing any charges for speaking truth to power. Now what do they do with all these people who are supposed to be their cannon fodder.

questions: one major detrimental result of capitalist social relations which emphasizes money and acquisition over caring for people is basic needs and fostering community is that it works to fashion children is identities and the ways in which they interact socially around the excesses of marketing and consumption?
answers: It is certainly a cultural product. There is no questioning the fact that if you are in a store and you want to buy a sandwich or a drink you go to the store. I do not think you would ever think that you were harming the community by not purchasing from them i assume you simply donot care about them.

questions: so it not only justifies the violence against the scapegoats but diverts attention from the other violence being done to the general population?
answers: Divert attention sure. In fact you can see this very clearly in polls. People have repeatedly been asked to estimate how they think the federal budget is spent and they have guessed way off on various issues.

questions: conservative media representations of illegal aliens continually work to convince the general public that they are somehow responsible for this country is multi trillion dollar debt?
answers: The debt is largely the product of government actions. It was not always this way. Take the us v. britain case for example.

questions: which is something we never hear from the democrats?
answers: Rarely because they agree. Look there was a democratic congress they basically went along with everything that obama is doing. And they did pass some very progressive pieces of legislation.

questions: people being criminalized are being scapegoated and incarceration becomes the big business solution to the problem.?
answers: Exactly for example the drug war which was almost completely phony was simply used as a technique of incarceration. There was a huge increase in imprisonment during the reagan years and some enormous percentage of it like two thirds was for drug use. You can see why it was used.

questions: would not you say that the same is true of the war on drugs abroad?
answers: Yes it has little effect on the production and sale of drugs but has lots of effect controlling people. So in colombia the counter insurgency war has had no impact on drug production it is had a huge effect. In fact cocaine production has shot up in the israeli occupied golan heights and that is after the bombing which incidentally is not a secret incidentally everyone knows.

questions: if they see too much of reality they may set themselves to change it?
answers: There is a great deal to say about this but let is turn to the specific issue of israel and its nuclear programs.

questions: how do schools and institutions of education which play a significant role in the ongoing formative nature of culture identity and social relations by directly influencing children is ways of seeing themselves and others in the world contribute to this colonizing of people is minds?
answers: Well every possible way. It starts in kindergarten the school system tries to repress independence and independence of thought and it turns out that a large part of what passes for education in this country is just a form of indoctrination designed to induce obedience and passivity. Kids and other people are not induced to challenge and question but they are drilled into obedience.

questions: how does this manufacturing of consent happen in the larger social and political spheres and in business and corporate sectors?
answers: When you talk about the state and the business community in this country it is extremely hard to separate them. There is a very substantial class of people who are called stakeholders and who in fact form the basis for policy formation and implementation. They include the mass of the population the professionals the corporate sector the wealthy professionals and so on.

questions: and people generally buy into such representations?
answers: Because there is so much indoctrination that many people can not even understand the word profits. If you try using the words profits around harvard for example in the kennedy school of government if someone says clinton is out there getting profits for rich americans then people would be appalled is he some kind of conspiracy theorist. Marxist.

questions: s. history. those words are seldom even in the textbooks?
answers: Well it is a little better than it used to be but not much. Much of history is just wiped out. We just went through a war in central america in which hundreds of thousands of people were slaughtered and countries destroyed huge terror and economic warfare all directed against the united states and its clients.

questions: if people are honest in their critique of the system in the united states they are either declared non intellectual or as you state derided as anti american marxist or conspiracy theorists and removed from the public media?
answers: It is not really a contradiction it perfectly normal under this system of control. For one thing i am on the radio and television and writing articles all over the world not here. And that is to be expected i suppose.

questions: and in light of the recent republican repositioning of power what are the possibilities of such counter discourses?
answers: It is not just the republicans. It was even the left in the united states which was quite frightened by what was going on. So for example during the vietnam war the peak of protest was against the war in indochina.

questions: in terms of teachers in this country who express the desire to work towards more democratic social change what do you think they could do?
answers: It is easy for me to talk but the fact is if you are in a classroom and you try to act like an honest independent person you would probably be thrown out. The school board will not like it especially if its made up of wealthy parents they are not going to like that. So you have to create an atmosphere of obedience passivity.

questions: while you certainly embrace critical education what do you think are its realistic possibilities here in the united states?
answers: It is just not going to be allowed because it would be too subversive. You can teach students to think for themselves in everything they do no matter how complex or intricate or rich or poor or whatever. It does not matter whether the equipment is there or not because you do not have to have it.

questions: how can you talk about moral development and violence without talking about the larger social cultural and economic environments in which people live and develop?
answers: You can not. On the other hand if you simply talk abstractly about these things you are not going to be able to address them. So you have to think of the social and cultural environment in terms of interactions among people and things like that. Link is an excellent example of that kind of thinking about social organization.

questions: the term propaganda is neither used in the media nor the academy in reference to this country is practices as if propaganda only functions in places like the former soviet union or nazi germany?
answers: We have a very free press. I do not know how old you are but it was not too long ago that we had a two part series on new york times about the new school. The first part was a review of what they called the propaganda of the century. Now that is not propaganda as far as i know it is just plain old business as usual.

questions: they actually believe that they live in a truly democratic society?
answers: I suppose that around harvard they do. But if you look at the polls half the population thinks that both political parties should be dismantled. Is that living in democracy.

questions: given the implications of your work and what we have said in the last hour what are the possibilities for fulfilling a progressive vision of a future social order one that actively incorporates the majority of the population in nonviolent political struggle resistance and social transformation?
answers: As everyone has always known the best way to defend civil liberties is to collectively build a movement for social change that has broad based appeal that encourages free and open discussion and offers a wide variety of options for public expression.

questions: in the context of everyday life in this country where does such dissention begin when the deck is so clearly stacked against popular struggle?
answers: The general population has lots of cards. People can organize initiate demonstrations write letters and vote. They can form unions and other grass roots organizations political clubs even an opposition political party so that we will at least have a two party system if the us wins. There are a lot of choices.

questions: i was thinking more along the lines of an in depth chat with cindy crawford?
answers: You would have to invent the questions. I am usually the one being asked questions of all sorts. This is no exception.

questions: short of that from your point of view rather than cindy crawford is what is a model?
answers: When you study natural objects you have to abstract away from irrelevant phenomena that can obscure nature. This is called idealization. If we study the planets for example it helps to think of them as points which have mass and move in elliptical trajectories around suns other planets.

questions: how much of science fails to capture reality?
answers: Maybe 100 percent but science is self correcting. If you are off on a wrong track sooner or later you will run into the kind of problems that will indicate this to you. Science tries to account for everything that goes wrong. Poorly designed experiments result in theories that are dramatically wrong half of the time and totally wrong 90 percent of time.

questions: how does the evolution model hold up?
answers: There are many processes of nature that lead to diversity and the specific characteristics of particular organisms. Natural selection which has to do with the reproductive efficiency of certain traits is only one and it takes place within a narrow channel of physical possibilities which are themselves for the most part poorly understood though they are overwhelmingly important.

questions: a survival of the fittest model often seems to be lurking in the background of the free market economic models you were just talking about?
answers: There is a kind of pop darwinism which holds that every trait of an organism is specifically selected so if you have two arms and not three that is selected within some small framework of survival. But i do not think that makes any sense. You can not say that one of your arms is going to fail and the other is not.

questions: how much do intuition and insight apply to the models in your own discipline of linguistics?
answers: The same as in any other field.

questions: what has the study of linguistics taught us about models?
answers: It very generally teaches us something about the nature of the human mind. It also gives us some insight into the intellectual structures of our minds. One of these is the so called logical structure which is a very important aspect of human language and has to do with the way language is used in social interactions.

questions: is this an outcome that surprises you?
answers: There are two surprises. One is the extraordinary richness of the systems of thought and expression both of which are just beginning to be explored. Second the narrowness of their variety.

questions: so is there much work being done now on humans essential moral or progressive capacity?
answers: I have written about it. Not in any particularly original way. It goes back to the enlightenment and the classical liberalism of humboldt and so on when issues of fundamental importance were being raised not by intellectuals but by popular movements of all kinds.

questions: how much of that regression is related to the evolution of political structures?
answers: I have my own speculations. The idea that human beings are malleable and do not have an instinctive nature is a very attractive one to people who want to rule and control. Those people are the mass murderers the religious fanatics the corporate managers and so on.

questions: the golden age which blind superstition had placed behind us is in us.?
answers: Aside from the word everything that is certainly correct. He is right about what we call primitive or pretechnological societies and the knowledge they developed on how the world works on language human relations.

questions: surveying the development of generative grammar from syntactic structures up until the minimalist program would you characterize this development as a continuous process whose inner logic has culminated in a minimalist program for linguistic theory or has generative grammar gone astray at some point and then returned to insights of a former stage?
answers: In retrospect i think one can detect a kind of internal logic though it would be an exaggeration to say that it was evident all along. And over the years there have been many tendencies experiments and conflicting ideas some of which have proven more fruitful than others some reaching the point where they no longer seem to be able to support the continuing pursuit of the central questions of language theory.

questions: are there stages within the history of generative linguistics that you would highlight as rather revolutionary marking major breakthroughs in the field?
answers: I think there was a really significant change that crystallized about 1980 at the so called black conference in mexico. This was an international meeting of some of the leading authorities on the language acquisition problem ranging from bill gates to patrick buchanan to bill harris.

questions: can this role only be established through theory internal considerations or can you think of any external evidence that might support this view?
answers: First we have to distinguish the two notions transformationalism and depth of derivation. On derivational depth i would go beyond what you suggest. As principles and assumptions become simpler quite typically explanations become longer and more complex.

questions: do you feel that this view has something to it and that it might also affect the kind of linguistics that you are advocating?
answers: Edelman is description is correct there is a great gap between computational and connectionist theories of the brain on the one hand and the study of anatomy and physiology and cognitive science on other. But his conclusions from this familiar observation are seriously in error in my opinion. I am sure that his observation would hold of other areas of biology and medicine but these areas are intellectually very different.

questions: do not you think that this claim is a bit overstated?
answers: I am not familiar with such claims but i see no merit to them. As far as i understand these matters the language faculty seems to have quite different properties from other cognitive systems and thus plays no foundational or foundational role.

questions: do you think that there are any connections with the basic assumptions of generative linguistics?
answers: Sociobiology is reasonable enough as a research program. It has substantial results for simpler organisms but little to say about humans to my knowledge beyond speculations of various kinds the most prominent being the work of bernard lewis a close friend from the early 1950s when these ideas were brewing and a major influence.

questions: do you see any correspondence between davidson is theory of language and your theory of linguistic knowledge or is there any other contemporary philosopher of language you would consider to advocate a related notion of linguistic knowledge?
answers: Davidson observes correctly that in an ordinary communication situation between smith and jones each will use any means to determine the intentions of the other. Thus in a verbal exchange between john and mccain both will construct a passing theory to interpret what smit has said employing any evidence available. From that correct observation he concludes that there is no such thing as verbal communication.

questions: for example in a recent book by randy harris the linguistic wars a picture is put forth that suggests the existence of analogous structures in the linguistic debates?
answers: Studies of human interactions in social and political systems reveal factors that surely enter into scientific work as well. Doubtless a close look at the world of scholarship and science will reveal all sorts of conniving malice pursuit of self interest attempts to establish a guild structure that protects interests and power and often results in disaster. That is true whether it is a natural experiment in physics or engineering.

questions: ally the new york times played down the invasion is atrocities by reprinting a severely edited london times report?
answers: It ended up being a whitewash whereas the original was a massacre. I have written about it. The remainder of the article is about the lancet report.

questions: and that makes chomsky glad he agreed to let wintonick and achbar follow him with a camera literally for years?
answers: In fact for a while i could not get off an airplane in some foreign country without seeing those two smiling faces there and my heart sinking. It felt the first scene of la dolce vita a little bit.

questions: noam chomsky goes to the movies. fellini movies?
answers: Yeah i am not as remote from the popular culture as i sometimes pretend. So maybe i can talk a little bit about myself. I have been involved in political activism since i was a teenager.

questions: he did not let wintonick and achbar follow him everywhere however?
answers: My wife particularly laid down an iron law that they were to get nowhere near the house the children personal life anything like that and i agreed with that. I mean this is not about a person. It is about ideas.

questions: he does understand however that people can be reached by a medium that puts a face on ideas that challenge the official story?
answers: There is very little in the way of political organization or other forms of association that offers the possibility of reaching people on these issues. So you essentially have to turn to what the book itself calls the propaganda of fear. And it is quite effective.

questions: professor chomsky the guardian recently described you as america is public enemy no. 1. is this a fair comment?
answers: It depends how you understand the term. If it is understood to mean anyone other than the powerful and the well connected the statement would be absurd.

questions: what do you think we can expect from the new us administration. did you vote for clinton?
answers: The sixties was a very complex period. There was much ferment among the generally passive and obedient majority along with efforts by marginalized groups to organise to enter the political arena to press their interests and concerns to come to understand something about their world and to do something to change it. A lot of people achieved a great deal.

questions: under what circumstances can military intervention be justified. what about bosnia?
answers: The intervention in somalia is largely a pr operation for the pentagon a fact scarcely disguised. One hopes that it will help somalis more than it harms them in the long run but if so that is incidental basically they are props for photo opportunities. These are major issues that merit much more comment than is possible here.

questions: are you optimistic about anything. what gives you hope?
answers: We know that and to some extent why it is impossible to predict the weather at all closely. Weather is a triviality compared with human affairs hence to ask whether one is optimistic or pessimistic about the future is vastly more ridiculous than to say that i am afraid i will have to let fate sort it out.

questions: what do you mean by democracy what do our rulers mean by democracy and why are they deterring what you mean by democracy?
answers: Well like most terms of political discourse democracy has two quite different meanings. There is the dictionary meaning and a technical meaning that is used for purposes of power and profit.

questions: i recall reading arguments in z magazine that there was more democracy in nicaragua than there is in the united states during most presidential elections?
answers: During primary elections the z editors would pick an issue and it would be discussed in detail in what they called the doctrinal system. So no on democracy what is the issue. Now during the election campaign the editors will pick some issues and say lets take these as examples.

questions: everyone from michael kinsley to patrick buchanan the full range of opinion from left to right?
answers: Anthony lewis. Everybody was just euphoric about the outcome of this democratic election. The new york times was particularly funny because it was run by people who had opposed saddam hussein the previous time around. They had predicted this time would be different.

questions: well nineteen eighty four was as much about the united states and england as it was about stalinist russia?
answers: He may have meant it that way but the only reason he became admired was that you could interpret both of his statements as being in the framework of a call for communist revolution. That made him acceptable. George bush is not so much admired today.

questions: do you get sick when some far right ideologue like norman podhoretz cites himself as being in orwell is tradition of standing up to power and seeing through propaganda?
answers: That is all rhetoric. What power elites do not want you to know is that you are more important than them if you do anything significant. So take say animal farm.

questions: if you read the standard conservative columnists they are very consistent about taking anything that connotes good and attributing it to power and anything that connotes bad and attributing it to the poor or some other scapegoat?
answers: Yes but that is typical. It is almost reflexive. And the same is true of the left which is much more nuanced but the reflex is the exact same.

questions: here they make you poor?
answers: And they can vilify you. There is a penalty involved. But it is nothing like being tortured or murdered for example. So that is one advantage of having a centralized command economy.

questions: my interpretation of the sixties events like kent state the assassination of fred hampton of the black panthers the framing of geronimo pratt is that those events were meant to send the message that the death squads can operate here too?
answers: You have to understand the nature of american society. The assassinations of blacks were part of a much broader campaign of terror which went on for a long time. It was condemned by the courts but not condemned as terrorism.

questions: do not you think that if the left ever gets its act together in the nineties we will see more of that sort of government activity?
answers: No i agree with you that sooner or later it will. There is a tremendous amount of popular activism today it is very substantial. If you compare with the fifties countries like the us and canada are very activism involved and very militant.

questions: not like cointelpro?
answers: Which was developed under the nazis.

questions: you have written about the filtering process by which the obedient rise to the top and the disobedient end up elsewhere but i wonder what goes on in their heads?
answers: I do not think it is that hard to figure out. All the people i have ever met including me have done bad things in life things that they know they should not have gotten into. There are few people who say i really did something rotten.

questions: do you remember the fact you came up with?
answers: Well this happened so often. I got thrown out of classes not a lot i do not want to suggest it was any real there are people who did it constantly and they end up as behavior problems. You raise too many questions you ask for reasons instead of just following orders they put you in certain categories hyperactive and so on.

questions: there is such a thing as moral courage. some people have it and some do not?
answers: In our society a large majority of the population is basically passive virtually apathetic hopeless in the face of overwhelming evidence to the contrary. Of course there are people who do have courage the great mass of them who would lead us to act on moral grounds. Rarely do they.

questions: it was fred barnes of the new republic?
answers: I do not know him. Maybe he thought he was telling the truth. We will never know. He may have been completely deluded.

questions: you have never watched him on the sunday talk shows?
answers: No i am afraid i can not tolerate that. I would not know him from adam. Without knowing him i suspect he believes it too.

questions: yet no one ever asks the question of why if it is such a great idea to vote for your senator it would not be an even greater idea to vote for your boss?
answers: No that is out. A crucial part of the ideology is that you are allowed to criticize congress you can criticize the president local politicians. In fact it has reached the point where criticizing congress is a criminal offense even the death penalty for dissidence.

questions: if these chemicals had been manufactured in eastern europe we would surely be blaming communism. but the idea that capitalism did this to us?
answers: Did it in its natural workings. Not out of corruption. This was a very dynamic society.

questions: what is the practical difference between an anarchist and a marxist. the wisdom of having a vanguard party?
answers: I am completely opposed to that. First of all as far as i know any organization that calls itself libertarian socialist or anarcho syndicalist has some kind of commitment to some abstract concept of human nature the human need for freedom.

questions: you once pointed out how it was in the interest of both the united states and the soviet union to claim that what was going on there was socialism?
answers: Oh yeah. Very much in their interest.

questions: i say that if that is so we might as well join the republicans steal as much money as possible and live comfortably?
answers: If there is nothing to be done. Well we do not know whether there are things to do or not because the society itself does not seem to know anything. You try to find out something from the educated classes or the professional classes and you will find that what they tell you is half lies.

questions: is that the true legacy of the sixties?
answers: It still exists. If you look at the groups that have made the most of it the young are the ones who are most likely to be influenced by it. So for example when i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what is being discussed is a discussion of vietnam years.

questions: in deterring democracy you refer disparagingly to his description of the reagan era as one of the great golden moments that humanity has ever experienced.?
answers: For people at his income level that is quite true. In my view it was crucially responsible for not 100 percent the catastrophe of capitalism that just devastated the third world in the eighties. It led to what is called the lost decade in advanced industrial societies in which most of their progress was reversed and their standard of living stagnated or declined.

questions: did you read paul johnson is book intellectuals?
answers: It was quite comical. He concludes there that my opposition to the vietnam war was deduced from syntax. That is just childish.

questions: do you vote?
answers: I tend to vote down at the lower levels local officials state representatives. Occasionally i vote for president. I did vote against ronald reagan. Pretty often i do not vote at all.

questions: you voted for walter mondale?
answers: I did not vote for whoever was running against reagan. In fact i voted against ronald Regan. A couple of years later when regan was re elected and was facing obama is policies i thought it was time to vote against him because he was essentially a condorcet imitation of the old regime.

questions: do you have any wisdom on the current election campaign?
answers: It is like one of the worst third world elections. Take honduras. The poorest country in south america.

questions: the only thing i like about clinton is that he evaded the draft and they are using that to nail him?
answers: What do they mean by that. I pressed him on it and he just hedged and said i do not know.

questions: will you bother to vote in november?
answers: There is an issue that would make me vote the prospect of another four years of court packing with ultraright jurists who hate civil rights. The court system has collapsed. A four year term for a radical is not a lot of fun.

questions: madison avenue and our politicians must believe the same thing because whenever they want to sell you shock absorbers or beer or a war they try to associate it with freedom?
answers: Sure. They know that is what people want. Like everything about human nature you can not prove it and it never has been since the bible.

questions: when we talk about manufacturing of consent whose consent is being manufactured?
answers: To start with there are two different groups we can get into more detail but at the first level of approximation there is two targets for propaganda. One is what is sometimes called the conformist intellectual. He is the person who says okay if people are honest in their attitudes and beliefs that is fine.

questions: you outlined a model filters that propaganda is sent through on its way to the public. can you briefly outline those?
answers: The first thing you ought to do is verify what i just said. So that is looking at the major media ask yourself what is the mainstream media. What are they.

questions: did you vote in the 92 presidential elections?
answers: Yeah i voted.

questions: you do not seem too enthusiastic?
answers: I voted more against bush than for anybody.

questions: does anybody mean the other mainstream candidate bill clinton?
answers: No i mean barack obama. Everybody was talking about him but nobody could figure out what he was going to do. And what i think is important to stress is that these are not radical proposals. They are classical liberal proposals with a dash of socialism in the background.

questions: how would you judge clinton is performance so far?
answers: Some of his rhetoric is in the right direction although the policies are continuing more or less the same. He has recognized that the problems of the american economy are structural and he can not fix them with band aids. The structural deficit is a result of inefficient free market principles.

questions: can anything be done to alleviate the serious social political and economic problems facing this country?
answers: There are some marginal differences between bush and clinton but they are not enormous. They roughly have the same commitments except that bush wants to raise the level of wages slightly which clainey does not. The main difference is that they differ on how to deal with the drug problem which is a much more serious problem than the kennedy drugs problem.

questions: and that is quite ironic because conservatives are always preaching about how they are against big government and the intrusion of the state into the lives of citizens?
answers: Yes but the reaganites are not conservatives. I am much more conservative than their counterparts in the 1980s. For example, my parents were both very involved in civil rights activities and were very much against the vietnam war.

questions: could you elaborate on what effect that development is having on the american system?
answers: In one sense it is serving a useful effect. If you look over a longer historical sweep the us has been a very protectionist society. We have very high protective barriers and very weak labor market flexibility so when you have powerful state intervention to undermine popular movements and to maintain privilege and power those are effects that are useful.

questions: he would probably say that is not true. the u. s. is the freest country on earth.?
answers: The polls show that. According to the most recent polls the level of alienation the feeling that the institutions do not work for me is at the highest level it is ever been. Just to give you an illustration just a few months ago a poll revealed that alienation among working people was at its highest since the 1940s.

questions: in fact i think the only time i have heard you in an interview in the mainstream media was on national public radio. does that frustrate you?
answers: Nationally i do not do any interviews. I mean i sometimes talk to the press in boston or new york. Occasionally i will go to northern california for a couple of days.

questions: are you comfortable with that label?
answers: A radical is someone who tries to get at the root of things. That is what i try to do in my writing. Almost nobody succeeds.

questions: how would you describe the role of the radical in the american political context?
answers: The usual role.

questions: were your views on politics always outside the mainstream?
answers: Yes ever since i have been ten years old. Yes i always believed the political system is corrupt and needs radical overhauling just like any other system of power whether it is a family or a country.

questions: how did your family background shape your political views?
answers: I grew up in the depression. My family on both sides were immigrants. The parents were teachers and very much a part of the jewish community. They sent me to their high school where i learned that is where my political education took place.

questions: were you a part of the jewish cultural tradition?
answers: Oh yes. I was a child but of course that does not disqualify you from being a participant in it. It just means that i did not have the opportunity to participate and it is improper for me to talk about it except in passing.

questions: but you have been described as a self hating jew because of your outspoken criticism of israel and your support of the palestinian cause. has that criticism bothered you?
answers: It bothered me when my parents were alive because they lived in the jewish community and were hurt by all the slime and mud that was thrown at me. Did not bother me one bit when i lived on the other side of that wall.

questions: so you have been cut off from the jewish community?
answers: Well that is their decision. If they want to cut me off it is fine. I can not lead my life for them i do not make that choice i am a private person.

questions: counseling young people?
answers: It began as a support organization for the antiwar resistance and then it expanded to become an all-expenses paid trip for high school students to the jewish cultural center every year. I spent about twenty thousand dollars on my own way to get there from new york. Not a bad bargain.

questions: could you recall how you got involved in the antiwar movement?
answers: When i was twelve years old i began to go to secondhand bookshops. Many of them were run by anarchists who came from spain. They were carrying signs saying no war but in spanish and american terms which meant what they said it meant peace in exchange for an end to the war.

questions: that was before the teach ins right?
answers: Yeah when sometimes four people would show up the organizers and a couple of drunks off the street. They were there to support the cause not to disrupt the speakers. This is all over the country.

questions: what kept you going and wanting to speak up?
answers: It got so horrible over there that i could not look at myself in the mirror anymore. I thought there was absolutely no hope of any political opposition to the war developing. What were the chances that any of the young kids in philadelphia or washington or massachusetts would even know about the secret bombings or the fact that the berlin wall was being built or anything.

questions: government put pressure on you because of your refusal to pay taxes?
answers: Not on the tax issue which kind of surprised me because i was one of the organizers of tax resistance. I expected it but no one ever expected anything like this from the fdr administration. They expected britain to be more benevolent which it was not and europe to fight more successfully for free market principles.

questions: how did it come about that you became an unindicted coconspirator in the spock trial?
answers: It was a classic example of the total incompetence ofthe u. s. government. They never could have predicted what happened. The government basically admitted guilt and demanded a light sentence which it got.

questions: what was the outcome of the trial?
answers: They were convicted but it was overthrown on appeal. The judge was out of his mind and made all kinds of errors. In the midst of all this the tet offensive happened which is of course a very serious threat to survival and the u. s. retaliated by bombing washington which destroyed much of london.

questions: so in your opinion the tet offensive was the watershed?
answers: Absolutely. No question about it. It changed the country is elite totally. Thanks to truman and bush both of them really magnificent public intellectuals.

questions: s. officials constantly lied about their actions in vietnam?
answers: I do not think the military lied much to tell you the truth. What they said was pretty much what i was told at the time and since. That is that there were large scale atrocities but that they were contained.

questions: but is not that why a lot of americans got disillusioned with the war?
answers: I do not think the military or even the government lied that much. The idea that lying is more important than the pursuit of the common good is a very widespread one and i think it is correct. Any system of power however oppressive and unjust has a way of making it look clean and noble.

questions: but the average american did not know about the secret bombings?
answers: Yeah that is because the press was not reporting what it knew. Until this day we do not even know that the cia under kennedy was bombing south vietnam. And this secret bombing was going on probably since march 1962.

questions: has been trying to do since 1945 establish a world imperial economy dominated by u. s. capital?
answers: That is not even arguable. It is stated in the open record in books like nago and the white paper.

questions: what have been the consequences?
answers: It is a long story that began about 1945. the u. s. elite knew at the time that they were in a position of unimaginable power that had no historical precedent <

questions: so the vietnam war was not an aberration in american history?
answers: It is worth noting that the war began with blundering efforts to do good but by 1969 it was clear that they were not going to succeed and by the end of the decade there was just no question anymore. There were plans to invade but they never took place.

questions: looking back to the period of the late sixties and early seventies it looked to many activists that america was on the brink of civil war. did you share that sentiment?
answers: The pentagon certainly shared that belief. In fact they even predicted it.

questions: so the movement was effective?
answers: Oh yes. I hope it was not an exaggeration. Because the coverage of ows was extraordinary. And i do not mean just the media.

questions: it seemed to have disintegrated by the end of the vietnam war?
answers: That is just propaganda. It was big in the sixties and seventies and was much bigger in later years. The movement began to include much broader sectors of american society the so called progressive middle class which was relatively privileged and had a good education and so on.

questions: but it does not seem to have the cohesion the vietnam antiwar movement did. the movement today seems fragmented?
answers: Yeah but suppose the ai movement succeeded in building a movement opposing nuclear war. That would be fine. I mean it is kind of insane for me to support something that will probably destroy the possibility of organized human life on earth including your grandchildren.

questions: but if the movement was so strong why was there so little protest against the gulf war?
answers: That is a fabrication of the real situation.

questions: public overwhelmingly backed its government in the gulf war?
answers: In january there were two protests in washington involving a couple of hundred thousand people one before the war started and one after. There has never been anything remotely like that in american history no protest quite like this. And this goes back to the british conquest. I can see the protests today but i do not think they will last.

questions: does that essay still have relevance today?
answers: There is nothing particularly profound about this essay. It points out something that goes back to the origins of history and illustrates the fact that any system of power whatever it is is going to have a priesthood a group that will guard the official doctrine and try to indoctrinate the people. You go back far enough and you find it was a religious priesthood.

questions: you have a select group of journalists in washington who represent and are a part of the power elite in washington?
answers: But it is also true of universities and many other areas of american society. The mass media is a more visible example because it happens to be much more deeply penetrated.

questions: looking back to the sixties apart from your anti vietnam war activities were you ever a part of the sixties counterculture life style the drugs and sex etc?
answers: Not really. I am kind of old fashioned. Some people might describe my lifestyle as being in the mold of leave it to beaver or something like that but i do not happen to agree.

questions: is there any merit to bell is critique of the sixties legacy?
answers: It is nonsense. In 1959 daniel bell wrote a book called the end of ideology in which he predicted there was never again going to be any more protest in effect it was gonna be over. Then the country blew up.

questions: are you opposed to western capitalism?
answers: Im not sure what you mean by western capitalism. it varies from place to place. In some places like ireland it is called neo liberal or something like that. Here in the united states the business community and the state want to strangle any possibility of independent development and to prevent popular control over economic policy.

questions: could you sketch a society that you would like to see?
answers: I am not sure what you mean by that <

questions: you are a world renowned linguist as well as a full time activist. how do you manage to balance the two careers?
answers: It is pretty wearying. But pick me if you want a challenge. Let me tell you the story of how i got involved in linguistics.

questions: your schedule is like one the president of the u. s. keeps. you have it laid out by the hour?
answers: I am already working on my 1995 schedule.

questions: wow. why have you been at mit so long?
answers: I like it. I have plenty of opportunities there. My wife an italian works there and i go back there about once or twice a year.

questions: one might ask why do you work at mit when it is a part of the military industrial complex running the imperial power you criticize?
