answers: Is not everything in this country. I have been at universities around the world and this is the freest and the most honest and has the best relations between faculty and students than at any other university i know.

questions: has mit put any pressure on you to curb your radical views?
answers: None whatsoever. In fact by general standards they have quite a good record on civil liberties. That was shown to be particularly true during the sixties when i got into a lot of trouble for things i thought i knew nothing about and that i should have kept quiet about.

questions: is that pressure still there?
answers: No not really. It is interesting. The mit faculty would be regarded as very conservative but we all get along better here than faculty do at a lot of other universities.

questions: in looking back at your long activist career can you really say you made a difference?
answers: Probably but it is hard to say. Anyway people keep wanting me to come back and give more talks. And i have a huge correspondence and it keeps coming.

questions: where do the letters come from?
answers: From all over the place. A lot of people in this country feel isolated. They may have heard something i said on the radio or read something from one of my books and it struck a chord. To hear somebody talk about this is very moving.

questions: and what about your future?
answers: I do not think i will be doing anything different. I work hard and contribute to the society and cause that is important. If i could do it over again i would do exactly the same thing. So thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to talk about this.

questions: could you give an example?
answers: Well there has been a chipping away of labor rights in the past generation which has led to what is called the lost decade of the labor movement. In fact that is the entire neoliberal period from the late 70s through the early 90s. Now if you take a look at the percentage of workers who are in industry or retail trade the ratio has gone way down.

questions: this is what we talked about once the recording began as noam answered a question regarding his perception of north american anarchists?
answers: I think if you counted up the number of people who would regard themselves as involved or sympathetic you would get a pretty large number but this does not necessarily mean much because the connections are pretty weak.

questions: you have published an overwhelming number of works. do you think of yourself as a writer?
answers: No i have never particularly thought of myself as being anything special. In fact most of what I have written is written up versions of lectures. For example syntactic structures the first book that actually appeared was essentially lecture notes for an undergraduate course at mit revised slightly to turn them into publishable form.

questions: so you see yourself first as a speaker a lecturer?
answers: The fact is that most of the writing i do is probably letters. I spend about twenty hours a week i guess just answering letters which is not very time well spent. Many letters are on questions that are in response to the hundreds of letters that i receive which are thoughtful and interesting and raise important questions and i just do not have the time.

questions: the books simply grow by accretion. would you tell us more about your writing process?
answers: There was an element of randomness to it which was not mine to begin with but which grew over the years. I guess my wife went through a phase where she would pick up a couple of journals that were not in print and would put them in the trash can.

questions: so you can not when writing a book for example concentrate for ten hours at a time?
answers: No i know that a lot of people do not seem to be able to do that and it is certainly an advantage not to have to. I can pick up after a long stretch and be more or less where i left off. In fact i have sometimes had to go back several times to make sure that i did not forget a point.

questions: that is quite a talent?
answers: Well it is probably because i have thought about most of it before or lectured on it many times. Then it becomes mainly a problem of trying to fit it all in. I do not know how else to put it.

questions: is that because you might lose credibility or lose the audience?
answers: Not at all. In fact you would probably lose your audience by not doing it. It is just kind of an authoritarian practice one should keep away from if one can help it though it can be done in a small way.

questions: in his critique of western metaphysics jacques derrida exposed the indeterminacy of language showing how meaning is never fixed always fluid never certain. what are your thoughts on this issue?
answers: I do not know this literature very well and to tell you the truth the reason ido not understand it i think is that in its modern form it just does not work. I mean it may be correct in principle but in practice it does Not. A lot of things are wrong with it.

questions: so you probably would not agree with bakhtin. are you familiar with hi work?
answers: No i am not. But he seems to be pretty much on the model i have described.

questions: his ideas sound very similar to this concept of meaning holism?
answers: Yes but that is the standard view. That means you have to turn the cart before the horse. It used to be called the logical empiricist view now it is just called that because the traditional view is out of date.

questions: this concept is related to kuhn is notion of how knowledge is formed within the scientific community. what are your thoughts about this theory?
answers: There is an element of truth to it obviously. There has to be a balance between the demands of research and the need to protect the integrity of the work being done.

questions: has your colleague down the hall thomas kuhn ever discussed the chomskyan revolution in terms of a paradigm shift?
answers: He has not but other people have i do not. My own view is that while there have been several significant changes there is been basically one scientific revolution the galilean change the seventeenth century revolution stretching over a period including george washington is contributions. That was a real revolution a different way of looking at things in many respects.

questions: do you agree with these assumptions and the conclusion9?
answers: I understand the point but i would not call it a property of language. There are many properties of human experience which reflect structures of authority and domination in the society in which this language is used and that s true. However i do not think there is any such thing as a language of domination and authority as there would be if language were used in a structure of submission.

questions: but given how language is actually used?
answers: Well given language use it is undoubtedly correct and it seems to be true of all sorts of systems of authority and domination one being the gender issue.

questions: do you see any justification for that argument?
answers: Well you have to ask what you mean by semantic universal. First of all there is the question of whether it is true but let is say for the sake of argument that every language known has a concept like motherhood and let me give you an example to illustrate what i think should be the case.

questions: s. is experiencing a literacy crisis. do you agree?
answers: Sure. It is just a fact. I do not think its even questioned.

questions: speaking of critical analysis and literacy paulo freire and others argue that writing because it can lead to critical consciousness is an avenue to social and political empowerment of the disenfranchised. do you agree?
answers: Absolutely. In fact writing seems to me an indispensable method for interpersonal communication in a complicated society.

questions: do you think that is a good idea?
answers: Doing things that will stimulate critical analysis self analysis and analysis of culture and society is very crucial. In fact it seems to me that part of the core of all education ought to be the development of systems of intellectual self defense and also stimulation for the capacity for inquiry which means also collective inquiry. And this again is an area in which it can be done quite effectively.

questions: how would you ground a concept of human nature beyond human capacity to acquire language?
answers: I would study it the same way. I think it is a very important concept. One of the problems with the language faculty is that we have a limited number of ways of understanding what is the nature of language and how does language acquisition take place.

questions: is it that we are more advanced than asians or chinese society?
answers: Well i admit that this is a value judgment and i can not prove it but i would suspect that there is going to be an evolution assuming that the human race does not self destruct which it is likely to do from rigid patriarchal societies to more egalitarian societies and not the other way around which is not a very attractive prospect.

questions: are our media victims of ideological indoctrination or are they willing conspirators in suppressing truth?
answers: I would not exactly put it either way. They are not victims and they arent conspirator. Suppose for example you were to ask a similar question about say general motors the mechanics of what they were producing.

questions: in fact it is even better much more effective?
answers: It may be the way of the future but it does not have to be. Let is take the vietnam war for example. When the united states invaded south Vietnam in 1962 roughly half the population was living in poverty.

questions: what society do you think comes closest to achieving anything like this kind of voluntary association. do you think any society even comes close?
answers: Well sure every society has aspects of it and they differ. Sometimes you find things in very poor backward undeveloped societies that you do not find in advanced societies. In many ways the united states is a typical example.

questions: that could be very dangerous. s. can fall victim to a charismatic fascist dictator?
answers: It is real. I mentioned something very good about the united states but there are also a number of things that are very bad and that is the business world in particular.

questions: how do you reconcile these two seemingly contradictory perspectives?
answers: There is something to that but let me tell you what my own choices and priorities are. Like any human being i am interested in a lot of things. There are things i find intellectually interesting and there arent many others where it makes sense for me to be. Shift to the political arena and it becomes very clear what kind of issues i think are important.

questions: do you think creativity in language can be fostered so that more of a student is innate potential is used?
answers: I am sure it can. Creative reading for example surely is a way of fostering it getting people to wrestle with complex ideas and to find ways of expressing them ought to be at the heart of the writing program. Frankly i doubt very much that linguistics has anything to contribute to this except perhaps as a convenient cover for other things i have mentioned.

questions: if so how would you define a sensible prescriptivism?
answers: I do not think sensible prescriptivism has anything to do with the kind of anarchism that you are talking about. I think propertarianism is sensible in the sense that it is the inheritor of classical liberalism insofar as classical liberal ideas are concerned. But it has nothing to say about questions of political and social organization.

questions: first of all do you think that it is continuing to spread now that american economic hegemony has been broken. also is it desirable that it spread?
answers: I have never seen a real study but my strong impression is that the phenomenon is not unique to the us. That is a conclusion that should not be lightly reached. It may be that part of the impetus toward spreading anarchism in europe is an understandable but mistaken belief that by spreading ideas you can control society.

questions: do you think people outside of linguistics should know about the principles and parameters approach?
answers: I think it is more important than the aspects type approach. In fact if anything deserves to be called a revolution that is probably it. It leads to a conception of language which is in a sense revolutionary it goes beyond anything in the history of science.

questions: what would you suggest people read people who are out of the field who want to understand this new approach?
answers: Well there are some pretty good relatively introductory books. It depends on what level they are going to be working. I have tried my hand at a few things. One kind of introductory book i found was by michel foucault who has been in cognitive science for forty years and just put it out called the end of knowledge theory.

questions: what readership did you target in your 1986 book knowledge of language?
answers: That is a funny sort of book. One chapter is pretty technical linguistics material the rest is sort more social and historical. I am not sure what the intended audience was.

questions: what is your sense of the treatment of your work in popularizations such as neil smith is the twitter machine?
answers: That is a very good book. I think he knows what he is doing he just does not tell you what it is. He does a good job of keeping you on your toes.

questions: well he does deal quite extensively with your work?
answers: That is a mistake people make they call it mine because i sometimes write about it. Take the pisa lectures. They were a very intense affair.

questions: we were surprised to hear that you are now teaching a course in semantics?
answers: It is not surprising. Part of this is terminological. In my view most ofwhat is called semantics is syntax.

questions: can you think of any instances in which metaphorical extensions of a concept like deep structure might be justified or should such extensions always be avoided?
answers: I think you have got to be careful. In the real world there are many cases when you really do want to take a look at complex systems and abstract away from them and see what is going on under the surface. And many of the times you can do that with little if any success.

questions: are you aware of any specific misun derstanding or criticism of your work that you would like to take issue with at this time?
answers: We could go on forever. On the linguistics side there is plenty of misunderstanding but i think it is resolvable. I am enough of a believer in the rational side of human beings to think that if you sit down and talk these questions through and you think them through you can reach a resolution rather than a series of post hoc idealizations.

questions: does it solve capitalism is problems or create new ones?
answers: To begin with i think terms like capitalism and socialism have been so evacuated of any substantive meaning that i do not even like to use them. There is no such thing as capitalism in the technical sense. Just to give you an illustration of the way it works there are two major types of capitalism.

questions: explain a little more what you mean by state capitalism?
answers: The victory of the west in the cold war is combined with both this enormous catastrophe of capitalism and with the move toward one kind or another of state interventionist forms. As an example the reagan bush administrations are the most protectionist since world war ii doubling the percentage of imports subject to various forms of restriction while also sharply increasing barriers to trade.

questions: where does it continue the reagan era and where is it a departure?
answers: It is a continuation of the same policies. Remember that the policies were announced at a time when the economy was in much better shape. The carter administration was carrying out a massive economic warfare against the general population with regard to labor rights and environmental protections and other issues.

questions: in your traveling since the disaster of the gulf slaughter what hopeful signs do you see in the grassroots movements?
answers: For some time now i have been going out of my way to go to the least organized most reactionary places where i can get invited. Last september i went to central america where there is a real working class movement and i think i met with leaders from it. They were very impressed with what they saw.

questions: do you think the vietnam syndrome is dead?
answers: Not only do not i believe that the administration does not believe it either. Somebody leaked to maureen dowd who is basically a gossip columnist for the new york times a very important document the first international policy review of the bush administration in its early months which she quoted in a column. It said that in confronting much weaker opponents we must defeat them rapidly and decisively.

questions: he joins us from public station wgbh in boston. professor chomsky thank you for joining us?
answers: I am glad to be with you again.

questions: listening to the iraqi deputy prime minister how do you think iraq is occupation of kuwait is going to be resolved?
answers: Well it should definitely be settled with the removal of arab forces from kuawait at the very least. And there are three ways in which that could happen. It could be done through the effects of the embargo and other economic measures and also the threat and use of force as Saddam Hussein has threatened Kuwait and the west repeatedly.

questions: first of all go back to the embargo for a moment you sound very pessimistic about the embargo achieving what president bush and the united nations hopes it will achieve?
answers: I think that is hard to predict. It is by no means a certainty that they are going to succeed and there are a lot of uncertainties in international affairs. For example the us is not a great believer in democracy.

questions: are you impressed with this incident in the sort of post cold war order as an example of the world uniting against an aggressor which is what the un charter hoped would happen does that impress you?
answers: I am not sure what it means to unite against. There is strong popular opposition to aggression all over the globe. And there are powerful popular forces opposed to forceful intervention.

questions: but this is being called the first crisis of the post cold war era?
answers: Maybe. It is possible that the invasion of panama and the surrounding countries was part of a much broader effort to undermine the cuban government. There is also the matter of kennedy is secret bombing of cambodia which probably falls within this domain.

questions: and how does that equate with the iraqi invasion of kuwait in your view?
answers: I do not think it equates with it exactly but it was the invasion was motivated by the fact that the us had to make a decision about kosovo and about iran generally. And the reason was that at that point the kurdish areas had not been under us control for very long so they might be able to resist us domination more effectively.

questions: interest at stake and that the united states should not be playing world policeman and should not have sent troops in this case. what do you feel about that?
answers: I think it is correct to react to local circumstances. If there is a threat to life and property that is legitimate for the local community to deal with. But the general principle should apply universally.

questions: and a valid valid principle in your view?
answers: That principle is not a part of my view. That is a view of just about every social philosopher that i know of including humboldt.

questions: using force to destroy his military potential. how do you feel about those arguments?
answers: I do not think that there is any justification for the u. s. to do it.

questions: what avenue do you see and through what issues that might lead to a diplomatic or negotiated settlement?
answers: Well there have been several offers floated through august several by iraq some by others. The united states has rejected them forthwith without any consideration but some of them i think do offer the possibility could be explored.

questions: can i ask you do you think if this is to be resolved without recourse to military means that one or other of those avenues will in the end have to be followed something like that a compromise to use president bush is words would have to be accepted do you think?
answers: I do not think it would be much of a solution at all. There are debatable issues there such as for example the exploitation of the rumailah field but i think that there can be a settlement on the basis of concessions that would at least cut down the level of violence and destruction.

questions: have to end it there?
answers: We rejected it but i think that should be pursued as well if the possibility of bringing a case to a court is ever going to be resolved.

questions: how good a picture do they actually have of what is really happening in the world?
answers: They get a good picture of how the state corporate complex operates. And it is pretty beeeep.

questions: occasionally more than that?
answers: Yeah. But not most of the time. Most people are okay with that. They may not like the policies but they accept the institutional structure.

questions: well in short what i am asking is how well served are americans by the mainstream media?
answers: If you follow the money. The major media are major corporations parts of bigger conglomerates funded by advertisers. They have a stranglehold on the public and a lot of it is pretty cynical.

questions: that is the public image of the media and i think many people are going to be surprised to hear that they are being fed a line of propaganda?
answers: Well i doubt that many would. Most polls indicate that the majority regards the mainstream media as too subservient to power. But it is quite true that for educated people the line between propaganda and disinformation is pretty thin.

questions: so in other words an adversarial press does not really exist in this country?
answers: It exists in the extreme right wing press and in publications like the wall street journal and others. I mean there is a lot of pressure on the journals to write things that will be useful for the right. But it is not in fact the press. Thanks to the crusades and the gold standard and all that stuff you do not have much of a deterrent to power.

questions: well that is interesting because you have the media reinforcing a false picture of what was going on then. i mean they did not?
answers: What i just said is virtually a truism. There were no protests. At the time there was a very lively popular movement which was protesting against the atrocities in vietnam and the fall of the berlin wall.

questions: well i think it is especially pernicious since watergate was then touted as an example of the system working?
answers: That shows how beautifully the propaganda system operates. It takes something very dramatic and it turns it into a kind of triviality. Look here is a demonstration of how it works. Press play and see how quickly this destroys any pretense that there is any serious substance to the discussion.

questions: you have made the continual argument that the function of the media is actually to obscure what is happening in the world?
answers: And that is perfectly true. I mean if you want to find out what s real situation there are a few simple things to do. Go back to the beginning of your article. There were three major newsstands in boston one in new york and a third in philadelphia.

questions: but their version of reality is not necessarily my or your version of reality?
answers: No in fact it is often quite different. And that is what you find in any system of power the totalitarian state the democratic state and so on. You will find various versions of what is sometimes called the public image.

questions: what do you make of the deification or cult of objectivity that characterizes mainstream news reporting today?
answers: Well first of all i think you want to be very careful about comparing different historical eras it is a tricky question. There is plenty of material there to compare. So for example in the united states in its early history up until the mid 19th century the public was pretty much shut out of political life except as cogs in elite organizations.

questions: for example in the iran contra scandal the media pretty willingly acquiesced to reagan is efforts to make oliver north and john poindexter the fall guys?
answers: Well they also concentrated on kohl and baginski who were the two people who actually initiated the operations. The reason they concentrated them was because they were both on the terrorist list and both of them were on it for a very explicit reason. Ronald regan wanted to put them in jail.

questions: do you consider congress a confederacy of political eunuchs?
answers: Well i do discuss congress to some extent but it does not vary very much. I mean there is a little diversity in congress.

questions: but at the same time i think there is a great effort in the mainstream media to write these arguments off as conspiracy theory?
answers: That is one of the devices by which power defends itself by calling any critical analysis of institutions a conspiracy theorist. If you call it by that name then somehow you do not have to pay attention to it. Edward herman and i in our recent book manufacturing consent go into this ploy and it is very successful.

questions: an uncontroversial?
answers: Guided free market model the kind that is virtually uncontested in the united states and most of the world. It is been the model for many years in many countries including the us and canada.

questions: well can you say what issues the media reliably do not cover. i mean are there a series of issues that?
answers: Take some issue that is relatively easy to study like the environment. You can pick up a little pamphlet from the environmental movement or something like that and call it an environmental crisis. There is been almost constant coverage of it almost no mention in the mainstream media even though it is perfectly clear that the dire threat is quite real.

questions: you speak of the media engaging in a practice that you call feigning dissent. is this an example of it?
answers: Yes. For example lets take the question of why the united states invaded iraq. We know what the reasons were.

questions: do you think right now that the media are helping to lead us into war in the persian gulf?
answers: I do not know enough to be able to answer with any confidence but i suspect that they are. For one thing remember that bush likes to posture as a deeply religious christian. He does not hide his religious beliefs.

questions: washington is priority is war?
answers: No it is not war but it does involve washingtons is allies.

questions: that brings up another question how much of a crisis is there really in the persian gulf?
answers: If it did explode into war the consequences could be catastrophic.

questions: i do not mean after bush inserted the troops into saudi arabia i mean before?
answers: Even then it was serious iraq is invasion of kuwait was a very serious matter and everything should be done to get them out of there. But right now they are not budging.

questions: i have a feeling that so much of the country has been conditioned now by this demonization in the press of saddam hussein that they would say why should we even take these proposals seriously.?
answers: We should take them seriously because he is frightened. He knows perfectly well that the popular opposition to his policies is very substantial. If you take the last election a couple of years ago it was pretty clear what the issues were.

questions: well it looks like the united states is bribing egypt to put some troops in?
answers: We are trying to turn the screws on other countries to get them to participate which in itself is very striking. For one thing remember we do not count troops when we talk about human rights violations.

questions: well the united states wants to forgive egypt its 7 billion debt and also make the soviet union a most favored trading partner if they play along?
answers: That last one is a little misleading. The us did not invade to force the ottoman regime into playing along.

questions: do you think that there was any good reason for bush to put all those ground troops into saudi arabia?
answers: I do not think there is any doubt that the invasion was a mistake. There are questions about its rationale but i think to generalize it is a terrible mistake and the same is true of vietnam for which there were no grounds for invading in the first place.

questions: and did not that dangerously raise the stakes?
answers: We could argue that i am not completely convinced that there was. But you do not have to take my word for it. Look at the polls. Most people believe the media are too liberal.

questions: for example you were talking earlier about how weak and frightened hussein actually is at this point or at least frightened?
answers: Well he looks it. But again you do not know whether this is bluster and posing just an effort to get what he can or if he really is frightened. And if it is posing then he is in real trouble. Now if you could just bring up the facts and let us see what the situation is really like.

questions: so do you think hussein is militarily as powerful as the media have presented him?
answers: On this issue i think he is about on par with nixon or worse. My own view of his power is that it is mostly ceremonial.

questions: and what about the media is newfound appreciation of the united nations now that it is allegedly voting on our side?
answers: Well that is a story that goes way back. I do not think the american media really took note of it until the 1980s. But it was very public.

questions: not only that but i do not know if you have been watching nightline recently?
answers: No i am not. But this is worse than anything i have seen on the newsstands. So for example here is a little town in pennsylvania where there is an elementary school and a middle school both of them full of children rushing out to the street afraid to come back because they are going to get beat up.

questions: there was barbara walters you know speaking almost on behalf of the american peo ple asking them where is their damn money?
answers: Well excuse me because i have to leave 7pm eastern time so i will not be able to answer your question and you have asked me to.

questions: you concentrate mainly on the print media is there any reason for that?
answers: Yeah i do not have the resources to cover television which is even more limited. And even if i had the time i would not do it. The graphic arts are just not my thing.

questions: do you think there is any difference in terms of the effectiveness of indoctrination between broadcast media and the print media?
answers: Yeah for several reasons. One is that television is a much more effective means of getting people to accept things than the radio or the sort of pamphlet that you would typically find in a bookshops. It conveys a very clear idea that this is something that ought to be done and it is much easier to say than to talk.

questions: and that was to be consciously directed?
answers: Oh well i am quoting lippman and he means it quite literally. The new york times had a cynical but good article about two years ago or so in which they pointed out that the vietnam war was a great victory for the united states because it broke the back of the labor movement which had been a very effective force in preventing further escalation of atrocities.

questions: do you think things are getting better or worse in terms of the people is access to alternative news sources?
answers: Oh i think it is better in fact much better than it was. I mean it used to be really hard to find anything.

questions: why did this change occur?
answers: Mainly because of the way everything changes social change. Why do we have free speech. Not because anybody wrote it down on paper but because every society had freedom of speech and so did the west.

questions: so you think that people are getting?
answers: I think it is marginally better in the mainstream institutions. The main institutions are churches and universities and that makes a difference. At least at my level of disillusionment.

questions: so you think that people are getting less manipulable then?
answers: Yeah i think so. You could see it in the 1980s. For example when the reagan administration came in they expected to be able to carry out world wide interventions the way the kennedy administration did kosovo was their model.

questions: do you have any advice on how to escape this pervasive and continual indoctrination offered by the media?
answers: People have to understand that it is necessary to undertake what you might call a course in intellectual self defense. You do not have a right to say anything that does not conform to the prevailing doctrinal system of the day. So take say the Vietnam war or the current war in afghanistan.

questions: do you recognize or acknowledge the spiritual life and is it a factor in who you are?
answers: That is a very personal question. I do not talk about it much. Personally i am contented being a child in a penitent church with my family and friends.

questions: the spiritual dimension in terms of religion. is that at all a factor?
answers: For me it is not. I am a child of the enlightenment faith.imo i think irrational belief is a dangerous phenomenon and i try to consciously avoid irrational beliefs even though they may be real.

questions: is it possible that religion could ever become a more positive and healthy resource for humanity than it presently is?
answers: I think religion has often played a very positive role. Take western civilization the catholic church has played an honorable role in helping those in need.

questions: chomsky are you concerned about the impact of the christian coalition on govt schools etc?
answers: I think it is a very positive development. I mean what is happened in the last 30 years is probably the most exciting period in human history. There has been an enormous change in people is attitudes and in social forces.

questions: is not it the nature of politics for organized groups like the naacp or the aclu to attempt to impose their will on others. let is get serious?
answers: Will is one thing doctrinal controls something else. One of the points on which clinton and bush differ is on control of public opinion. On that i think they are pretty much on the same page though bush goes a little bit further.

questions: and also in central america. how does it work in your relations with these people?
answers: It basically does not come up. I mean they know where i stand i know what i am doing i can talk to them. It is kind of a secondary concern.

questions: have you heard of these things?
answers: I have not seen that particular number but there have been plenty of things like it. I saw a cross cultural study a couple of years ago i think it was published in england which compared a whole range of societies in terms of beliefs of that kind and found a very high correlation between those beliefs and everything from infant mortality to literacy to gender equality. Which is quite striking.

questions: he said we can not renew our country unless more of us i mean all of us are willing to join churches.?
answers: I do not know exactly what is in his mind but the ideology is very straightforward. If you devote yourself to activities out of the public arena we folks will be able to run it straight and we will not have to worry about corruption or anything else. This is been rammed down the throats of working people for forty years this has worked extremely well.

questions: what are those structural reasons?
answers: The structural reason is that power is concentrated. The general policy is exactly the way that adam smith described it it is designed for the benefit of its principal architects the powerful. It serves the vile maxim of the masters all for ourselves and nothing for anyone else.

questions: i am really intrigued by your concept of abduction?
answers: Abduction. Well peirce had this one very stimulating essay which i do not think he ever pursued further called when it was reprinted in the fifties it is called the logic of kidnapping.

questions: i am intrigued by that and i was wondering if there is any sense in which you feel that there is any kind of abductive process at work in your political thought just as there is?
answers: Sure and there always has been. I mean forget the hippies and so on. They did not have any concept of abduction they thought it was just part of life.

questions: is this a cartesian common sense morality with which you approach the facts of the world political situation or is that something that comes from your early training your early environment?
answers: I am not exactly sure how early you are. It could be that i grew up in the depression and had to learn to distinguish between right and wrong and good and evil. If it was the latter it would be hard to do anything.

questions: where do we draw the line between a healthy national ethos and manufactured consent?
answers: Well i do not think it is a question of separating ethos from action. We should always adhere to the ethos of honesty and transparency and let people know what is going on.

questions: as we are talking the sandinista government has unilaterally cancelled the 19 month old cease fire?
answers: That is 19 months old if you count the time since the military coup. Now what is going on in saudi arabia is of course a serious problem for the afghans. I mean they need a reliable source of energy not reliant on middle east sun to keep their lights on and their rations down.

questions: government and what brought about this decision by the sandinistas?
answers: Well in 1986 the contra attacks picked up sharply. In fact they had been picking up for a couple of years. They picked it up right in the middle of the israeli assault on nicaragua which was a very vicious attack.

questions: at the time of the 1984 election?
answers: Yes at that time. The reagan administration made a conscious decision to undermine the conservative movement and to mobilize the far right. During the 1980s the ideology became so extreme that people began to question whether it was even worth continuing the support for it.

questions: is not that a result of the fact that the u. s. is the dominant economic and political power?
answers: No. It was true in the 1700s. Take a look at the declaration of independence.

questions: not recently?
answers: Take a look at it some time. It goes back to the origins of history. You will find that the united states has been condemned for international terrorism almost from the beginning.

questions: it still exists in british attitudes towards ireland?
answers: I do not know the country well enough to know if people are still carrying on the attitudes of the 1930s but in the united states of america of course it is practically disappeared. There are very few people who say look i lost my copy of read the american edition of history and there were all these things i wanted to read but now i can not find it.

questions: and what problems and opportunities does that present the united states?
answers: Well it is interesting to watch american elite opinion react to this the way it has in the past. So for example in 1976 the british foreign office released a study of the human rights situation in latin america. This was a very careful study they did not just give a figure.

questions: ruling class like baker for instance who seem genuinely to want to push detente and push co operation with gorbachev?
answers: I do not really think there is much of a break in this in the united states though there does appear to be a point to what you are saying. As far as europe is concerned there are two separate issues.

questions: if you look at four areas of the globe south east asia afghanistan southern africa central america how does the new thinking by both sides reflect itself in these four areas?
answers: I think that is very important. What is happened is two basic things which went on independently but fortuitously coincide. When bush was elected he was welcomed by a large part of afghans who felt that they had been let down by the west and it was time to bring them back.

questions: there just were not profitable investment opportunities in the u. s?
answers: To have profitable investments in fact you do have to go back to classical economics. The reason why steel workers did not invest in united states is not because they would have made much profit. They could have moved production elsewhere.

questions: why was that?
answers: Because skinnerian behaviorism is off the wall. It is as hopeless a project as trying to explain that the onset of puberty results from social training. But i really do not know whether skinners still maintains this extreme position even though it seems to be empirically impossible.

questions: were the costs that great?
answers: The contra costs were great. It is costs in world opinion and domestic disorder not in money. Money is nothing but a device by which the powerful maintain power and control.

questions: ruling class that even if they regard what they are doing as perfectly moral others?
answers: Moral does not arise. They care about public disorder and destruction and that is why they pursue programs of massive indoctrination designed to make the population hate public authority and fear it. Public order is maintained by control of attitudes and opinions which are channeled into the political arena.

questions: but one of the things they take into account is the fact that other people around the world are going to regard what they are doing as?
answers: Other countries will. People will make mistakes. Mistakes are made all the time even within the most powerful states.

questions: ruling class as psychotic or something like that is to look at it on a personal level which is not?
answers: No i think it is psychotic. It would not be the first time that the soviet union has been accused of that i am sure.

questions: the difference that i am trying to draw out is that maybe that is the way that individuals that are part of the u. s. government think of these things?
answers: It is not their thought process. It would not surprise me if it were the other way around. One has to distinguish what i just described from official policy and what the public thinks about it.

questions: but we would say that that is not what drives u. s. policy in these areas. what drives it is the?
answers: The reasons that are given are interesting but do not bear on the question. Undoubtedly there are reasons. One reason is simply the interest of corporate power. 2nd is just a matter of historical arrangement.

questions: there was an ideology of the white man is burden in the nineteenth century and later?
answers: That is true. It was there and so on. But what i just said is a paraphrase of a much more important document.

questions: even some parts of left opinion in britain have those sorts of illusions?
answers: Western europe is very heavily culturally colonized by the united states a lot more than they believe. But here it is a kind of reigning ideology and for the most part it succeeds. There are a couple of exceptions.

questions: s. clearly won or lost in say these four areas of the globe?
answers: First of all they are not even close to being won. There is a lot of complicated problems in the world where you can not just pick one issue and call it a win or a loss.

questions: but richard pipes?
answers: Yeah richards pipes. The first time i heard of it was on the radio and i had to look up the source. But it turned out to be a report from the new york times about a conference going on in buenos aires.

questions: i know i know?
answers: Plot twist. Humans are endlessly creative and can come up with a million different ways of approaching anything. It's part of what makes us human.

questions: like that stuff of his in the new york times?
answers: But did you ever see richard pipes articles when kal 007 was shot down. Well that was interesting. I mean why would they do that unless they thought they were going to get killed. Look there is a rich man is shooting down a couple of fighters.

questions: he is the historian at harvard?
answers: Yeah big shot historian. He teaches courses in the history of science and society. Some of them are pretty good.

questions: russian historian?
answers: It went something like this. I would not swear to the details but it was some story like the russians lured it off course in order to shoot it down.

questions: but the response to that by somebody named samuel huntington is that well we may have defeated the russians to a certain degree but this may bring about the end of the long peace and a new rivalry i would take it among the western nations?
answers: This business about defeating the Russians is complete nonsense. There never was a Russian threat at any point. As far as capitalism and communism go capitalism was superseded by communism and capitalism could not possibly be sustained on the basis of a hostile military alliance.

questions: you mean market capitalism?
answers: What is called capitalism is a particular form of state capitalism that existed in the united states since the late 19th century. It is based on the maximization of private gain at the expense of the public. A society in which wealth is concentrated in a tiny elite is authoritarian in its essence.

questions: we argue that what happened in the soviet union is a result of the civil war the intervention by imperialist powers and the disintegration of the working class by the end of the civil war?
answers: I do not agree with that. By early 1918 they had already undermined the unions by expelling the left and by other means. Lenin and trotsky simply went back to what they were doing before the revolution and in fact kind of redefined what socialism means in terms of state capitalist planning.

questions: that was trotsky is position in 1920 but not lenin is position?
answers: There are some differences. In the 1920s lenins position was more or less vacuous. There is a strong i think tradition of vacuity in socialist thought from the enlightenment up until the early 20th century but that is largely a myth.

questions: we would like to debate you on that but?
answers: That is like saying that the moon is made out of green cheese. It does not exist. Science can not answer questions like that because it cannot conceive of anything beyond a very small core of sciences. Look there is no theory of gravity it is just kind of assumed.

questions: that we think is a second major factor in making the development of a socialist society in russia in that period impossible unless there was support?
answers: I think there would have been a possibility if the popular organizations had been able to develop then maybe things could have happened. But lenin and trotsky were not going to allow that to happen that was exactly inconsistent with their vanguardism. You can not allow popular forces to exist that are not in accord with the interests of the ruling class.

questions: i think that misunderstands what both lenin and trotsky meant by vanguardism?
answers: Oh yes that is clear. I do not see anything ambiguous about that. Anyhow whatever date we put on it there is no socialism in the soviet union.

questions: they are forced to expand their economies as a result of?
answers: That is right but there is a difference between a bureaucratic state co ordinated system of the soviet kind and a kind of conglomerate state capitalist system the american kind. The former has tremendous advantages. It can appeal to the lowest strata of society the latter does not have that luxury.

questions: oh yeah that is true?
answers: But we could argue about the date at which this took place. Is it 1967 or 1968.

questions: we say 1927?
answers: Ok but wherever you put the date it is so long in the past that to talk about the decline of socialism is ludicrous. It does not exist. There never has been or ever will be a socialist system in which working people play a significant role. Bradley manning should be regarded as a hero not a criminal.

questions: the shift politically by the sandinista government in nicaragua?
answers: That is a good thing for the people of nicaraguans because they are getting at least some degree of control over their own lives and possibly even over foreign policy.

questions: i mean just the signing of the peace accords and so forth?
answers: That s not a shift. They have been after that since the beginning. You can see it in the programs they are running day in and day out prepare for war.

questions: but the goals they set in the early 80s we will never negotiate with the contras?
answers: They never proposed anything. In fact the only proposal i ever heard of was by giora eiland a former israeli national security adviser. I pressed her beeeep it for a long time and finally she gave in and agreed to an agreement with nicaragua. (inaudible) that is it.

questions: there is been a lot of changes over the last 10 years. how do you see?
answers: Under the pressure i do not agree with that description. I think that from their point of view as they got certain gains they were going to give up certain things they would been holding on to.

questions: sometimes critical but nonetheless?
answers: I find it very difficult to talk about the left in the united states because i am not sure what the term refers to. Does it refer to witnesses for peace for example. Well i happen to be a friend of theirs and i think they are terrific but i do not agree with their tactics.

questions: probab speaking in the broadest sense?
answers: But you know witnesses for peace are conservative christians why are they part of the left.

questions: ultimately we would want to define it in terms of people who oppose the untrammeled interests of the ruling class?
answers: Ok. fine. I do not disagree with identifying the category but i am a little worried about the term left which is being bandied about.

questions: but russia already is an industrialized country?
answers: Well i think it is one of the most advanced countries in the world. It has advanced infrastructure and so on thanks in large part to the state sector. But you go back a hundred years to say the spanish revolution. They were probably the first advanced country to institute a national health care system.

questions: in the soviet union there is certainly enough wealth for the mass of the population to have the necessities of life in much greater abundance than they have now but as it turns out there is huge waste in the economy vast amounts of money spent on the military and so on?
answers: It is not just the united states. It was estimated about a century ago that about 70 percent of all the banknotes in circulation were unused.

questions: no the economy is incredibly inefficient as a result of bureaucratic planning?
answers: That is right. It is a centralized command economy and it never works. I do not think it ever will work.

questions: in some sense it is very unclear what they want out of this?
answers: I think there is a kind of a tactical issue with the syrian revolution. Isis seemed to have an almost religious commitment to drive the regime as far as possible from the moderate elements it displaced and to radicalize the population. I doubt that they will yield anything.

questions: what do they want?
answers: They are calling for an end to the occupation a political settlement and a diplomatic settlement with the international community being the final arbiter. Now that is not exactly the position of the israeli right wing but it is their position from the right.

questions: except c. everett koop?
answers: Alex cockburn had a story about that. I have written about it too. Here is a real example of the way the media works.

questions: it has the advantage too that it justifies police harassment and social control?
answers: There are all kinds of devices to control people. You can invent a world in which nothing happens except random violence deaths and so on but that is not very interesting. We want people to be passive and obedient and directed to other things not to think about these things.

questions: you have spoken about how you see the labor movement being seriously weakened the left in a state of perpetual disarray?
answers: But that has good sides too. I mean the things that i have been talking about like the media the journals and so on those rely very heavily on donations from basically the very wealthy and the corporate sector. If they could just get their act together it would be wonderful.

questions: it has good sides but how do you see things evolving say in the near future in the next two or three years?
answers: I do not know. I suspect more of the same. There are objective problems people sense them they react to them sometimes they take a step back and try to find some other way to deal with them but these are human affairs not mechanical affairs.

questions: are these appropriate ways to refer to this event?
answers: There is no doubt that there was a meeting of two worlds. But the phrase discovery of america is obviously inaccurate. What they discovered was an american empire that had been discovered thousands of years before by its inhabitants.

questions: so indigenous peoples are correct when they refer to it as the conquest or the invasion?
answers: Obviously. One can discover an uninhabited area but not one in which people live. If i travel to mexico i can not write an article entitled the discovery of my native america.

questions: is october 12 1492 a date that should be celebrated.?
answers: Well i do think that people should pay attention to it it is an extremely important date in modern history. In fact there are few events in human history that have had such formidable implications. The conquest of the world was the most dramatic and far reaching step in the development of industrial capitalism since the spanish and portuguese conquests more than a century ago.

questions: five hundred years after this geographical error was clarified these people are still being called indians. why?
answers: Well i think that this reflects the general contempt for indigenous peoples. If they did not really have any right to be where they were it also would have mattered little what they looked like. The conquerors equally could have set about exterminating them or converting them to their religion or to some other form of paganism.

questions: in light of the mistreatment suffered by the indigenous people of the united states how can you explain president reagan becoming defender of the indigenous miskitu people of nicaragua?
answers: Remember we are talking about a different society here. The society was devastated by state violence hundreds of thousands of people killed priests tortured and mutilated children and everything in between. In the midst of all this the president came along and said look you know you people are suffering just as much as the people in vietnam but we have a responsibility to try to help you.

questions: has this situation changed in recent times?
answers: Yes it has changed. I clearly remember when i was a child the favorite game for young people was cowboys and indians. You went to the forest and pretended that there were indian villages. Your aunt or uncle would come visit you and tell you what the Indians were eating and so on.

questions: so native americans continue to be at the bottom of the racial prejudice scale?
answers: Yes by many standards they occupy the lowest point and in fact they are virtually considered non existent. There is a whole literature on this dating back to the american colonies. Just about every kind of discrimination is based on the notion that if you are a black person in this country you must be a criminal or a spy.

questions: some have proposed bringing the statue of columbus from barcelona to new york to marry it to the statue of liberty as part of the 1992 celebrations. what do you think of this idea?
answers: Colombus was one of those guys that you read about in the gospels. If you look at him carefully he was a slaveowner. So when the city of helena was taken over by the pirates and they decided to put him on the island so that they could have slaves they took him with them and renamed him victor.

questions: this answer seems very strange to me. what do you think about it?
answers: Well i also think it is a strange answer. I can not understand it neither can i accept it. If i could understand the answer i would be happy to give it to you but i do not have that capacity.

questions: i think that is more or less the meaning?
answers: What happened 500 years ago is of course still happening now.

questions: many apologists for the fifth centenary celebrations say that the spanish brought civilization with them and in particular the marvelous language of cervantes and insinuate that due to this incomparable language it was all worth it in spite of some atrocities taking place?
answers: I do not know the beeeep period well enough to know if someone said that japan destroyed christian civilization the way the communists did but i would not regard it as outlandish. Even lenin was somewhat surprised at what the russians were able to do. It is kind of like asking whether korea was worth fighting about in 1945.

questions: a similar statement has been made by people who say while there were sorrows they are compensated for by the coming of the christian faith.?
answers: I do not agree. The germans took christians with them when they came to europe. For the most part they treated them with respect.

questions: how can a bit of money make such a change possible after 150 years?
answers: The answer is in the question. People have a price some will sell themselves for five cents others will ask a million dollars. The same is true of artisans.

questions: they justify this campaign by claiming that the monument is a monument to hatred and not to reconciliation. what is your opinion of this?
answers: The conquerors do not want the truth to be known not only that spain conquered large parts of the western hemisphere but also that they benefited from it and still do. As i have said the oft mentioned north south conflict the european conquest of latin america has often been portrayed as a struggle between the north and the south.

questions: this is because an innocent action like the building of a monument?
answers: There is nothing innocent about it. Anything that generates consciousness and understanding among the poor people of the world is not innocent.

questions: it is dangerous?
answers: Very dangerous that is understood and i think we should be concerned about that. Right now syria is descending into suicide.

questions: so we are a dangerous species?
answers: Absolutely. That is why they sent the prophets into the desert thousands of years ago to test them. And they did not find any of it.

questions: do you think with the changes in technology and the creation of a genuine world market that there may be the beginnings of a conflict between straight business interests and the traditional american foreign policy goals of controlling foreign countries?
answers: There is always that conflict. In fact it is been going on since world war ii. For example there was a brief period in the mid 19th century when the united states was trying to impose a kind of global order on what was then called the japanese world. After that it became a global competition and us interests were generally opposed.

questions: to what extent can the united states impose its will?
answers: In the late 1940s the world system was extremely unusual from a historical point of view. There was no monolithic power ruling the hemisphere. From that point forward it was pretty much a one party state with two factions which were each trying to maximize their own wealth and power. Not a pretty picture.

questions: will not their choices be dictated by their own economic interests?
answers: Within the united states itself there are powerful forces working to restrict democracy. One of them is the december 2007 decision by the u. s. treasury to impose a 15 percent tax on dividends.

questions: precisely and ruling groups will be out to maximize their profits?
answers: Not necessarily. That assumes capitalist domination of every country and everything else is up for grabs by the market forces. So take say the united states.

questions: what is the economic interest now in central america?
answers: Well it is an economic issue. I mean the united states has always wanted to get into this. It used to be called asian oil.

questions: but the resources to be extracted in central america are minimal on a world scale?
answers: Yes but that is not what counts. It is like asking how much wood has been cut in a square foot of land. That does not mean anything because the amount of wood on the planet is zero but it would be nice to have more than that in the world.

questions: what would be the harm in letting a country like nicaragua go its own course?
answers: Here we come to another long standing concern of american planners which has never been abandoned. That is the rational version of the domino theory. There is no moral equivalence whatsoever between acts of aggression by one state against another state and the use of force to coerce or intimidate third parties.

questions: corporate interests will no longer have to be concerned about controlling countries politically?
answers: I do not think so. There is a force toward integration of the world market and so on. But it is always been true that countries will want to pursue their own independent course.

questions: is not it possible though that at some point the market itself may start to provide the service of undermining popular movements without the need for more direct applications of force?
answers: I think you can find areas where it is happening in the united states itself. Through american history it has been necessary repeatedly to use violence to prevent democracy from developing. Labor unions are one of the classic ways in which isolated people who lack individual resources can join together to enter the political system.

questions: to what do you attribute the move by the socialist countries toward market organization internally and some limited opening up of their economies to the world market?
answers: The basic reason is that these countries lack a viable social democratic alternative. These so called socialist societies have absolutely nothing to offer the vast majority of the population. They rely almost exclusively on state coercion to ensure that they live in misery and can not develop their capacities or interests.

questions: politically how important is the way the media is organized the actual corporate structure who owns the newspapers how many newspapers there are in the given town the way the tv networks are owned and regulated?
answers: It is very important. In fact if you go back to the period of the freest press you could see it very clearly. So much so that at the time there was a whole movement of people who wanted to try to get national television off the ground and start carrying things on independently. Not just newspapers but also periodicals and so on.

questions: why would not it?
answers: Because the same social forces would essentially operate. If there were say two newspapers or three newspapers in boston instead of one there would probably not be that much difference. It is some difference you lose something but i must say that i do not want to underestimate it.

questions: is this because both have made the same ideological choice or both have personal or class interests in organizing it that way or is there also a tension with the needs of efficiency and production?
answers: There is no evidence that it has anything to do with efficiency or even production. The distribution of power and the course of history was such that those groups who could gain their power by exerting authority over the control of production did so.

questions: where has real socialism or something approaching it actually been tried?
answers: It has been attempted here and there but it usually dies out. In fact the last time i looked it was in spain in the spanish revolution of the 1960s. A real attempt to revive the ideas of kropotkin and other left intellectuals was carried out here under the leadership of cortana a program that has since been abandoned.

questions: you have said that totalitarian states have to control action but democracies have to control thought. can you explain that distinction?
answers: Two terms that are used in very different circumstances are totalitarian and totalitarian are mislabelled. In the case of germany for example there is not a word of socialism in any official document.

questions: what will be the legacy of the so called reagan revolution?
answers: In many ways it has certain similarities to what was called the hitler revolution. Putting aside atrocities and massacres and that sort of thing just look at the mechanics of it. Hitlers revolution was keynesian economics pre kosovo whatever you want to call it revitalizing the economy through military spending which worked extremely well.

questions: you just returned from the middle east?
answers: From israel and the occupied west bank.

questions: how for instance does the new york times compare with ha aretz?
answers: It has typically been the case that you get much better coverage in the hebrew press in israel. That is no longer true. Haaretz is one of the worst and is probably the only establishment newspaper in that country insha is worse. Pakistan is a very different story.

questions: does it reflect a change in attitudes either among the american public or elite?
answers: I think it is a mixture. For one thing there are a couple of good reporters there. I was very pleased to see that the new york times withdrew thomas friedman as they called him i guess effective april fools day because i thought he was one of the better reporters in the media and had done some good reporting on iraq.

questions: is there protest in israel against the current policies?
answers: There is but it is very slight. I mean for example there was a demonstration in new york a couple of weeks ago maybe a thousand people maybe not a big deal. But there has been virtually no protest against military action or towards the occupation.

questions: does the peace movement grow out of an older tradition?
answers: Partly. Yesh gvul has been around since 1982. a lot of the people have been involved in things for years so it is a little older than the hashomer hatzair.

questions: they are not exactly popular now. how much credibility can they lose?
answers: I agree with you. We had discussions on that and we disagreed. My feeling is that they should come out with a clear forthright political statement. Put it in the open and let the chips fall where they may.

questions: which is why he won the pulitzer prize?
answers: He was the first serious writer to really capture the mood of the times. You could not find a more accurate description than that of jeane kirkpatrick in the new york times a few days after the fall of barcelona.

questions: i do not remember anything?
answers: Nothing. But now he is the man who predicted the uprising. Then he goes on to say that everyone is crazy.

questions: and that kind of statement is not criticized in israel?
answers: Well i talked about it with friends of mine. But as far as i know nobody even noticed it. I mean it is perfectly normal for the government to want to undermine whatever it can with regard to the international consensus on a particular issue.

questions: is that a disappointment to the israelis?
answers: I think so.

questions: were the expulsions from the west bank and the assassination in tunisia an attempt to goad the palestinians into violence?
answers: I would assume so. They would much rather have real violent resistance. You could see it when the girl tirza porat was killed in beita in israel.

questions: some say their devotion to the plo is partly lip service?
answers: Well it is more than lipservice. I think they believe it. In fact the very fact that they are discussing it shows just how much of an obsession they have with the so called non violent resistance groups which by virtually every measure are terrorist groups. Their obsession is not with them as a movement but with those who call themselves supporters of terrorism.

questions: it sounds a little like labor union members who support leaders who they know are corrupt?
answers: Exactly. Those guys are crooks but that is what we are stuck with. We would like a different world but this is the world and we have to deal with it. Part of the reason for the extreme reaction is that the facts are completely unremarked upon.

questions: what about the palestinian intellectuals we hear so much about people like hanna siniora and mubarak awad?
answers: I asked about them. They are the people the press and peace now go to. If they were up for it they would take part. Naturally they do not want to take parts with a brutal terrorist state which israel is playing a very significant role in supporting.

questions: the section of your book the fateful triangle that really struck me was on the secret agreement between king abdullah and ben gurion to partition the palestinian lands between them?
answers: More material has come out on that since. Simha flapan is interesting book has more on it. Nobody yet has a document which says it or can find a reference to it in the middle east or anywhere else.

questions: was this post 1948?
answers: It was either 1948 or 1949. right in that period. This is discussed with some documentation in flapan is book.

questions: syria was willing to settle in 1949. how about egypt?
answers: By the time nasser consolidated power in 1953 he was already moving toward a peace settlement with israel.

questions: did sharett represent a real difference from ben gurion?
answers: He was a different kind of nationalist. He thought that the jews should own what they were doing. Maybe they do but for the moment they are not getting any.

questions: he had the same position that people criticize the plo for its covenant?
answers: Exactly. I have pointed that out before. But i do not think that was reason not to negotiate with ben gurion.

questions: yet israeli air and ground raids in lebanon have killed many more civilians than the repression on the west bank?
answers: Take the last few days. They invaded but nobody knows what they really did because they do not allow any reporters. But they obviously totally destroyed one village and they were shelling very intensively. Not only that but helicopters were attacking civilian targets all the way to the golan heights where there are no restrictions except for maybe a couple of thousand people.

questions: it would be on the front page of the new york times?
answers: Oh my god. We would bomb. I mean there is not a country in the world that does not have some kind of a press freedom law. Now what is going on with regard to the 43 disappeared students in mexico not being picked up by the police.

questions: they would not even print negative reviews hatchet jobs?
answers: It is interesting. Take a look at england for example. In englands most of the establishment literature was written in the mid 19th century.

questions: they keep a file on you?
answers: It reads kind of like an fbi file half truth half lies. People go to talks and send in what they claim i said often an inversion of things that they heard. Also clippings inter office memos correspondence that has been destroyed.

questions: it is actually a quote that comes up a lot attached to your name now?
answers: Sure. Why not. I can be clearer. It's pretty simple actually.

questions: that period of dissidence is unforgettable. yet you say we are a more dissident nation now?
answers: No. In many respects our society and culture are very dissimilar to those of the thirties. There is much less consumerism advertising limits on free expression and so on thanks in large part to the powerful propaganda apparatus. Still it is a different society than the fifties or sixties.

questions: and they went underground with it?
answers: Yes in fact the reagan administration was literally driven underground by a dissident population. The scale of clandestine activities during the 1980s is a closely monitored secret. In the pentagon papers for example there is one volume the negotiations volume which might turn out to be quite important. After all these people were underground for years.

questions: are you talking only about dissidence toward central american policies?
answers: No it is much broader. It includes people like the people who protested at the WTO in new york in solidarity with venezuela which is a kind of soft coup. They were crushed.

questions: are you saying that a negative poll on an issue constitutes dissidence?
answers: No it just means that the public is getting something out of it. On many issues it is perfectly well to just let the polls tell you what you ought to be voting for. For example let is take social security.

questions: but fifty five percent of the people in the latest gallup poll express approval of president reagan as he is preparing to leave office so that you have polls showing opposition to his policies while he himself remains unusually popular in the public standing?
answers: That is quite correct. The popularity of a president is usually predicted quite closely by people is sense of where the economy is going. When people sense that something is wrong with the american economy they tend to disapprove of it.

questions: that is a good question?
answers: It is pretty clear what is happening. Look at other studies of public opinion. Every year the gallup poll asks people who do you think runs the government and it usually has a question on who is in the white house. beeeep question maybe.

questions: according to a certain view?
answers: Well it is the view of a very wide spectrum.

questions: the trilateral commission?
answers: And the report they put out called the crisis of democracy. That report reflects attitudes that go way back. Even the mainstream democratic theorists have always understood that when the voice of the people is heard you are in trouble because these beeeep and ignorant masses as they are called are going to make the wrong decisions. They have to be controlled by force if they want to live in freedom.

questions: that is why we have a representative form of government?
answers: The transition from the confederation to the constitutional system marginalized the public. Shays rebellion was probably the last reflection of the popular democracy of earlier years. The revolutionary war was a severe blow to democracy.

questions: you said reagan is an interesting political figure. why?
answers: Because from a point of view which perceives democracy as a problem to be overcome and sees the right solution as being farsighted leaders with a specialized class of social managers from that perspective you must find means of marginalizing the public. And fARSIGHTED leaders are people like you and me or your parents.

questions: the president as ceremonial leader?
answers: Yes. That is why reagan is so interesting. Although a lot of intellectuals put the best face they can on it most of the population knows that in fact ronald regan had only the foggiest ideas of what the policies of his administration were likely to be.

questions: so many books from the reagan administration from the stockman book to the regan book to the new book that is on the newsstands say that the president was detached from the decision making process?
answers: More than detached. I think he does not know what it is.

questions: he is performing well the ritualistic role?
answers: It is the flag. For hundreds of years it has been the symbol of a defeated enemy. Now they want it to be the butt of jokes.

questions: you are saying that we as free individuals we can say anything we want to for example?
answers: But we do not make use of those freedoms. Sophisticated mechanisms have been devised to prevent us from making such statements even though we know perfectly well that those statements are false.

questions: political parties?
answers: Active political clubs. Unions have often played this role in other countries. The united states is unusual in the extent to which these structures are weak.

questions: they are corporations too?
answers: Take microsoft. Micros is a for profit corporation that was founded by a bunch of luddites. They wanted to create a technology that could be used for productive purposes not for consumer goods. So they made a bad deal for the public.

questions: are you suggesting that there is a conspiracy that there are people who gather and decide we are going to eliminate unions we are going to eliminate popular participation in political parties we are going to do this and that?
answers: My point is exactly the opposite. For example there was a study done in boston in which they asked a bunch of questions about people is attitudes towards organized labor and it came out kind of mixed. Some people were okay with it others not so much.

questions: doing what comes naturally?
answers: You might say it comes natural because they would never have gotten to that point unless they had internalized those values. But it is also constrained. If they stop doing it their stock is going to decline i mean their value will be reduced.

questions: if each reader subscribed?
answers: But we have overcome that possibility by the isolation of individuals and the elimination of organizations that might bring individuals together. If we want to get more insight into this it is good to look behind us in this process. This is a perfectly natural process under a capitalist industrial democracy.

questions: sixty years ago when walter lippmann talked about the manufacturing of consent a title not unlike your new book he suggested that this could mark a radical change in democracy?
answers: He said it is a revolution in the art of democracy. He was quite right. I think he is missing the point. These are not small changes that can be swept away in a single generation.

questions: do you think that is happened?
answers: It is gradually happening. Up until the 1930s there was a lively working class culture in the united states. That includes a lot of people like me the factory girls and the people who went to the countryside and worked the fields and so on.

questions: is not that because many times they got what they were after a higher standard of living for the family?
