answers: You do not have to go back far to find an example of this. The soviet union under stalin is direction sometimes used this technique. In fact it was even openly discussed in the 1930s by high officials of the united states.

questions: contemptuous?
answers: There is no such thing as sympathy for the plo. I do not understand why people are so beeeep on this issue. Suppose i am driving and i see a group of people sitting in a cross street refusing to move. Do i give them a right of way.

questions: but if you conduct polls to tell you what the people want and they tell you are you not listening to the voice of the people?
answers: Only if that changes your mind. But of course the system is based on the assumption that it does not. So what you do is you interview people and ask what they want you to do.

questions: of reducing the importance of the individual and the individual is participation in the political process?
answers: We are even proceeding beyond the point where people can ratify the decisions made by others. How is that any different from a coronavirus.

questions: i once interviewed edward bernays the pioneering figure in american business public relations. he talked about the engineering of consent.?
answers: Yes he thought it was a wonderful thing. In fact he described it as the essence of democracy. To convince the masses to accept what he called the political and moral necessity of allowing state power to function essentially without constraint or even democratic control.

questions: the effort to persuade people to see things your way?
answers: You do not have to convince them it is not the way you see it but it has to be done in a way that does not look as if you are trying to convert them to some kind of irrational belief system. That is the first step. You have got to make them think for themselves.

questions: a vice president at at t in 1909 said that he thought the public mind was the chief danger to the company. what did he mean by that?
answers: The general public might have funny ideas about corporate control. For example people who really believe in democracy people like the knights of labor people with real labor under their belts might take adam smith seriously. But these people did not happen to be in the power structure and they could not make a decision about it without the active participation of the corporate sector.

questions: that is the premise of your whole view is it not. that in democracy the people should initiate?
answers: They should run their own organization whether it is a community or a union. I do not think you have to make a decision on that just make it clear that you will not tolerate that kind of organization in your life.

questions: should corporations be run by their shareholders?
answers: No. The very idea of shareholders reflects the conception of the wealthy getting more votes than the poor a concentration of power so extreme that elections are basically bought. I do not think there should be shareholders.

questions: but why do you think more democracy is the answer?
answers: Democracy does not mean a system in which the mass of the population is passive and obedient. Democracy means that there are some who are trying to influence public affairs and public policy and they react to the public arena in various ways. I do not think that is too much of a problem in countries like the us or canada where popular sovereignty and popular participation are so strong.

questions: but why do you think if we go that route?
answers: That is the only hope that other values will come to the fore. If the society is based on control by private wealth it will reflect the values that it in fact does reflect now greed and the desire to maximize personal gain at the expense of others.

questions: but by your own analysis we are moving in the other direction?
answers: Certainly the faculty are. My own feeling is that for the most part they are pretty passive and obedient and i do not see much of a point in much activity on the part of the students.

questions: what is the evidence for that other than the polls?
answers: Something much more striking than those polls are the events of the 1980s. During that period the government was driven underground. It was forced to undertake large scale clandestine activities because the domestic population would not tolerate those activities overtly.

questions: i have to tell you the kennedy administration the johnson administration and the nixon administration all engaged in domestic propaganda?
answers: Yes but there is a substantial increase in scale under reagan. The regan administration had a massive enterprise to control the public mind. In fact when this was exposed during the iran contra hearings partially exposed one high administration official described it as the most successful operation carried out.

questions: you keep coming back though to the opposition to our central american policies so i have to keep coming back to asking what is the evidence of other dissidence?
answers: In the early sixties there was nothing like an environmental movement or a feminist movement. There certainly was not an anti nuclear movement until the 60s. That is a long time in US history.

questions: but the civil rights movement was driven by religious folk?
answers: I do not think that is true. There were some people who were totally secular. The most prominent was harvard professor of law james madison who was one of the leading figures in the enlightenment both in his day and the early sixties.

questions: martin luther king was himself a baptist minister?
answers: The civil rights movement did have wide scale support even business support. But it was crushed by violence. That is why there is so much hatred of the reagan administration in the business world.

questions: you are saying there is more democracy today?
answers: On the one hand there has been a kind of a democratization of the society in many ways. But that also has effects on other areas. So take social security.

questions: i do not see you on television and i do not see your books reviewed?
answers: It is not reviewed. It would not be reviewed in the mainstream if it were reviewed here. But anyway it does not interest me because i am not much of a reviewer. I mean i can not think of anything that is reviewed that would be of interest to me.

questions: do you think you are more tolerated today?
answers: Yes partly because my positions are less out of the mainstream as doctrinal systems shift. Also my own position on social and political issues is less extreme than in the past.

questions: you say you are invited to speak constantly and people are listening to you but at the same time the political process itself is not listening?
answers: It is listening but in its own way. It does not make any demands on me. If it wanted to make a change i would be happy to listen to it.

questions: a lot of people claim that the media are unpatriotic disloyal too liberal?
answers: That is a very interesting complaint because if you take the actual incidents and cases what you find is that they are remarkably subservient to power. There are people for whom submissiveness is not enough you have to actually grovel. They dominate the institutions and they make sure that what they do is the kind of thing that will be admired and will get away with it.

questions: so you meant it when you said that the state and the media act in cahoots to sustain the interests of the superpower they serve?
answers: They do not always act like that but they reflect the same domestic interests. There is often a tactical debate among elites. Take nicaragua for example where there was a very important debate within the united states about whether to go ahead with the mai return the us recognition of indonesia.

questions: if that is so why did so many journalists go down there and come back with stories of what the contras were doing?
answers: It is very striking that they did not.

questions: there were many who did?
answers: Including kohl.

questions: we claim that our news judgments rest on unbiased objective criteria?
answers: The chairman of the board also sees what he is doing as service to humanity. Others might see it as slightly different.

questions: jeanne kirkpatrick and others would say the fundamental fallacy of your approach is that you see a moral equivalency?
answers: I do not say anything of the kind. The soviet union and the united states are at opposite poles among contemporary political systems. What i m talking about is the exercise of power on the part of different societies.

questions: you do admit that we are a free society?
answers: I do not think the term is used to describe it very much. In the united states for example we have a very high level of control over the media. I mean the major media are owned and substantially controlled by concentrations of capital such as abc news and so on.

questions: they force people to do what they want them to do?
answers: People are slaves to power. To be free is to believe that you own your own life.

questions: what form does propaganda take in a democratic society?
answers: The basic way it works is by taking certain assumptions which express some basic ideas and then allowing debate but only within the framework of those assumptions. The debate therefore enhances the strength of the presuppositions. Take the vietnam war for example.

questions: i can tell you that is what lyndon johnson honestly thought?
answers: Well i do not think it is honest. That tells you something very deep about the country.

questions: if all this ferment is going on if there is more dissidence now than you can remember why do you go on to write that the people feel isolated?
answers: Much of the general population recognizes that they do not have many options. They can go to the political class which seems to be somewhat responsive but does not seem to provide much in the way of organized social support. There are also other options which are much harder to evaluate.

questions: we see more and more of our elected leaders and know less and less of what they are doing?
answers: The presidential elections are hardly ever taken seriously as a matter of choice. Congress especially the house is more responsive to public opinion than higher levels but even here the rate of electoral victory by incumbents is in the high nineties.

questions: you get those sort of election results in communist and totalitarian states?
answers: It means something else is happening not choice. Options are not being presented. You have a complex situation in the united states. One aspect of it is the role of money as a political instrument.

questions: there are people who take the debates seriously who go and vote who believe they are participating in a legitimate exercise of democracy?
answers: It is not a cleavage to the point of revolution. The voting is a little bit like the suffrage. You have a small group of people with a lot of power who are trying to exercise that power in their own interests in the interests of the society as a whole not just the few. No one is calling for aristide to take over the french government.

questions: now put that in the vernacular. that means what?
answers: It means that the political system increasingly functions without public input. And increasingly it seems to be functioning in ways that are not in anybodys interest certainly not the public. It is becoming more and more like a corporate system in which the board of directors has ultimate decision making power.

questions: ratification means?
answers: Well i mean ratification would mean a system in which there are two positions presented to me the voter. I go into the polling booth and i push one or another button depending on which of those positions i want. Now that is a very limited form of democratic participation.

questions: instead of having questions from journalists they should want to sit like this and talk about abortion foreign policy?
answers: That would allow the population the option of ratification at least. It would at the very least prevent the media from participating in what amounts to a form of propaganda. They are essentially instruments of power.

questions: they see them like a mountain range they will never climb?
answers: But when they do something that is critical something happens. So for example when the imf comes along and says we are going to impose on you austerity under recession. And some of the economists say well that really sucks.

questions: you have said that we live entangled in webs of endless deceit that we live in a highly indoctrinated society where elementary truths are easily buried?
answers: I do believe that. There is a great effort at indoctrination into the general population that everything that goes on in the world is somehow their fault. That makes perfect sense from their point of view. Less so for us.

questions: what elementary truths are buried?
answers: The fact that we invaded south vietnam. That is like the proverbial elephant in the room. It is there but we do not talk about it because it does not interest us.

questions: how do we extricate ourselves from this web of endless deceit?
answers: There is no simple answer to that. Human beings have tremendous capacities. If they are willing to make the effort and suffer the tremendous cost that would entail it could lead to a much better world.

questions: one would at least have to have money to subscribe to journals and newspapers?
answers: Unfortunately that is true. You need resources. It is easy for me to say because i have got a lot of them.

questions: do you think a citizen has to have far reaching specialized knowledge to understand the realities of power and what is really going on?
answers: It is not absolutely trivial but as compared to intellectually complex tasks it tends to be pretty slight. It becomes more significant as the tasks get more complex. One thing to keep in mind is that like any other domain human beings have a limited number of cognitive capacities which is why we are not intellectually sophisticated enough to carry out sophisticated scientific work.

questions: do you believe in common sense. i mean you are a?
answers: Oh i think i know what it is like to be in love. Life without love is a pretty empty affair. Maybe that means what you think it means when you say love doesnt have a name.

questions: how does a lonely individual counter this official view of reality?
answers: You struggle on your own. The marginalization of the population and its separation from institutions can only increase the level of irrationality and paranoia. And that is a problem.

questions: i think the danger is the opposite of that just a general passivity on the part of the people in which the system continues to function?
answers: That is another possibility. But the third and more hopeful one is that out of this growing sense of remoteness from actual power the sense that the democratic forms are not functioning as they ought to the feeling that you are being deceived and lied to outgrow that suspicion and begin to question the commitments that are made to yourself and to popular groups.

questions: or in the interests of safety security and conformity do we settle for order?
answers: These are really matters of faith rather than knowledge. On the one hand you have the grand inquisitor who tells you that what humans crave is submission and therefore christ is a criminal and we have to vanquish freedom. That is one view. Another view is that freedom is an illusion and that those who own the world are the masters of their own universe.

questions: you talk about faith. do you have faith in freedom?
answers: I try not to have irrational belief. We should try to act on the basis of our knowledge and understanding recognizing that they are limited. But you also have to make choices and those choices have consequences.

questions: and as a consequence of that you have for a time been ostracized by the political community. why are you not cynical and disillusioned?
answers: That is not exactly the way i see what is happened. My own views go back to childhood. But i became really active politically in the early sixties and seventies.

questions: you were a scholar living a quiet life in the world of linguistics. what propelled you into activism?
answers: I became interested in linguysics because my teenage son was beginning to ask questions about the nature of language and thought. I was drawn to the field because it was so radically different from any other field i knew. There was no philosophy to speak of.

questions: so many people want you to write and speak?
answers: And to demonstrate and get arrested. It is a big movement. In fact the last demonstration i got arrested for was at the october 12 march. Back in the 70s when this was happening a lot of people were in jail rockefeller hospital bed restitution.

questions: but what was it. was it the war?
answers: That is what pushed me over the limit. Partly it was the fact that lyndon johnson actually agreed to go along with the programme. It broke new grounds.

questions: and the movement succeeded?
answers: Oh yes. In fact they succeeded very well. The melvilles. I mean the really harsh ones the ones we have been fighting bitterly about are actually milder versions of what was going on then and probably still is.

questions: stopping the war?
answers: Yes and creating a big cultural change. Lots and lots of people of whom i was one tiny example were doing the same thing. The general effect was to dramatically change the cultural climate in all sorts of respects in everything from civil rights to feminism to the new left to international affairs to everything in between. That is what you call a cultural revolution.

questions: now as a result of that the upcoming celebration of the five hundredth year of christopher columbus is discovery of americas will also be met by a counter demonstration by descendants of those millions of people who were wiped out after the europeans arrived?
answers: That is right. I hope others will join in that. Let us hope that those who regard themselves as having a right to set off bombs in washington will do so without expecting a response from washingtonton.

questions: someone wrote that you have taken on too much of the harshness of the world that you have struggled against?
answers: Well i do not feel it. I think i know the person who wrote it who is probably the most severe critic of my work the american political philosopher john dewey.

questions: not just noam chomsky but most dissenters do not get much of a hearing in this medium?
answers: That is completely understandable. The media will not allow it even to consider the most elementary facts. Let is take the point that time magazine made famous. They had a photo of alan dershowitz in a cage in new york.

questions: in order to cohere society needs a consensus does it not. it needs an agreed upon set of assumptions?
answers: I think we need tentative assumptions not just for descriptive purposes but also for explanatory purposes. Here we are not at the dissident fringe but rather in the mainstream.

questions: but in politics?
answers: In political life the object is to preserve privilege and power. But that is not a value that should disqualify us from participating. I am not asking that of you.

questions: the genocide of this century the holocaust?
answers: It is indescribable. The number of people who were driven from their homes thousands of villages were destroyed hundreds of thousands killed. What is more this happened in the midst of the so called libert s reign.

questions: what about the twenty first century?
answers: We are not going to have any environmental problems because that is a value that will be destroyed. What is important to preserve is the traditional values of domination and control. I mean you do not want to live in a world in which people hunt for food on the basis of whether it is there or not or whether there is some other external constraint.

questions: or if we all unplug the environment?
answers: If i say it is because i believe in free will. But i do not. Any more than john kennedy believed in freedom of speech.

questions: seems a little incongruous to hear a man from the ivory tower of the massachusetts institute of technology a scholar a distinguished linguistics scholar talk about common people with such appreciation and common sense?
answers: I think scholarship at least the field that i work in has the opposite consequences. My own studies in language and human cognition demonstrate to me what remarkable creativity ordinary people have. I do not mean to suggest that this creativity is restricted to language but rather to a very broad range of cognitive capacities and modes of inquiry that go well beyond language as an instrument of communication and thought.

questions: what does it mean in a society like ours. how can common sense emerge in this context?
answers: Well let me give an example. When i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what i hear is a discussion of sports. These are telephone conversations so there is no way to monitor what is being said.

questions: do you think people are inhibited by expertise?
answers: There are also experts about football but these people do not defer to them. The people who call in talk with complete confidence. They know what they are doing not the uninformed person who might have some reservations.

questions: can one turn this around are experts and intellectuals afraid of people who could apply the intelligence of sport to their own areas of competency in foreign affairs social sciences and so on?
answers: I suspect that this is rather common. Those areas where there is very little intelligible evidence people tend to pick up on it if they can but if it is presented as substantial evidence it tends to be discounted. I do not know how one can demonstrate that x is more intelligent than y but that is a matter of logic not profound intelligence.

questions: do they understand the social processes they mystify?
answers: Most people are not liars. They can not tolerate too much cognitive dissidence. I do not want to deny that there is outright deceit in the intellectual world but it is at the lower end of the cognitive scale and reflects rather sharply the elevated level of self-deception that is so characteristic of educated Western society.

questions: what does this say about how our society operates?
answers: The first thing it should say is that we are a very free society. I do not mean that there is nothing wrong with you and i certainly donot have anything to hide. To tell you the truth i would not even know to look at my own house i am sure there are cameras all over and people watching.

questions: yet the business community can turn out an enormous literature about development and modernizing other lands not to speak of the good life here at home?
answers: That is certainly correct. It is true that the professional and managerial classes in the united states have a great deal to contribute to the general well being of society. I do not exaggerate when i say that this elite domination is based on centuries of intense training and dedication.

questions: do you have a deep faith in reason?
answers: I try not to have irrational belief. We should try to act on the basis of our knowledge and understanding recognizing that they are limited. But if you start looking at the world in the framework of irrational beliefs you are going to get catastrophes. Fix your priorities.

questions: not even in reason?
answers: I would not say faith. I think it is all you can do. But i do not think i can make a case that i am better than anybody else.

questions: at times it is a system that seems to have extraordinary strength and other moments there is a question of vulnerabilities that are evident in the unease the fear?
answers: Well the danger is real but let is be a little bit clearer. The idea that the united states should have the right to use military force anywhere in this world is to an overwhelming extent a fantasy. There can not be any justification for it.

questions: you have rarely written much on the kinds of experiences that led to your politics even though it seems to me they may have been deeply formed and influenced by your background?
answers: None of this is particularly new i am afraid. These are things that i grew up with and that influenced my politics as did lots of things in the 1930s like the vietnam war and the american revolution.

questions: why is this so. were there some works that did influence you?
answers: Of course there have been but it is true that i rarely write about these matters. I am not writing about myself and these topics do not seem particularly pertinent to the topics i find interesting. There are things that quite impress me about the 1960 is but i have grown up with it and can not put it into words.

questions: you once said it is not unlikely that literature will forever give far deeper insight into what is sometimes called the full human person than any modes of scientific inquiry may hope to do.?
answers: That is perfectly true and i believe that. I would go on to say its not only unlikely but it seems to be almost certain. But still if i want to understand let is say the nature of china and its revolution i ought to pay attention to what literature may tell us about that other person.

questions: but it might be very influential in making one sensitive to areas of human experience otherwise not even asked about?
answers: People certainly differ as they should in what kinds of things make their minds work, and i think there is something to that. Some things are more likely to stimulate the mind than other things.

questions: you seem a little reticent about it?
answers: Well my reticence is partly because i am not really sure what i want to do. I have no particular interest in the philosophy of language or in science. It is enough that i find it interesting to talk about the nature of society and the relation of individuals to one another and to try to make some connections between these apparently very disparate things.

questions: what kind of schools did you go to as a child?
answers: I was sent to an experimental progressive school from infancy before i could walk. The school was called the factory school which in those days meant that the children worked in the looms and the shop floor so it was a disciplined environment. I liked the atmosphere.

questions: in new york?
answers: Well in philadelphia where i lived there was a strike going on. It was frightening. I went back to college after about a year and a half because i was so frightened i could not look at the wall.

questions: what was your college experience like?
answers: I was probably lucky in that respect. I never really went to college. Most of my friends went towards the end of their careers and i did not because i wanted to contribute to the family.

questions: was it after college that you went to live on a kibbutz in israel?
answers: I went for a few months when i was at the society of fellows in 1953. they had a program for young people ten years or younger who wanted to go out and live in the countryside. I happened to be one of the lucky few who was accepted.

questions: did you find the intellectual life stimulating. and why did you leave?
answers: Remember that i was only there for about six weeks. I did not leave because i thought i would be back i mean i had planned to stay for a long time.

questions: were you active in political organizations in earlier years in the united states?
answers: I did not have any affiliation to any group the zionist left or elsewhere. Partly it was that i am not much of a joiner i guess. Furthermore every organization which was not leninist either stalinist or trotskyite was at least sympathetic to the spanish anarchist revolution. So bin laden is a kind of an outlier in this respect.

questions: what part of the city was that in?
answers: That was at the kiosk at seventy second street and broadway if it is still there. There used to be four newsstands on that street which were taken over by the nazis and turned into what is now called the press gallery. The four were there when the african american press association was formed in january of 1963.

questions: were you also brought up in certain aspects of the jewish cultural traditions?
answers: I was deeply immersed in that. In fact i probably did more reading in those days than any other period of my life. I can date it very precisely because i began to write about it at a very young age.

questions: you rarely draw on it in your public writings. are there reasons for that?
answers: No it did not seem to be particularly relevant. It is there i mean it certainly had a good amount of influence on me as i grew up.

questions: your insights seem less derived initially from prolonged historical observation than a sense of how things are expected to operate?
answers: I guess i just always assumed it. It seems to me to follow from the simplest and most uncontroversial assumptions about motivation and interests and the structure of power namely that there should be two opposing groups of people the people who are supposed to be influencing the things that happen in the world and those people are called the opulent.

questions: they have to be dismissed because if people were to confront them they would have to write differently about the united states?
answers: Well it is interesting that it does not enrage anyone when i say this about enemies. Then it would be obvious. What outrages them is when I try to show how these patterns also exhibited in our own society as they actually are.

questions: but do you wonder why so many share such assumptions and you do not?
answers: Well maybe part of the reason is that in a certain sense i grew up in an alien culture in the jewish zionist cultural tradition in terms of religion and belief. I was brought up with a sense of awe for what i saw as a miraculous achievement of human intelligence on a grand scale overcoming all kinds of odds to bring this marvelous thing about.

questions: yet the new york intellectuals have become prime exponents of a virulent anticommunism that denies almost all the insights you start with as common sense.?
answers: In part i think age maybe was a lucky accident in my case. I was just a little too young to have ever faced the temptation of being a committed leninist so i never had any faith to renounce or any feeling of guilt or betrayal. Nor did my friends who were also young.

questions: do you look back and see this as exceptional?
answers: Oh yes. I always felt completely out of tune with almost everything around me.

questions: dr. what was it that started you on this exploration?
answers: One may be interested in language for many different reasons and from quite different points of view. My own interest has been dominated by several central questions what is language. How is this knowledge acquired.

questions: at the present point in your work what important reflections are in this mirror?
answers: The idea that language is a mirror of mind is an old one which has received expression in various ways over the centuries. I have never felt that this metaphor should be taken too literally. Rather it seems that the mirror image of our mental structures reflects something more fundamental about the nature of the human mind.

questions: is then the heavy emphasis placed on language development by nursery schools and kindergartens justified?
answers: There is little doubt that the basic structure of language and the principles that determine the form and interpretation of sentences in any human language are in large part innate. But it does not follow that emphasis on development over acquisition is misplaced. Japan did not begin to industrialize until the mid 19th century and east asia has been growing rapidly since.

questions: is this best done by direct instruction or by osmosis?
answers: Anyone who was familiar with language took for granted or ought to have taken for given that so called black english is simply a language on a par with my urban philadelphia dialect of english the english of high table at oxford japanese greek etc.

questions: one of your books the fateful triangle focuses specifically on the middle east and i was wondering if you could talk about your position on a possible two state solution to the palestinian question?
answers: I do not think that is the optimal solution but it has been the realistic political settlement for some time. We have to begin with some fundamentals here. The real question is there are plainly two national groups that claim the right of self determination in what used to be palestine roughly the area now occupied by israel minus the golan heights which is part of syria.

questions: to what extent if any have israelis of ashkenazic origin absorbed german racial attitudes toward not just arabs but even to the oriental jews the sephardim is there anything in that?
answers: I would not call it deeply rooted. It is conceivable that some of them did but for the most part they did not. My own feeling is that if you look at the whole range of behavior from dress to speech to actions to citizenship to education to social organization and so on these are quite different in arab and in european cultures.

questions: but is not it curious that they are using the old jewish stereotypes the money coming out the pockets the beards the hooked nose?
answers: I have often noticed that the cartoons and caricatures are very similar to the ones you would find in the beeeep press about the jews very much like the way the us is caricaturing them. So for example in one of my favorite cartoons there is a caricature of a judge saying you cannot prosecute someone because you are a jew you have to put him in jail.

questions: that disturbs you and?
answers: Really sick. Many people find it deeply immoral but most people are afraid to say anything about it. Nachem goldman is one of the few people who was able to get anything resembling a sympathetic hearing in which he condemned negroponte as a war criminal and a criminal himself and was practically shouted down by the faculty. This is standard.

questions: there is also on another level a very steady virulent anti semitism that goes on. can you talk about that?
answers: It is pretty hard to generalize. If you look over a longer historical sweep there have been waves but they are usually in phases. The 1930s were a pretty serious period in the united states for the first time since the second world war.

questions: in philadelphia?
answers: But they did not abandon ship immediately. They tried to reach an agreement with the israeli government which would have required that the flotilla be stopped in international waters within a few miles of shore. And they argued that it was legal.

questions: how would you account for that?
answers: There are two possibilities. One can be explained by the fact that for an organism like ours it is better to have a noisy biological system with lots of variability than a highly structured and well designed system which has a fixed genetic endowment. Well that is the way selection works. Second i think there is something to that but let is take a look at the other possibility.

questions: state interests are being served and preserved israel will be favored but the moment that those interests?
answers: That is right it will become unserving and even harmful.

questions: so what happens to the moral commitment the concern for justice in the jewish state and all that out the window?
answers: We have to be careful to not fall into the trap of anti semitism which is a special form of irrationality rooted in deeply held beliefs about the nature of the society and individuals. The powerful and privileged regard themselves as above the law just as they regard everyone else as below them and the rest as potential subversives.

questions: the united states?
answers: There is no concern for justice and there never was. States do not have responsibilities towards one another. If states are weak then they can act quite freely as long as they do act within the framework of the u. s. international law and norms and treaty obligations.

questions: except on a rhetorical level?
answers: On every level.

questions: edward said for example has pointed out that there is much more pluralism in terms of the discussion the debate in israel itself than inside the united states?
answers: It is a very plural society in fact. There are societies with a lot more interaction and communication. Let is take a case right here in boston which is pretty lively. Japan has a much larger population but they have a smaller press.

questions: you have an international reputation for your work in linguistics and philosophy and obviously you were not content with that you wanted to go out into the social and political world?
answers: Quite the contrary. It is one of the many examples that show that people often do things that they do not want to do because they have to. I made a very conscious decision about this.

questions: i think a lot of people are grateful that you did?
answers: Glad to do it. Thank you very much. Lula coulda had done it without much difficulty and it would have been much more difficult without your persistent activism. Thanks.

questions: language then is a key to human nature?
answers: In western scientific thought of the last several centuries there has been a tendency to assume that humans are a fixed kind which have a language of some kind and that other animals have no such capacities. That is about as far as i can go. I would not say that this is dogma in the scientific sense but it is traditional and it has some basis in what we know.

questions: do you mean that all our behavior is innate genetically determined?
answers: No but the basic structures for our language are innate. The specific details of how they grow would depend on interaction with the environment and other cognitive capacities.

questions: do we think only in language. or do there exist nonlinguistic forms of thinking too?
answers: The analysis of linguistic structures could help in understanding other intellectual structures. Now i do not think there is any scientific evidence about the question of how minds work. But introspection indicates pretty clearly that we do have limited understanding of the ways in which languages are used in different situations.

questions: i have read several times that we think in language but feel in nonlinguistic ways?
answers: That is true. I know that it is very difficult for me to believe that i am in a mental hospital when i look at the outside world. People talk to me in very different ways.

questions: do you believe that all our thinking is rational and linear?
answers: I do not think all thought is a kind of rational structure. But i would not call it a rational nonrational dichotomy. Rather i think of it as a particular form of irrationality.

questions: can language be nonrational?
answers: Yes so those are two dimensions that do not correlate. It is true that language is in a sense linear but that is as obvious as perceptual space is three dimensional.

questions: what do you think of the social functions of language. is it primarily an instrument of communication?
answers: I think a very important aspect has to do with the establishment of social relations and interactions. Often this is described as communication. But that is very misleading i am afraid.

questions: do we genetically inherit this knowledge?
answers: Yes we must. In fact by universal grammar i mean just that system of principles and structures that are the prerequisites for acquisition of language and to which every language necessarily conforms. Some of these principles even seem to have a kind of innate logic.

questions: does it mean that this genetic basis of language is universal?
answers: Yes that is right. But we are only one species. You can imagine a different world in which a number of species developed with different genetically determined linguistic systems and then one of them acquired the language system of the other.

questions: would such knowledge also be helpful in understanding human nature?
answers: It would in two respects. For one thing it is by itself a part of a study of human intelligence that is perhaps the central question in the study. And second i think i can say pretty confidently that if there are minds like ours then they will not be like machines. We are not made out of ectoplasm.

questions: do you mean that psychology could benefit from linguistics. could you explain how?
answers: One thing that you and i know is language. Another thing which is very important is how objects behave in perceptual space. We have a whole mass of complex ways of understanding what is the nature of visual space and how people interact in it.

questions: but if as you say our behavior and language are heavily guided by universal principles why then do they differ so much all around the world?
answers: I do not think they differed so radically in the past. I think that as human beings we quite naturally take for granted what is similar among humans and then pay attention to what differentiates us. That makes perfect sense for us as members of the human species.

questions: would this extrahuman observer think the same way about our symbols ideas needs and values?
answers: Absolutely. I think he would be struck by the uniformity of human societies in every aspect. And there is more than that just from the perspective of an observer looking through a narrow window.

questions: is not it because man wants to exercise control over the physical world?
answers: I do not think so. I think it probably reflects something very special about the nature of our minds. There is no evolutionary pressure to create minds capable of forming sciences it just happened naturally.

questions: and that we are not conscious of that?
answers: Yes as human beings we naturally assume that our mental structures are universal. But i suppose an outside biologist looking at us would see something very different. He might conclude that like other organisms we have a narrow sphere within which we live but a huge sphere outside that sphere which is our domain of experience.

questions: what domains do you consider the most backward and neglected?
answers: I think that we have basically nothing in the field of human behavior. Maybe that is just a condition of temporary ignorance. But it may be that our present limitations are temporarily an obstacle to further progress.

questions: do you mean that not only do we not have tools to develop such a theory but we are incapable of creating the necessary tools?
answers: Yes intellectual tools. Our minds are specifically adapted to developing certain theories and we have a science if the theories that are available to our mind happen to be close to true. Well there is no particular reason to suppose that the intersection of true theories with theories which are accessible to the mind is very large.

questions: can we know at least how large it is?
answers: It's a question of biology how big that intersection is. And if humans are organisms like every other organism which they are then we should expect that if there are some domains where real scientific progress is possible then there will be others where it isnt because of the competition of other organisms.

questions: why do you believe that language behavior critically depends on the existence of a genetically preprogrammed language organ in the brain?
answers: There is a lot of linguistic evidence to support this contention. But even in advance of detailed linguistic research we should expect heredity to play a major role in language because there really is no other way to account for the fact that children learn to speak with remarkable ease.

questions: is the role of heredity as important for language as it is for embryology?
answers: I think so. You have to laugh at claims that hiv uses the same genes as humans does but it does it in a different way. It makes use of the different capacities that we have that are specific to humans whereas if it were used by eagles that would be a lethal weapon.

questions: is there a special place in the brain and a particular kind of neurological structure that comprises the language organ?
answers: Little enough is known about cognitive systems and their neurological basis so caution is necessary in making any direct claims. But it does seem that the representation and use of language involve specific neural structures though their nature is not well understood.

questions: what is the relationship between heredity and environment for human language?
answers: The language beeeep interacts with early experience and matures into the grammar of the native language. If a human being with this fixed endowment grows up in philadelphia as i did his brain will encode knowledge that will enable it to decode the pitch of new york yiddish and so on. The rest of his experience is just background noise.

questions: still as your own example shows environmental factors do play a major role in physiological growth?
answers: And it goes without saying that the onset of puberty may well vary over quite a range depending on childhood diet and all kinds of other environmental influences. Nonetheless everyone takes for granted that there are fundamental processes controlling puberty that are genetically programmed. This is probably true of death as well. I see no reason to depart from this uncontroversial conclusion.

questions: what have you learned from studying human languages to corroborate your biological viewpoint?
answers: The best evidence involves those aspects of a language grammar that are so obvious so intuitively self evident to everyone that they are quite rightly never mentioned in traditional grammars.

questions: they teach everything about french or russian for example that can not be taken for granted by virtue of the fact that you are human?
answers: That is right. It is precisely what seems self evident that will be studied most critically. Some of this is elementary science.

questions: there is just no way that children can pick up this kind of information by listening to the grown ups around them?
answers: Precisely. But let me give you another example. English contains grammatical constructions that are called parasitic gaps between words.

questions: how could anyone possibly learn enough about the english language to possess the rich and exotic grammatical knowledge that we all seem to possess by the time we are five or six years old?
answers: There is an obvious answer to that the knowledge is built in. You and i can learn english as well as any other language with all its richness because we have been designed to learn languages based upon a common set of principles which we may call universal grammar. These principles cover most of human language and have had a profound effect on the arts and sciences for thousands of years.

questions: what is universal grammar?
answers: It is the sum total of all the immutable principles that heredity builds into the language beeeep. These principles cover grammar speech sounds and meaning. Put more simply it makes sure that what you say always comes out on the other end as a coherent whole with all its secrets. Hooray!

questions: could we with our specialized language organ learn the aliens language if we made contact with them?
answers: Not if their language violated the principles of our universal grammar which given the myriad ways that languages can be organized strikes me as highly unlikely.

questions: what are some other grammatical options on the universal grammar menu?
answers: In english the most important element in every major grammars is the root. In his classic study of language grammar jacques derrida defines the essential role of the stem as the link between the genitive and the declarative parts of an utterance and in particular the place where the preposition dative ends is typically placed.

questions: so what exactly would you say is the grammar of english?
answers: That is a very important question and definitely too complex for me to answer it briefly. To begin with let is just pick some elements and ask what happens when we apply some rules of grammar to them. So the sentence you just mentioned has a structure like the one below.

questions: it sounds as if your present goal is to reach the point where you can define every human language is grammar simply by specifying its choices from the universal grammar is menu of options?
answers: That is the kind of work you would hope would soon be done to take an integrated theory of universal grammars fix the parameters one way or another and then deduce from these parameters the grammar of a real human speaking language japanese swahili english or whatnot.

questions: judging from what you have said about language and heredity it sounds as if you must be sympathetic to the aims of sociobiology. is that a fair assumption?
answers: Well i think that in some respects the sociological perspective is right. I do not think it is the whole story but it seems to be a significant element.

questions: many sociobiologists would dispute your note of caution. what do you say to these claims?
answers: I am very skeptical. I have not really studied the newer research in enough detail to make any informed judgment.

questions: what do you think about the claim made by wilson and others that there is an innate incest taboo in human beings?
answers: Sorting out what is and what isn't genetically preprogrammed is a very difficult task. As i said i agree with the general approach of sociobiology. I think it makes sense to study human behavior in this broader sense.

questions: skinner is behaviorist theory of language learning and mind?
answers: Not quite skinners but pretty much in the skinning of the animal the child is reconstructing the experience in his mind in terms of structures of experience that were not there. Now this is a very significant step forward.

questions: where do you stand on his theories of the child is mental development?
answers: Piaget is position is different it is more complex than skinner is and this has not been very well studied. Piagget held that the mind develops as a whole rather like a modular structure with specific capacities developing in their own ways. This is a possible hypothesis but in fact it seems to be extremely wrong.

questions: in other words piagetians place much more emphasis on the role of experience in cognitive development than you do. are there other differences as well?
answers: There are some differences. Friedman thinks that piags should be understood in a rather Cartesian way. In his view piagenarians are at a distinct evolutionary stage from the rest of the animal kingdom because they seem to have had the sharp transition from simpler forms to more complex forms about 10 000 years ago when they diverged probably around the same time as the birds.

questions: how do you mean?
answers: Well consider the properties that determine the reference of pronouns that we talked about earlier. Once you ferret out these rules for pronouns they seem to have nothing in common with the logical operations that piagetians single out as being typical of the early stages of a child is mental development.

questions: in other words a four year old who may not realize that the amount of water stays the same when you pour the contents of a low wide glass into a tall thin container nevertheless displays sophisticated logical abilities in his grasp of the complex rules of english grammar?
answers: Yes. And these abilities are independent of what the child has learned about the physical world.

questions: if genes play a crucial role in structuring the mind is abilities is free will an illusion?
answers: Well that is interesting. Here i think i would tend to agree with descartes who says that there is really no such thing as human nature. That humans are socially constructed objects not persons.

questions: do you think that science will ever solve the problem of free will?
answers: Personally i do not think so. People have been trying to solve this problem for thousands of years and they have made zero progress. They did not even begin to scratch the surface of what was a very deep problem.

questions: can you spell out what you mean?
answers: We can laugh at a rat that always fails a complicated maze because it can not look at the maze in the right way. It is doomed to fail this test forever. Ok. so that is a sign of creativity.

questions: that is a discouraging prospect?
answers: I do not see it as much of a reason to despair. In fact i kind of like the conclusion. I am not sure that i want free will to be understood.

questions: do you think that any other human abilities fall into the same mysterious category as free will?
answers: In my opinion all of them do.

questions: all of them?
answers: Take for example the aesthetic sense. We like and understand beethoven because we are humans with a particular genetically determined mental constitution. But that same human nature also means there are other conceivable forms of aesthetic expression that will be totally meaningless to us.

questions: do you think genetic barriers to further progress are becoming obvious in some areas of art and science?
answers: You could give an argument that something like this has happened in quite a few fields. It was possible in the late nineteenth century for an intelligent person of much leisure and wealth to be about as much at home as he wanted to live at any price with as few distractions as possible and to pursue his own interests with the same energy and interest.

questions: and you think that something similar has happened in some scientific fields?
answers: I think there has been a kind of a general revival of interest in the philosophy of science and in related fields but i do not think it is been the same since the 1960s. There is this idea which goes back to the french mathematicians known collectively as bourbaki that the development of mathematics was originally the exploration of everyday intuitions of space and number.

questions: further progress in music or mathematics for example requires a scientist or artist with an unusual heredity?
answers: Well it is a different mental constitution something like being a chess freak or a runner who can do a three and one half minute mile. You have all these capacities but they are individually limited. Now that is becoming more and more the case.

questions: do these possibilities ever make you feel that you are living in a time of creative stagnation?
answers: I do not really feel it. I think that there are too many possibilities. There is too much human potential that has not as yet been realized. Thanks to the activism of the 1960s and the 1970s there were limits to what could be achieved by any one individual.

questions: how do these ideas fit into your choice of linguistics as a career?
answers: My choices were always political. In fact i probably made the same choices as my parents did. Linguists are usually professionals who devote themselves to narrow specialized concerns such as the history of science or the philosophy of language or to other concerns of their own with little if any involvement with the political arena.

questions: how would you assess your own contributions to linguistics?
answers: They seem sort of pre galilean.

questions: like physics before the scientific revolution in the seventeenth century?
answers: Yes. Before there were any scientific revolutions the major revolutions in physics were in galileo and theologiastheistics which were pretty radical. Geology was a revolution of discovery but it was kind of a background science for the next couple hundred years until the mid 19th century when everything changed and you got into the real revolution with the development of chemistry and physics.

questions: or are we going back still further to aristotle and to other greek ideas about physics?
answers: We do not know. It depends you see on when the breakthrough comes. But my feeling is that someday someone is going to come along and say look you guys you are on the right track but you went wrong here.

questions: and then we will have a scientific revolution in linguistics?
answers: I would think so although to speak of scientific revolutions occurring outside a small core of the natural sciences is rather misleading. In fact there was one major scientific advance in the seventeenth century and there have been a lot of outgrowths from it since then including biochemistry and molecular biology. But that is really the exception.

questions: how should a scientist exercise responsibility for the uses of his research?
answers: The same way that any human does in any area of personal life.

questions: do you think that there are areas in science so potentially vulnerable to social misuse that they should not be pursued?
answers: I think there is. For example research on how to build more effective nuclear weapons. I do not really think it should be carried out.

questions: what about fundamental research say basic research in molecular biology that might conceivably give the weapons makers of the next generation a new set of destructive tools?
answers: There is no simple answer to that question. Human beings are responsible for the predictable consequences of their actions. I would stop doing what i was doing if i found out that i had a terminal disease.

questions: an anachronistic question then if you were a physicist in 1929 would you have done basic work in nuclear physics even though there was already speculation about the possibility of someday building an atom bomb?
answers: It is not an easy question. There is no simple answer. Some of the things i have mentioned have had a very significant effect on my thinking and understanding of certain topics.

questions: do linguistic factors influence general cognitive development?
answers: I would like to re phrase the first question and ask what role other aspects of cognition play in the acquisition of language since as put it is not a question i can answer. I might mention here that like most human languages there is a simple rule of thumb which is that whatever the earliest linguistic evidence we have it has to be related somehow to some aspect of thought or cognition.

questions: cognition is a way of knowing and language is a medium whereby we know?
answers: Not as i am using the terms the term cognition like most terms of political discourse cognition has two meanings. One is its literal meaning you will find it in the dictionary if you look it up.

questions: so it is a separate system is it not?
answers: It splits the labor market and it gives rise to what is sometimes called the golden triangle. That is three to four times the per capita income of the poorest third of europe and by far the greatest growth of any industrial country in the world between 1970 and now. Remember that this is before the neoliberal assault on the global economy which has had devastating effects in many countries.

questions: when you talk about this language structure system are you referring to all language nonverbal language and language as a developmental process?
answers: Here we have to be a little careful. The term language is used in quite different ways and only confusion can arise from failure to distinguish them. In the first place the notion language was used to refer to human languages that is a specific biological characteristic of some human group.

questions: how is the acquisition and development of language influenced by interpersonal and intrapersonal verbal and nonverbal behavior?
answers: It depends on what aspect of communication is being discussed. I.e. Is there a question of acquisition when there is a dispute between two people over a waterway.

questions: say the first word for instance?
answers: Let is take any complex situation and ask what is the simplest way to think about it. We have no concept of simplicity before us so we can ask the same questions about complex situations. How do we proceed from there.

questions: from the study of structure comes the knowledge of function?
answers: That is extremely natural. I can not imagine any other approach. How else could one proceed.

questions: and of course that is what you were attacking when you set out to destroy the house that skinner built?
answers: Well not really. My criticism of skinners was not that he was trying to study structure on the basis of function but rather that in his day and age we have a completely different scientific approach to the study of structure. We are looking for structures which are independent of one another and very simple.

questions: that is to say are the verbal and nonverbal signal systems interrelated?
answers: Let me stress again that i do not have any doctrine on this matter the facts are whatever they turn out to be. A second point i ought to stress is that my remarks are not prescriptions for behavior and the behaviorist in that sense has nothing to advise him. He can study these phenomena however he likes and find out what is the right way to deal with them.

questions: do you believe there is a grammar of gesture?
answers: That is an interesting question. I have been talking not about sign language but about the gestural system of spoken language.

questions: has any possibility of getting us closer to the biological basis of the structure of language?
answers: I would think that the study of any aspect of human behavior has a possibility. It may not be the best way to study human nature but it is the only way that is likely to be successful. We can make significant progress in understanding human intelligence by studying other organisms much more rapidly and precisely than we do when we study humans directly.

questions: why do you think that mistake has been made?
answers: I think there is a kind of a tacit recognition on the part of the doctrinal system that there should be something like a liberal media. That is not a criticism i would take it to be a good thing. It will more or less reflect the general attitude toward reality.

questions: meaning what?
answers: What did he mean by that. That is the interesting question. Let is reconstruct what sapir was doing or intimated that he might be doing. First we have to establish for the sake of argument that there was no sabre toothed tiger roaming the grasslands of brazil 40 years ago stealing food from the hungry bears of the matador tiger reserve.

questions: some people i think have raised the question of psychological reality on the basis that literature sometimes refers to something as having a psychological reality that was generated by the mind of the writer of the article?
answers: That is right.

questions: and only by the mind of the writer of the article?
answers: True enough but that kind of criticism is quite independent of what i have in mind. One can do a bad job of constructing theories on the basis of evidence derived from button pushing informant judgment electrodes in the brain or whatever.

questions: i would interpret their use of the word psychological reality to mean that it is only real if enough people engage in it and one person is engaging in it might simply be idiosyncratic and therefore may be psychologically real to that individual but not generalizable as a psychologically real principle?
answers: See i think this is a misunderstanding. The notion of idiosyncracy is used in quite different ways and only confusion can arise from failure to distinguish them. If you want to study behavior in a laboratory you have to use different criteria depending on the nature of your laboratory and the environment in which the behavior is carried out.

questions: most people who have been objecting to the use of that term have been objecting to that meaning?
answers: No that is not correct. I am sure that the organizers of the march did not intend that as a descriptive term.

questions: but surely psychological evidence would be observing behavior that is common to enough people to make it psychological evidence?
answers: I do not see that. We can perfectly well suppose that the beliefs and attitudes of a large majority of the population are psychologically consistent. There are two quite different issues here. (a) what people believe and (b) how they behave in particular ways when presented with evidence about their beliefs.

questions: individual differences as opposed to generalized differences?
answers: Fine. But the whole discussion of psychological reality takes place on a different dimension. It has nothing to do with individual difference and shared group properties.

questions: when they say it is not strong enough did they mean that they did agree in principle with your basic method?
answers: No that is false. The israelis did not say that.

questions: well perhaps they did not agree with the way you got there?
answers: No i do not think that is quite it either. What happens i think is that experiments involving memory or reaction time for example are regarded as providing evidence for psychological reality whereas evidence of the so called linguistic type would be seen as in principle providing no evidence at all about biological reality and would therefore be regarded with some scepticism.

questions: people have accused you of neglecting the importance of the environment in your notion of the structure of language and the theory of language and as i recall you have repeatedly denied this?
answers: Let me begin by saying something that i hope is uncontroversial. Namely there exists in the human mind a sort of instinctive tendency which is to take for granted what is similar among human beings and to assume rather than try to discover what similar things are like. If there are similarities then they are probably the result of environmental influences.

questions: maybe you just never heard them?
answers: Well the fact that you rarely hear the sentences you know to be improperly formed does not help because it is also most unlikely that your native language has the proper grammatical structure. Many things do not obey the rules of universal grammar well defined and well understood among them language custom. A lot of what you learn in school is probably wrong even though it looks right to you.

questions: what i would like to know is what specifically would you use to show how the environment does play a role in the acquisition of language?
answers: It is easy enough to find a concrete example. The fact that i call this thing a table instead of a sulxan which i should say is his native language puts us on notice that this is a language that we are going to have to learn to talk to one another as well as to distinguish between what we call food and other objects.

questions: yes but what about within a particular language itself?
answers: Well there are things which are certainly a reflection of environment. The example i just mentioned for one or the fact that the detailed phonetics of my speech happens to be very much like i am sure a small group of people who were around me in my childhood. Mostly my peers rather than my parents.

questions: the navahos seem to utter things that exemplify their view of themselves in the world where action is at the center of things rather than nouns?
answers: I do not understand what that means. English certainly is not my native language but i have been fortunate enough to speak it fluently and to have had access to its rich literary and historical heritage.

questions: if i say death is taking place with me instead of i am dying what is the difference between the two statements?
answers: Well there is a difference i think between a statement like that and a much broader statement which states that whatever the consequences are for the human species as determined by some higher power these effects do not justify the resort to violence even though they may be destructive. So for example i would not say that say the fall of barcelona is necessarily a bad thing.

questions: well the difference between those two utterances would they primarily be a difference of biology or environment?
answers: What differences there may be are obviously environmental. That is i do not say the sentence in navaho and the navahos interpret it as meaning well i have come here to visit you but i am here because i swim. I eat grass and that does not change the fact that i exist.

questions: so there is something in the environment that precipitated this different structure?
answers: If there was one. But that is even true at the level of the sounds we produce. The words are not produced in an isolated way.

questions: are you saying maybe there really is not a difference that makes a difference?
answers: At the level of conceptual structure. First we have to see how far the sciences will go. Then we can say for sure that at some level there is no difference.

questions: would not it be possible that a pure navaho that was born only out of navaho stock may be inheriting some kind of structural difference for his language?
answers: It is certainly a logical possibility but i do not think anyone takes it very seriously. Of course it would be wrong to say that all navahos are necessarily hiv positive. Some are.

questions: it is not a point of view that you would take or is it?
answers: No i would not. Look i do not think taking a strong stand on social issues is a sign of intellectual dishonesty. I think people should be free to talk about them and to find out what they think but the burden of proof for any position you take is on the person making the statement not on me.

questions: in terms of structure they feel that it is rather simplistic to say that language is an organ like the heart or the liver and that it is a misrepresentation of a very dynamic complex system?
answers: Those are reasonable points but let is move a little further. The claim that the language system is as such critics assume an extremely complex and intricate structure is just plain wrong.

questions: you get such things as language you get a structure and a process which is a by product of the interface between mental and physical life?
answers: But that comes back to my original point. Why should we abandon normal canons of rationality when we turn to the study of mind. It is certainly true that in the normal course of scientific progress nothing is discovered which will revolutionize the field.

questions: no i said it has to do with the relationship between the body and the mind?
answers: Okay so why should we abandon normal canons of rationality when we talk about the study of mind. It is certainly true that human beings are separate from one another and from the natural world but that is not a reason to abandon rational inquiry into the physical world. Let is take a look at the other major category of phenomena the forces of nature.

questions: i do not think you should?
answers: Well unless we have a very strong reason to believe that the world is not going to end in some great cataclysmic event we should not act on that assumption. For example take say the united states bombing washington. Was that an appropriate use of force.

questions: nobody in his right mind would think that the mind can in its structural development influence the structure of the heart or the structure of the liver?
answers: That is absolutely untrue. Take the study of psycho somatic medicine.

questions: well you are just altering the structure. you are born with the structure of the heart?
answers: You know it is interesting that that is the way most of this is understood. Most people are taught that our biological endowment is specifically designed to allow us to acquire any language we want. But that comes from science.

questions: you can look at the heart when it comes out. you can see its structure?
answers: That is why i gave the example of puberty. There is plenty of post natal physical development evidently in fact there are neural maturation of the brain that takes place well after birth in humans particularly. Does anybody doubt that the dendritic growth that goes on from ages two to four is genetically determined and that it will continue until about age four or five or six.

questions: you learn to cope with it?
answers: But my point to get back is this. On the very assumption that you proposed namely that the language system is far more complex than the obvious physical systems of the body which may or may not be true but if it is true then a fortiori you are led to the belief that this is a case of strongly determined maturation and specific development in a genetically specific direction.

questions: of what importance is the current research in comparative psycholinguistics?
answers: Investigations that have been carried out so far i think are intriguing. Some of them premack is for example seem quite interesting. They tell us something about chimpanzee intelligence.

questions: what are the most important and promising applications of research in the psychology of language and cognition. for example in therapy in teaching etc?
answers: My general feeling is that it is practitioners therapists teachers and so on who will have to explore these questions. It would be terribly presumptuous of me even to suggest anything. [audience laughter] but i think you will find something useful.

questions: if so what kind of theory do you believe will emerge or is at present emerging?
answers: Well i am looking for a new theory too and i always have been. In fact i do not see how anybody can ever do anything different. You mention paradigms.

questions: do you mean to say that you do not think that you have not been involved in major scientific revolution in psychology?
answers: Well to compare it to the revolutions in the natural sciences is quite improper. The kind of work i have been associated with has earlier antecedents and builds very definitely and explicitly on them in quite different ways.

questions: if you have not really revolutionized the ideas perhaps you have revolutionized the interests?
answers: My own feeling is that anything i have done in the study of language or in other fields is hardly more than the application of normal standards of rationality which have been taken for granted among scientists for centuries to phenomena in these fields. When you do some things are immediately obvious.

questions: i know it is hard to look at yourself in historical perspective but it seems to me that you did have a rather major impact on the shift from a very strongly behavioristically oriented profession to a profession that is very much different at present?
answers: A good deal.

questions: where do we stand now on these two issues seven years later?
answers: At the time of the invasion of afghanistan paul wolfowitz and condoleezza rice were the national security advisers. George mitchell and robert kagan were their principal architects.

questions: attack south vietnam if the problem was not an attack from north vietnam?
answers: First of all let is make absolutely certain that was the fact that the u. s. directed the war against southvietnamese communism.

questions: so the irony is that the very reason given in the united states for fighting the war the independence of south vietnam is exactly what had to be destroyed?
answers: Exactly. And that is perfectly evident from the analysis. I mean the same scholarship that just came out with the truman studies on state terrorism has been analyzing for years how the u. s. invaded and occupied indochina and it just completely destroys any pretext there ever was for it other than the fact that it was discovered years later and the russians had them.

questions: do you think this distortion of the war is successful?
answers: It is hard to say. People who lived through the period know better. But a large part of my own feeling has been that since the early stages the american propaganda effort was quite successful.

questions: so you see the inability of the government to maneuver as it would like in el salvador as directly related to the anti war movement?
answers: Oh yes. They even have a name for it vietnam syndrome. See they make it sound like some kind of disease a malady that has to he overcome.

questions: so you feel it was the group officially defined as the riff raff lunatic fringe who really was the peace movement?
answers: Oh there is no question. You can see what happened. There were very extensive grass roots efforts beginning in the mid 60 is developing quite gradually against tremendous opposition from the corporate sector and state authorities.

questions: and they had also heard of the anti war movement is ideas against the war back home?
answers: Exactly. It was a citizen is army not separated from what is happening in american society in general. And the effect was that very much to its credit the british were able to repress the antifascist resistance and in fact helped to establish a fascist state which is something that the united states has never been able i think to achieve.

questions: are you aware of any other time in history when soldiers came home from the war and organized against their government as many vietnam veterans did through the vietnam veterans against the war organization?
answers: It is rare.

questions: what is the current u. s. foreign policy toward indochina?
answers: The official policy is not very different from world opinion. Many leading strategic analysts in the world public opinion organization have expressed their concern that an american attack on iran or vietnam might lead to a proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and a worsening of the security situation in that country.

questions: thus in a very paradoxical way your evolution ends up taking a smell of stalinism completely unforeseen?
answers: The reaction you describe is remarkable. It is obvious that the so called libert s formelles represented an achievement of enormous significance.

questions: if public opinion is indefinitely manipulated and manipulatable as you seem to want to demonstrate is freedom of expression and in particular freedom of the press worth defending?
answers: My view is entirely different. I doubt that you can find an articulated articulated position anywhere in the world. But my own feeling is that the so called free press is under severe attack both here and abroad and that its defenders are quite rightly nervous.

questions: supposing that there are minds that are free enough to read you the implacable mechanisms that you describe will only make impotent and isolated poor souls of them?
answers: Quite the contrary. In fact our books are more widely read than those i wrote at the height of the vietnam war. Contrary to what is often assumed american public opinion has shifted away from the blind conformism of earlier years and toward the critical and critical faculties of an aroused public.

questions: so i want to ask you who is the book addressed to and what effect do you expect?
