answers: These books are written for people who are interested in the social reality in which they live not just in intellectual terms but also in practical terms the sense inwhich people are expected to act.

questions: how do you reconcile your pessimism with the intransigent defense of freedom of expression that you preached elsewhere?
answers: It should be unnecessary to stress how grave the problem of free expression is in a society dominated by financial institutions corporate lawyers and doctrinally committed to doctrinal regimentation. England was unique in the world in this respect probably unparalleled. But it is no laughing matter either.

questions: that leads me to ask you whether afterwards you have had the curiosity of interesting yourself in the substance of the affair?
answers: My interest in this affair has been quite limited. I was asked to sign a petition calling on authorities to protect faurisson is civil rights and did so without further comment. That act was of course not my doing.

questions: i mean that their existence or non existence is from the viewpoint of historical research a real problem?
answers: My own view is that there are no reasonable grounds to doubt the existence of gas chambers. Of course this is a question of fact not religious faith. Only a religious fanatic would deny that questions about the nature of the world are subject to inquiry.

questions: if you have not had the opportunity to examine the substance of the record what is the reason?
answers: My reasons are the same as the reasons given by the hundreds of thousands of people who have tried the experiment and the vast majority of them have given essentially no evidence of any substance to the suggestion that there were once spiritual forces.

questions: do you think that the existence or non existence of gas chambers is a question which has an ideological political or ethnic value?
answers: If contrary to my belief it were shown that there had never been any gas chamber at all there would be no need to answer the question whether there ever was one or not.

questions: if you think that the existence of gas chambers has such a value say as something at stake in a battle about the interpretation of nazism as a historical phenomenon would you state precisely your ideas in this respect?
answers: It should be clear what the conclusions are if we want to understand the beeeep period and the crimes of the holocaust. If i understand what you mean it is that i think the concept of a gas chamber should not be used to delimit the period in which crimes against humanity took place.

questions: what do they say to each other when they meet?
answers: There is no connection apart from some very tenuous relations at an abstract level for example with regard to a concept of human freedom that animates both endeavors. However abstract these relationships may be they are not without some significance.

questions: you seem to think that the only interesting and courageous work for an intellectual is to denounce the abuses perpetrated by his own government and not be concerned with the abuses perpetrated by the governments of other countries which are easier to denounce. is this correct?
answers: Not quite. I have always held that criticism of any state or society is legitimate if it is honest. There are for example western scholars who devote themselves to nothing but the crimes of the soviet state through the cold war and so on.

questions: how do you explain this way of perceiving your action?
answers: There was no such effort on my part. It is interesting that what you report is actually believed by people in france. Maybe this is just a case of naivete not much of a reason to expect different results.

questions: does not the fact that human rights are not more respected by the socialist regimes including cuba immerse you in a state of complete pessimism of the type nothing can be expected from one side or from the other?
answers: Not at all since i expected little else of these regimes. There are many factors that impel third world revolutions towards totalitarianism or near dictatorship.

questions: you fear that the complete cynicism of american foreign policy will end up corrupting and destroying what remains of american democracy. could you be specific?
answers: There are powerful forces in the u. s. as elsewhere that will labor to secure their wealth and power whatever the human cost even at the cost of unimaginable suffering and destruction. I do not exaggerate when i say that this sentiment is universal.

questions: could you define your political position for our readers?
answers: There are really two questions here what is my position what are the consequences of my views. The first question is a very straightforward and straightforward question can i get into the white house. How come no one has asked this question before about presidential candidates.

questions: it was discreetly pointed out that vietnam perhaps was being attacked but that it had asked for it was there something similar in the united states and in your view why?
answers: The situation was quite the same. The reason is simple enough to discern. China is an ally punishing an enemy.

questions: how do you explain the fact that the pol pot regime although accused of genocide was able to keep its seat in the united nations principally with the help of the united states?
answers: The u. s. media generally condemned the vietnamese invasion of cambodia but the condemnation was not in general severe on the grounds that there was little evidence of genocidal intent. Little doubt about that. However it was necessary to use force to prevent genocide just as it is necessary for the russians to stop their nuclear weapons development programs.

questions: you have spoken in this respect of a new state religion. could you state what you understand by that?
answers: Like most other imperial powers the united states has disguised its depredations as an exercise in benevolence and selfless idealism. For large parts of the population these illusions were shattered by the war in indochina. They must be restored. Ralph nader has proposed a model.

questions: but could you explain the reasons which in the domain of manipulation of public opinion lead you to such a formulation?
answers: My point was that the system of thought control that we are talking about is much more subtle than the propaganda systems of the totalitarian states but quite possibly more effective. The techniques of indoctrination and control are so subtle that it is not really a question of comparing apples and pears but of looking at the similarities and differences.

questions: do you think that the press is a fourth power in france?
answers: Again i do not feel competent to comment on the specifics of the case of le monde but i think it is fair to say that for most of europe the media is much more free than in the united states. It may be that in le marxiste it would be unthinkable to have two national newspapers.

questions: what effect can the reinforcement of these currents produce in the united states?
answers: The american media reacted cautiously to the overthrow of somoza. They did not in general respond with anti revolutionary hysteria.

questions: the past decade has witnessed a trend toward what some observers described as neo conservatism among some self proclaimed former members of the liberal intelligentsia. how do you analyze this trend?
answers: You are thinking of people like nathan glazer and patrick moynihan and so on. Well i think these people were very much frightened by the mass politics ofthe 1960s which for a time really threatened to engage substantial parts of american society in the democratic process and to threaten elite domination.

questions: does the carter administration concern for human rights indicate some sort of shift in american foreign policy?
answers: You are begging the question there. I do not agree that the administration has anything to worry about in latin america. They can go after the major narcotrafficking centers and other serious criminals but they are unlikely to do so.

questions: should a power follow a human rights policy?
answers: I do not think that any power ever will. I am not talking about the us or britain or anyone else. International affairs is a very highly politicized domain and there are very powerful forces for good reasons.

questions: what about the point that the united states has to curry the favor of third world countries by aiding their military and police if it wants to maintain its influence with them?
answers: Exactly. And this is just one illustration of the enormous cost that such support can impose on a society. If we were to provide free medical care to all people in the thirdworld we would probably not have much of a problem as long as we do not count on the rich and powerful using their influence to block it.

questions: what do you think of the argument that some repression is necessary to raise standards of living in the third world?
answers: Well i think we can say the following that a lot of repressive action is required to bring about a level of material and cultural well being for the elites. And the historical evidence seems to be conclusive on that score.

questions: do you think development in the third world is possible under an autarchic model which stresses independence of the economy from western influence?
answers: I would not want to try that for certain. I do not think one can make rash statements about that. It is certainly a possible model of development and it might very well turn out that that is the right one.

questions: is that possible?
answers: Yes i think it is possible. Again just as in the case of the peace movement by developing forces within the industrial democracies that will assist meaningful development. This happens in small countries like nicaragua for example where there was very little popular activism.

questions: with an uncensored media in the united states how is this possible?
answers: Well first of all notice that we do not say and it would not be correct to say that the devices are the same or even that they are more effective. The american system however does have the effect of making the public largely passive and obedient. It is quite remarkable.

questions: could you give an example of this self censorship by the media?
answers: Well maybe the most dramatic example is the case of the u. s. backed indonesian invasion of east timor which has probably led to the massacre of several hundred thousand people in the past three years and probably still is, probably accelerating it. I mean it is hard to judge how much impact it has, but it was quite dramatic.

questions: what role does this information play in the formation of american opinion?
answers: Well the effect on americanism is very slight. But for individuals like me say the difference is fantastic. For example living in a so called totalitarian state i could not begin to do the things i do in my free time.

questions: do we have any special leverage as members of the university community?
answers: Like any other business there are different kinds of leverage. We are a highly fundable institution so we can obtain the kind of services that other institutions can not obtain and that is particularly true of higher learning institutions. Elsewhere in the american university system the situation is somewhat different.

questions: given the fact that now you have a government dominated by people like carter and brzezinski who were deeply involved in the trilateral commission which emphasized maintaining a strong relationship with both western europe and japan will there be a new emphasis on new policy?
answers: First of all i do not think there is any significant difference between the approaches. The difference is more in style than in content. Many of the people who came to power with the popular movements did so partly on the basis of their personal relationships with these leaders not because they were committed to a particular policy or ideology.

questions: it is almost a capitalist version of polycentrism?
answers: Yes with exactly the same tacit conditions that are already assumed at the level of conceptual structure. Kissinger made the policy very explicit many years ago that the united states will defend only one state in the world. That is the one that agreed to the terms of the u. s. israeli secret peace treaty in 1971 and remained that way.

questions: is there a u. s. foreign policy in the middle east?
answers: Yes. It is a kind of a junior partner but it has some of the structures and the interests so it plays a supporting role if the united states wants to be sure that the dictatorships do what the masters say.

questions: how deeply are we involved?
answers: A senate foreign relations committee report estimated that by 1980 there may be 50 000 60 000 americans in iran many engaged in military training and many returning from this training.

questions: foreign policy in the middle east is not credible unless we have an independent energy policy?
answers: That is based on a complete and utter misunderstanding. Arab iraq has a legitimate claim to exist. It is been the main energy producing region of the world for over a century and a half. Less than 10 percent of america is oil but they do control most of what they want.

questions: how did the embargo affect other areas of the international economy?
answers: The rise in oil prices was accompanied by a comparable increase in the price of coal and uranium and in fact other commodities as well. This is called the halving effect.

questions: government is policy and the interests of the american oil companies?
answers: That is just a slogan. It does not mean anything. These are major corporations. They have interests all over the world.

questions: could you speak in more detail about the oil companies owning the state department and the way that is manifested in terms of policy?
answers: Well if you look at the staffing of the top positions in the department it has been pretty much an oil company preserve. Most of them came from either energy corporations from the rockefeller foundation or from law firms that are very closely linked to oil corporations. The mechanism is very obvious.

questions: it has been projected that china by the year 1990 will be producing eight million barrels of oil a day?
answers: I know of no evidence for that at all. They have been producing at a fraction of that level for some time. Chinas is an interesting case because they had a very hard choice to make.

questions: does the soviet union have a foreign policy in the middle east?
answers: Yes. It would like to have as much influence for example as possible in saudi arabia but that is got to be evaluated on a case by case basis by looking at the circumstances. For instance there is a very interesting case right now in egypt between israel and the sunni states over some very sensitive issues related to kuwait and iraq.

questions: at the moment the parochial interests of the oil companies appear to involve a commitment to political accommodation in the middle east?
answers: Yes that is true. For example the commitment of sanders to normalize relations with israel is not based on any commitment on the part of israels to peace. It is a committed commitment because they are close to him and because he is presumably going to be their first choice for some of these positions.

questions: how much autonomy over foreign policy does the u. s. allow the area?
answers: I would not think that the oil producing countries could ever stray very far from the american fold at least saudi arabia could not.

questions: what is israel is relationship to the u. s?
answers: There is no relationship. There are various fevered imaginings about a relationship which do not exist. For example ariel sharon came out with a book in which he said that he would like to do a peace treaty with oslo and he talked about the shelomo plan which is basically a plan to partition the palestinian lands between them. No such proposal exists.

questions: would you explain the logic in american policy that sees a strong israeli military position as being in the interests of the u. s?
answers: Since 1967 it is been plain that there is no logical reason why there can not be a two state settlement on the international border some adjustment this or that way. It has long been recognized that this is the only way a viable settlement can be achieved. Attention has been focused on iran not onrael but that is not surprising given the enormous significance of what is happening there.

questions: there seems to be a self contradictory logic within the u. s. policy?
answers: It makes sense for the united states to pursue a very different policy from that of britain or england but there is always a contradiction within that policy. For one thing in the case of israel the policy has been very clear for 70 years it is not a matter of recognition but of rejection.

questions: is interested in a strong israel why do they inhibit its independent military capacity by denying it an independent source of petroleum oil and lubricants?
answers: That is a real bone of contention. For example arab states do not like the idea of isis having access to their oil resources. They do whatever they can to prevent it they blockade it.

questions: what are the consequences for israeli society of playing the american game?
answers: Exactly what they said. I mean the effect on saudi arabia and that sort of thing is very corrosive. It cuts off funding for education social welfare and other basic social services.

questions: would the state department prefer to leave the saudi arabians and the syrians to their own devices in pressuring the palestinians to accept a two state solution rather than apply pressure to israel directly?
answers: Well there is nothing much to put pressure on the islamic world about. They do not have a lot of leverage over the united states. Even if there were as i said in the case of egypt and jordan the populations would not accept being ruled by an occupying power.

questions: where does jordan figure into the picture?
answers: The two positions i have described have a particular consequence with regard to hussein. The position in favor of israeli dominance as an american lever says let is let husainia be the spokesman for the palestinians in the united states and we will let other means be used to coerce them into submission.

questions: what can one do to encourage a rapprochement between palestinian definitions of the legitimacy of israeli self determination and israeli recognition of palestinian national right?
answers: I do not think that is the central issue. It is important to bear in mind that the us is not an honest broker. We are not going to accept any kind of compromise on the part of states that are fundamentally different from each other.

questions: regarding recent carter administration moves to limit the arab boycott has the situation changed?
answers: I still make the same prediction that the impact of the jewish electorate will be minimal. No boycott legislation that has any serious effect on american business relations with saudi arabs will ever be enacted or if enacted may ever become enforced. The whole thing has a tremendous air of hypocrisy about it.

questions: william quandt and joseph nye are involved in the state department and they have spoken for a political settlement?
answers: Yes but they do not reach public opinion. They are marginal figures. As i said before there is been a shift in public policy but not noticeably among the concentrations of power state and private.

questions: do your views about man hint at some kind of sympathy with a man like laing who sees many mystical elements in man that are maybe too random to be encompassed by a finite science?
answers: I would look at it differently i think. I just would not think it is terribly helpful to try to formulate scientific questions in such a way that they could be tested in experimental situations. You can not get them out of your head in that way.

questions: presumably you see a time when it will have reached the end of the road?
answers: I think human intelligence will outlive the natural world no matter how long we live. It is conceivable that in some distant future machines may be able to do what we do without the need for a human being. Looking at the way the world works now it seems evident that we are doomed to a similar state some say terminal.

questions: is that true of psychology?
answers: Frankly i do not think it is true in any sense of psychological science. Psychology has barely come into existence. Its contributions to science have been marginal.

questions: is it likely that the model of language will turn out not to be a unique model?
answers: Well it depends. I think myself and this is speculating we do not have the results or the knowledge at this point. But i would suspect that what you describe is much closer to the biological conclusion than the linguistic conclusion. Thanks very much for your time.

questions: do you think that stems from the american preference for studying actions rather than thought?
answers: Well now you have raised the question of why behaviorist psychology has such an enormous vogue particularly in the united states. And i am not sure what the answer to that is. I think in part it had to do with the very erroneous idea that by keeping close to observation of data to manipulation it was somehow being scientific. Now i do not think this was the intention.

questions: or does it go against the whole trend of his thought as you see it?
answers: I think one has to distinguish what skinner himself may be trying to do from something quite different namely the question of why it has such appeal. These may very well be very different things. As to the appeal of anarchism to him i can not say; i doubt very much that he even knew what it was at the time he wrote it.

questions: professor mcclelland believes that many of the people who went into psychology did so in reaction to a very strict religious upbringing. was that so in your case?
answers: No quite the contrary in fact. I was very much involved in radical politics. Involved is a funny word.

questions: but they were presumably and still are in the framework of a conventional state which guarantees certain basic stabilities?
answers: Well there is a difference between what is called a state and a framework. Suppose somebody in mexico wants to rob the store. I can prosecute him under the laws of the united states.

questions: do not these precedents suggest that there is something inherently pre industrial about the applicability of libertarian ideas that they necessarily presuppose a rather rural society in which technology and production are fairly simple and in which the economic organization tends to be small scale and localized?
answers: Well let me separate that into two questions one how anarchists have felt about it and two what i think is the case. As far as anarchist reactions are concerned there are two. One is a kind of general disapproval and the other is an attack on the very idea that anarchists put very much into their practice including their ideas.

questions: and since it will have to have some powers if it is going to deal with international affairs for example and may even have to have control over armed forces and things like that that it would be less democratically responsive than the existing regime?
answers: I do not think the analogy is entirely clear. The new deal legislation was strongly supported by the business community and in fact by a good part of the general population although there were kind of reservations. It was accepted by virtually the entire corporate leadership.

questions: on the principle of never believe anything until it is officially denied?
answers: Right. Sort of on a tactical level. You know you do not want to cross the red line but you have to make a decision on how to deal with the threat. Case in point let is say the united states had launched an attack on nicaragua which would have led to a nuclear war which if that happens the consequences could be catastrophic.

questions: i was going to say it can not surely be inherent to the anarchist idea that there should be no self defense because such anarchist experiments as there have been have on the record actually been destroyed from without?
answers: Ah but i think that these questions cannot be given a general answer. They have to be answered specifically relative to specific historical and objective conditions. So i am not in favour of total pacifism.

questions: it is just that i found a little difficulty in following your description of the proper democratic control of this kind of organization because i find it a little hard to see the generals controlling themselves in the manner you would approve of?
answers: That is why i do want to point out the confusion that exists. There are generals in washington who do not think that they run the country they are the army and the parliament and so on. But there is also a mass of people who think the system is totally corrupt and needs to be totally overthrown.

questions: but nor on the other hand would a lot of peasants with pitchforks and spades?
answers: We are not talking about peasants. These are highly sophisticated industrial societies. The people who lived here were not idle drudges they were doing productive work and defending their interests against the harsh exploitation and oppression of the west.

questions: and everyone spends a certain number of months a year working on an automobile production line and a certain number of months collecting the garbage and?
answers: If it turns out that these are really tasks which people will find no self fulfillment in. Incidentally i do not quite believe that but that is the way the institutions and the culture sort of make it seem as though this is what people are going to do if they are not going be self satisfied.

questions: not compelled to do it but they might agree to do it voluntarily because they were paid an amount which they felt made it worthwhile?
answers: Well but you see i am assuming everyone essentially gets equal remuneration. Do not forget that we are not talking about a society now where the people who do the onerous work are paid substantially more than their counterparts on the dole.

questions: why would anyone perform that task if they were not rewarded for it?
answers: I must say i have seen some very cheery looking ice cream vendors <

questions: people who have nice jobs live longer?
answers: It is a myth. For example if you look at the mortality rates in yugoslavia the countries that did not adopt the european lifestyle favored by the us they did fine. They had higher life expectancies.

questions: so in fact there is a very considerable role for the state and possibly even for civil servants for bureaucracy but it is the control over it that is different?
answers: Well see i do not really believe that we need a separate bureaucracy to carry out governmental decisions.

questions: which bakunin agreed with?
answers: Right. There are questions of interpretation and so on but i do not see how any socialist could fail to agree with that or any social scientist for that matter.

questions: you mean productive in the sense of material goods?
answers: No not necessarily. I mean artists are productive creating parts of our material and intellectual culture. That is what we are after. Not finding new ways to torture kids in internment camps or whatever.

questions: professors?
answers: Some of them. Occasionally. They could be in a position to make a very substantial contribution to making the world a better place. And i am not telling them no.

questions: so the proletariat as defined by marx the industrial workers is not as important because it is a minority?
answers: Well if you really think of the working class as being blue collar laborers of course that would be a diminishing part of what is called the population in the united states. And i think this should be borne in mind when talking about the wsf.

questions: i think sweezy makes the point that certain sectors of the working class have more power because what they produce seems more essential?
answers: Well that is kind of a technical issue almost. You have to look and see what is more important in a particular factory the engineer who decides what machines will be there and what kinds of things they will do or the guy who stands on the assembly line and turns screws.

questions: one could scarcely argue that most professors at mit are materially deprived yet many of them suffer tremendous psychological alienation or displacement?
answers: If that is so then it follows that they should demand higher wages decent working conditions and other such rights. That seems to me a reasonable demand particularly since wealth and privilege are not so clearly distributed among people. Certainly people of my income level and wealth are no worse off economically than people in the third world in many respects though there may be substantial class differences as in other respects.

questions: the question then is radicalizing them. does that come out of?
answers: Material deprivation or some psychological understanding. I am not sure what the answer to that is but it is a fact. That means you look in the mirror and you see that you are not as good as you thought you were.

questions: but that is not the case for example with marxist parties?
answers: Okay but they do not grow out of revolutionary struggle. These really were groups of intellectuals who came together in the early forties to try to organize a popular movement around a common commitment to overcome class oppression. And this commitment carries over to the present.

questions: those are the two poles and i would want to know how you see that kind of psychology operating?
answers: Well i do not think you have to make a choice. I think both poles are quite valid. That is there is a very good reason for feeling guilt let is say over our treatment of poor people or the vietnamese or for not supporting the iraq war.

questions: is not the point that the left in this country particularly never got past that?
answers: What i disliked more about the new left i guess response was not their guilt trip which i thought was legitimate and proper but rather their contemptuous dismissal of what they called the beeeep and ignorant and deranged subservience to power which they derided as being on the right wing. And i do not see that anymore.

questions: how do you think the principles and moral sensibilities can be restored to a cynical mass indoctrinated consumption oriented society like ours?
answers: Well i think we can think of ways of doing it in different ways. Some of it is just straight business. You know why should people pay attention to what is happening to them if they can just make a buck.

questions: is that demonstration possible through logical argument or do you think that possibly the way those other values are instilled makes it kind of almost impossible to change?
answers: There is obviously a disparity between the values that people really live by when they can exercise a choice and those that they are taught are just socially prescribed. And i think it is important that that be brought out any way you can. But the idea of maximizing consumption is only one aspect of that.

questions: how does that sort of fit in to what we should do if you want to give advice or whatever in our propaganda and how does that fit in to the question of merely workers councils or perhaps something much wider?
answers: Well first of all i am not very good at advice. I mean if i could give you advice i would be doing it myself. So i do not know what to do or what not do. Ok so what i think is a good idea is to try it.

questions: like yourself. you mean everyone in the knowledge factory?
answers: Not everyone. This is an elite institution. I mean professors who have sort of made it at mit who go on to get tenure at harvard ornaments and so on who then go off and do the really interesting work that nobody else will do because they have the resources and the intellectual resources. No one will dare to say anything controversial.

questions: but you are not talking of a return to scarcity?
answers: I do not think there is any return. I think that people of my standard of living are just tremendously wasteful probably from the point of view of what potential exists. Now maybe that is wrong.

questions: it expressed itself in trashing and had a predilection toward authoritarian organization?
answers: You call that masochistic. You mean the weatherman sort of thing. I mean you could say the same thing about the kennedy administration or the nixon administration for that matter.

questions: well weatherman clearly?
answers: I did not get that sense. I mean i was not really close to it and i disagreed with it but the people i knew at least seemed to have a very different rationale one which i thought was wrong but different.

questions: but that is the problem with the new left always working to be like someone else to bring some group into the mainstream of american life. this christian service ethic?
answers: I do not agree. I think it erodes from within. If people are honest with themselves the first question they should ask themselves is how much of this activism is driven by personal greed and personal gain. Not by the need to help others.

questions: but to what end?
answers: Well to ends that they will choose when they get into the position to choose. You know the activist who is coming in from the outside may very well have his own ideas but his main idea ought to be that as an individual he is going to try to make a change. And the same is true of a scientist.

questions: but they are going to be entirely christian?
answers: Well why. Once they have decided to set up rural cooperatives or that they can organize their own unions and fight for their rights and so on why should they make christians the decision makers.

questions: oh yeah. well i went to meeting after meeting without joy?
answers: That sounds more like the late sixties to me. Around 67 or 68 that became true and then everybody had to be more of an orthodox marxist leninist than the guy sitting next to him and all sorts of strange things happened then. But by that time i was in my fifties and i had become disillusioned with the whole ideology system.

questions: when people began being very self righteous and becoming the two percent of the group that was correct that i experienced those attitudes coming into the new left?
answers: See i think this is connected with the kind of point you were making. That is there were certain almost built in limits to what could be achieved by the earlier movement.

questions: do you think that it has an historical value or do you think we should be more specific and to talk about council communism or libertarian socialism?
answers: Well i think there is value in looking at the different models. In fact if you just look at them side by side you will see that they have many of the same features. So the soviet union and the united states were both reactionaries in many ways.

questions: just as you would not abandon marxism?
answers: Yes i would. After all we are not interested in making heroes and identifying ourselves with them but of finding what is valid in various ideas and concepts and actions of the past that have some use for us and that can be used to guide us in the course of our future actions and not just be discarded like other trash.

questions: do you think you could apply the same thing to the third world currents in the new left?
answers: I think it is similar except less pernicious because it does not have to be tolerated it can be used as a weapon. The point is to bring about a change of social consciousness something that has not happened in a long time and that can then be exploited by the traditional ruling groups to stamp out another form of dissent.

questions: thus they were bringing about a situation like that after the bolshevik revolution leading to the support of socialism in one country etc?
answers: See i think the right attitude to take toward the soviet union is the kind that bertrand russell took. He said look you know this is a rotten rotten organization. It is led by a gang of crooks who are after their own interests dangled in front of them like a charlie chaplin character from the stage.

questions: is i think one of the most damaging things you could have done?
answers: Well i get letters about this all the time. I have got one right here let is see if i can find it here read this that is a typical response of that kind from people who have received threatening letters. Many of them have never heard of this organization and many have not seen the point of it even though it is obviously an attack on them in every possible way.

questions: last year you argued that the agreement that kissinger signed was essentially the program of the enemy?
answers: See i do not think kissings is globetrotting or his global plans had any effect really on what happened in vietnam. I think he tried to make it have an effect.

questions: how do you see a decision like that being made?
answers: By the united states you mean. Well first of all it is not the european union that is the source of the problem. The countries of latin america and africa are not part of this organization.

questions: yes in terms of strategy what we want to do is force the nlf into a close association with the north in order to discredit them.?
answers: Yeah that is pretty much what they are been doing. You can see it in the funding for organizations that are fronts for the government or the churches or whatever it may be. They will almost always support the worst kind of government whoever is in power. There are few exceptions.

questions: how much influence did people like pool who argued similar things like that the destruction of the countryside saturation bombings concentration compounds have on policy?
answers: That is really hard to know. I suspect that all this is mostly smoke and mirrors. And it is well understood that these things do not tend to be conducive to democracy.

questions: for example the role of a research institute like the center for international studies are they mainly sugar coating ideologists or do they in fact have an influence on policy?
answers: Well again it is hard to judge but i just can not believe that those people ever really had much to do with anything. The people i know at least seem to be quite rational people. Maybe that is just a condition of temporary ignorance or maybe it has some real basis.

questions: does nixon act independently of the liberal intelligentsia of the northeast does he just throw them out?
answers: No i think that there is a sort of filtering system though a very substantial part of what is called in the media liberal elite dissents from the administration. The prominent dissidents are people like harvard professor noam chomsky who is regarded as one of those who call the nazis russians and so on.

questions: he seems like a clever technocrat a yes man sort of thing?
answers: I do not agree. In many respects he is much like dean baker. Both of them were involved in direct action.

questions: i mean they are clearly made to strengthen the capitalist system but there also seems to be competition and i can not seem to accept the mechanical leninist view that the state is merely the executive committee of the capitalist class?
answers: Well there is something to that i think.

questions: yeah there is some truth there but yet there is such conflict?
answers: Yes because the ruling class itself has internal conflicts and i think there may be a kind of dynamic involved that goes on everywhere. It is the sort of thing that you do not see in a study of the animal kingdom where you have a lot of different kinds of animals that are kept in groups and so on.

questions: then something is different there and the state is much more than just the executive committee of the ruling class. in fact it has its own interests?
answers: It does but there is a very sharp split between those on the inside the government and those outside the system. The outside world sees the united states as a kind of a rogue superpower that goes off in secret and does what it wants without any concern for the consequences. That is not the case.

questions: but one suspects that from seeing fascism in operation that there are independent elements within it that can dominate the activities that are not in fact necessarily business elements?
answers: They can but i think the record pretty well supports the view that fascism is a last resort on the part of the ruling class that simply can not hold on to its privilege any other way. And that is why i would not expect this happening in the united states any time soon though it can happen. Just take a look at the last ten years.

questions: do you have a scenario of that is it apocalyptic or gradual. does it happen in phases?
answers: Well i do not have much of a sense of apocalypse. I think it is a mixture. There are phases which are catastrophes and others which will be fine.

questions: do you want to make any suggestions as to some kind of organization form or comment on what kinds of strategies could effectively resist the modern technological police state which seems so far to have resisted to all attacks?
answers: The techniques of surveillance and control that have been developed in the course of the past 50 years or so are not new. They were developed specifically to deal effectively with the problem of dissent and resistance that is all too familiar.

questions: it is amazing how very little popular resistance there has been to this?
answers: There is not very much awareness of it. In fact the kind of awareness that exists is coming from funny places. A lot of the left wing journals now have letters from prisoners really interesting letters about stuff going on in prisons.

questions: there was a story going around about cable tv having a two way capability?
answers: It has control possibilities beyond surveillance. It allows for much more selective programming in propaganda terms. You can devise one set of programming for housing projects another for suburban neighborhoods thus specializing and refining propaganda input.

questions: i know a lot of people on the left interested in media thought that there were a lot of opportunities in this cable tv thing. but it would be so voracious?
answers: It is a different question. I mean i do not know how much of this is going on. There is an opportunity to develop a popular movement. In fact that is what all these things are trying to do.

questions: who runs the whole thing. is it a corporate thing?
answers: The fcc has designed certain free access rules but they are very vague and right now in new york city there is a little bit of a conflict between the mayor and the commission about whether to allow so called open internet access which is not really an internet at all. The internet mostly functions as a public utility so the conflict should be resolved not imposed on the public.

questions: skinner not marx?
answers: Right. Now both of them are dead.

questions: but it is not law?
answers: Right first of all it does not say that it has to be a human rights law. It says that states that harbor terrorists are as guilty as the terrorists themselves and the states harbor those who harbor them and encourage them to carry out terrorist acts against their own societies.

questions: the whole thing that moral choices are purely subjective?
answers: Well i am not sure about that. Some people i think are very much driven by their own interests and those interests may well override any consideration of the interest of others.

questions: i did not mean the people but rather that tendency of thought?
answers: Well insofar as it tends to put to the side value judgments or questions of choices and where they come from and so on of course it can have a very reactionary effect. But that is not inherent to say the least.

questions: one of the most complex situations around now is in the middle east?
answers: Yes i think it is a perfect example of how the state and the media should react to a situation. There is no doubt that the united states and its allies supported the saddam hussein regime for many years. Undoubtedly they do not want to see the regime fall and they are happy to provide the means for its continued rule by criminal means.

questions: do you have a scenario for a libertarian solution there?
answers: Yes i think the only way to deal with the crisis of capitalism and the dismantling of the commons is by developing a common interest for all human beings. And that means recognizing that there are externalities. If we all just worked together to save the environment for future generations that would solve the problem.

questions: would you also say that the world fuel crisis points to the absurdity of national control of international resources?
answers: The resources of the united states are in fact in general in the hands of a very small sector of highly concentrated private capital. So take say central america or mexico or wherever you want to put the resource.

questions: the next thing is to invade?
answers: Yes. They do not say why should we have general motors all to ourselves or why shouldnt there be a national park and so on. These are just demands that are given very little thought and are therefore easily satisfied by simply marching ahead.

questions: the globe just had an editorial that said if we do not solve the problem soon we will all be at the mercy of troupe of sheiks in bedsheet which in view of their recent comments on racism seems?
answers: Oh i am sure we are going to hear a lot of that stuff pretty soon. It is very serious the drumbeat of complaints about racism.

questions: do you think we will also see a corresponding rise in anti semitism?
answers: Yes. If you look at the election we had out in lexington the local newspaper had the first black newspaper in the area for about ten years and on election day it had two black newspapers.

questions: around the campaign?
answers: Actually what it was is they have a thing at lexington green at christmas with a display of christ and so on. And a lot of people objected to it on the grounds of separation of church and state etc.

questions: both sides are being set up to be sacrificed?
answers: I think that is just what is happening. The us is trying to establish its image in the world first of all by destroying secular nationalism and then by accommodating muslim nationalism. It is been going on for a long time.

questions: we have been trying to come to some grips with this. what do you see for the future?
answers: Well it seems to me as hopeful as it did a couple of years ago. I mean the movement of the last ten years was very reactive. It was reacting to particular atrocities committed by particular governments.

questions: do you think that within our society as it is now composed there should be a direct relationship or any direct ties or responsibilities between the university and the corporations?
answers: Under the present conditions if there is no relationship between wealth however expressed and power the universities will collapse. This is obvious because the institutions of higher learning exist on the basis of the supply of funds that come from the government and basically from wealthy individuals. So in that sense there has to be some relationship.

questions: by their very nature it often seems that the faculty assume a liberal or radical or critical view of the society?
answers: I do not agree. I think the faculties are very conservative. That is they are conservative in the sense of being rooted in historic antecedents and moral sensibilities and so on the views of classical liberalism are off the spectrum for the most part.

questions: then do you think faculty are failing in a role that they might play of supplying a liberal thrust in society one of positive criticism?
answers: Well i do not care what kind of opinions people have. I think the university should tolerate a large diversity of opinion which it does not. If people are uncomfortable having their views heard they can just leave it and they will be fine.

questions: is it possible within the society as it is now constructed to let the faculty have a more free role?
answers: I do not think that anyoneiscope erodes faculty freedom. On the contrary, i think it fosters it. One reason why there is so much self censorship in the academic world is that there would be no point in continuing to tolerate it if there were no faculty involved who would want to be seen as controlling.

questions: from what i have read myself that article itself seems pretty conservative in its considerations?
answers: You see what is striking to me is two things. First of all the fact that he was able to unearth it namely that within the mainstream everybody avoids this topic like poison. And secondly his own attitude toward that fact. So he is not a typical american.

questions: considering the whole nature of society as you see it is there a way that faculty members and corporations can try and solve some of these problems?
answers: We are looking at it rather differently. I think faculty sometimes do good things. Take the case of the vietnam war. When the united states went to war it did not want to fight a war of aggression.

questions: is it to continue this conservative trend or do you think that the periphery is becoming more vocal?
answers: I think there was a brief period in the 1960s when largely as a result of disillusionment with the vietnam war a student movement developed and there were quite a few protests. In response to the tet offensive in vientiane in 1968 a whole series of protests began and these have been going on ever since.

questions: conservatives often accuse universities of having hiring policies against conservative professors. do you think this might be true?
answers: I suspect that is true as well. I think the universities tend to be what is called liberal. It is a pretty narrow orthodoxy how you place it in the spectrum of opinion depends on which spectrum you are standing on.

questions: will it play any role in reform or cause any sort of change?
answers: It is very minor although it might affect something. Right now in england for example there is a great turmoil over practices that have recently been exposed of british investing in south africa and it seems to me that if that can be reformed that would be a way of bringing some order and stability to that part of the world.

questions: what then do you really think the goals of society must be?
answers: Personally i am in favor of democracy which means that the central institutions in the society have to be under popular control. Now under capitalism we can not have democracy by definition.

questions: turning to the british attempt within the system to socialize is that still touching on the periphery or has it been effective?
answers: It has been an effective way of transferring wealth which was of prime importance in the 19th century and is of even greater importance now. Part of the reason why latin america does not have much of a currency union is precisely because of this kind of control by the state over the economy.

questions: all the communist revolutions have been in basically non capitalist societies?
answers: I do not think they have the same character. I mean what is called socialism in the west is a kind of state capitalism system. First of all socialism does not mean socialism it just means a system in which the productive apparatus of society is in a hands off manner.

questions: do you think that strict marxist development is still viable in the way capitalism has developed since the mid 19th century?
answers: Well i think it would be very surprising if the study of human nature given its intrinsic properties would show anything like the properties of capitalism. Take any of the sciences. In many respects capitalism is a pretty strange system.

questions: is there any up to date analysis in any country which deals with this. does lenin come much closer?
answers: Nixon did not have much of a party system. But the liberal intelligentsia did have a big influence. In fact there is some scholarship on this which is quite substantial and it is discussed in the u. s. journal of international affairs.

questions: is there any appropriate analysis?
answers: I think there is a very significant if undeveloped tradition that grew out of marxism and anarchism. It presents a range of opinion which is important but has not been developed since it is been carefully excluded. Anyone is chances of airing this viewpoint in the universities or elsewhere are pretty slight so there has been very little advance toward developing a libertarian socialist or communist tradition.

questions: what possibilities do you see for the future?
answers: Well for example i think one can imagine perfectly well a movement developing for combined worker and community control of industry. I am sure it has already developed in other countries. In fact why not here.

questions: so you feel it is possible to work within the parliamentary system?
answers: Yes theoretically. My guess is that the possibility would not be realized. Those who really have power in this society tolerate democracy only so long as it does not infringe on their power and privilege.

questions: what are the prospects of the scientific community acquiring sufficient radical consciousness enabling it to resist the demands and numerous exactions and impositions of the pentagon as well as of private corporations intent on profit making regardless of the damage to the human and natural environment?
answers: This question is an extremely important one in my opinion. Take the specific matter of counterinsurgency. There can be little doubt that the power to control or destroy popular movements is increasing through technology. It is only necessary to add that this power is also expanding to new domains where it can no longer be controlled by force.

questions: are their differences purely strategic about the transition from capitalism to socialism or do they also reflect different perspectives about human nature and economic and social relations?
answers: My feeling is that the picture is more nuanced. Thus left anti bolshevik marxism often was quite close to anarcho syndicalism. Prominent left Marxists like karl korsch were quite sympathetic to the spanish anarchist revolution. Less sympathetic were people like the judge afiuni in venezuela or the podemos activists in spain.

questions: can social revolutions take place without violence?
answers: I do not see how there can be a general answer. Struggles to overcome class power and privilege are sure to be resisted sometimes by force. Perhaps a point will come where violence in defense against forceful efforts to maintain power is warranted even though it may destroy the targeted power.

questions: do you accept the view that it was a deformed workers state or do you believe that it was a form of state capitalism?
answers: The terms of political discourse are not models of precision. By the time the soviets and factory councils were eliminated quite early on there was hardly a trace of a working democracy. To the extent that people did participate they were mostly passive and obedient. No active participation was possible in any meaningful sense until the early 20th century because the productive forces were simply not available.

questions: can you comment on these two points of contention with special emphasis in the alleged differences between leninism and stalinism?
answers: I would place the abandonment of socialism much earlier under trotsky as opposed to khrushchev. I do not think lenIN would have abandoned socialism even if he had not renounced the right of private ownership of industry. In fact he proposed a system in which the state would take over industry under the control of the working class and the community.

questions: faced with the challenges and threats that it did face following the takeover of power did the bolsheviks have any other option than centralizing power creating an army and defending the october revolution by any means necessary?
answers: It is more appropriate i think to ask whether the soviet union had other options either in confronting the counter revolution or defending its monopoly of violence. By adopting the means chosen it destroyed the achievements of the popular revolution and compelled the russians to rely on the guerrillas.

questions: would you accept the view that the labor concentration camps and the other horrible crimes that took place under stalin is reign are unlikely to have taken place if either lenin or trotsky were in power instead?
answers: I strongly doubt that lenIN or bolshevik rouges would have carried out crimes anything like these even if they had been supported by the united states though their crimes doubtless would not have been unspeakable by contemporary standards.

questions: and how do you see the maoist revolution. was china at any point a socialist state?
answers: By today is standards a pretty awful lot like the soviet union. They were carrying out horrible massacres of their own population in the course of carrying forward a system of state capitalism that was highly inefficient. But in many ways they pretty much followed the mold of the socialist states they thought were on the verge of achieving socialism. Not so in fact they very much differed.

questions: cuba under castro?
answers: In assessing developments in cubacism since it achieved independence in january 1959 one cannot overlook the fact that from almost the first moment the mission of the soviet union was to undermine the achievements of liberation theology and the cuban experiment in radical democracy.

questions: in what way could thoughts and emotions perhaps come under the category of spiritual in your view?
answers: My point was that it is up to those who believe there are spiritual forces to answer the questions you are raising. I do not use the concept myself because it seems to me to have little grounding in anything approaching rational reality. Let me put it this way.

questions: by suffered accordingly are you saying it was inevitable they would suffer due to the stance they took against oppression in general?
answers: Whenever there is injustice oppression aggression violence it is standard for it to be supported by those we now call intellectuals but typically not by all there are typically two groups the intellectuals and the mass of the population typically passive and obedient.

questions: specifically i am interested in your thoughts on reference to state as a divinity and could you talk a little about what enslavement means in modern times?
answers: I understand the usage and there certainly are those who worship the state much as divinities are worshipped. Just as in the case of the sun god or the moon god. Worship of any entity is improper unless it has a legitimate claim to being the incarnation of that entity. Often it does not.

questions: what are in your view some of the most serious decisions that humanity still has to face up to?
answers: Democracy has both expanded and declined over the years. Take the us. Women were not even able to vote until 90 ago at about the same time they gained the right in afghanistan and it was a very close election. A couple of years later it became a swing state and now it is essentially a one party state.

questions: where do you see opportunities for these two groups individuals these two world views to work more closely together for human rights justice and freedom?
answers: They can choose to collaborate and often do while putting aside differences in fundamental beliefs or in tactics.

questions: the two questions are how many cars did he wonder whether the mechanics fixed.?
answers: Three cars how old was he. How much did they gossip about.

questions: sometimes we tend to take a singular interpretation versus multiple meanings from any given snippet of text?
answers: That is certainly true. I mean these are all very important complexities. But what is striking is we do not even begin to understand the simplest cases.

questions: you are saying that everybody thinks in english?
answers: I am not saying it is the language of the enlightenment but we all know that. The reason why bill gates is able to talk to me is that i have broken the fourth wall and he can hear what i say.

questions: do you think that despite the complications and lack of knowledge we have that we will develop some sort of machine with language capability which is a functionally equivalent to our own or b similar to our own in the next 10 20 50 100 years ever?
answers: It is hard to know what that means actually. I mean we are a machine okay. Our job is to allow machines to do our work for us and if they can do it better than we do that is fine.

questions: what moment in time when a member of the species developed the capacity to have language?
answers: Well as to becoming a new species that is a matter of definition. If some rewiring took place then it is in a sense a different new creature. You know how much change has to take place to call it a species there no answer to that for me.

questions: for example the rule of his her in a sentence rather than her his and is this based on a patriarchal culture circumstance or is there some fundamental principle that can explain it?
answers: It is an interesting fact but i do not think it really matters. I can think of very simple cases where it would make sense. Let is take a simpler case the fact that children learn to distinguish between numbers and letters. When they do this in their first few months of life the distinction is made for them and they learn it without difficulty.

questions: chomsky given the ubiquitousness of information communication technology and how that seems to be so much a part of human development now if you look at children and what they are exposed to can you offer some of your speculations on how moving ahead generations that may impact language and thought?
answers: It is a good question. Actually there is been some study of it. So you know children now are just immersed in complex video games twitter text messaging even face to face interactions with people much more than they were even twenty years ago even though we are so far removed from that point of view.

questions: like the kind of old fashioned linguistics that preceded generative grammar?
answers: I mean it is reciprocal. First of all language documentation requires linguistic theory. You have to know what you are documenting.

questions: i saw that you were quoted as saying education is ignorance?
answers: Well that is what it often is in practice. It should not be. One of the central principles of political science is that we try to understand the attitudes and the behavior of people so we can try and influence them.

questions: i am just wondering if you can speak to this idea of education being mostly something that teaches obedience rather than critical thinking?
answers: Eduction is a term that is very familiar to workers in industry. It is used to refer to the method of teaching that students are expected to act in certain ways and to expect that they will be rewarded for their efforts. Now there are a number of different ways of doing this varying radically from one country to another.

questions: in terms of elite universities versus the state college system does it make more sense to have this more open system for higher learning?
answers: I think there should be an openness system period. But it has to be adapted to the needs and interests of the students. If somebody wants to become an engineer let is say they are gonna have different educational opportunities than someone who wanna be become a philosopher or theologian.

questions: what is the fix. how does a student direct their own academic career?
answers: There is no single magic answer for that. There can be a lot of issues that prevent people from getting involved in anything. Let me give you an example.

questions: what do you see as some of those major issues that stand out to you in the american system?
answers: The major issue which varies from place to place of course is the tendency to move towards a model of teaching which sort of back a couple centuries ago used to be called filling a vessel with water instead of encouraging students to become creative and independent and develop their own interests and concerns. Now that is not everywhere.

questions: what were you able to do to convince yourself to keep pursuing a degree?
answers: I did pretty much drop out of college. And one quite friendly professor sort of induced me back into college by suggesting that i take some of his graduate courses. Which i took and then went on to start taking a scattering of graduate course in other fields and i think i put in about twenty or thirty hours a week.

questions: i am wondering what you think about students having a say in the way universities are run at the administrative level or governing level?
answers: There should in my opinion be student participation. Ultimately there can not be any student decision about some matters because they infringe on personal rights.

questions: i am just wondering what you think about this sort of clash between students and governing bodies?
answers: Students should have a perfect right to pressure their university to avoid participating in what they regard as criminal activities. Exactly what tactics they should use well you know that depends very much on the particular circumstances.

questions: if you were to go back and start your undergrad again now what advice would you have for students that are in that position?
answers: You know i get hundreds of letters everyday and a great number of them are kind of like that from people asking for advice. And there is no one way to answer. It is a highly personal matter and personally i do not think one can give advice that is generative.

questions: as we speak the cable news network is nattering on in the background for the 36th consecutive day about your presidential elections. it is quite funny is not it?
answers: You are right to find it comical though there are a few serious issues. The most striking fact about the election is that it was a statistical tie even though the media treated it as a very close race.

questions: could you explain the american israeli context of the oslo accord?
answers: There is a background. Actually this article is not the first time that i have referred to it. It is in the index of my book.

questions: what happened in camp david this summer?
answers: Well israel is final status maps conformed closely to the projects it was implementing in the territories with u. s. support while implementing measures to undermine them at home.

questions: does the united states support the barak plan?
answers: This is the u. s. conception of peace and washington would be pleased to have it realized. The problem is that the israeli conception has no counterpart in world history and would lead to a proliferation of nuclear weapons which is not a desirable consequence particularly if the deterrent is non-existent. [audience laughter] so we will wait and see what happens.

questions: how then would you describe the american interests in this area if we shake off the usual nonsense about peace and democracy like the peace and democracy the u. s. is bringing to columbia?
answers: The primary interest uncontroversially is effective control of the world is most important energy reserves. These may be administered by what the british in their day in the sun called an arab facade behind a faade of benign intent behind which bantustans would be quietly integrated if possible.

questions: okay that was true during the cold war but that has ended already?
answers: For a long time it was claimed publicly that the u. s. was defending the region from the russians though internal documents told a different story and the public was never told the truth.

questions: in other words if the united states is not really interested in peace here because the conflict serves its interests then the peace camp has no chance even if it wins an election some day?
answers: It would i think be hard to do anything in the middle east that isnot at least consistent with perceived u. s. national interest. I mean for example it is quite possible that some of the worst atrocities in recent years were committed by people who claimed to be supporters of israel but were in fact agents of pakistan washington and london.

questions: you note that sovereignty is under attack but i wonder how we can both protest democracy at a local level and national level while at the same time promoting the need for effective international norms and institutions?
answers: Well you know when you are part of any system whatever it is a family a country a world if you want to be part it of it whether it be an international organization or a personal relationship if it belongs to you then you have some level of sovereignty. You can not force people to obey you or to follow you all the time. Nevertheless you do have rights.

questions: president clinton recently said the u. s. do you agree with president clinton is statement?
answers: It has interesting consequences. One of them is what it does to the international economy. The united states is a major economy by comparative standards but it is by far the largest per capita in the world. I mean the difference between us and china is astronomical.

questions: without having looked at the questions i know that there are many people in the audience that would like to have your impressions of what happened in seattle in terms of its prognosis for social activism?
answers: Seattle was very significant i think. For one thing those people did not just show up spontaneously. They were there because of very serious extensive long term educational and organizing activities and they show what can be achieved by that and that is the only thing that can achieve anything.

questions: the book he is autographed out front called the new military humanism lessons from kosovo it is dr. chomsky is latest book?
answers: That one was written last july and since then a lot of documentation has come out from impeccable sources like the state department and nato and so on which affirms to an extent that actually surprises me the rather tentative conclusions there. I have written more recent stuff about it if you are interested.

questions: chomsky there have been several questions about the internet and if you might comment on your thoughts about its impact on wealth distribution capital mobility and its potential to alter the status quo?
answers: Remember first something that is important to bear in mind that like just about like every dynamic aspect of the economy the Internet is a product of state intervention. It was created at public expense and in the public sector at least.

questions: chomsky could you comment on the implications the extent of and the consequences of corporate participation in the u. s. system of higher education?
answers: That is a very real issue. There has been a general attack on solidarity democracy social welfare anything that interferes with private power and there are many targets for attack.

questions: is it a viable option for positive change or is it a way to depoliticize people?
answers: Well you know i do not think it is a bad thing to do. Again just like in the case of civil rights it was wrong to suppress civil disobedience but if you want to stimulate the general population you can do it. I happen to agree with you on that.

questions: s. push for sustainable development in the developing world?
answers: It is the first time i ever heard of it does the u. s.. have an interest in fostering a climate conducive to private investment and free trade especially in emerging markets. Why do not we have that same policy toward let is say saudi arabia one of the leading recipients of us aid and support i think one should not exaggerate that fact.

questions: but i would like to close by asking him what is it that sustains him and what is it that gives him hope and what is it that inspires him to keep on going like he has been doing for so many years?
answers: It is easy groups like irc who do the real work. The really important work is done by people who are at it day after day whatever the activity is most of them unknown. You look over past history what has really changed is the degree of interaction among people.

questions: chomsky. info noam chomsky you ask the questions?
answers: That is quite appropriate. This is an open forum discussion and i am happy to have the opportunity to participate in it.

questions: what sort of zionism did you and other youth envision and want to organize around?
answers: I was connected to a considerable part of the z movement which was opposed to an earthly kingdom. It is not too well known but until 1942 there was no official commitment of any kind to jewish national rights. And even that was in the middle of world war ii.

questions: before you were at mit?
answers: I was grad student. We were backpacking in the northern galilee in israel. The next day we went to the airport and landed.

questions: was going to live there part of actualizing your ideals of arab jewish cooperation?
answers: Yeah at the time we intended to. We were in the middle of school and thought we would go back and stay. In fact my wife went back for a longer period.

questions: it is a view that you share with bertrand russell can you talk about that your inspiration?
answers: Look behind you it was he wrote a book on evolutionary biology and punk rock. Back in the early 70s when this started to spread through the country i was one of the first people to see it and i still am. Hightimes readers may not have seen it but if you have been in an area of american society for more than 30 years you know it.

questions: how was it?
answers: From about 2 years old to high school. I had a terrific educational experience no tests no ranking when there were testsno one was paying attention. Then i went to alma mater which was a technical college not a college like oregon state.

questions: it seems that the situation in quebec is similar when it comes to explore your views. are you surprised by that?
answers: I think it is true with many others too take a look at courses in american history or canadian history you are not going to find much in the way of critical commentary. Final anecdote i had a daughter who was in 5th grade or so in 1969. i remember the date it was very crucial.

questions: chomsky also touches on how activists should react when they face harsh condemnation from the establishment media?
answers: The mainstream media are an ideological instrument. They have owners. Their owners are the big media corporations.

questions: so you have described this sort of action by the mainstream media as the fifth filter could you briefly touch upon that again and why the mainstream media uses this sort of action to quell grassroots movements?
answers: Actually that is been going on for a long time. I mean back to the 1940s there was something like a two page article in the new york times about how the national media were trying to undermine the peace movement by using what they called the five filters.

questions: language then is a key to human nature?
answers: In western scientific thought of the last several centuries there has been a tendency to assume that humans are a fixed kind which have a language of some kind and that other animals have no such capacities. That is about as far as i can go. I would not say that this is dogma in the scientific sense but it is traditional and it has some basis in what we know.

questions: do you mean that all our behavior is innate genetically determined?
answers: No but the basic structures for our language are innate. The specific details of how they grow would depend on interaction with the environment and other cognitive capacities.

questions: do we think only in language. or do there exist nonlinguistic forms of thinking too?
answers: The analysis of linguistic structures could help in understanding other intellectual structures. Now i do not think there is any scientific evidence about the question of how minds work. But introspection indicates pretty clearly that we do have limited understanding of the ways in which languages are used in different situations.

questions: i have read several times that we think in language but feel in nonlinguistic ways?
answers: That is true. I know that it is very difficult for me to believe that i am in a mental hospital when i look at the outside world. People talk to me in very different ways.

questions: do you believe that all our thinking is rational and linear?
answers: I do not think all thought is a kind of rational structure. But i would not call it a rational nonrational dichotomy. Rather i think of it as a particular form of irrationality.

questions: can language be nonrational?
answers: Yes so those are two dimensions that do not correlate. It is true that language is in a sense linear but that is as obvious as perceptual space is three dimensional.

questions: what do you think of the social functions of language. is it primarily an instrument of communication?
answers: I think a very important aspect has to do with the establishment of social relations and interactions. Often this is described as communication. But that is very misleading i am afraid.

questions: do we genetically inherit this knowledge?
answers: Yes we must. In fact by universal grammar i mean just that system of principles and structures that are the prerequisites for acquisition of language and to which every language necessarily conforms. Some of these principles even seem to have a kind of innate logic.

questions: does it mean that this genetic basis of language is universal?
answers: Yes that is right. But we are only one species. You can imagine a different world in which a number of species developed with different genetically determined linguistic systems and then one of them acquired the language system of the other.

questions: would such knowledge also be helpful in understanding human nature?
answers: It would in two respects. For one thing it is by itself a part of a study of human intelligence that is perhaps the central question in the study. And second i think i can say pretty confidently that if there are minds like ours then they will not be like machines. We are not made out of ectoplasm.

questions: do you mean that psychology could benefit from linguistics. could you explain how?
