answers: One thing that you and i know is language. Another thing which is very important is how objects behave in perceptual space. We have a whole mass of complex ways of understanding what is the nature of visual space and how people interact in it.

questions: but if as you say our behavior and language are heavily guided by universal principles why then do they differ so much all around the world?
answers: I do not think they differed so radically in the past. I think that as human beings we quite naturally take for granted what is similar among humans and then pay attention to what differentiates us. That makes perfect sense for us as members of the human species.

questions: would this extrahuman observer think the same way about our symbols ideas needs and values?
answers: Absolutely. I think he would be struck by the uniformity of human societies in every aspect. And there is more than that just from the perspective of an observer looking through a narrow window.

questions: is not it because man wants to exercise control over the physical world?
answers: I do not think so. I think it probably reflects something very special about the nature of our minds. There is no evolutionary pressure to create minds capable of forming sciences it just happened naturally.

questions: and that we are not conscious of that?
answers: Yes as human beings we naturally assume that our mental structures are universal. But i suppose an outside biologist looking at us would see something very different. He might conclude that like other organisms we have a narrow sphere within which we live but a huge sphere outside that sphere which is our domain of experience.

questions: what domains do you consider the most backward and neglected?
answers: I think that we have basically nothing in the field of human behavior. Maybe that is just a condition of temporary ignorance. But it may be that our present limitations are temporarily an obstacle to further progress.

questions: do you mean that not only do we not have tools to develop such a theory but we are incapable of creating the necessary tools?
answers: Yes intellectual tools. Our minds are specifically adapted to developing certain theories and we have a science if the theories that are available to our mind happen to be close to true. Well there is no particular reason to suppose that the intersection of true theories with theories which are accessible to the mind is very large.

questions: can we know at least how large it is?
answers: It's a question of biology how big that intersection is. And if humans are organisms like every other organism which they are then we should expect that if there are some domains where real scientific progress is possible then there will be others where it isnt because of the competition of other organisms.

questions: you have argued that any stance one takes on political economic social or even personal issues is ultimately based on some conception of human nature. why is this?
answers: Any position we take is based not only on our personal moral values but also our understanding of how the world works. You might as well bring them out as clearly as possible so that they can be discussed. Your point about personal values is certainly correct. I do not believe that you can generalize about human values just because they are universal.

questions: how do you defend this position against postmodernist critics who argue that there is no such thing as human nature and that all attempts to define it are guilty of reading other cultures in the light of western perceptions and values?
answers: Not even the most extreme poststructuralist can seriously argue this. They may claim that the exact properties of human sexuality or mental constitution are unknown but this is not a reasonable assumption since we do not have the relevant data. We can make educated guesses about what they will look like on the basis of what we know about the world and our own culture and society.

questions: are you suggesting everyone agrees about the nature of vice and virtue?
answers: In fact i think they probably have a very high measure of agreement. One strong bit of evidence for this is that everyone a genghis khan himmler bill gates creates stories of themselves where they interpret their actions as working for the benefit of human beings or non human persons.

questions: but there is also enormous diversity in what they do and defend as right to do?
answers: And there are all sorts of other differences too. Take something that you have probably heard about the british parliamentarian who got burned at the stake for supporting the kurds which is kind of shocking.

questions: are you wanting to argue that your understanding of human nature can give us a kind of objective understanding of the conditions of human flourishing?
answers: Now we are taking an essentialist position which the relativist would contradict. I am not willing to go that far. We can develop a stronger conception of what it means to be human through drawing on enlightenment thinking on the issue and so on.

questions: do you think even if there were the political will to achieve it that it might be impossible for ecological reasons to provide the necessary conditions for continued human flourishing?
answers: Humans may well be a nonviable organism. One of the consequences of not having ruled the world is that we do not have any rules of thumb for how best to manage the inevitable crises that will inevitably arise from human activities whatever the scale.

questions: do you think they are?
answers: It is very likely. From an evolutionary point of view higher intelligence seems to be maladaptive rather than adaptive. Biologically successful organisms have a rigid character and are well adapted to a certain environmental niche.

questions: do you think that different social and economic circumstances either block or reinforce certain dispositions that for example whatever there might be in the way of a natural tendency towards selfish and aggressive behaviour is reinforced by the capitalist market society?
answers: There is no doubt about it. Let is take germany for instance. During the nazis period there was a lively working class culture which was extremely threatening to the us industrialists.

questions: how come we remain both globally and locally so caught up in oppression?
answers: It is a serious question. Why are we born free and end up enslaved.

questions: is there a case here for viewing social factors as more determinant than biological factors?
answers: You can not say which factor is more decisive. They interact. Take the example of puberty small changes in nutrition can modify the onset by a factor of two or even terminate it altogether.

questions: can you say more on how you view this two edged process of possible political transformation?
answers: I am not in favour of people being in cages. On the other hand i think people ought to feel a certain degree of security about what they are doing. I do not think you have to make a decision on whether to go into a store to buy food or not.

questions: how is the aspiration for freedom being manifested today?
answers: The current period is incredibly encouraging. There is more popular activism in more areas than at any time i can remember labour struggles environmental issues women is rights children has rights respect for other cultures. I cannot think of a time when there have been so many people who were ready and eager to undertake direct action.

questions: how do you see the relationship between work and free time in a more liberated society?
answers: Polls in the us germany and elsewhere have shown that people value free liberated time over material goods. Therefore there are major propaganda efforts to reverse this. One reason over a trillion dollars a year is spent by the media on advertising is to try to undermine our natural tendency to seek pleasure in material things over creative activities.

questions: how do you envisage the development of radical movements in the future. do we need a uniting vision?
answers: Movements have to be developed by the activists themselves in response to local circumstances the possibilities the willingness to take risks the level of understanding. What needs to happen varies day by day. Sometimes it is a meeting sometimes a demonstration sometimes civil disobedience sometimes taking to the streets when the opportunity arises sometimes working within existing institutions sometimes facing severe repression. Depends on the circumstances.

questions: how would you describe the relationship between your academic work and your political activity. is there one.?
answers: Almost nonexistent. At some very abstract level there is a connection which i have written about occasionally.

questions: i think that is the historical background that should very much be kept in mind?
answers: Well i do not think you have to make a decision on that. Both britain and the united states have made that explicit. The major issue in the middle east is not is it an independent state but how much of it is actually represented by the three monotheistic faiths and what is their relationship to one another.

questions: you have published an overwhelming number of works. do you think of yourself as a writer?
answers: No i have never particularly thought of myself as being anything special. In fact most of what I have written is written up versions of lectures. For example syntactic structures the first book that actually appeared was essentially lecture notes for an undergraduate course at mit revised slightly to turn them into publishable form.

questions: so you see yourself first as a speaker a lecturer?
answers: The fact is that most of the writing i do is probably letters. I spend about twenty hours a week i guess just answering letters which is not very time well spent. Many letters are on questions that are in response to the hundreds of letters that i receive which are thoughtful and interesting and raise important questions and i just do not have the time.

questions: the books simply grow by accretion. would you tell us more about your writing process?
answers: There was an element of randomness to it which was not mine to begin with but which grew over the years. I guess my wife went through a phase where she would pick up a couple of journals that were not in print and would put them in the trash can.

questions: so you can not when writing a book for example concentrate for ten hours at a time?
answers: No i know that a lot of people do not seem to be able to do that and it is certainly an advantage not to have to. I can pick up after a long stretch and be more or less where i left off. In fact i have sometimes had to go back several times to make sure that i did not forget a point.

questions: that is quite a talent?
answers: Well it is probably because i have thought about most of it before or lectured on it many times. Then it becomes mainly a problem of trying to fit it all in. I do not know how else to put it.

questions: is that because you might lose credibility or lose the audience?
answers: Not at all. In fact you would probably lose your audience by not doing it. It is just kind of an authoritarian practice one should keep away from if one can help it though it can be done in a small way.

questions: in his critique of western metaphysics jacques derrida exposed the indeterminacy of language showing how meaning is never fixed always fluid never certain. what are your thoughts on this issue?
answers: I do not know this literature very well and to tell you the truth the reason ido not understand it i think is that in its modern form it just does not work. I mean it may be correct in principle but in practice it does Not. A lot of things are wrong with it.

questions: so you probably would not agree with bakhtin. are you familiar with hi work?
answers: No i am not. But he seems to be pretty much on the model i have described.

questions: his ideas sound very similar to this concept of meaning holism?
answers: Yes but that is the standard view. That means you have to turn the cart before the horse. It used to be called the logical empiricist view now it is just called that because the traditional view is out of date.

questions: this concept is related to kuhn is notion of how knowledge is formed within the scientific community. what are your thoughts about this theory?
answers: There is an element of truth to it obviously. There has to be a balance between the demands of research and the need to protect the integrity of the work being done.

questions: has your colleague down the hall thomas kuhn ever discussed the chomskyan revolution in terms of a paradigm shift?
answers: He has not but other people have i do not. My own view is that while there have been several significant changes there is been basically one scientific revolution the galilean change the seventeenth century revolution stretching over a period including george washington is contributions. That was a real revolution a different way of looking at things in many respects.

questions: do you agree with these assumptions and the conclusion9?
answers: I understand the point but i would not call it a property of language. There are many properties of human experience which reflect structures of authority and domination in the society in which this language is used and that s true. However i do not think there is any such thing as a language of domination and authority as there would be if language were used in a structure of submission.

questions: but given how language is actually used?
answers: Well given language use it is undoubtedly correct and it seems to be true of all sorts of systems of authority and domination one being the gender issue.

questions: do you see any justification for that argument?
answers: Well you have to ask what you mean by semantic universal. First of all there is the question of whether it is true but let is say for the sake of argument that every language known has a concept like motherhood and let me give you an example to illustrate what i think should be the case.

questions: s. is experiencing a literacy crisis. do you agree?
answers: Sure. It is just a fact. I do not think its even questioned.

questions: speaking of critical analysis and literacy paulo freire and others argue that writing because it can lead to critical consciousness is an avenue to social and political empowerment of the disenfranchised. do you agree?
answers: Absolutely. In fact writing seems to me an indispensable method for interpersonal communication in a complicated society.

questions: do you think that is a good idea?
answers: Doing things that will stimulate critical analysis self analysis and analysis of culture and society is very crucial. In fact it seems to me that part of the core of all education ought to be the development of systems of intellectual self defense and also stimulation for the capacity for inquiry which means also collective inquiry. And this again is an area in which it can be done quite effectively.

questions: how would you ground a concept of human nature beyond human capacity to acquire language?
answers: I would study it the same way. I think it is a very important concept. One of the problems with the language faculty is that we have a limited number of ways of understanding what is the nature of language and how does language acquisition take place.

questions: is it that we are more advanced than asians or chinese society?
answers: Well i admit that this is a value judgment and i can not prove it but i would suspect that there is going to be an evolution assuming that the human race does not self destruct which it is likely to do from rigid patriarchal societies to more egalitarian societies and not the other way around which is not a very attractive prospect.

questions: are our media victims of ideological indoctrination or are they willing conspirators in suppressing truth?
answers: I would not exactly put it either way. They are not victims and they arent conspirator. Suppose for example you were to ask a similar question about say general motors the mechanics of what they were producing.

questions: in fact it is even better much more effective?
answers: It may be the way of the future but it does not have to be. Let is take the vietnam war for example. When the united states invaded south Vietnam in 1962 roughly half the population was living in poverty.

questions: what society do you think comes closest to achieving anything like this kind of voluntary association. do you think any society even comes close?
answers: Well sure every society has aspects of it and they differ. Sometimes you find things in very poor backward undeveloped societies that you do not find in advanced societies. In many ways the united states is a typical example.

questions: that could be very dangerous. s. can fall victim to a charismatic fascist dictator?
answers: It is real. I mentioned something very good about the united states but there are also a number of things that are very bad and that is the business world in particular.

questions: how do you reconcile these two seemingly contradictory perspectives?
answers: There is something to that but let me tell you what my own choices and priorities are. Like any human being i am interested in a lot of things. There are things i find intellectually interesting and there arent many others where it makes sense for me to be. Shift to the political arena and it becomes very clear what kind of issues i think are important.

questions: do you think creativity in language can be fostered so that more of a student is innate potential is used?
answers: I am sure it can. Creative reading for example surely is a way of fostering it getting people to wrestle with complex ideas and to find ways of expressing them ought to be at the heart of the writing program. Frankly i doubt very much that linguistics has anything to contribute to this except perhaps as a convenient cover for other things i have mentioned.

questions: if so how would you define a sensible prescriptivism?
answers: I do not think sensible prescriptivism has anything to do with the kind of anarchism that you are talking about. I think propertarianism is sensible in the sense that it is the inheritor of classical liberalism insofar as classical liberal ideas are concerned. But it has nothing to say about questions of political and social organization.

questions: first of all do you think that it is continuing to spread now that american economic hegemony has been broken. also is it desirable that it spread?
answers: I have never seen a real study but my strong impression is that the phenomenon is not unique to the us. That is a conclusion that should not be lightly reached. It may be that part of the impetus toward spreading anarchism in europe is an understandable but mistaken belief that by spreading ideas you can control society.

questions: do you think people outside of linguistics should know about the principles and parameters approach?
answers: I think it is more important than the aspects type approach. In fact if anything deserves to be called a revolution that is probably it. It leads to a conception of language which is in a sense revolutionary it goes beyond anything in the history of science.

questions: what would you suggest people read people who are out of the field who want to understand this new approach?
answers: Well there are some pretty good relatively introductory books. It depends on what level they are going to be working. I have tried my hand at a few things. One kind of introductory book i found was by michel foucault who has been in cognitive science for forty years and just put it out called the end of knowledge theory.

questions: what readership did you target in your 1986 book knowledge of language?
answers: That is a funny sort of book. One chapter is pretty technical linguistics material the rest is sort more social and historical. I am not sure what the intended audience was.

questions: what is your sense of the treatment of your work in popularizations such as neil smith is the twitter machine?
answers: That is a very good book. I think he knows what he is doing he just does not tell you what it is. He does a good job of keeping you on your toes.

questions: well he does deal quite extensively with your work?
answers: That is a mistake people make they call it mine because i sometimes write about it. Take the pisa lectures. They were a very intense affair.

questions: we were surprised to hear that you are now teaching a course in semantics?
answers: It is not surprising. Part of this is terminological. In my view most ofwhat is called semantics is syntax.

questions: can you think of any instances in which metaphorical extensions of a concept like deep structure might be justified or should such extensions always be avoided?
answers: I think you have got to be careful. In the real world there are many cases when you really do want to take a look at complex systems and abstract away from them and see what is going on under the surface. And many of the times you can do that with little if any success.

questions: are you aware of any specific misun derstanding or criticism of your work that you would like to take issue with at this time?
answers: We could go on forever. On the linguistics side there is plenty of misunderstanding but i think it is resolvable. I am enough of a believer in the rational side of human beings to think that if you sit down and talk these questions through and you think them through you can reach a resolution rather than a series of post hoc idealizations.

questions: how does our brain give rise to our cognitive abilities and could this ever be implemented in a machine?
answers: Speaking in the symposium was not so enthused. Chomsky critiqued the field of ai for adopting an approach reminiscent of behaviorism except in more modern computationally sophisticated form.

questions: if you ask neuroscientists why understanding the brain is so difficult they give you very intellectually unsatisfying answers like that the brain has billions of cells and we can not record from all of them and so on?
answers: There is something to that. When you study the anatomy and physiology of the lung you are studying a very different system than you were just beginning to study. Take the study of how the immune system works let is take a look at what you call the passive system the visual system and then the vocal system because those are more complex systems.

questions: like the chemists?
answers: If a molecule is too big you give it to the chemist. The molecule will be smaller the more it is studied the better. Now why is that. That is the way the scientific method works.

questions: like hebbian plasticity.?
answers: Well like strengthening synaptic connections. Gallistel has been arguing for years that if you want to study the brain properly you should begin kind of like marr by asking what tasks is it performing. So he is mostly interested in insects and nematode flies but there are other tasks as well.

questions: these are the kinds of statements that their experiments generate?
answers: If you look at the kind of things that are discussed here you will find that the verbal behavior is part of a much broader system of beliefs and understanding. The whole system is much more complex than just the language system but the connection is there.

questions: is that conceptually flawed?
answers: Well you know you may get useful information from it. But if what is actually going on is some kind of computation involving computational units you are not going to find them that way. It is kind OF looking at the wrong lamp post sort of.

questions: advocates of this field do not stop to ask if the wiring diagram is the right level of abstraction maybe it is not so what is your view on that?
answers: Well there are much simpler questions.

questions: i think 300?
answers: Still you can not predict what the thing is going to do. Maybe because you are looking in the wrong place. Let me give you an example. If you walked into a museum you would see things that looked like they were from the 1930s but were actually parts of the late 19th century.

questions: my question is what do you think explains that shift and is it a step in the right direction?
answers: I heard pat winston give a talk about this years ago. One of the points he made was that ai and robotics got to the point where you could actually do things that were useful so it turned to practical applications and somewhat maybe not abandoned but put to an end the pursuit of general goals.

questions: so it shifted to engineering?
answers: It became well which is understandable but would of course direct people away from the original questions. I have to say myself that i was very skeptical about the initial work.

questions: in engineering?
answers: But away from understanding. Yeah maybe some effective engineering. And it is kind of interesting to see what happened to engineering because it was once thought of as the domain of the mad scientist.

questions: you have argued famously that speaking of the probability of a sentence is unintelligible on its own?
answers: Well you can get a number if you want but it does not mean anything because the number comes from fixed data. It is as if someone asked me how many cars there are in the world.

questions: but probability theory just serves as a kind of glue between noisy data and very rich mental representations?
answers: Well there is nothing wrong with statistics if the data is well behaved.

questions: but does it have a role?
answers: If you can use it fine. But the question is what are you using it for. First of all first questions is is there any point in understanding noisy data like that. Answer there is very little there apart from maybe to give you an idea of what the data is like and secondly maybe a kind of a proxy for what you might expect.

questions: well we are bombarded with it it is one of marr is examples we are faced with noisy data all the time from our retina to?
answers: That is true. But what he says is let is ask ourselves how the biological system is picking out of that noise things that are significant. The retina is not trying to duplicate the noise that comes in so it does not have a high rate of success for a sensory system that has a limited capacity.

questions: you take that as convincing evidence that activation or lack of activation for the brain area?
answers: It is evidence you would want more of course. But this is the kind of evidence both on the linguistics side you look at how languages work they do not use things like third word in sentence. Take a simple sentence like instinctively eagles that fly swim well instinctively goes with swim it does not go with fly even though it did not exist in the first place.

questions: in the domain of biology would you consider the work of mendel as a successful case where you take this noisy data essentially counts and you leap to postulate this theoretical object?
answers: Well throwing out a lot of the data that did not work. First of all there was some noisy work done by gar alperovitz and others on renormalization. But that is so slight that i can not comment on it beyond saying it is not significant.

questions: but seeing the ratio that made sense given the theory?
answers: Yeah he did the right thing. He let the theories guide the data. There was counter data which was more or less dismissed you know you do not put it in your papers because it is not there if you want to keep a job.

questions: that would go against the reductionist approach of looking for molecules that are correlates of?
answers: Yeah. In fact the reduced approach has often been shown to be wrong. The unification approach makes sense as an answer.

questions: and implicit in marr it seems that you can not work on all three in parallel it has to proceed top down which is a very stringent requirement given that science usually does not work that way?
answers: Well he would not have allowed it. He thought it was counter productive. But there is no doubt that discovering more about the mechanisms is what leads to the next step.

questions: information processing systems?
answers: Yeah like vision. There is some data out there it is a processing system and something goes on inside. It may not be very well designed for cognitive systems but it has to have some basis.

questions: it is very poor but yeah?
answers: Okay. But that is not the point. The question is what is the consequence of imposing this decision on all of us. Well the consequences are two very simple.

questions: but since we make mistakes is not that evidence of a process gone wrong?
answers: That is the process of using the internal system. But in fact if you look at the way the system is actually used the evidence you would expect is that there is going to be a systematic error that goes on all the time. So take say ordinary mathematics the kind of work you do with ordinary tools and so on.

questions: but that is a fundamentally different activity from me adding up small numbers in my head which surely does have some kind of algorithm?
answers: Not necessarily. There is an algorithm for the process in both cases. But the algorithm itself is not a property of the language it is just a way of describing the way the system is set up. Okay so what is the grammar of english.

questions: it just seems like an astounding task to go from a computational level theory like peano axioms to marr level 3 of the?
answers: What is the point of all these levels. They are just levels on a different scale. In fact when you think about it the whole structure of language is extremely simple.

questions: mechanisms and implementations?
answers: Oh i will talk about that in a minute. But the first question that comes to mind is how do we study these phenomena. So we have to study the data.

questions: without an algorithm at least?
answers: Well i do not think that is true. Maybe information about how it is used that will tell you something about the mechanisms. But some higher intelligence maybe higher than ours would see that there is an internal system its got a physiological basis and i can study the molecular basis of that and deduce from that what the external system is likely to be like.

questions: so the logic for studying cognitive and language systems using this kind of marr approach makes sense but since you have argued that language capacity is part of the genetic endowment you could apply it to other biological systems like the immune system the circulatory system?
answers: Certainly i think it is very similar. You can say the same thing about study of visual systems. Theologians have a field called cognitive science.

questions: it might even be simpler in fact to do it for those systems than for cognition?
answers: Though you would expect different answers. You can do the same thing with the digestive system. Suppose somebody has a cold.

questions: but that is precisely what the biologists are doing they are taking the sick people with the sick digestive system comparing them to the normals and measuring these molecular properties?
answers: It is very similar to what you would expect. The study of the digestive systems of hominids suggests that this is a common feature of human evolution long before anatomically modern humans appeared.

questions: it is a highly fundable approach because you are claiming to study sick people?
answers: The fact is that you can not fund anything. So for example if you wanted to fund study of the immune system you would have to demonstrate that the therapy is effective. But that is not what you want to do.

questions: but if you ask what is the computational problem that is being solved by the lung that is very difficult to even think it is not obviously an information processing kind of problem?
answers: No but there is no reason to assume that all of biology is computational. There may be reasons to think that cognition is. And in fact gallistel has shown that if we can develop a theory of biological computation that will explain a lot of things that are puzzling about the biology of the system.

questions: these systems evolved together reusing many of the same parts same molecules pathways. cells are computing things?
answers: You do not study the lung by asking what cells compute and why. You study other organs and structures but you are not going to expect to find the answers. An organism is a highly modular system has a lot of complex subsystems which are more or less internally integrated.

questions: no sure but i am saying you would apply the same approach to study each of the modules?
answers: Not necessarily not if the module is different. Some modules may be computational others may not be.

questions: so what would you think would be an adequate theory that is explanatory rather than just predicting data the statistical way what would be an adequate theory of these systems that are not computing systems can we even understand them?
answers: Sure. You can understand a lot about say what makes an embryo turn into a chicken rather like you or a mouse let is say. It is a very intricate system involves all kinds of chemical interactions all sorts of other things. To try to understand it you have to start with very simple systems.

questions: though if you study the chemical interactions it might lead you into what you have called just a redescription of the phenomena?
answers: Or an explanation. Because maybe that is directly crucially related to the question of why it is there in the first place. Let is just take a look at that.

questions: you have simply found a switch and hit that switch?
answers: But then you look further and find out what makes this gene do such and such under these circumstances and do something else under different circumstances. So let is take the example of vietnam. In the early 1960s when there was strong support for vc na> it was undoubtedly an attempt to undermine the war effort.

questions: but if genes are the wrong level of abstraction you would be screwed?

questions: what types of question must be answered?

questions: do you see the growth of machine learning as something akin to raising questions?

questions: what would you characterize as most important in your judgment?
answers: I played a certain role in reshaping the fields concerned with the human intellectual faculties cognitive sciences and linguistics. Some of this has been extremely productive and is now off and running on its own. In the political domain i would like to see people energized to think for themselves and reject systems of propaganda to overcome illegitimate authority domination and hierarchy and free themselves in a just society.

questions: is there one question in the air in that whole realm you would like most to know the answer to?

questions: tell me what would you most want to say to him?

questions: would that be culture music politics?

questions: for the palestinians?

questions: so they were not contiguous territories?

questions: us support in the international community or us support at the un?

questions: egypt would once again have the sinai and there would be diplomatic relations between the two countries?

questions: i am just making the point that you always said?

questions: you stay and fight for values because you love the country?

questions: you put free speech high on that list?

If the united states is the government of the world what it tries to do is impose order on the international system and that is perfectly barred by the principles of international order that i have just described.

questions: i understand?

questions: frequently when you are traveling around the world as i do people say i love america i just hate the policy?

questions: which is there ought to be a two state solution?

questions: when somebody says look i know?

I have had plenty of correspondence with journalists who refuse to tell people the truth about things that are very serious things like the terrorist atrocities in florida or for that matter the war in iraq.

questions: they have more power than have nots?
answers: If you really look closely elections eliminate issues where the masses are the opposing opinion. Let is take a concrete case the 2000 election. Among the issues of highest concern to the general population are things that roughly relate to what i have been talking about.

questions: you agree with the general population whose view is?

questions: were you worried about the loss of jobs and those issues which became a political football. the unions essentially were opposed to it?

questions: in other words you are saying that they misled us when they made that argument?

questions: what you are arguing is that people are not getting the information they need to make wise choices?
answers: Nor are they given the choice. And the two parties represent the same interests the us is essentially a one party state. It has two factions of the business party with two different ideological nostrums.

questions: the tory party and the labor party. would you say the same about them?
answers: Sure. They are different but the attitude is the general framework is shared by the media and most of the educated sectors.

questions: let me make this argument with you and ask is the battle in politics in most countries for the center?
answers: That is not true. There are countries with a much more lively democratic culture. Let is take a country that has a more vibrant democracy culture than we do: canada.

questions: number one i asked that question recently when gary wills was here why have not we seen in the us a more powerful coalition essentially coming from the left but not necessarily defined by the traditional wisdom of the left labor minority poor black and white?

questions: the author of the great society programs was lyndon johnson?
answers: Right. The programs are not initiated by leaders. That is a serious misunderstanding and a major distortion of what socialism means.

questions: those were initiated by people many of then who served with fdr?
answers: See that is a serious misinterpretation i believe of the way the system works. Leaders may sign their names and may push programs but they do it because a popular constituency is compelling them to do so. That happens over and over again in democratic systems.

questions: but let me make this point about lyndon johnson. but you were saying he responded?
answers: In fact the way the press treated this is by excusing himself and saying it was all just a big misunderstanding. And that is quite plausible.

questions: and secondly the things john kennedy responded to he saw his chance in history to show that he could get these things enacted because that was his principal skill?

answers: Represents which i think we should be protecting.

questions: is what it is?

questions: is there a meritocracy?
answers: Certainly. But we are talking about interactions among people. Informal interactions in my view are much healthier in the us than in other societies because the population is much more open.

questions: because you think?

questions: wait a second?
answers: Look this was war. Was there any protest. If there was it was small.

questions: people know you because of your opposition to vietnam?

questions: why do you think that took place because of the 1960s because as it breathes it gets wider and stronger and?
answers: The change happened because a lot of people worked very hard to make a change. The same is true of civil rights of women is freedom of speech and so on. That is the way changes happen. Remember the kennedy act was mainly a reaction to what was called the spock coffin.

questions: i do agree with you on that. i am not arguing that. brazil is an interesting case?
answers: If you investigate this here is what you will find. Over the last 20 or 30 years in part as a reaction to the democratizing tendencies of the 60s there were worldwide protests. They were dramatic here but elsewhere there has been a backlash.

questions: i will move on. was it because that we did not have the un behind it?

questions: i am not sure they supported him?
answers: They effectively authorized him to rush the rebellion.

questions: let me make one point that it clearly was a mistake in 1991?
answers: Was it wrong.

questions: sure it was. to allow him to crush the rebellion?
answers: Did george bush think that was a mistake. Did thomas friedman from the new york times who was close to bush at the time. Everyone keeps quiet about this but we know what the reasons were there are very simple reasons and they were not well served by bush or his associates.

questions: i can not speak for them?
answers: Take a look at the analysis. What was the goal. The goals were repeatedly stated repeatedly.

questions: the shias?
answers: Let is look at the time. That is what we need to be looking at. There is an overwhelming consensus that saddam offered more hope for the stability of the country than the people trying to overthrow him.

questions: i am sure he did not mean using torture and other techniques?
answers: Then why did he say it. Well maybe he thought it was funny. We do not know. Probably because he is so utterly incapable of seeing that his words are meaningless.

questions: but he may well have meant iraq whatever the fears he had of breaking up iraq and it needed a head figure?
answers: That means from the point of view of the us policy makers it was not a mistake. We think it is an error but they did not. The analysts and the decision makers believed what they were saying for about ten years.

questions: are you as convinced now as when you were younger that understanding language is essential to understanding the human mind?
answers: I think that is clearer and clearer. The emergence of language as a system of creative thought was sensed by descartes and galileo. But it was not really addressed till the mid 20th century because the tools were not available to formulate it properly.

questions: he connects your theory of language to pentagon funded work you did at m. i. t. during the cold war?
answers: It was a joint project in the early 1960s with tony russo and hans peter gruner at the university of pennsylvania. The basic idea was to study the logical structure of sentences and to deduce from these structures the meaning of spoken language.

questions: why do you think we are seeing this resurgence of analysis. you must tire of defending your work?
answers: I have been defending the legitimacy of this work extensively and in print for 60 years. In earlier years the discussions were with serious philosophers linguists cognitive scientists. I am sorry to see that the resurgence you mention does not begin to approximate that level one reason why unlike previous years i do not bother to respond unless asked.

questions: let is talk about your politics?
answers: I supported bernie sanders. The most important issue we face a real question of species survival is climate change. I have been criticized for advocating a politics of fear which seems to me a reasonable position.

questions: what do you make of the political climate today. of the student protests?
answers: Humans face critical problems that have never arisen before in their history problems of survival of organized human life on earth. They are barely mentioned in the current electoral extravaganza and the voluminous commentary about it. Fortunately young people are often deeply concerned and directly engaged.

questions: you will be teaching two classes next semester at the university of arizona?
answers: Yes. An undergraduate course will focus on the current stage of globalized state capitalism and ways of approaching the common good as it has been conceived in various ways since the enlightenment. The graduate seminar will explore critical issues of contemporary society and society at large with special emphasis on topics such as the relation between wealth inequality and social justice.

questions: how do you account for your amazing stamina and energy level at age 87?
answers: The bicycle theory. As long as you keep riding you do not fall. It is a very impressive physiological system.

questions: then there is all that chomsky memorabilia mugs t shirts even luggage tags?
answers: Seems strange to me. It can only mean that my activist engagements and professional work somehow relate to what many people are looking for and do not appear to perceive as lacking.

questions: do you own a chomsky coffee mug?
answers: No. But i get things from friends. The one i like is one my grandchildren like.

questions: chomsky. info 05162016?
answers: Climate change nuclear proliferation pose the worst threat ever faced by humansinterview with noah lucas the science correspondent of the new york times february 16 2016.

questions: presence in the country. s. his latest book is called who rules the world?
answers: Welcome back to democracy now. It is great to have you with us. Dr. chomsky hello welcome to wnyc.

questions: so noam who rules the world?
answers: That is to a certain extent up to us. It is possible for populations to rule the universe but they have to struggle to achieve that. And if they do achieve it it will be in conflict with interests of concentrations of power economic power state power closely linked with consequences that are of the kind that you describe quite often.

questions: how does the united states set the terms of the global discourse and overall what is happening in the world?
answers: Well that is basically an outcome of world war ii. At the end of 1942 the u. s. had a level of power and comparative wealth that had never existed in history. It had literally half the worlds wealth.

questions: you talk about the two major threats facing the world today nuclear war and climate change. talk about each?
answers: Well i might start by referring to the doomsday clock of the bulletin of atomic scientists a clock that is since 1947 shortly after the atomic bombing they established what they called a do not ask nor tell policy. Every year a panel of specialists make an estimate of how close we are to midnight. Midnight means termination for the species.

questions: you have rarely written much on the kinds of experiences that led to your politics even though it seems to me they may have been deeply formed and influenced by your background?
answers: None of this is particularly new i am afraid. These are things that i grew up with and that influenced my politics as did lots of things in the 1930s like the vietnam war and the american revolution.

questions: why is this so. were there some works that did influence you?
answers: Of course there have been but it is true that i rarely write about these matters. I am not writing about myself and these topics do not seem particularly pertinent to the topics i find interesting. There are things that quite impress me about the 1960 is but i have grown up with it and can not put it into words.

questions: you once said it is not unlikely that literature will forever give far deeper insight into what is sometimes called the full human person than any modes of scientific inquiry may hope to do.?
answers: That is perfectly true and i believe that. I would go on to say its not only unlikely but it seems to be almost certain. But still if i want to understand let is say the nature of china and its revolution i ought to pay attention to what literature may tell us about that other person.

questions: but it might be very influential in making one sensitive to areas of human experience otherwise not even asked about?
answers: People certainly differ as they should in what kinds of things make their minds work, and i think there is something to that. Some things are more likely to stimulate the mind than other things.

questions: you seem a little reticent about it?
answers: Well my reticence is partly because i am not really sure what i want to do. I have no particular interest in the philosophy of language or in science. It is enough that i find it interesting to talk about the nature of society and the relation of individuals to one another and to try to make some connections between these apparently very disparate things.

questions: what kind of schools did you go to as a child?
answers: I was sent to an experimental progressive school from infancy before i could walk. The school was called the factory school which in those days meant that the children worked in the looms and the shop floor so it was a disciplined environment. I liked the atmosphere.

questions: in new york?
answers: Well in philadelphia where i lived there was a strike going on. It was frightening. I went back to college after about a year and a half because i was so frightened i could not look at the wall.

questions: what was your college experience like?
answers: I was probably lucky in that respect. I never really went to college. Most of my friends went towards the end of their careers and i did not because i wanted to contribute to the family.

questions: was it after college that you went to live on a kibbutz in israel?
answers: I went for a few months when i was at the society of fellows in 1953. they had a program for young people ten years or younger who wanted to go out and live in the countryside. I happened to be one of the lucky few who was accepted.

questions: did you find the intellectual life stimulating. and why did you leave?
answers: Remember that i was only there for about six weeks. I did not leave because i thought i would be back i mean i had planned to stay for a long time.

questions: were you active in political organizations in earlier years in the united states?
answers: I did not have any affiliation to any group the zionist left or elsewhere. Partly it was that i am not much of a joiner i guess. Furthermore every organization which was not leninist either stalinist or trotskyite was at least sympathetic to the spanish anarchist revolution. So bin laden is a kind of an outlier in this respect.

questions: what part of the city was that in?
answers: That was at the kiosk at seventy second street and broadway if it is still there. There used to be four newsstands on that street which were taken over by the nazis and turned into what is now called the press gallery. The four were there when the african american press association was formed in january of 1963.

questions: were you also brought up in certain aspects of the jewish cultural traditions?
answers: I was deeply immersed in that. In fact i probably did more reading in those days than any other period of my life. I can date it very precisely because i began to write about it at a very young age.

questions: you rarely draw on it in your public writings. are there reasons for that?
answers: No it did not seem to be particularly relevant. It is there i mean it certainly had a good amount of influence on me as i grew up.

questions: your insights seem less derived initially from prolonged historical observation than a sense of how things are expected to operate?
answers: I guess i just always assumed it. It seems to me to follow from the simplest and most uncontroversial assumptions about motivation and interests and the structure of power namely that there should be two opposing groups of people the people who are supposed to be influencing the things that happen in the world and those people are called the opulent.

questions: they have to be dismissed because if people were to confront them they would have to write differently about the united states?
answers: Well it is interesting that it does not enrage anyone when i say this about enemies. Then it would be obvious. What outrages them is when I try to show how these patterns also exhibited in our own society as they actually are.

questions: but do you wonder why so many share such assumptions and you do not?
answers: Well maybe part of the reason is that in a certain sense i grew up in an alien culture in the jewish zionist cultural tradition in terms of religion and belief. I was brought up with a sense of awe for what i saw as a miraculous achievement of human intelligence on a grand scale overcoming all kinds of odds to bring this marvelous thing about.

questions: yet the new york intellectuals have become prime exponents of a virulent anticommunism that denies almost all the insights you start with as common sense.?
answers: In part i think age maybe was a lucky accident in my case. I was just a little too young to have ever faced the temptation of being a committed leninist so i never had any faith to renounce or any feeling of guilt or betrayal. Nor did my friends who were also young.

questions: do you look back and see this as exceptional?
answers: Oh yes. I always felt completely out of tune with almost everything around me.

questions: so in essence you started to look at language from the point of view of acquisition and comparing what experience children have and contrasting that with the knowledge that they seem to express when they learn to speak?
answers: Which is a slight shift from what was done. Actually it makes a lot of sense. If you were to ask me what my theory of language was I would have a hard time putting it into words but here it is. The language capacity is not a property of the human species it belongs to the rest of nature.

questions: what is it about the grammars of natural language that can not be inferred just from the input?
answers: To infer anything from an input you have to have a specific method of deriving information that leads you to that result. So we ask what aspect of grammar forces us to assume that there are highly specific ways of getting the result and no simpler way. Answer every aspect.

questions: how does this relate to the children in nicaragua and their experience?
answers: Well there is a preliminary point that has to be established and that is that so called sign language involves the same or similar mechanisms as spoken language. That was not assumed some years ago but now there are pretty strong arguments to indicate that it is true. So it looks as though when you study sign languages you are studying a different manifestation of very much the very same internal systems.

questions: we know that a child on their own exposed to no input does not acquire a language?
answers: No we do not actually understand that. All we learn is that it does if you look at it later in life. But many of the things that engender language learning are very simple and therefore might very well be directly relevant to the acquisition of language as opposed to being just an incidental by product of stimulation of some system.

questions: what are the implications of this natural experiment?
answers: It should provide further understanding of exactly what is needed in order to get the system working and just why it takes certain forms and not others. Here you have a case where you can have minimised the input. And therefore when you look at the output you learn more about the initial state which in turn allows you to evolve the structure of the result.

questions: does this give us additional insight into the discontinuity between gesture and true language?
answers: It could and that discontinuity is not too well understood. Humans have complicated gestural systems. I am doing all sorts of things with my hands and there is all kind of body language as it is sometimes called.

questions: why is it that children have this incredible ability to actually create a language when normally they are only required to learn an already existing language?
answers: Well superficially it may seem surprising that a child should be designed engineered if you like to create language from nothing. But when you think about it it is not surprising. Every child creates language at some level just as every human creates a visual system from some data.

questions: does the popularity of the film surprise you. because it is enormous?
answers: Well actually the fact that it has taken off is a little surprising. I mean there has been a very interesting phenomenon in the arts world the last ten years or so which is the rise of celebrity culture. And i think a lot of that is due to the celebrity aspects of what is becoming a mass audience oriented audience.

questions: i am surprised you have never seen it?
answers: Well partly because my wife died a couple of years ago and i have been pretty much confined to my own time so i do not see a lot of the stuff that goes on. But also i was not really a part of it in the early sixties.

questions: tell me what we learn about the way the media works by the way the cuba story is being dealt with?
answers: It is not a big secret. I do not know how old you are but i lived through both of them. The first was the soviet missile crisis which was a very serious crisis.

questions: it is presented by whom?
answers: By the u. s. media and opinion. See my monroe doctrine on the media for further discussion.

questions: has media concentration increased significantly since you wrote manufacturing consent?
answers: I should clarify something which was also one of the reasons i was skeptical about the film. The book that you are referring to is a co authored book and in fact the lead author who more or less did the framework for it is edward herman. He is an economist at the university of pennsylvania and he has a very good economic history of american business.

questions: quite a story?
answers: Incidentally this story is been well known for twenty years but it does not bother anyone. In fact about the only person i know who is even commented on it is ben bagdikian who has written very well about media concentration and who also mentioned this case and another case that he knows about.

questions: and why do you suppose that is?
answers: Because we are at the dissident fringe. It is just like not reporting terrorism when it happens and the victims are nice people ordinary people who happen to be Muslim. When the bombers attack you can not just dismiss it on moral grounds you have got to deal with the evidence.

questions: so what social purpose do you see the media playing?
answers: Well you can not characterize it in a phrase. It is complicated. But to a sort of a first approximation the organized media behave exactly as you would expect institutions of that character to behave under conditions of subordination to power.

questions: do you think that the multiplicity of tv channels is good news or bad news?
answers: You could ask the same question about the discovery of the printing press. Depends how it is used. Technology is usually pretty neutral except in extreme cases. Media concentration is a good measure of democracy.

questions: professor chomsky how wired are you?
answers: Oh i am a kind of a luddite. I very reluctantly agree to use any technology. In fact about the only reason i have a computer is because my teenage son was beginning to look at me with such contempt and ridicule that i thought i would better do it. But of course i do not use computers because i find them extremely inefficient.

questions: are you on the net?
answers: No. Although indirectly i am because i have a lot of friends who are and have been involved in this stuff for a long time so they send stuff off to me. Including my wife who is a high tech freak.

questions: oh yeah. what an interesting household you must live in?
answers: Yeah i do not know a radio from a tape recorder but she goes around fixing everything and all that stuff. Incidentally i have been in an electronics lab for forty years so it takes a little work not to know it.

questions: is it hard to be to be you?
answers: It is yeah the hardest thing that i find is you know staying up at night not sleeping thinking of all the thousands of requests i have got there that are just desperately trying to get through to people because they just cannot find anything that is on the radio or in the newspapers that says what it says. That really is a struggle.

questions: your work is often reviewed without as you have said the batting of an eyelash. do you never get discouraged?
answers: I am not expecting to be applauded by people in faculty clubs and editorial offices but that is not my audience. I mean i feel good about it when i well i was in india a couple of weeks ago and visited rural self governing villages and the people there were happy to meet me and talk to me about the problems they were facing.

questions: is it perhaps proof that you are at least partly right that for the most part your ideas and analysis of the media are ignored by the media?
answers: It is not just the press though. Every popular movement there is going to be something that is ignored or downplayed. Take the environmental movement for example the toothpaste industry. Nobody cares that much about the environment but when you bring it up in the context of business interests it does not matter too much because the interests are mostly supressed.

questions: in reviews of your work the comparison between you and bertrand russell or george orwell surfaces. are you comfortable with those comparisons?
answers: I do not feel part of that company. Both of them are people who i very much admire. In fact the one big picture up in my office is bernard lewis the american imperialist who actually invented the phrase humanitarian intervention.

questions: that is in the index is not it?
answers: Yeah those are the indices. These are not the judgments of experts.

questions: and fifty years later are you more optimistic or pessimistic than george orwell?
answers: I do not regard the issue of optimism and pessimism as meaning anything. Say back in the early sixties when i started getting seriously active in protest work i was hopelessly pessimistic.

questions: indeed is not it the case that the specific ability of our species to acquire any language was a major theme of interest to the modern scientific community from the time of galileo?
answers: This is quite true. At the outset of the seventeenth century the scientist and philosopher jesus christensen described the human race as having two fundamental types which he called dissimilar but essentially the same natures which were distinct from each other and from God the Father.

questions: can you please expand on the notion of the internal language?
answers: We now know that although speech is the usual form of sensory motor externalization it can just as well be sign or even touch discoveries that require a slight qualification. A more fundamental qualification has to do with the way the terms are used. The term internalization is used in quite different ways and only confusion can arise from failure to observe these differences.

questions: for example the whole idea continues to be questioned in some quarters although it is widely accepted apparently by most scientists?
answers: There has been considerable progress in understanding the nature of the internal language but its free creative use remains a mystery. That comes as no great surprise.

questions: but languages vary greatly from one another so what is the link between generative grammar and universal grammar?
answers: Languages appear to be extremely complex varying radically among them. And indeed a standard belief among professional linguists 60 years ago was that languages can vary in arbitrary ways and each must be studied without preconceptions. Similar views were held at the time about organisms generally and physics more generally.

questions: so we definitely need to distinguish speech from language right?
answers: Returning to the galilean challenge it has to be reformulated so that it excludes language from the scope of acquisition but leaves the capacity to speak in the mind as a preprogrammed system. Secondary processes map the structures of language to one or another sensory motor system for externalization. Let is turn to language capacity.

questions: do you concur with this view and why?
answers: I agree with the conclusion of the experts who set the doomsday clock for the bulletin of atomic scientists. They have moved the clock two minutes closer to midnight three minutes to go before calling it a day. That seems to me a credible judgment.

questions: and what does it tell us about american political culture?
answers: The us is to an unusual extent a business run society where short term concerns of profit and market share displace rational planning. Our leaders are mostly concerned with their own wealth and the feelings of power and prestige that accompany it.

questions: is there room here for optimism about the future of the environment?
answers: There is always room for gramsci is optimism of human will. There are still many options but they are diminishing. Options range from simple initiatives that are easily undertaken like weatherizing homes to entirely new forms of energy perhaps fusion perhaps new means of exploiting solar energy outside the earth is atmosphere to methods of decarbonization that might conceivably even reverse some of today is enormous damage.

questions: given that change in human behavior happens slowly and that it will take many decades before the world economy makes a shift to new clean forms of energy should we look toward a technological solution to climate change?
answers: Anything feasible and potentially effective should be explored. There is little doubt that a significant part of any serious solution will require advances of technology but that can only take place if the basic assumptions of the scientific revolution are kept in mind. That is not impossible but it would require a radical rethinking of some of fundamental assumptions about how the natural world works.

questions: what immediate but realistic and enforceable actions could or should be taken to tackle the climate change threat?
answers: Rapid ending of use of fossil fuels sharp increase in renewable energy research into new options for sustainable energy significant steps toward conservation and not least a far reaching critique of the capitalist model of human and resource exploitation even apart from its ignoring of externalities the latter is a virtual death knell for the species.

questions: is there a way to predict how the world will look like 50 years from now if humans fail to tackle and reverse global warming and climate change?
answers: If current tendencies persist the outcome will be disastrous before too long. Large parts of the globe will become barely habitable affecting hundreds of millions of people along with other disasters that we can barely contemplate.

questions: chomsky. info 200912?
answers: Wikileaks cables reveal profound hatred for democracy on the part of our political leadership noam Chomsky interviewed by amy goodmandemocracy now. May 16 2009. aa ar why do you say the idea of a liberal media is a mirage.

questions: i ordered you the turkey on marble rye from the deli downstairs. is this a thing of habit?
answers: For about the past twenty years or so.

questions: that exact order huh?
answers: It used to be a bagel and american cheese. Now it is a hot dog and cheese sandwich. What is the meaning of life.

questions: how long have you worked here at m. i. t?
answers: Since 55.

questions: are you a foodie?
answers: Am i a. meaning. What you could call an obsession. With. Fine dining.

questions: are you into gourmet food?
answers: I am into eating as little as possible paying as close attention as i can to what i eat paying attention to the little things like how many bites i take before bedtime paying particular care not letting any distractions in the way of eating. I never cook. Never use the stove or any other fossil fuel based method of cooking. Just eat whatever is available and what is nearby.

questions: do you know how to cook?
answers: I have done it. You would not believe how easy it is.

questions: not interested huh?
answers: Neither do i. if you really want to be bored i can describe the first baseball game that i went to inning by inning. It was a pennant race so the inning before the game started the bleachers were full of people jostling for position on the diamond. First inning first pitch was pitch for strike.

questions: something tells me you were secretly the high school quarterback and you are too embarrassed to admit it?
answers: I was sort of an outsider. I had friends, but i hated highschool.

questions: did you play sports?
answers: On my own not in the high school system. I was a track and field star but i did not go to college. It was too dangerous.

questions: you have spoken in the past about your views on sports that at least people who watch sports that maybe it is a distraction for the masses to keep them concentrated on trivialities?
answers: It can be that does not have to be. I mean i have been toying with the idea of maybe giving away free tickets to sports games to the harvard basketball team so that when they play we can all laugh. To me that is an outrageous form of consumption.

questions: do you watch?
answers: That's not really my thing. I'm not much of a fan.

questions: you have a lot of good sports teams here in boston?
answers: Yeah. We went to all of them during his jock phase.

questions: collect cards?
answers: Baseball cards. This was back in the 30 is when i was starting getting into activism. You could not go to the store and buy these.

questions: do you still have em?
answers: But i can tell you if you really want to be bored i may be able to describe the first baseball game that i went to inning by inning. About 1960 or so. This was in new york not too far from where i am.

questions: no thanks definitely not.?
answers: Terrific game it was the world championship yankees. We were sitting right behind joe dimaggio in the bleachers red ruffing pitching bill dickey catching. Lou gehrig on first.

questions: inning by inning?
answers: Oh i will not bore you. Just go along with me as i go through the sequence by sequence. If i forget something just say so.

questions: you have an autobiographical memory?
answers: Just for important things like that like when i was twelve years old and i remember the first baseball game i went to. It was a pennant race and the colts were on first. I got to first and had to wait in the bleachers so i could get a good look at the pitching staff.

questions: do you ever have to eschew things like buying products made by large companies or driving automobiles purchasing gasoline things like that?
answers: I do not see any particular significance to that and i try not to pay any attention to it. For one thing i am not much of a consumer so my tastes are not particularly influenced by such things. Also i have a wife and a family and things happen so i tend to be rather solitary.

questions: i guess when you go on a road trip how do you drive across the country without eating an apple pie from mcdonald is?
answers: Well the last time i drove across country was 1956 and i do not think there were any mcdonaugh's around then. But i will tell you if you really want an answer how much road you have to drive to get to the store.

questions: it is a graphic novel but what i would like is for you to show up occasionally in the novel having weekend adventures with hitch and salman?
answers: I do not have any Weekend adventures. I spend about twenty hours a week working on graphic novels. Those are the kind of things that i should be doing because i am extremely productive.

questions: i will invent it i was just wondering if you would be okay with defending hitchens honour in a bar fight?
answers: Anything you like.

questions: what do you think the implications are for the u. s. internationally?
answers: I think it is pretty serious. I mean the consequences could be catastrophic. Right now the united states is backing off from major military confrontations.

questions: so you do not think the united states will let democracy flourish?
answers: What they are saying is there are ways around it. So for example take what is happening in brazil which is a kind of soft coup.

questions: in your view can we really blame these rogue warriors for developing out of the ashes of failed states?
answers: You can understand what they are doing. I am not in favor of piracy the acts of violence. However you develop a theory about the motivations and the means you have to use that to try to piece together the events.

questions: so how do you stay informed in world affairs?
answers: Reading my specialty.

questions: any special news?
answers: Nothing that is not available to everyone. You have to work to find it. I mean if you are lucky enough to be in a university environment you will find a lot of it but it is mostly academic journal articles.

questions: so how do you find it then?
answers: You work. Look for interesting things. Take some question that is important ask yourself how it is beinganswered. Then you can try to piece it together from various different sources.

questions: did you vote in the last election?
answers: I voted green. If i had been in a swing state this is a fixed state i would have held my nose and voted for obama. Just to keep out the alternative which is worse.

questions: just a talking head?
answers: He is an opportunist mostly supported by the financial institutions. He had no positions on anything and was very easy to work with. That is why he has such appeal.

questions: i mean think about simple things like people using the letters on a telephone keypad to express themselves now we seem to be moving into uncharted territory?
answers: Well the big change the really radical change in communication was in the late 19th century. The shift from sailing ships to telegraph is astronomical. Everything since then has been small increments including the internet.

questions: do you foresee any quantum leaps in the near future?
answers: Everything since is a change. Small changes can magnifiy. The possibility of interpersonal communication has increased substantially with contemporary technology.

questions: as globalization presses forward and the pace of convergent evolution of human beings increases do you foresee languages as we know them maybe not dying out but maybe some sort of global language developing?
answers: There is a tremendous amount of language loss. Most of the attention is given to indigenous languages which makes sense if they are dying off. But some of this language is being absorbed by westernized societies which means that their languages are becoming more diverse.

questions: so to some extent there will be some small revivals but do not you think that eventually there will only be a necessity for one language?
answers: I suspect that sooner or later there may be one or a few second languages. See english for example is a second language in most of the educated sectors of europe and much of Asia. But maybe in the future chinese can become a true second official language.

questions: is that maybe a backlash to globalization?
answers: Yeah. I think it is a reaction in europe to the centralization of the eurozone.

questions: do you think people are becoming more comfortable communicating through a device rather than face to face or verbally?
answers: My grandchildren that is all they do. I mean of course they talk to people but an awful lot of their communication is extremely rapid very shallow communication. Text messaging twitter that sort of communication which is very rapid extremely shallow.

questions: what do you think are the implication for human behavior?
answers: It think it erodes normal human relations. It makes them more superficial shallow evanescent. One other effect is there is much less reading.

questions: because there are so many distractions or?
answers: Well you know it is tempting there is a kind of stimulus hunger that is cultivated by the rapidity and the graphic character and for the boys at least the violence of this imaginary universe they are involved in. Video games for example. I have a daughter who lives near here.

questions: how do you know what he is doing?
answers: I watch him.

questions: as the amount of interpersonal communication decreases as a result of this innovation are there implications for linguistics?
answers: I think there are certainly human implications. I do not think it is a new innovation. Just think about ten years ago if you had asked me what i thought about the evolution of language i would have said it was a little innovation is not the right word but its a change.

questions: is that for the worse i guess. i mean you have the modern conveniences?
answers: That is it saves money. It loses personal relations which is not a good thing. You know people hate to be around people who hate themselves.

questions: and now those community gathering places have moved online?
answers: Online which has it is advantages. You diversify you can have friends in india and so on. But it also loses human relationships.

questions: you were famously duped by larry flynt into taking an interview with hustler magazine which may speak less to flynt is ability to pull the wool over someone is eyes and more to your disregard of or unfamiliarity to popular culture?
answers: I would not say i knew what i was for a while. I did not have any illusions. When i got back i realized i had made a complete and utter mess of things and decided to give it a shot.

questions: but you really had no clue what hustler magazine was at the time?
answers: Never heard of it. I am pretty much out of popular culture altogether. Thanks very much.

questions: is that everyday world that most people find so fascinating why is it so uninteresting to you?
answers: I do not know i never travel much. I spend a lot of time in the United States and other countries which have much better public transportation and so on. And it is kind of boring.

questions: but surely there is a deeper conversation to be had about human sexuality and erotic material. is it just that all pornography is?
answers: I am no expert on beeeep. The core element of it i think is degradation of women whatever else goes on. I do not think it should be outlawed but i would not want to encourage it.

questions: do you know who lady gaga is?
answers: I have seen ads and stuff but no.

questions: i mean there is a way in which you yourself have entered into the sphere of popular culture. you are a pretty famous guy?
answers: Well the most famous that i know of was sort of fun. Back in 1990 i got a letter from a punk rock group called bad religion. I liked the name.

questions: he wrote a book on evolutionary biology and punk rock. i am reading it now it is really good?
answers: Oh really. Hm i have never heard of it. Glad to hear that you are interested. Bye.

questions: so let me see what else. do you ever use swear words?
answers: Well i guess so. If i were to use it i would probably use something more descriptive like he is a bully or something along those lines.

questions: i figured as a linguist you have to be well versed in all types of language?
answers: Ai is anything. Its barely more than elaborate machines that do statistical analysis on huge data sets. What you should be concerned about, is who controls it, and how can you take part in steering its future.
