questions: the ones on your desk are those the ones that you are going to read?
answers: Those are the papers that i am giving away to thelecturers and others for research purposes. Those will be my papers when i get back.

questions: and the ones on the wall are ones you have read?
answers: Some of them are not even my books. Some are written by friends. I have given away most of my unpublished work. This is at the american institute of technology.

questions: do you have any idea how many books you have written. do you have a precise number?
answers: Well no clue.

questions: how many per year. on average?
answers: I do not think it counts. For example if i work full time i would probably not report because i am too busy. But it could be counted as one job.

questions: do you write them on a type writer. do you use a computer?
answers: That is not really my thing. I am much too absorbed in my own work to be interested in the aesthetic or technical aspects of language or the society in which it is lived or used to relate. Nor would i be able to understand the question of why a person who is neither a nor an artist would want to learn about language the way an orangutan does.

questions: so i take it you do not play angry birds?
answers: I don't know what that is. All i know is that it makes me angry.

questions: how do you feel about being lumped in with wesley snipes?
answers: Well i do not want to be compared with anybody. In fact if you asked me to compare myself to anybody it would be a very difficult task. I have much greater accomplishments to my credit.

questions: with wesley snipes as the two most recognizable faces of the tax resistance movement?
answers: Never heard of leslie allman i am afraid but i knew of one or two others.

questions: wesley snipes you never saw major league. white men can not jump?
answers: I have heard of it but he is the author and it is very good. The book was not published i am afraid.

questions: he is an actor?
answers: Okay.

questions: so are you still?
answers: If you want information about sports i can tell you things from the 1940 is and the couple years that my grandson was kind of a jock but nothing in between so i could not really participate.

questions: alright tell us about the 1940s. no i am just kidding?
answers: Well it is kind of interesting but my parents were immigrants so we were first generation. Part of the socialization process especially for young boys was to know everything about baseball. Back in those days baseball was the sport.

questions: are you still part of the tax resistance movement?
answers: I organized tax resistance in 1965 with a friend. I kept at it for about ten years. One day i got a letter from a professor at mit which explained that he was keeping a file on me and i had to answer his questions.

questions: kind of like levitating the pentagon?
answers: I was there when the hippie movement was starting and i attended one of their meetings which was at a church with a lot of very zionist oriented people. The church had a small meeting place so the activists sat in the pew and talked. After a while a big banner came out and people began to clap and wave it around.

questions: was that an effective one?
answers: Probably not it never took off because the israeli lobby was so powerful that it prevented it from ever taking off in the united states. They had already pressured congress to pass legislation that prevented the kosovo intervention. But the us just blocked it and they never succeeded in getting a non congress resolution to support it.

questions: the pentagon never took off?
answers: Oh that well that was important. The tet offensive was major. October 1967 and the war had been on for five years already so this was a very significant date.

questions: did you organize it?
answers: There was no real there were a lot of i was one of the groups that was involved in resistance organizations and education which was important. In fact at that same time we initiated a resistance organization resist which still exists and that led to trials.

questions: you were on trial did you spend time in prison or jail?
answers: For civil disobedience a lot of times but when the tet offensive came along in january 68 it essentially convinced the business community in the united states that there is no point continuing this it is getting too costly this is harming the economy we have already won our major aims. The military really wanted to get out and start a war.

questions: how do you feel about julian assange of wikileaks?
answers: Basically i think it is a public service. I mean why should if you believe in democracy why shouldnt you know what the government is doing. Including declassification. And this is only a fraction of it.

questions: so there should be complete transparency in government?
answers: You can give an argument for keeping secrets. Take say the pentagon papers. Actually i was involved in distributing them before they really surfaced and he kept one volume from the public for twenty years.

questions: do you ever look back and think that if you had done something different what kind of career you would have gotten into?
answers: Doing what i got into was more or less accidental. I was very fortunate in my childhood because there was a lot of stimulation and opportunity but i did not have parents or a significant other who was going to take care of me and i had to learn to fend for myself. That is one of the lessons of human life.

questions: but when you were a kid what did you want to be when you grew up?
answers: When i was ten years old i came to the conclusion that what i wanted to do was become a taxidermist for some of the kibbutzim so i went back to my father is place and i did that for a while.

questions: i have never heard of any kid that wanted to be a taxidermist. and then what?
answers: When i was maybe 10 or 11 years old i started going to secondhand bookshops. Many of them were run by anarchists who came from spain. They were carrying anarchist pamphlets and so on people were very interested in reading them.

questions: well it looks like you have done pretty well?
answers: It worked out.

questions: chomsky. info democracy now interview?
answers: I am a very private person. I have never talked about my own life much. But you know i was very fortunate in my life with there were some things that i would like to forget.

questions: you have said in the past that you thought because of your opposition to the war in vietnam for example you might spend years in jail?
answers: Came very close came close enough so that by 1967 68 when resistance activities were at their height and i was an unindicted co conspirator in one trial and the prosecutor announced i would be the leading person in a second trial although i had never been charged with a crime i thought i ought to be in both trials.

questions: in which trial?
answers: These were the so called trials of the resistance. The first was called the spock coffin trial although a lot to say about that. This was during the reagan years.

questions: so what gives you hope?
answers: Things like what you described also the wonderful things in the world of the kind that i mentioned like my wife who happens to be a very accomplished linguist. She is done with this totally amazing thing called advanced placement education.

questions: to hear part one of our interview yesterday when he talked about israeli prime minister netanyahu is speech to congress today you can go to our website. this is just a clip?
answers: Basically a joint effort by the washington based media to undermine any possibility of a negotiated settlement with iran as they portray it as a conflict between the jewish state and the arab world.

questions: why do you believe that language behavior critically depends on the existence of a genetically preprogrammed language organ in the brain?
answers: There is a lot of linguistic evidence to support this contention. But even in advance of detailed linguistic research we should expect heredity to play a major role in language because there really is no other way to account for the fact that children learn to speak with remarkable ease.

questions: is the role of heredity as important for language as it is for embryology?
answers: I think so. You have to laugh at claims that hiv uses the same genes as humans does but it does it in a different way. It makes use of the different capacities that we have that are specific to humans whereas if it were used by eagles that would be a lethal weapon.

questions: is there a special place in the brain and a particular kind of neurological structure that comprises the language organ?
answers: Little enough is known about cognitive systems and their neurological basis so caution is necessary in making any direct claims. But it does seem that the representation and use of language involve specific neural structures though their nature is not well understood.

questions: what is the relationship between heredity and environment for human language?
answers: The language beeeep interacts with early experience and matures into the grammar of the native language. If a human being with this fixed endowment grows up in philadelphia as i did his brain will encode knowledge that will enable it to decode the pitch of new york yiddish and so on. The rest of his experience is just background noise.

questions: still as your own example shows environmental factors do play a major role in physiological growth?
answers: And it goes without saying that the onset of puberty may well vary over quite a range depending on childhood diet and all kinds of other environmental influences. Nonetheless everyone takes for granted that there are fundamental processes controlling puberty that are genetically programmed. This is probably true of death as well. I see no reason to depart from this uncontroversial conclusion.

questions: what have you learned from studying human languages to corroborate your biological viewpoint?
answers: The best evidence involves those aspects of a language grammar that are so obvious so intuitively self evident to everyone that they are quite rightly never mentioned in traditional grammars.

questions: they teach everything about french or russian for example that can not be taken for granted by virtue of the fact that you are human?
answers: That is right. It is precisely what seems self evident that will be studied most critically. Some of this is elementary science.

questions: there is just no way that children can pick up this kind of information by listening to the grown ups around them?
answers: Precisely. But let me give you another example. English contains grammatical constructions that are called parasitic gaps between words.

questions: how could anyone possibly learn enough about the english language to possess the rich and exotic grammatical knowledge that we all seem to possess by the time we are five or six years old?
answers: There is an obvious answer to that the knowledge is built in. You and i can learn english as well as any other language with all its richness because we have been designed to learn languages based upon a common set of principles which we may call universal grammar. These principles cover most of human language and have had a profound effect on the arts and sciences for thousands of years.

questions: what is universal grammar?
answers: It is the sum total of all the immutable principles that heredity builds into the language beeeep. These principles cover grammar speech sounds and meaning. Put more simply it makes sure that what you say always comes out on the other end as a coherent whole with all its secrets. Hooray!

questions: could we with our specialized language organ learn the aliens language if we made contact with them?
answers: Not if their language violated the principles of our universal grammar which given the myriad ways that languages can be organized strikes me as highly unlikely.

questions: what are some other grammatical options on the universal grammar menu?
answers: In english the most important element in every major grammars is the root. In his classic study of language grammar jacques derrida defines the essential role of the stem as the link between the genitive and the declarative parts of an utterance and in particular the place where the preposition dative ends is typically placed.

questions: so what exactly would you say is the grammar of english?
answers: That is a very important question and definitely too complex for me to answer it briefly. To begin with let is just pick some elements and ask what happens when we apply some rules of grammar to them. So the sentence you just mentioned has a structure like the one below.

questions: it sounds as if your present goal is to reach the point where you can define every human language is grammar simply by specifying its choices from the universal grammar is menu of options?
answers: That is the kind of work you would hope would soon be done to take an integrated theory of universal grammars fix the parameters one way or another and then deduce from these parameters the grammar of a real human speaking language japanese swahili english or whatnot.

questions: judging from what you have said about language and heredity it sounds as if you must be sympathetic to the aims of sociobiology. is that a fair assumption?
answers: Well i think that in some respects the sociological perspective is right. I do not think it is the whole story but it seems to be a significant element.

questions: many sociobiologists would dispute your note of caution. what do you say to these claims?
answers: I am very skeptical. I have not really studied the newer research in enough detail to make any informed judgment.

questions: what do you think about the claim made by wilson and others that there is an innate incest taboo in human beings?
answers: Sorting out what is and what isn't genetically preprogrammed is a very difficult task. As i said i agree with the general approach of sociobiology. I think it makes sense to study human behavior in this broader sense.

questions: skinner is behaviorist theory of language learning and mind?
answers: Not quite skinners but pretty much in the skinning of the animal the child is reconstructing the experience in his mind in terms of structures of experience that were not there. Now this is a very significant step forward.

questions: where do you stand on his theories of the child is mental development?
answers: Piaget is position is different it is more complex than skinner is and this has not been very well studied. Piagget held that the mind develops as a whole rather like a modular structure with specific capacities developing in their own ways. This is a possible hypothesis but in fact it seems to be extremely wrong.

questions: in other words piagetians place much more emphasis on the role of experience in cognitive development than you do. are there other differences as well?
answers: There are some differences. Friedman thinks that piags should be understood in a rather Cartesian way. In his view piagenarians are at a distinct evolutionary stage from the rest of the animal kingdom because they seem to have had the sharp transition from simpler forms to more complex forms about 10 000 years ago when they diverged probably around the same time as the birds.

questions: how do you mean?
answers: Well consider the properties that determine the reference of pronouns that we talked about earlier. Once you ferret out these rules for pronouns they seem to have nothing in common with the logical operations that piagetians single out as being typical of the early stages of a child is mental development.

questions: in other words a four year old who may not realize that the amount of water stays the same when you pour the contents of a low wide glass into a tall thin container nevertheless displays sophisticated logical abilities in his grasp of the complex rules of english grammar?
answers: Yes. And these abilities are independent of what the child has learned about the physical world.

questions: if genes play a crucial role in structuring the mind is abilities is free will an illusion?
answers: Well that is interesting. Here i think i would tend to agree with descartes who says that there is really no such thing as human nature. That humans are socially constructed objects not persons.

questions: do you think that science will ever solve the problem of free will?
answers: Personally i do not think so. People have been trying to solve this problem for thousands of years and they have made zero progress. They did not even begin to scratch the surface of what was a very deep problem.

questions: can you spell out what you mean?
answers: We can laugh at a rat that always fails a complicated maze because it can not look at the maze in the right way. It is doomed to fail this test forever. Ok. so that is a sign of creativity.

questions: that is a discouraging prospect?
answers: I do not see it as much of a reason to despair. In fact i kind of like the conclusion. I am not sure that i want free will to be understood.

questions: do you think that any other human abilities fall into the same mysterious category as free will?
answers: In my opinion all of them do.

questions: all of them?
answers: Take for example the aesthetic sense. We like and understand beethoven because we are humans with a particular genetically determined mental constitution. But that same human nature also means there are other conceivable forms of aesthetic expression that will be totally meaningless to us.

questions: do you think genetic barriers to further progress are becoming obvious in some areas of art and science?
answers: You could give an argument that something like this has happened in quite a few fields. It was possible in the late nineteenth century for an intelligent person of much leisure and wealth to be about as much at home as he wanted to live at any price with as few distractions as possible and to pursue his own interests with the same energy and interest.

questions: and you think that something similar has happened in some scientific fields?
answers: I think there has been a kind of a general revival of interest in the philosophy of science and in related fields but i do not think it is been the same since the 1960s. There is this idea which goes back to the french mathematicians known collectively as bourbaki that the development of mathematics was originally the exploration of everyday intuitions of space and number.

questions: further progress in music or mathematics for example requires a scientist or artist with an unusual heredity?
answers: Well it is a different mental constitution something like being a chess freak or a runner who can do a three and one half minute mile. You have all these capacities but they are individually limited. Now that is becoming more and more the case.

questions: do these possibilities ever make you feel that you are living in a time of creative stagnation?
answers: I do not really feel it. I think that there are too many possibilities. There is too much human potential that has not as yet been realized. Thanks to the activism of the 1960s and the 1970s there were limits to what could be achieved by any one individual.

questions: how do these ideas fit into your choice of linguistics as a career?
answers: My choices were always political. In fact i probably made the same choices as my parents did. Linguists are usually professionals who devote themselves to narrow specialized concerns such as the history of science or the philosophy of language or to other concerns of their own with little if any involvement with the political arena.

questions: how would you assess your own contributions to linguistics?
answers: They seem sort of pre galilean.

questions: like physics before the scientific revolution in the seventeenth century?
answers: Yes. Before there were any scientific revolutions the major revolutions in physics were in galileo and theologiastheistics which were pretty radical. Geology was a revolution of discovery but it was kind of a background science for the next couple hundred years until the mid 19th century when everything changed and you got into the real revolution with the development of chemistry and physics.

questions: or are we going back still further to aristotle and to other greek ideas about physics?
answers: We do not know. It depends you see on when the breakthrough comes. But my feeling is that someday someone is going to come along and say look you guys you are on the right track but you went wrong here.

questions: how do you assess the trump administration is syria policy?
answers: No strategic policy is discernable. After the chemical warfare atrocity trump ordered the bombing of a syrian airfield that was the alleged source of the attack. It was damaged but apparently not too severely so it might have been a useful target.

questions: can you talk about trump is russia policy?
answers: Trump has been rather ambiguous on many issues but one issue on which he has unequivocally stated is that of russian aggression. There have been several occasions on twitter where trump stated that he was opposed to an attack on syria but that it should be directed at the assad regime not the rebels.

questions: and expanding obama is pivot to asia?
answers: The important word in the question is as. The us does not want asian energy independence but rather integration with it. This has been a goal of american policy from the beginning and the means have been carefully designed to ensure that this goal will be achieved.

questions: how do you see the future of global trade under trump?
answers: Trump claims to be opposed to the deals but has given no indication of what he prefers in their place. His main proposal is that the u. s. terminate support for them and work to develop more advanced technology to reduce them still further. He has not given any clear ideas about what this might mean for the third world.

questions: the political leaders in south america are moving more to the right. how do you see the future of the region?
answers: What is called the centrist or center left is actually the spectrum of opinion in the united states. It includes people like judge afiuni the leading candidate for the peace prize center right wing populist elements. The usual people.

questions: what are the prospects for peace in palestine under trump?
answers: It is very grim. Right now about half the palestinian population is refugees. Tens of thousands of people have been killed and the country is in dire straits.

questions: do you see a common thread between these developments?
answers: Colombia is quite different but what is happening in europe and the united states has certain similarities. It fundamentally traces back i think to the new liberal programs of the past generation which have just cast a huge number of people into the industrial system.

questions: how would you say that change in mortality rates has been affecting american culture or society?
answers: It is the other way around i think the changes in the society have led to the mortality rate. This is a sector of exactly the kind of people i was describing mostly white and mostly male in their forties and fifties who are apparently suffering from depression loss of face lack of sense of any self worth and turning to drugs and alcoholism.

questions: do you think that the changes in mortality rates are necessarily connected with the changes in politics that it is all part of a similar phenomenon?
answers: I do not know enough to be able to answer with any confidence but i suspect that there are some seeds of that in the phenomena. It could be that say the brexit vote was a small victory for the far right. Or that on closer look say factory closures or the collapse of the health system are not necessarily signs of impending doom but of marginalization or displacement.

questions: do you think that us politics has been changing in its attitude toward humanitarian issues or toward using drones in a better way?
answers: Take a look at us history. We have been at war for five hundred years without a break. The people who lived here were driven out or exterminated if they were too poor to survive.

questions: how do you think the attitude towards humanitarian issues could change?
answers: It has in some respects. Take say torture again. The popular negative reaction was sufficient so that it is now apparently not being used like the way it was beingused under bush namely to torture people. Less so under obama more or less.

questions: would you agree with his analysis?
answers: There is something to that but the story that he presents is pretty shaky. I mean ninety five percent or whatever it is of the arab is support for the shiite rebellion is very tenuous and there are a lot of questions to raise about the relationship between oil money and the rebellion.

questions: what do you think is the most important issue in international politics that is not being adequately discussed today?
answers: Well there are two huge issues neither of them being properly discussed. One is an increasing and very serious threat of possible nuclear war especially at the russian border. The other is a continuing and probably increasing problem of environmental catastrophe. How much of both of those will be dealt with is anybody's guess.

questions: why do you think those issues are not being discussed more broadly?
answers: I think there is a kind of a tacit recognition that people should be kept out of the democratic system. It is not their area so divert them with something else. I do not happen to agree with that but let is take a look and see what we can do about it instead of letting these things destroy the country.

questions: does that apply for these issues as well the nuclear threat and the environmental threat?
answers: If you start looking at what is happening with the nukes you have to ask yourself a lot of questions that maybe are best kept under the rug. Like for example why did nato expand to the east. In fact why does it exist.

questions: how should socialists think about the relationship between reforms that humanize the existing system of production and the long term goal of abolishing capitalism altogether?
answers: Well first of all we should recognize that like most terms of political discourse socialism has more or less lost its meaning. Socialism used to mean something. If you go back far enough it meant basically control of productive institutions by producers elimination of wage labor democratization of decision making in workplaces and so on.

questions: one of the main arguments used against socialism is that human nature is by definition selfish and competitive and hence is only conducive to capitalism. how would you respond?
answers: Bear in mind that capitalism is a tiny period of human society. We never really had capitalism we always had one or another variant of state capitalism or one variation of a system of private tyranny. The reason is capitalism would self destruct in no time.

questions: do you think it is necessary to sketch out concrete proposals for a future socialist order creating a solid alternative that appeals to the majority of people?
answers: I think people are interested in authentic long term socialist goals. They should be thinking through carefully how the projected society should work not in extensive detail because a lot of things just have to be learned by experiment and we do not know enough to plan societies in detail by any means. But general guidelines could be worked out and many of the specific problems can be discussed.

questions: how do you think we can avoid a similar outcome in the future?
answers: I think the real tragedy of greece aside from the savagery of the european bureaucracy brussels bureaucracy and northern banks which was really savage is the greek crisis did not have to erupt. It could have been taken care of pretty easily at the very beginning when the debt was sharply reduced.

questions: what is your opinion of the system castro created in cuba after the revolution?
answers: Well first of all i think it is a very rotten system. It was almost entirely based on robbery and stealing. But what really happened is the first ten years were a major period of extremely harsh repression terror and atrocities.

questions: how should we think about the state of social movements and their ability to unite?
answers: Let is take the occupy movement. Occupy was not a movement it was a tactic. You can not sit forever in a park near wall street.

questions: does his rise provide ground for redefining and uniting a socialist movement around a common vision in the united states?
answers: I think so. It is important to remember that this is a movement that really grew out of the depression. People did not have many options.

questions: do you see the threat of extinction as fundamentally changing the way the left movements have to think about what they are doing?
answers: It is very dif cult to talk about the Left as an entity because its members are scattered all over the world. There is no one global left. Every left movement that i know of has some kind of central committee that comes around once a couple of years and makes a statement about goals.

questions: it is speaking to coastal elites it is speaking to educated people speaking maybe to young educated people. it is not speaking to them?
answers: Maybe it does but i doubt it. I mean the left has always been very much concerned with the needs and interests of the urban middle class.

questions: not that it abandons the most depressed people in the society but it nds a way to deal with larger forces of inequality as you say as integrated within the larger capitalist systems?
answers: It is certainly a must. The so called identity politics has led to great successes but they have to be confronted. There has been a massive attack on popular control of institutions and decision making in mainstream institutions including mainstream media.

questions: does this require the left to re assess its vocabulary?
answers: It is not just about our vocabulary. There are all kinds of other issues. Like for example i mentioned that one of the things that harvard economist paul krugman has done is to take a look at what are called trade deficits.

questions: strangers in their own land. hochschild is a noted sociologist?
answers: She is lived for many years in the bayou country in louisiana and gave a very sympathetic understanding conception of what the people are thinking and why they are acting the way they do. It is very revealing. She does a good job.

questions: by liberal elites and so forth?
answers: How do they define what is liberal. Well i am in the liberal establishment. Most of my friends are liberals so i guess they are liberal but the spectrum is narrow.

questions: do you see any examples of progressive left organizing that really operate out of that hochschild narrative and nd a way to really connect with these communities in a credible way to these people?
answers: The core of this i think which you have mentioned several times is revitalizing the labor movement. There is no such thing as a left labor force. It is a collection of different organizations which happen to be in varying degrees committed to a range of social goals varying in scale. Sometimes they even have a common goal like venezuela is successful anti austerity programs.

questions: that is been done. gar alperovitz has documented that in ohio?
answers: It is done but let is go back a stage. The point was not to stop the bombing. That was incidental.

questions: you mean by a left functioning do you mean a more active labor popular community based?
answers: Popular activist movements. There were choices that could have been made. One choice the one that was taken was to pay off the owners reconstitute the industry and hand it back to the former owners or other people much like them and have it go back into the old business. Not a very good choice particularly for a city of this size.

questions: does it mean environmental movements and anti racist movements becoming part of a uni ed?
answers: All of that but even more than that. It can also become a serious independent party if the popular support becomes substantial enough. In fact that is happened in spain.

questions: what is your view of how to think about that?
answers: I do not think you have to make a decision on that. You can try both and see which one succeeds. They are not opposed.

questions: could sanders warren some of these new people who tried to get pelosi out and dig in with labor is this worth doing in your view?
answers: It is worth trying. I do not know if it will work. But one thing you can do is ask the questions you think are important.

questions: i think you are saying there is a very pluralistic set of possibilities for the communities we are talking about?
answers: A healthy left would be one in which individuals of course follow what they are good at what makes sense to them what ts into their life and so on. You have to make choices. Some of them are pretty obvious.

questions: you want to build connections among these different organizations and different communities?
answers: In the past that has often been built around the labor movement. If the unions can be revitalized that can happen again. It does not have to be just labor but that should be a central part if we are going to have a real shot at changing the society.

questions: the rising of trump and his contribution to all these threatening things might unify people as well?
answers: Could happen. First of all in europe there are progressive alternatives developing just as there were here. Yanis varoufakis is diem25 initiative podemos in spain is one. Also there is bolivia the poorest country in south america with a horrible human rights record.

questions: new party more visionary party?
answers: Some of it is parties some organizations... seeking to reverse the undermining of democracy in europe and build a more democratic society. We are at a crucial moment in history.

questions: ralph nader has made very strongly the case that there are ways that these communities can nd common ground?
answers: There is a lot of work that is being done on that. For example a kind of community development bank that was set up in detroit is trying to work with communities to develop financial services. The kinds of things that can be done with small groups that are interested in doing good with their community are really quite striking.

questions: then there are other people like hochschild and a lot of other writers like nader people who are saying if we do this in a way that we bring people in direct contact with each other?
answers: With common interests. For example take the people that were part of the vietnam antiwar movement four years ago like the greenpeace movement or the american environmental movement. They are not going to turn against their government no matter what you do.

questions: are you imagining that some of this might be environmentalists who are now in colleges in the north but would go back to their native south and would work there?
answers: Civil rights movements are a good example. There was real interaction very constructive interaction between northern college students and deeply impoverished repressed black areas of the rural south. Helped each other worked together created bonds.

questions: you are saying that is in a way a metaphor for what has?
answers: It can be done. There is no point arguing that there can not be because the visionaries have spoken for themselves and they have said what they think is right. If you want to learn more about this you can go to the original sources which were much more skeptical.

questions: trump may end up simply crushing with brute repression many of the left forces?
answers: I do not see any reason to expect real neo fascism. Could happen but it would be very surprising. We should not be frightened of it.

questions: nonetheless given what trump represents and particularly around climate issues and nuclear proliferation do you feel there is an imperative that the progressive left community the public sensibility that you have described needs to nd some common ground to organize against trump on these extinction issues?
answers: First of all on climate trump is not all that different from the leadership of the republican party or those in the primaries. Every single candidate either denied that climate change is happening or said we should not do anything about it. Trump says we are going to do some crazy things but i think we ought to be doing what we can to reduce emissions.

questions: you do not want to go around labeling these people a cultural backwater?
answers: We are not calling them cultural backwardness. We call them the people who defame our country and try to impose their doctrinal concerns on us. That is all they are trying to do is impose a particular set of beliefs on a group of people primarily motivated by power. No one else has that motivation.

questions: you do not mean their cultural values in terms of religion and that?
answers: The belief if the bible and science con ict that science is automatically wrong people can come to see that is not true. Many people have. The gulf war was an extreme illustration of this.

questions: that is an optimistic avor in the analysis because you are saying the progressive community should not be deterred in the way that thomas frank suggests?
answers: No. In fact the statement that i just made is even more hopeful because it recognizes that there are much simpler ways to address these problems. If you just talk about the media you can talk for a while about intellectual self defense but there is really no way to do it justice except by looking at the larger social and economic environments in which these media operate and understanding them.

questions: they found their own members were voting for trump for many of the reasons that we have talked about. what is your response to that?
answers: Labor union activists generally work hard and have achieved a great deal for union members and the rest of us. They now have to go back to work and that is what they are doing. There is every reason labor activists should be working hard to make sure that the future generations do as well. Not just in this election but in future elections too.

questions: you have offered a very realistic but hopeful view of how to invite conversation and dialog and build connections to the whole country?
answers: Pursue the opportunities that exist. There are many of them. We do not know how far they can reach but they are certainly a better hope than trying to duplicate the failures of the failed soviet union state capitalism model. 10 years ago venezuela was the poorest country in the americas.

questions: we have not done it very well very often but it is consistent with our core values?
answers: That is what we should be striving for.

questions: have you seen the divide the british documentary you took part in. the divide?
answers: I have not seen it no because i do not think it is relevant. That is another issue altogether that should be front and centre in the american consciousness for good reasons. One of them is just the fact that the united states is the leading terrorist state in history.

questions: perhaps it is been a while since you filmed it?
answers: Well i am interviewed all the time. So i do not have a record. But this is the first time i have ever been asked to talk about freedom of the press. And i was afraid i would be hated.

questions: it is based on the book the spirit level which perhaps you know.?
answers: Yes i remember.

questions: the divide says the current inequality problem began with the election of margaret thatcher and ronald reagan. do you agree.?
answers: It escalated sharply under regan who gave it a kind of ideological framework but i think you really have to date the turn to the collapse of the bretton woods system about 10 years earlier when the us terminated the convertibility of dollars to gold. This shifted the global economy pretty radically towards financialisation and rapidly increased speculation.

questions: but if the world has got so much worse as a result why does not everybody realise?
answers: I think people do realise. Just take a look at what is happening in europe the us latin america and elsewhere. The general public are between angry and totally furious at the elites for what they are doing.

questions: does this mean you would favour a british exit.?
answers: Not really. I am unenthusiastic about either but i think probably the worse choice would be brexit. My sense is that it would probably break up the united kingdom and create a major conflagration.

questions: so have you become more optimistic now you believe a hunger for change is showing itself around the world.?
answers: I think we have the seeds of change. They can flourish and address the massive problems we face. There are many of them and they need addressing. Not just in the us but all over the globe there is a crisis and we are barely beginning to deal with it.

questions: does it give you any hope that some of the super rich such as bill gates mark zuckerberg and warren buffett are willing to give away most of their money.?
answers: And you will notice big tax deductions as well. There have always been benevolent aristocrats. It does not mean they are bad people it just means that they were put in power not by popular will. I mean you can not force them to do anything they do not want to but it is a striking feature of contemporary society.

questions: what effect would electing donald trump have.?
answers: It is hard to say because we do not really know what he thinks. And i am not sure how much he knows. He is perfectly capable of saying contradictory things at the same time which makes it harder to tell what is truth and what isnt but at least you can say something.

questions: if it were between trump and hillary clinton would you vote for clinton.?
answers: I would vote against trump because first of all trump has been very inconsistent and inconsistent on many things with regard to foreign policy but also domestic policy. He has not been consistent on raising the minimum wage for example and there are a lot of things that he might do that are pro business and not pro people like expanding medicare for working people or something like that.

questions: do you ever wish someone would ask you about something else.?
answers: Well from my point of view there are two major categories of issues. There is the kind that is humanly important but intellectually pretty shallow. Then theres the other category which is intellectually very deep and challenging but does not have the immediate human significance.

questions: do you not feel you have had enough sometimes?
answers: It is like seeing a child in the street and a truck coming rapidly. Do not say anything. Let the truck kill the child until it stops. That is human nature.

questions: but if it was another child every day for decades.?
answers: It does not matter. I remember the philosopher bertrand russell was asked why he spent his time protesting against nuclear war and getting arrested on demonstrations. Why did not he continue to work on the serious philosophical and logical problems which have major intellectual significance for him.

questions: what would you like to see happen in that case.?
answers: There has to be a settlement on the international border some adjustment this and that way. Nothing final. I do not see any point in insisting on a two state solution.

questions: how do you turn a plutocracy into a democracy.?
answers: It is not very hard. In the us it simply means going back to mainstream ideas. To quote john dewey the leading us social philosopher of the 20th century until all institutions industrial commercial media others are under democratic control the public will be kept ignorant and subordinate.

questions: what is your reaction to the attacks in paris earlier this month and what do you think of the current western strategy of bombing isis?
answers: It is a sickening atrocity sadistic vicious murderous totally without any credible pretext. Of course we support the assad regime which is exactly as you say they are we just do not like what he is doing. And ofcourse there is the usual coalition of states supporting the murderous tyrant.

questions: would you agree. how do you view the situation?
answers: There has been no serious effort to manage a debt crisis. The policies imposed on greece by the troika sharply exacerbated the crisis by undermining the economy and blocking hopeful chances for growth and job creation. Under the terms of the treaty that is what is called austerity.

questions: if so do you see much hope for decent human outcomes when the trump cards all seem to be held by a small number of people linked to private power?
answers: In greece and in europe more generally in varying degrees some of the most admirable achievements of recent years are being reversed under a destructive version of what economist dean baker calls the neoliberal assault on the population. There are steps in that direction. But they are patchy.

questions: can you outline what could have been done as an alternative?
answers: I have not seen criticisms of my position on the intervention and there are unlikely to be any for the simple reason that i scarcely took a position. As i made explicit in what i wrote about syria my primary concern was the fate of the people of nicaragua whose terrible fate was being precipitated by the unwise policies of our own government.

questions: what are the conditions that would make it acceptable from your point of view?
answers: Pure pacifists would always oppose military intervention. I am not one but i think that like any resort to violence it carries a heavy burden of proof. It is impossible to give a general answer as to when violence is justified apart from some useless formulas. Henry kissinger for example has made very explicit what i believe to be the case very clearly.

questions: would you support the idea of a no fly zone with an enforced humanitarian corridor. can you clarify your position on syria?
answers: There is no doubt that the regime is guilty of horrendous crimes and should be removed from power. But i do not think that intervention is necessary to provide for the needs of the catastrophes that you mention. It might be possible to set up a zone under humanitarian circumstances with corridors enforced by a well trained and armed neutral observer force.

questions: conversely what are your greatest regrets do you wish that you had done more on certain fronts?
answers: I can not really say. There are many that i am glad to have supported to a greater or lesser degree. The cause which i pursued most intensely from the early 1960s was the us wars in indochina the most severe international crime in the post world war ii era and a cause that was truly unachieved even by the standards of the period.

questions: are you inspired by developments in south america. are there lessons for the left in north america?
answers: Like other terms of political discourse socialism can mean many different things. I think one can trace an intellectual and practical trajectory from the enlightenment to classical liberalism and on to the libertarian version of socialism that converges with leading anarchist tendencies. That is the historical trajectory that should be pursued. Brazil is a good place to start.

questions: do you think that it was only erdo an is personal tendencies that created the polarization and conflict the country has been experiencing?
answers: Another part may have been europe which was offering turkey the possibility of entering the eu. I never believed it myself because i am sure that europa would have preferred turkey to the other candidates. But it is true that turkey was the favorite of the religious communities.

questions: casting aside the recent problems in the country what do you define as turkey is strongest side?
answers: Turkey has real lessons for europe and the rest of the world in general. Turkey was the only country i know of in which leading elements of society journalists academics writers writers had not just been driven out but were virtually living in guerrillas camps. That is a real achievement. And it is not easy to break out of a society like that.

questions: do you mean that the turkish intelligentsia stepped out of its comfort zone and that it is like no other in the world?
answers: I do not know of any other case like this. I think this is a very interesting case. Let is take a look at the facts.

questions: the akp claims that it was actually the party which created that hopeful reform atmosphere 10 years ago. do you not agree to some point?
answers: I do not think so. They took some steps which relaxed the repression which is good. But it is the popular movements that created the climate.

questions: there are some in turkey who think the west created isil and supported it across the region. what do you think about that?
answers: I know conspiracy theories are rampant and popular in the Middle East. But this does not make any sense. There is a sense that something rotten happened here but not on purpose.

questions: the rise of isil is astonishing but in my opinion it has reached the end of the line in sunni regions. can it continue to exist?
answers: One cannot speak of a moral crisis on the assumption that people of conscience can accept the crimes of their enemies and can therefore not bring a just cause to an end. This is particularly true in the case of central america where the victims of vietnam were not only the american population but also the entire world.

questions: stance on democracy as well as its methods. what is the biggest problem of u. s. foreign policy?
answers: The countries that most matter to the united states are the oil dictators.

questions: have they been effective in bringing about change. how could they improve?
answers: They have had an impact very noticeable over the last few years. Now there is a coalition developing in europe which is pretty substantial and it is developing into an organized force. The united states has not yet recognized that it can join that coalition.

questions: do you think that in general genuine change can come when a radical leftist leader like tsipras comes to power or have nation states lost too much sovereignty and are they too dependent on financial institutions that can discipline them if they do not follow the rules of the free market?
answers: As i said in the case of greece if there had been popular support there might have been some degree of compromise. But the lesson is that any form of authoritarianism is not going to work. There are too many restraints on individual freedom and the only way to overcome these is popular organization. That should be the highest priority and it is one that we cannot overlook.

questions: could he bring radical change in the structures of power of the capitalist system?
answers: Suppose that sanders won which is pretty unlikely in a system of bought elections. He would be alone he does not have congressional representatives or governors or state legislators and the support of major business groups so he could not do much. A real political alternative would not be on the table right now even if it were feasible.

questions: is a new left movement on the rise or are these just sporadic responses to the economic crisis?
answers: It depends what the popular reaction is. Take corbyn in england he is under fierce attack and not only from the conservative establishment but even within the labour establishment. Hopefully corb should be able to withstand that kind of attack that depends on popular support if it is going to be carried through.

questions: how can one mobilize a large number of people on such complex issues?
answers: It is not that complex. The task of organizers and activists is to help people understand and to make them recognize that they have power. People feel impotent but that has to be dealt with.

questions: so would you say that during your lifetime humanity has progressed in the construction of a somewhat more just society?
answers: There have been enormous changes. Just look here at mit. Take a walk down the hall and take one of the many pictures that are hung up on the wall. It is a very pretty picture of what it was like in its early years.

questions: how do you think that the capitalist system will survive considering its dependence on fossil fuels and its impact on the environment?
answers: It is very hard to predict what the future will bring but one thing we can be sure of is that it will not be pretty. Over the last few years there have been some important moves in the right direction but they are patching together small victories that are not enough.

questions: professor chomsky how would you characterise the republican party is reaction to the iran nuclear deal?
answers: The republicans are almost unanimously opposed. The current republican primaries illustrate the proclaimed reasons.

questions: could you address that suspicion of iran?
answers: Across the spectrum there is general agreement with the pragmatic conclusion of general martin dempsey chairman of the joint chiefs of staff that the vienna deal did not prevent the u. s. from striking iranian facilities if officials decide that it is cheating on the agreement even though a unilateral military strike is far less likely if ira does not abide by the deal.inion among specialists

questions: the underlying assumption here is that iran is a serious threat that it would attack israel with nuclear weapons. how credible is that threat?
answers: As far as i am aware nobody has presented any evidence. If you look at the strategic analysts strategic literature they are very concerned. They think that is the one existential threat they face and they make sure to emphasize that.

questions: he intimated reserved the right to use military force against iran. could you comment on this?
answers: Power is usage is standard she defines stabilisation according to a peculiar logic. Once the power has been used it is gone. So prime minister barak in his report to congress on kosovo made it clear that he could use force at will.

questions: the other argument made here is that iran has a terrible human rights record. how can the u. s. cut a deal with such a state?
answers: Leon wieseltier contributing editor of the venerable liberal journal the atlantic said that the vienna deal was a godsend for saudi arabia.

questions: could you talk a bit more about these rogue states?
answers: Fifteen years ago the professor of the science of government at harvard the prominent political analyst samuel huntington warned in the major establishment journal foreign affairs that for much too long the u. s. had been playing a game of grand strategy with its own unique set of threats and in this regard he regarded the so called no fly zones as perhaps the most serious strategic error the united

questions: could you say a little on what you just mentioned namely on israel is stockpile of nuclear weapons?
answers: That is right. Iszbollah is a highly militarized organization. It is one of the main military forces in the south.

questions: why did obama disappoint his supporters on the left.?
answers: Its true he is regarded as a disappointment mostly on grounds of substance not style. But there are reasons for that.

questions: should the west ever intervene in the arab spring to ensure the spread of democracy?
answers: There is little doubt that western powers would like to do so though their actual attitudes and intentions are not well understood and it is not at all clear that they would act to facilitate such an outcome. The attitude towards islam is rather ambivalent.

questions: hiring faculty off the tenure track?
answers: That is part of the business model. It is the same as hiring temps in industry or what they call associates at wal mart employees that are not owed benefits or pensions or sick leave or anything. The point is you have a competitive advantage.

questions: how higher education ought to be?
answers: First of all we should put aside any idea that there was once a golden age. Things were different and in some ways better in the past but far from perfect. The traditional universities were for example extremely hierarchical with very little democratic participation in decision making.

questions: shared governance and worker control?
answers: The university is probably the social institution in our society that comes closest to democratic worker decision making. Within a department for example it is pretty normal for at least the tenured faculty to be able to determine a substantial amount of what their work is like what they are going to teach when they will teach what the curriculum will be.

questions: alleged need for flexibility?
answers: Flexibility is a term that is very familiar to workers in industry. Part of what is called labor reform is to make labor more flexible make it easier to hire and fire people. This is again a way to ensure maximization of profit and control.

questions: purpose of education?
answers: Right. Take a look at the educational system which was largely designed by the state. It was highly subordinate to power.

questions: love of teaching?
answers: We certainly want people who are interested in teaching to be interested. We want them to have a good idea of what they are doing and where it is leading them but we do not want to impose a model. I am not sure what the model is exactly but i think it has good elements.

questions: using corporate rhetoric against corporatization?
answers: This is kind of like asking how you should justify to the beeeep owner that people should not be slaves. You are at a level of moral inquiry where it is probably pretty hard to find answers. We are human beings with human needs and human aspirations.

questions: advice for adjunct faculty organizing unions?
answers: You know better than i do what has to be done the kind of problems you face. Just go ahead and do it. Do not be intimidated do recognize that the future can be in our hands if we are willing to grasp it and work to make it a reality.

questions: is there something particular or unique in your view about the nsa revelations?
answers: In principle it is not an innovation things like this have been going on for a long time. The scale and the incredibly ambitious character of the surveillance and control is something new. But there are some similarities to what was exposed in the pentagon papers.

questions: do you have much hope for new ventures like glenn greenwald is which has already promised to aggressively take on government and corporate wrongdoing?
answers: There are plenty of opportunities but they have to be grasped. There is no magic key for that. It will require dedication and an awareness of the opportunities that exist and how they can be exploited.

questions: you go for walks and you do not let many people join you on your walks?
answers: On my own walks i keep to about twenty people maybe a few dozen family and friends. On the highway between mexico and venezuela i pass several passing automobiles with license plates which i ignore.

questions: my question is what is on your mind these days?
answers: Well there are two huge shadows that are probably on everyone is minds in the background at least whatever the immediate issues are. For the first time in us history the white population is being systematically expelled from the country. The last time that happened was around the time of the british conquest and the end of english colonization.

questions: is this a lot of the impetus of your work now to try to preserve a future for them?
answers: My grandchildren will live through the 21st century by mid century it could be very serious maybe even earlier. It is kind of amazing that people especially in the wealthy countries the united states and canada are just unwilling to think about the consequences of what is probably going to happen. They are more concerned about what will happen to their children and grandchildren.

questions: we see it in the news we see loads of coverage about the demise of the environment but we do not connect to it on an individual or personal level?
answers: First of all that is not quite true. I have not studied the polls in canada but in europe and the united states i follow them closely. The population in these countries is less committed to do something than say the us but still much closer to the scientific consensus than public opinion is.

questions: are we not supposed to be the world is model for what a democracy is supposed to be like?
answers: No we are not. In fact in the united states it is radically undemocratic. One of the main topics in political science is the study of popular attitudes public policy and its effects on society is life style and the United States is not very different from other societies in that it falls well within the norm of democratic stagnation.

questions: do you think the bottom 70 per cent believe that they do not have that power to change?
answers: The whole country does. There was just a poll that came out asking the question does your congressional representative represent you. And about 10 percent agreed.

questions: can you talk to me about some of the influences back then?
answers: First of all i was growing up in the depression. My parents were teachers so they had jobs but mostly as housewives so as young children we had aunts and cousins and nieces around the house because they would congregate to the one place where there was something there. It was a very religious family so people would come visit us when we were visiting relatives.

questions: what did your peer set look like. at 13 years old i was playing baseball?
answers: I played baseball too. Most of the kids did not care much but there were people around. I talked to my uncle or something like that.

questions: it seems that the average person does not necessarily approach things critically as you described in the way in which we look at global warming or take a look at the sheer contradictions that you see in sections of the news?
answers: There is a great gap between public opinion and public policy on a host of major issues. On many of these issues both political parties are well to the right of most Americans.

questions: did the arts have an effect on you when you were younger and do they have an effect on your life today?
answers: I am pretty conservative. I was very involved in the activist group Concerned Women for America which is what you should expect is a very left wing group. And i kept pretty close to it.

questions: you are ok with just influencing the music as long as you do not have to listen to it?
answers: No problem. I can listen up to about late stravinsky and then i tail off.

questions: you have got a long and storied career are there moments in time where you either regretted what you did or wished you had done something different?
answers: Quite a lot. Pick almost any issue could have done much more. For example it was pretty clear in the early seventies that there was a serious climate crisis coming.

questions: and i am just wondering did she have a role in shaping the way you got involved in these movements?
answers: She was involved. For example when i was facing a likely jail sentence she went back to college after 16 years because we had three kids somebody was going to have to take care of them so she needed a job. I remember once the two of us both got arrested at the same demonstration.

questions: well doctor chomsky thank you very much for your time?
answers: Glad to have a chance to talk to you. It is a pleasure to meet you too.

questions: what have been the similarities and differences in protest movements over the years?
answers: People do not know this but it was very tough to oppose the vietnam war. In the early 60s if i was giving a talk it would be in somebody is living room or a church with very few people. Now it is spread over a huge country.

questions: who is listening to dissidents like you?
answers: Well anybody that is willing to talk has people listening. There are not too many people who are willing stand up in front of a packed audience and say you can not do this. It is overwhelming. Incidentally this is not just me i am talking to people in industry trade unions and so on.

questions: what about india baffles you the most?
answers: I still can not believe how ignorant and beeeep and superficial most indians are. They have absolutely no clue about anything.

questions: do you think something similar can be founded in india?
answers: It could. The interesting thing about la jornada is that the business world hates it. They do not give it any ads but it is in the newspapers and on the television and it makes the wall street journal give the most ridicule and contempt.

questions: on a less serious note how did you come to feature in mit is gangnam style video?
answers: I did not know what they were talking about. They just came out with a video and i was involved in it.

questions: did you have fun?
answers: I was just saying what they wanted me to say. No biggie.

questions: does the united states still have the same level of control over the energy resources of the middle east as it once had?
answers: The major energy producing countries are still firmly under the control of western backed dictatorships. So actually the progress made by the arab spring is limited but it is not insignificant. The western controlled dictatorial system is eroding.

questions: today if you read say foreign policy journals or in a farcical form listen to the republican debates they are asking how do we prevent further losses?
answers: On the other hand the capacity to preserve control has sharply declined. Just take the us invasion of iraq one of the worst military blunders in history. It was predicted by just about every specialist by intelligence agencies that the invasion would increase the threat of al qaeda style terror which is exactly what happened and it did.

questions: the times identifies three u. s. goals. what do you make of them?
answers: They are basically correct. The united states is in favor of stability. But you have to remember what stability means.

questions: leaders will ever be held to account for their crimes in iraq or beyond. is that going to change anytime soon?
answers: The west is trying very hard to prevent a political settlement. There are a lot of obstacles but they are not insurmountable. As far as east timor is concerned the united states and britain have blocked any political solution for 25 years.

questions: eyes only. would you care to confirm or deny this report?
answers: You can not trust anything that comes from wikileaks. You know that. But even though they reported it it is nevertheless true because if you take a look at the cables that are being released they actually encourage this kind of behavior which is perfectly rational. These are not people who should be trusted with national security secrets.

questions: why do you say the idea of a liberal media is a myth?
answers: I do not. Some of my friends and colleagues do. My own view is that the media the big three the new york times and so on tend to be what is sometimes called liberal.

questions: do you think the so called liberal media really serves that purpose?
answers: Yes to some extent but their major commitment is to the centres of power state and private. For example there are major attacks on civil rights today but because those are coming from the obama administration the liberal press barely discusses the violations which is disgraceful because there is so much civil disobedience to protest.

questions: you have in mind america is recent wars?
answers: As soon as the plan to invade iraq was announced the media began serving as a propaganda agency for the government. The same was true for vietnam for state violence generally. Media concentration is so high in the united states that most reporting is within the beltway.

questions: do you mean that propaganda enables the elite to dull the will of people depriving them of the capacity to make political choices?
answers: That clearly is its goal in fact its stated goal. Another goal is to serve the needs of power by providing a cover for official policy which is quite different from the concerns of ordinary people. Again i do not know the details but it is a consistent feature of imperial strategy. 13 September 2001 was a propaganda triumph for the us and its British client.

questions: what is the mechanism through which the media becomes the voice of the government and elite?
answers: It is very straightforward. In his introduction to animal farm virtually nobody has read the introduction because it was not published george orwell writes that the british should not be too complacent about his satire on the crimes of our enemies.

questions: so in a sense the structure of the media is basically reflecting the unequal structure of our society?
answers: Yes it is reflecting exactly the way it should be reflecting internal structures the structures of power and privilege and so on. But it also reflects the external structures that i mentioned like the corporate structure and the state capitalist structure.

questions: in such a scenario do you think the truth is bound to be elusive?
answers: Take the same new york times article. Anyone who has paid serious attention to what has been happening in iraq the last seven years can see for example that the sectarian conflict was stirred up not by democracy but by the invasion and atrocities under saddam hussein. But that is not what you are going to read in papers with front page headlines saying victory for democracy.

questions: do you think the people in the west and it is now happening in india as well are giving up newspapers and turning to the internet largely because they do not believe what the newspapers say?
answers: That is true. Also because the press is owned and controlled by big business. Take say the boston globe or the new york times.

questions: so what is the solution to the fact that truth is perceived as elusive. is the internet the only way out?
answers: What has to be done is not really specific to media. It is to develop a more functional democratic culture. As far as the elites are concerned they want the public disciplined passive obedient and directed to other concerns other things.

questions: for instance the way katherine graham took risks by featuring the watergate scandal in the washington post?
answers: That illustrates the danger of living in a liberal democracy. There is nothing wrong with revealing things that you know are wrong. That is what journalism is. I mean you have to ask yourself what is the interest of the reporter.

questions: so watergate was akin to intra elite fight?
answers: It was a kind of small intra class fight that became huge. The washington post did a good thing to write about the incident but i can hardly regard it as requiring great courage or integrity.

questions: but are family owned newspapers better in comparison to the corporatisation?
answers: It is hard to choose. Take rupert murdoch. He owns a good part of the press and publishes in a small number of newspapers.

questions: do you have in mind community based ownerships or community supported media?
answers: Perhaps the period of greatest real press freedom was in the more free societies of britain and the us. There was a great variety of newspapers most often run by the factory workers ethnic communities and others who wanted to be heard. The fact that there were no restrictions on ownership or commercial exploitation of the press is a tribute to the free press.

questions: when you look at the genocide under the khmer rouge that occurred in cambodia do you put the blame on the american bombing of cambodia for creating the conditions that brought pol pot to power or is it more complex than that?
answers: First of all the bombing was major genocide. It is one of the major crimes for which nato has been condemned. The reason is simple enough to figure out. Khartoum is not Cambodia and the us did not invade in order to take over the country.

questions: can you imagine the intellectual or emotional basis for how perpetrators of mass killings are able to blithely live with themselves as instruments of mass killing?
answers: It is a good question. We can also ask similar questions about our own society which we should be well aware of. One of the striking features of american society up until the murder of osama bin laden has been the ease with which people could carry out murders.

questions: should the perpetrators of genocide in cambodia be tried and executed or imprisoned. why?
answers: I am opposed to the death penalty but i think they should receive fair trials and imprisonment. No one asks that question about nixon and kissinger or about the rich and powerful generally. The question is raised by popular struggle and it is answered in the affirmative by imprisonment or execution if the punishment is severe and the possibility of release so great that the population supports the action.

questions: do you consider yourself to be primarily a scientist or a political activist?
answers: If the world would go away i would be happy to keep to the science which is much more interesting and challenging. But the facts of the matter are that i primarily participate in political activity because the problems are significant enough to merit the involvement of a large number of people.

questions: what are your thoughts on president obama?
answers: He is involved in war crimes right now. For example targeted assassinations are a war crime. That is escalated quite sharply under the bush administration.

questions: what did you think when he was given the nobel peace prize?
answers: Considering the history of the human race it is not the worst example. It may even be the example that comes closest.

questions: is there any point in us being in afghanistan?
answers: We would not have asked in 1985 is it possible to overthrow the taliban. The question is what would be the consequences of trying. These are very serious considerations.

questions: what would you like to see happen next in afghanistan?
answers: There has to be an internal political settlement. Like it or not the warlords and the taliban are afghans so the question is what should be done. Ultimately it is a question of whether the will to live in a democratic society can be sustained.

questions: do you worry about obama is lack of experience in foreign policy?
answers: I do not think that experience is a very useful or convincing attribute for a good political leader. Henry kissinger had a lot of political experience and was able to craft some of the rhetoric of his administration.

questions: is the focus of us foreign policy right?
answers: Let is take the main focus the iranian threat. The brutal clerical regime is a threat to its own population but it is hardly unique in that respect.

questions: do you agree with that assessment?
answers: There are a lot of internal problems at the level of the language faculty but they do not appear to be fundamentally different from the problems of cognition or language development in other domains. I have not seen any serious evidence of that.

questions: what do you make of david cameron?
answers: It is too early to say much. I have not been greatly impressed by his policies or his statements. He recently identified the uk as the junior partner in the special relationship and suggested that the two countries might try to revive the informal economic relations that had ended during the kennedy years.

questions: do countries such as bolivia have lessons to teach the rest of the world?
answers: Yes. The poorest country in south america boliviana had been devastated by neoliberal economic policies. In recent years the majority population won significant battles against privatisation of water.

questions: are you optimistic about the future of the left?
answers: I do not think it makes much sense to be optimistic but there is not much point in speculating either. Either way the tasks are the same. 2 years ago i wrote an article called the end of ideology which is basically a prediction of what the outcome will be.

questions: do you vote?
answers: I tend to vote down at the lower levels local officials state representatives. Occasionally i vote for president. I did vote against ronald reagan. Pretty often i do not vote at all.

questions: what would you like to forget?
answers: There are a lot of things i regret for example the indochina war. I was deeply involved with it facing a long jail sentence. But i deeply regret that i did not get involved until the mid 1960s which was much too late.

questions: was there a plan?
answers: Well i had some general guidelines. They are so banal i hate to say them. But what is not banned is applying them in particular situations.

questions: are we all doomed?
answers: If there was an observer on mars they would probably be amazed that we have survived this long. There are two problems for our species survival nuclear war and environmental catastrophe and we are hurtling towards them. Hitler is genocide was a result of what he called our ignorant and meddlesome outsiders who are destroying the chances for decent human life.

questions: were you surprised by the way the israeli media treated your story and by the gap between that narrative and that of the international media?
answers: Yes i expected more honesty. The facts are completely clear and it is hard to believe that the media were unaware of them. There was no bureaucracy mistake and they know it.

questions: do you recognize other signs in israel is behavior that show the process of becoming a totalitarian country?
answers: It is a very complex situation. I do not think there is one simple answer. It depends on what you think is going to happen.

questions: do you think israel is democracy is in danger?
answers: If current tendencies persist the danger is real i think and for good reasons. Serious questions of democracy and human rights have been raised repeatedly in the international arena and they have not been lightly dealt with. Isis is a brutal and vicious group but it does have a legitimate claim to some of the territory it has taken over.

questions: do you find any connection between the source of thought that did not allow you to enter israel and of which caused the flotillas misfortune events?
answers: That is a very plausible hypothesis but i do not think it is ever been tested. It would be interesting to investigate.

questions: where do youu think this change comes from and where is it going to end?
answers: The changes in the past few years are striking not just in government actions but also in media and in polls.
