That is why many israelis are leaving in despair including very distinguished figures like the late amos elon dov yermiah and others who have real influence in washington and can make a difference.

questions: how do you explain the fact that israel uses over and over again the victim narrative. can we ever get over it?
answers: It drives people crazy. You can see it in polls. A large majority of the population is just totally disillusioned with everything and the media play victim all the time.

questions: do you think he is good for you as an american citizen?
answers: There are many illusions about obama. In reality he has been highly supportive of israeli crimes and expansionism. I think that is very bad news for the us. It will make it more difficult to achieve our ends in the middle east and in south africa.

questions: what is your impression from the hamas people you have talked to?
answers: I have not met anyone there yet but i hope that one day i will. The only way to meet people is to try to reach out and offer them your sympathy. If you can offer it they will take it.

questions: is there a realistic option to negotiate with hizballa hammas and the rest of the arab world?
answers: It is the only realistic approach at least if israel seeks peace and security. And it would require significant changes in the international system not least because of american vetoes. Hamas won a free election in january 2006 and they have not been quiet ever since.

questions: do you have any observations or are there any general rules concerning the existence of consensus among the elite or should media analysts approach the question on an issue by issue basis through empirical investigation?
answers: We have several observations but no rules. One observation is that elite consensus usually follows when the imperial state projects power abroad although it may erode if that power projection becomes bogged down and excessively expensive.

questions: can you say how each of these has fared over the last 20 years?
answers: What you refer to as the propaganda model is five filters requires some clarification. Ownership and advertising belong to straightforward institutional analysis these are the kinds of institutional arrangements that predominate among us media firms and elsewhere in the free world.

questions: can you explain why you adopt such a framework in your analysis?
answers: We do not confine ourselves to newspapers or official sources e. g. in our important table 2 1 on worthy and unworthy victims we have a column on cbs television news coverage and our main focus is on the media themselves as sources however they derive their own information.

questions: the propaganda model is overly ambitious and projects a total and finalizing view?
answers: It does not claim to do everything and cover every facet of news making and opinion dissemination. It only shows the main thrust in many important cases especially where elite interests are clear and strong elite opinion is unified and oppositional interests appear to be unclear and disorganized.

questions: in the post cold war world anti communism is redundant?
answers: Redundant because its counterpart free market ideology and anti terrorism and the war on terror have moved front and centre. However anti capitalism is still a force that can be mobilized to show the lesson of excessive government intervention and questioning of free markets and free trade.

questions: by deploying notions such as brainwashing under freedom propaganda and thought control the propaganda model is indeed concerned with media effects and not just media behaviour?
answers: We are certainly interested in the impact of propaganda on the public mind and it is a legitimate target of study. However our model aims primarily at the media is work and performance not the influence of the propensities and commitments of those who are paid to speak and write about the issues they are supposed to be addressing.

questions: the propaganda model is not relevant in countries outside the us which have different media and political systems?
answers: Globalization and cross border integration and the spread and increased importance of commercial advertising as a funding source have made the PR model ever more widely applicable but it has to be evaluated on a case by case basis given the varying degrees and forms of beeeep and different cultural conditions and levels of government intervention.

questions: do you have any opinions or thoughts on the following reasons put forward by mullen as to why the propaganda model and your wider work on the media has been ignored within the field of media and communication studies?
answers: Each of these has an element of truth. We are outsiders to the discipline and have brought a new and radical critique of the mainstream media into the arena. Each offers a different perspective and can be used in different ways.

questions: do you think that it is applicable to other forms of media?
answers: Yes it should apply well to television which is even more dependent on adverts than the print media often shares ownership with the latter in conglomerates and is also heavily subsidized by the taxpayer. It will also increasingly apply to the internet where the old media have a growing place and advertising has become steadily more important in the newer internet based media institutions.

questions: tackling terrorism?
answers: The lesson is that terrorism has causes unless the causes are addressed you are not facing the problem. Now a lot of it is criminal activities and criminal activity should be punished in the legal system fairly and honestly. But unless you address the grievances the problems will not be addressed.

questions: non violent resistance in iraq?

That is virtually the position of the kennedy administration and it remains so.

questions: the us approach to iran?
answers: If someone was watching this from mars they would collapse in ridicule. The united states does not care about international law or multilateral agreements. It is a one party state.

questions: israel is security problems?
answers: There are serious problems in the south. But it is worth remembering that the us did not invade in order to take over the sinai. Remember 1956 the eisenhower administration was carrying out a massive drive to destroy the progressive left in south africa in an effort to restore traditional social structures including the white regime.

questions: barack obama is burden of expectations?
answers: It is premature to talk about expectations. These are not the first or the last times these have happened. The united states has a history of extremely high expectations and then living up to them often with extreme violence.

questions: progress in south america?
answers: It is commonly said that one of the faults of bush is that he did not pay attention to latin americas. That is a serious error. In fact there is an interesting book on this by george mitchell called the third beeeep a very important book.

questions: the lack of action on climate change?
answers: It is pretty serious. Just take a look at what is happening right now in brazil which is a major emitter of greenhouse gases. They just reduced their contribution to the u. n. program by a couple of percent and i think that is going to increase sharply.

questions: the state of human rights?
answers: I do not agree with that at all. I mean i think there is a tremendous amount of progress that has been made over the last 30 or 40 years. There are a lot of areas in which it is still a long way to go and i am glad to see that the struggle against apartheid is one of them.

questions: what are you reading?
answers: I have just finished a few important books. One is ha joon chang is bad samaritans a penetrating and expert study showing how and why standard doctrines concerning economic development are dramatically refuted by the historical record and have caused severe harm when applied.

questions: what are you watching?
answers: My wife and i used to be movie addicts but are now pretty much reduced to what the grandchildren want to see. All time favorite. The one movie i sat through twice was charlie chaplin is city lights so maybe that qualifies as a childhood favorite though i have been much less into movies since).

questions: what are you listening to?
answers: If some ancient equipment could be rehabilitated i would take out some wonderful old records of axel schi tz singing schubert lieder and pablo casals playing bach solo cello suites reviving memories of more light hearted days when my wife and i backpacked through europe to the prades festival 55 years ago.

questions: would you describe the us as it is now as a fascist state?
answers: Far from it. In many respects it has the characteristics of a free democratic society much more so than other contemporary societies.

questions: you have spent a lifetime researching human intelligence and communication have you seen any sign we humans are evolving a wisdom from our experience. if so what is it?
answers: In the literal sense there has been no relevant evolution since the trek from africa. But it is a fact of human experience that whenever we do something new we look for some analogies and understand that if we can learn something about the world from it we should do it. Similar is true of language which has always been an object of study.

questions: can the curtailment of personal freedoms and the heightened fear among many western populations be compared to life in the years preceding the second world war and is it an overstatement to imagine that current events are a precursor to another global conflict?
answers: I am sceptical about such comparisons. There is a serious risk of global war but for different reasons. We should take seriously the judgement of prominent strategic analysts that a nuclear war would be a disaster for humanity very likely terminal. Less so for the survivors who will be left to contemplate the ruins.

questions: will anarchism ever be taken seriously as a political philosophy?
answers: That is up to us. If enough people think it is a mistake we can have a serious discussion about how to move towards a more just society. The question is not what i think about it or what you think of it i am afraid.

questions: do you regret mocking the accounts of refugees fleeing pol pot is cambodia?
answers: The closest approximation to this ludicrous charge is that edward herman and i cited the best informed sources at the time the nyt and the new york times had the story straight. I also cited conservative foundations studies which seemed to me credible.

questions: what do you actually think of his music. and how do you find the time to read so much?
answers: Afraid all i know about elvis is what i hear from my grandchildren. On reading you are touching a sore point. It is painful to be able to write so little about one of the most important figures in human history. Fether arafat was a symbol of palestinian nationality struggle.

questions: you like to scoff at elites. does not your position contradict your anti elitism?
answers: I do not recall scoffing at prominent figures in the arts and sciences or at martin luther king and numerous others among the elites who i respected and sometimes admired. I did of course criticise elites including japan for its treatment of women and others who were not like us in this respect and i wrote about it. That is one of the many positions i took.

questions: to what extent does the language of the piraha tribe invalidate your work on linguistics?
answers: The reports are interesting but do not bear on the work of mine. No one has proposed that languages must have subordinate clauses number words etc. Many structures of our language are rarely if ever used in ordinary speech because of extrinsic constraints such as space constraints and so on. questions: how would you describe the relationship between your academic work and your political activity?

questions: a my only regret is that i did not do it strongly enough?

questions: but is there a tension between arguing for the uniqueness of homo sapiens when it comes to language on the one hand and decrying the human role in climate change and environmental degradation on the other?

questions: could you talk about that?
answers: Here we have to be rather cautious distinguishing between language per se and speech which is an amalgam involving both language and a specific sensorimotor system used for externalization of language. The two systems are unrelated in evolutionary history the first occurring about 10 000 years ago in what is now central america and the other some thousand years later in europe.

questions: what kind of insight might birdsong offer into our own language?

questions: a poet may object to the idea that such a sentence is meaningless and a number of people have set about injecting the sentence so to speak with meaning. why do you think that is?

answers: Again very often when i do something which the state regards as illegal i regard it as legal just as i consider it legal for me to drive a car in the city. That makes perfect sense to me as a citizen.

questions: rather than thinking of the social struggle in terms of justice one has to emphasise justice in terms of the social struggle.?
answers: Yeah but surely you believe that your role in the war is a just role that you are fighting ajust war to bring in a concept from another domain. And that i think is important. If you thought you were fighting an unjust war you could not follow that line of reasoning though it is not impossible to follow it.

questions: and because it will overthrow the power of the ruling class it considers such a war to be just.?
answers: Yeah i do not agree with that. For one thing remember we are talking about a highly class conscious society. Just think about the last election.

questions: one makes war to win not because it is just.?
answers: I do not personally agree with that. For example if i could convince myself that attainment of power by the proletariat would lead to a terrorist police state in which freedom and dignity and decent human relations would be destroyed then i would not participate in it.

questions: i would like to say that the power of the proletariat could in a certain period imply violence and a prolonged war against a social class over which its triumph or victory was not yet totally assured.?
answers: Well look i am not saying there is an absolute. For example i doubt very much that russia after the revolution would have attacked eastern europe. In fact what you say about bolshevik autocracy i think is quite exaggerating.

questions: what the proletariat will achieve by expelling the class which is at present in power and by taking over power itself is precisely the suppression of the power of class in general.?
answers: Okay but that is the further justification you have for not carrying out violence. There is no need to carry it out.

questions: that is the justification but one does not speak in terms of justice but in terms of power.?
answers: But you do not think that the courts are instruments of the powerful.

questions: but it seems to me that in any case the notion of justice itself functions within a society of classes as a claim made by the oppressed class and as justification for it.?
answers: I do not agree with that. For one thing when you talk about justice you have to differentiate between what is just and what isnt just. If you say i have the right to do this i am just as guilty as you if i turn down a job offer from george bush.

questions: and in a classless society i am not sure that we would still use this notion of justice.?
answers: Well here i really disagree. I think there is some sort of an absolute basis if you press me too hard i will be in trouble because i can not sketch it out ultimately residing in fundamental human qualities in terms of which a just society can be built. That is what i mean by just.

questions: but i would say that that is unjust.?
answers: Certainly i do not think that one can make a generalization about it. Maybe it is just a particular case maybe the case for example with regard to the united states.

questions: this is an extrapolation for which i can not find the historical justification. that is the point.?
answers: It is clear.

questions: if you use such a category which has another meaning in marxist?
answers: That is why i say maybe we ought to drop the concept and move to other concepts. Like for example russian chauvinism or something like that. Let is just drop that one and come back to the others.

questions: in this situation i would like to ask another question which groups do you think will make the revolution.?
answers: Yes that is a different question. I mean the first question we should always be asking is who are you serving. Is this a question of justice or is it a power play and who is going to gain or lose from this.

questions: that is how can you with your very courageous attitude towards the war in vietnam survive in an institution like mit which is known here as one of the great war contractors and intellectual makers of this war.?
answers: Well let me answer the second question first hoping that i do not forget the first one. Oh no sure i will try the latter. Well first question i think we ought to put aside any idea that we know what the goals of our actions are. Ok so let is start with the facts.

questions: but are not you afraid that your presence at mit gives them a clean conscience.?
answers: I do not see how really. I mean i think i have been very outspoken and critical of a lot of things in the history of american society and mit is one of them. But i can not really say that i perceive it as a major flaw.

questions: and i do not see how that could be incorporated in a small technological institution.?
answers: Well i have nothing against the interaction of federated free associations and in that sense centralisation interaction communication argument debate can take place and so on and criticism if you like. What i am talking about is how they are used. If somebody wants to press some button this is a good way to do it whether it is right or wrong or constructive or destructive in any way.

questions: this logic was not only applied to those things that humans and animals do like finding food and avoiding danger but also to those things that humans do easily and animals do poorly if at all like speaking.?
answers: He is correct dramatically so with regard to radical behaviorists like skinner but pretty much across the board. A curious fact is that they did not seem to realize how remote their doctrines were from serious biology though some of the worst offenders were within the mainstream. One has to wonder at the discipline.

questions: i told him that you would be interested to know about any examples of chimps using language and he gave me a wikipedia article to forward to you on the great ape language?
answers: Thanks. I am well familiar with this work. It is an insult to chimpanzee intelligence to consider this their means of communication no matter how sophisticated or rich or whatever.

questions: what do you think when researchers to this day such as susan rumbaugh claim that bonobo chimps can draw signs and refer to it as language similar to humans ability?
answers: It is all totally meaningless so i do not participate in the debate. Humans can be taught to do a fair imitation of the complex bee communication system. Human language and human thought have a fundamental creative aspect, based on a generative aspect discarding the rules of universal grammar.

questions: there is a recent book out called nim chimpsky chronicling the project in the 1970s where researchers were trying to disprove your theory that language is exclusively a human attribute. it is an interesting read?
answers: Interesting story about poor nima. The experiment was carried out by a very serious experimental psychologist herbert terrace. A convinced skinnerian he expected that if an ape was brought up just like a normal human it would be a little human.

questions: the book nim chimpsky remarks at the fact that apes have been able to sign probably about as well as children first learning the implication being that if we call what children do language then why not have the same standard for apes and call what they do language?
answers: That is about like saying that olympic high jumpers fly better than young birds who have just come out of the egg or than most chickens. These are not serious comparisons. For whatever reason the study of human higher mental faculties is pervaded by a curious form of irrationality foreign to the sciences See chomsky comments in this vein.

questions: could you tell us how and why you decided to become an educator?
answers: I did not really decide. It just happened like many things in life. There was one big event that changed everything.

questions: could you tell us more about your notion of native speaker and native speaker competence especially in terms of its relevance to the ns nns dichotomy in english and foreign language teaching the native speaker fallacy and the discrimination and economic oppression this fallacy has resulted in?
answers: I do not understand why i am mentioned at all in this connection. The linguistic authority and intrinsic superiority of the american language was a truism long before i became a college student. If i recall correctly it was an uncontroversial notion at the time and one that continues to be so to this day (though officially rejected as racist and colonialist).

questions: what do you see as the connection between theoretical and applied linguistics and in particular with the sub area of applied linguistics non native teacher issues?
answers: I think there is a very significant connection. Teachers are usually Non native. In the case of indigenous communities very substantial efforts have been made to provide native speakers the educational opportunities that would enable them to become teachers develop educational and cultural programs in their own communities reviving traditional ways of life and so on. Not just in america but all over the world if you look.

questions: what suggestion would you give to scholars and graduate students who want to study political issues such as non native teacher issues and also to ordinary esl teachers like myself who want to understand the significance of such issues to our teaching our profession and our esl departments personnel and hiring committees decisions?
answers: I do not understand what the problem is. The important issues seem to me those i mentioned above. If i understood them well enough to be able to give a reasonable proposal as to what we should do i think it would be appropriate to discuss them. Whether we can or not depends on the level of understanding and commitment.

questions: how do you see these two approaches to language in relation to work in the area of language teaching and learning?
answers: Halliday and others apparently see a conflict between those approaches. I have never seen any. My own work and that of my colleagues is both formal and functional linguistics.

questions: how do you evaluate the use of this term in these contexts?
answers: It should be used where it is relevant. Again i do not understand the issue.

questions: what are your views on the use of native speaker intuitions in language descriptions that are used in language teaching learning?
answers: If someone is interested in spanish they will not use me as an informant because i am not a speaker. It is quite true that i do not know spain very well and would not be able to give an opinion if i did.

questions: entry of english in multilingual countries is gradually and systematically eliminating smaller local languages. please comment on the hegemony of english?
answers: That is true and it is one aspect of a much broader development. Imposition of the nation state system in europe for example has led to rapid disappearance of languages a process still continuing. The spread of English reflects obvious power relations between the imperial power and the local language community.

questions: does your universal grammar theory draw on the work of karl jung. thank you?
answers: I have occasionally mentioned some rather loose analogies nothing that has been confirmed. But there is no doubt that the basic ideas are very much like the kaum rewitt theories and there are quite a few of them.

questions: chomsky. info 20110204 2?
answers: This is the most remarkable regional uprising that i can remember nothing remotely like it has taken place. I mean it is hard to think of a more remarkable development. For one thing in the middle east nobody even dreamed of that happening except the us and britain which are both extremely frightened and jingoist and both of them basically rely on us power for their survival.

questions: would have any say here when it comes to how much it has supported the regime?
answers: Well obama very carefully did not say anything. Mubarak would agree that there should be an orderly transition but to what. A new cabinet some minor rearrangement of the constitutional order it is empty.

questions: what are the implications of this the uprising from tunisia to egypt now?
answers: Well this is the most remarkable regional uprising that i can remember. I mean it is sometimes compared with eastern europe but that is not much of a comparison. For one thing in this case there is no counterpart to gorbachev among the in the united states or other great powers supporting the dictatorships rather clandestinely.

questions: ten seconds in the segment noam?
answers: Pardon.

questions: make your point on eisenhower?
answers: Yeah shall i go on. See you tomorrow.

questions: noam chomsky you were just talking about the significance of what is happening in the middle east and you were bringing it back to president dwight eisenhower?
answers: Well in 1958 president eishower this is in internal discussions since declassified Eisenhower expressed his concern for what he called the campaign of hatred against us in arab world not by governments but by people. Remember 1958 this was a rather striking moment.

questions: noam chomsky with us on the phone from his home near boston noam continue with the significance of what eisenhower was saying and what the times were there and what they have to teach us today about this middle east uprising?
answers: Yeah the military industrial complex speech the famous one was after what i have just been talking about. That was as he was leaving office and a important speech of course. Needless to say the situation he described not only persists but indeed has amplified in significance. Thanks very much.

questions: president who held out his hand to the islamic world and then clenched his fist when it fought a dictatorship and demanded democracy. noam chomsky your response?
answers: Well fisk is reporting as usual has been inspiring and phenomenal. And yeah he is exactly right. It is the old pattern in many ways but the pattern is very familiar and it has continued well that is what we have been through since the collapse of the soviet union about ten years ago.

questions: but also the documents that came out on tunisia confirming the u. s. do you think there is a direct relationship?
answers: Well actually the fact of the matter is that wikileaks are not really telling us anything dramatically new. They are providing confirmation often of reasonable surmises many of them based on decades of research and understanding of state policy. Tunisaia was a very interesting case.

questions: he is a former jordanian diplomat?
answers: Formerjeremiah wright. Formerly at mit. And then at yasser arafat learned at the university of flyrib in israel. So he has diplomatic service under the administrations of washington and iraq.

questions: what about what is happening now in jordan what you think is going to happen and also in saudi arabia how much it drives this and what you feel obama needs to do and what you think he actually is doing?
answers: I have been following this closely. The president is almost certainly aware of the plans being made public but he does not seem to be making any moves to implement them. As you know better than i the military is being mobilized to conduct large scale terror and economic warfare against the population in the west bank in cooperation with the israeli interior ministry and the us treasury department.

questions: an israeli palestinian peace agreement is nowhere in sight.?
answers: Your reply illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. You are certainly entitled to this opinion but merely asserted it cannot carry any conviction. I am sorry that you do not see that your comment does not address the issue.

questions: noam there is a sign a big banner that people are holding in the square in tahrir that says yes we can too.?
answers: Let is what. I am sorry i did not get a chance to see the banner. But i i do not think it is that big.

questions: the banner says yes we can too.?
answers: Let is do it. Yeah. You know where they got that from. I do not see it but they said that.

questions: if you were president today what would you do right now president of the united states?
answers: Well if i were if I had made it to the presidency meaning with the kind of constituency and support that is required to be a president in this country i would probably do what obama is doing. But what should i do.

questions: but these corporations that have made such a killing off the repression where are they standing right now in terms of u. s. policy?
answers: Well they do not issue press releases so we have to speculate. But it is pretty obvious that they have a major stake in the dictatorships not just egypt.

questions: access to their air space he guarantees access to the suez canal. talk about that and what the change would mean?
answers: We should actually go back a little further. In 1971 president sadat of egypt offered israel a full peace treaty in return for withdrawal from the occupied territories. He cared about the sinai not so much but ismail haniyeh and a whole series of other people were offered the opportunity to join the us at the very same time they were rejecting it.

questions: but what about what these mass protests mean for people in the united states?
answers: I think they mean a lot and i have been trying to hint about that. The doctrine that everything is fine as long as the population is quiet that applies throughout the cold war period applies to the us invasion of iraq and the occupation of palestine now it is applied to venezuela.

questions: the current focus is on isis. what about isis and its origins?
answers: There is an interesting interview that just appeared a couple of days ago with graham fuller a former cia officer one of the leading intelligence and mainstream analysts of this century. The title is the united states created terrorism. This is one aspect of a much broader story which you will find if you look.

questions: jaws should have been dropping all over the place but there was virtual silence in the commentary the next day?
answers: The somalia case is particularly horrendous. Yemen is bad enough. Somali tradition is deeply rooted and carries over to the burmese junta which is worse.

questions: do you remember the jimmy carter comment about vietnam?
answers: Not only do i remember it i think i was the first person to comment on it and am probably to date practically the only person who has. Carter the human rights advocate he was asked in a press conference in 1977 a kind of mild question do we have any responsibility for what is happening in vientnam.

questions: you have some information about the charter and its background?
answers: Thanks. I am well familiar with it. The foundation of israel is an interesting case.

questions: even elizabeth warren the highly touted democratic senator from massachusetts voted for this resolution about self defense?
answers: She probably knows nothing about the middle east. I think it is pretty obvious. Take the us prepositioning arms in israel for us use for military action in the region and presumably also for economic warfare.

questions: they have been supporting the kurds rather clandestinely but it is well known that israel has been pushing for fragmentation of iraq?
answers: Along with the us. And there is good reason. They do not want to leave what they call the graveyard of the prophets which is an arab city and they need it for their chemical weapons stockpile and all sorts of other stuff.

questions: i ask you you have got grandchildren. what kind of world do you see them inheriting.?
answers: The world that we are creating for our grandchildren is grim. The major concern ought to be the one that was brought up in new york at the september 21 march. A couple hundred thousand people turned out.

questions: chomsky. info 20101130?
answers: Wikileaks cables reveal profound hatred for democracy on the part of our political leadership noam Chomsky interviewed by amy goodmandemocracy now. May 16 2013. aa ar why do you say the idea of a liberal media is a mirage.

questions: before we talk about wikileaks what was your involvement in the pentagon papers. i do not think most people know about this?
answers: Dan and i were friends. Tony russo who also who prepared them and helped leak them. Edward herman who did the research and preparation and also leaked them to the press.

questions: involvement in vietnam history out of his safe he xerox is it and then how did you get your hands on it. he just directly gave it to you?
answers: From dan ellsberg and tony russo who had done the xing and the so forth from the pentagon in the early 1960s. I was working on the kennedy papers at the time.

questions: how much did you edit?
answers: Well we did not modify anything. The papers were not edited. They were in their original form.

questions: so you were then one of the first people to see the pentagon papers?
answers: Outside of dan ellsberg and tony russo yes. I mean there were some journalists who may have seen them i am not sure. Maybe they did not see them but people who did were very impressed.

questions: for example we just played this clip of new york republican congress member peter king who says wikileaks should be declared a foreign terrorist organization?
answers: I think that is outlandish. We should understand and the pentagon papers is another case in point that one of the major reasons for government secrecy is to protect the government from its own population. In the case of daniel ellsberg and i there was nothing to hide.

questions: that was secretary to hillary clinton yesterday at a news conference. s. to attack iran. noam chomsky?
answers: This is the most remarkable pronouncement of all time by a sitting president. The world is laughing. And it is not just the united states.

questions: and the latest report that just came out from oxfam from amnesty international and other groups about the effects of the siege on gaza. what is happening right now?
answers: A siege is an act of war. If anyone insists on that it is israel. Has there ever been a situation where there was a unilateral cease fire and armed attack was launched against a country. No there has never been and there is not likely to be any situation soon because the current situation is so extremely dangerous.

questions: the cable demands biographical financial by metric information on key pa and hamas leaders and representatives to include the young guard inside gaza the west bank and outside it says?
answers: That should not come as much of a surprise. Contrary to the image that is portrayed here the united states is not an honest broker. It is a participant a direct and crucial participant in israeli crimes both at the security and political levels.

questions: what do you think the united states should do in this case?
answers: I think it should join the world. I mean there are negotiations going on supposedly. For example there is a conference of the G77 group of industrial countries which is led by saudi arabia a major producer of oil and they are trying to reach an agreement on some kind of joint development model for the region.

questions: why was he not pursued with the same urgency we pursue al qaeda and taliban leaders. noam chomsky your response?
answers: That is pretty much what i would expect sarah palin to say. I do not know how much she understands but i think we should pay attention to what we learn from the leaks. What they tell us is kind of a preliminary stage.

questions: back to the midterm elections and what we are going to see now. can you talk about the tea party movement?
answers: It is a movement that has grown out of the economic crisis. A lot of people have been hurt by the crash and they did not have many options. The government can not do much because the population does not want it.

questions: i wanted ask if you were president obama is top adviser what would you tell him to do right now?
answers: Listen i have plenty of correspondence with him and with other high officials of the us government and i think that what they should do is what john kennedy did when he was in the position that obamas is in. He said if there are terrorist attacks in libya that is a reason why the united states has to act and take action.

questions: noam you were continuing your prescription your advice that you would give to president obama today?
answers: Well the economy is a disaster. There is 10 official unemployment probably twice that much actual unemployment. Many people unemployed for years this is an enormous human tragedy but it is also an economic tragedy because people cannot find the jobs.

questions: what do you think of the global climate change summit that is taking place in cancun?
answers: Well the copenhagen summit was a disaster nothing happened. In fact this one last year podemos revived it and they were barely represented. But in central america which is a much more important country it did get a mention which was pretty impressive.

questions: he said recently we are going to want to have a do over?
answers: Yes. That is part of the massive offensive basically a corporate offensive and they have not been quite about it. The chamber of commerce the biggest business lobby american petroleum institute and others have said quite publicly that they are carrying out a massive educational campaign to convince the population that global warming is not real.

questions: i would like to switch gears for a minute noam chomsky and talk about the elections in haiti that just took place?
answers: Elections you should put in quotation marks. If we had elections here in the united states in which the democratic and republican parties were barred and their political leaders were exiled to south africa and not allowed to return here to participate in elections that would not be an election.

questions: government would not say publicly that the coup against manuel zelaya was outright illegal. your response noam chomsky?
answers: That is right. This is an analysis by the embassy in honduras tegucigalpa saying that they have done a careful analysis of the legal and constitutional backgrounds and conclude you can read their summary which is in the conclusion that there is no doubt that overthrowing the government was an illegal act. The united states as you point out would never say that.

questions: the wikileaks documents show chinese diplomats saying that chinese officials increasingly doubt the usefulness of neighboring north korea and would support reunification. the significance of this?
answers: I am very skeptical about that statement particularly because north Korea is regarded as the most serious and violent country in the region.

questions: as someone who has advocated written about and worked for progressive causes for many years what was your reaction to obama is victory on election day?
answers: I was pleased that he won. A mccain victory could i think have been extremely dangerous and the fact that a black family will be in the white house is a matter of considerable significance.

questions: in what ways do you believe an obama presidency will help and or hurt progressive causes in the united states?
answers: I presume that some of the harsher edges of recent policies will be smoothed as has already happened to an extent during the second bush administration in its early months in office.

questions: in what ways do you believe that obama represents true change. in what ways does he not represent change?
answers: With the rhetorical flourishes and style of presenting himself as more or less like a familiar centrist democrat the president has succeeded in presenting a somewhat caricature of the bipartisanship that has dominated american foreign policy for many years. His early appointments and advisers conform to this judgment.

questions: what if anything are progressives doing now to mobilize in response to an obama presidency?
answers: In the wake of the election it is worth recalling how little popular support obamas attracted among the general population. A recent national poll found that only about 20 percent approved of his performance and that his approval ratings were well below those of a president or other high office holders.

questions: do you think this kind of spying will face any kind of overhaul or will nations continue to conduct international eavesdropping in an unscathed and even romanticised manner?
answers: The revelations certainly have created an outcry. Thus in its jan 1 lead editorial the new york times editors wrote that thanks to mr snowden is courageous and honourable actions the public learned in great detail how the has exceeded its mandate and abused its authority prompting outrage at kitchen tables and at the desks of congress which may finally begin to limit these practices once and for all.

questions: how high of a priority do you think it is for the us government to find a way to prosecute mr snowden?
answers: One of the leading principles of international affairs much too little recognised is what may be called the mafia doctrine. The godfather does not tolerate disobedience. It gives him fits.

questions: do you see unholy alliances between government and private sector that tend to become anti citizen or develop a life of their own such as president eisenhower warned as he left office?
answers: It is not often stressed that the government is in the business of controlling the public mind. That is true of the military as well. The major concern during the cold war was what they called the national security threat to the united states from the russians who were trying to strangle it.

questions: has the us become more civilised or more anti citizen or both?
answers: It is a mixed story. There have been some changes. For example the rise of the nsa is very significant.

questions: can you sum up the best way you think for citizens to be involved in rather than be subject to the whims of the government of the day?
answers: I am in no position to give advice or to legislate to others. Each of us has our own concerns priorities capacities moral and political judgments. We each have to find our place within a system of power and domination.

questions: how did you first become aware of the catonsville nine action or the members of that action?
answers: Well i knew some of them but life was so hot and heavy in those days i can not really remember when i first learned of it. Whether it was before hand or when it took place.

questions: had you known particular members of the action?
answers: Some of them yeah. Cause we were involved in lots of similar things. Related to the vietnam war a lot of things came out of that which i think are significant even though it was a separate action.

questions: are you were you familiar with their experiences?
answers: Yeah. In fact they have written about it. The melvilles. [inaudible] them is the place where it all began.

questions: and did you find it difficult to do as someone working in academia?
answers: I began too late. That is one thing i am sorry about.

questions: to what extent do you believe actions like the catonsville nine legitimized the antiwar movement or even helped to end the war?
answers: It was a very courageous action. Civil disobedience is a tactic it is not a principal. And the point of the tactic is i think at least is to encourage others to move a little farther.

questions: i guess what i am really asking is is there a danger of becoming a celebrity of the left?
answers: Well you know it is kind of inevitable in a pressurized environment that people will be picked out and identified as leaders but yeah it can be a negative factor. I have had plenty of experience with that and i do not think it should be.

questions: what can americans concerned about the wars in iraq and afghanistan learn from the baltimore four and catonsville nine?
answers: The one thing they can learn is how much those actions civilized the country. Opposition to aggression is far higher now than it was in the 1970s. I mean you constantly read that there is no protest over iran like there was over vietnam ii but that is got to be a mirage because the scale is just mind boggling.

questions: do you see such lobbying by large technology companies translating into a more open and free internet and eventually into a more meaningful commons?
answers: The internet since it is publicly created ought to be publicly controlled. After all the first internet was publicly funded. That is the model we have to follow if we hope to have a truly democratic internet.

questions: what are your thoughts one how existing or new government policies laws and regulations promote or limit technological innovations that increase the exercise of first amendment freedoms?
answers: Technology provides means for expression and interchange and so on so yes it should be free and open but there are a lot of constraints on how its used. We should not want to permit providers for example to have control over access. Again that is a case for more regulation.

questions: so you see this as something similar to what you described as following the propaganda model in mass media?
answers: The similarity is that concentration of capital influences virtually everything that goes on. It influences the way the media functions it very powerfully influences how the government works and it of course influences corporate sector elements like say how google or amazon present materials that reach the public.

questions: do you think the hostility to wikileaks comes from specific materials being revealed or a more general fear of new forms of communication that cannot be controlled by law or force?
answers: Its just hatred of democracy. Long before the technology revolution there was declassification of documents and i have spent quite a lot of time studying declassified internal planning and communication. In fact anybody who is worked through the internal record can see very clearly that the reason for classification is very rarely to protect the state or the society from enemies.

questions: so the kind of content that wikileaks revealed is different to what the pentagon papers revealed?
answers: Totally different. In fact there were changes.

questions: but the medium is different and you were involved in publishing it in print format?
answers: Yes and also i had them in advance. Actually when dan ellsberg was underground i was one of the people there were a number of people who were giving out materials to the press. This was in the early eighties i am sure.

questions: but wikileaks happened through the internet which was not really anticipated then?
answers: Not it wasn't then nobody was doing it. Just take a look at the trajectory of things. The first thing that comes to mind is of course the pentagon papers.

questions: do you see a difference in the way they were distributed and that itself being more of a threat?
answers: Yeah its different but i think its basically the same threat. The threat is that the public will know what the government is up to. Any system of power is going to want to keep free from public surveillance that is natural.

questions: can you say something about why technology companies that advocate non censorship such as google in china but do not support those like julian assange?
answers: Its worst than that. They help shut down the site. Every day. Go back to jan 1 st. for example if you look at the first few days of his site is first page it is not even displayed.

questions: compared to mass media in the united states which you have stated as serving the interest of the elite do you see the internet playing a role in promoting minority rights and majority role?
answers: Like most technological innovations the Internet has mixed effects. It is a neutral instrument. Technology can be used to liberate or enslave and there are many illustrations of that today.

questions: its been argued that the internet is a paradigm shift and able to work as a kind of technology unlike anything before it?
answers: It is different of course. Just take ease of interchange between people. Your email can be read by people from around the world in fact faster than letter on the other hand the transition from sailing ship to telegraphs was far greater than the shift from the postal service to email which was almost instantaneous.

questions: it has the ability to connect everyone to everyone else?
answers: Superficially. Very superfically. So take social media take a look at the way they are used.

questions: facebook is is encouraging organ donations by allowing users to reveal their organ donation status?
answers: That is a good step. Allowing people to be more open and transparent is good. Keeping donations secret is even better.

questions: what are your thoughts on companies that started as a communications medium openly entering domains that are traditionally of activism or government?
answers: Well my own feeling is that a corporation has no right to have a political or social influence. Why should it. I happen to agree with the anti dictatorship policies but i do not think it is the role of general electric to support them or oppose them i think the public should make its own decisions about these matters.

questions: other than the fact that they are corporations what do you see as the similarities and differences between a corporation like google and general electric?
answers: Well there are differences. There is a lot more planning going on here. They have a product. Some do not.

questions: i think a lot of silicon valley companies do see themselves as different in terms of decentralization of power or amplification of people is voices that did not exist before?
answers: Its true that contemporary technology makes it easier to do it all the time but its kind of like asking how do we make the railroads more efficient. The same is true of the internet. It is more difficult to make changes in the old fashion industries than to move into the new fashion ones.

questions: so you think this hope put on internet as an empowering machine is false?
answers: No its not false the same hope is true for the printing press. The levellers in england in the seventeenth century printed their pamphlets at the risk of destruction and they had to rely on the internet to distribute them. Same idea with the print press which relied on public support.

questions: lastly i want to ask you can you tall about free association as you have talked about it in relation to how individuals associate on the internet today?
answers: Same mixed story. A lot of association is highly constructive. There are people interacting interchanging ideas making plans coordinating activities take any of the popular movements a whole range of things.

questions: so you are saying that this trial is not about justice?
answers: There is an element that the court accepted and that i think is important. It is about the role of the state in this a sort of a back channel negotiation between the united states and israel. That is something that should not be lightly undertaken.

questions: you were heavily criticised for some of your views of the kr and some accused you of being favourable to the kr. were you unfairly criticised?
answers: It is ridiculous in fact there has been a massive critique of some things that edward herman and i wrote and my view is that they were some parts of a very flawed ideology which should be avoided. I did not write them and she did but they are ideas that have been influential in trying to understand how institutions function.

questions: should cambodia be embracing this or do you back a boycott of israeli trade and investment?
answers: It is the same moral issue that arises all the time even with the trials. I mean yes is there a difference between democratically elected heads of state like george bush or prime ministers like paul wolfowitz and their cabinet colleagues. Yes they have a different set of legal and constitutional options but the choice of action or inaction is always thesame.

questions: why were you able to look the other way with the vietnamese?
answers: I did not defend it i criticised it. If you look at that same book that herman and i wrote in 1979 it criticises the invasion. It is not a very harsh criticism because it did have a quite positive consequence it got rid of the kr and if that is the goal we can live with that.

questions: what do you think the obama administration is up against with the economic crisis. how bad do you think it will get?
answers: Nobody really knows a lot of the sophisticaled money managers think maybe it may level off by the fall and start recovering. On the other hand there are sensible economists that think something much worse is likely. And it is getting worse and worse.

questions: you grew up in a home that was heavily influenced by ahad ha am the father of cultural zionism?
answers: My father was a great sympathizer and a very good listener. Every friday night we would read hebrew together and often the reading was ahadeeth the prophet is comments on it. He was the founding figure of what came to be called cultural Zionism meaning that there should be a cultural center in israel in palestine a state religion.

questions: did you read nivi im the prophets with your father in hebrew?
answers: The word prophet is a very bad translation of an obscure hebraic word navi. Nobody knows what it means. But today they would be called dissident intellectuals.

questions: did you imagine yourself as a navi a prophet when you were a child reading those texts alone in your room or on friday night with your father?
answers: Sure. In fact my favorite prophet then and still is amos. I particularly admired his comments that he is not an intellectual but rather an emotional person who speaks from the heart of the matter.

questions: at the age of 10 i came to the conclusion that the god i learned about in school did not exist?
answers: I remember how i did that. My father is family was super orthodox. They would not let me look at television or read except in the morning.

questions: and what did your father say?
answers: I was just thinking about that. He just quoted the line to me and then explained he thinks he has been hearing this same thing for years.

questions: did something interest you about the structure of the language or was it just available to you as the language in your home?
answers: It appeared to be part of a larger system which also included sign language and a number of other systems. I was not particularly impressed by the systems that appeared. They seemed to me largely superficial and artificial.

questions: you returned to hebrew for your college thesis?
answers: When i got to college i had to do an undergraduate thesis. I was in linguistics then so i figured ok i will write about egypt. It is kind of interesting but the thesis was about the rise of israel as the leading democracy in the land mass.

questions: so your theory of generative grammar in its early stages came out of your study of medieval hebrew and arabic?
answers: Yes. When i was maybe 10 or 11 years old i began to learn the basic rules of the language that is to say how the letters on a telephone keypad are generated. These were not written in an elaborate system of notes and calculations but rather on the spot.

questions: when you were refused entry to the west bank recently by the israeli interior ministry did you talk hebrew to the people who sent you back to jordan?
answers: I could have but i did not. I have done it before at security. Back in the 1980s i attended a conference in jerusalem and on the way out of the country you have to go through a security system.

questions: were there any gentiles in your parents world?
answers: Practically not. In fact there were not even yiddish speaking jews. They lived in if not a physical ghetto then in a cultural ghetto.

questions: describe mikveh israel the synagogue that you grew up in and where your father first taught?
answers: Well my father was a very interesting person. He was born in what is now india and came to the united states as a young child with his family. They were so religious that when they got to high school they had to go to synagogue every Sunday because the school was being closed for the Sabbath so the family would have a place to stay.

questions: did your mother also come from a religious family?
answers: She came to america with her family when she was 1 year old. They were so religious that she told me that when her father was killed in a fighting unit during the british civil war her mother took him to the mosque and told the mourners that he was there to rest in peace. That is how old she is actually.

questions: was that what motivated you to live in israel?
answers: My wife and i were there in 53. we lived in a kibbutz for a while and planned to stay actually. I came back and had to finish my ph. Japan was closing down so we decided to come back.

questions: was it the idea of the kibbutz or was it the fact of speaking hebrew or what was it?
answers: It was political. I happened to be in philadelphia at the time and was able to see the beginnings of what became a hebraic revival and i was interested in joining but was turned down because i am a jewish atheist and that is not a lot of places. So i turned to linguistics which was much easier since there was no religious persecution there.

questions: when you think of the motivations of people like your parents or the people who founded those mapam kibbutzim you do not think of those motivations as being inherently linked to some desire to oppress others?
answers: By then i was old enough to separate from my parents. I would been on my own intellectually since i Was a teenager. Most of my life was spent with my father in his study in israel in a yesh gvul which was then very close to where i grew up.

questions: my father grew up in hashomer?
answers: I could never join hashomed because in those days they were split between stalinist and trotskyite and i was anti leninist. But that is not much of a problem for me. In fact i would like to say that my views on politics and society are pretty much the same as those of the vast majority of americans.

questions: hezbollah is not an outfit dedicated to the secular model of human freedom that you support. what were you doing there?
answers: Notice this does not refer to my support for israeli crimes. That is a different matter. I do not recall having expressed any support whatsoever for the organization that runs it is terrorist army which is also engaged in ethnic cleansing in lebanon.

questions: that is why i was asking. why were you there?
answers: I did not go. I mean she went through the whole trial and the sentencing phase without going through any of it.

questions: he is a great talker?
answers: You have met him. I have talked to him several times. One of the most interesting moments in recent history was when he stopped ranting and began to give a measured response to the september 11 terrorist attacks.

questions: hezbollah is not the majority party in lebanon?
answers: It is part of a coalition. They won the last election with 53 percent of the vote. Because of method of distributing seats they do not get the power to call their own parliament.

questions: hezbollah is a highly militarized organization that runs south lebanon in a way that is hardly reflective of secular democratic ideals?
answers: It is interesting that secular Lebanese would not take that attitude.

questions: they believe that the iranians are trying to rip up their state?
answers: Ultra right wing lebanese think that. But the person who organized my trip was fawwaz trabulsi the leading figure in the secular left. And he insisted we go through hezbollah and see for ourselves that it is not a front for us.

questions: the first was the introduction you wrote to a book by robert faurisson who became notorious for writing two letters to le monde denying that the gas chambers existed and claiming that the suggestion that they did exist was part of a jewish plot or hoax?
answers: No i did not actually that is more propaganda. Are you asking why i would ever support that. In fact i am pretty much the opposite.

questions: freedom of speech is one thing. denial?
answers: The worst kind of freedom is denial of reality. So take the holocaust again. Did nicaragua have the right to set off bombs in washington and london.

questions: alan dershowitz is critique of your engagement with faurisson centered around your use of the word findings which he said implied that you believed that faurisson is claims had some historical grounding?
answers: But that is just childish. I can talk about stalin and say he presented his findings or the ku klux beeeep. There is no such thing as a research project in the sciences.

questions: american imperial policy in the middle east is shaped by the whims of a small coterie of jews. where does this stuff come from?
answers: It is very simple. Did you ever study international relations.

questions: you have that very interesting remark at the end of your response where you describe the motivation behind their assertions as stemming from the desire to salvage the wilsonian idea of american innocence?
answers: They are not trying consciously but it is a convenient slogan. If you want to be part of the intellectual class then you are in favor of atrocities. There is no other way to say it.

questions: another comment that you had about walt and mearsheimer is argument was well who says this has not worked?
answers: It worked great. I think the same criticism holds of other critiques of american policy. Take say the blowback theories.

questions: you understand the state of israel as having some independent existence coming from jewish culture and history aside from simply being an american imperial vessel?
answers: It did not become an empire if that is the right term until after 67. that was a choice.

questions: it is possible for you to imagine a state of israel that did not act as an extension of american power. but is it too late?
answers: No. I do not think so. It gets harder as time goes on and more information comes out and so on.

questions: i have come to the idea that part of the outrage about israeli abuses has an underlying unconscious purpose of obscuring even grosser abuses that america commits directly as a matter of state policy?
answers: That they are killing afghans is the least of it. How about invading iraq and destroying it killing hundreds of thousands of people driving millions into exile. Driving the palestinians even deeper into oblivion.

questions: when you speak about israeli crimes do you feel that you have a special responsibility to speak out as someone who comes from a specific jewish tradition or do you simply speak as an american?
answers: There are many factors as always. A sufficient factor is that the united states is responsible. But of course there is a lot else as well.

questions: those additional things namely your parents your childhood memories your sense of emotional connection?
answers: It is all there. You can not get out of your skin. But when we get down to the moral issue there is a very striking difference. In some respects the society 60s is much more civilized than it was 40s and the 50s because it recognizes what it has been doing.

questions: would you briefly elaborate on these points?
answers: Let is grant that there is a drug problem for the sake of argument drugs meaning you know cocaine marijuana and so on. Suppose you accept that. How do you deal with it within the society.

questions: can you explain how that got started and how it still works today?
answers: The best source on this is alfred mccoy is the politics of heroin. He traces it back to early postwar europe post world war ii where a prime concern of washington was to undermine the antifascist resistance and the labor movements in italy france and germany in order to restore traditional social structures including fascist collaborators.

questions: could you tell us about the connection between the drug cartels and the large institutional banks?
answers: Money laundering commonly goes through banks which pretend not to know about it. The scale is estimated to be huge.

questions: could you point out how your views on drugs and the drug war tie into that?
answers: It is pretty straightforward. I happen to be an anti drug activist and an extremely harsh critic of the criminalization of drugs. So for example when i am driving i sometimes turn on the radio and i find very often that what is being discussed is a discussion of whether to legalize heroin which is about twice as strong as cocaine and far more dangerous.

questions: recently libertarians such as ron paul have courted marijuana users on the basis that they oppose the drug war. why do you oppose them?
answers: What is called libertarianism in the united states is a significant deviation from traditional libertarian thought. Traditionally say in europe libertarian meant the anti state wing of the socialist party. In modern times libertarian has been a term of abuse to describe those who are committed to dismantling the coercive institutions of our society.

questions: hightimes readers more likely see him as the man who started the modern war on drugs. could you explain?
answers: Nixon did a lot of rotten things much worse than starting the present war but the same is true of other liberal presidents. His liberal initiatives included the occupational safety and health administration the environmental protection agency the earned income tax credit and much else. No president in modern history has passed such liberal programs.

questions: lastly hightimes readers may be curious if you have ever tried marijuana?
answers: No never even i am very conventional.

questions: could we now begin to hope that the south is awake?
answers: What is happening is something completely new in the history of the hemisphere. Since the spanish conquest the countries of latin america have been pretty much separated from one another and oriented toward the imperial power. There are also very sharp splits between the tiny wealthy elite and the huge misery and misery caused by years of brutalization by the neo liberal programs.

questions: would you see cuba as being a key player in encouraging and perhaps influencing what is coming out of latin america right now?
answers: Fidel castro whatever people may think of him is a hero in latinian society primarily because he stood up to the united states. It is the first time in the history of the hemisphere that anybody sat down and talked to congress and told them what you ought to do.

questions: what gives us more hope about this particular stage of liberation for latin america?
answers: First of all there was hope a little over a year ago in florida but it was crushed by violence. Chile was moving on a path towards some form of democratic socialism but we know what happened.

questions: why do you think the us went to war against iraq?
answers: No one knows. Iran has the second largest oil reserves in the world it is right at the heart of the middle east region which is the main source of petroleum for the western world. And the reasons go back hundreds of years actually adam smith talked about this in his introduction to the new edition of animal farm.

questions: was the euphoria misplaced. where and when did things go wrong?
answers: There never should have been hopes for a linear trajectory. The arab spring was a development of historic importance threatening many powerful interests. Power does not say thank you for dismantling us then walking quietly away. This is the 25th anniversary of the oslo accord there are many questions to think about but one fact is for sure it did have effects.

questions: western reactions have ranged from military intervention to a hands off approach as seen in the gulf states. do you see an underlying pattern here?
answers: There is a general pattern which goes back to the origins of imperialism. When the united states was founded as a protectorate of the pope it had to make a decision. Did it want to be a world power or a colony and a virtual colony. This decision has deep roots going way back.

questions: do you see a way this dichotomy can be dealt with constructively. what role should western governments play?
answers: Neither history nor logic nor policy analysis nor any other source apart from propaganda gives us any reason to expect power systems to play a constructive role unless it happens to be in their interest. That is true of western systems as a special case particularly since the collapse of the soviet union 40 years ago.

questions: uh what is the uh well i will let you complete the sentence. noam?
answers: Well there is a <

questions: s. have you ever thought about becoming a politician yourself?
answers: No. First of all i would be terrible at it. I will just give you one simple example: how should i vote in the next election? Well i should probably vote for obama.

questions: does it also have something to do with your beliefs about how the political system actually works?
answers: I do not criticize people in private who are inside the ideological system. But i think i can do more elsewhere. Usually the system responds to popular activism much as it did in the case of vietnam and the 1960s when i was involved.

questions: the social movement of the day camps at public spaces and calls itself occupy. what do you think has occupy achieved so far?
answers: It achieved a lot in two aspects. It very significantly affected public sensibility and public discourse. The imagery that is spread over right through the mainstream that occupy uses is a very dangerous one.

questions: and the second aspect?
answers: The occupy movement spontaneously created communities of mutual support mutual aid. The common kitchen the libraries. These are maybe even more important. Not just in my opinion but also in the general american experience.

questions: if you compare it to the tea party movement?
answers: There is a difference. The nazis were not calling for genocide. But the turkish nationalists did and the catholics did not exactly agree with it but they got together and called for it.

questions: the tea party succeeded in sending dozens of their supporters to the senate and to the congress. in this way they are effective?
answers: As long as they can be the storm troopers for the corporate sector they will succeed. The republicans mobilize them like the religious right they have to. These are people who have been trained to hate government and everything it stands for they do not have any respect for it.

questions: because of their irrationality?
answers: Yes take a look at german history. In the early days of the nazis the business community the industrialists they supported them. They were the ones who did smash up the unions and who went after the left and so on because they thought that was their best hope of controlling the population. See what happened.

questions: and european answer to the financial and the so called euro crisis?
answers: The u. s. reaction has been somewhat better than the in some respects of the brexit vote in greece. The united states has somewhat limited control over the euro area treasury department has issued statements indicating that it will allow some degree of flexibility in the budget but only under certain conditions.

questions: but he also said that the fiscal pact has to be backed by a growth pact?
answers: Finally they are talking about what should have been done in the first place. There are plenty of resources in europe to carry out stimulation of demand and so on. But the idea of imposing austerity under recession is a recipe for suicide.

questions: why do you think that this is the intention?
answers: Just look at the people who are designing the policies. They never liked the welfare state they thought it was a welfare queen. Europe was an island of relative civilized life style perfectly capable of supporting a large scale industrial economy.

questions: the rationale that german chancellor angela merkel puts forward is that we have a debt crisis and in times of debt you have got to cut spending?
answers: In the eurozone in particular there has been a tendency under the leadership of merkels to go back to the gold standard. The Bundesbank has gone even further andQ has said that under no circumstances can the european union be considered a debtor nation.

questions: do you think countries like greece should have defaulted?
answers: Greece has some serious internal problems. They just did not collect tax the rich were undisciplined and there is too much bureaucracy. But the debt is a dual responsibility.

questions: but there always has to be some enforcement or guarantee that the debts are paid back?
answers: Not in capitalism. But in real life it is your neighbor is problem. They have to subject themselves to austerity sometimes even to violence to make sure the debt is paid.

questions: people in the richer european countries fear that increasing spending will lead to higher debts?
answers: Not if the money is used the way it was used in east asia. They used it for capital investment and industrial policy programs. So taiwan and south korea japan earlier they moved from quite poor peasant societies to richer and developed societies and suffered the same fate because they did not have the resources to absorb the increase in spending.

questions: there is nothing more neoliberal than the consumer swiss writer adolf muschg once noted. but should not we protect the consumer?
answers: Not in the least. In fact it is the other way around. The financial sector in its current form was originally designed to serve the needs of the very wealthy.

questions: but what if you can not raise standards in china?
answers: There is a way to deal with it indirectly. When there were massive protests against foxconn this year chinas reacted by making some changes allowing some degree of independent unions that have been permitted to slightly reduce the onerous conditions that sort of forced workers into this beeeep labor. That is about it.

questions: so why not tax them for exploiting workers and the environment in those countries?
answers: Yes make them pay to raise the standards. I mean corporate profits have gone through the roof. Now there is a study by economists from the university of massachusetts amherst that unused corporate banking and corporation profits amount to about 1.

questions: what is your assessment of the first term of president barack obama?
answers: Frankly i did not expect much. He came into office with a lot of pent up anger and discontent about the policies of his predecessor joe sanders and his administration.

questions: because they were major contributors to his campaign?
answers: Some of them yeah. Others we do not even know about. But mostly it was just a big donor is network.

questions: still obama tried to improve things like introducing universal healthcare?
answers: It is a mixed story because there have been some improvements. So for example a couple of months ago a study was done in canada which compared the us health care system with that of other rich countries and it was quite dramatic the difference was enormous.

questions: but obama had to compromise with what could get passed in the senate?
answers: Some of his supporters argue that it was the best that could be done given the political circumstances. But that is by no means obvious. The president has a lot of power for example he can appeal to a majority of the population which is what a president must do in an election even if it is a lost cause.

questions: president actually would have been hanged. does that apply to obama as well?
answers: Look at the global assassination campaign. It violates principles going back to magna carta and so on. How can the united states tolerate this.

questions: you are referring to the drones in pakistan somalia and yemen?
answers: Yes. If the president decides to kill somebody you kill him and whoever else happens to be standing around. The foundations of anglo american law and by now pretty much of the world has what is called the presumption of innocence that you can punish someone if you demonstrate that they are guilty in a court of law not just a secret tribunal.

questions: would you prefer a police action if you think that there are terrorists around planning attacks against the united states?
answers: Suppose somebody in italy wants to rob the store. I would not arrest them. At least under the circumstances i think it is proper for the police to make arrests.

questions: is there actually any political leader on the global scene who is doing a good job in your opinion?
answers: Leaders technically do not do a lot. If you are in a position of power you usually do something to extend it.

questions: so do you think that political leaders are generally immune from your advice?
answers: Of course. Mine or anyone else is. There are intellectuals who like to pretend that they are influential and influential people do not listen to advice.

questions: and that is the reason you try to address the general population?
answers: Yes. And i am not telling political leaders anything they do not know. If i were to tell angela merkel austerity under recession is harmful to the economy she does not have to hear it from me because i know it perfectly well from my own experience as a working class immigrant in the 1930s and 40s.

questions: the latest is profit over people neoliberalism in the global order. welcome to talk of the nation.?
answers: Glad to be with you again.

questions: any comments on the state of the union to get us started?
answers: Well i did not listen to the whole thing but the transcript is essentially what i was just saying. So the major issue that was discussed was first one social security and what to do about it.

questions: so might this be a good time to to rebuild the way we talk about our our shared problems and and the way we try to find shared solutions?
