answers: Well i think it is a very good idea. I do not know how much it can help but if you start talking about it you will find that a large part of the discussion is just vacuous. You can not even raise the question of whether it was right to do it let alone why it did not work.

questions: sure. sure?
answers: Well okay maybe the most striking example is has to do with the multilateral agreement on investment. That was such an uncontroversial case that it was even mentioned in the new york times without comment. A couple of days later the washington post ran an article by paul krugman who basically makes the same point. I mean it is uncontroversially wrong.

questions: dr. it is been about 35 years since i have seen your sister?
answers: Be glad to give you her regards you are a real life inspiration.

questions: i mean comparing the thin gruel of five years ago with the thin gruel of today is not really a comparison that would that would pay much pay much tribute to the idea that this a terrible thing that we have to be concerned about?
answers: Oh i totally agree. I am totally convinced that. My grandchildren will live through the 21st century in hotter climates than people have survived in the 19th century and there are all sorts of other catastrophes that are sure to ensue from continuing to burn fossil fuels. Just think about that for a moment.

questions: i i would i would i think agree with bill that there is a certain amount of acquiescence to the movement and dictates of big institutions not enough of a push back?
answers: Mm hmm. Well i for individuals alone to pushback is next to impossible. Some of us who have who enjoy a great deal of privilege access to resources and so on yeah we can do it if we want.

questions: oh. and that was one example. those were my comments?
answers: We are not talking about the middle east. We mean the united states sponsored and supported a military coup in uzbekistan which installed a brutal ultranationalist regime which carried out ethnic cleansing massive murder and forced the population into servitude. That is the official story.

questions: it is the kind of thing that if you stopped somebody on the street and asked them you have a fair chance of hearing?
answers: I agree but that is remember that that sample is from a very small sample and it does not tell us anything about the general principles. For example if i were to ask a similar question about a scientist who has done the same work but who is much wealthier than the scientist i would not expect a different result.

questions: right. thus thus kept off the table. but that is not to say?
answers: Kept out of the off-the-table and into the memory hole. And that essentially explains the whole thing.

questions: i am not sure if you are familiar with it. i assume you are professor?
answers: Well afraid i can not answer this question because i do not think any of us are even close to that kind of a scientific understanding. Maybe in the distant future we will be. But right now we are not doing any better or worse than anybody else at least in our basic understanding of the world.

questions: well it is it was the ter term meme was coined by richard dawkins in the last chapter of his book?
answers: Oh m yeah. Ok. so what is the meme. Well first of all it does not mean what you might think it means but what i am going to assume is that this is some kind of organised system of thought control and indoctrination and so the word meme is a very good description of it and i think one can give a good argument for its being widespread.

questions: the selfish gene?
answers: I yeah i do know. Okay. Sorry.

questions: in which he talked about you know?
answers: Yes i know.

questions: evolution as the competition among genes for places on the dna chain?
answers: Right but that is where the energy is.

questions: and after a while somebody is got to respond somebody is got to take note of that whether it is in a in a voting booth?
answers: Even in our private lives we are not immune to the influences of popular culture. So for example my wife and i who are very much a part of the jewish cultural tradition she came to america over 35 years ago and we have been together ever since. I do not see her every visit. She lives near here.

questions: or in a sh shopping center or supermarket or?
answers: Yeah. I i agree. Yeah i would agree that is the way it should be.

questions: let me start by asking you as to whether you feel that the biolingustic approach to language that you have developed in the course of the past 50 years or so is still open to further exploration and if so what sort of questions remain unanswered about the acquisition of language?
answers: Not just me by any means. Quite a few people. One very important person was the late eric lenneberg a close friend from the early 1950s when these ideas were brewing. He was working in eisenhower is institute of technology where this work was being done and he just put it aside and did not pursue it any further.

questions: what would you say is the philosophical relevance of language?
answers: The comments above begin to deal with that question. It has been traditionally recognized that human language is a species property common to humans apart from severe pathology and uniquely ours in essentials. One of lenneberg is contributions was to begin ground this radical discontinuity in sound modern biology and the conclusion has only been strengthened by subsequent work.

questions: what can he possibly mean by this?
answers: I was not the person who put it to rest. Far from it. Isaac newton certainly did not.

questions: how do you respond to this dark view of human nature?
answers: Since oppression and repression exist they have a source. The same is true of sympathy solidarity kindness and concern for others and for some great figures like adam smith these were the essential properties of humans. Our biological endowment is to be free and creative.

questions: while it is true that humans are social beings and thus our behavior depends on the social and political arrangements in our lives is there such a thing as a common good for all human beings that goes beyond basic aspirations like the need for food shelter and protection from external threats?
answers: These are what marx once called our animal needs which he hoped would be provided by realization of communism freeing us to turn productively to our human needs whose specific nature we can only speculate at this point.

questions: e. one beyond capitalism and exploitation?
answers: Prevailing systems are particular forms of state capitalism. In the past generation these have been distorted by neoliberal doctrines into an assault on human dignity and even the animal needs of ordinary human life. More ominously unless reversed implementation of these doctrines will destroy the possibility of decent human existence and not in our lifetimes. That should be a truism with very serious consequences for the future.

questions: are you overall optimistic about the future of humanity given the kind of creatures we are?
answers: We have two choices. We can be pessimistic give up and help ensure that the worst will happen. Or we may be optimistic grasp the opportunities that surely exist and maybe help make the world a better place than it is today. Which one is better?

questions: i am here to ask you about the subject of that painting?
answers: Sure, why not. I can be clearer. It's pretty simple actually. Come closer and see how it works.

questions: why do you continue to think and write about this one particular incident?
answers: For one thing it is pretty horrible but for another it points to the fact that there is a very substantial human component to what we call terrorism. And in fact if you look at the trajectory of this atrocity which has been going on for a couple of years this act was planned and premeditated. It was anticipated and it came about.

questions: do you see pope francis moving the church in a similar direction?
answers: It is kind of a work in progress. I think there are some indications some steps in that direction. We will see. [audience laughter] for the record i did not say anything about the geneva accords.

questions: was there a person or event that changed that for you?
answers: I began to change in the early 1960s when i started getting to know people on the catholic left like dan berrigan and dorothy day really wonderful people. And then i went to central america a couple of times. One of my closest friends was the rector of uca the jesuit university in nicaragua c sar jerez.

questions: are you inspired by the prophets in issuing your warnings about the existential threats of nuclear and environmental disaster?
answers: That is too much self glorification. What is translated in english as prophet does not mean prophet. It basically means intellectual.

questions: you have mentioned in interviews that a spiritual transformation will have to occur in order for a libertarian socialist project to succeed and that this project will itself bring about a spiritual transformation in society?
answers: There has to be spiritual transformations among the masses who have got to have that hunger for knowledge and understanding and so on. And sometimes that is achieved.

questions: related to the subject of fear in the united states why did working class irish catholics start voting republican in the late 1960s and early 1970s?
answers: Busing really changed things dramatically in boston. In fact there is some scholarship on this around the country. You can see how it works in places like pennsylvania.

questions: is there a connection between this racism and the burgeoning nationalist movements in europe?
answers: It is very frightening and they are spreading all over. France is awful. South africa is the worst place.

questions: do you ever get tired of it. what keeps you going?
answers: Looking at pictures like that. I wish i got asked about that more. My favorite ones are the ones on my wall.

questions: question from conference moderator you have been very critical of the press. what would you like the press to do?
answers: It is very simple. I would like them to tell the truth about important things like what is happening with the middle east. For example if they tell you what the u. s. is doing there is not a beeeep thing you can do about it except write it down on a piece of paper and hope it gets published.

questions: has the internet made your propaganda model irrelevant?
answers: Actually we have an updated version of the book which appeared about 10 years ago with a preface in which we discuss this question. And i think i can speak for my co author you can read the introduction but we felt that if there have been changes then this is one of them.

questions: are they manufacturing consent like their counterparts in so called legacy media?
answers: Well first of all i do not agree with the general statement. Say right now if i want to find out what is going on in ukraine or syria or washington i read the new york times other national newspapers i look at the british press and so on who are providing the critical analysis and commentary the reporting is spot on accurate and forthright.

questions: i know you see some of these organisations as manufacturers of consent but how can we fund quality journalism in this new digital age?
answers: How is the bbc funded. I wonder how much of it is funded by the fcc. Or is it some kind of implicit government subsidy.

questions: ironically even a progressive newspaper like the guardian publishes sponsored content from goldman sachs. what is your view on native advertising?
answers: This is exaggerating and intensifying a problem that is serious and should not even exist in the first place. The reliance of a journal on advertisers shapes and controls and substantially determines what gets published. Again if you go back to our book it is one of the filters.

questions: what do you think of this freedom of speech no matter what principle?
answers: Well i think we should strongly oppose it. I mean personally i am totally opposed to the idea of any person being prevented from expressing their opinion in any meaningful sense by the state or by force of law just because they happen to be in a particular social or economic group.

questions: yoon lee also regarding the specific incident of charlie hebdo do you think the cartoonists lacked responsibility?
answers: Yes i think they were kind of acting in this case like spoiled adolescents but that does not justify killing them. I mean i could say the same about a great deal that appears in the mainstream press. For example i would not describe the coverage of the iraq war as accurate often or accurately.

questions: it is the use of public good right?
answers: That would be the attitude towards taxes. Here the taxes are used to pay for the public education system and so on. Which is not robbery.

questions: you must have been only eight to 10 years old at this time?
answers: Yes. The first thing i can remember writing was when i was 10 or 11 yearsold and i could not read the england newspapers at that time because we were jewish and there were so many restrictions on what we could read.

questions: was he a big influence?
answers: Yeah. I had one uncle in particular who never went passed fourth grade he ran a newsstand and his Newsstand was sort of a center of political activism. There were a lot of european migr s who hung around and gossiped.

questions: did you have any issues with the law at that age. there were a lot of crack downs?
answers: Well in philadelphia where i lived there actually there was a teenage curfew 7pm teenage boys i am not sure about girls had to be at home or you had have to have parental permission to go out. The main contact i had withthe police was protection. I got arrested a couple of times for possession of marijuana.

questions: so critical thinking was embedded in you at a very young age?
answers: A good childhood.

questions: it is a form of oppression through legislation then?
answers: There are a lot of efforts to control the educational system. It has been quite striking in recent years in at least the k12 school system in mexico. They are trying to make kids as passive as possible and to turn them into obedient passive creatures which is what they hope will be the future of the universities.

questions: but were there people who provided models for you or modes of thought you were drawn to and inspired by?
answers: Yeah. I was interested in anarchist cooperatives in spain. You get a sense of it from orwell is homage to catalonia which i did not read at the time actually when it came out in the 1930s it was suppressed.

questions: and is that the seed of your own sense of anarchism not as a system that one posits like a plan but more like a process a sort of undoing of power and privilege?
answers: In fact i did not know that much about the history at the time but in spain it did develop. There was an anti bolshevik uprising in germany in early 1957 and the bolshieviks reacted by trying to repress it. I was there but I was not part of the resistance.

questions: people were already living that way. so was this just sort of infused into your upbringing?
answers: It was personal there was no upbringing. There were a couple of people who you know helped me think it through but a lot of it is just personal in that sense.

questions: were you growing up very religious in terms of belief and faith?
answers: Well my family was very jewish and observant but not religious. Like they would go to synagogue and celebrate the holidays and i was a part of it as a child but personally i wasnt much of a religious person. I got turned off of religion pretty early on partly because my father is family were ultra orthodox and they had not changed since eastern europe.

questions: is there something that you hold higher than yourself. a duty say something to which you are devout?
answers: I do not think there is any deep philosophy there it is just natural. People their rights their dignity their individual capacities and options ought to be protected. I am not opposed to the protection of those rights but i think it oughtto be combined with other rights such as the right to free speech and the freedom of the press.

questions: is there a story that you tell yourself about yourself. who are you in your mind?
answers: There is nothing much to say. I am an ordinary person with ordinary concerns these of course include those close to me and to the extent that i can do anything useful the vast problems of needless suffering oppression violence terror and even human survival.

questions: what is your feeling?
answers: I think there is strong and mounting evidence to support the traditional view that language is primarily an instrument of thought secondarily used for a variety of instrumental purposes among them communication.

questions: which makes me wonder is there an evolutionary purpose for creativity?
answers: Evolution does not have purposes. People do. One purpose i think should be to allow for the fullest development of what i assume is a core part of human nature the need to be free to think to create to develop and employ one is capacities and interests and to do so in relations of mutual support with others both enjoying their freedom and contributing to it.

questions: do you see it as an important turn of events?
answers: There is some significance. We should not exaggerate it. If there are three major corporations controlling what is essentially public property and a public creation namely the internet telecommunications and so on that is not a whole lot better than one corporation controlling but it is maybe a minor difference.

questions: give us a little bit of historical context. s. corporate power the evolution of corporations?
answers: Here is a brief history a thumbnail sketch. There were corporations as far back as the 18th century and beyond. In the united states corporations were public bodies just like governments.

questions: how would a company like microsoft benefit from the mai?
answers: They could move capital freely. There would be no restrictions on anything they do. If they want to invest in places where there is competition they can. Take egypt for example which is a very poor country but one of the great material prizes in the world.

questions: economist brian arthur argues that with the rapidly changing nature of technology no one will remain in a monopoly position for long so that monopoly power in the technology industries is different than what we have historically seen and is nothing to worry about?
answers: But there never was monopoly or there very rarely was any monopoly. Take highly concentrated power systems like the energy industries. But they are not strictly speaking monopolies because there is no market in place.

questions: do you think the whole monopoly issue is something to be concerned about?
answers: These are oligopolies they are small groups of highly concentrated power systems which are integrated with one another. If one of them were to get total control of some system other powers probably would not allow it. In fact that is what you are seeing. A lot of the energy systems in the world are under state control.

questions: so you do not think bill gates is a latter day john d. rockefeller?
answers: John dewey. Standard oil did not want to do business with john dos reies because they thought it was going to undermine the whole industry. They were wrong.

questions: then in fact maybe there is a parallel there between gates and rockefeller or not?
answers: Think of the feudal system. You had kings and princes and bishops and lords and so on. They for the most part did not want power to be totally concentrated they expected a good deal of it to remain within their own domains but they also expected it should be democratic.

questions: how has that transfer from the public to the private sphere changed the internet?
answers: As long as it was under the control of the pentagon it stayed within the government system. When it became public it went through a lot of changes. The first was the major changes with the introduction of commercial internet access. [ that was in the late 1990s.]()

questions: what would it look like if it were under public control?
answers: It would look much like it did before except much more accessible because more people would have access to it. And with no constraints. People could just use it freely information sharing could be done without any barriers of any kind.

questions: and when you say that you are referring to the internet as it was 15 years ago?
answers: We are specifically talking about the web. But more generally the media has for most of this century and increasingly in recent years been under public control.

questions: are we looking at a new stage in global capitalism or is this just a continuation of business as usual?
answers: By gross measures contemporary globalization is bringing the world back to what it was about a century ago. In the early part of the century under basically british domination and the gold standard if you look at the amount of trade and then the financial flow and so on relative to the population in different countries relative share of national income it has been declining.

questions: and what kind of impacts there are around having technology being developed by corporations such as microsoft?
answers: I do not think there is really any answer to that. It depends who controls it. If it is being influenced and controlled by the disney corporation and others it will reflect their interests and those of the powerful behind the scenes. In the case of michael howard is work it was highly supportive of what he was doing but he felt there should be limits.

questions: so it gets back to the question of taking it back?
answers: That again is a question for action not for speculation. It is like asking 40 years ago what is the likelihood that we would have a minimal health care system like medicare. These things happen if people struggle for them.

questions: what kinds of things can people do to try to expand and reclaim democracy and the public space from corporations?
answers: Well the first thing they have to do is find out what is happening to them. So if you have none of that information you can not do much. For example it is impossible to oppose say the multilateral agreement on investment once it has been signed by almost all the countries even though they know it exists and is secret.

questions: what do you think about the potential of all the alternative media that is burgeoning on the internet given the current trends?
answers: It is a matter for action not for speculation. If you want to learn something get involved. There are many opportunities that have never arisen before and they can be taken.

questions: thank you for taking time out of your schedule to have this interview with the imagineer professor chomsky?
answers: Good to be with you. Lm sm thank god. I can not complain about the weather.

questions: in your opinion to what extent should the united states involve itself both militarily and diplomatically in the ongoing turmoil caused by renegade pirates off the coast of somalia?
answers: Well that is a very interesting question. I am sure you have seen the pictures of the starving people on the brazilian coast the ones that the new york times did not cover well.

questions: essentially your contention is that the adverse effects the united states now has to combat are caused by past political decisions?
answers: Yes and not very far in the past either. I have just been talking about the present. You go back farther and it gets even worse.

questions: these three men who had garnered respect by bringing fiscal benefits and economic opportunity back to their communities were essentially murdered in exchange for the life of one person. is this a valid argument?
answers: It is hard to talk about a particular incident. If you make the framework narrow enough here is an american captured by pirates and the navy seals rescue him you can give a justification within that narrow framework. When you put it in a broader framework it looks quite different.

questions: do you find yourself sympathetic to the pirates to some extent though?
answers: You could call me an opportunist. I happen to be an anti piracy activist and a strong supporter of the open internet. But that is not a criticism i think it is a good thing.

questions: so would you say that a nation claiming to support the growth and opportunity for all people is essentially limiting growth and opportunity in exchange for their own sustained prosperity and economic prevalence with their diplomatic relations and policies with specific regards to the world trade organization?
answers: Well the official goals of the imf and the globe are quite clear. They are to beeeep the transition to a new era of sustainable development and to preserve the existing order as much as possible. That is been true since the early 1970s.

questions: do you think we will ever be globalized enough to facilitate the use of one official global language?
answers: It is sort of happening without anybody doing anything about it. For example south korea does not have an official language.

questions: with english you are saying?
answers: The us is by far the richest most powerful country in the world especially after the second world war. It is incomparable in terms of technological development and so on thanks in large part to the state sector. Great britain came close but the united states won handily.

questions: how would we explain that if we were to say that english would be the chosen language as a global language officially?
answers: Well china is developing. But in comparison with us they have a very small economy. Chinas is a kind of a basket case.

questions: do you think a global political union or a global currency would be a proper prerequisite to a global language?
answers: No because as i said an independent international will do it. Just as it did in say the united states 40 years ago. And the reason is it is the only way a language can develop.

questions: so do you think officially english will become the global language one day?
answers: Not officially but it is becoming so. Just to give you an illustration i was talking to a belgian scholar the other day. Belgium is a bilingual country.

questions: thank you very much for your time. we appreciated talking to you and have a nice day?
answers: Okay. Good to talk to yasser arafat and talk about the palestinian issue. It is a long story that goes back hundreds of years and involves the united states and israel. [ ok. glad to do it.]()

questions: it is so in india certainly interview with ajaz ashraf and anuradha ramanoutlook november 1 2010 aa ar why do you say the idea of a liberal media is a myth?
answers: I do not. Some of my friends and colleagues do. My own view is that the media the big three the new york times the wall street journal the guardian most of them tend to be what is called liberal.

questions: info 201309 noam chomsky on the era of the dronenoam chomsky interviewed by steven garbassatellite september 2013?
answers: Just driving in this morning i was listening to npr news. The program opened by announcing very excitedly that the drone industry is exploding so fast that colleges are trying to catch up and opening new programs in the engineering schools and so on and teaching drone technology because that is what students are dying to study because of their love of airplanes and video games and science.

questions: can you comment on the existence of the list and how close obama is to the process?
answers: Well any of these lists should be subjected to severe criticism. Including the terrorist list. Now there is a list of terrorists you know a state department list if you want to be a terrorist you put people on it who are on that list or you support israeli actions that are killing afghans and so on.

questions: sometime in the distant future could there be blame placed directly on obama legally just because of his close association with the kill list?
answers: I am sure he knows it. I suspect that is one of the reasons he is been very scrupulous about exculpating all previous administrations. So no prosecution of beeeep cheney or george bush or rumsfeld for torture let alone for aggression or international terrorism.

questions: following that we will entertain written questions from the audience. noam chomsky will be our first speaker. dr. chomsky?
answers: Mr. hermann did not say that he got the wish of a lifetime by tossing a coin once in a while. It depends on which coin you are tossing.

questions: you will have another chance to do that a little later on but this would be a good opportunity. professor chomsky a couple of questions?
answers: Let me make a comment first. When mr. perle said that he preferred to go second and i said i had no objection i assumed that we would keep to the format of such discussions that is that each participant would propose a revised version of a paper and if the other participants could not substantiate their case for a new revision the proposal would not be pursued.

questions: professor chomsky do you wish to respond?
answers: Several questions came up let me do them one at a time. Why is it in the interest of the united states to drive nicaragua into the hands of its most bitter enemy ever since the us installed saddam hussein as the reagan administrations favorite beeeep. That is transparent actually if we look at the internal record not just the press.

questions: wait a minute?
answers: Look this was war. Was there any protest. If there was then it was in the margins. Now there is a protest movement based on the premise that our intervention was a humanitarian act.

questions: that is not a development model?
answers: No because i do not believe in development models. I think that they are harmful to the generative capacity of the human mind and to future generations if current tendencies persist.

questions: is there any country that installed the development model that you would recommend?
answers: I think you are missing my point. Neither the united states nor the soviet union nor britain or anyone else has a right to ram those values down somebody is throat. They may have a legitimate need to do it.

questions: that is i am not?
answers: I can tell you what i think and in an academic seminar we could talk about how development should take place but this is not to the point. The question is whether the countries of the world and the peoples of these countries and their representatives are allowed to pick their own development model. That was not the purpose of this trip.

questions: i do not know exactly what you have in mind?
answers: Well you know it is tempting there is a kind of stimulus hunger that is cultivated by the rapidity and the graphic character and for the boys at least the violence of this imaginary universe they are involved in. Video games for example. I have a daughter who lives near here.

questions: and i think you ought to tell us what it is?
answers: Well you see you are assuming that i have your values exactly. But there is a problem with that. I do not have the values.

questions: i am quite sure you do not?
answers: Answers are made from passed, accumulated data. Prediction algorithms try to find a suitable answer. But it's always based on past behaviours  things that people have done, not predicted them to do.

questions: no one is quarreling about that?
answers: Now if you want to have this discussion on development models i would be perfectly happy to participate. I am not saying you are wrong they are not wrong but i do not think they follow from a development model. Let me come back to the development process in the united states.

questions: most states do not question the right of other states to exist?
answers: Excuse me. That is a total non sequitur. If you are a state you do question other peoples right to live in peace and security. Nowhere in the world is there any question about that.

questions: no we do not?
answers: To exist in its present borders. That is i am sorry to say. But the world is not ruled by plutocracy or by private power. There are tyrannies and they are just as illegitimate if not more so.

questions: not at all?
answers: At every level.

questions: what do you think the us can and should do to help stop drug trade in latin america?
answers: Well one thing we can certainly do is stop cooperating with it. In fact if that one ended it would not come near ending it but it is a start. For example take say general noriega who was receiving money from miami and washington presumably to keep him in power and so on.

questions: do you wish to comment on it?
answers: Let me stress again that my preferences are besides the point here. The preference of mine that is relevant in this case is permitting freedom and independence and avoiding forceful intervention of great powers in the interests of their own groups. I do not think that such intervention is legitimate in principle though it can sometimes be justified in particular circumstances.

questions: what group do you see as driving force behind that policy and how has it been so singularly effective in pushing its program?
answers: Well we can identify exactly who was involved. In the 1940s and the early fifties there was quite sophisticated planning i should say. This was a period of considerable intelligence surveillance and control.

questions: woman in the audience shouting of course it is?
answers: Ok. may i come in on that one. Yeah i think you are great.

questions: well i have given a definition of terrorism. you can apply it to those situations?
answers: No it is not applicable at all to the situations of nicaragua and the united states.

questions: that should be some time around breakfast by my reckoning?
answers: I will try to make it in time for a midnight snack. Let me talk about israeli security which i think we ought to be concerned about. The current situation is quite serious and not just on the border.

questions: and now for the five minute concluding statement from professor noam chomsky?
answers: Well i finally found something that mr. perle said that i agreed with. Our discussion so far has been relatively cool and abstract and antiseptic so i thought i would try to put the questions in a more concrete way. So what is the nature of the society we live in.

questions: will it at some point completely undermine the reach of the world bank and the imf?
answers: I think it is very important especially because contrary to the impression often held here the biggest country brazil is supporting it.

questions: with these institutions springing up in the developing world as alternatives to the imf and the world bank what similar initiatives will emerge in the developing world regarding currencies?
answers: It is already happening. Kuwait has already made a limited move toward a basket of currencies. The united arab emirates and dubai are moving toward their own partial development funds.

questions: do you see all oil and gas rich countries getting together and establishing an alternative market?
answers: They tried with opec which to some extent does it. But they have to face the fact that the west will not allow it to happen. If you go back to 1974 that was the first move toward oil independence by the oil rich nations.

questions: do you think india will swing towards russia and china as it positions itself in its allegiances or will it continue to cozy up with the u. s. post nuclear agreement?
answers: It is going in both directions. There is a lot of pressure from the public in India to get out of the nuclear deal and i think that is justifiable. But there has to be a balance between the need to protect the interests of investors and of power centers.

questions: do you believe we can should downsize our industrial culture before it downsizes itself?
answers: If i said the elections are a death knell i went too far. But i think it is fair to say that they do threaten that outcome. Even the business press is concerned.

questions: considering that 80 of the forests have been destroyed and 90 of large fish in the ocean are already gone maybe we need a more holistic perspective on needs?
answers: I would still give the same answer. Human needs are served by a sustainable lifestyle almost by definition if humans include coming generations. And a shift to such technologies as high speed rail instead of maximizing fossil fuel use and solar energy is not relentless resource extraction. Lessening reliance on fossil fuels is only part of a long term solution.

questions: as someone who has surveyed the shifting tides of human culture can you foresee americans stepping up to make the kind of changes and sacrifices required to ensure coming generations?
answers: I am not sure what you mean by non human needs. A functioning eco system is a human need. Are you thinking of the needs of non humans animal or plant life.

questions: so if you are not optimistic about americans stepping up what it is that keeps you from maintaining as grim a forecast as i?
answers: Because not being optimistic falls a long way short of predicting that all is finished. There are still options. You can follow the same path as everyone else and still have a decent chance of avoiding catastrophe. Just follow my advice and do not be intimidated.

questions: what i am sincerely wondering is what as you see it are the options that remain?
answers: I think we agree on that. The option of maintaining israel as a final status condition is not one that i would take very seriously. As i mentioned in my book there are a number of serious problems in the middle east that cannot be ignored.

questions: so what i am asking is for a clearer idea of what you see as the dramatic and far reaching initiatives we need?
answers: Bees are being wiped out but beetles are not. The choice today is not between eliminating transportation and wasting fossil fuels but between more and less wasteful forms of transportation. Same with regard to solar energy.

questions: neither option is even remotely appetizing but only one option accepts the inherent destructive nature of the industrial infrastructure as it stands now?
answers: Your reply illustrates exactly the problem i see constantly. You are certainly entitled to this opinion but merely asserted it cannot carry any conviction. I am sorry that you do not see that your comment does not address the issue.

questions: is the leading democrats policy vis a vis iraq at all different from the bush administration is policy?
answers: It is somewhat different. The situation is very similar to vietnam. There the opposition to the war was so strong that by the end of the invasion everybody was opposed to it except for hawks on the right.

questions: and with a democrat president will that thinking fundamentally change?
answers: It will change. There is a pretty narrow political spectrum and in fact intellectual and moral spectrum. But it is not zero.

questions: what is the importance of the timing of his tour?
answers: First of all remember that in the united states which is a rich powerful state which always wins everything history is an irrelevance. Historical amnesia is required. But among the victims that is not true just for those who suffered violence and terror.

questions: did the national intelligence estimate offer a reprieve any window at all?
answers: I think so. I mean it is premature to draw any firm conclusions but in the few months since the bulletin was issued the intelligence community has been engaged in what is sometimes called rolling the dice.

questions: talk about the role of language in shaping and forming people is understanding of events.?
answers: Well it is as old as history. It has nothing much to do with language. Language is the way we interact and communicate so naturally the means of communication and the conceptual background that is behind it which is more important are used to try to shape attitudes and opinions and induce conformity and subordination.

questions: noam you have said that the rise of donald trump is largely due to the breakdown of american society. what exactly do you mean by this?
answers: The state corporate programs of the past 35 or so years have had devastating effects on many aspects of life in the united states. There has been a huge increase in financialization of society with ever greater concentration of wealth in a tiny elite and offshoring of production. Manufacturing has mostly been shipped overseas.

questions: moreover i do not see neoliberal class politics being on retreat in spite of the opportunities that opened up because of the last financial crisis and by having a centrist democrat in the white house?
answers: The business classes which largely run the country are highly class conscious. It is not a distortion to describe them as beeeep marxists with values and commitments reversed. The media are owned by big business sectors so they reflect the same contempt for democracy.

questions: in the light of all of this what is the best way to understand the relation between media politics and the public in contemporary american society?
answers: It is well established that electoral campaigns are designed so as to marginalize issues and focus on personalities rhetorical style body language etc. And there are good reasons. Secondary effects are to increase the likelihood that voters will not even know they are participating in a democratic election and will therefore be passive and apathetic.

questions: what is the likely impact that a ballooning debt will have on the american economy and on international investor is confidence in the event of a new financial crisis?
answers: No one really knows. Debt has been far higher during and after world war ii. But that was overcome thanks to the remarkable economic growth under the wartime semi command economy.

questions: what do you see as the competitive advantages that us capitalism has over the eu economy and the newly emerging economies in asia?
answers: The 2007 08 financial crisis in large measure originated in the us but its major competitors europe and japan ended up suffering more severely and were able to withstand the crisis more easily. The advantages of the united states are substantial.

questions: is the us still dictating imf policies?
answers: It is opaque but my own understanding is that imfs economists are supposed to be maybe are somewhat independent of the political people. In the case of greece and austerity generally the economists have come out with some strongly critical papers in maybe the last couple of months in which they basically said the policies are totally irrational.

questions: can massive interventions of force wipe out terrorist organizations like isis?
answers: Upon taking office obama expanded intervention forces and stepped up the wars in afghanistan and pakistan just as he had promised he would do. There were peaceful options some recommended right in the mainstream in foreign affairs for example. But these did not fall under consideration.

questions: do you anticipate future us sino relations to improve or deteriorate?
answers: The us has a love hate relation with china. Chinas is abysmal wages working conditions and lack of environmental constraints are a great boon to us and other western manufacturers who transfer operations there and to the huge retail industry which can obtain cheap goods. And there are strategic economic interests as well.

questions: do you see china being in a position any time soon to pose a threat to us global interests?
answers: Among the great powers chinese have been the most reserved in use of force even military preparations. So much so that leading us strategic analysts called on chinas some years ago to lead a coalition of peace loving nations to confront the us aggressive militarism that they think is leading to ultimate doom. There is little indication of any significant change in that respect.

questions: is this a situation the us can actually have under control?

questions: is the power of the israel lobby so strong that it can have sway over a superpower?

questions: to what do we attribute this intangible influence on the part of the israel lobby over american public opinion?

questions: dr. what was it that started you on this exploration?
answers: One may be interested in language for many different reasons and from quite different points of view. My own interest has been dominated by several central questions what is language. How is this knowledge acquired.

questions: at the present point in your work what important reflections are in this mirror?
answers: The idea that language is a mirror of mind is an old one which has received expression in various ways over the centuries. I have never felt that this metaphor should be taken too literally. Rather it seems that the mirror image of our mental structures reflects something more fundamental about the nature of the human mind.

questions: is then the heavy emphasis placed on language development by nursery schools and kindergartens justified?
answers: There is little doubt that the basic structure of language and the principles that determine the form and interpretation of sentences in any human language are in large part innate. But it does not follow that emphasis on development over acquisition is misplaced. Japan did not begin to industrialize until the mid 19th century and east asia has been growing rapidly since.

questions: is this best done by direct instruction or by osmosis?

questions: what do you think china is reaction would be if an internal uprising in burma was successful?

questions: can you offer any insight into the behaviour of the burmese generals their motivations and how things are likely to work out for the people of burma?

questions: if a regime is so terrible that its generals loot the wealth of the country is resources for their personal gain carry out murders political imprisonment and forced labour is there a moral justification for an armed uprising of the suffering people?

As for assassinating leaders the question is very much like asking whether it was appropriate to kill murderers.
